title: Hail the Pirates Wins Seminole for Galbreath
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 31Business was down again at Hialeah today, but the day was not entirely melancholy for John W. Galbreath, board chairman of the financially beleaguered track. Hail the Pirates, bred and owned by Galbreath's son, Dan M., raced head and head with Step Nicely from the fiveeighths pole to the wire and won the $59,300 Seminole Handicap by a nose. Nalees Rialto was a distant third.

title: Letters: Roomier Planes
description: To the Editor: I am six feet tall and weigh 170 punt's, and I am fully convinced that coach accommodations in today's commercial airplanes must have been de signed for someone else. There is simply no way to avoid constant jostling, poking, and banging by the elbows, knees, feet and newspapers of adjacent fellowsuffering travelers.

title: Congress Acts on Jobs &
description: Behind the bombast of President Ford's renewed rejection yesterday of emergency jobs for the jobless is the reality that his own program promises them nothing more than yearafteryear unemployment. The emptiness of the Administration program was precisely what impelled Congress by an overwhelming majority last week to disregard President Ford's veto threat and vote a public works bill aimed at generating at least 600,000 jobs and providing extra cash for states and cities caught in a fiscal squeeze resulting from the economic slump.

title: The World
description: The United States last week exercised its veto for the 13th time in the United Nations Security Council, blocking, as expected, a resolution calling for a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan. Despite continued diplomatic contacts in Washington and elsewhere, a prolonged statemate on MiddleEast peacemaking seems likely.

title: Janette Horton Becomes Bride Of Thomas Hall
description: Janette Elizabeth Horton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jared Churchill Horton of Greenwich, Conn. was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Joseph Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Thomas Hall of Bradenton, Fla., formerly of West Redding, Conn.

title: Larose's Score Gains 22 Draw
description: SY LOUIS, Jan. 31Claude Larose scored on a deflected shot during a St. Louis power play in the third period tonight, rallying the Blues for the second time and fashioning a 22 tie with the New York Islanders in the National Hockey League.

title: An Island For Two
description: Peter is a bandit. Not a hardened criminal, mind you, just an 18yearold orphan who holds up a department store in Switzerland for getaway money. Judith is a sweet 17yearold whom he takes as a hostage.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Your Jan. 17 story on International Business Machines preliminary earnings results (I.B.M. Profits Rise 31.8% In Quarter) quotes some inaccurate statements made by Morton Shepetin, vice president of Dean Witter and Company.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Ohio State, Big Ten, Rose Bowl and Odd Doings Along the
description: Amidst the politicking and infighting surrounding the plethora of recent college bowl ernes, nothing beat the ironic absurdity surrounding the Rose and the Orange Bowls. The entangling postseason alliance of the Big Ten and the Pacific8 forced Woody Hayes to take his No. 1ranked Buckeyes back to replay 14thranked University of California, Los Angeles, a team lie had poured it on, 41 to 20, in the third game of the season. This gave Woody's hated rival, Bo Schembechler, the priVilrge of taking his fifthranked Wolverines to Miami to play thirdranked Oklahoma, now the accepted national champion. The incidental outcomes that singed the egos of the truculent Hayes and his feisty former assistant are as interesting as how they came about.

title: M. T. A. POWERSAVER BEING TESTED ON IND
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has begun a sixmonth test of two subway cars equipped with energystorage machines designed to cut power consumption by a third.

title: Waterfront Unit Inquiry Aims At a Rise of Injuries on Docks
description: Concerned over the mounting cost of workmen's compensation to local shippers, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has opened an investigation into allegedly fraudulent injury claims by dock workers.

title: DINING OUT
description: The Michelin Guide in France gives two stars to those eateries it deems worth a detour for the motorist and three stars to the very few places it considers worth a special trip: Most of its onestar restaurants are good places to eat if you happen to be in that town.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES TRADE SURPLUS during 1975 soared to a record $11.05 billion despite only a modest gain of exports over imports in December. In 1974, the nation had a deficit of 52.346 billion & The Index of Leading Indicators rose 0.4 percent in December to 102.2 [1967=100 For the fourth quarter, however, the index was down 0.2 percent from the third quarter & Value of building contracts dropped 23 percent in December compared with December of 1974 despite a 34 percent gain in residential construction contracts.

title: Rhodesia Minister Sworn In
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)A South Africanborn lawyer, Harry Squires, today was sworn in as Rhodesla's Minister of Justice, Law and Order.

title: Racing Group Broadens Base
description: The rapid growth of offshore racing and Canada's recent yachting independence has spurred the United States Yacht Racing Union to reorganize its structure to represent all facets of the sport the onedesign and offshore racers as well as the regional associations. Sailing has become more universal. The whole game has expanded, and with all the developing interests, we needed broader representation from the principal groups in yachting. explained explained Harry Anderson, the Union's executive director.

title: Rockefeller Comes Home to Westchester G.O.P.
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31Vice President Rockefeller came home to Westchester County this week, greeting old friends at a fundraising dinner and indulging their insistence on calling him Governor.

title: The Winter Olympics: Who Should Win What
description: What the United States Alpine ski director, Hank Tauber, likes best about the Winter Olympics, he says. is that the best often don't win in skiing. Our racers are not among the favorites and that gives us an advantage.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Minister
description: The Sunday service at Cochesett United Methodist Church in West Bridgewater, Mass., was ending, Giving the patriarchs and matriarchs equal billing, the Rev. Julieanne Hallman pronounced the benediction: May the Lord of Abraham and Sarah, of Isaac and Rebecca, of Jacob and Rachel, make His face to shine upon you. As the organ pumped out the recessional, she walked up the aisle, the hem of her electricblue robe, with its apron of dayglow green, brushing the pews, and took her post by the door.

title: POLITICS HOLDS UP DECISION ON HELMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The decision whether to charge Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, with perjury in connection with his Senate testimony has bogged down in a tangle of legal questions and increasing political wariness, according to highly placed Ford Administration officials.

title: The Irish Are Crying in Costlier Beer
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 31The eldderly greengrocer was quite cheerful. Thank God. he said, I drank plenty of it when it was cheap.

title: Four novels
description: Helen Yglesias's second novel begins with Anne Goddard, its heroine and sometimenarrator, meditating on her earliest memories of her mother and trying to piece together, from shards of information and misinformation, her mother's European past. Anne is the youngest of seven children, born in her mother's middleage, an accident; she seems to recall being carried in a bushel basket from the top floor of the tenement where we lived to my father's grocery store a few blocks away, although one of her sisters disputes that her memories could go back that far.Anne's recollections of her immigrant mother are vivid, discrete, unchronologicalin the space of a page, and in that order, Anne is in the middle of a divorce, 10yearsold, 25, and 15. It becomes clear early that the mother is dead, and that her death took place some time ago. Anne sat shivu with the family in the posh Westchester home of a brother whd has made it big in business. (How preposterous of me, she says, to have ever worried that Jewish was not American.) She joins her father and brothers in synagogue (the only woman there), rushes past that part in the service where she thinks to herself, The men bless God because He has not made them women. The women, in smaller print, bless God for having made them according to His will, goes on to her private Kaddish, says it, is comforted. And from the present, the novelist's slippery vantage point, we learn that she has other magic. From my garden I cut a spray of dill and add it to the last cooking minutes of the chicken soup and evoke her in the delicate sharp scent. I insist her existence, and own.

title: Mc Tear Stays Unbeaten By Taking Two Sprints
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Jan. 31 (UPI)Houston McTear, the Florida schoolboy sprint sensation, kept his indoor season record spotless tonight by wining two races within 15 minutes in the Albuquerque Jayce invitation track meet.

title: Wendy Hafer Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hafer Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Hafer's.daughter, Wendy Ann Hafer, to Randy Paul Cowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence J. Cowley of Center Moriches. L.I.

title: Quota Hiring of Teachers In Boston Upheld by Court
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Federal Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. was correct in ordering the hiring of black and write teachers on a quota system during school desegregation, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit has ruled.

title: Will Russia ever feed itself?
description: If the Sahara were collectivized, grouses one citizen, they would soon be importing sand. Until the peasants love of the soil revived, the outlook for Soviet agriculture is bleak.

title: Tory Church Wins Bicentennial Role
description: SETAUKET  A local church, noted for its Tory activities during the Revolutionary War, has been named Suffolk Bicentennial church by the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: Elisabeth Demleitner, above, and Stephan HoelzIwimmer of the West German luge team in Innsbruck with new streamlined helmets they will wear in Olympics.

description: VALIUMANIA

title: Soviet Fleet Assessed
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UPI)The director of Japan's Defense Agency said today that the Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet, based in Vladivostok, consisted of 715 ships totaling 1.2 million tons, including submarines and cruisers. The agency director, Michita Sakata, said at a budget committee meeting that the Soviet Union maintained the fleet for both offensive and defensive purposes and to safeguard sea lanes.

title: STATE ASSEMBLY CALLED EFFICIENT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut issued a series of charts, graphs and tables this week designed to show that the State Assembly was more costeffective than its California counterpartand thus fully justified the $18 million appropriation it was seeking in the budget next year.

title: Sheryl Amsler Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Amsler Jr. of Albany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Louise Amsler, to John Harris Konecky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Konecky of Sands Point, L.I. A wedding in August is planned. Miss Amsler is with the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association in New York, where her fianc is with the Milton Paper Company.

title: Why Canada Tries Controls
description: OTTAWAPrenotification. Profitmargin test. Cost justification. Farmgate exemption. Wage guideline.

title: Seattle to Get AL Club If 3 Conditions Are Met
description: American League baseball owners resolved yesterday to put a team in Seattle in 1977 if three conditions were met. One of the conditions was the dropping of a $32.5 million lawsuit.

title: Fund Is Established to Finance Salk Institute Cancer Research
description: The establishment of the Armand Hammer Cancer Conference and Prize Fund has been announced by the Salk Institute of San Diego.

title: 2 Women Tied On 141 in Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth lost a threeshot lead in the last three holes today and dropped into a tie with Jane Blalock for the lead after two rounds of the $40,000 Burdines invitation golf tournament. Each had a 141 total at the Kendale Lakes Country Club.

title: Nettles, Tucker Lead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 31The New York Yankees Craig Nettles and Tucker posted a second straight 55 today for a 36hole total of 110, 32 under par. They increased their lead to six shots in the $30,000 golf tournament.

title: Olympic Family. Affairs
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 31 (AP)Argentina's fatherandson Olympic contingent arrived unexpectedly in Innsbruck today after the organizers had given up hope on the South American nation's participation in the Games.

title: Twyla Tharp's Descent Into Slapstick
description: I don't relish the role of party pooper, especially when the hostess is as gracious and ingratiating as choreographer Twyla Tharp. Critics and audiences alike are rejoicing over her new work, Push Comes to Shove, for American Ballet Theater. Clive Barnes calls it tremendous and dazzling. Time magazine says it just might be the most important dance event of the year. But to assume from such praise that this work is Tharp's crowning achievement is to misconstrue the very nature of her great talent. Viewed in the context of Tharp's overall career, Push Comes to Shove is more a deviation than a culmination, intermittently quite funny, but ultimately inconsequential.

title: Rarities in Food
description: THE gourmet cook in search of unusual foreign foods can find an enormous selection of ethnic food specialties within the borders of the Garden State.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP)The Soviet Union's boxing team won its third straight match against American amateurs today, with a 72 victory in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

title: The Concorde Question
description: PARIS, Jan. 30  The pilot of an American airliner taxiing to its gate at Charles de Gaulle Airport spoke breathlessly on its public address system: Look quickly to the left, ladies and gentlemen, and you will see the Concorde!

title: Mark Philip Harty To Wed Miss White
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank ??? ??? White of Hamilton: N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Cummings White; to Mark Philip Harty, son,ot Mr. and Mrs. William Albert Harty Jr. of Amherst, N. Ir.

description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: 119 of Picasso's Last Works Stolen From Avignon Palace
description: AVIGNON, France. Jan. 31. (Reuters)Three thieves stole 119 Picasso paintings tonight from the Palace of the Popes here. It was one of France's biggest art robberies, museum officials reported.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: consequently selling the black experience short.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: We've got to be careful about wishing. Here we are, always wishing for a good new funny American play so that we won't have to hang our heads in shame every time we think of how beholden we are to the British for all our Broadway hits, and what do we get?

title: What Makes Betty Run
description: Toms RIVER IF YOU add wideeyed to wellmeaning and thoughtful, Louise Saul's adjectives describing New Jerseyans running for school boards, you might have a workable definition of Betty Berman, wife, parent, daughter, former teacher, freelance writer and, yes, schoolboard candidate.

title: FollowUp on
description: With the price of copper soaring prohibitively, the United States Treasury asked Congress in December 1973 for authority to mint aluminum pennies. The legislation died in 1974 after the vendingmachine lobby protested that the new coins would jam their machines.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Mind trips. Three weeks ago, as we rattled off a list of the categories of genre fiction that are the staff of life for paperback publishers we neglected to mention one of the hardiest science fiction. This month, as almost every month, the major firms will be issuing an average of more than one book a day about the heroes and monsters of imaginary worlds, dramatized speculation about what would happen if

title: Jean McKeever, Economist, to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mo. Halfred Lawrence McKeever of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Elizabeth McKeever, to David Edward Weiskopf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weiskopf of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Olympic Briefs
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 31 (UPI)The International Olympic Committee confirmed today that the Montreal Summer Olympics would open as planned. The I.O.C.'s nineman executive board questioned Dr. Victor Goldbloom, the Quebec public affairs minister, for 10 hours about construction problems at the main Olympic stadium in Montreal and its related problems. A statement at the end of the meeting said: It has been confirmed that the games will open on July 17th, 1976 in Montreal.

title: J. L. Jones Weds Kathy Johnson
description: Kathy Allan Johnson. an account executive for Stall Levenson Associates Inc. Dallas, and Jerry Lyle Jonei. a sales representative for WFAATV, also in Dallas, were married there yesteiday afternoon in the Perkirfs Chapel at Southern Metho7 dist University. The Protntant ceremony was per; formed by the Rev. Walker Rainey. He was assisted by Richard Greene, a lay minister.

title: Lebanese in Brooklyn Feeling Pangs of War
description: It is 5,600 miles from Bay Ridge to Beirut. But the ties that bind this large Lebanese Christian community in Brooklyn to the strifetorn Middle East nation are firm and strong. And, these days, Bay Ridge's Lebanese are full of anguish and fears, anxiety and tears.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although arguments against the disclosure of the C.I.A.'s activities arrive at different conclusions, they all seem to begin with the same fearinspiring premise: What other country would be so foolish as to divulge its trade secrets (Does Macy's tell Gimbel's?) to the competition? The implication is that, having committed this unprecedented folly, the United States has become much more vulnerable, and its biggest competitor, the Soviet Union, not only much stronger but freed of any constraints that previously may have allowed for a kind of parity in the espionage community.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Immorlality is conferred in devious and unexpected ways. If you're an architect, there's always hope. The latest switch in architectural immortality has come with the remake of King Kong. The producers have been running a fullpage ad announcing that their first fullpage ad was so popularwith 25,000 requests for fullcolor reprintsthat they are working around the clock to fill orders. The ad shows King Kong breaking up airplanes with his right hand and clutching Whoever plays ray Wray in his left hand, standing astrideand this is the pointnot the Empire State Building, as in the original film, but the World Trade Center towers.

title: World News Briefs
description: LIMA. Peru, Jan. 31 (AP) The leftist military regime today swore in Gen. Jorge Ferpandez Maldonado, a prime nover in nationalizing Peru's mines, as Prime Minister.

title: Jesse (Lone Cat) Fuller Dead; Influential OneMan Band, 79
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)Jesse Fuller, a folkblues musician who was considered one of the greatest oneman bands died this week, it was reported yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Alan Kennedy Marries Miss Page
description: Harriet Sayles Page and Alan Montgomery Kennedy, both of San Francisco, were married there yesterday morning in the Shakespeare Garden of Golden Gate Park. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roy Erford, minister of both St. Paul's Methodist Church and St. Francis Presbyterian Church in San Francisco.

title: INVESTING
description: Last week, for the first time, newspapers began to. publish stock market tables containing expanded information for issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Lovely Monster
description: Technology has improved since Victor Frankenstein went into production, but the old recipe is still in use. Like Mary Shelley's creation, the monster in this fantasy is made up of spare parts. Dr. Kraft Tellenbeck solders him together using an innovative cellglue, a kit of laserlike tools and a nasty sense of humor. And like Dr. Frankenstein, Tellenbeck stints on the one thing a monster needs above all else: love.

title: Labor Talks Constant Part Of Conversation by Athletes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 31Golf and socializing, not to mention a $10,000 first prize, are supposed to be the subjects for attention in the 10th annual tournament for major league baseball and football players put on by American Airlines, but inevitably the talk turns to topic A of today's sports scene: labor relations.

title: Egypt Plans MineRemoval
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31 (AP)Egypt plans to remove about four and a half million land mines planted by British and Axis forces during World War II in the El Alamein area along the Mediterranean, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported.

title: Wendy Chambers Married in Jersey
description: Wendy Chambers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Chambers of Westfield, N. 3., was married yesterday afternoon to Theodore Albert Sledzinski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Walter Sledzinsld of Detroit.

title: Leafs Victors On Late Goals
description: TORONTO, Jan. 31Dunr Wilson's scraggly hair was even scragglier with dampness tonight after his strenuous effort in the New York Rangers 64 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Answers/Questions
description: ACATS AND PLANTS (Jan. 18) in Mrs. P. T., Brooklyn, N. Y. was concerned because her two Siamese cats used dracaena tubs as litter boxes while she was on vacation. Now the plants leaves are yellowing and she asked how to save them. Marcia Frierdich, a Wisconsin reader, had the same problem. She writes, I took my cat to a vet and found that it had kidney failure and couldn't handle the high protein in cat foods and table scraps. High protein caused her to drink huge quantities of water and urinate often. I prolonged her life with a lowprotein, lowash diet. I saved the plants by repotting them in fresh soil. Although my dieffenbachia roots and stem were dead, I cut the top off and rerooted it in vermiculite.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Unless otherwise noted, the critical judgments in this Guide reflect the published views of Times critics.
description: Unless otherwise noted, the critical judgments in this Guide reflect the published views of Times critics.

title: U.S. Citrus Aid for Egypt
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31 (AP)Egypt and an American company, In ternational for Agriculture, hay signed a $47 million agreement to plant orange and grapefruits on a 15,000acre area in the Nile delta. Egyptians said that the orrharda would yield $60 million a year.

title: College Soccer Coaches Happy: Rules Unchanged
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's recent convention in St. Louis produced no legislation that might handicap the development of college soccer. Proposals that might have been detri mental to the sport were de feated. The key areas of postseason practice, outside participation and limitation of the number of games are unchanged. News of Soccer

title: OF SPECIAL INTEREST
description: 10:00 A.M. (2) LAMP UNTO MY FEET. A halfhour conversation with the Archibishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Donald Coggan; with Ted Holmes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Soviet Union yesterday issued its final economic figures for 1975, confirming earlier estimates of a serious decline in agricultural production and revealing a failure to meet many of the goals of the last fiveyear plan. The statistics indicated continuing growth in most key sectors except agriculture, but the increase generally was below the goals set in 1970. Production of consumer goods, which was one of the priorities, was still below heavy industry. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: BRIDGE
description: Sponsors and cash prizes in tournament bridge are very rare in this country, but they are the norm on the other side of the Atlantic. And a notable attempt to develop a European tournament circuit analogous to tennis has recently been made under the sponsorship of Philip Morris International. Ten countries stage qualifying tournaments at intervals of about one month. Each tournament is a separate entity with its own prize structure, but it awards points toward an overall prize that was won for 19745 by the British women stars Rixi Markus and Fritzi Gordon.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Review. it was incorrectly stated that the cost of Red No. 2 dye consumed in food products during 1974 was nearly half a cent per dollar spent on such food. The correct figure is nearly onetwentieth of a cent.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: It is a very promising last quarter of our century which begins with new pictures the ones by Jasper Johns which view at the Leo Castelli Gallery. The show consists of recent paintings, drawings and one very large print. Their cumulative effect is that of a family album in which is recorded an exceptionally high incidence of twins. lookalike seniors and juniors, and a touch or two of incest.

title: Notes: Educating Teachers on Taxes
description: AMONG the American multitudes now facing up to the annual income taxreturn headache are thousands of teachers who have missed the boat literally and figuratively, Because of their ignorance of the tax laws, they have not gone on trips they might have been able to afford or they have taken a trip and failed to take all the deductions they were entitled to.

title: Making Trivia From Trash
description: HAVE YOU noticed how everyone in New Jersey is tackling the ecology crisis with all stops out? Adult evening schools offer courses ranging from Preparing a Gourmet Meal from Scraps to The Automotive Repairwoman, and garden clubs endeavoring to line some of the heavily traveled highways with decorative shrubs are keeping one step ahead of asphyxiation.

title: Blood in The Snow
description: Some kids are Fight Kids and some kids are Flute Kids, Max Murphy tells his bullying enemy, Crow Hintz, and I'm no Fight Kid. And so, denying his father's insistence that he follow macho pursuits, Max trades the gun inherited from his grandfather for a flute (cast away in Crow's attic) with which he can learn to make music that would sound [as) if it were coming down in a ribbon from the sky.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Soundonfilm home movie cameras are currently being marketed by at least eight manufacturers, but all bear a marked family resemblance and all have characteristics and capabilities that are often quite similar. Thus it becomes possible to generalize on both their strengths and weaknesses, and to summarize what can and cannot be done with them.

title: Pompeian Exhibit in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)An exhibition of treasures from Pompeii and Herculaneum, the ancient cities in Italy buried by the volcano Vesuvius in the year 79, will be staged in London next November.

title: Two Juries to Sift Charges I.R.S. Head Balked Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Department of Justice has authorized two Federal grand juries, one sitting in Miami, the other here, to investigate allegations that Donald C. Alexander, the Internal Revenue Commissioner, improperly curtailed tax investigation in the Caribbean.

title: New jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayCoach House, Kenilworth Road, Rye, N. Y. Regular, limit and children's working hunters; equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The ordering period for the 12coin, nonsilver, 1976 uncirculated set opens tomorrow. The cutoff date for orders will be announced when the Mint determines that its potential production capacity has been reached.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Angler in Winter
description: OAK BEACH, L. I.Dawn was bitterly cold and bleak.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LABOR LEADERS CHOOSE CANDIDATE: Senator Birch Bayh addressing labor gathering In Boston yesterday. A group of labor leaders announced its endorsement at meeting.

title: F.B.I.'s Hiss Files Show Bumbling, Not Malice
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, acting under court order, has Just released 15,376 pages of files on the Alger Hiss case. The records help to clarify lingering questions about the bureau's probe into Whittaker Chambers's charges against Mr. Hiss. The bureau continues to hold 1,055 pages under various Freedom of Information Act exemptions. The American Civil Liberties Union, which filed the original suit to open the records, intends to return to court to press for full disclosure.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The allure of A CHILD'S GARDEN OF DEATH by Richard Forrest (Bobbs  Merrill, $7.95) is less in the story than in the telling. The plot is worked out well enough, though there is nothing particularly original about its ingredients. A grave with three skeletons, one of them of a female child, is discovered in a small Connecticut town. The deceased had been murdered about thirty years ago. The local police chief asks his brotherinlaw to help in the investigation. Then the detail work starts: identifying the bodies, backtracking, relating of clues to the present.

title: Art
description: Arts and Leisure Guide KATONAH, 28 Bedford Rd., Katonah, N.Y.The American Scene and New Forms of Modernism, 19351954. Through March 14. Drawinos and paintings by Andrea Shapiro. Through Feb. 8. Tues.Thurs., and Suns., 25; Fris.Sots., 105.

title: What's a Nice Girl Like Her Doing in A Role Like This?
description: She stomps onto the screen, all 250 pounds of her, wearing a pair of black leather boots, a mannish gray uniform, and wielding a whip that she constantly cracks across peoples backs. She is Hilda, the cigarpuffing commandant of the Nazi concentration camp in Lina INertmuller's extraordinary new film, Seven Beauties. As played by the American actress Shirley Stoler, Hilda is a chilling portrait of monumental evil, a tightlipped and steelyeyed believer in the master race, who is totally devoid of emotion as she casually condemns prisoners to the firing squad. This woman is a kind of Superbitch of Belsen, said Vincent Canby in The Times. A sadistic pile of frozen Teutonic dough, played brilliantly by Shirley Stoler, said Jack Kroll of Newsweek.

title: Notes: Is It Really a Good. Season?
description: What has happened to the Broadway season that, last fall, promised to be the best in years? Part of that promise the dollar partis in the process of being fulfilled, but by and large Broadway's 197576 season, now well past the halfway mark, has suffered some disappointing artistic failures.

title: New Boats Bait For Cold Fishing
description: MONTAUKThe changing nature of both fishing boats and fishermen was brought into focus here last week as 39 anglers braved a stiff wind and subfreezing temperature to board the newly christened fishing boat Peconic Queen III for a predawn departure from Pier One.

description: Roosevelt Results

title: FORD URGES G.O.P. TO SHUN ES. ROLE IN PROVIDING JOBS
description: DEARBORN. Mich., Jan. 31 President Ford, calling political promises of full employment a cruel illusion, urged Middle Western Republican leaders here today to unite behind his goslow prescription for economic recovery.

title: ORT ADOPTS BUDGET OF 10% OVER 1975
description: The American ORT Federation adopted yesterday a budget of $45,465,000 to maintain and enlarge its network of 679 vocational schools and installations around the world for the training of Jewish men and women.
