description: The Soviet Union yesterday issued its final economic figures for 1975, confirming earlier estimates of a serious decline in agricultural production and revealing a failure to meet many of the goals of the last fiveyear plan. The statistics indicated continuing growth in most key sectors except agriculture, but the increase generally was below the goals set in 1970. Production of consumer goods, which was one of the priorities, was still below heavy industry. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: More Elderly Retiring in North
description: HARRISON, Mich.January is the cruelest month in the north woods. The wind pierces to the bone. Great drifts of snow swirl out of the stands of jack pine and maple, clogging roads and making life hard even for the rabbits.

title: The Gull Wall
description: The Gull Wall is a sprawling, unwieldy book which almost repels the reader with its broken syntax and deliberately private images. Despite Whitmanesque invocations in several titles, the energy of the poems is strangely solitary, as if it did not care to share itself. The opening poem. To the Creative Spirit. lets the reader know what to expect:

title: FRED HARRIS'S WIFE SPEAKS IN HARLEM
description: LaDonna Harris, campaigning yesterday on behalf of her husband, Fred Harris, the former Senator from Oklahoma who is now seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, talked to more than 100 women in Harlem. Her theme was children.

title: Thomas Parker Becomes Fiance Of Miss Higgins
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Higgins of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Barbour Higgins, to Thomas Jefferson Parker, son of Capt. Jefferson D. Parker, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Parker of McLean. Va.

title: Press of Americas Reported Facing Tighter Controls
description: The press of the Americas is under increasingly severe stress, and there is a decline in the number of countries where newspapers are permitted to report or comment freely, according to a report presented to the Executive Committee of the Inter American Press Association.

title: Pipe Organ Adds a Touch of the Past to Theater
description: PORT WASHINGTONThe theater was pitch black, except for one eerie light in tha ercheetra. pit. And ghostly organ music flooded the auditorium. It would have been an ideal setting for Phantom of the Opera, but that was not the case.

title: Samuel Dunton, Photographer For Zoo and Aquarium, Dead
description: Samuel Cady Dunton, who had been the staff photographer for the New York Zoological Society for 40 years at his retirement in 1974, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived at 73 Lakewood Avenue, Babylon, L.I.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The Supreme Court has again strengthened the powers of lawenforcement officers in relation to rotential defendants by upholding It& power of Federal agents to mite arrests in public without warrants, provided there is probable cause to suspect that a felony has been committed.

title: Article 19  No Title
description: Lynton Wells YWY75, 1975Photo emulsion, oil and acrylic on canvas & Extending dramatically the esthetics of the medium.

title: Design
description: Henri Gueron, Paul Laird and Richard Hertz have never met, but they share several things in common. All are divorced. All are fathers. And all have designed apartments that not only suit their single lifestyles but also accommodate their children when they come to visit.

title: Bennington College Picks City Lawyer As Its Acting Head
description: Joseph F. Iseman, a New York lawyer with the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, has been appointed acting president of troubled Bennington College in Vermont.

title: Taiwan's Second City
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 31 (AP) The population of Kaohsiung, second largest city in Taiwan, passed the one million mark this year, the municipal government of the southern port announced.

title: Adversary Proceedings
description: The United States Supreme Court, balancing the danger of possible infringement of First Amendment guarantees against the need to correct the campaign financing abuses disclosed during the Watergate investigations, has decided that Congress acted in a generally Constitutional manner in its effort to legislate reform.

title: ALPINE SKIING
description: WomenLindy Cochran, 22, Richmond, Vt.; Abbi Fisher. 18, South Conway, N.H.; Cindy Nelson, 20, Lutsen, Minn,; Susie Patterson, 20, Sun Valley, Idaho; Mary Seaton, 19, Hancock, Mich., and Leslie Leletc Smith, 17, Killington, Vt.

title: Food and Fuel for Thought
description: LET your mind wander to a sunny summer weekend and a trip to the shore, bumper to bumper on the Garden State Parkway, cars overheating, horns blaring and the children squirming in the back seat.

title: Big Business And the Plans To Make It Behave
description: WASHINGTONElliot Richardson, whom no one has ever accused of being slow at law, or politics, may have given a subtle hint at one issue he thinks is going to arise in this year's Presidential campaign. Over Spanish omelets and Danish pastry, he tried last week to tell two dozen disbelieving reporters why he was enthralled with his new job as Secretary of Commerce. After having been Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Attorney General and Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, why in the world did he want to become Commerce Secretary? Hardly anybody in Washington knows where the building is.

title: DaytoDay Schedule of Innsbruck Competition
description: All times are New York time. Innsbruck time is six hours later. For example, 6:30 A.M. in New York is 12:30 P.M. in Innsbruck.

title: CHILEAN REFUGEES ACCUSE COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 31 Some Chilean exiles here charge that Colombia is embarked on a policy of harassing them into leaving the country.

title: Unions: Setback Abroad
description: AMSTERDAM  An international group of unions has failed to stop the Dutchbased multinational Akzo N.V. from making major job cutbacks irr its moneylosing Dutch and West German synthetic fiber plants.

title: Miscellany
description: FILM FORUMRainer Werner Fasbinder's The American Soldier. 15 vandam St. Thur. next Sun., 7:30.

title: Singles, Happy Not Hectic
description: WENDY SIMON says she loves New Jersey. She loves her apartment, which she has decorated with imagination in shades of yellow, gray and white. And she loves her job in Carlstadt, where she works as a merchandiser for a buttonandbuckle company.

title: Letters
description: Maurice Sendak's Fantasy sketch (Endpaper, Jan. 11) was rather bizarre. It needed some comments, so here they are:

title: Wood Type Obsolete, Yet in Demand
description: Type made of woodthat is, individual letters, numbers and other characters cut out of wood, instead of cast in metal, was once a staple of printing newspaper headlines, posters, broadsides and handbills in the United States. Now virtually obsolete as a printing medium, wood type is, nevertheless, in great demand by many hobbyists, craftsmen and decorators who use it to create unusual looking collages and abstract geometric constructions that serve as wall hangings, table decorations or shelf ornaments in homes and offices.

title: The World
description: MADRIDSpain in the months ahead, as described by Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro, will be neither fish nor fowl but an ambiguous creature that may well be carrying Mr. Arias's end as a political leader here.

title: WEIGHTS ON CANS OFTEN CONFUSING
description: The drained weight of pears canned under 16 different brand names varied by as much as 45.8 percent despite the fact that all the cans showed the same net weight, according to tests conducted by the Suffolk County Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: A Soldier Reports
description: This is the first fullfledged war memoir by a senior member of the American Government. A Soldier Reports, by the commander of United States forces in Vietnam from 1964 to mid1968, deserves to be reviewed on its own terms, not as a literary document but as a soidier's version of events. Gen. William C. Westmoreland dues not explore the moral aspects of the war and displays virtually no understanding of the struggle as seen from the United States. But therein lies much of the book's value: this is the view from inside the whale.

title: TV's Cop Shows are Crazy About Psychotics
description: When the Family Hour is over, the TV screen turns blueblue serge, to be exact. The cop opera dominates the tube at night. But even the casual viewer may have noticed that the copsandrobbers genre is being superseded by a new breedcops and crazies. Joseph Wambaugh, the creator of Police Story, labels the phenomenon the Psycho of the Week syndrome.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Two lightweights, a heavyweight, a light heavyweight and a welterweight, all highly rated, are among the cast for the four 10round bouts scheduled for Madison Square Garden Friday night. The lightweights are Ray Lampkin, the No. 1 challenger, and fifthranked Vilomar Fernandez. Pedro Soto faces Tom (The Bomb) Bethea in one heavyweight bout, and Duane Bobick, undefeated in 33 fights, meets Larry Middleton in the other. The welterweight bout matches Saoul Mamby and fifthranked Harold Weston Jr. The first bout is at 8 o'clock.The $150,000 Hopeful Pacing Series begins next week at Roosevelt Raceway. This weekend will feature junior freeforall pacing events. Post time nightly is 8 o'clock.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: FILM VIEW
description: It is fourfifty on a Wednesday afternoon, inside the last house on the left as one staggers down 42d Street from Seventh Avenue toward Eighth. Outside there is snow that is turning to neonlit slush even before it hits the sidewalk. Inside the light is almost as bright as on the street though the temperature is warmer. Two people on the opposite side of the balcony are arguingcrossly but lethargically. Each appears to forget from time to time what it is he finds insupportable in the other. Angola? Belfast? A rude smell? Two rows away from me a man, who has apparently been eating his lunch (or art early supper), starts to retch. With several other patrons in the vicinity, I look around, alarmed. Will I have to move? Leave entirely? No. The man doesn't get sick.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Dismisses Opposition Government of a State and Takes Over Rule
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 31Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, continuing the concentration of political power in her own hands, today ordered the dismissal of the opposition government in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

title: Court Seems Involved With a Higher Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)For a moment, it looked as though some local officials in Virginia might be trying to appeal one of the Ten Commandments to the Supreme Court.

title: Photography
description: LOU BERNSTEINBlackendwhile photographs of People and animals, taken from 1962 to the present. Stlegiltr, 31 W. 13th St. Opens today. Through Feb. 21. Tues., 79 P.M.; FrlsSuns., 16.

title: Taiwan's Second City
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 31 (AP) The population of Kaohsiung, second largest city in Taiwan, passed the one million mark this year, the municipal government of the southern port announced.

title: Only One Is Seeking Mexican Presidency
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31Mexico's tiny opposition party has decided not to present a candidate in the forthcoming Presidential elections, and the Government has expressed fears that the result could be harmful to democracy.

title: HIONG KONG BEGINS BUILDING A SUBWAY
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 28Traffic along Nathan Road, Hong Kong's biggest shopping center, will be disrupted for the next three years. Thousands of squatters are being uprooted and many itinerant vendors are being told to find new sites.

title: The Shortchanged Review
description: Ironically, Michael Dorn Moody's The Shortchanged Review, which has been moved from Off Off Broadway to the Mitzi E. Newhouse in Lincoln Center, is also about wishing, though it takes itself much more seriously and to no one's great profit. WISH is the name of the audiencesponsored radio station that is gleamingly suspended, tapes on the spin, above the suburban homestead of the idealist who runs it. The idealist is named Nicky Shannigan. He lopes abOut like an old buckandwing hoofer who's lost his stage (in Mason Adams's rather interesting performance), and he neglects his family altogether while he pursues his career as A talent junkie, finding and promoting music no one's heard yet.

title: The Ballet: Balanchine's Gaspard
description: Ravel's curious nightthoughts for the pianoGaspard de la Nuit, inspired by poems by the French writer Aloysius Bartrandwere the basis for one of George Balanchine's ballets for last summer's Ravel Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: ART
description: THE exhibition now at the Rutgers University Art Gallery in New Brunswick emphasizes the growing importance of photography in the production of contemporary art works. The 90 works on view use the photographic process in a rich variety of ways, extending dramatically the esthetics of the medium.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: I T was womens week in New Jersey. First, the Attorney General did his part to promote an increase in the birth rate by ruling that working women can get disability payments when they take time off to have babies. And then the State Supreme Court came along and ruled that the wives of judges could engage in political activity.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Drawing Now at the Museum of Modern Art, through March 9. Open 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily; until 9 P.M. Thursday; closed Wednesday. TwentiethCentury American Drawing; Three AvantGarde Generations at the Guggenheim, through March 21. Open 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. Tuesday; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday through Sunday; Closed Monday.

title: Very InterestingThose Oriental Vegetables
description: Among the aavantages or having one's own vegetable garden is the chance to plant and grow the unusual. I find some of the most fascinating vegetables are of the oriental cuisine. The variety is large, and a few of the perennial kinds can be grown with ornamentals in border plantings.

title: GarmentIndustry Labor Talks Aim to Avert Strike Tomorrow
description: Union and dress manufacturer representatives were locked in hard bargaining late yesterday in an effort to avert a strike threatened for tomorrow morning by 55,000 members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Leo Stein, publicrelations spokesman for the Union, said: There is hard negotiation now on the economic package of a new contract. Considerable progress was made Friday on resolving enforcement of contract provisions and on working conditions in the shops.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Biblical Songs.

title: The Region
description: Governor Carey has begun a publicrelations campaign in his dispute with Special State Prosecutor Maurice Nadjari, whom the Governor tried and failed to dismiss. The publicly conducted squabbling has so far obscured the substantive legal issues in the controversy.

title: Endpaper
description: The bit of prose which follows is the beginning of a story written for this occasion. Readers of The Times are invited to complete it in not more than 750 words, and accordance with the rules listed below, as an experiment in literary collaboration. I will be the final judge, and the winning work will be published on a future Endpaper page. A $250 prize is offered by The Times. I hope that the entries will be serious, rather than parodies or burlesques. I have done the easiest part, the beginning; you are asked to provide the terrifying middle and the subtle, incomparably beautiful ending. God be with you.D.B.

title: Fear Waits on Cypress Road
description: When Laura and Ned Evans find a corpse on their grounds late one night, Ned says, Come, Laura  let's go back to bed. This is no time to discuss what happened.

title: Food for Thought for Elderly on L.
description: HEMPSTEAD  More elderly die of the effects of malnutrition than anything else, said Dr. Carol Lucas, director of the Town of Hempstead's Office of Services for the Aging. It isn't just a question of money either, she added. Eating alone is not fun. Just grabbing coffee and cake or tea and toast or some other snack is much less bother. But it takes more than that to sustain life.

title: IRVING B. TAUB
description: Irving B. Taub, credit manager of John Chatillon and Sons of Kew Gardens, Queens, scales, measuring instruments And springs, died Friday at his home, 10 Copley Road, Larchmont, N.Y. He was 70 years Old.

title: Foreign Policy Muddle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31There have been so many puzzles here over the conduct of American foreign policy in the last couple of years that the notion is getting around that the President ana the Congress can't agree on anything, but this is not precisely true.

title: Israel Faces Water Curbs
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 31 (UPI)An unusually dry winter may force water rationing in Israel next summer. A spokesman said the surface of the Sea of Galilee, Israel's principal natural reservoir, was 45 inches below normal.

title: U.S. Jewish Group Clarifies Its Stand On Mexico Travel
description: The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations has stated that it is up to each of its member organizations to decide whether it wants to resume travel programs to Mexico.

title: The Nation
description: Though the relation between the results of precinct meetings and the action of a party convention is tenuous, the preliminary count in last week's Mississippi's meetings has demonstrated one concrete political fact. George C. Wallace's strategists have mastered, in Mississippi at least, what they failed to in 1972, the intricacy of caucus politics. The Alabama Governor will probably go to the Democratic convention with half of Mississippi's 24 delegates. His political workers are moving on to South Carolina, where caucuses begin Feb. 28.

title: Pope Paul Assails Feminists Who Risk Tirilizing Women
description: ROME, Jan. 31 (AP)Pope Paul VI today appealed for wisdom and realism in granting women positions of power and assailed feminist movements that he said run the risk of virilizing and depersonalizing women.

title: Amy Satuloff Will Be Bride
description: Amy Beth Satuloff and L. Craig Lemle, graduates of Lehigh University, will be married in June. Their engagement has been annouced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Satuloff of Harrison. N.Y.

title: Critchell Rimington Dies at 68; Publisher of Yachting Magazine
description: Critchell (Bob) Rimington, former publisher of Yachting magazine, and a writer about the sea and yachting, died Friday in Washington, Conn. He was 68 years old and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Angolan Leftist Charges U.S. With Economic War
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 31The head of the government set up here by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola charged last night that the United States was waging economic war on Angola.

title: New Rail Plan Drafted by State
description: AFTER a rash of railroad reorganization plans in the past year  preliminary, revised and final Federal plans who needs still another one? Well, for a starter, tens of thousands of New Jersey commuters and scores of freight shippers do.

title: ... Meanwhile, New Business
description: WASHINGTONDuring a single week last month, the Household Finance Corporation, the Phelps Dodge Company, the Skelly Oil Company, the First National Bank of Arizona and the National Association of Retail Grocers all notified the Federal Government they were going into politics.

title: Madrid Lifts Film Curb As Cultural Reins Ease
description: MADRID, Jan. 31Abolition of censorship for film scripts has just been announced and it appears to be part of the effort to make Spain less different from the rest of Western Europe in culture as well as in politics.

title: Williams's Flawed Entertainment
description: It was distressingly apparent at the American Conservatory Theater's recent premiere of Tennessee Williams's latest play, This Is (An Entertainment), that the work fails to live up to the assertion of its title.

title: Jackson Challenges Policy of Detente In Bid to Gain Massachusetts Votes
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31Senator Henry M. Jackson, trying to separate himself from the rest of the pack of Democrats running in the Massachusetts Presidential primary, has found one issue above all that he believes he can make his own detente.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The body of a 57yearold woman was found in the basement of one of a row of houses in Richmond Hill, Queens, that were destroyed by a gas explosion and fire Friday night. John and Anna Kezar were admitted to the burn treatment units at Harlem and Jacobi Hospitals, where they were reported to be in critical condition. The police were checking a report that leaking gas was present in the basement of the Kazar home at 13418 86th Road. The blast occurred at 9:45 P.M. and caused extensive damage to tho Kam home and the adjacent building at 134??? 86th Road, where the dead woman, Margaret Eacik, had lived. Two other houses also were slightly damaged, but the families escaped injury.

title: Late Television Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Burma Curbs Dancing
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 31 (AP)The Government has banned performances of decadent Western music and dances in hotels, restaurants and other public places, the stateowned Working People's Daily reports.

title: TV Schedule
description: The Winter Olympics will be televised in this country by ABC (Channel 7 in New York) at these times (all times are New York time):

title: Rangers LineUp
description: Rangers LineUp

title: Fighting Like Cats and Dogs Over Cats and Dogs
description: WHAT every lawyer knows is that the biggest troubles come from statutes that mean well and look innocuous. The kind that begin life as nice little propositions, float unharmed through the wiliest legislative traps, are signed into law without fanfareand then rise up in the most unexpected ways to do untold damage to unbelieving citizens.

title: Who the Hell Is William Loeb?
description: Perhaps we have Orson Welles to blame. Citizen Kane glamorized cantankerous newspaper publishers, and made attractive the life of a bully protected by the First Amendment. The remarkable thing about American journalism is that it produces so few William Loebs, whether out of prolem.

title: Defeat Foreseen for Ford's BlockGrants Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Ford's proposal to consolidate a multitude of special Federal aid programs into four broad block grants to the states is likely to be defeated this year by the same forces that caused the defeat of similar proposals over the last nine years, according to senior members of Congress.

title: Dire Outlook for L.I. Schools
description: NORTH BELLMOREThe 197576 school year may go down in history as the year in which public elementary and secondary education in New York State closed down because it ran out of money, was the dire prediction made recently by the head of the NassauSuffolk School Boards Association.

title: U.S. May Again Seek Amnesty Resolution in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, Jan. 31The United States, which abandoned a drive last fall to get the United Nations to seek the release of all political prisoners, is testing the waters for another attempt.

title: Court Upholds 43.4% Rent Rise For MitchellLama Project Here
description: A State Supreme Court justice last week upheld an order of the city's Housing and Development Administration imposing a 43.4 percent rent increase over a twoyear period on tenants of Trinity House, a 29story MitchellLama apartment house on the West Side.

title: Miranda Slain
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 31 (AP) Ernesto Miranda, for whom the Supreme Court's landmark decision requiring the police to inform suspects of their rights was named, was stabbed to death today in what officers said appeared to be a bar fight.

title: Births
description: Births

title: Meagher Captures Iona School Mile
description: Now my brothers can't kid me anymore, Tom Meagher said yesterday after winning the mile run in the 15th annual Iona College schoolboy meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Regulatory Agency Appointees Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31A preliminary hearing to develop the platform of the Democratic National Committee was told today that past Administrations had filled the Federal regulatory agencies with failed politicians, special interest lawyers and unknown mediocrities.

title: POLITICS
description: THE only time that an incumbent New Jersey Governor was rejected by his own party occurred in 1973, when the Republicans denied William T. Cahill renomination. While the rejection was obviously hard on Mr.'Cahill's psyche, as it would be for any politidal leader, it turned out to be a disaster for the G.O.P. because six months later it suffered the worst election defeat in its history.

title: It Was a Long and Hectic Millrose Night
description: Olympic fever or not, a record crowd of 18,142 paid $119,010 to watch 600 young athletes run and jump in Madison Square Garden, and records were still falling early yesterday morning after 6 hours of the Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: The Shopping Centers
description: THE NEW JERSEY Symphony Orchestra has played there to an audience of thousands; a local competition was held in the Miss TeenAge America contest; a playhouse staged dramas, comedies and musicals; demonstrations were presented in Colonial cooking, American quiltmaking and transcendental meditation, and little children listened to story hours and gaped at puppet shows.

title: U.S. to Get Buddhist Bell
description: SEOUL South Korea, Jan 31 (APSouth Korea is CdSling a reproduction of a 1.200yearold Buddhist bell as a Bicentennial gift. to the American people. The I 0fooihign. 20ton Friendship Bell will be shipped before July 4 to Ios Angeles, where 50.000 KoreanAmericans live.

title: Editors Choice
description: ANDRE MALRAUX, by Jean Lacouture. Translated by Alan Sheridan. (Pantheon Books, $12.95.) A crafty unraveling of the confused strands of events in the life of a man in whom reallife and fictional heroism merge.

title: S.O.R.C. Changes to Trim Sails
description: The Southern Ocean Racang Conference, the series of six midwinter races in Florida waters with a distinguished 40year history, was won last year by Dennis Conner sailing the 36foot One Ton sloop Stinger.

title: Coast Drought Is Worst in 70 Years
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31The most severe drought in California in more than 70 years is causing fire hazards, itchy skin, an economic threat to cattle ranchers and farmers, frustration for skiers and danger to wildlife.

title: Future Events
description: Feb. 5In our nation's capital (you can't get far from Washington this year) is  an American organization, the African Wildlife Lead ership Foundation, dedicated to the conservation of Africa's irreplaceable fauna. Its programs are designed to help African peoples understand the value of this resource and to develop skill for its conservation. The foundation's conunitments are supported by a board of most distinguished trustees Kermit Roosevelt, for instance, the grandson of our 26th President, V/710 was not only a notable hunter but also an ardent, farseeing, conservationist, and Gilbert M. Grosvenor, vice president of the National Geographic Society and editor of the society's magazine. For the third time the foundation will hold its annual exhibition of contemporary wildlife and sporting art at the Sportsmen's Edge Gallery here, which includes paintings, carvings and sculptures of game and wild fowl, big game of the veldt, Rocky Mountains and Canadian wild, hunting horses and hounds, denizens of the deep and rivers by noted artists of the genre. A benefit preview from 6 to 9 P.M. includes two specimens of domestic highlife  cocktails and hors d'oeuvre. Preview tickets from the gallery, $12 a person, $20 a couple. The exhibition will be open to the public Feb. 7 through 21, with 10 percent of the original art sales and 20 percent of print sales going to the foundation.

title: Picture credits
description: IMODEL BY ROGER LAW AND PETER FL CRAMPUCIC, PHOTOGRAPH Y.

title: Importers Cautioned  On Thefts
description: Importers of cargo by sea and air and the operators of their terminals have been put on notice by the United States Customs Service that they may lose their permits to unload shipments here unless they tighten up on cargo security. The warning was issued earlier this month in a circular letter to the industry by Fred R. Boyett, Regional Commissioner of Customs in New York.

title: JOB CUTS HURTING THE LIFE SCIENCES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Federal policies and the recession may severely hamper the research work of a generation of biomedical scientists, group of experts have warned.

title: M.I.T. Gets Gift From Japan
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 31 (AP)A $1 million gift from Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Company Ltd. has enabled the Massachusetts Institnute of Technology to establish a new professorship, the Matsushita professorship of electrical engineering in medicine, Howard W. Johnson, M.I.T. chairman, has announced.

title: CHESS
description: The sum of two weaknesses is not always double that of each separately: often the total debility to the division. is increased fourfold. But more surprisingly, there are congenial weaknesses that cancel each other.

title: Karen Ramsing Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Karen Clews Ramsing to Christopher Noel Luhn has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thor H. Ramsing of Greenwich, Conn., and Chestertown, Md., parents of the future bride. Mr. Luhn is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wickliffe Adkins Luhn of Sarasota, Fla. The wedding is planned for June 12.

title: It Has Been Fertilized by Suburban Clout
description: In midApril of 1974 a group of Republican state senators and assemblymen from Long Island met in Albany with Republican Gov. Malcolm Wilson, who was facing an election in November. A few days earlier Mr. Wilson had proposed a new formula for the distribution of state aid to local school districts, and the only subjects discussed at the meeting were the coming campaign and property taxes in New York's suburban Nassau and Suffolk counties, on Long Island.

title: Paperbacks
description: FAMILIES AND SURVIVORS, by Alice Adams. (Warner, $1.50.) Louisa Calloway of Virginia and California is the center of this sharpeyed, sparely recorded look at the generation that came of age during the 1940's and then had to breast the changing domestic tides of the 50's and 60's.

title: More Hospital Closings Here Are Urged
description: The list released last Saturday by Mayor Beame of eight private hospitals that he felt should be closed to save money is only the beginning of what is expected to be a much longer list.

title: Strike Hits Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL N. J., Jan. 31A strike of Garden State Park's parimutnel clerks today forced the postponement of the opening of New Jersey's thoroughbred racing scheduled for Monday at the track.

title: Functional Pop Art Shown
description: WOODMERE Meet some pop art that speaks for itself.The pieces involved are abstract works that include framed collages, soft wire sculptures, threedimensional wall hangings and freefloating mobiles. Each is an artistic object in its own right. But there's a switch. Literally.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: CHANGE, any change, comes slowly, rarely easily, in ??? suburban New Jersey communities. In my town of Montclair, Bloomfield Avenue, a broad thoroughfare that runs west from Newark far out past West Caldwell, is changing.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: All tennis players fall roughly into three classesbeginner, intermediate and advanced. If you play, in what class are you, and what can you do to improve?

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: I believe my generation is unprecedented for its liberalism and activism in. America. And I earned my credentials. Beginning with volunteer work in the Presidential campaign of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Eugene Nickerson's gubernatorial race in New York, I have worked my way up the ladder of political involvement, Included in those years was a stint in Mayor John V. Lindsay's abortive 1972 Presidential race, service as one of McGovnrn's California coordinato as well as work for the setenator at the Miami Conver.,:on and a year as national president of the College Young Democrats.

title: Buffalo Cafe Will Reopen After Outbreak of Hepatitis
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 31 (UPI) Erie County Health Department officials have announced that Greenstreets Cafe, which has been closed since Dec. 24 be. cause of an outbreak of hepa. titis among employes, will reopen next Monday.

title: Red Smith
description: The powers, principalities and archangels of the baseball hierarchy descend upon the Americana Hotel tonight for the New York Baseball Writers annual hogkilling. They will graze, drink, caper, relive their jocund yesterdays and toast the fair adventure of tomorrow just as though they were confident there would be a tomorrow. The sober truth, which will not be heard tonight, is that they do not know when their teams will go to spring training, if at all, and they do not know when or whether the 1976 season will open.

title: United by Pollution
description: Barcelona is to be the scene this month of a meeting as politically noteworthy as it is environmentally promising. Among those scheduled to sit down together to sign a convention for arresting the pollution of the Mediterranean Sea are representatives of Israel and the Arab states, as well as of Greece and Turkeyproving that politics can end at the water's edge if the water is dirty enough to be a common danger.

title: Vote Commission Action Is Handicapped by Feuding
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Federal Election Commission, fighting for a new legislative franchise to keep it alive after yesterday's Supreme Court decision, is handicapped by a ninemonth record of abysmal relations with Congress. In dealing with the senators and representatives who must now decide its fate, the reform agency has been, at various times, clumsy, illinformed, distant, politically insensitive and selfrighteous, even descending at some points to outright misrepresentation, according to political and legal observers.

title: Catherine Patricia Bennett Is Married to J. B. deSibour
description: Catherine Patricia Bennett, a member of the staff of the National Security Council in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to J. Blaise deSibour Jr., an insurance executive in Washington.

title: Reneging on Uranium at Westinghouse
description: Two decades ago, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was at the center of efforts by the Government and private enterprise to persuade the nation's electric utilities to use nuclear technology for producing electricity.

title: COAST QUAKE FEAR MAY BAR PROJECT
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31The Inauguration of the largest pending atomic power project on the West Coast may be delayed or even prevented by the belated discovery of possible earthquake hazards.

title: Turkey Is Withdrawing 2,000 Cyprus Troops
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 31 (Reuters)  Two thousand Turkish soldiers will be withdrawn from Cyprus starting next week, the Army said today.

title: ExKnick Player Acquitted In Marijuana Case in Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 31 (UPI)Tom Hoover, a former New York Knickerbocker basketball player, has been acquitted of charges of possessing 125 pounds of marijuana in 1973.

title: Jersey Landlord Charged With Apartment Snooping
description: GLASSBORO, N. J., Jan. 31 (AP)Three Glassboro State College coeds told the police they were worried about the strange noises they heard in the walls of their apartmentsespecially since the noises seemed to follow them as they moved.

title: Access to Students Redords Still Burdening Schools
description: One year after it went into ieffect, the socalled Buckley Amendment has apparently achieved its basic purpose of assuring parents and students the right to view academic records.

title: A Bird's Best Friend
description: At first glance, it looks like the avian version of maximum security. Near the entrance, a greenbilled Cape Barren goose stands on one leg, curiously checking visitors in and out. Not far away, a small flock of jetblack swans patrols the grounds, craning their necks toward cage after cage of unusual inmates.

title: An Antic Parable From Hungary
description: Reestablishing a contact that has been almost completely severed since World War II, Hungary, which in bygone days exported Ferenc Molnar, Bela Lugosi and the Gabor sisters, has now sent us one of its new plays. The Tot Family, by Istvan Orkny, has opened at the Arena Stage In Washington, D. C., where it will run until the end of this month.

title: A Very Human President
description: Back in the L.B.J. days, Washington used to have a great time with the subject of President Johnson's aide, Jack Valenti. People analyzed, reanalyzed and rereanalyzed Valenti's idolatry of Lyndon Johnson. Did come from the assistant's bantam size compared to the President's 6 feet 4 inches? Was it a result of his being that none too comfortable combination, a Texan ItalianAmerican, now bedazzled by his post as a key aide to a Texan WASP President of the United States? Whatever the stumblings of amateur psychiatry, the unabashed worshipfulness was there. In 1965 the whole nation learned the extent of itwith loud guffawswhen Valenti went to a Boston advertising convention and delivered bimself of a description of L.B.J. as sensitive, cultivated, extraordinary man: having extra glands of energy and an instinct for rightness.  I sleep each night a little better  because Lyndon Johnson is my President.

title: A Disenchanted Electorate May Stay Home in Droves
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The people who study the electorate, not the Presidential candidates, in order to read the direction of American politics see a fog of futility setting in around the 1976 election.

title: FOXHALL FINNEY
description: Foxhall Finney, who had been vice president and secre tary of Street & Finney Inc., an advertising agency that closed in 1968, died yesterday at his home in Hampton, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A number of major Manhattan properties have recently been foreclosed or transferred in lieu of foreclosure.

title: What's Doing in PHILADELPHIA
description: BICENTENNIAL CITYPhiladelphia tried and failed to obtain massive Federal funding to stage a world's fair as the focal point for the country's 200th birthday celebration this year. But Bicentennial's centerpiece or no, this is where the action was in 1776. Which is why President Ford (Independence Day), Queen Elizabeth (July 6), King Gustav of Sweden (April 6) and an expected 20 million other visitors will jam the narrow streets of William Penn's town on the De/aware this year to see the shrines of democracy in the country's most historic square mile. Bicentennial salutes are scheduled almost daily, but one of the bestattended events will be on July 4, with President Ford heading the speakers in a noonday program outside Independence Hall. This will be followed by a sixhour parade with all 50 states participating. Another event, the International Eucharistic Congress, Aug. 18. sponsored by the Vatican and the Philadelphia Archdiocese, is expected to draw millions of Catholics from all over the world. Pope Paul has said he will be on hand if his health permits. A full year of major sports events includes the AllStar baseball game July 13 at Veterans Stadium. Broad and Pattison Avenue. For ticket information and prices call 215MU 61776. Ext. 8420.

title: True Grit: Rigors Of a Sinai Safari
description: ONE can tour the Israelioccupied Sinai Desert in airconditioned desert cars and sleep in hotels; it costs around $70 a day. Or, you can see the Sinai the way I didroughing it with the Neot Hakikar organization whose tour groups bump along the desert'tracks in vintage vehicles, clamber over. rock trails, and camp under the stars in sleeping bags. The fiveday In the Footsteps of Moses safari cost me $145, complete.

title: State's Farmers Find No Profit In 1975's Record Apple Crop
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Farmers in New York State grew more apples in 1975 than at any time in the last 50 years, but the result was a financial disaster for them, according to farm experts here and in the major fruitgrowing areas of the state.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Maybe there is good reason why there are a few months of respite from weeding, sowing, planting chores. They allow gardeners time to mull things over, plan, think through last year's mistakes and evolve new approaches for this year. But some gardeners out there have been dawdlers. Raise your handsHow many have mailed in their seed orders?

title: Per. Ellingsen to Wed Miss Pisani
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Pisani of Rumson, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Bernadette Pisani of New York, to Per E. Ellingsen of Oyster Bay, Li., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ellingsen of Oslo, Norway.

title: Jordan Experiences Influx of Western Technology
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 31When Jordan's armed forces put a recruiting commercial on television recently, they chose not to stress the charms of oldstyle desert warfarethe fierce cries, the windblown Arab headdress, the rifle fusillades.

title: Seoul Officials Say Strong U.S. Pressure Forced Cancellation of Plans to Purchase a French Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO. Jan. 31  South Korean officials have said that American pressures that bordered on threats led them to cancel plans to buy a French nuclear processing plant.

title: Lisa A.Lowdermilk Affianced To Philip Richard Toohey Jr.
description: Lisa Ann Lowdermilk and Philip Richard Toohey Jr. plan to be married March 7. Their engagement has been an,nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Wayne A. Lowdermilk of Englewood, Colo., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. George R. Harrah of Essex, Conn., and Mr. Toohey of New York and a grandson of Jack I. Straus, chairman of the executive committee and former chairman and president of R. H. Macy & Company Inc.

title: Senegal Bans Mass Media
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 31 (Agence FrancePresse)Senegal this week joined in France's official crusade against Franglais or Frenglism by banning the English expression mass media. It will be replaced by the word mediat President Leopold Senghor is a scholar of French.

title: Friday's Fights
description: Los Angeles  Andy Price, 145 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Rudy Barra, 145, Storkton, Calif., 10 rounds.

title: Expert Believes a Bomb Caused Airliner Crash in Saudi Arabia
description: LONDON, Jan. 31An expert on air sabotage who was called to the scene to help investigate the crash of a Middle East Airlines plane in Saudi Arabia on Jan. 1 said today it was a virtual certainty that the plane had been destroyed by a bomb.

title: Motherwell Aquatint Series Shown
description: HUNTINGTONOne of the finest art works produced by Robert Motherwell in his career and one of the finest of contemporary art is his A La Pintura, series of aquatints, which are on view at the Heckscher Museum through today.

title: EXPORTS OF ARMS DEBATED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31A public debate over export of Japanese military weapons has erupted within the governing establishment here.

title: How to Get Lost And Found
description: WHEN I was a student at St. Francis Xavier High School in New York during World War I, New Jersey, across a Hudson as yet untouched by bridge or tunnel, seemed a long way off. We had some students, not too many, who lived in Jersey, and we pitied them for the ferry ride they had to take morning and afternoon across the great watery divide.

title: Washington Report
description: EWARD J. PATTEN of New Jersey's 15th Congressional District is a liberal Democrat and a 14year veteran of the House of Representatives who scored 100 percent last year with the A.F.L.C.1.0.'s Committee on Political Education. This year, however, his constituents are moving toward the right. and so is he.

title: Beame's Tactics Are Making the Watchdogs Edgy
description: In assorted private placesthe Governor's office, City Hall warrens and a banker's salonthe component parts of New York City's altered fiscal machinery are operating, sometimes together, often apart.

title: Blown Figures
description: Blown Figures is the fifth book by this already accomplished writer of fiction, and to date, her most ambitious. In it Audrey Thomas approaches the height of her powers as a spinner of prose, a teller of surprising and engaging tales. With each of her books, the reader feels that the next will nut only be better but different in some unimaginable way. Blown Figures is unlike any of its predecessors in technique, at any rate.

title: Food
description: French chefs, over the years, have had a convenient device for naming dishes. It is the phrase a Ia mode, which means in the style of. Things called turquoise mean a Ia mode turquoise, or Turkish style; antiboise, in the style of Antibe; genoise, Genoa; and so on. It might be thought of as a way of getting off the hook. We take that tack on this page with a menu that might be called  la mode mexicaine, knowing full well that the dishes are not more authentically Mexican than El Paso. They are simply good dishes using some of the flavors and staples sometimes found ??? Mexican cooking.

title: Blink, and You've Missed the Movie
description: They are either abbreviated double features or extra long previews but whatever, they are Continental Airlines latest move in the industry's periodic game of amenities oneupmanship.

title: LETTERS To THE JERSEY EDITOR
description: Having read your new New Jersey section for the past two Sundays, I feel unequivocally qualified to comment. You capture nicely what I think life in New Jersey is all about: Many things, from bluebloods in Princeton to blue collars in Jersey City. Section 11 seems to care about bringing it all across.

title: At 73, Sir Lennox Berkeley Visits U.S.
description: Sir Lennox Berkeley, here for performances of a new composition this weekend, contemplated New York from the living room of his hotel suite overlooking Central Park and found it to his liking.

title: LETTERS
description: John J. O'Connor's column on Leonard Bernstein's televised Charles Eliot Norton lectures, Can Serious Music Be Visualized'? [Jan. 18j was a grave injustice. To [term] the lectures as superficial is absurd. These lectures have been those of an erudite, fertile mind, and the TV presentations by one who greatly loves music, art and philosophy. To respond to Mozart or a Beethoven in the manner of a Bernstein is highly commendable acid uppropriute.

title: New & Novel
description: Ron Kurz's bitter comedy is focused on the last picture show to play at a decaying innercity movie palace. The main event at the Black Rococo Theatre is the personal appearance of Lorenzo Jones, hero of a quickie blackexploitation film titled Superdude. The promotion succeeds so well that it causes a riot; more admissions are sold than even the vast hall can admit. In the ensuing disaster, mr. Rutz spins into orbit a galaxy of grotesque characters whose conduct ranges from fair to rotten. At the bottom of the scale is the concessionaire, a swine who padlocks the exits so that his customers cannot escape. At the top is Mr. Nice Guy, the young theater manager, who does his best to save lives. And in between are the greedy, the pathetic and the bestial, who comprise the exploiters and the exploited. A crackling social satire by the author of Lethal Gas.

title: Art Devoted to Helena Rubinstein: 13 Views of a Gosrnetic Empress
description: There are 13 Helena Rubinstein., hanging in a room at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Madame, as she was known to her family and staff, looking imperious in the large portrait by Graham Sutherland, dominates the room. In it she wears a Chinesered brocade dress by Balenclaga; her throat, ears and redtipped fingers are piled with some of her famous jewels.

title: City Is Seeking Compromise in Dispute Over a Proposed Complex in Rego Park
description: City officials sought last week ways to find a compromise in an increasingly polarized dispute between supporters and opponents of a proposed $150 million housing, commercial and garage complex at the junction of Queens Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway in Rego Park.

title: Wood It Burns
description: Will wood become an important fuel in this era of energy consciousness? Not likely, but one textile company in Alexander City, Ala., is converting its coalburning power plant to a woodburning facility.

title: New Books for DoItYourselfers
description: In answer to the increasingly growing demand for howto information about all phases of home repair and improvement, book publishers are continuing to issue a stream of new volumes which are designed to serve as a source of instruction and ideas for doityourselfers and wouldbe doityourselfers.

title: Miss CortsVergara Married to Editor
description: The marriage of Nhora Isabel CortesVergara to Harold Andrew Comerer took place yesterday afternoon in Shepherdstown, W. Va. The Rev. Cyril Draina performed the ceremony in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.

title: Cooper, 211, Leads Senior Golf by 2
description: ORLANDO. Fla. Jan. 31 (AP)Pete Cooper shot his second straight 71 today and increased his lead to 2 strokes, with 211, after three rounds of the Professional Golfers Association seniors hampionship.

title: Greece Reports Findings Of Many Valuable Relic.
description: ATHENS, Jan. 31 (AP)About 4,000 items of immense value dating hack to the sixth century B.C. have been discovered during diggIng in a cemetery outside Athens, the Government has announced.

title: Not a Minute To Spare
description: PEOPLE with a keen sense of timing rule the world, and then there are the rest of us. Well, not really, timing Means nothing to most people.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: DANES TIGHTEN UP ON PORNOGRAPHY
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 25Denmark is recoiling from its cheerful tolerance of pornography and salable sexuality, previously the greatest in Europe.

title: Americans are spending almost half a billion dollars a year on a drug to relieve their anxietya fact that is in itself considerable cause for anxiety.
description: The medicine most frequently prescribed today in the United Statesand probably in the worldis not, as might be expected, a hopeful remedy for some lifethreatening or fatal condition like cancer or heart disease or a crippler like arthritis. Instead, it is a white or pastelcolored tablet generally prescribed for an emotional state vaguely described as anxiety. It is Valium and, for its sole manufacturer, this pallid substance has yielded just about the richest harvest of profit of any single medicine in history.

title: Tombs Excavated on Crete
description: HERAKLEION, Crete, Jan. 31 (UPI)British archeologists have excavated eight ancient tombs near the site of the Minoan palace of Knossos, archeological sources report. They say the tombs were part of a cemetery used about 1,000 800 B.C.

title: CHARLES SCHNEIDER
description: Charles Schneider, a social science teacher in the Rye Neck High School, Mamaroneck, N.Y.; died Friday evening in the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital after neurosurgery. He was 52 years old and lived in Goldens Bridge, N.Y., and at 3000 Bronx Park East the Bronx.

title: Headliners
description: Eric C. Leek, a New Jersey hair stylist, has won the nation's richest lottery prize: $1,776 a week for life, with a guarantee of at least 20 years of payments ($1.8 million) for himself or his heirs. Praise the Lord. I hope I can help a lot of people! Mr. Leek said. He said he planned to use some of the money to build a youth center in North Arlington, N.J. Mr. Leek. 26 years old, was accompanied at the drawing by his fiancee, Mathilde Caldas. They had planned to be married in June, but the news of the money so overjoyed Miss Caldas that at one point she asked, Is there a priest in the house? Miss Caldas says she will probably quit her bookkeeper job; Mr. Leek is planning to pursue a career as a gospel singer.

title: The Bus As an Ego Trip
description: ONE spring day, rather than sit in my tidy, newly acquired Washington, D.C., apartment curled up with TV Guide, feeling very 57 and freshly divorced, I packed a gossamer suitcase, donned a navy blue dripdry pantsuit, pinned a sturdy daisy corsage on the lapel, locked the door and headed for the Greyhound bus station, where I purchased a 30day Ameripass and set out to see the worldthe part of the world, that is, served by Greyhound and connecting bus lines, which includes the United States and southern Canada.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Adolf Hitler was one of the first really great bad sports. His pioneer work was done at the Olympic Games of 1936 when he not only refused to congratulate America's unbeatable sprinter, Jesse Owens, on his victories, but also blatantly snubbed Owens, a black man, for making a hash of Hitlerian theory about Aryan supremacy.

title: Nadjari's Biblical References Are Used to Answer Critics
description: Comparing himself to his ancestors who labored morally and spiritually as condemned people in a condemned land. Maurice H. Nadjari used Biblical references yesterday to answer his critics.

title: ln Memoriam
description: GWIRTZMANIrving L. In cherished memory of you, beloved husband and father, who Passed away Jan. 28, 1966. Your wisdom. humor, love will never be forgotten. You are sadly missed.

title: Theater
description: celebration of American theater music with Patrice Molise, John Refill. ??? Grimes, Dick Shawn. Cyril Ritchard, Larry Kurt and Lillian Gish. Waller Kerr wrote that the play is exactly what you expect it to be. a collection of songs from here, there and All Wien, and added, As though by magic or ESP. the fact that the songs are going to be served up intact communicates Itself io the audience Instantly and at once calls a halt to an abominable practice that haunts most trips down Memory Lane. St. James.

title: Town Would Build Sunrise Extension
description: EAST HAMPTON  The state may have killed the proposed Sunrise Highway extension, but Eugene Haas, the new Supervisor of East Hampton, would like to resurrect the controversial bypassas a town road built, he hopes, with Suffolk Coun??? funds.

title: Poetry Readings
description: JOHN BALABAN and REG SANERDonmelt Library Cantor, 20 W. 53d St. Tues., 7:30. Free.

title: More Trouble for the Garment Trade
description: For the second time in four years, the women's garment industrya $32 billion industry nationwide and the largest private employer in New York Cityis under Federal investigation for alleged orice fixing.

title: Lisbon Defends Agrarian Reform Law
description: LISBON, Jan. 31The Portuguese Government defended its agrarian reform law today as a basic instrument for social justice but emphasized that measures were being taken to end deviations in its arplication.

title: Downstairs, Upstairs
description: WHEN I was a child, my parents and I lived downstairs in a large twofamily house on the east side of Passaic, and my mother's parents, Polish emigres, and her three sisters and four brothers lived upstairs. In the 40's, even as now, Passaic was rigidly divided into ethnic sections, and the woolen mills and the river were frontiers one did not casualty venture past. Only the most discontented could not find their needs met in the 10block area. Work, school, church, family friends  all were almost literally a touch away.

title: Olympics Create Problem for Pro Track
description: The Olympic year is generally a good one for track and field promoters. Fan interest in the sport is, naturally, at its height, and every major race takes on special significance. For the International Track Association, however, the Olympics represent a challenge. In the months ahead, the professional tour will have to sustain interest without being able to add many new athletes, since most amatours will want to preserve their eligibility for the Games. Afterward, the I.T.A. must lure enough of the new Olympic stars into turning pro to assure continued fan support in the postOlympic years.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Oliver Willams

title: Spain: Hope Postponed
description: Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro has disappointed the hopes for a rapid transition of Spain from the late Generalissimo Franco's authoritarian system to a modern Western European parliamentary democracy. The program for liberalization presented by Mr. Arias Parliament and country is so vague and so limited as to raise serious doubts among Spanish moderates that peaceful evolution to a freer society will be possible.

title: MAJOR ART WORKS GIVEN TO FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 31  The major pall of a large private art collection has been donated to the state.

title: Linton Wells, Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 82
description: Linton Wells, a foreign correspondent who circled the world a dozen times in the 1920's and 30's in pursuit of wars, revolutions and adventure stories, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 82 years old.

title: Lefrak City Crucible Of Racial Change
description: For the 20,000 mostly middleclass residents of Lefrak City, a highrise Queens rental community that has recently swung from largely white to largely black, the experience of sudden racial change has not been an easy one.

title: 7 KILLED IN BEIRUT IN RAID ON PAPERS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, (Sunday), Feb. 1Gunmen of the Syrian financed As Saiqa organization reportedly attacked hte offices of two leftists newspapers in western Beirut last night, killing seven people and wounding several others.

title: Egypt Reports It Has Cut Military Debt to Moscow
description: CAIRO. Jan. 31 (Reuters)Egypt has repaid a considerable part of its military debts to the Soviet Union, according to Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayMidIsland K.C. allbreed and obedience match, Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I.; entries from 8:30 A.M.; judging 11:30.

title: Laura Merriam Sets Spring Bridal
description: Mr. and Mn.s William R. Merriam of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Elizabeth Merriam, to Paul Burgess Fay 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fay Jr. of San Francisco. A spring wedding is planed.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARYA MAN (Arra). Kuwait March 17; sails from Ft. Wolcott St., Brooklyn.

title: SLAVERY REPORTED AMONG REFUGEES
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Jan. 31A Marine Corps gen. eral has reported that slave children, hidden weapons and unsanitary habits existed among the more than 50,000 Southeast Asian refugees cared for here last year before their American resettlement.

title: Card Of Thanks
description: ZUKERMANDebra. The Zukerrhen Family and the Abrams Family of L. I. sincerely thank their friends and relatives for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: PEOPLE
description: THE HERO of a book on Harper & Row's midsummer agenda is Burt Ross, the former Mayor of Fort Lee and now director of the state's Energy Office. The Bribe chronicles how Mayor Ross gave court testimony in 1974 that helped convict six men in alleged bribe scheme.

title: Lake Mohawk Lures Fliers Seeking Peace
description: Pilots Quiet HeavenIT is nudging toward sunset, but to Capt. Kingsley Purton Jr., flying at 4.000 feet in a United Airlines 707 Jet, the day is really just dawning.

title: Fashion
description: Some of the best places to shop for clothes geared to sunny climes are the boutiques with foreign accents. These shops carry imports from Europe, Asia and Latin America, some of which are designed and made specially for the shop, so the wearer can feel in step with fashion but not stamped out of a cooky cutter.

title: Immaculata Beats Queens Five, 6950
description: MALVERNE, Pa. Jan. 31 In a game matching two nationally ranked women's basketball teams. Immaculate routed Queens College, 6950, today.

title: Gurney's Inn Loses Bid for Health Spa Funding
description: HAUPPAUGEA loophole in the state law that permits taxfree financing to expand local industries will prevent Gurney's Inn in Montauk from funding its $1.3 million health spa under New York's Industrial Development Act.

title: TV VIEW
description: Norman Lear's Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman is not, as was claimed in a recent edition of The Village Voice, better than Ingmar Bergman's Scenes from a Marriagealthough such promiscuous analogizing has a certain panting charm, as if one were to compare Dennis the Menace with Martin Luther King, or Ralph Ginsberg with Sacco and Vanzetti, or Marion Javits with Catherine the Great. (For a week there, in fact, it was difficult for us newcomers to Channel 5, switching the dial anxiously at 11 o'clock at night, to distinguish this freeform soaper from the continuing saga of Mrs. Javits, the Shah of Iran and pillowtalk in the Senate cloakroom. I am a woman emerging in my own right sounded like something Mary Hartman might say. This is because if anything has been said, Mary Hartman is likely to say it again.)

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE annual report of the President's Council of Economic Advisers last Monday opened with a declaration that the country is now recovering from the most severe recession in postwar history'.

title: Congressional Firmness Thwarts the Grand Design
description: WASHINGTONThe Administration is playing the only cards it has in the game over Angola, much as it did in the closing days of the war in Vietnam.

title: Columbia Bows In 2 Overtimes
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 31  The Brown University basketball team snapped a ninegame losing streak tonight by defeating Columbia, 6968, in double overtime in an Ivy League game in Marvel Gym.

title: BiState Met Hockey
description: BiState Met Hockey

title: WALLACE ISOLATED BY TIGHT SECURITY
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31At first glance, it seems just like the old days.

title: The Economic Plan Is Fixed
description: WASHINGTONWith the annual flood of words and figures that appear in and accomnemy the President's budget and economic report now out of the way, what meaning can be derived from it all?

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Let me offer three thoughts, with a few elaborations, on New York City Ballet. The first thought concerns the new strength of the company's male dancers, the second is about the continuing impact of Jerome Robbins upon the company's repertory, and the third and last is not so much a thought as a paean of praise to George Balanchine's new ballet, Chaccone.

title: Joan Escherich Plans A Wedding in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Escherich of Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Escherich, to Mark Jeffrey Welshimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Welshimer of Canton. Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title: Rozelle Policies Seen Safe Despite Rosenbloom Barbs
description: The National Football League, with all its troubles, has another one it doesn't need. One of its foremost owners, Carroll Rosenbloom of the Los Angeles Rams, is sniping at Coramissioner Pete Rozelle, who previously had been sacrosanct. It is difficult to determine the motives behind the criticism by Rosenbloom, who can be devious, but he is angry.

title: Linda J. Martin, Charles G. Cole Set June Bridal
description: Linda Jane Martin and Charles Glaston Cole, who are in their final year at the Harvard Law School, will be married in Cincinnati in June.

title: The Syrians Have the Best Chance of Solving the Puzzle
description: BEIRUTMoslem refugees move into luxury apartments and seaside cabanas vacated by the upper, Christian and Moslem middle classes. The seaside villa of the Christian Interior Minister is stormed and burned. A dissident Moslem lieutenant deserts with armored vehicles and a small following and proclaims himself leader of something called the Lebanese Arab Army.

title: Seton Hall's 2 Early Bursts Help Sink Manhattan, 9381
description: Snapping an irritating string of nine straight losses to Manhattan over the last eight college basketball seasons, the Pirates of Seton Hall finally topped the Jaspers yesterday, 9381, in the final of the second Madison Square Garden Classic.

title: The Brilliant, Brooding Films of Rainer Fassbinder
description: Lots of people are capable of turning out movies cheaply and quickly, but a fastworking movie artist is rare. One thinks of Chaplin, Keaton and Ford in their early years, and of such contemporary figures as Godard and Chabrol. Currently, the leading example of filmartistontherun is the amazingly productive 30yearold West German screenwriter, director and actor, Rainer Werner Fassbinder.

title: Summoning of Jurors by Phone Is Approved in Monroe County
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 31 For the last year, Monroe County has experimented with a system that allows persons called for jury duty to go to work or stay home as long as they leave a number where they can be reached if needed.

title: Dutchess Sheriff to Face a U.S. Hearing
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 31A Federal Court judge will travel to Poughkeepsie Monday to begin hearings on a motion that the Dutchess County sheriff be held in contempt for not complying with a 1973 court order to improve conditions in the county jail.

title: Memorial Services
description: BISERDavid I. Friends and colleagues of Dr. David I. Elise:, who died on Dec. 28, 1975, are invited to a memorial service at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, CrotomomHudson, Sunday, Feb. 1, at 2 P.M.

title: Renee Josephine Allard Bride Of Francis Betts 3d, Consultant
description: The First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Renee Josephine Allard, daughter of Lillian McNair Allard of Philadelphia, and the late Rene Joseph Allard, to Francis Marion Betts 3d, son of Mrs. Betts Jr. of East Aurora, N.Y., and the late Mr. Betts.

title: How can we sell the Protestant ethic at a psychedelic bazaar?
description: Daniel Bell has a fine ear for titles. To publish in 1960 The End of Ideology and in 1976 The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism is in its own way remarkably sensitive. During the 1950's it was widely believed that all reasonable men had come out on the far side of ideology, which in context usually meant socialist theory. Today the phrases, if not the substance, of socialist theory are the points around which much contemporary argument turns. Bell, a professor of sociology at Harvard, is an influential political and cultural thinker, and we might pause to consider whether these book titles are examples of what he himself calls Tendenz vending: the promotion of intellectual fashions, within what he calls cultural mass production.

title: HEART AILMENTS RECEIVE PRIORITY
description: Red, white and blue signs saying Emergency Heart Care Station went up last week outside the emergency rooms of nine New York City hospitals that have agreed to give priority care to people with chest pains and are possibly having a heart attack, When a patient comes in with a chest pain, that's ithe has a passport right in for treatment, said Dr. Joseph Schluger in announcing the new program at a news conference at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: HicksvilleCommedia, based on the Commedia dell Arte, the old Italian street theater, presented by the Panto Puppets, today, 1 P.M., Nathan's Famous, 1401 MidIsland Shopping Center. Free.

title: 31 Right Mind Scores as Foul Claim Is Denied

title: Democrats Rated Over G.O. P. On Inflation and Jobs in Poll
description: Twice as many Americans believe that the Democratic Party is better able to deal with what they regard as the nation's biggest problemsthe high cost of living and unemploymentthan is the Republican Party, according to the Gallup Poll. A survey of 1,572 adults around the country indicated that 40 percent of the public thought that the Democratic Party could do a better job in handling the two problems.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Let the N.B.A. Players Vote

title: World of Our Fathers
description: The first generation tries to retain as much as possible. the second to forget, the third to remember. Little wonder that the outcropping of AmericanJewish writing in the past 30 years is so often a literature of memory. an attempt to recover the world of childhood and adolescence as the last place the trail of Jewish identity was seen before it faded into the lawns of suburbia and the bright corridors of the professions. Why this interest, though? Why not stick to the present, as my father would say. The farther hack you go. the miserable it gets.

title: Dunlop Back at Harvard And Full of Enthusiasm
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 31After 32O days as Secretary of Labor, John T. Dunlop went home to the academic world at Harvard University today. resentful that electionyear politics had fored him to quit but full of enthusiasm and plans for new undertakings. Dunlop Back at Harvard And Full of Enthusiasm

title: TV VIEW
description: The pictures were familiar, depressingly familiar. White Americans, their faces twisted with bitterness and hatred, were screaming almost hysterical insults at black Americans. In the 60's, similar pictures were perhaps most prevalent in the South. More recently, the prime sources have shifted to the North, to places like South Boston. These particular pictures were recorded, by producer Richard Kotuk, in New York City's Rosedale, a workingclass community of 6,000 families in the borough of Queens. The documentary (shown on WNET/13 two Sundays ago at 8 P.M.) was called Rosedale: The Way It Is and marked the beginning of a new season for Bill Moyers Journal on public television.

title: For children
description: For children

title: Reynard
description: You hear the yelping in the night and you know the foxes are out. Then you hear the finespun yapping answer and you know they are looking for mates. They wouldn't pass up a grouse or a rabbit if it happened to be in their path; but grouse and rabbits are yearround, and the fox's mating season is brief. So the dog fox yelps and the vixen yelps her answer, and soon after midMarch the pups are born.

title: ERNEST WHITLOCK, ENGINEER, IS DEAD
description: Ernest W. Whitlock, a leading water engineer, died Thursday in Hackensack (N. J.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 1405 River Road, West Englewood. N. J.

title: MOSCOW EXPANDS AID TO VIETNAMESE
description: MOSCOW. Jan. 31The Soviet Union is believed to have increaged its economic aid to North Vietnam in recent months as part of a process in which MoscowHanoi relations have been strengthened at the expense of Chinese relations with Hanoi.

description: Frances Rose Curran, past president of the Visiting Nurse Associations of Brooklyn and of Cambridge, Mass., died yes terday in Boston. She was 77 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Britain vs. Iceland
description: LONDONA few years ago an African diplomat at the Court of St. James's was rash enough to liken his hosts to a toothless bulldog. Words were exchanged at the highest level and the offender was sent packing by his government back to the tropics. It is a shame, for had he been in Britain these last two months he could have witnessed, along with millions of other British television viewers, some touching scenes of gumbaring.

title: Columbia Students Will Operate A Nonprofit Grocery on Campus

title: Whither the Democratic Party?
description: DENVER  Arnold Toynbee observed shortly before his death that history showed that the same traits that made nations great eventually led to their downfall. I would propose a corollary to the thesis: The same traits that built the Democratic Party, if followed blindly, could lead to its downfall or, at least, to serious setback at the polls.

title: Judge Rebuts Wallace Attack; Cites Bad Conditions at Prisons

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Not long ago I reviewed a new piece of music and wrote something to the effect that the composition did not have much in the way of idea. Now comes a letter from the composer asking for something in the way of definition:

title: In Truth, Travel Is Not Broadening
description: As traveler and trencherman, I was a prisoner of the conventional wisdom that tourists are doomed to put on pound after inevitable pound. But as physician, I began to have my doubts & and after several months of investigation, they have been confirmed. The evidence suggests that the vast majority of vacationerswhether they count their calories or notgain little or no weight during trips, cruises or stays at resort hotels. The major reason: They leave behind four big bugaboos of dieters: (1) boredom, (2) dayto, day frustrations, (3) television sets, (4) refrigerators.

title: J51 a Way to have Failing Properties
description: A littlenoticed change in the city's J51 tax abatement program that took effect last month has sparked investor interest in converting loft buildings, office buildings, and vacant hotels like the Royal Manhattan into apartment houses.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: KATIEKatharine Hepburn is returning to Broadway after an absence of nearly seven years. (In 1969, she played the fashion designer Chanel in the musical Coco.) This time, she takes the role of a vibrant older woman who is visited in her English country home by her cherished grandson, his two friends and their lovers. The play, which opens Tuesday, is the latest effort by Britain's Enid Bagnold, best known for The Chalk Garden. Miss Bagnold is a vibrant 85.

A grant of $25,000 from the National Endowment for the Arts will allow George Wein, who is both the director of the Jazz Repertory Company and producer of the Newport Festival, to produce four concerts covering the early work of Duke Ellington as part of the Festival.

title: Liberal from Goldwater Country

There he sits, with a 100 percent rating from the A.F.L.C.1.O. and 82 percent from Americans for Democratic Action, racking up victory margins of up to 70 percent. When conservative Arizona Republicans (if that's not a redundancy) are asked why they vote both for Udall and Goldwater, they reply, Because they're honest.

During the last 12 months it has shown tremendous growth. We processed and approved an average of 75 applications a month last year, said Patricia Elmore, the membership chairman, and now have 1,400 on the rolls. At the start of 1975 we had five chapters. Now there are eight and applications for another five.

title: The Puritan Origins of The American Self
description: In what fundamental ways, if any, is American life unique? Although it has been the subject of serious inquiry for some two centuries, the question still dominates scholarship in American studies. Of course, no one doubts that our culture and society differ from their AngloEuropean prototypes, but few scholars agree about the extent or the character of those differences. Are they basic or superficial? Are they structural or largely attitudinal? Do they inhere in our institutions or do they merely reflect, on the plane of manners, style or ethos, the special but transitory circumstances surrounding the nation's origins?

title: THE MISSING MIDDLE
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.For ambitious high school students, Brown University has quietly become one of the most popular schools in the country. It is fourth in the Ivy League pecking order, as they say in the admissions office, which means that it loses students consistently only to Harvard, Yale and Princeton. And it's not uncommon now for students to choose Brown over one of those schools, or over such nonIvy institutions as Williams or M.I.T. For years, Brown was one of the least exclusive of the Eastern private schools. We used to be the doormat of the Ivy League, Brown's admissions director, James Rogers, remarked recently. He spoke cheerfully, because all that has changed.

title: The Edge
description: Go on, suspend disbelief. Just for a minute, pretend that The Edge is the work of an implausibly handsome, crinklyeyed unknown first novelist named, oh, John V. Lindsay. Long fascinated by politics and the passing strangeness of its bedfellows, Mr. Lindsay has chosen to set his insights on some big but barely moving targets: the awesome power of power, for instance. Also lawnorder vs. certain inalienable rights. And private affairs vs. public imagery. Sound promising? Campaign promising? Well, it's an election year. And, as another unknown first novelistSpiro somethingonce put it, one goes the fiction route because one can't bear to write anything serious about politics at this point in time.

He said that government geologists had so far found deposits of nearly 8 million tons of uranium, thorium and other raw materials for nuclear fuel.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP

title: ART VIEW
description: The fate of drawing in recent art is not a subject easily encompassed. No other branch of the visual arts has lately been as radically redefined as this one, which even in the heyday of earlier avantgarde innovations managed to retain a certain fixed identity. So comprehensive, indeed, is this redefinition of the art of drawing that it is probably an illusion to think it can any longer be usefully defined at all. To speak of a drawing in 1976 is to speak of a void that can be filled, or not filled, by almost any conceivable process of making a visible mark an an existing surface. By the standards that now prevail, the receipt handed to you at the supermarket checkout if corrected by the cashier's hand, is no less a drawing than a pencil portrait by Ingres; the sheet on which I type these words, making handwritten amendments and additions as I go, is no less a drawing than one of the masterworks of Hokusai. We are now adrift in a medium deprived of significant boundaries.

title: U.S. Olympic Six Ready To Play European Style
