title: Berman A Legend Arrives from Russia
description: From the national magazines in New York and from the larger cities of the midwest the music critics came, two weeks ago last Wednesday, to an allpurpose gymnasiumauditorium at Miami University of Ohio, to hear the American debut of the legendary Lazar Berman. The following Saturday, the 45yearold debutant pianist blew in and out of New York to play the Tchaikovsky First Concerto with Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic. (The critics were impressed; writing in The Times, Harold C. Schonberg declared there never was a doubt that a master technician was at the keyboard.) This week and next Berman will make three appearances in this city, recitals tomorrow night and Feb. 9 in the rembodelled Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92nd Street YMHA, Thursday with Henry Lewis and the beleaguered New Jersey Symphony all Carnegie Hall.

title: The Olympic Sports: What They're All About
description: This is racing against the cloth in three eventsdownhill, slalom and giant slalom. The downhill involves highspeed racing of 1 to 2 miles down slopes. The giant slalom is somewhat the same as the downhill except that courses are shorter and there are gates through which the racers must pass. In the slalom, the gates are more closely spaced and more numerous than in the giant slalom.

Sher, ??? who developed a cure for skin Cancer using Thorium X. lie also founded the Kings Highway Medical Group and served as Medical Director until his death Dr. Harris, en alumnus of Western Reserve University, earned his PhD In Organic Chemistry from Yale University. He received furls Doctor from St. Louis Law School and was admitted to the Missouri: Bar. He is Director of the New York City Crime Lab. title: The Auctioneer
description: For generations, John Moore's family has farmed and lived upon the sort of land in Harlowe, N. H., urban folk dream about: open pastures ringed by virgin pine: clear water ponds to swim in during summer, ice skate upon at winter: stone walls held together by a sinewy net of Concord grape vines; a tidy, white 19thcentury farmhouse atop a rolling hill, a barn filled with a century of discarded Americanaobjects city people, eager for o'dtime sentiments and values. buy at weekend auctions to turn into planters and lamps or to hang upon their walls. Therefore when Bobby Gore, Harlowe's lone sheriff drops by one spring Thursday to ask John Moore if he has anything to contribute to a coming policeman's benefit auction, Moore's only question is, What do you need an auction for?

title: Sheila Doherty Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adrian W. Doherty of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Marie Doherty, to William E. Marfuggi Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marfuggi of Bernardsville, N.J. A May wedding is planned. Miss Doherty, is a fashion coordinator with Klopman Mills, a division of Burington Industries. Her fiance is a student at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Advertising
description: Over at Doyle Dane Bernbach the folks are happiest when they're advertising product that's as good as gold. Now they're advertising gold itself, and in the next couple of weeks they'll be finding out for sure whether advertising can really sell it. Early indications are that it can.

title: Hundreds Arrested in an Indian State After Takeover
description: MADRAS, India, Feb. 1 (AP) The Indian Government today arrested hundreds of members of a regional political party opposed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi after a federal takeover of the administration of the state of Tamil Nadu.

title: The Times Issues a New Manual of Style
description: A discernible trend in written and spoken language over the last decade has been toward casual use of what were once generally regarded by the public as offensive vulgarities, obscenities and slang. Novels now abound in such words and phrases; they have become the common coin of movies, and some of them have been smuggled into television and radio programs.

title: SUIT ON POISONING BY MERCURY IS SET
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. Feb. 1Hearings are scheduled to open here tomorrow in a $3.6 million suit against three companies charged with negligence that allegedly caused four members of an Alamogordo family to be stricken with mercury poisoning, resulting in severe brain and muscular damage and damage to the eyes.

title: The New School Law
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1 New Jersey's new public school law, upheld last Friday by the State Supreme Court, may cost nearly $1 billion to put into effect, but it will not in itself provide a school system that will offer piano lessons to Newark's blacks or to children in Jersey City's Puerto Rican wards. What the law does is order the state's 607 independent school districts to turn out students who are able to read, write and do simple arithmetic, and it directs the state government to pay much of the cost in the poor school districts.

title: Pathologist Found That Liver Could Control Pernicious Anemia
description: Dr. George Hoyt Whipple, cowinner in 1934 of the Nobel Prize in medicine, died yesterday in Strong Memorial Hospital of the University of Rochester. He was 97 years old.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS VOTE TO WALK OUT
description: Members of the Newark Teachers Union voted overwhelmingly late yesterday to strike this morning, but school authorities said they would keep the schools open with supervisory personnel and teachers who crossed the picket lines.

title: Announcer, 101, Takes Coast Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI)  Announcer, lightly regarded, rart the best race of his career today, moving between horses to capture the $55,300 San Marcos Handicap over Santa Anita's turf course. Zanthe was second, a halflength behind, and Top Crowd third. Announcer equaled the race record of 1:58 25 for the 1 miles set by Round Table in 1959. Sent off at odds of 101 by the crowd of more than 38,000, Announcer paid $22 for $2 and earned $32,800 for the Elmendorf Farm of Maxwell Gluck in scoring his first victory of 1976. Last year the son of Verbatim won five of 19 races.

title: Farce Or Tragedy
description: WASHINGTON  When the House of Representatives voted the other night to have its committee's report on executive branch intelligence abuses censored by the Executive, I was reminded of a mocking English verse about journalists. Suitably adapted, it would go like this:

title: Little Beebe's ClaimBox Caper
description: A fugitive from the claiming races named Right Mind won the Stymie Handicap at Aqueduct Saturday, and there was a nice touch of poetic justice in that, for Stymie himself started life as a selling plater. The late Hirsch Jacobs claimed Stymie for $1,500 out of the third race of his life and gave other owners 10 chances to claim him away before the colt began to show his real class. In the next few years, this showy chestnut with his white blaze and flowing mane, his majestic carriage and consuming stretch run, became the darling of New York fans and the richest animal in history. His bankroll of $918,485 was an alltime high until of the first millionaire, Citation, topped his record. As any horseplayer knows, the claiming race is an effective device for classifying horses according to their ability. Conditions for the race specify the claiming priceit can be anywhere from $1,200 to $50,000and by entering his horse the owner offers it for sale at that price. If he slips a good horse into a cheap race to win a bet, he risks losing him. If he enters the horse over his head, he stands little chance of winning. Any owner racing at the meeting may drop a claim in the box before the race. If several enter claims for the same horse they draw lots and the winner gets the horse whether it be alive or dead, sound unsound, or injured before or during the race or after it.

title: News Summary and Index

title: HANOI SAYS NIXON PLEDGED 3 BILLION AS POSTWAR AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1North Vietnamese leaders recently told several visiting members of Congress that former President Nixon sent them a memorandum early in January 1973 that they said promised $3.25 billion in American aid after the signing of the Paris agreement to end the war in Vietnam.

title: ArabControlled Detroit Bank Seeks F.D.I.C. Aid to Stem Loss
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1A year ago a Saudi Arabian businessman, Ghaith Pharaon, bought a controlling interest in Detroit's billiondollar Bank of the Commonwealth. There were predictions that he would use the financially troubled bank to funnel Arab oil money into Middle West businesses.

title: Books of The Times
description: Last semester, a student in one of my classes said to me, You know, you read too many good books. You're out of touch. You could lose your humanity. It's a thought. I may be living in an ivory tower without knowing it. Perhaps I ought to read some books that are not so good, find out what is happening out there in limbo.

title: Democrats in Bay State Seek to Lure Humphrey
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1Efforts to draw Senator Hubert H. Humphrey into the Presidential race are bubbling up among some restless Democratic Party veterans in Massachusetts. And in Washington, the Congressbased draftHumphrey committee, as a result of the Supreme Court's ruling Friday, feels liberated to raise and spend money on just such selfstarting, formally unauthorized Humphrey campaigns as the one here.

description: Dr. Claus W. Jungeblut, former professor of bacteriology at Columbia University, who was well known for his research in infantile paralysis, died yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 78 years old.

description: Maritime Fruit Carriers Group, a large merchant shipping company, announced yesterday the replacement of its two top officials, negotiations to refinance its debts, and plans to move its headquarters from Israel.

title: Krause, Baritone, in Superior Recital
description: A superior vocal recital was given at Kaufmann Concert Hall on Saturday night by Toni Krause, the Finnish baritone, who limited his program to songs, by Schubert, Brahms and Ravel. With Irwin Gage, one of the best of all accompanists, at the piano, Mr. Krause offered Schubert's Des Schwanengesang and three songs to Schiller poems before intermission and six Brahms songs and Ravel's Don Quichotte a Dulcinee after it.

For whatever reason, young people in their 20's and 30's are showing less interest in the stock market than the young people of a few years ago did. And this attitude has persisted despite the recent market surge.

Yunich, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, by some members of the board and at least one state official could be a prelude to a fullscale effort to oust the former departmentstore executive from his $80,000 a year post, according to M.T.A. and Carey administration aides.

New Jersey Briefs

description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1Anyone doubting Jimmy Connors's claim of being the best tennis player in the world didn't see him devastate Bjorn Borg, the 19yearold Swedish star, this afternoon. Proving there was still a respectable distance between his No. 1 world ranking by the Association of Tennis Professionals and Borg's No. 3, Connors beat him, 76, 64, 60, for the singles title at the United States pro indoor championships.

ODD DANCES GIVEN BY VARNEY AND WITT

The desires were no doubt honorable, but the dances were collections of exhausted gestures without any fresh inspiration.

However, in hopes of proving that American radio can again provide sterling dramatic productions, Edward Albee, the playwright, has written and directed an 80minute drama called Listening.

But Andre Watts divided his recital program between the two composers yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, and found legitimate similarities as well as some illegitimate ones. Mr. Watts appeared in the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series for the ninth year in succession, and packed the hall, as usual.

description: Over the next 30 months New York City will have to abandon what is perhaps its, most treasured boastits big nessand, more importantly, will have to admit to itself that it is a city that can no longer grow.

title: Article 2  No Title
. . . Mutual Restraint
description: The United States, in turn, has offered to accept a major constraint on deployment of airlaunched cruise missiles in return for Soviet agreement to a range of 1,500 rather than 375 miles. For each bomber equipped with strategic cruise missiles, each side would have to give up one of the 1,320 MIRV multiple warhead ballistic missiles, such as Minuteman III and Poseidon, to which it is entitled under the Vladivostok agreementa heavy price. As a result, as few as 100 B52's may be so equippeda total of 1,200 to 2,000 cruise missiles, instead of the 11,000 the United States Air Force has indicated it might deploy if unlimited. And the substitution of subsonic, secondstrike cruise missiles for firststrike ballistic missiles would add stability to the strategic balance.

description: WASHINGTONIsrael's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, came to America with more than a plea for the restoretion of aid cuts. He came with specific ideas to blunt the SovietSyrianP.L.O. diplomatic offensive.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Division of Human Rights has ordered District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees to reinstate one of its employees who complained that she was barred from returning to her job as a union organizer after recovering from a serious spinal injury last May 20. The organizer, Shirlee Evans, charged that she had been told she could not go about her duties with a cane unless she consulted a physician first, according to the state division. She filed a complaint instead, the division said, resulting in the reinstatement order with back pay at 6 per cent interest. The union said it was appealing the decision in the courts.

title: Bache and Smith, Barney Involved in Name Changes
description: Two leading Wall Street brokerage houses are opening for business today under new but still familiarnames.

title: F. MILTON WIEGMAN
description: F. Milton Wiegman, who retired four years ago as a vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Friday in Stuart, Fla. His age was 70. He had been with the bank for 40 years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: St. Johns Turns Back Army
description: An aggressive Army basketball team just wouldn't give up against St. John's yesterday. So the highly favored Redmen had to go into overtime before finally beating Army, 8775, before 5,445 persons at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Chinese Are Hailed in Wyoming
Texas and Louisiana Race To Get Supertanker Port
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1The race betiveen Texas and Louisiana to build the nation's first socalled super port has rounded the first turn, but industry investors say it will be 1980 at, the earliest before the proposed ports will be able to unload their first oil supertankers.

title: City Beats Lehman, 6650
description: City College won its first game from Lehman in three years when it beat the Lancers, 6650, yesterday. The game, played at the Lancers court in the Bronx, matched the finalists in last year's City University of New York tournament, won by Lehman.

title: HANOI SAYS NIXON PLEDGED 3 B1LUON AS POSTWAR AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 North Vietnamese leaders recently told several visiting members of Congress that former President Nixon sent them a memorandum early in January 1973 that they said promised $3.25 billion in American aid after the signing of the Paris agreement to end the war in Vietnam.

title: Fire Kills 2 and Burns 7 In Ohio Sport Goods Shop
description: NORTH KINGSVILLE, Ohio, Feb. 1 (AP)Two persons were killed and seven were burned critically by a series of explosions and a fire yesterday that leveled a sporting goods store in this Lake Erie community, the authorities reported,

title: Oregon Track Meet Summaries
description: TRACK EVENTS

title: Distress Signal
description: The report on the state of black America released last week by the National Urban League is a profoundly depressing document. Beyond the statistics it contains gloomy enough by themselvesthe report dramatizes a substantial failure of political leadership.

title: STRIKES PERSIST AT PAPER MILLS
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 1If the newspaper seems thinner and a little grayer these days, it could be partly for the reasons that have plunged an obscure town in northern Ontario into the worst economic conditions since the Depression of the 1930's.

title: SALT Breakthrough ...
description: A break in the deadlock in the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT II), which now appears possible as a result of the BrezhnevKissinger discussions in Moscow, would be good news for world peace. But equally important is the way the deadlock evidently is being broken.

title: SOVIET DECLARES KISSINGER TWISTS ITS ANGOLA POLICY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1  Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, in a rare personal attack on Secretary of State. Henry A. Kissinger, today accused him of using untenable logic, offering untruths and defending concoctions in his recent statements to Congress about Soviet policy in Angola.

title: BERTRAM BRUMMER OF SALOMON BROS.
description: Bertram F. Brummer, a partner in Salomon Brothers, died Saturday at University Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here and in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: The Search for an Adjective That Will Cure Discrimination
description: BOSTONIn the event that some of the impoverished millions in the United States have begun to be concerned about, who will carry on the research projects of the universities and Federal Government after the socalled academic experts have passed on, it will come as good news that the public schools are busily at work in turning out another generation of selfserving experts in the art of Needless Knowledge and Inert Ideas.

title: Philadelphia Police Face Aid Loss in Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Philadelphia Police Department is in danger of losing thousands of dollars of Federal assistance because of discrimination. against women, a Federal agend cy confirmed yesterday.

title: Influence Peddling Is Hinted in U.S. Job Referrals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The General Services Administration released today a list of 311 Congressmen and members of the executive branch who made job referrals to the agency, many of which are believed by investigators to have been result of influence peddling in the Nixon Administration.

title: Campus Minorities Group
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Leaders of Murmansk Say Port's Lusty Life Fosters True Collective Spirit
Bridge:
description: Doubling the opponents in a game or a slam they expect to make is usually a sucker's action. There may be something to recommend such a double, however, if it is clear that the declaring side is at full stretch and that the declarer will have to cope with perverse distribution.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1976

title: WALPOLE, N.H., BARS PLANNED PULP MILL
description: WALPOLE, N.H., Feb. 1  Residents of this quiet, rural village on the Connecticut River rejected this weekend a plan to build a giant $200 million paper pulp mill on 600 acres of the town's best farmland.

title: Medicare Wastes Millions By Renting Medical Aids
description: Because of a loophole in the law, millions of dollars in public funds are being spent needlessly for renting, medical equipment for sick and disabled beneficiaries of the Medicare program for the elderly.

title: RUMSFELD POLICY KEYED TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the United States should spend enough on defense to keep a rough equivalence with the Soviet Union, but that that did not mean spending a new dollar every time Moscow did.

title: 5 Children Die in Fire
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 1 (UPI)Five children from two families died last night in a fire in a house on the East Side while their parents attended a party. The victims were identified as Ricky Alexander, II years old; Danyell Alexander, 2; Robert Alexander, 9; Carie Lynn Turner, 5; and Alonzo Lamar Turner, 4. The children were staying with the Alexander children's grandparents.

title: Personal Finance: PreRefund Bonds
description: The combined advantages of a fixedincome security and exemption from Federal income taxes have made municipal bonds more attractive to the public in recent years. As a result, various segments of the taxexempt market that had been virtually restricted to dealing with professionals have started to attract a wider audience.

title: Light Trucks Sales Expand
Environmentalists Celebrating 2 Victories in Struggle to Clean Lake Michigan.
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1Protectors of the environment, especially those groups fighting to clean up Lake Michigan, are celebrating two victories.

title: Cerebral Palsy Telethon Gets $2.5 Million Pledges
description: The 25th annual United Cerebral Palsy weekend telethon produced $2,571,038 in telephoned pledges, according to officials of the fundraising appeal, which was seen here over WORTV from 10:30 P.M. Saturday to 7 last night.

title: HAROLD F. HALL
description: Harold F. Hall, a specialist in magazine circulation, president of the Catholic Library Guild Inc. and proprietor of Hall's House of Gifts in White Plains, died of cancer yesterday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Home Construction Costs At Record $28,970 in '75
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1It cost an average of $28,970, a record high, to construct a singlefamily home in New Jersey last year, according to official statewide buildingpermit records. However, actual costs to the buyers of new houses were far higher after the inclusion of lot prices and the developer's markup.

title: Brooklyn's King Dominates Vols Victory
description: The leadership in Southeastern Conference basketball belongs to Tennessee and the bragging rights are held by Bernard King.

title: Picasso Theft Valued at $4.5 Million
description: PARIS, Feb. 1A tentative value of $4.5 million was placed today Qn 119 Picassos stolen last night from the Palace of the Popes at Avignon, in southern France. The police said it was perhaps the biggest art theft of its kind in French history.

title: RESEARCH DEAL SET BY COLIN, HOCHSTIN
description: Justin S. Colin and Roger J. Hochstin  partners in a Wall Street firm, the Colin, Hochstin Company  have invested an undisclosed amount of capital in the researchoriented firm of Alliance One Institutional Services. Alliance said yesterday.

title: City Resisting as P.BA.. Seeks to Buy Landmark
description: If Samuel De Milia, second vice president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has his way, the imposing statue  adorned, marble  hailed Surrogate Court building in downtown Manhattan's Civic Center will be taken over by the P.B.A. to use as offices, a police museum and, in the basement, an 80car parking garage.

title: Crenshaw Wins Second in a Row
Williwaw Is First in 100Mile Sail
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 1The 1976 Southern Ocean Racing Conference's opening, race of the year, the 100mile Anclote Key event, was won today by Williwaw, a Division II, Class II, boat designed by Doug Peterson and sailed by Lowell North. Williwaw turned in the lowest corrected time of the 78 boat fleet  13.9962 decimal hours.

title: Concertos by Queens Chamber Group
description: Since it is usually impossible to pry Manhattanites loose to partake of the musical enrichment Queens has to offer, the Queens Symphony Chamber Orchestra has been spending one Sunday a month displaying its tonal wares at the New York Shakespeare Festival Theater, on Lafayette Street. Although there occasionally is some annoying leakthrough of sound from other activities in the building, the hall itself contributes an appropriate ambiance, with its Baroque arches and live acoustics.

title: DUKE JORDAN PLAYS PIANO AT CLUB HERE
description: For the last 15 years, Duke Jordan, one of the major pianists of the bebop era, has been an elusive performer, playing only occasionally and usually at obscure, outoftheway bars. But he has now settled into a regular Tuesday through Saturday schedule at Churchill's, Third Avenue near 74th Street. Despite a dreadful piano and patrons who converse in a sustained shout, he is playing with the same loose swinging ease that prompted Charlie Parker to hire him on the spot the first time Mr. Parker heard him.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: PIKE CRITIC TO OFFER A CENSORED REPORT
description: DALLAS, Feb. 1 (AP)Representative Dale Milford, Democrat of Texas, says he will have his personal copy of a report on United States intelligence operations put in The Congressional Record without classified details if the House Select Committee on Intelligence does not make it public.

title: Priest and Rabbi Hold Service On Jewish Roots in Scripture
description: An Episcopal priest and a Reform rabbi alternated in reading biblical passages in a service devoted to the roots of the Jewish people in Scripture yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: About New york
description: These are stories about two New Yorkers, a girl 12 years old, and a boy, 11. The girl and boy do not know each other, and they have nothing in common except that they both live in Manhattan and they both lose things.

title: U.S. ASKED TO END LIE DETECTOR USE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The House Government Operations Committee called today for all Government agencies to stop using polygraphs and other similar devices known as lie detectors.

title: CARTER IS WINNER IN PORTLAND, ME.
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 1 Jimmy Carter of Georgia won a 46 percent victory in Democratic precinct caucuses in Maine's largest city this afternoon.

title: CHARLES ESPOSITO
description: Charles Esposito, assistant foreman in the delivery department of The New York Times since 1951, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, after having been injured In an accident at The Times. He was 57 years old and lived at 7173 244th Street, Douglaston, Queens.

title: Briton Olympic Skating Favorite
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 1For years, John Curry of Britain was just another name in the figureskating summaries.

title: Joan Sherman Married to John Lisowski
description: Joan Betti Sherman and John I. Lisowski, both of Little Falls, N. J., were married yesterday evening at the Manor in West Orange, N. J., by Judge Paul B. Thompson of the Essex County Court.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS VOTE TO WALK OUT
BMW Captures Daytona Race Contaminated Fuel Delays End
Bruins Post 6th Victory In Row, 53
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)Joe Zanussi, a defenseman, scored his first National Hockey League goal and also picked up an assist to lead the Boston Bruins to a 53 victory over the Atlanta Flames tonight. It was the Bruins sixth straight triumph.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Feb. 2, 1976 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Retired Executives Get State Benefits
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1A number of executives, forced by their companies to retire because they have reached age 65, are drawing New Jersey unemployment benefits even though they get company pensions and Social Security payments.

title: City Seen Entering A Retrenchment Era
description: Over the next 30 months New York City will have to abandon what is perhaps its most treasured boastits bignessand, more importantly, will have to admit to itself that it is a city that can no longer grow.

title: Bicentennial Wagons Roll
description: POLK CITY, Fla., Feb. 1 (UPI)The Florida Bicentennial wagon train, escorted by 35 horseback riders, left here today on a fivemonth journey that will end with its arrival at Valley Forge, Pa., next July 4. The four covered wagons making up the Florida unit are scheduled to join up with wagon trains from Alabama, Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi at various points on the route to the Revolutionary War campsite.

title: Avoiding School Chaos
description: Frantic efforts by City Hall to block passage of the StaviskyGoodman bill designed to prevent the schools from absorbing an unfair proportion of budget cuts do much to confirm the fears of the measure's sponsors that the schools have indeed been singled out for a succession of new blows.

title: Study Urges Major Overhaul of Marines
description: Basic changes in the organization and deployment of the Marine Corps and a sharp reduction of its tactical air power are recommended in a new study released yesterday by the Brookings Institution.

title: Oil Rigs Off Angola's Coast Now Idle
McCarthy Will Detail Drive For Independent Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy plans to disclose later this Week some of the details of his petition drive in a continuing campaign for the Presidency as an independent, his national chairman, Ronald Cocome, said today.

title: Rangers Win, 32, on Sacharuk Goal
Uganda Emerges on City List As Chief Diplomatic Scofflaw
description: Uganda has emerged as a sort of triplecrown champion among parking violators with the three mostticketed diplomatic vehicles among the 2,000 assigned to United Nations missions and foreign consulate here.

title: Italian Bank Rate Lifted
description: ROME, Feb. 1 (Reuters)The Italian Bank rate was raised today to seven percent from six percent, effective tomorrow, the Treasury Ministry announced.

title: 1,000 Titanium Workers Strike at Sayreville Plant
description: SAYREVILLE, Feb. 1 (AP)About 1,000 workers at the titanium pigment division of NL Industries Inc. here went on strike today, a company spokesman said.

title: Miranda Card Read to Suspect In Slaying of 66 Court Figure
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP) The police used a Miranda card to read to a Mexican immigrant his rights before arresting him In connection with the barroom slaying of Ernesto Miranda, the man whose name was given to a landmark Supreme Court decision on defendants rights.

title: Olympic Downhill Made Safer; Olympic Downhill Made Safer
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 1 (AP)The Olympic flame came to Innsbruck today and blazed beneath the famed Goldenes Dachl (little golden roof) where 5 centuries ago Maximillian I tossed coins to troubadors in the courtyard.

title: EDWARD S. STANTON, OBSTETRICIAN, DIES
description: Dr. Edward S. Stanton, an obstetrician and gynecologist on the staff of Lenox Hill Hospital for 30 years, died Saturday at the hospital. He lived at 444 East 82d Street and in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Algerian Force Apparently Wiped Out At Desolate Oasis in Spanish Sahara,
description: AMGALA, Spanish Sahara, Jan. 31 A twoday skirmish between Moroccan and Algerion troops here has apparently ended with the liquidation of an Algerian unit of several hundred men and with the Moroccans in complete control.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: HELLERHerbert C. Dear Bert, You will always be my most favorite person, I love you, Maggle.

title: EMERY I. KARMAN
description: Emery I. Karman, a partner In Josephthahl & Company, stockbrokers, died yesterday at his home. 969 Park Avenue.

title: Undoing One Gag
description: The gag order by a trial judge in Brooklyn forbidding the press to report the background of defendants in a homicide case has now been removed by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court. Newspapers can continue to publish the facts, as they have been doing in defiance of this prior restraint, without being subject to a contempt citation.

title: Ballet: Soaring Dancing by Bujones
description: In a sense James in La Sylphide is perhaps the best male role in all of 19th century ballet. Not entirely by accident perhaps, the choreographer, August Bournonville, devised it for himself. James has a great deal of dancing to doeven more in Erik Bruhn's version than in the traditional Danish production, for Mr. Bruhn very sensibly has James dance the second of the two male variations in the first act, allotting the first to James's rival for the hand of fair Effie, who lives right in the heart of Bonnie Walter Scottland.

title: Son of a Former Editor on the Pine Ridge Reservation Is Slain
description: WANBLEE, S.D., Feb. 1 (UPI)  Federal agents and Pine Ridge Reservation authorities swarmed the reservation today trying to find the killer of Byron DeSersa, son of a former reservation newspaper editor, who is a supporter of the American Indian Movement.

title: SOVIET DECLARES KISSINGER TWISTS ITS ANGOLA POLICY
Pilot Refuses to Fly 2 Children Of Broken Family Out of Israel
description: TEL AVIV. Feb. 1Twice in the last three days an airline pilot has refused to carry two balking children from the custody of their mother in Israel to their father in West Berlin.

title: Beanie Asks Intense Effort To Avert a Garment Strike
description: With a plea from Mayor Beame for them to continue negotiations around the clock if necessary, union and employer representatives in the dressmaking industry worked throughout the day yesterday and into the early hours this morning to try to reach a contract agreement and avert a strike today by 55,000 workers.

title: Article 1  No Title
COMPANIES ADOPT CODES OF CONDUCT
BERNARD RYAN 84, A JUDGE 31 YEARS
description: Bernard Ryan, a judge of the State Court of Claims from his appointment by Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1930 to his retirement as Presiding Judge at the end of 1961, died yesterday of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 84. A lifelong resident of Albion, N.Y., he also had a winter residence at 13 West 13th Street.

title: SURVEY STUDIES PUBLICTV VIEWER
description: A national survey of publictelevision viewing by the Roper Report service has found that 59 percent of the viewers have a high school education or less. This finding is cited by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which commissioned the study, as refuting the widely held belief that public television viewers tend to be intellectuals.

title: Gandhi Foes Denounce State Takeover
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2Opposition members of Parliament staged a brief boycott today to protest the federal Government's action Saturday in dismissing a hostile state government in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

title: Few Take Icy Buffeting in Stride
description: Like the city and suburban landscape, life across the New York metropolitan area yesterday was transformed  for better and for worseby the snowstorm that struck the Northeast.

title: Dividends
CORRECTIONS
Walter Carpenter Jr., 88, Dies
description: Walter S. Carpenter Jr. former president and chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died yesterday at his home near Wilmington, Del., at the age of 88.

title: Queens Boy, 2, Dies in Fire
description: A 2yearold Queens boy died in a fire at his home yesterday afternoon as heat and smoke prevented a livein maid from going to his aid, the police reported.

title: STEEL OUTPUT RISES 3% IN LATEST WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 31 hit a new weekly high for the ytar at 2.32 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was 3 percent higher than the 2.25 million tons poured in the preceding week. The new production capability index reached its 1976 high of 77.7 percent, against 75.1 percent a week earlier.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  of  the  street regulations are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions Atilt apply. Snow tires or chains will he required for driving on thoroughfares designated as mow emergency streets,

title: U.S. Affirms Soviet Builds Its Third Aircraft Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2, (Reuters)The Soviet Union has begun building a third aircraft carrier, Navy Secretary J. William Middendorf said today.

title: Publicity Curb Called Aid In Selecting a Hearst Jury
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2Judge Oliver J. Carter of Federal District Court said in a memorandum today that he elected to conduct secret examinations of prospective jurors in the Patricia Hearst trial because this was the best way to prevent further prejudicial publicity from reaching the panel.

title: Hanoi Hinted at Offering Proof of Nixon Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The North Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister indicated to visiting members of Congress that if the Ford Administration denied that former President Richard M. Nixon had pledged $3.25 billion in postwar American aid, Hanoi might make the suppoprting documents public.

title: Motherwell, at 61, Puts Eternal Quality Into Art
description: Robert Motherwell is a survivor. Hale and prosperous and turning out a good deal of work, he is one of. the few left of the pioneer group of New York painters who, more than 30 years ago, evolved. the first great American style of art known as Abstract Expressionism. What's more, after a series of operations last year, he has fully recovered and says that at 61 he still loves painting as much as I did the day I began.

title: Total Value of Taxable Real Estate Here Shows Drop
description: The total value of taxable real property in New Yrk City will decline this year for they first time in 33 years, officials of the Finance Administration said yesterday.

title: BRITISH LIBERALS PONDER TOP POST
Dutch Canals Freeze and Overnight It's a Hans Brinker Land
description: OUDERKERK AAN DE AMSTEL, the Netherlands, Feb. 1This weekend the vast complex of Dutch canals froze solid for the first time in seven years, and the people took to the ice.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The United States Postal Service is, in most respects, a monopoly. With a few narrowly defined exceptions, the service has the sole right to the business of delivering letters.

title: Prison Terms Are Begun by 10 In Arson Case in North Carolina
description: BURGAW, N. C., Feb. 2 (AP) Ten persons convicted of arson and conspiracy in a racial disturbance in Wilmington in 1971 broke bread and shared wine today with families and friends before surrendering to begin their orison terms.

title: 2 CONSUMER BILLS APPROVED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, (UPI)  The Senate approved today two pieces of consumer legislation one prohibiting credit discrimination on the basis of race, religion or age and a second requiring truth in lending disclosure for leasing contracts.

title: FRANCES SPRAGUE JOY
description: Frances Sprague Joy, who organized the general library of the. National Broadcasting Company in 1930 and was chief librarian until her retirement in 1953, died Friday in Bradenton, Fla. She was 79 years old.

title: Notes on People
TALKS OPEN IN SPAIN ON SEA POLLUTION
description: MADRID, Feb. 2Thirteen Mediterranean nations began meeting in Barcelona today to discuss specific legal commitments to control water pollution.

title: Resignations Seen in College Scandal
Factory Orders Down Slightly And Inventories Up in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Total new orders received by manufacturers declined slightly in December though durablegoods orders, in contrast to, a preliminary estimate, in1 creased, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Newark Teachers Report No Progress on Contract
description: NEWARK. Feb. 2Teachers and the Board of Education here failed to make progress today toward a settlement of a contract dispute and, after a snowstorm closed city schools, the teachers put off setting up picket lines until tomorrow.

title: Chess:
The Soviet View of Emigration
Dr. Roy Langfitt, 81, Dies; Taught Education at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Roy Emerson Langfitt, professor emeritus of education at New York University, died Saturday in Worthington Manor Care Center, Parkersburg, W. Va. He was 81 years old.

description: All News: WCBS. WINS, WNWS. Hourly on the Hour: WOXR, WJLK, WMCA, WNBC. WNCN, WNEWAM, WOR, WSOU.

title: Michinan 107, Wisconsin 86
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 2 (AP)Michigan's star guard, Rickey Green, poured in 32 points as the Wolverines ran up their biggest point total of the season routing Wisconsin, 10786, in a Big Ten game.

title: N.B.A., Players Reach Tentative Pact on Suit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 The National Basketball Association and its players reached a tentative agreement today for an outofcourt settlement of the Oscar Robertson suit.

title: Newark Teachers to Begin Picketing
description: NEWARK, Feb, 2Teachers and the Board of Education here failed to make progress today toward a settlement of a contract dispute and, after a snowstorm closed city schools, the teachers put off setting up picket lines until tomorrow.

title: STRIKE IMPERILS NEWSPRINT SUPPLY
description: A prolonged strike of Canadian woodpulp and paper work, ers. plus the expected increase in the price of newsprint, is expected to have considerable impact on many American newspapers by the spring of summer.

title: PROAMNESTY UNIT RAPS NEW INQUIRY
F.E.A. Sets Rules To Roll Back Prices Of U.S. Crude Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Federal Energy Administration announced today the adoption of final regulations to roll back crudeoil prices as required by the new Energy Policy and Conservation Act. The average price for new oil will now be $11.28 a barrel.

description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: DR. SIDNEY AXELRAD, DEAN AT QUEENS, 63
description: Dr. Sidney Axelrad, dean of graduate studies and professor of sociology at Queens College. died Sunday at his honie, 1148 Fifth Avenue. He was 63 years old.

title: City Accused of Misusing Education Aid From State
Japan to Extend Sea Limit To 12 Miles by Year's End
description: TOKYO, Feb. 2 (AP)Japan plans to extend its territorial sea limits from the present three nautical miles to 12 by the ned of this year regardless of any decisions made at the Law of the Sea Conference, Prime Ministerd Takeo Miki said today.

title: Gifts of $1.6 Million To Permit Overhaul Of Botanical Garden
description: Donations of more than $1.6 million, including an $850,000 contribution by Enid A. Haupt, a member of the Annenberg publishing family, will enable restoration work that had been jeopardized by the city's fiscal crisis to begin next month on the Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: French Seal Off Djibouti
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Feb. 2 (Agence France  Presse)  French forces today sealed off this capital, it was announced here. The action came two weeks after officials said they had broken up a terrorist network in France's last African possession.

title: N. Carolina Gets Trials
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP)The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will be host to the first trials camp for the Olympic basketball team May 30 to June 5, Stan Watts, chairman of the Olympic basketball committee, said yesterday.

title: Eroding Trust
description: The Ford Administration's repeated scoldings of Congress about interference in executive conduct of foreign policy grow ever more lame as new incidents of diplomatic dissembling become known. The latest disclosure involves a claim by Hanoi leaders that they have a secret letter from former President Nixon committing the United States to supply $3.25 billion in reconstruction aid to North Vietnam.

title: Holmes Released on Bond
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP)  Ernie Holmes, the Pittsburgh Steeler defensive tackle who was arrested Saturday night on charges of possession of 250 milligrams of cocaine, was released today on $1,000 bond.

title: MILTON BIOW DIES
description: Milton H. Biow, founder of the former Biow Company, long one of the country's largest advertising agencies, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 470 Park Avenue.

title: Corporate Profits Rise 1%
description: Corporate net profits of the nation's private business enterprises edged up I percent in the fourth quarter last year over the 1974 period and were 2 percent ahead of the rebounding third quarter, according to a preliminary tabulation issued yesterday by the First National City Bank.

title: Study Finds Catching a Cold Is More Difficult Than It Was Thought
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 2The person who recoils from every common cold sufferer is probably recoiling without good cause.

description: The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Elinor C. Guggenheimer, called on the Federal Government yesterday to investigate coffee prices to de termine whether the coffee pro ducers cartel was running the price up and if American companies were improperly involved in their activities.

Kentucky 85, L.S.U. 71
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 2 (AP)Mike Phillips scored 35 points and hauled down 20 rebounds as Kentucky, defeated Louisiana State, 8571, tonight, but his performance was almost overshadowed by unusual plays.

description: The total value of taxable real property in New York City will decline this year for the first time in 33 years, officials of the Finance Administration, said yesterday.

description: Donations of more than $1.6 million, including an $850,000 contribution by Enid A. Haupt, a member of the Annenberg publishing family, will enable restoration work that had been delayed by the city's fiscal crisis to begin next month on the Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden In the Bronx.

title: Storm Slows Traffic and Closes Schools
description: An onrushing Atlantic Coast storm yesterday suddenly changed driving rain into ice and blinding snow in the metropolitan area, bringing traffic to a crawl and closing many schools.

title: New Mexico Family Wins Settlement In Suit on Children's Mercury Blinding
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 2A $3.6 million liability suit against three companies charged with causing four members of an Alamogordo family to be stricken with mercury poisoning was settled out of court in favor of the plaintiffs today, several hours after the trial had opened.

title: MOYNIHAN RESIGNS POST AT THE U.N., CITES HARVARD JOB
Blaze at Boston Globe
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)A minor fire in The Boston Globe's exhaust ventilating system this afternoon forced the news paper to cancel its final evening edition; a spokesman announced. Ink mist and paper in the vent system caught fire and spread smoke through a mailing room. No damage estimate was available.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1976

title: A Chilean Law to Protect Suspects Called Inadequate
description: GENEVA, Feb. 2 (upi)The International Commission of Jurists told Chile today that its law passed last week to protect suspects from the danger of torture is iadequate.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING HELD IN PINE RIDGE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Feb. 2 (UPI)F.B.I. agents arrested today a 28yearold man and charged him with murder in the slaying Saturday of an editor's son on the Pine Ridge reservation.

title: Trudeau Ends Caracas Visit
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 2 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today ended a fiveday official visit to Venezuela after issuing a joint communiqu with his host, President Carlos Andres Prez, condemning international terrorism.

title: 4 Girls Killed in Fire CRESSON. Pa., Feb. 2 (AP)
description: Four young girls were killed early today when fire swept through an apartment here. Firefighters were hindered by subzero weather in battling the blaze which took the lives of two sisters, a friend and a baby sitter. Authorities identified the dead as Michelle Adkins, 13 years old, and her sister, Sally, 7; a friend, Beverly Ann Ritz, 13, who was spending the night in the Adkins apartment, and the baby sitter, Diane Eger, 16.

title: Remark by Rabin in U.S. Reignites Rivalry With Defense Chief
A.T.&T. Divestiture Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) A Federal Communications commission task force study made public today recommended that Congress enact legislation to force the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to divest itself of its wholly owned manufacturing and supply subsidiary, the Western Electric Company.

title: Dance Theater of Harlem To Open at Uris Feb. 25
description: Dance Theater of Harlem will open at the Uris Theater on Feb. 25 for its third New York season. Opening night will be a gala benefit for the company and will include the premiere of Arthur Mitchell's Manifestations, a pas de trois for Susan Lovelle, Homer Bryant and Mel Tomlinson based on the story of Adam and Eve and set to a score by Primous Fountain, a 26yearold composer from Chicago.

title: Cheevers on Verge Of Rejoining Bruins
description: With goalie Gerry Cheevers ready to sign a contract in a matter of days and Bobby Orr back on skates and preparing to return in a couple of weeks, the streaking Boston Bruins are looming as a giant contender to win the Stanley Cup. Only a legal technicality needs ironing out, said Harry Sinden, the Bruins' managing director, before the 35yearold Cheevers can rejoin the team he helped to the championship in 1970 and 1972 before jumping to the Cleveland Crusaders of the World Hockey Association. Orr, recovering from the fifth operation on his left knee, recently told friends on the New York Rangers that he will not play another game for the Bruins until they sign him to a contract for next season. Orr, considered by many as the greatest defenseman in hockey history, will become a free agent after this season and presumably could join any he chooses.

title: Pentagon Plans Impact Reports on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Sometime this spring, the Ford Administration will take the novel step of informing Congress what impact various weapons programs requested by the Pentagon may have upon international efforts to control the weapons.

title: More States Force Disclosure of Assets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The mood of political reform generated by the Watergate scandals has spurred the passage of scores of laws that are forcing one million state and local officials to allow the public its first glimpse of probably their most guarded secrets  their financial affairs. And many of the officials don't like it.

title: Rutgers Downs Princeton, 7562
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2Gov. Brendan Byrne of New Jersey was willing to give Gcv. Otis Bowen of Indiana the Hoosiers and 2 points, in a RutgersIndiana basketball match after Governor Byrne had watched undefeated and sixthranked Rutgers defeat Princeton, 7562, at Jadwin Gymnasium tonight.

title: Barthelme Wit Livens Conversations
High Tides Around New York
After Dunlop
Storm Slows Traffic and Closes Schools
description: An onrushing Atlantic Coast storm yesterday suddenly changed driving rain into ice and blinding snow in the metropolitan area, bringing traffic to a crawl and closing many schools.

title: DR. SIDNEY AXELRAD, DEAN AT QUEENS, 63
description: Dr. Sidney Axelrad, dean of graduate studies and professor of sociology at Queens College, died Sunday at his home, 1148 Fifth Avenue. He was 63 years old.

title: ECOLOGISTS URGE ATOM SAFEGUARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Natural Resources Defense Council urged the Government today to take immediate emergency measures, such as the use of Federal marshals, to strengthen security at 16 research and processing plants licensed to use weaponsgrade nuclear materials.

title: Hans Richter, 87, Is Dead
description: GENEVA, Feb. 2  Hans Richter, the artist and film director, died yesterday in a hospital at Locarno. He was 87 years old.

title: Montreal Sets Up Plans For Olympic Emergency
Letters to the Editor
description: Nuclear Spread: The Cure Begins at Home

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a report on a manmade marsh in the Mississippi River Delta that appeared in The New York Times yesterday, part of a comment by Donald G. Schueler, a board member of the New Orleans Audubon Society, was inadvertently omitted. Mr. Schueler noted that the Army Corps of Engineers had taken years to begin such work, but added that the corps was to be congratulated for its recent encouraging efforts.

title: Garment Pact
description: In the early years of this century, when the sweatshops on the Lower East Side were draining the lifeblood out of immigrant seamstresses and their children, the infant International Ladies Garment Workers Union initiated wage policies aimed at standardizing pay rates and preventing exploitation.

title: Foresight Opens Commuter Roads in Storm
description: TEANECK, Feb. 2Milton Robbins, the township engineer here, peered through the predawn darkness today into the teeth of a howling blizzard. Lightning flashed, windows rattled, broken tree limbs sailed by on Wyndham Road.

title: Cannon Ploy Backfires On 5 Rutgers Students
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 2 Michael Borden, chief of the Rutgers University police, said today that he was waiting for a report from the Princeton University security division before deciding whether to press charges against five Rutgers students who tried to steal the Princeton Cannon Saturday and bring it back to Rutgers.

title: Interest Rates Up
description: Interest rates moved up a notch or two in the money and capital markets yesterday, but trading activity was unusually light because of the cold weather in the Northeast and also because everyone was waiting to see how the Treasury's financing operations this week would go. Treasury bill rates rose slightly in the Government's weekly auction of shortterm securities, and then tradres and investors spent the afternoon trying to refine their guesses of orders for the Treasury's new 8 percent sevenyear notes currently being offered in blocks as small as $1,000 and at a price of 100 percent of their face value.

title: Congress Asked to Increase Grants for College Students
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 2 (UPI) A government grant program for needy college students is running out of a money and the Administration has asked Congress to approve another $180 million for it, the Office of Education said today. The increase would raise the total amount available for socalled basic opportunity grants to $1 billion.

title: Honeywell and Control Data Show Sharp Gains in Profits
description: Two of the nation's large computer companies, Honeywell Inc. and the Control Data Corporation, showed sharply improved earnings for the quarter and the year ended Dec. 31.

title: Few Take Icy Buffeting in Stride
description: Like the city and suburban landscape, life across the New York metropolitan area yesterday was transformed  for better and for worseby the snowstorm that struck the Northeast.

title: WHEAT IS BUOYED BY DRY WEATHER
description: The weather dominated commodity markets yesterday. In Chicago wheat traders pondered continued reports of dry weather hurting the new winter wheat crop as they bought wheat futures. in the East, a snowstorm snarled transportation so much that some exchanges opened late because of the straggling arrival of floor traders. On the New York Cotton Exchange, center for orange juice futures and wool, no trading took place.

title: A Farm Family's Chores Get Done Despite Storm
Court Rules Against Withholding of Data In Ashland Oil Case
STOCKS DECLINE ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Despite a weatherdelayed opening that trimmed an hour and 15 minutes from the trading day, volume othe New York Stock Exchange yesterday again topped 20 million shares. Prices, on the other hand, backed down somewhat in an extension of last Friday's profit taking.

title: Del Bello Calls for a View Of Westchester as Urban
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 2Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, said tonight that Westchester had become an urban county and thus was obliged to change some traditional attitudes to remain competitive.

title: AnacondaTenneco Merger Set
description: The Anaconda Company, which has been fighting a tender offer by the Crane Company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to a merger with Tenneco Inc. worth about $500 million.

title: ARCO CUTS PRICES ON DIESEL FUELS
Morgan's Analysts Optimistic on Debt Of Poorest Nations
description: The financial problems of the world's poorest nations, while immense, are still manageable, economists of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company assert in the bank's monthly publication, World Financial Markets.

title: Sports Today
description: National Basketball Association's All Star game, at Philadelphia. (TelevisionChannel 2, 9:30 P.M)

title: C. Francis Beatty, 85, Dies
description: C. Francis Beatty, who retired in 1955 as director in charge of industrial relations of Socony Vacuum Oil Company Inc., died Saturday in New Milford, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in Pawling, N.Y.

title: Drexel Burnham Acquires
description: Washington Forum Inc., a private company that analyzes the impact of the Federal Government on institutional investors, has been acquired by Drexel Burnham & Company, the brokerage house, from Alliance One Institutional Services, both; firms said yesterday. The amount involved was not disclosed.

title: U.S.C. Star Returning
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP) Earl Evans, who has missed five games for the Southern California basketball team with a strained tendon, will make the trip to play Washington this weekend.

title: The Necessity for Cuts
description: Mayor Beame, already faced with serious and growing gaps in New York City's threeyear financial plan, is understandably concerned over the prospective loss of $100 million in state aid under Governbr Carey's proposed new state budget. But the Mayor's plan to lead a fight against the local aid cuts is an illconsidered reactionone that could turn a manageable misfortune into unmitigated disaster for the state and all of its localities, including this city.

title: Helping New York
description: Conditions on the Cross Bronx Expressway were treacherous. Snow pelted down, cars slid across the icy spots and drivers looked grim. Vernon Charles and Jeffrey Bickart, however, sat in a green Mustang listening attentively to the crackling reports of a citizens band radio and looked expectant. It was their kind of day.

title: SHOP TALK
Alfred Montezinos Resigns As the President of Cartier
description: Alfred Montezinos resigned yesterday as president of Cartier Inc. after two years in that post with the Fifth Avenue jewelry store. Mr. Montezinos said, I am terminating my association with Cartier because I believe my policies will be inconsistent with those of the new owners.

title: Secretary Loses Her Job Over Pallottine Leaks
description: BALTIMORE, Tuesday, Feb. 3 (AP)A secretary at a direct mail firm partially owned by the Pallottine Fathers has been dismissed because she leaked information to reporters investigating the Roman Catholic missionary order, according to The Washington Post.

title: Bill Aims at a Reduction In Public Employee Strikes
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2A bill that sponsors hope will cut down strikes by state employees will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow as the first step in finding new ways to settle governmental labor disputes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Winds gusting at more than 60 miles an hour blew down the Mason airdome at Columbia's Baker Field yesterday morning. The airdome, a fabric structure held up by air pressure, is used by the Columbia track team and those of St. John's, Fordham and Manhattan. Al Paul, Columbia's athletic director, said the bubble had sustained two major rips, but the extent of the damage was not yet known. Columbia was trying to reschedule Friday's dual meet with Rutgers, the last of the season, at another site

title: I.R.S. Urged to Aid PublicInterest Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2In an effort to increase the sources of permanent funding for, publicinterest law, an organization of influential lawyers plans to mount an effort to get the Internal Revenue Service to change its regulations restricting publicinterest firms.

title: New Paths in the Dress Industry
description: The contract settlement reached yesterday between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the dress industry embodies a major philosophical change for the 75yearold union and lays the groundNews work for a sweepAnalysis ing revision of labor relations in the women's clothing industry.

title: U.S. Sled Teams Get Into a Feud
description: IGLS, Austria, Feb. 2 (UPI) A feud has broken out in the United States Olympic camp between the bobsled and luge teams.

title: Sadat Quoted That U.S. Plans P.L.O. Recognition
description: CAIRO, Feb. 2 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said in an interview here today that he had tacit agreement from the United States to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Nostalgia Is Expensive at REA's Auction
Comptroller Says Role in Regulating Banks Falls Short
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 James E. Smith, Comptroller of the Currency, has acknowledged that his office has not sought to pursue the kind of activist regulatory policy toward the nation's banks that he now feels it should.

title: U.S. Study Is Urged On Price Increases Of Coffee Sold Here
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Elinor C. Guggenheimer, called on the Federal Government yesterday to investigate coffee prices to determine whether the coffee producers cartel was running the price up and if American companies were improperly involved in their activities.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2united States auto plants built 665.S23 cars last month, up 51 percent from 440,686 built in the depressed yearearlier periud, reports from the four companies showed today.

title: Concorde Test at Kennedy Urged by City Trade Board
description: A sixmonths test of operations by Concorde supersonic airliners should be held at Kennedy International Airport, rather than at any other city's airport, the New. York Board of Trade said yesterday.

title: BRITON RECRUITING FOR ANGOLA GROUP
description: LONDON, Feb. 2At least 1,000 Britons are being sought to fight in Angola against Sovietsupported forces, a key recruiter said today.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: By The Associated Press

title: HOUSE FIGHT DUE ON NATURAL GAS; Key Republicans Meet With President on Strategy for Pricing Battle Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Key House Republicans met with President Ford and energy officials at the White House tonight to map tactics for a major floor battle in the House tomorrow on naturalgas pricing.

title: Judge Orders Reduced Bail For Miss Fromme's Friend
description: SACRAMENTO., Calif, Feb. 2 (AP)A Federal district judge ordered the bail of Sandra Good, a follower of Charles M. Manson, reduced to $40,000 today after refusing to release her without bail.

title: G.M.'s Earnings Rise by 21.7% in Quarter
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2The General Motors Corporation today reported earnings for the last quarter of 1975 that were the second highest for a fourth quarter In the company's history.

title: British Laborites Restudy Premises About Economy
American Ballet Theater Ends Outstanding Season
Lonely Crusader Battles Sexism She Sees in U.N.
description: Shirley Hazzard seems a woman in perfect control. Fastidious and cool, crowned with smooth black hair, she site in her polished apartment high above Manhattan or in two little white rooms on the island of Capri, writing sensitive, tender stories about love and ultimate loss.

title: OPEC Investible Surplus Likely to Edge Up in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The investible surplus of the oilexporting countries will rise slightly this year after a sharp decline in 1975, according to new estimates by the United States Treasury. The new estimates put the surplusmoney left for investment after paying for importsof the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at $44.9 billion in 1976.

title: More States Force Disclosure of Assets
New School Taxes Unlikely in Jersey, Senate Chief Says
Drought Ruins Israeli Crops
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Winter grain crops in southern Israel must be considered a total loss because of drought, according to a senior official at the ministry of agriculture. Irrigation will be required to save the cotton crop.

title: ASTEROID SIGHTED IN ORBIT NEAR EARTH
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (Reuters)An asteroid of the type that has made the giant craters on planets of the solar system has been found near earth, the California Institute of Technology has reported.

title: Dr. Roy Langfitt, 81, Dies Taught Education at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Roy Emerson Langfitt, professor emeritus of education at New York University, died Saturday in Worthington Manor Care Center, Parkersburg, W. Va. He was 81 years old.

title: HOLLANDER ADMITS FRAUD ON MEDICAID IN NURSING HOMES
Rain, Snow and Gales Paralyze Traffic
description: New Jersey was pummeled yesterday with winds up to 60 miles an hour and freezing rains that turned to snow, leaving a thick coat of ice on the state's highways that paralyzed traffic and caused many commuters and schoolchildren to stay home.

title: Coopman, the Quiet Belgian, Enters Glare of Ali's World
description: INGELMUNSTER, Belgium In early November JeanPierre Coopman laid aside his 12pound hammer at the Van der Kerkhove stonecutting plant in this small Flemish town and went home to start fulltime training for the biggest fight of his boxing careeragainst Richard Dunn of Britain for the European heavyweight crown.

title: Prudential Wins Suit
description: The Prudential Group. Inc. said late yesterday a wholly owned subsidiary. the Prudential Oil Corporation, had been awarded a jury verdict in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Phillips Petroleum Company for $1.5 million plus interest. The suit, filed in 1967 involved a refining and chemical complex constructed by Phillips in Puerto Rico. It could not be learned last night wether Phillips planner to appeal.

title: T. I. Corp. Unit Is Accused Of Bank Account Scheme
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP) The California Department of Insurance has started administrative proceedings against a unit of the T. I. Corporation, charging it with intentionally and knowingly overdrawing its bank accounts as part of an alleged checkkiting scheme.

title: Helping New York
description: Conditions on the Cross Bronx Expressway were treacherous. Snow petted down, cars slid across the icy spots and drivers looked grim. Vernon Charles and Jeffrey Bickart, however, sat in a green Mustang listening attentively to the crackling reports of a citizens band radio and Joked expectant. It was their kind of day.

title: HOLLANDER ADMITS FRAUD ON MEDICAID IN NURSING HOMES
description: Eugene Hollander, a major figure in the nursinghome industry here, pleaded guilty yesterday to state and Federal charges of bilking Medicaid of hundreds of thousands of dollars to pay for such personal items as paintings by Renoir, Utrillo and Mary Cassatt, and furnishing and decorating his apartment at 980 Fifth Avenue.

title: LaidOff Officers Wait, Wait for Recall
Major Independents
description: By The Associated Press

title: Fashion: Wintry Winds Raged, But It Was Summer on 7th Ave.
description: The shows went on as scheduled yesterday on Seventh Avenue, despite raging winds and freezing cold. The models all showed up, and so did the audience. The thing is, the theme was summer, and someone at each presentation felt obligated to thank the audience for turning up and to remind the guests that, yes, indeed, summer was around the corner.

title: Australia Names Envoy
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 2 (AP)Australia's next ambassador to the United States will he Nicholas Fancourt Parkinson, the government has announced. Mr. Parkinson, 50 years old, who takes up his seat in early March, was high commissioner to Singapore from 1970 to 1974 before being appointed deputy secretary of the Foreign Ministry.

title: Allegra Kent Is Eloquent in City Ballet Episodes
description: Allegra Kent is an enchanting ballerina who has fashioned a unique career of triumphant returns to the New York City Ballet. Detailing her unexpected arrivals and departures there will someday provide a scholarly footnote to the company's history. She rarely selects an easy or surefire vehicle to reappear in, choosing Agon at one time and Episodes on Sunday evening at the State Theater. She was delectably eloquent.

title: Bradford Bixby Smith, 76, Economist for U.S. Steel
description: Bradford Bixby Smith, economist of the United States Steel Corporation from 1939 to his retirement in 1965, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived at 7 Heathcote Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: BankAmerica Dividend Up
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, holding company for the Bank of America, announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend of its common stock to 39 cents a share from 37 cents. The dividend is payable March 1 to shareholders of record Feb. 13.

title: DONALD STRALEM, A PHILANTHROPIST
description: Donald S. Stralem, an investment banker long active in philanthropic work, died Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 72 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and in Manhasset. L. I.

title: Presidential Candidates May Escape Fund Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The active Presidential candidates, all held by the Supreme Court last week to strict 1976 campaign spending limits, may escape them entirely if Congress does not revive the Federal Election Commission.

title: Memo Indicates City Obscured Stadium's High Cost
description: On Oct. 1, 1973, Mayor John V. Lindsay broke ground at Yankee Stadium for a renovation that he said would cost the city $27 million.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Report Inaccurately Quoted Former Intelligence Head
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) In a Washington dispatch of Dec. 3. 1975, on testimony before the House Intelligence Committee on estimates of Communist troop strength in Vietnam, United Press Internad tional incorrectly quoted Lieut. Gen. Daniel O. Graham, then director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, concerning North Vietnamese and Vietcong troop figures. [The dispatch appeared in the New York Times on Dec. 4].

title: Vietnamese Children Caught in West German Dispute
description: OBERHAUSEN, West Germany  One hundred twenty crippled and burned Vietnamese children, victims of the Indochina war, are caught here in a political battle about whether they should be sent home.

title: Prof. Mary A. Wyman, 87
description: Dr. Mary Alice Wyman, professor emeritus of English at Hunter College, died last Tuesday in Damariscotta, Me., where she lived. She was 87 years old.

title: U.S. Forces Debate Commanders' Qualities
description: The recent removal of two United States generals for displays of abrasiveness has focused attention on a debate in the armed services over the Qualities needed to command forces of wellpaid and educated volunteers and for daily contact with sensitive foreign allies and arms purchasers.

title: Manning Operated On
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Archie Manning, the New Orleans Saints quarterback, underwent surgery to repair tendinitis in his right bicep today. His doctor said he would be fit to play at the start of the 1976 season.

title: Graebner Upset by Amaya, 20
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 2 (UPI)  A University of Michigan student, Victor Amaya upset Clark Graebner today in the first round of the $60,000 International Players Association tournament

title: Moynihan Affair (Conc.)
description: It will come as no surprise to those who know both the man and the organization that Daniel Patrick Moynihan's career at the United Nations has cone to an end only seven months after he was sworn in as chief United States delegate. What is a surprise is that Ambassador Moynihan evidently has quit not primarily out of frustration with the United Nations but because he believes his efforts have been blunted and undermined by the Department of State and even by Secretary Kissinger.

title: Win With Women Drive Starts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Representative Bella S. Abzug said today that last week's Supreme Court's decision scrapping some of the limitations on campaign contributions would make it harder than ever for women to run for public office.

title: Wells's Gardner Unit Elects New President
description: Having been executive vice president and managing director for the last three years of Gardner Advertising, St. Louis, Barry Loughrane has now been promoted to president upon the retirement of Warren Kratke.

title: Weatherman Here Caught by Surprise
description: The plummeting predawn temperatures that caused the metropolitan area's rainslicked roads and highways to ice up yesterday morning caught meteorologists at the National Weather Service by surprise.

title: Wallace's Right Leg Put in Cast After Accident Aboard Plane
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace's right leg was put into a cast tonight after a state trooper stumbled while carrying him in a plane in Pensacola, accidentally pulling on the Governor's paralyzed limb, officials said. As he was wheeled out of a doctor's office, Mr. Wallace told reporters he was in no pain.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN IN LOWER VOLUME
description: Yesterday's wintry blasts had little effect on the price of issues on the American Stock Exchange. Although trading was delayed by 30 minutes to a 10:30 A.M. opening, the Amex market value index gained 0.38 to close at 96.67 as advances led declines by 384 issues to 322.

title: Today's Entries at Hialeah
description: FIRST$4,500, cl., 3YO, 1??m.

title: Hockey Scoring
Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Byrne's Amount of Pay Is Uncertain, He Says
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2 (AP)Governor Byrne said today that he was tight with a buck but could only estimate how much he made a year. He supplied the tightwith  a  buck description when a news conference question suggested that he might be profligate with the public purse.

title: Ford Said to Plan to Push for IsraeliJordanian Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Ford, looking for ways of keeping Middle East diplomacy alive, has agreed to pursue a suggestion made by Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and see if it would be possible to arrange negotiations between Israel and Jordan for an accord on the West Bank of the Jordan River, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Planned Sale of Church Now in Doubt
description: The Asia Society may not be buying Central Presbyterian Church after all.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Long Reserve Mining Dispute Is Far From Resolved
description: MINNEAPOLISThe nation's longest environmental and health controversy, a sevenyearold issue involving the Reserve Mining Company's dumping of thousands of tons of industrial waste each day into Lake Superior, remains far from resolved.

title: Ford to Stress Soft Sell In New Hampshire Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Ford, whose bid for the Republican Presidential nomination rests on making the most of his White House incumbency, will take part in only one overtly political event in a twoday tour of New Hampshire next weekend.

title: A STRIKE IMPERILS NEWSPRINT SUPPLY
description: A prolonged strike of Canadian woodpulp and paper workers, plus the expected increase in the price of newsprint, is expected to have considerable impact on many American newspaper by the spring or summer.

title: Lodge Entertaining Is Over, Rockwell And Northrop Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Officials of two giant defense contractors, the Rockwell International Corporation and the Northrop Corporation, said today that they did not think their companies had done anything wrong by entertaining Government officials at private hunting lodges, but promised not to do it again.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where al ternate  side  of  the  street regulations are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply. Snow tires or chains will he required for driving on thoroughfares designated as snow emergency streets.

title: Dress Industry and Union Agree on 23 Percent Raise
description: The garment union and the dress industry reached agreement early yesterday on a 40month contract that will provide 23 percent pay increases and establish the basis for a future pact governing the entire outerwear industry.

title: Music: Lazar Berman
People in Sports
Concorde Test at Kennedy Urged by City Trade Board
description: A sixmonths' test of operations by Concorde supersonic airliners should be held at Kennedy International Airport, rather than at any other city's airport, the New York Board of Trade said yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: All bridge players have days that make them feel that there is no justice in the game, and even that the fates are singling them out for special injustice. They are heavily punished for making reasonable bids, while their opponents do something outrageous and make a profit from it.

title: Levi Suggests Abolishing Parole, Jailing Criminals for Full Term
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2, (AP)Attorney General Edward H. Levi suggested today the abolition of the Federal parole system and the jailing of convicted criminals for their full sentences with time off only for good behavior.

title: WILLIAM W. FIRMAN
description: William W. Fireman, vice president in charge of marketing for ABCTV, died Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old.

title: Parents Close Tap on Sodas In Westchester School Menu
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y.  It was the first lunch period at Woodlands High School. The students were sitting at long tables busily consuming the usual array of allAmerican lunch foodshamburgers, French fries, pizza, heroes (or wedges, as they call them here); pretzels and potato chips.

title: Schools and Banks in Beirut Getting Back to Work
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 2Life in Beirut came closer toda to being normal than it has been in about two months.

title: 3 Engineers Quit G.E. Reactor Division And Volunteer in Antinuclear Movement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2Three managing engineers from the division of the General Electric Company that builds nuclear reactors quit their jobs today and volunteered to work for the California movement to halt nuclear power.

title: L'Ensemble Presents A Concert
description: Music for the millions is one of those democratic shibboleths that any citizen of the Republic must endorse in this Bicentennial season. But, given a choice, which of us would not prefer to hear music for the dozensor, at most, for the small hundreds?

title: PROAMNESTY UNIT RAPS NEW INQUIRY
description: A council of more than 100 national organizations has criticized a new Ford Foundationfinanced study of problems of Vietnam veterans, deserters and draft evaders as academically discredited and said that its own members would refuse cooperation.
