title: Basketball Scoring AMERICAN ASSOCIATION
Focus of Controversy at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2It was to have been a routine United States statement, but as Daniel Patrick Moynihan delivered it a few days ago to the Security Council he ineluded a lament over what he said was the small number of truly democratic countries surviving in the world.

title: In Wake of the Storm: How Did You Get In Today?
description: With snow cloaking its flight and ice smoothing its way, New York City slipped into the intemperate zone yesterday.

title: 30 Families Are Evacuated In 5Alarm Brooklyn Fire
description: A fivealarm fire, burning out of control for more than two hours, heavily damaged a fourstory apartment building, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn late yesterday. but there were no immediate re ports of injuries, the Fire Department said.

title: Rights Bill for Women
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Senators Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut and Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois introduced legislation today to create a national center for women, The center would be headed by an administrator named by the President and confirmed by the Senate. It would review, monitor and examine existing Federal. rights programs affecting women to guarantee that they are doing the job Congress intended.

title: In Westchester, the Snow Means Children Stay Home
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 2Pat O'Connor's six children woke up at 6:30 this morning when the principal of the Mount Kisco Elementary School called to tell her that schools would not be open today.

title: College Conference Standings
The Texts of the Letters By Moynihan and Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Following are the texts of Daniel P: Moynihan's letter resigning as United States representative at the United Nations and President Ford's letter accepting the resignation:

title: Fast Shuffle
description: In an extraordinary legislative maneuver, Congress last week passed a bill to permit the mass spraying of blackbirds that roost in large numbers in Western Kentucky and Tennessee. The bill would suspend the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act and the Pesticide Control Act; it would also override an agreement reached between the Department of Justice and two conservation organizations during a lawsuit concerning this problem. Yet Congress took this action in a matter of minutes without committee hearings, without serious debate and without a record vote.

title: Advertising
description: The Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, the country's fourth largest ad agency, has been chosen by RCA Consumer Electronics division to replace the J. Walter Thompson Company as agency for its color television receivers. Billings on the business are estimated at $10 million.

title: French Police Have 2 Leads In the Theft of 119 Picassos
MOYNIHAN IS OPEN TO A SENATE RACE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2  Daniel Moynihan would seriously consider seeking the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, his lawyer said today, if there were indications that Democrats around the state wanted him to runindications that were quickly forthcoming as word spread of Mr. Moynihan's decision to resign as chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Beyond the Bazaars of Muscat Lies Urban Sprawl
description: MUSCAT, OmanThe musky bazaar fragrances mix with the reek of automobile exhausts, and the resonant Arab courtesies are drowned out by construction noise.

title: Miss Nelson Rates As Top U.S. Skier
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 2Where are they all, the successors to those great names that made Olympic ski history for America over the years?

title: Robert Motherwell on Art and Artists
description: PAINTING: For me, painting is like farming or gardening. You can't force it, you must cultivate it at its own speed. That's not to say there aren't magic moments, but I'm sure there are in farming, too.

title: Israeli Team Smaller
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 2 (AP)Israel will send a smaller contingent to the Olympics in Montreal than it sent to Munich four years ago, Josef Inbar, head of the Olympic Committee. said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge temporarily banned the state yesterday from enforcing a law that denied Medicaid funds for abortions for women on welfare. Judge George Barlow of United States District Court issued a temporary injunction against the law and said he would hold a hearing to consider a permanent ban on the new state statute. Governor Byrne signed the law last December. Similar legislation in other states had been struck down by the Federal courts.

title: Motherwell, at 61, Puts Eternal Quality Into Art
description: Robert Motherwell is a survivor. Hale and prosperous and turning out a good deal of work, he is one of the few left of the pioneer group of New York painters who, more than 30 years ago, evolved the first great American style of art known as Abstract Expressionism. What's more, after a series of operations last year, he has fully recovered and says that at 61 he still loves painting as much as I did the day began.

title: Market Place
description: It is an article of faith in Wall Street circles that stocks provide the best avenue to longterm investment successwith better possibilties than either corporate bonds or United States Treasury bills.

title: Comptroller Says Role in Regulating Banks Falls Short
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2James E. Smith, Comptroller of the Currency, has acknowledged that his office has not sought to pursue the kind of activist regulatory policy toward the nation's banks that he now feels it should.

title: Robert Motherwell on Art and Artists
description: PAINTING: For me, painting is like farming or, gardening. You can't force it, you must cultivate it at its own speed. That's not to say there aren't magic moments, but I'm sure there are in farming, too.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Holding the Olympic torch aloft, Guido Caroli, then Italy's foremost speed skater, glided across the ice of the modernistic pine stadium that had been constructed for the 1956 Winter Games at Cortina d'Ampezzo, the Italian mountain village. Turning toward the dignitaries' box, where Giovanni Gronchi, the President of Italy, beamed approval, Guido Caroli didn't notice the microphone wires on the ice. He flopped in an embarrassing pratfall. But he quickly regained his balance, skated on and lit the huge bowl in which the Olympic flame would burn.

title: DONALD STRALEM, A PHILANTHROPIST
description: Donald S. Stralem, an investment banker long active in philanthropic work, died Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 72 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and in Manhasset, L. I.

title: BOSTON FIRE FOUGHT BY MORE THAN 300
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)A generalalarm fire that engulfed an old shoe factory late last night and early today was battled by more firefighters than any blaze in the city's history and resulted in an estimated loss of over $1 million.

title: Prof. George S. Jackson, 69, Of English Faculty at Maine
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., Feb. 2George Stuyvesant Jackson, professor emeritus of English at the University of Maine at PortlandGorham, died at the Maine Medical Center in Portland Saturday. He was 69 years old.

title: A Returned Favor Gets a Stranded Motorist Going
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 2Avid tennis players will understand why Richard Marra got stuck in the snow this morning.

title: E. Chester Peet, 73, Dies
description: E. Chester Peet, a former vice president for finance who retired in 1972 as a director of the Shell Oil Company, died Sunday in the Bahamas. He was 73 years old and lived also at 847 Sasco Hill Road, Southport, Conn.

title: Snowstorm Extends Time For Car License Renewal
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2 (AP) Motorists stranded at home by today's nearblizzard got a second 24hour extension of their drivers' licenses from the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Books of The Times
description: Which. are the most enthralling pages of Richard Rlugees Simple Justice: The History of Brown v. Board of Education and Black America's Struggle for Equality? My own favorites happen to be those that evoke the tension, cautious optimism, and camaraderie that fused the members of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. during the long summer of 1953.

title: U.S. Denies Involvement
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The White House and the State Department issued statements today denying reports. that the United States Government was financing the recruiting in Brittain or elsewhere of mercenaries to fight with westernbacked forces in the Angola civil war.

title: MOYNIHAN RESIGNS POST AT THE U.N., CITES HARVARD JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Daniel P. Moynihan resigned today. as the United States representative to the United Nations.

title: Cal Hubbard Joins a 3d Hall of Fame
description: Cal Hubbard, who gained the professional and college football Halls of Fame on the strength of his playing ability, was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday for his umpiring, marking the first time anyone ever has gained such recognition in both snorts.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Symphony No. 1. RimskyKorsakov; Organ Concerto in E flat, Bach; Divertimento in D, Mozart.

title: Stuyvesant Students Protest 13 Layoffs
description: About 250 Stuyvesant High School students, defying the frigid weather that kept many city pupils away from school, demonstrated in front of the high school yesterday to protest the loss of the equivalent of 13 teacher jobs.

title: ExBoston School Leader Is Acquitted
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2  A former member of the Boston School Committee, Paul J. Ellison, was found not guilty today in Suffolk County Superior Court on five counts of attempting to incite perjury.

title: Out in the Cold
description: The suddenness with which yesterday's storm swept over the metropolitan area greatly aggravated the disruptions normally caused even by less unexpected snowfall. Lashing winds and poor visibility hampered early morning efforts to keep highways open, and thousands of commuters on the region's railroads found their journeys stretched by two or three hours.

title: Sammartino Is Victor
description: Bruno Sammartino, the Worldwide Wrestling Federation heavyweight champion, squared accounts with Billy Graham by winning their return match last night in Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 25,600, including 3,100 watching on closed circuit television in the Felt Forum, saw Sammartino inflict several cuts on the forehead of the challenger. Referee Danny Bartfield halted the match at 17:55.

title: Dollar Off Sharply In Europe as Gold Rises $2 an Ounce
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 2 (UPI)The dollar fell sharply on European money markets today, reaching 12week lows in Frankfurt and Amsterdam, while a revived interest in gold buoyed the price by $2 an ounce.

title: Racing, Nets Game Postponed
description: Yesterday's sudden snowstorm and the hazardous driving conditions that it created severely disrupted the horse racing schedule in the East. The storm also forced the postponement of the New York Nets pro basketball game against the Denver Nuggets.

title: College Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Presidential Candidates May Escape Fund Limit Candidates for President May Escape Outlay Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The active Presidential candidates, all held by the Supreme Court last week to strict 1976 campaign spending limits, may escape them entirely if Congress does not revive the Federal Election Commission.

title: Alabama 69, Georaia 67
description: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 2 (AP) Tommy Bonds poured in two 18foot jumpers in the final 19 seconds to force an overtime, and Anthony Murray tallied three field goals in the extra period tonight as 11thranked Alabama defeated Georgia, 6967 in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: $29 Million A.T.&T.Libel Suit Is Expected to Go to Trial Soon
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 2  A multimillion  dollar libel suit filed against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by a dismissed Southwestern Bell Telephone Company executive and the family of a Bell vice president whose suicide note spurred an A.T.&T. investigation is likely to go to trial before the end of March.

title: Most Banks Are Increasing Reserves for Loan Losses
description: The massive losses experienced by many banks on bad loans in the last year have resulted in a fundamental change in the method of providing for these losses as mandated by Federal bank regulators.

title: Aspin Gets Leverage With Press Releases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 You're a junior member of a Committee and you don't have the leverage of a subcommittee or committee chairman, so what do you do?

title: Dress Industry and Union Agree on 23 Percent Raise
Amtrak to Cut Fares 25% On Some Northeast Service
description: PHILADELPHIA, (AP)Amtrack wil cut ticket prices by 25 per cent on round trips in the Northeast corridor between Boston and Washington starting Feb. 15.

title: Murder Charge Is Dropped In the Slaying of Miranda
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., (AP)The authorities dropped a murder charge tonight that had been lodged against a man in the slaying of Ernesto Miranda, but the suspect remained in Maricopa County Jail, accused of being an illegal alien.

title: N.B.A. Team Owners Vote To Bar Merger With A.B.A.
Defense Sums Up at Carson's Trial Here
description: A defenses lawyer at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson summed up yesterday, stating:

title: IRAN MAY REDUCE U.S. ARMS BUYING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Iran, the Pentagon's largest foreign customer, is threatening to cut back its arms purchases because of the rising cost of weapons and a drop in oil revenues.

title: Notes on People
description: The House of Commons elected a new Speaker yesterday to succeed 71yearold Selwyn Lloyd, a Conservative member and former Foreign Secretary, who retired after five years.

title: PRISCILLA PORTER
description: Priscilla Alden Laing Porter, wife of Dr. Lowrie J. Porter, a retired dentist and past president of the New York Academy of Dentistry and American Association of Orthodontists, died Monday at their home on Buckfield Lane in Greenwich, Conn. She was 74 years old.

title: As Carter Moves Into the Limelight, He Becomes Highly Visible and Vulnerable
New Corrections Head
description: There are reports from Albany that Governor Carey's nomination of Herman Schwartz to be chairman of the revamped State Commission of Correction is in trouble in the State Senatewhich is astonishing in view of Mr. Schwartz's outstanding qualifications for the job.

title: GRAINS ADVANCE IN A LATE RALLY
description: A lastminute rally sent prices of grains and soybeans higher yesterday after a session marked by declining prices.

title: United Technologies Lifts Net by 25.2% for a Record
New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne said yesterday he might ask the New Jersey Supreme Court to redistribute immediately the current amount of money available for state aid to school districts next year. Mr. Byrne said that if the court held to the deadlines set forth in its recent opinion only chaos would result.

title: Market Place
description: Investors are becoming increasingly aware of two relatively new means of providing for financial wellbeing their own or their heirs.

title: Accord Reached in Ottawa On Canadian Digest Edition
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 3 (AP) Canada's revenue minister announced today that Government officials and publishers of Reader's Digest had reached an agreement that would permit the magazine's Canadian edition to have the status of a Canadian publication.

title: State Commerce Chief Sets Task Force on Stock Tax
description: John S. Dyson, New York State Commissioner of Commerce, announced yesterday the formation of a securities industry task force to advise Governor Carey on the concerns of the industry. Its first project, Mr. Dyson said, would he to work on legislation related to the stock transfer tax.

title: A Freed Dissident Says Soviet Doctors Sought to Break His Political Beliefs
Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The Senate moved today to close debate and then voted 70 to 13 to adopt a Housepassed bill that would permit open production by American rice growers. Final pasage came shortly after the Senate voted 70 to 19 to invoke cloture on the measure, which would suspend ricemarketing quotas and lift restrictions on rice growing by new producers.

title: Welcome Wind Sends Mercury Soaring to 27
description: West winds brought warming temperatures yesterday to help the New York metropolitan area recover from Monday's sudden snowstorm and ice storm, but tenant complaints of breakdown of heating systems in apartments and businesses poured in at a high rate.

title: Primary Ballot In Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 3 (UPI) Governor Wallace and Senator) Bentsen led the Democratic candidates filing for places on the Texas Presidential primary ballot for May 1.

title: Slates for Wisconsin Ballot
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 3The Wisconsin Presidential primary selection committee nominated nine Democrats and two Republicans today for placement on the preferential primary ballot April 6.

title: PENTAGON BUDGET REPORTED PADDED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Pentagon's budget request for the fiscal year 1977 has been padded by $3 billion as a cushion against expected Congressional cuts, according to a memorandum prepared in the President's Office of Management and Budget.

title: Aspirants for the Senate Profess Little Concern About Moynihan
description: The Democrats who want to run for United States Senator from New Yorka group that for the most part cultivates an antipolitics image expressed little public concern yesterday about the possibility that Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who enjoys an image as a nonpolitician, might run for the job, too.

title: KISSINGER WARNS OF COSTS IF TALKS ON ARMS CURB FAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that failure to achieve a new SovietAmerican agreement curbing strategic arms could mean that the United States would have to spend as much as $20 billion more to build up its strategic forces over the next five years.

title: It's Hot Chocolate Weather: Give the Real Thing a Try
3 Are Accused of Holding Mother and 2 Daughters
description: Three brothers were arrested and accused of holding for 14 hours a mother and her two young daughters in their Bronx apartment and attempting to extort $10,000 from the father.

title: 3 to Share Top Billing In Hope Golf
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 3Jack Nicklaus, who ran up a devastating 82 in his last competition round nine days ago, has a chance to wipe the egg off his face in a fiveday tournament that begins here tomorrow.

title: Fire Kills Syosset Woman
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Feb. 3 (UPI) a 67yearold woman reported a fire in her home here and then died trying to extinguish it, officials reported. Volunteer firemen said they found the women, Frances Rinaldo, in a groundfloor utility room at the rear of her home at 500 Woodbury way.

title: Gunmen Seize 30 French Children in Eastern Africa
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Feb. 3 (AP)Four gunmen seized 30 French children and their driver today and held them hostage aboard a hijacked school bus, demanding that France grant immediate independence to this small eastern African territory.

title: Harry Kelly, Physicist 67,
description: Harry C. Kelly, a physicist who served as provost of North Carolina State University from 1962 to 1974, died Monday evening, apparently, of a heart attack, in Raleigh, N. C. He was 67 years old.

title: Excerpts From Statement by Dissident on His Detention in Soviet Mental Hospital
description: PARIS, Feb. 3Following are excerpts from a statement issued in Russian, French and English today by Leonid I. Plyushch, a dissident Ukrainian mathematileased after more than two years in a Soviet mental hospital.

title: BAR GROUP SCORES DISCIPLINE SYSTEM
description: In a report highly critical of existing procedures, a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended yesterday that major changes be made in the way lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx are disciplined.

title: Spartan President Assures Backers
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 3 (UPI)The president of Michigan State Clifton R. Wharton Jr., assured the university's financial supporters today that the school was taking steps to restore the good name of Spartan athletics.

title: An Astronaut Quietly Makes Mark in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3As the sandyhaired man in a well  tailored suit walked briskly across the Senate floor this week, an audible murmur swept through the tourist galleries.

title: BAR GROUP SCORES DISCIPLINE SYSTEM; Faster, Expanded Inquiries Urged HereNonlawyers Would Participate in Plan; Bar Group Scores System For Disciplining Lawyers
description: In a report highly critical of existing procedures, a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended yesterday that major changes be made in the way lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx are disciplined.

title: Spurs 118, Pacers 112
A Decade of Mrs. Gandhi: Evolution of Full Control
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 3Ten years ago a shy and lonely woman took the reins of government in the world's second most populous country with a promise to try to be a worthy servant of this great people.

title: First Jersey Card Draws 6,173 Fans
description: Leonard Pearlstein's Jaunty Jack staved off a closing rush by Irish Highball yesterday and scored a twolength victory in the feature race at Garden State Park, where New Jersey's 300day thoroughbred racing season opened. It was the first victory in three starts this year for Jaunty Jack, who was ridden by Juan Torres. Jaunty Jack raced the six furlongs in 1:113/5 and paid $9.40, $4.80 and $2.40 for $2 across the board. Irish Highball returned $4 and $2.40 and Dance King, the 35 favorite in the sevenhorse field, was $2.20 to show.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Although profit taking held the averages down for much of the day, most stock prices climbed yesterday in continued active trading. Buying in the final halfhour pushed the averages slightly ahead on the day.

title: Lawsuit Opposes Lending Public School Teachers
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3 (AP)Judge Raymond J. Pettine of Federal District Court denied a petition yesterday for a temporary restraining order to slop assignment of public school teachers in East Providence and Central Falls to Roman Catholic schools.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: RAY ASKS FOR TRIAL IN DR. KING'S DEATH
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 3 (UPI) ames Earl Ray contends he did not shoot the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., says his guilty plea was illegally coerced and wants a trial, an attorney for Mr. Ray argued before a Federal appeals court today.

title: 25 Drown in Philippines
description: MANILAFeb. 2 (AP) About 25 people were believed. to have drowned when their bus crashed into the Hinohan river in the Central Philippines about 300 miles south of Manila. The Evening Express reported here. The paper said 15 people swam to the river banks.

title: Amex Seat Price Rises
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday a seat was sold for $47,000, up $2,000 from the last sale on January 28. The exchange said the current market is $46,000 bid, $50,000 offered.

title: Work Without Pay Set in Mozambique As Economy Falters
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Attendance Down, Betting Up in State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3 (UPI)Although attendance was down, a longer racing season and offtrack betting helped raise the state's share of horse racing revenues to record levels in 1975, the Tax Commissioner, James H. Tully Jr., said today. The state netted $192.9 million on horse racing in 1975, Tully said, up $3 million from 1974.

title: A Freed Dissident Says Soviet Doctors Sought to Break His Political Beliefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 3Leonid I. Plyushch, a dissident mathematician recently released from a Soviet mental hospital, described today the attempts he said had been made there since 1972 to break down his political beliefs.

title: SIX MAYORS VOW TO FIGHT AID CUT
description: The Mayors of New York State's six largest cities vowed yesterday to present a united front in seeking to persuade the Legislature not to accept Governor Carey's proposed $371 million cut in aid to localities in the coming fiscal year.

title: ABC MAY BE HURT BY THE OLYMPICS
description: With at least 20 fewer affiliated stations than either of the other networks, ABCTV has traditionally been the thirdplace network in primetime competition. But this season it has tied NBCTV for second place, has been the leader in the national ratings for the last three weeks and seems headed for its best season in at least 10 years.

title: Women Voters Plan 5 Televised Forums In Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3With the blessings of the Republican and Democratic National Chairmen, the League of Women Voters said today that it would sponsor five televised forums across the country in which Presidential candidates would be asked to appear and speak on specific issues.

title: Seaport Building Dating to 1772 Burns
description: The city's oldest commercial building, constructed for a sea captain in 1772, has been seriously damaged by a fire believed to have been started accidentally by derelicts living on the ground floor.

title: Protest Group Hails Aid for Reopening Of 7 City Libraries
description: Public officials and private citizens who had been fighting to keep seven branches of the New York Public Library open received the news of victory with, guarded expressions of joy yesterday.

title: For Italy's Top Party, Reform Would Help More Than Dollars
Article 2  No Title
Stirrings in Poland
description: Five years have now passed since the turbulent period in which massive riots by Polish workers forced the ouster of Wladyslaw Gomulka as Communist Party chief and his replacement by Edward Gierek. Major concessions made to the populace at that time permitted restoration of order, and an oppressive quiet has dominated the Polish scene ever since.

title: Article 3  No Title
Senator Discloses Names
Talks on Constitution Reopen On a Positive Note in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 3Northern Ireland's feuding politicians began another attempt today to reach agreement on a new form of constitution for the province.

title: Campaigns Unlimited
description: By abolishing all restraints on political expenditures by individuals and organizations, the Supreme Court in its decision last week opened wide the doors to a return of the evils that the 1974 Federal Campaign Reform Law was intended to prevent.

title: Clash Is Reported
description: LUANDA, Angola, Feb. 3 A spokesman for the Popular Movement forces said today that they had beaten back an attempt by a column of white mercenaries to advance southward from a point near the Zaire border.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Labels Soon May Tell How Much Liquid Comes With the Peas
description: With nutrition labeling now in effect, the next step toward letting consumers know what they're getting in food stores is likely to be drained weight.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3The consumer agency that Congress created three years ago, which is now staffed by hundreds and financed by a multimilliondollar budget, exercised its legal authority for the first time last month to issue a set of safety standards for industryspecific requirements for the construction of swimmingpool slides.

title: Nigeria to Get a New Capital And Seven Additional States
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 3 (Reuters)  Gen. Murtala Muhammed, the Nigerian head of state, announced today that a new national capital would he established in the center of the country and that seven new states would be created, making a total of 19.

title: Zoning Trial Opens for 23 Municipalities
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 3Twenty  three Middlesex County municipalities went on trial today in a court action by civil rights organization and five individuals to bar zoning regulations they say exclude housing for minorities and lowincome families.

title: Rights Leader, Victim of Crash, Being Buried Today in Georgia
Can the Future Be Repealed?
description: LUXEMBOURGAlmost every important new invention this century brings with itor threatens to bring grave human, economic, political and strategic problems that could alter existing society.

title: FRANK B. POWERS, 63, OF SCRIPPSHOWARD
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 3 (UPI)Frank B. Powers, former general business manager of the ScrippsHoward newspapers, died here today in a hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: U.S. Death Rate in '74 Lowest on Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The, United States had a lower death rate in 1974 than in any year since records were begun in 1900, according to final figures released today by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Montclair Group Protests School Cuts
Nassau Executive Seeks $2.1 Million For a Rifle Range
description: MINEOLA, LI., Feb. 3Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, said today that he would ask approval for the county to build a pistol and rifle range at a cost of $2.1 million.

title: Connors Looking To Change Image
Reaction to the Budget Message Is Mixed
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3Governor Byrne's halfhour budget message to a joint session of the Legislature drew mixed reactions from the assembled lawmakers and from about 150 residents of MontClair who had come to Trenton protest proposed cuts in state aid to education.

title: Byrne's Fiscal Gamble
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3Governor Byrne is taking a calculated gamble by offering a sharply pared state budget that he hopes will create grassroots pressure on the State Legislature to enact a graduated state income tax. If the service cuts made by the Governor do not ignite the anticipated backfire, Mr. Byrne may have proved to everyone's satisfaction but his own that the state can get by without an income tax.

title: Despite Rigors, Buddhism Continues to Win Adherents in U.S.
description: Seated on small cushions, the 10 newcomers to the Zen Studies Center at 223 East 67th Street wrestled themselves into the full lotus position, or a variation thereof, and listened to their instructor, a blackrobed lay monk with a shaved head.

title: People in Sports
description: Dock Ellis, who has been unhappy about a lot of things in his career and never afraid to talk about them, said he was glad to be sent to New York after signing his contract with the Yankees yesterday. The 6foot3inch, 195pound righthander acquired from the Pittsburgh Pirates along with Willie Randolph, a second baseman, and Ken Brett, a lefthander, in exchange for George [Doc] Medich signed for one year for about $80,000. Randolph, who played at Samuel Tilden High in Brooklyn, also signed a oneyear pact for $20,000.

title: Burns Says Fed Trims Its Growth Goal For Nation's Money Supply During 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board disclosed to Congress today a slight reduction in the lower. end of the Reserve's target range for growth of the nation's money supply during 1976, but said it implied no change in monetary policy.

title: INJURED WALLACE BACK IN CAMPAIGN
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3His badly sprained right leg in a cast, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama flew back to Florida tonight to resume a Presidential campaign swing interrupted yesterday when an aide stumbled and dropped him as he was being transferred from his wheelchair to an airplane.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Associated Press incorrectly reported in a London dispatch printed in The New York Times on Jan. 21 that the clock above Britain's Houses of Parliament had been stopped so that the room that houses its mechanism could he repainted. Only the chimes of Big Ben were stopped. The clock kept running.

title: Lindstrom, Hubbard and Connor
description: One day in 1920 James T. Farrell, who had not then created Studs Lonigan,: Danny O'Neill, GasHouse McGinty or any of his other fictional characters, was trying out for the St. Cyril High baseball team in Jackson Park on Chicago's South Side. At the far end of the same field, Hyde Park High was playing Tilden Tech in a league game. The crowd standing around and watching, Jim wrote many years later, kept growing as park stragglers and pedestrians came to the sidelines. and among the odd group of high school students and miscellaneous men there was a growing and even electrified excitement. Playing shortstop for Tilden Tech was a 15yearold boy who still wore knee pants and long black stockings. This kid was making sensational plays and the crowd was. swelling not so much to see the game itself as to watch him. We stopped practice and also watched. The kid's name, I learned, was Lindstrom.

title: From a Royal Kitchen, a Festive Taste of Africa via Brazil; Brazil's Feijoada.; (Cont'd)
Article 1  No Title
Harrisburg Suspect Charged
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 3 (UPI)Frank D. Newberry, 43, of Philadelphia, was charged with setting a general alarm fire that destroyed the fivestory New Plaza Hotel in center city early today and injured about nine persons. The fire was set, said Fire Chief Charles Henry, I have no doubt of it.

title: UTILITIES IN PACT ON NUCLEAR FUEL
description: A group of electrical utilities that recently sued the Westinghouse Electric Corporation over its cancellation of contracts to supply them with uranium to fire their nuclear power plants, reached agreement late last night in Richmond, Va. on a plan to divide among themselves 14.9 million pounds of uranium that Westinghouse said it has in inventory or on order.

title: Reserve Says List of Banks Under Surveillance Grows
British Detain Mercenaries
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP)British policemen, acting on a tip that armed mercenaries bound for Angola were assembling in London, detained 160 men tonight but freed them when they were found to have no weapons. Scotland Yard said it questioned the men for 90 minutes.

title: About New York
description: Danilova was teaching, evoking the Imperial Ballet and the Romanovs, the Ballet Russe and Diaghilev. Danilova was bowing her head, stamping her feet and putting her arms in front of her face in a way that was supposed to make you think of the steppes. It did. Danilova was passing on the things she knew.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1976

title: Gas Deregulation
description: Long before the energy crisis the debate over deregulation of natural gas prices raged stormily, stirring high emotions, demagogueries and mutual deceptions, and with literally billions of dollars at stake. Abruptly and with scarcely a pretense of proper parliamentary Procedures, this twodecade debate all but expired yesterdayto the clear elation of the gas industry.

title: INTEREST RATES SHOW INCREASES
Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: City Offered Regional Planning Views
description: An official of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority called for a regional transportation tax to close masstransit deficits and subsidize a 25cent subway fare; a young researcher proposed a nofare subway system financed by a valueadded realestate tax and the chairman of a Bronx community planning board urged banks to help form apartment residents into sociological entities as a step toward obtaining rehabilitation loans.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1976

title: William A. Welch, 61, Dies;
description: William Addams Welch, a radio and television writer of more than 500 television plays and as many radio scripts, died Monday in Hollywood. He was 61 years old.

title: KISSINGER WARNS OF COSTS IF TALKS ON ARMS CURB FAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that failure to achieve a new SovietAmerican agreement curbing strategic arms could mean that the United States would have to spend as much as $20 billion more to build up its strategic forces over the next five years.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  of  the street regulations arc normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply. The snow emergency, requiring snow tires and chains on certain streets, has been lifted.

title: Head of Oil Shale Corp. Resigns
description: The resignation of H. I. Koolsbergen as chief executive officer of the Oil Shale Corporation of Los Angeles was announced yesterday. He also is the company's chairman.

title: City Will Halt Work On 8 Projects Today If Albany Bill Stalls
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3New York City officials said today that they would halt construction on eight financially ailing housing projects tomorrow afternoon if a bill allowing continuation of the work remained stalled in the Senate.

title: WILLIAM W. FIRMAN
description: William W. Firman, vicepresident in charge of marketing for ABCTV, died Saturday at Stamford (Conn,) Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old.

title: Pentagon Suspends Northrop Payment Gulf and Phillips Petroleum Cited in Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The Defense Department has temporarily suspended payment on certain Northrop Corporation contracts while it audits the company's books seeking improper use of Government funds, Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. said today.

title: ELECTION AID ROLE SOUGHT FOR G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3A move to prevent any interruption in Federal election campaign subsidies to candidates and conventions by transferring authority to pay them to the Comptroller General began today under bipartisan sponsorship.

title: Despite Rigors, Buddhism Continues to Win Adherents in U.S.
description: Seated on small cushions, the 10 newcomers to the Zen Studies Center at 223 East 67th Street wrestled themselves into the full lotus position, or a variation thereof, and listened to their instructor, a blackrobed lay monk with a shaved head.

title: Consumer Group Says Caffeine Poses Peril to Pregnant Women
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Citing tests that show the offspring of animals fed caffeine suffer higher rates of birth defects, a consumer group has urged the Government to warn pregnant women vigorously but with delicacy to lower their coffee consumption.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Associated Press incorrectly reported in a London dispatch printed in The New York Times on Jan. 21 that the clock above Britain's Houses of Parliament had been stopped so that the room that houses its mechanism could be repainted. Only the chimes of Big Ben were stopped. The clock kept running.

title: Colby, In Out of the Cold, Discusses C.I.A.'s Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3One week after the Senate's confirmation of George Bush as Director of Central Intelligence ended William E. Colby's 25 year career as a spy, Mr. Colby relaxed in the sitting. room of his modest suburban home and talked about the elephant.

title: MUSKIE PONDERS HUMPHREY STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that his 1968 runningmate, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, was the best bet to win the Democratic Presidential nomination this year, but that Mr. Humphrey had yet to demonstrate that he retained the leadership ability he had eight years ago.

title: Americans Top Yugoslavia Russians Win
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 3 (AP)A young and determined United States hockey team defeated Yugoslavia, 8 4, tonight to enter the Olympic medal tournament and begin to dream the impossible dream of beating the heavily favored Soviet Union.

title: Chrysler Reaches Pact to End Strike At Glasgow Plant
description: LONDON, Feb. 3  The Chrysler Corporation and militant Scottish workers reached agreement late tonight on terms to end a weeklong wildcat strike that threatened to undermine the British Government's $335 million rescue of the company's troubled subsidiary here.

title: Doomsday Is Coming at 7:32 A.M., Jan. 2, 2000 (6:32 A.M., Central Standard Time)
description: MONTGOMERY, ALA.

title: Moynihan's Decision
description: Daniel P. Moynihan's decision to resign as United States representative at the United Nations is attributed to a conclusion that he lacked the support of Secretary Kissinger. Page 12.

title: About Education
description: Efforts by the State Education Department to suspend the doctoral programs in English and history at the State University Center at Albany have forced educational and political leaders to confront some fundamental questions about who has the power to determine what is taught in state universities.

title: 8CENT LETTER RATE URGED BY POSTMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) A group representing 50,000 letter carriers called today for a rollback in the cost of mailing a letter from 13 cents to eight.

title: Books of The Times
description: We are so accustomed to seeing clearly defined photographs of large land and sea areas, ranging from chunks of continents to the planet itself (thanks to moon shots and space probes), that it takes an effort to realize the enormous difficulty involved a couple of centuries ago in charting the course of even a single river. Sanche de Gramont's chronicle of the adventures surrounding those who triedoften hopelessly to follow the course of the river Niger in west Africa is a case in point.

title: Secure the Refuges
description: An important and longoverdue bill to give greater protection to the National Wildlife Refuge System is about to be debated and voted on by the Senate. It provides that none of the more than 360 refuges may be abolished or transferred from the Fish and Wildlife Service to any other Federal or state agency without express approval of Congress.

title: Director of Hospital Fund Says 2,800 Beds Must Go in the City
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The president of the United Hospital Fund of New York said today that 2,800 hospital beds in the city should be eliminated to help solve the financial and managerial crisis facing the city's healthcare institutions

title: Simple Games Planned by Innsbruck
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 3The Hapsburgs ruled this provincial capital of the Tyrol, Napoleon's troops fought here and tomorrow, 12 years after the ninth Winter Games were held here, the 12th Olympic Winter Games will open in this ancient town of medieval walls, narrow alleys and Baroque churches.

title: Cut in Iran Oil Revenues Forces a Budget Deficit
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 3The economic growth rate of Iran, which has suffered a sharp drop in oil revenues, has shrunk by 60 percent since last spring and its budget envisages a deficit of $2.4 billion in the next 12 months, the country's chief planner reported today.

title: City Will Halt Work On 8 Projects Today If Albany Bill Stalls
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3New York City officials said today that they would halt construction on eight financially ailing housing projects tomorrow afternoon if a bill allowing continuation of the work remained stalled in the Senate.

title: Piano Skill Is Displayed By Atamian
description: Most music competitions in this city are won by young artists who are polishing their studies with one of the major teachers here. Last year, however, the piano division of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's annual contest ended with the first prize going to Dickran Atamian, a pupil of John Perry at the University of Texas in Austin.

title: Experts Rush to Create Unified City Accounting
description: Working under intense pressure, a small group of city bureaucrats and borrowed experts is rushing to create what may be the most undramatic yet revolutionary of all the changes wrought by the fiscal crisisa unified modern accounting system.

title: African Writer Reported Under Arrest in Ghana
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Feb. 3 (UPI)Kofi Awoonor, one of Africa's best known writers and an assistant professor of English at New York State University in Stony Brook, is under arrest in Ghana, according to word received today by the university's English department. Mr. Awoonor is a Ghanaian.

title: Mrs. Trudeau Replies on Radio to Critics of Tour
description: OTTAWA. Feb. 3Margaret Trudeau, the wife of Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau, telephoned an openline radio show today with a spirited defense of her controversial defiance of diplomatic protocol during the couple's official 11day tour of Mexico, Venezuela and Cuba.

title: CHRYSLER TO BUY EUROPEAN PARTS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would buy fourcylinder engines and axletransmissions from the Volkswagen company for Chrysler's 1978 model subcompact, which will have a frontwheel drive.

title: Better Times for Udall
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3It looks as if they may have buried Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona too soon.

title: Trudeau Says He Urged Castro To Get Out of Angola
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 3Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that he had urged Prime Minister Fidel Castro to remove Cuban troops from Angola, calling the intervention a serious mistake that would harm both Cuba and Africa.

title: Blacks Said to Total 97% Of Pupils Bused in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Feb. 3 (UPI) Nolan Estes, independent school district superintendent in Dallas, admitted under questioning today that 97 percent of the pupils bused in the system since 1971 have been black, many being taken long distances to schools already having a black majority. His statement came during the second day of hearings in Federal District Court on plans to desegregate Dallas schools.

title: 4 Americans Toppled in First Round
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 2 (AP)Mark Cox of Britain defeated Stan Smith, 63, 76, in the opening round of a World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today at the indoor Sports Palace.

title: Man Plunges to His Death From the Empire State Observation Deck
Japanese Teachers Resisting Plan To Tighten Supervision Over Them
description: TOKYO, Feb. 3The Ministry of Education and the Japan Teachers Union, the two most powerful forces in Japanese education, are locked in a controversy over a proposal to increase the supervision of teachers.

title: THAIS SAID TO AGREE ON 3,000 U.S. TROOPS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 3 (AP)The Thai and United States Governments have tentatively agreed that about 3,000 American military advisers will remain in Thailand after the March 20 deadline for withdrawal of all American forces from the country, official Thai sources said today.

title: Albert Drieu, Among First Of City's Aerial Policemen
description: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Feb. 3 (AP)Albert Drieu, one of New York City's first aerial policemen, died yesterday at his home here.

title: Health Care Cost Rise Is Said to Lead Field
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Health care costs increased faster in 1975 than did any other category of American consumer spending. Congress was told today.

title: For Marymount, a Night of Glitter
description: Everyone talked about the weather Monday night at the Golden JubiLee gala of the Marymount School of New York. Well, almost everyone. Not Sister Genevieve Toner.

title: Byrne's Budget May Require New Taxes
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3Governor Byrne presented a $2.762 billion budget today, and recommended a spending and taxreform plan that could require a billion dollars or more in new levies.

title: MURDER CASE GAG IS APPEALED TO U.S.
description: Lawyers for the defendant in a Connecticut murder trial asked a Federal appeals court here yesterday for a reduction of bail and the removal of an order that bars participants in the case from making public statements about it.

title: SkiRace Courses Declared Perfect
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 3My deepest hope is that it does not snow.

title: Cut in Iran Oil Revenues Forces a Budget Deficit
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 3The economic growth rate of Iran, which has suffered a sharp drop in oil revenues, has shrunk by 60 percent since last spring and its budget envisages a deficit of $2.4 billion in the next 12 months, the country's chief planner reported today.

title: Hepburn Is Center of Gravity
description: They say that to understand is to forgive, but I am not sure that I understood Enid Bagnold's new play, A Matter of Gravity, which opened at the Broadhurst Theater last night, not so much starring Katherine Hepburn as enshrining her. Miss Hepburn with her radiantly raddled beauty, her grace and meticulous theatrical sensibilityshown in the jerk of an eyebrow, the twitch of a corner of the mouthis per fectly remarkable. And if she occasionally looks puzzled, if her voice falters, ever so slightly, in a morass of half epigramswhy not? But she did presumably choose the playor perhaps the play chose her, for she is almost its only virtue.

title: No Strings Attached
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan's departure from the United Nations gives us an opportunity to reexamine a basic issue: Should the United States determine its foreign policies on the basis of whether they are right and just, rather than merely politically expedient?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The jury in the Shelton, Conn., firebombing case yesterday found one defendant guilty of illegal transportation of explosives and possession of an unregistered firebomb firearm and exonerated another defendant of charges of possession of an unregistered firearm. Peter Betres. 55 years old, was found guilty on the explosives and unregistered firearm charges, each of which carries imprisonment penalties of up to 10 years and fines of $10,000. His cousin, Ronald Betres, 33, was found not guilty on the firearm charge.

title: Rail Accident Kills One
description: WARD, Ark., Feb. 3 (UPI) A MissouriPacific train struck derailed units of another MoPac train early today near this Lonoke County town, killing one person and injuring two others. J. D, McCormick, MoPac general superintendent, said names of the victims were being withheld until relatives were notified.

title: Advertising
description: Charles J. Prince is an agency man who feels so strongly about the aggressive pursuit of new business that he once quit his job because his management would not set up a newbusiness program.

title: Injury to Fetuses Is Traced in Study To Vinyl Chloride
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP The wives of men who work with vinyl chloride are twice as likely to have miscarriages or stillbirths, probably because the chemical causes spermcell damage in their husbands, a Government study says.

title: Priest in Brooklyn Is Slain As 3 Try to Rob Rectory
description: Three men who pretended to seek information about a baptism shot a Roman Catholic priest to death yesterday in the rectory of a church in Brooklyn during a robbery attempt, the police reported.

title: Bridge:
Food Prices Decline Slightly
description: Food prices declined in the New York area last week after two weeks of significant price advances, and the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 1.3 percent on the week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Moynihan Said to Feel He Lacked Vital Support
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3Daniel P. Moynihan's decision to resign as United States representative at the United Nations is attributed to a conclusion that he lacked the support of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: A City Salt Spreader's Life: When It Snows He Pours
description: To Cecil Thomas, driving a vibrating, clanking saltspreading truck on icy Manhattan streets in 15degree weather is the easiest job in the department.

title: Oregon Teachers on Strike
description: ROSEBURG, Ore., Feb. 3 (UPI)Roseburg teachers went on strike today. The school board and the Roseburg Education Association have been trying to reach a new contract for a year. The main point of dispute was job protection to probationary teachers  those with less than three years of experience. Money has not been a main issue in negotiations.

title: ELIZABETH C. SEELY
description: Elizabeth Caven Seely, who was librarian of Sarah Lawrence College from 1941 to 1974, died Monday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. She was 70 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: CHRYSLER TO BIN EUROPEAN PARTS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would buy fourcylinder engines and axletransmissions from the Volkswagen company for Chrysler's 1978 model subcompact, which will have a frontwheel drive.

title: Bill to Make City Restore School Cuts Faces a Veto
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2The State Senate today passed and sent to a certain death on the Governor's desk a bill requiring New York City to restore millions in cuts in the school budget this spring.

title: Bureaucrats and Borrowed Experts Are Rushing to Create Unified Modern Accounting System for City
Carey Wants Port Agency to Aid Some City Projects
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Governor Carey said today that he would ask the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to use its borrowing power to complete some of the waterfront projects that New York City has suspended because of its fiscal situation.

title: Reserve Says List of Banks Under Surveillance Grows
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Federal Reserve official in charge of bank reguation testified today that there are now 63 bankholding companies receiving more than normal supervisory attention by the Reserve. A year ago, the figura was 35.

title: Byrne Budget May Need Billion From New Taxes
Excerpts From Kissinger Speech on Arms Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech given in San Francisco by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger on SovietAmerican relations.

title: Metropolitan Museum Seeks Parking Income
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opened an underground garage for visitors and some staff members in August 1974, has been soliciting longterm parking customers for 50 of the 472 spaces, a museum official said yesterday.

title: Virtues of Slow Growth
description: The burst of activity on Wall Street, which has carried the Dow industrials up more than 160 points since the first weeks of December, seems almost too good to be true to some investors. Do they dare look a gift horse in the mouth? And how does the soaring market  with volume averaging 30 million shares a dayaccord with the forecasts of most economists, including President Ford's own economic advisers, of rather sluggish overall economic growth and only slowly receding unemployment?

title: Fire Termed Suspicious
description: FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 3 (UPI)A fire marshal today termed as suspicious a blaze that forced the evacuation yesterday of 20 patients from the Northwestern Institute for Mental Health.

title: ZAIRE BARS ENTRY TO MERCENARIES
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 3 (AP)Zaire banned today any foreign mercenaries from passing through the country on the way to fight in Angola.

title: Boston Fire Laid to Arson
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)A $1 million fire that injured five persons, left 150 others homeless and required more men and equipment than any fire in the city's history was caused by arson, according to Fire Commissioner George Paul.

title: S.E.C. Investigating Cenco for Possibility of 2 Frauds
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of Cenco Inc. is centering on the possibility that the company may have been victimized in two apparently unrelated frauds.

title: Man Found Dead on Roof
description: A 36yearold resident of 258 West 117th Street, identified as Rodney Richardson, was found dead yesterday on the roof of the building. The cause of death remained undetermined pending a report from the Medical Examiner.

title: WINE TALK
description: The 1975 vintage in the Beaujolais country was one of the poorest in years, but you would never know it talking to wine men. They expect that it will continue their run of prosperity that began more than a decade ago when the rest of the world discovered Beaujolais wine.

title: SATELLITES TO AID SHIPS' MESSAGES
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3A maritime satellite system (Marisat) is scheduled to be inaugurated this month, opening a new era in communications for ships at sea.

title: Princeton Six Wins
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Flames, Islanders Again Tie
Amex Prices Rise As Volume Gains; Options Deals Up
description: The American Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday in active trading. For the fourth consecutive day the Amex market value index posted gain, rising by 0.37 to close at 97.04.

title: Elias Gilner, Author, Dies at 87;
description: Elias Gilner, an author and one of the founders of the Haganah, the Israeli resistance movement, died Monday in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Metika Freeman of Darcy Lane, Eastchester, N. Y. Mr. Gilner, whose home was at 630 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, was 87 years old.

title: Illegal Contributions to Campaigns Alleged
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 3The Attorney General of Texas filed civil suits today seeking a total of more than $1.4 million in damages from the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company for allegedly making illegal campaign contributions to Texas politicians over a 14year period.

title: U. S. Death Rate in '74 Lowest on Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The United States had a lower death rate in 1974 than in any year since records were begun in 1900, according to final figures released today by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Influence of Media Studied Closely as Campaigning Steps Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 One of the most conspicuous creatures in the political menagerie this election year is a foraging beast, of pronounced herd instincts, known as the media.

title: About Real Estate
FORD AIDES DROP INTERNES FOR 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The White House is suspending its summer interne program this year because of fears that using college students in an election year might be a violation of Federal campaign laws.

title: Clemson Beaten, 9789, By North Carolina State
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 3 (AP)Kenny Carr scored 38 points as he led North Carolina State to a 9789 victory over Clemson in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game tonight.

title: FORD SAYS COURT WENT TOO FAR ON ABORTION IN '73
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Ford said today that the Supreme Court went too far in striking down laws against abortion but that he was opposed to restoring abortion limits nationally through a constitutional amendment.

title: Error Found in Ruth's R.B.I.'s
description: Baseball's records committee has discovered, a clerical error in Babe Ruth's runbattedin total. The committee, appointed several months ago by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, therefore changed the slugger's total in 1926 from 155 to 145. It also found that mistakes pertaining to five of his home runs during the 192123 period had cost him five runs batted in. The adjustments placed his career total at 2,204, second to Hank Aaron, the leader with 2,262.

title: Three Political Killings Stir New Fears Over Jamaica's Course
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 3 Three men, one a policeman, were killed and several wounded yesterday in a new outbreak of violence by armed political gangs at a time of generally increasing tensions here.

title: Rams Drop Bid to Get Namath
description: When the National Football League season starts, Joe Namath will again be fighting the winds of Flushing. Queens, and will not, as he had hoped, be warmed by the southern California sun,

title: Tenafly Gets $500,000 to Save Palisades Tract
description: TENAFLY, Feb. 3A drive by residents of this community to raise $1.9 million needed to purchase the 274acre tract known as the East Hill property was buoyed today by a commitment of $500,000 from the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

title: HOUSE FIGHT WON BY GAS PRODUCERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Administration and natural gas producers won an important victory today when the House voted for immediate consideration of legislation to end Federal regulation of gas prices charged by producers.

title: Crane Chairman Is Critical Of AnacondaTenneco Deal
description: T. M. Evans, chairman of the Crane Company, which had sought to acquire the Anaconda Company, said yesterday that the proposed merger of Anaconda into Tenneco Inc. did not appear to be very attractive for Anaconda shareholders.

title: 10 Reported Dead and 1 Missing In Fire on the Upper West Side
description: Ten persons were reported dead and one missing in an earlymorning blaze today that swept through a sixstory tenement on the upper West Side.

title: Seaport Building Dating to 1772 Burns
description: The city's oldest commercial building, constructed for a sea captain in 1772, has been seriously damaged by a fire believed to have been started accidentally by derelicts living on the ground floor.

title: AGEDADVISORY UNIT SWORN IN BY BEAME
The Physicist as a SoftShoe Man
description: Physicists who produce dazzling theories made light of themselves and their profession last nightin a cabaret.

title: House Group Votes to Abolish Intelligence Unit in Pentagon
GOING OUT Guide
description: THAT VOICE The quavery, hightreble drawl of Butterfly McQueen made the actress's characterization of Prissy in Gone With the Wind as distinct and almost as wellknown as Vivien Leigh's Scarlett O'Hara. Surprisingly little is known about Miss McQueen personally, although she has also delighted audiences in other movies, such as Mildred Pierce and in the shopping sequence of The Women.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  of  the street regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply. The snow emergency, requiring snow tires and chains on certain streets has been lifted.

title: WOMAN INDICTED IN CHICAGO BLAZE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (UPI)A Cook County grand jury returned a 47count indictment today charging a 21yearold nurse's aide with arson and murder in the fire that killed 15 elderly residents of the Wincrest Nursing and Rest Home.

title: PENTAGON BUDGET REPORTED PADDED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Pentagon's budget request for the fiscal year 1977 has been padded by $3 billion as a cushion against expected Congressional cuts, according to a memorandum prepared in the President's Office of Management and Budget.

title: EARL RUSSELL BRAGG
description: Earl Russell Bragg, former president of the Central Worsted Company of Plainfield, Conn., a familyowned textile manufacturing concern, died yesterday in Chester, Conn., where he lived. He 85 years old.

title: MISS AYASHAH GIVES SOLO DANCE EVENING
description: Najma Ayashah's Evening of Entertainment Monday at the Cubiculo was strongest in its explorations of Kathek dance and its subtle rhythmic structures, though the program of solos included gypsy and Arabic dances as well. Miss Ayashah presented her performance with the assistance of Sabah Nissan as narrator.

title: Bank, 49.3% Owned By Delaware, in Red
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 3 While the Farmers Bank of the State of Delaware looks for $10 million to $20 million in state funds to bolster its sagging finances, virtually everyone else is looking for a scapegoat.

title: In Memoriam
description: LEVINERebecca. In loving memory of Rebecca And Harry J. Levine, always in our hearts.

title: Abortion Is Big Issue in the Primaries In Massachusetts and New Hampshire
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3So many of the candidates say they are personnally opposed to abortion, said Joseph Acorace, president of the New Hampshire Right to Life Committee. And then they inject that word but. They're trying to influence the prolife vote in their favor, but they don't want to earn it by taking a solid position for life.

title: Court Ruling Put Off On Giants Transfer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 The disposition of the San Francisco Giants, and therefore the shape of the National League, remained unresolved today after a 90minute hearing in Superior Court before Judge John Benson, who must decide whether to drop, extend or make permanent a restraining order that prevents completion of the club's sale and move to Toronto.

title: Rutgers Wins Fans Along With Games
description: More than a million persons saw the Monday night telecast of Rutgers 7562 victory over Princeton. The estimate came from Joe Gallagher, the producer of the local college basketball TV series, and was based on a WORTV survey compiled yesterday.

title: Stage: Phyllis Wheatley
description: Children's theater is seldom used, effectively, to educate or to inform. The goal is usually entertainment. When writers of children's theater contemplate significant events, such as moments in the nation's history, they tend to glamorize or to condescend.

title: GRANT SUPPLIERS FORMING A GROUP
description: Eight large suppliers of the W. T. Grant Company, concerned over the reluctance of many other producers to ship goods to Grant, have formed a committee to urge a larger flow of merchandise in the next 60 to 90 days.

title: Maazel Conducts the Cleveland Here
description: If heavenstorming is a conductor's line, what could be more appropriate for it than the Resurrection? Lorin Maazel led the Cleveland Orchestra in a fervent, sometimes perfervid, performance of Mahler's grandiloquent Symphony No. 2 at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. This is a work in which the willingness to take emotional chances is a prerequisite In any serious interpreter, and Mr. Maazel proved to be a chancetaker.

title: Miss Wade Victor
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 3 (AP)  Virginia Wade and Evonne Goolagong posted victories in the opening round of a $75,000 Virginia Slims tournament tonight, but secondseeded Martina Navratilova and three others lost bouts with the flu.

GOLD
