title: Moynihan's Decision
description: Daniel P. Moynihan's decision to resign as United States representative at the United Nations is attributed to a conclusion that he lacked the support of Secretary Kissinger. Page 12.

title: FINAL 36 CHOSEN FOR HEARST JURY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3  Seating of a jury and opening of Patricia Hearses bank robbery trial tomorrow was assured tonight with selection of a panel of 36 persons from whom 12 jurors and four alternates will be selected in the morning.

title: Zoning Suit Opens for 23 Jersey Municipalities
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb 3Twenty  three Middlesex County municipalities went on trial today in a court action by a civil rights organization and five individuals to bar zoning regulations they say exclude housing for minorities and low. income families.

title: MARGARET THOMSON, A CHINA MISSIONARY
description: Margaret Seabury Thomson, who with her late husband, Dr. James Claude Thomson, served for many years as educational missionaries in China, died Tuesday in South Kent, Conn., at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Julius E. Waller. She was 86 years old.

title: TV Spot Ads Selling Presidential Hopefuls in Primaries
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31  The selling of the President has begun for the 3.5 million adult viewers in the area reached by Boston's TV transmitters.

title: BOARD MAY DELAY TEACHER STEPUPS
description: The Board of Education is planning to delay salary stepups scheduled to be paid March 1 to 25,500 city teachers unless the board and the teachers' union can agree to a citymandated deferral of raises by early next week.

title: Angola Divides Cubans
Article 1  No Title
New RailroadAid Law: A Giant Step
description: When President Ford signs the Railroad Revitalization and Reform Act at the White House this afternoon, the Federal Government will be taking an irreversible further step into sponsorship and subsidization of the nation's rail system. Conceivably it could lead eventually to a management role and ownership.

title: Ford Will Restore Connally to Intelligence Board
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) President Ford will reappoint John B. Connally to the Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, Administration sources said today.

title: Opening Statements Offer 2 Pictures of Miss Hearst
Rumsfeld Denies Defense Budget Has $3 Billion in Cut Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld insisted today that the defense budget had not been padded by $3 billion as a cushion against Congressional cuts.

title: 100 Survivors of Fire Put Up in Hotels
Irene Worth Talks About Art, EnergyEven Acting
description: Once upon a time, great actresses were thought of as poor mindless parrots who could hardly stumble through a sentence once they got off the stage. Oysters and adulation kept them going through the supper hour; thereafter, shop talk and a small shut mind were all that could be expected.

title: State Senate Balks A City Housing Bill
Big Board Seat Price Rises
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $65,500, up $500 from the last sale on Feb. 2.

title: Zaire, in Cabinet Shakeup, Replaces Foreign Minister
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 4 (AP)President Mobutu Sese Seko today announced a Cabinet shakeup, including appointment of a new Foreign Minister.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE EVENING BREEZE charles De Forrest was holding forth at the piano bar of Tres Amici on a recent night. This is an attractive restaurant three doors north of 74th Street on Third Avenue, with a wide, beige canopy and clear, bright lettering out front. Inside, at 9:40 o'clock, latedining traffic moved steadily toward the rear, past the entrance bar and Mr. De Forrest's keyboard, which is stationed between two brick arches.

title: Kissinger Believes Cuba Exports Revolution Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has concluded that Cuba is again in the business of exporting revolution on its own initiative, this time to Angola, to the Sahara and perhaps elsewhere outside the hemisphere, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: Nonexistent Bingo Funds Linked to Killing of Priest
description: Robbers who killed a 76year old Capuchin priest in his friary in Brooklyn on Tuesday after noon may have been looking for the proceeds of a bingo game that was never heldan affair canceled Monday night because of the snowstorm.

title: Illiteracy Rises Despite UNESCO Effort
The Court on Politics
description: Ever since the passage of the 1974 campaign reform law, critics of the complex act have looked to the Supreme Court to cure what they regarded as its defects. There always seemed a certain irony in that: politicians and political commentators giving up on the political process and seeking salvation from judges on a highly political matter.

title: TV: Bridge to Gold, ABC's Fanfare for Olympics
description: ABCTV's twohour introduction to its scheduled marathon coverage of the Winter Olympics was an intriguing exercise in trying, sometmes desperately, to generate maximum interest and audience ratings. Presented at 9 o'clock Tuesday evening. Bridge to Gold touched every conceivable source of ballyhoo.

title: 2 TV DOCUMENTARIES ON CHINA ART LISTED
description: Two differing network versions of the show of archcological discoveries from China that recently toured United States museums will he broadcast on two consecutive days here, The Red Flower and the Green Horse, a CBS News special, will appear Stocky at 10 A.M., and Six Hundred Millennia:China's History Unearthed will be broadcast by Channel 13/WNET on Monday at 8 P.M.

title: 14 Arrests on Drugs
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 4 (UPI)  Fourteen persons, including Anne Karlen Shaw, the 21yearold daughter of the chairman of the state Republican Party, nave been arrested on drug charges resulting from three months of undercover work, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Grasso Budget Would End Tax on Business Services
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 4Gov, Ella T. Grasso today proposed a record $1.801 billion budget designed to provide a measure of relief to Connecticut's hardpressed business community and to hold the line against spending.

title: Reilly Hearing Is Told of Slain Woman's Feud With a Neighbor
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 4 A Superior Court judge was told here today that for months before she was murdered, 51 yearold. Barbara Gibbons had been involved in a feud with a neighbor over charges that he had had sexual relations with her son, Peter Reilly.

title: Personal Finance: Pitfalls of Installment Contracts
description: A woman bought a washing machine recently under an installment sales contract and found that it broke down repeatedly during the first two months. When the store that sold it refused to exchange it, she refused to continue paying for it. That's when her real troubles began.

title: Kodama's Background
description: Mr. Kodama, who was named in the Lockheed report, is regarded as one of the most powerful men in Japan. Now 65 years old, he was instrumental in founding Japan's governing LiberalDemocratic Party and has had a hand in naming several prime ministers. He has settled many disputes among businessmen and commands the loyalty of the ultra right wing in Japan.

title: CITY IS ACCUSED AS FIRE KILLS 10
description: An Upper West Side fire that killed 10 persons early yesterday quickly became a focus of controversy, with some survivors contending that the Fire Department had taken up to half an hour to respond to the alarm and Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan insisting that it had taken only three minutes.

title: Senate Confirms Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (Reuters)The Senate today confirmed James W. Hargrove, a 53yearold Texas financial consultant, as Ambassador to Australia. It also approved Albert B. Fay as Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago, Willard. A. Depree as Ambassador to Mozambique and Anthony Quainton as Ambassador to the Central African Republic.

title: Ford Authorizes Killing Of Kentucky Blackbirds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) President Ford signed a bill today authorizing the extermination of millions of blackbirds and starlings roosting within a 100mile radius of Fort Campbell, Ky., and a Federal judge refused to halt the extermination in a nearby Kentucky county.

title: A Regulator for Ford
description: The man who was nominated by President Ford yesterday to be a member of the Interstate Commerce Commissionand who will be appointed chairman if confirmed by the Senate  is apparently the President's kind of Republican. The liberals consider me a conservative and the conservatives consider me a liberal, Warren Bruce Rudman, a 45yearold lawyer, said yesterday. I consider myself a moderate Republican.

title: MARITIME FRUIT LAGS IN PAYING CREDITORS
description: The Maritime Fruit Carriers Company, an Israelbased shipping concern, announced yesterday that it had failed to pay $23.5 million of $88.5 million owed to banks and other creditors.

title: CONCORDE FLIGHTS TO U.S. APPROVED FOR 16 MONTHS; FOES RENEW CHALLENGES
Missile in Israel Operational
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 4Israel said today that Lance groundtoground missiles acquired from the United States were operational. Defense Minister Shimon Peres visited a Lance missile base, where he watched soldiers demonstrate the weapne.

title: Williams Makes Bond Plea
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4 (UPI)  William A. H. Williams, convicted of extortion in the kidnapping of Reg Murphy, former Atlanta Constitution editor, has asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to release him an $25,000 bond pending a new trial. Mr. Williams was convicted of extortion Aug. 3, 1974 and sentenced to 40 years in prison for the kidnapping. Last Nov. 28, the Appeals Court threw out his conviction.

title: CONCORDE FLIGHTS TO U.S. APPROVED FOR 16 MONTHS; FOES RENEW CHALLENGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Transportation Secretary. William T. Coleman Jr. ruled today, that France and Britain could operate limited service by the Concorde supersonic jet airliner to New York and Washington on a 16month trial basis.

title: For Children, Fun Is an Operetta With Real Musicians
The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
Stock Prices Climb To 27Month High
description: Fed by a broad demand for stocks varying from speculative to conservative, the market pushed ahead yesterday to its best level in 27 months. Trading volume of 38.27 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange ranked the third busiest session on record.

title: People in Sports
description: Cleon Jones, who became a free agent following his release by the New York Mets amid a flood of controversy last year, has agreed to report to the Chicago White Sox training camp at Sarasota, Fla., for a comeback attempt, the White Sox announced yesterday.

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS GAS DEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Representative Robert C. Krueger told the House today that enactment of his bill to end Federal regulation of producer prices of natural gas would raise the average residential gas bill for all of 1976 by $12.

title: A Long, Sad Day Is Marked at P.S. 75 After 4 of Its Pupils Are Killed in Fire
description: I remember Freddy, said Rafael Trinidad, a thirdgrader at Public School 75 on the Upper West Side. We used to play football together in the gym. Now he's just dead.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne announced in Newark a $1.2 million contract toward construction at Liberty State Park in Jersey City of a harborside recreation site that will offer a spectacular view of the Statue of Liberty in time for the Bicentennial Fourth of July.

title: Music: Bold Piano Style
description: Andrzej Wasowski, a Polishborn pianist who teaches at the Oral Roberts University in Tulsa, Okla., gave a recital in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night that was longer in interest than in complete satisfaction. A veteran performer, he went about his playing in an individual manner, attacking the music with a boldness that was arresting, but disturbing to the overall structure of a piece.

title: Irving A. Swarzman Dies; Rainbow Shops' President
description: Irving A. Swarzman, founder and president of Rainbow Shops, a chain of 60 stores retailing women's readytowear apparel, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 755 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Times Company Earnings Off For Fourth Quarter and Year
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in the fourth quarter of 1975 amounted to $1.4 million, equal to 13 cents a common share, compared with $4.3 million, or 38 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: FRENCH KILL SIX HOLDING CHILDREN
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Feb. 4 (AP)French sharpshooters killed six guerrillas holding 30 children hostage in a hijacked bus at the Somali border today, officials said. Before one of the gunmen was shot, however, he loosed a burst of automatic fire, killing a French girl and wounding six other hostages.

title: Advertising
description: Over at Philip Morris U.S.A., John T. Landry, executive vice presidentmarketing, thinks the company has a winner on its hands with Merit, the new lowtar highflavor cigarette.

title: Stocks Up Sharply On Amex, OTC; Volume Is Heavy
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market made sharp gains yesterday in heavy trading.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign that appeared yesterday in The New York Times, it was reported incorrectly that an article critical of Mr. Carter would appear in the February Issue of Harper's magazine. The article is in the March issue.

title: Compromised Fish
description: The Senate has found the best tentative solution available for the problem posed by the ruinous competition for America's coastal fish. Had it voted to extend United States jurisdiction to a 200mile limit immediately, the Senate might well have compromised this country's position at the International Law of the Sea Conference, to be resumed next month.

title: Computers Hum as the Saints Go Marching In
description: Saints have known almost every conceivable form of martyrdom. Now they are undergoing trial by computer.

title: BERNIE MANN, 61, LED BAND AT PARAMOUNT
description: Bernie Mann, who headed the All American Band that played Tor stage shows in the old Paramount Theater died on Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 61 years old.

title: O'Dwyer Bids State Take Over City Water System
description: A takeover by the state of the city's entire watersupply system was proposed yesterday by the City Council President, Paul O'Dwyer, and the Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso.

title: A.T.&T. EARNINGS EASED DURING 75
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest investorowned company, reported yesterday almost no change in its earnings for 1975 despite a 10.6 percent increase in operating revenues. Earnings per share were down due to an increase in shares outstanding since the end of 1974.

title: Article 2  No Title
DELAY IN ELECTION IS VOTED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 4The lower house of the Indian Parliament, its small but voluble Opposition overwhelmed, voted tonight to postpone the national elections that had been scheduled for next month.

title: Dismay and Anger Voiced; Suits to Bar Plane Hinted
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 4Federal, county and state officials and representatives of groups opposed to the Concorde reacted with dismay, anger and threats of lawsuits today to the decision by Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. to permit limited landings of the supersonic jet at two airports.

title: Byrne's Austerity Budget Hailed by Fiscal Experts
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4  Although Governor Byrne's strippeddown state budget for 197677 is being assailed by teachers, state financial experts said today that they expected the budget to have a salutory effect on New Jersey's credit rating.

title: J. Marcus Fleming Is Dead; Research Official at I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4J. Marcus Fleming, deputy director of research for the International Monetary Fund, died of cancer yesterday at his home. He was 64 years old.

title: College Heads Call Byrne Budget Crippling Blow
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 4Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers University, said today that Governor Byrne's proposed budget would deal a crippling blow to the university and reduce higher education in the state to a shell.

title: Mrs. Grasso Offers $1.8 Billion Budget
Tolentine Relies on Browne
description: A 6oo10nch basketball player whose favorite pastime is listening to Bob Dylan's music may bring Tolentine a championship in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Assocition. The player is Charley Browne, and his scoring and rebounding are the main reasons the Bronx school has won 13 of 14 games and leads its ManhattanBronx Division III with a 60 mark.

title: DOCTOR SLOWDOWN ENDING ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4A 35day slowdown by hundreds of Southern California physicians virtually collapsed today without having forced reform of the medical malpractice insurance system.

title: The Stage: David Dukes
Brooklyn Cultural Units Given a Minibus Transit
description: A minibus system linking seven educational and cultural institution in Brooklyn with free transportation for their student bodies, faculties and staffs will be started on Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: U.S. Crime Insurance: What Went Wrong

title: SUSPECT CHARGED IN MIRANDA CASE
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 (UPI) A murder charge was filed today against a Mexican national sought in the slaying of Ernesto Miranda, whose name was given to a landmark United States Supreme Court ruling.

title: Big A Card Halted After Two Races
description: Winter racing continued its losing streak at Aqueduct yesterday when the jockeys. after two races on an uneven and unsafe track, unanimously decided to sit out the rest of the ninerace card.

title: Soviet Assails Kissinger
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Soviet press agency, Tass, accused Secretary of State Kissinger today of attempting to distort the foreign policy of the Soviet Union in a San Francisco speech yesterday. Ignoring the actual state or affairs and the generally known fact that the foreign policy of the Soviet Union is a policy of peace, Kissinger spoke about some kind of Soviet expansion and ascribed aggressive intentions to the Soviet Union, Tass said.

title: Enforcing NursingHome Convictions
description: The operator of a Bronx nursing home was convicted last July of stealing the life savings of two patients. Sentenced to three years in prison but paroled pending an appeal, he is still operating the nursing home. The operator of a New Rochelle nursing, home pleaded guilty last December to the theft of $187,000 from Medicaid. She is expected to receive a suspended sentence on her promise to repay the money, but sentencing has been postponed while the court considers her request that the conviction not be a ground for lifting her operating license.

title: More Than 800 Die in Guatemala Quake
Notes on People
description: By a 79to7 vote after an hour of debate, the Senate confirmed W. J. Usery Jr. yesterday as President Ford's third Secretary of Labor. The Georgiaborn onetime welder, aged 52, has been the Administration's labordispute troubleshooter as head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. Mr. Usery is a former official of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and served as an assistant Secretary of Labor as a Nixon appointee.

title: Northwestern Gets Aide
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 4 (AP)Johnny Cook, a former Northwestern University running back, has rejoined his alma mater as an assistant football coach, John Pont, head coach and athletic director, said today. The 25 yearold Cook will be in charge of defensive ends.

title: Film: Hubert Smith Examines Family in 3 Works
Ford Promotes a Writer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) President Ford has promoted me of his speechwriters, Milton Triedman, to the position of special assistant with the designation of senior writer, Ron lessen, the White House press secretary, announced today. Mr. Friedman has been a member of Mr. Ford's writing staff since January, 1974.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: A Bergen Family's Records Dating to 1696 Found
description: HARRINGTON PARK, Feb. 4Deeds, maps and other hsi historic documents going back its 1696 have been uncovered and donated to the Harrington Park Historical Society.

title: Paris Red Charges Soviet Repression
Bridge:
description: There are some textbook bidding sequences that hardly ever seem to occur in real life. An example is shown in the diagram: North opens one diamond and later bid hearts twice, indicating six diamonds, five hearts, and a better than minimum hand. Although he has only 13 highcard points, the power of his diamond suit justifies the strong reverse sequence.

description: FIGURE SKATING

title: Foolish Pleasure Triumphs With Trainer in Mourning
Red Cross to Weigh Ban On Incendiary Weapons
description: LUGANO, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (Reuters)The International Committee of the Red Cross has set up an international working group to examine proposals for banning incendiary weapons such as napalm.

title: Jordan Indefinitely Puts Off Elections Set for March
description: AMMAN. Jordan, Feb. 4 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan issued a decree today indefinitely postponing parliamentary elections that had been scheduled for March 23 because of the continued occupation of the West Bank by Israel.

title: Defense Line of WesternBacked Angolans Is Expected to Fall
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 3Authoritative sources well informed on the Angolan civil war say they believe the Westernsupported Angolan troops will be pushed southward within a month from the center of the country to a line about 100 miles north of the SouthWest African border.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Feb. 4, 1976 Petition filed by:

title: State Proposes New Regulations On Access to Criminal Records
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The state is preparing new regulations to restrict access by outsiders to criminal records and to expand the rights of those involved to review, correct and sometimes expunge them.

title: Beame Bids Albany Reject Carey Trims in Local Aid
description: ALBANY. Feb. 4  Mayor Beame joined with other representatives of cities, counties and school districts here today to plead with the Legislature for rejection of Governor Carey's proposed reductions in state aid to localities.

title: Algerian Tells Moynihan Third World Is Not Hostile
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4Algeria's chief delegate, Abdellatif Rahal, advised Daniel P. Moynihan today not to leave the United Nations with the belief that the third world nations were systematically hostile toward the United States.

title: Building Service Employees Elect New President Here
description: John J. Sweeney has been elected president of Local 32B of the Service Employees Inter national Union, the local announced yesterday.

title: FUELOIL SUPPLIES DROPPED LAST WEEK
description: With unusually cold weather persisting across much of the country last week, supplies of distillate oil, used primarily for home heating, continued to drop according to a report yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The decline for the week was the third in a row.

title: Sister of Sam Ervin and 4 Held by a Gunman 2 Hours
Rodman Wanamaker, Polo Star, ExPolice Deputy, Is Dead at 77
description: Rodman Wanamaker, a former sevengoal polo player and a former Deputy Police Commissioner, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Arms Smuggling Is Said to Aid Protestants Less Than the I.R.A.
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland(Security officials, seeking to quell the flow of arms to Northern Ireland, have concluded that the bulk of weapons in Protestant hands are home grown but that there is some smuggling to Protestant sympathizers, primarily from Scotland and Canada.

title: Contract Is Set for Liberty Park
description: NEWARK, Feb. 4Governor Byrne announced today a $1.2 million contract toward construction at Liberty State Park in Jersey City of a harborside recreation site that will offer a spectacular view of the Statue of Liberty in time for the Bicentennial Fourth of July.

title: Mr. Ford on Abortion
description: Few current domestic controversies are more suited than the abortion issue to try a Presidential candidate's capacity for straight talk; President Ford is the latest to fail that test. While avoiding Ronald Reagan's allout regressive antiabortion stand, he has joined several of the Democratic candidates in straddling the issue in hopes of creating an illusion of middleoftheroad reasonableness.

title: The Pop Life
description: Carole King ends the first leg of her return to touring at San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House Monday nightwhich date falls on her birthday and marks the end of her Tapestry album's fifth year on Billboard magazine's top 200 sales chart. The second leg begins Feb. 29, and the singer checks into the Beacon Theater here for three nights March 5.

title: A.B.A. WILL NOT FILE BRIEF ON NEWS CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) With a showdown coming in its own ranks about the issue of free press and fair trial, the American Bar Association has decided to stay out of a battle over the question in the Supreme Court.

title: A Welshman Recalls 48 Years as a Judge
description: In an effort to get opinions from authorities of other countries, the more prestigious clubs in the United States occasionally invite leading judges from abroad.On Philadelphia's recent slate of 31 arbiters was George W. R. Couzens, from Crickhowell in Wales, who did his first judging 48 years ago.

AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (5I6) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3417767.

description: The prosecutor at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson summed up yesterday, asking the jury:

KISSINGER WARNS OF DIVISION IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, seeking support for the Administration's foreign policies, said today that the United States was more endangered by our domestic divisions than by overseas adversaries.

title: The Concorde Decision
description: Taking careful measure of the complexand often conflictingvalues of technology, the environment and world politics, Transportation Secretary Coleman reached yesterday a cautiously balanced decision on the Concordeone that establishes a limited test period for flights into the United States under carefully controlled conditions.

title: N.Y. FED RECEIVES F.D.I.C. PAYMENT
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that it had received nearly $600 million in 1975 from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in connection with the liquidation of the Franklin National Bank, which failed in 1974.

title: Action Near Huambo Reported
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 4 (UPI)Westernbacked AngoIan forces are attempting to drive Popular Movement troops from a crossroads town near Huambo, military sources here said today.

title: Arbitrator Upheld In Baseball Ruling
DR. ALBERT A. COLE
description: Dr. Albert Allan Cole of 25 Central Park West, a psychoanalyst, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday. London: Morning fixing $130.40, down $1.30; afternoon fixing $129.75, down $1.95. Paris: Afternoon market quotation $134.56, down $1.98.

title: REAGAN IS PICKING HIS FLORIDA SPOTS
Worms and Cold Combine to Threaten Much of State Peach Crop, Experts Say
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Feb. 4A plant pathologist said today that New Jersey stood to lose a third of its multimilliondollar peach crop this year.

title: No Sentiment Allowed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Revolutionary movements, it has frequently been noted, generally develop what the English historian E. J. Hobsbawm calls nstrked puritanical tendencies. . . . The Robespierres always win out over the Dantons. Recent events suggest that, in a broad sense, this observation still, holds.

title: Coleman Saw Landing By Concorde in Canada
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Only once before making his decision on the Concorde did Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. see or hear the supersonic jet land at an airport, and that was by coincidence.

title: Tenants on E. 79th St. Lose Heat
In Memoriam
description: MINTZMary MarcusonIn Wirt, memory of our Sainted mother.

title: Rochester Fights Measles
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 4 (AP)Monroe County Health Department nurses continued vaccinating pupils yesterday in an effort to halt an outbreak at Benjamin Franklin High School. Officials confirmed 47 cases of measles at the school. Nurses administered vaccine to about 750 pupils and teachers on Monday.

title: Trial's Spectators Start Lining Up at 7 A.M.
ROLE OF ASYLUMS DEFENDED IN SOVIET
Canadiens Drub Hawks, 83
SALES CLIMB 27% IN DOMESTIC CARS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4Sales of new United States cars were up 27 percent in January over last year, but import sales slumped 21 percent, automobile industry figures showed today. Auto analysts said the sales gain was better than expected and noted that last year's domestic sales had the benefit of price rebate programs.

title: JAPAN RIGHTIST GOT $7 MILLION FROM LOCKHEED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation paid $7 million to a powerful Japanese rightist, who had both political influence and ties to the Tokyo underworld, to help the company sell its airplanes in Japan, a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Ford Abortion Stand Draws Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)President Ford's suggestion that states be given the legal right to decide whether to permit elective abortions was strongly criticized in Congressional testimony today.

title: Rain and Snow Ending Drought in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP) Rain and snow across most of California have ended a monthslong drought, the worst in 72 years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: A.M.C. Reports Profitable Quarter; Dow's Earnings Climb by 34%
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Feb. 4The American Motors Corporation announced today that it had net earnings of $7.5 million, or 25 cents a share, in the last three months of 1975. Roy D. Chapin, A.M.C.'s chairman, predicted at the annual meeting that the company would remain profitable for the rest of the year.

title: LowKey Pageantry Marks Start of the Olympics at Innsbruck
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 4The 12th Winter Olympics were declared open today.

title: Jerseyans Go to City to Study State
description: They came to New York from New Jerseyto learn about New Jersey.

title: Ban on Heated Pools Leaves Some Californians Boiling
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., Feb. 4  Part of the California dream is in jeopardy. And Donald Lyon, along with many, other Californians, is racing against a deadline to keep the dream alive. He's building a heated swimming pool.

title: Chess:
Serkin Recital Canceled
description: Rudolf Serkin's recital on Fob. 18 in Carnegie Hall, rescheduled from Jan. 28 because of illness, has been canceled. The pianist had the flu, and his recovery was slower than expected. His schedule and that of Carnegie Hall have made it impossible to find a future date for a recital this season. Those holding tickets for Jan. 28 can get refunds by returning the tickets to the box office in person or, accompanied by a selfaddressed stamped envelope, by mall.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 4 (UPI)The Virginia Squires, again on the brink of folding, presented the City Council today with a plan to rescue the American Basketball Association franchise, a team spokesman said.

title: Ban on Heated Pools Leaves Some Californians Boiling
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., Feb. 4  Part of the California dream is in jeopardy. And Donald Lyon, along with many other Californians, is racing against deadline to keep the dream alive. He's building a heated swimming pool.

title: 2 Key Argentine Aides Replaced As Economic Troubles Worsen
Potatoes Retreat On News Europeans Bar U.S. Shipment
description: Two cargoes of potatoes at sea that have not received proper certification by inspectors for the United States Government depressed potatofutures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The May delivery closed at 15.70 cents a pound, down from 16.55 in active trading of more than 5,680 contracts.

title: Allan D. Emil, Lawyer, 77, Dies; Philanthropist and Arts Patron
description: Allan D. Emil, a senior partner in the law firm of Rosenman Colin Kaye Petschek Freund & Emil and a wellknown figure in philanthropies and the arts, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived at 60 Sutton Place South here.

title: New Hampshire Prepares to Pass First Judgment on Candidates
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 4A late January thaw has ended. thrusting this rocky corner of New England abruptly back into the icy grip of winter.

title: Carey Gives the Legislature Proposals For a Major Revision of Health Care
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4  Calling health care the top priority of his administration, Governor Carey today sent to the Legislature the first of dozens of healthrelated bills emphasizing preventive medicine, a shift from institutional to smallerscale health care and what Mr. Carey said would be a better use of the state's strained healthcare resources.

title: Nuclear Devices Tested
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Feb. 4 (UPI)Two mediumsize nuclea devices were detonated 20 minutes apart early today 2,100 feet beneath the Nevada test site floor. The detonations. which had yields of 20 to 200 kilotons, were barely felt in Las Vegas 120 miles to the south of here. They were the second and third announced tests this calendar year and the 284th and 285th announced since the ban on atmospheric testing went into effect.

title: France Asks U.N. Meeting
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign that appeared yesterday in The New York Times, it was reported incorrectly that an article critical of Mr. Carter would appear in the February issue of Harper's magazine. The article is in the March issue,

title: Article 4  No Title
Yale Shuts Gates To Curb Assaults
description: NEW HAVENPhelps Gate, Yale University's handsome old archway looking out on the town green, has been barricaded, its grassy view blocked by a sturdy brown fence. The gate was closed because two students were raped in dormitory rooms during the fall term and a third woman was beaten and robbed by an intruder in her dormitory room recently.

title: European Socialists Rebuff U.S. on Ties With Reds
description: BONN, Feb. 4Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has been reported urging West European Socialist parties to reject feelers of cooperation by the Italian and French Communists, baffling and confusing some Europeans who think that the American pressure is counterproductive.

title: MORTON LEXOW, 90, ROCKLAND LAWYER
description: Morton Lexow of Suffern, N. Y., who was District Attorney of Rockland County from 1918 to 1930, died Tuesday at the Allendale (N. J.) Nursing Home. He was 90 years old.

title: Connors Struggles To Defeat Fleming
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 4 (UPI)Jimmy Connors had to struggle to beat unseeded Peter Fleming in the second round of a $60,000 Independent Players Association tennis tournament today.

title: Mr. Ford's Secret Sellout
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4One section of the stillsecret Pike committee report especially troubling to the White House is the revelation of a shameful action for which President Ford must be held responsible: the betrayal of the Kurdish people.

title: Mischief on Housing
description: The order reluctantly issued yesterday by the city to halt construction on eight huge housing projects, in which upward of $120 million has already been invested, is a consequence of politicsasusual by the Democratic majority in the State Assembly.

title: Decision on Entry Is Due in March
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 4 (AP)A decision on the Memphis Grizzlies entry into the National Football League will be made at a midMarch meeting of the league, an N.F.L. spokesman said today.

title: India: More Repression
description: Instead of observing her tenth anniversary as India's Prime Minister by lifting some of the repressive measures she imposed last June, Indira Gandhi has expanded and tightened her grip on the country. An obedient Congress Party majority in the lower house of Parliament has voted to postpone the national elections that should be held next month, press censorship has been made permanent and Mrs. Gandhi's regime has taken control of Tamil Nadu, dismissing that state's freely elected Government.

title: Help for Refugees Sought
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 4 (AP)The National Front for, the Liberation of Angola appealed today for international help for some 24,000 refugees from northern Angolan areas taken by Cubanaided forces.

title: NEW 8% U.S. NOTES RISE TO PREMIUM
description: The Treasury's new 8 percent sevenyear notes, which have met an explosion of demand From investors and speculators since they were first announced last Wednesday, climbed to a halfpoint premium yesterdaya subCredit stantial oneday Markets advanceas they began trading on a whenissued basis. The Treasury announced yesterday afternoon that the results of the subscription offering would be announced at 10 A.M. today.

title: British and French Voice Relief Over SST's Trial
description: PARIS, Feb. 4The decision by Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. to give the Concorde limited access to New York and Washington was more favorable than expected and should permit the supersonic carrier to prove itself as a good neighbor, officials of Britain and France agreed tonight.

title: Article 3  No Title
Iran Is Said to Press West to Step Up Oil Purchases
description: LONDON, Feb. 4  Iran, which is suffering unexpected economic reversals because of a sharp fall in demand for its oil, is reportedly applying pressure on Western Governments to force multinational oil companies to Increase their purchases of Iranian oil.

title: Seven Women on the Jury Selected for Hearst Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4Patricia Hearst leaned over toward her defense counsel, F. Lee Bailey, and indicated during the last few minutes of jury selection which jurors she wanted removed from the list.

title: Books of The Times
Lawyers Clash on Motive In Hearst Robbery Trial
Illiteracy Rises Despite UNESCO Effort
description: PARIS, Feb, 4An ambitious UNESCO project to eradicate illiteracy, begun a decade ago, has been a dismal failure, according to the organization's own report.

title: Beame Moves to Allow Architects to Inspect Buildings
description: Legislation aimed at reducing corruption in the construction industry by shifting most inspections for code compliance from the city's Buildings Department to private architects and engineers was submitted by Mayor Beame to the City Council yesterday.

title: Nets Triumph, 117112
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4 (AP)John Willianson and Bill Melchionni combined for 36 points tonight and steadied the New York Nets to a 117 112 American Basketball Association victory over the Spirits of St. Louis despite Marvin Barnes's 40 points and 19 rebounds.

title: JAPAN RIGHTIST GOT $7 MILLION FROM LOCKHEED,
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation paid $7 million to a powerful Japanese rightist, who had both political influence and ties to the Tokyo underworld, to help the company sell its airplanes in Japan, a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Cotton Is King of the Beene Bag Follies of 1976
description: The hush was not of boredom but anticipation. The chuckles were real, not forced as the models emerged from the fitting rooms cradling a cabbage or cauliflower in their arms or swinging a bunch of carrots by their greens.

title: Hanson Inc. Makes Offer For All of Hygrade Shares
description: Hanson Industries Inc., the American subsidiary of the Hanson Trust Ltd. of Britain, is seeking to acquire all of the stock of Hygrade Food Products Corporation in which it already owns a 30.5 percent interest. Newton Glekel, chairman of Hygrade, a large meat packer, disclosed its plans at the company's annual meeting here.

title: Public Advocate Phone To Be Open 24 Hours
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4 (AP) The Department of the Public Advocate announced today that it was expanding its costfree phone line for citizen complaints to an aroundtheclock operation.

title: IngersollRand Dividend Up
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Feb. 4 (Reuters)—The IngersollRand Company said today it raised its quarterly dividend to 67 cents a share from 62 cents, payable March 1, to shareholders of record Feb. 17.

title: NURSING HOME FIRE KILLS 6 IN ILLINOIS
description: CICERO, Ill., Feb. 4 (AP)Smoke and fire bursting from a fourth floor room killed six persons and injured 23 early today at a recently built nursing home in this suburb west of Chicago.

title: 72 Yachts in S.O.R.C. Start 409Mile Voyage
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 4The Southern Ocean Racing Conference's big race, the 409mile voyage from here to Fort Lauderdale on Florida's East Coast, began today with 72 yachts sailing out from Tampa Bay and south in light breezes.

title: Islanders Win, 65, With 4 Late Goals,
description: John Ferguson, who may or may not know better, took the Rangers back to the days of old last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP)  The United Auto Workers charged today that thousands of United States jobs could be lost because of the Chrysler Corporation's decision to purchase engines and transmissions from West Germany for a 1978model subcompact car.

title: Dismay and Anger Voiced; Suits to Bar Plane Hinted
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 4  Federal, county and state officials and representatives of groups opposed to the Concorde reacted with dismay, anger and threats of lawsuits today to the decision by Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. to permit limited landings of the supersonic jet at two airports.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Now that the inmates are taking over the asylum of sports, the onus will be on the wardens to be more humane, if not more charitable. Charles O. Finley, the turnkey of the Oakland A's, soon will discover that his dictatorial manner has not endeared him to many of his best players. When a Federal judge, John W. Oliver, upheld yesterday the arbitration ruling of Peter Seitz that liberated Andy Messer smith and Dave McNally from baseball bondage, it meant that many baseball players will decline to sign the contracts offered to them this year. By not signing, they will maintain the possibility of joining Messersmith and McNally in free domland. Among those unlikely to sign are many of the A's who have debated Charles O. Finley in salary arbitration the last two years.

title: Guatemala at a Glance
description: Vital StatisticsGuatemala is a country of 42,040 square miles, slightly smaller than Pennsylvania, with coastlines of about 200 miles on the Pacific Ocean and 70 miles on the Caribbean Sea. It is bounded by Mexico to the north and west, by Belize on the east, and by Honduras and El Salvador to the east and south. Inland from a region of lowlands along the Pacific coast, many volcanoes rise steeply, thousands of feet above the land. The tallest, Tajumulco, is 13,846 feet high.

title: 6 IN GRAIN THEFTS PUT ON PROBATION
description: NEW ORLEANS. Feb. 4Six defendants who had pleaded guilty to conspiracy in systematic thefts of grain from foreign shipments were placed on probation in Federal District Court here today, and one was fined $500.

title: 3 U.S. AGENCIES STUDY SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) The Justice Department and two other Federal agencies are investigating several Senators for possible criminal activity involving illegal campaign contributions from the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Senate Ethics Committee said today.

title: Dan Connors to Be Scout
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) Dan Connors, who played linebacker for the Oakland Raiders in the National Football League for 11 years before his retirement last season, has been hired as a scout for the N.F.L.'s new Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: E.R.A. Dies in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 4 (AP) A resolution to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment died in the Virginia General Assembly today for a fourth straight year.

title: Shirley MacLaine Wins London Critics' Acclaim
description: LONDON, Feb. 4Shirley MacLaine danced, sang and joked her way into the hearts of her audience and newspaper critics Monday night in a 70minute show that opened at the London Palladium.

title: FARMERS BANK TALKS MERGER WITH GIRARD
description: The Farmers Bank of the State of Delaware disclosed yesterday that it was discussing a merger with the Girard Bank of Philadelphia as one of three plans under consideration to keep the Delaware bank solvent.

title: BASIE'S BAND SHINES IN JAZZ SUBTLETIES
description: Count Basie's twonight engagement at the Bottom Line last night and Tuesdaywas the first time his 18piece jazz band has played at the West Fourth Street club, which usually books smaller groups. But it proved to be an ideal setting for Mr. Basie's current band, one of the best he has had in his 40 years as a leader.

title: Georgetown Stuns St. John's, 7473
Market Place
description: The investment annuity is becoming popular with investors as a wrapper under which taxable fixedinterest investments can be sheltered and made to yield more than such taxexempt securities as municipal bonds.

title: SENATE SUSTAINS FORD'S MILK VETO
New Jersey Briefs
description: Newark Teachers to Ignore Court Order

title: State Senate Balks A City Housing Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The State Senate held up action today on a bill that would allow work to continue on eight moderateincome housing projects in New York City, thereby triggering the layoffs of an estimated total of 2,500 construction workers.

title: Jersey Says It Is Getting Five More Wall St. Firms
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4Five or six more brokerage firms in New York City will soon announce they are moving a large part of their operations to New Jersey, Joseph A. Hoffman, State Labor and Industry Commissioner, disclosed in an interview today.

title: LowKey Pageantry Marks Start of the Olympics at Innsbruck
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 4The 12th Winter Olympics were declared open today.

title: MARTIN BUCHBAND, OTOLARYNGOLOGIST
description: Dr. Martin Buchband of 30 Central Park South, an ear, nose and throat specialist and a fellow of the International College of Surgeons, died yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Archer Price Change Set
description: The metals division of R.J.R. Archer Inc. announced yesterday it was withdrawing its Jan. 12, 1976 price list for aluminum converter foil so that its prices will be those lower ones in effect on its list of Sept. 1, 1975. The division said that the move reflected market conditions.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists In Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island will be able to park their cars today on both sides of streets where alternate sideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. In Manhattan, however, the rules will again be in effect. The regulations had been suspended because of the snow. All other parking and standing restrictions still apply throughout the city.

title: Marquette to Play Wrong Foe Here
description: Plenty of fans in the expected capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden tonight probably would like to see highly ranked Rutgers play higherranked Marquette.

title: Text of Coleman Statement About Concorde
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Following is the text of the opening statement by the Secretary of Transportation, William T. Coleman Jr. at the news conference where he announced that the Concorde would be allowed to fly into two United States airports for a 16month trial period:

title: ROXANE F. DOBA
description: Roxane F. Doba of 200 Lexington Avenue in Oyster Bay, L. I., a senior executive with Glick & Lorwin, education consultants, until her retirement in 1971. died Tuesday of cancer. She was 58 years old.

title: Paris Red Charges Soviet Repression
description: PARIS, Feb. 4The French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, opened his party's 22d congress today with an attack on the Soviet Union for unjust and unjustifiable acts of repression against Soviet citizens.

title: Fans Rub Elbows With Opera Stars At SupperDance Following New Aida
description: Every opera season has its Event of the Year, a production that the musical world anticipates for months before and talks about for months after.

title: People and Business
Screen: Next Stop, Greenwich Village, a Commonplace Mazursky Memoir
3 Who Killed Priest May Have Sought Bingo Funds, but Game Was Canceled
description: Robbers who killed a 76year old Capuchin priest in his friary in Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon may have been looking for the proceeds of a bingo game that was never heldan affair canceled Monday night because of the snowstorm.

title: Paris Cites Growing Danger
description: PARIS, Feb. 4The French attack on the bus was ordered because of a growing threat to the childrens' lives, Olivier Stirn, minister for Overseas Departments and Territories, said at a news conference here today.

title: Appeal Is Likely
description: It is expected that Judge Oliver's decision will be appealed, but John Geherin, legal counsel for the owners, said Wednesday no action would be taken until he had a chance to analyze the ruling.

title: CAMBODIA PLANS MARCH ELECTION
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 4 Cambodia today scheduled nationwide elections in six weeks.

title: MARY ALEXANDER, LIBRARIAN, 86, DIES
description: Mary Louise Alexander, who had been director for more than 20 years of the Ferguson Library in Stamford, Conn., died yesterday at her home, 3030 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. She was 86 years old.

title: TV Review
description: The argument that process may be everything in television is getting new and solid support from an organization called Martha Stuart Communications. Miss Stuart has taken the standard commodity of talking heads and given it a fresh context, and she is proving it to be a still sturdy vessel for information. Her programs are called Are You Listening?, and three of the halfhours have been seen on public television.

title: Agency Moves to Speed Up Licensing of C.B. Radios
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 5 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ordered its staff today to go ahead with plans for a temporary permit procedure to take care of the avalanche of applications for Citizen's Band radio lcenses.

title: Rule of Reason
description: Recourse to arbitration as a rational way to resolve employeremployee disputes got two needed lifts in recent court decisions.

title: Profits Scoreboard; (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)
description: OCT.DEC. PERCENT EARNINGS CHANGE 1975 FROM 1974

title: Reilly Takes Stand for First Time in Bid for New Trial
New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Three Sources of Camping Information
description: For families that want to start thinking about what to do this summer, the Walden School, 1 West 88th Street, will hold a free gettogether called Summer Camping 76 on March 1 from 6 to 9 P.M. in the school auditorium. Representatives from 45 camps in New York, New Jersey, New England and Pennsylvania will be there to describe their offerings.

title: Jamaican Chief Sets Up Council To Help Fight Political Violence
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 5 Prime Minister Michael Manley, seeking to stamp out what he has called the monster of violence in our society, announced last night the formation of an advisory council to help curb an upsurge in political shootings in a tense slum neighborhood.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Kinshasa and the Angolan War
ExMaryland Star A Fatality on Court
description: LEESBURG, Va., Feb. 5 (AP)  Twentytwoyearold Owen Brown, former University of Maryland basketball forward, died of an apparent heart attack last night while playing a pickup game with coworkers.

title: Hearst Jury Sees Film
description: Movies of the bank robbery for which Patricia Hearst is on trial were shown in court, and two of her former associates pleaded that she not sell them out to gain her own freedom. Details on Page 26.

title: Auto Output to Fall Slightly From Last Week's Level
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5American auto plants plan to build 167,895 cars this week, off less than 1 percent from last week's 168,622, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

title: 18 Gang Members Indicted In 5 City Truck Hijackings
description: An 18member gang was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having carried out five truck hijackings in 1971 and 1972 that netted more than $400.000.

title: Profit Taking and Money Fears Lower Amex and OTC Prices
description: Profit taking and fears that the Federal Reserve Board might soon tighten its monetary policy weakened prices yesterday on the. American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Soviet Ships With Cuban Force Reported 30 Miles Off Angola
JORDAN CONVENES OLD PARLIAMENT
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 5 (Reuters)The newly revived Jordanian Parliament met here today, with representatives of the Israelioccupied West Bank, in attendance, and approved a constitutional amendment empowering King Hussein to put off elections indefinitely.

title: 2 Who Were Freed On Robbery Charge Enter Guilty Pleas
description: Two youths who had been released on robbery charges by a Criminal Court judge in the Bronx on the ground that their constitutional rights had been violated by the police, pleaded guilty to felony charges in the same case.

title: Market Place
description: The sixmonthold composite ticker tape was incorporated last month into the daily newspaper quotations supplied by the Associated Press. Investors reactions have been mixed.

title: Wiretaps Bring 87 Arrests
description: HARTFORD (AP)Courtapproved wiretaps resulted in 87 drug and gambling arrests last year and cost Connecticut more than $21,800 to operate, according to John P. Cotter, the chief court administrator, says.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Pack Trips
description: Although summer seems far away, now is the time for those who would like to make a horseback pack trip in any of Wyoming's wilderness areas to start planning for the event.

title: Red Smith
description: Jim Farley Jr., probably the only boxing commissioner on earth who was bred for the job, goes up to Albany next week to be confirmed by the Senate as chairman of the New York Athletic Commission. Pending confirmation, he has been interim commissioner since last August when Governor Carey appointed him to succeed an empty office. Jim may never attain the eminence of his father, who rose from boxing commissioner to Postmaster General of the United States and chairman of the National Democratic Party, but he is a big improvement on his immediate predecessor. Things have changed more than somewhat since Jim Sr. presided over the Sweet Science 45 years ago. For one thing, New York had boxing then. And I hope we'll have it again, young Jim said yesterday, although I'm realistic enough to know we'll never get back to the time when Friday night was fight night in the Garden and you could feel the electricity clear up to Pelham Bay.

title: Article 4  No Title
Simon Is Optimistic The City Will Repay Loans From U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Treasury Secretary William E. Simon today expressed optimism regarding New York City's finances and said there was a reasonable prospect that the city would repay its Federal loans.

title: City Health Agency Votes to Shut 4 Hospitals in Plan to Cut Budget
description: The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporations voted yesterday to go ahead with a plan it had tentatively approved two weeks ago to reduce the number of municipal hospitals from 18 to 14, thereby cutting $240 million from its budget by mid1978.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Any restaurant where somebody has had enough imagination to decorate the walls with lithographs by Daumier racks up a couple of pluses on my score card that could offset a fault or two in the kitchen. The kitchen at Le Cheval Blanc, a longtime resident at 145 East 45th Street that I have somehow missed until last week, doesn't need that kind of help, but it's still very pleasant to sit in the small front room surrounded by Daumiersoriginals clipped from mid19thcentury jourpals. You would need a stepladder to see most of them properly, but no matter. They're there.

title: Big Board Orders Work on Saturday
description: The New York Stock Exchange, citing the recent heavy volume, yesterday ordered all trading floor brokers to report to work on Saturday to help expedite the comparison of buy and sell transactions on which there is some doubt.

title: Senate Gets Busing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, and 20 other Senators introduced a bill today to bar lower Federal courts from ordering busing to desegregate schools. Senator Roth said the measure would substitute state courts as the appropriate tribunal in cases where busing may be employed as a remedy under standards announced by the Supreme, Court,

title: New Round in Ulster
description: Nearly all 78 members of Northern Ireland's Constitutional Convention have returned to Stormont to resume deliberations on the future of the strifewracked province, thus providing practically the only cause for hope in the Ulster cockpit. Even the majority United Ulster Unionist Coalition agreed to prompt resumption of private negotiations between the parties; and the opening session was devoid of ProtestantCatholic acrimony.

title: 2 FEDERAL JUDGES UPBRAID MEROLA
description: A stern warning was issued yesterday by two Federal judges who declared that prosecutors who made improper statements about criminal cases could be vulnerable to damage suits for violating the rights of defendants.

title: 28 National Banks Called In Serious or Critical State
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Comptroller of the Currency, James E. Smith, said today that the United States banking system was sound, but disclosed that there were 28 national banks in either critical or serious financial trouble.

title: OVERHAUL URGED FOR SPECIALISTS
description: A fiveman committee of the New York Stock Exchange recommended yesterday a major overhaul of the specialist system.

title: Auto Heir Chosen by McCarthy To Run for the VicePresidency
description: WASHNGTON, Feb. 5Eugene J. McCarthy announced today that he had selected William Clay Ford as his running mate on the independent thirdparty ticket with which he plans to challenge the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees in the fall.

title: LAMBERT BRUSSELS IN FUNDING FOR WDW
description: WDW Inc., parent of the research  oriented brokerage house of William D. Witter Inc. announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for an additional $8 million in capital from Compagnie Bruxelles Lambert, through the Lambert Brussels Corporation of New York, a local subsidiary.

title: DR. KATHLEEN DIETRICH
description: LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP)Dr. Kathleen B. Dietrich, pioneer in research and operating on blue babiesthose born with defective heartsdied in Guy's Hospital here yesterday. She was 55 yeas old.

title: CLOTHING UNION SETS BOYCOTT OF IMPORTS
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, expressing concern about climbing imports of men's and boys clothing, announced yesterday a campaign for a nationwide boycott of such products made abroad.

title: Tatyana Lyudvinskaya, 88, Old Bolshevik and Writer
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Tatyana Lyudvinskaya, one of the few remaining old Bolsheviks, has died here, Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, reported today. She was 88 years old.

title: Carson Acquitted of One Slaying Count
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants were acquitted yesterday of intentionally killing a 34yearold Brooklyn man, but the jury continued to deliberate on a second murder charge.

title: Stocks Encounter Sharpest 76 Drop
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday, registering ther sharpest declne of 1976 on the heels of a prolonged advance that had carried the market to a 27 month high.

title: Taylor Resigns Basketball Post
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 5 (AP)Fred Taylor, the Ohio State University basketball coach, submitted his resignation today, effective at the end of the seasonhis 18th.

title: Henry Rudin, Who Headed Real Estate Firm, Is Dead
description: Henry Rudin, board chairman of the Rudin Management Company, a real estate organization that builds and owns residential and office property, died Wednesday at his winter home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 74 years old and also Lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Koch, Skier, and Miss Young, Skater, Take Olympic Silver Medals for U.S.
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 5Austria and the Soviet Union won opening day gold medals as they were supposed to do in the Winter Olympics but three astonishing performances by Americans today produced two silver medals and an undreamed of sixth place.

title: Jury in Grain Inquiry Hears Head of Cook Industries
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5Edward W. Cook, chairman of Cook Industries Inc., a leading concern in the grain export trade, appeared before a Federal grand jury here today as an investigation of his company appeared to be approaching a decisive stage.

title: A Carey White Sheep
description: Wags were saying Carey had a little lamb, but it was a sheep that Martin T. Carey, brother of the Governor, picked up at the A.S.P.C.A. shelter yesterday.

title: Bentsen Wages Desperate Fight To Gain Delegates in Oklahoma
description: CHICKASHA, Okla., Feb. 5Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. of Texas, fighting desperately to avoid elimination from the Presidential sweepstakes, is throwing major resources into the campaign for Oklahoma's 37 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Buckley Asks Bar to Find Kunstler Unfit to Practice
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative  Republican of New York, has asked the New York Bar Association to disbar William M. Kunstler because of his alleged condoning of political assassinations.

title: Election Unit Will Not Rule on Morton
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Federal Election Commission decided today not to render an advisory opinion on whether Rogers C. B. Morton, a recently appointed White House counselor, can act as a political adviser to President Ford while on the public payroll.

title: 6 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
description: Six more food establishments were cited by the city Health Department Wednesday for failing an inspection. They are subject to being closed if violations of the health code are not corrected before a second inspection.

title: 1,200 on State's SmokeFilled Special For Annual Amtrak to Washington
description: ABOARD THE JERSEY CONGRESSIONAL, Feb. 5New Jersey's annual political pilgrimage to Washington by more than 1,200 government and business leaders was made aboard a brand new Amtrak train today, and the familiar smokefilled atmosphere was unmistakable.

title: Addendum to Long List Of Pay the $2 Stories
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5For those who feel they have been wronged by parking meters that eat their dimes and then subject them to parking tickets, the word went out today mutter, raise a fist, kick the meter, but never, never put your feelings down on paper, especially to the clerk of the court.

title: RAYMOND A. MEANY
description: Raymond A. Meany, who retired in 1965 as general plant supervisor in Brooklyn after 51 years with the New York Telephone Company, died Wednesday at his home at 18 Summit Road in Elizabeth, N. J. He was 76 years old.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 12%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: COLUMN BY SAFIRE ON KURDS ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The State Department today sharply criticized a column by William Safire of The New York Times that accused the Ford Administration of the betrayal of the Kurdish people.

title: 8% Treasury Notes Draw a Deluge of Orders
description: The new 8 percent notes that were sold by the Treasury ths week attracted an avalanche of orders totaling $29.2 billion from speculators and investors, the Government announced yesterday.

title: Judge Declines to Imprison; Convicts in Medicaid Fraud
description: The operators of the Hillcrest Nursing Home in Spring Valley N.Y., received conditional discharges yesterday on their conviction for Medicaid fraud.

title: U. N. Board Urges Mexico to Intensify Drive on Narcotics
description: GENEVA, Feb. 5The International Narcotics Control Board has called on Mexican authorities to intensify their fight against the illicit drug trade because of the large quantities of heroin, cocaine and marijuana that are reaching the United States from Mexico.

title: FORD SUPPORTER PRAISES REAGAN
8, 711, 319.5 Newsmen; 7 Hotels
Needed Bank Reform ...
description: Disclosure by the Federal Reserve System that the number of bankholding companies on its problem list has jumped sharply in the past year, along with a comparable increase in banks under special surveillance, raises serious concern about the adequacy and the basic concepts of banking regulation in the United States.

title: Pentagon Asks Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Pentagon sent Congress today a proposal to authorize $3.4 billion in military construction in the United States and abroad. Included is $1.3 billion for military family housing.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  of  the  street regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: RISE IN G.H.I. RATE APPROVED BY CITY
description: The Board of Estimate gave its reluctant approval yesterday to a contract providing for an $8.1 million increase in Group Health medicalinsurance premiums paid by the city for its employees, their dependents and retired Civil Service workers.

title: TAX CHIEF TO TALK TO A GRAND JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Donnald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, has agreed to a request from the Department of Justice that he testify before a Federal grand jury here next week about severas alleged irregularities in his administration of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: NADJARI ALLEGES PAYOFFS TO POLICE
Policing the Bar
description: In a remarkably selfcritical and constructive report, a prestigious committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York calls for tough new ways to censure, discipline or disbar lawyers who are unethical or criminal in their practices. The whole grievance machinery, which the Bar Association handles under the rules of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division for the First Department (covering Manhattan and the Bronx), would be changed from a clubby, secretive atmosphere to open procedures that would include nonlawyers. The effect could be a brake on misconduct and an aid to restoration of public faith in the legal profession.

title: Allin's 135 Leads; Palmer Posts 64
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 5Palmer shot 64? Arnold Palmer?

title: NADJARI ALLEGES PAYOFFS TO POLICE
description: For the last two decades, according to allegations in testimony before a special grand jury, Transit Authority policemen have accepted payoffs from subway concessionnaires every time a suspect was arrested for tampering with a subway vending machine.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LILT TILT There's nothing intimate or publike about the Camelot Pub from outside, with its huge tentlike canopy and its halfblock facade jutting from an apartment tower on Third Avenue, between 72d and 73d Streets. Walk in, turn left and you face a cavernous dining room. Turn right and you're inside a small, snug cocktail lounge, with an ample bar and wall banquette and the smooth singing and friendly chatter of Louise Ogilvie and Ed Linderman.

title: Evelyn Russell Dies at 49, Stage and Screen Actress
description: Evelyn Russell, a stage and screen actress, died Jan. 28 at her home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. She was 49 years old.

title: Advertising
Seymour R. Thaler Dead; Former State Senator, 56
description: Seymour R. Thaler, the former crusading State Senator who was about to take a seat on the state Supreme Court when his career was shattered in 1972 upon his conviction of conspiracy with two others to sell stolen securities, died early yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 56.

title: OTTO F. RIEG
description: Otto F. Rieg, who retired in 1967 as vice president in charge of the underwriting department of the Home Insurance Company, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing in Ocean Ridge, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived at 26.01 Warren Road in Fair Lawn, N. J.

title: Fund Is Set Up Here to Help Rehouse Victims of Quake
description: Moving to aid the victims of the earthquake in Guatemala and Honduras on Wednesday, a group of Latin America's friends here have established a special relief fund and appealed for donations to provide housing in the devastated areas.

title: Auto Worker Absenteeism Still High Despite Layoffs
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Moves to Establish A Zion Sq. in U.N. Plaza
description: A bill changing the name of part of United Nations Plaza to Zion Square was passed yesterday by the City Council Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs.

title: Anaconda Merger Under F.T.C. Study
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced in Washington yesterday that it would investigate the proposed merger of Tenneco Inc., and the Anaconda Company. The decision for the F.T.C. to undertake the investigation came after a conference of that agency with the Justice Department's Antitrust division.

title: Japan's Socialists Ask Inquiry Into Reported Lockheed Payments
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5Opposition Socialists today demanded a full investigation of reports from Washington that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had paid millions for help in selling its planes in Japan.

title: A SPECIAL INQUIRY ON C.I.A. AND F.B.I. URGED BY CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence called today for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate evidence of criminal activity by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Airline Costs Cited
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a net loss for last year's fourth quarter of $33.2 million and a net loss for all 1975 of $46.1 million.

title: FEAR OF ACCIDENT SHUT ATOM PLANT
description: VERNON, Vt., Feb. 5The Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant here has been closed because of a possible flaw in its safety system that could permit a devastating nuclear accident.

title: Koch Rewards His Coach's Confidence
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 5Like the tennis player caught moving to his left when a returning shot comes booming to the right, skiminded spectators looking for the unexpected found themselves at the wrong place at the wrong time today.

title: Judge Sirica Has A Coronary Attack While Giving Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Federal District Judge John J. Sirica, who gained national recognition for his dogged pursuit of the truth in Watergate, suffered a massive heart attack today. His condition was critical

title: Pesticides Control Of Insects Is Found To Decline Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Chemical control of important insect pests is losing effectiveness and the loss will probably accelerate, according to a report released today by the National Academy of Sciences. The report was more than three years in the making.

title: Nets Bow To Spurs By 124116
description: SAN ANTONIO , Feb. 5 (UPI)James Silas scored 37 points and George Gervin 35 tonight as the San Antonio Spurs defeated the New York Nets, 124116, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Questions for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Senate Intelligence Committee sent a questionnaire on intelligence matters to former President Richard M. Nixon today and requested that it be answered expeditiouslywith sworn written statements.

title: Rain Ends Costly California Drought; Cold Feared
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5Rain has fallen on much of California during the last two days, breaking the worst drought to hit the state since 1904. But California farmers are counting losses from the drought that could run into many millions of dollars, and many now fear that a cold snap following the summerlike weather will add millions more to their losses.

title: Ben Kahn, Furrier, Dies; Fashion Leader Was 89
description: Ben Kahn, a leading furrier and founder of the company that bears his name, died here yesterday of a heart attack in Bellevue Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Hollywood. Fla.

title: Ballet: Harlequinade
description: The first time one sees George Balanchine's Harlequinade, one is apt to say how sweet, how quaint, how atmospheric, how delicately redolent of the decadence and tinsel of 19thcentury ballet! On the second viewing, the special delights of that distant prospect, of that insight to a largely forgotten ballet past, have probably evaporated, and by the time one has seen it for the 20th or so time, the ballet, to be frank, may be getting tedious. Harlequinade is one of those very unusual ballets that are probably best seen just once and then allowed to marinate forever in the memory.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: LOSS OF BUSINESS LAID TO BIAS BAN
description: New York has lost a substantial amount of business and is threatened with the loss of thousands of jobs because of A new law aimed at preventing bias, according to testimony yesterday before a legislative committee..

title: Airlines Lost $87 Million in 1975
description: Rising fuel prices, costly strikes and proliferating fare discounts drove the nation's airlines into a nearrecord deficit last year, according to recentlyreleased yearend statements.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Bus fare discounts for 30,000 students will end Feb. 13, the Board of Public Utility Commissioners said yesterday, unless the Legislature appropriates money to subsidize the program.

title: Westminster Dog Show, on Its Centennial, Still the One; Westminster Dog Show, Marking Its Centennial, Continues to Be Great One
description: Never had there been a dog show like it in America.

title: Lisbon Shifts Gears for the Long Road of Rebuilding
description: LISBON, Feb. 5After 21 months of sterile convulsions, the Portuguese revolution has come to a pause and seems to be seeking its own identity.

title: Seven Are Indicted On Racing Bribery
description: Three men who allegedly bribed jockeys at the Pocono Downs track in Pennsylvania so they could collect bets on exacta races were indicted by a Federal grand fury in Brooklyn yesterAt the day on charges of conspiring to influence sports contests. Also indicted were four jockeys who were said to have accepted the bribes to control the way their horses ran.

title: Harry Knowlton, Professor, Field Examiner for N.L.R.B.
description: Harry E. Knowiton, who had been a professor of horticulture at the University of West Virginia and a field examiner for the National Labor Relations Board in San Francisco, Boston and New York, died yesterday in the Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Hal Wissel, Fordham University's basketball coach. denied last night that his job was in danger as a result of his team's 714 wonlost record. Reports of disharmony between the Ram players and the coach fueled rumors that Wissel was about to be replaced. Among the reported replacements was Frank McLaughlin, the assistant to Digger Phelps Notre Dame. Wissel said he had met with members of the administration yesterday. They said there had been no discussion about my contract, about terminating it, about anything, he said.

title: 7th Ave: 3 Hits Bring Joy
description: Things are looking up in the state of fashion. Three smash hits in a row were enough to send store people into the snow with smiles on their faces and visions of summer dancing in their heads.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1976

title: About New York
description: The doubledecker bus is supposed to return to Fifth Avenue in the spring, and it should bring with it a certain charm. Charm is the least definable of New York's qualities, but when it is there, everyone knows it. Everyone knows a doubledecker bus has charm.

title: Two Federal Judges Issue a Warning to Merola
description: A new stern warning was issued yesterday by two Federal judges who declared that prosecutors who made improper statements about criminal cases could be vulnerable to damage suits for violating the rights of defendants.

title: Regional Opportunity
description: The proposal by City Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso that the state take over New York City's watersupply system and manage it on behalf of the broader southeastern region represents a potentially significant breakthrough in citysuburban relations.

title: Visa Is Sweet Sorrow to a Soviet Couple
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  Aleksandr and Lyudmila Lunts have packed their books in suitcases. They have begun to say goodbye to friends. They are finally going to Israel.

title: Ford Approves Funding For Railways; Hails Bill
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 5 (AP) President Ford today signed and praised a $6.4 billion bill to fund a new railroad system from the seven financially ailing Northeastern carriers and to provide new regulatory flexibility for all railroads.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Visa Is Sweet Sorrow to a Soviet Couple
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  Aleksandr and Lyudmila Lunts have packed their books in suitcases. They have begun to say goodbye to friends. They are finally going to Israel.

title: GAS DEREGULATION LOSES IN HOUSE IN SURPRISE VOTE
Rickles Enters Contest For Peyser's House Seat
