description: YONKERS, Feb. 5Robert N. Rickles, former Air Resources Commissioner in New York City, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 23d Congressional District.

title: Rutgers Memorial Service Pays Homage to Robeson
Flyers' Dry Spell Ends at 5 Games
GAS DEREGULATION LOSES IN HOUSE IN SURPRISE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Liberal Democrats, in a dramatic comeback, defeated the Administrationbacked naturalgas deregulation bill on the House floor today, making it unlikely that any such measure would emerge from Congress this year.

title: State Acts to Cut DayCare Center Costs
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5The state has announced tough new measures to cut costs at the city's publicly financed daycare centers, to speed up licensing of the centers and to eliminate those that do not meet standards.

title: CAREY IS DISPUTED ON TAX REVENUES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5A panel of legislators was told today that a realistic projection of tax revenues for next year would reduce the need for budget cutbacks proposed by Governor Carey.

title: Hirschfeld Backers List Business Profit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The campaign organization backing Abraham Hirschfeld for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate has filed a financial report here indicating it made a profit by helping) to build a Bronx garage.

title: Burglars File Complaint
description: CAMP HILL, Pa. (UPI) Burglars broke into Dr. Samuel L. Jones's office, ransacked it and left a note complaining that nothing there was worth stealing. We could not find a thing to steal, said a note left in the doctor's typewriter. However, the note added, Sorry for the mess.

title: A SPECIAL INQUIRY ON C.I.A. AND F.B.I. URGED BY CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence called today for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate evidence of criminal activity by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: World Agricultural Development Fund Is Set Up
description: ROME, Feb. 5Representatives from 74 countries reached agreement here today on the terms for the creation of an International Fund for Agricultural Development to help poor countries increase their food production with lowinteres loans.

title: Control Board Is Seeking Negotiations To End Local City University Subsidy
Providence Defeats Niagara Five, 7667
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I, Feb. 5 (AP)Joe Hassett scored 13 of his gamehigh 21 points in the second half tonight in leading Providence to a 7667 basketball victory over Niagara.

title: HOUSE PANEL HEARS ABORTION ARGUMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Opponents of efforts to overturn the Supreme Court's liberal abortion rights decision argued today that Congress cannot stop abortion, merely limit it to the rich or create hazardous medical conditions.

title: A.M.A. Disputes, but Others Praise, Series About Incompetent Physicians
SOUTH KOREA CALM AS CURBS CONTINUE
Judging the Judges
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 5A young black man is convicted in an American city of dealing in drugs and gets a substantial prison sentence. A middleclass white youth from a respected family in a nearby suburb is convicted of the same offense and gets a suspended sentence. In one courtroom, a homicide conviction brings a life sentence, which in practice may mean 15 years in prison. But in another courtroom, in the same courthouse, the penalty for a homicide committed in similar circumstances may be one to five years, with the possibility of early parole.

title: School Boards Urge State To Change Aid Formula
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP)Tha state should scrap its present stateaid formula and return to a formula based on the taxable wealth of school districts, the State School Boards Association said today.

title: TV NETWORKS SEE AD SALES RECORDS
description: Despite a slight decline in daily viewing, an extremely high rate of program failure and a critical consensus that regular program fare has been notably poor, the three television networks are forecasting record revenues and profits for 1976 on the basis of advance sales.

title: Dixon Replaces Walker in Coast Mile
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP)John Walker has pulled out of the featured mile race and Filbert Bayi won't be here, either, but the event still figures to excite the crowd at tomorrow night's Los Angeles Times Indoor Games. The spotlight shifts to Rod Dixon, Walker's New Zealand countryman, and Paul Cummings, former National Collegiate champion from Brigham Young.

title: ARGENTINE FUNDS AIDED TERRORISTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5A retired army lieutenant has testified before a congressional investigatory committee that foreignmade submachine guns were purchased with funds of Argentina's Ministry of Social Welfare to arm a rightwing organization known as the Triple A.

title: PATRICIA HEARST IS QUOTED ON S.LA.
ENERGETIC ELATION IN CURSON'S SEPTET
description: Ted Curson, an imaginative, creative and warmly communicative trumpet and flugelhorn player who has done most of his performing in Europe in the last 10 years, appeared with his sevenpiece group for three nights this week at the. Tin Palace, Second Street at the Bowery, and will return there on Sunday evening.

title: ITALIAN SOCIALISTS WON'T OPPOSE MORO
Barge Tour a Slight to Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.,It's being called the Battle of Saratoga, Part II, and it stars a cast of thousands said to feel they are being treated like a rabble in arms by the State Bicentennial Commission.

title: Cran Man Set to Push Ocean Spray Message
description: Soon to join all of our television favorites such a George Whipple and the Man from Glad will be the Cran Man, who will be pushing his Cran Wagon for all the world to see.

title: MARY W. MILBANK
description: Mary Weatherbee Milbank, widow of Dr. Samuel Milbank, physician and past president of the Westminster Kennel Club, died Wednesday at her home at 610 Park Avenlue. She was 89 years old.

title: French Party Endorsing A National Communism
description: PARIS, Feb. 5A proposal that the French Communist Party broaden its appeal by dropping a key Marxist doctrine and seek power through democratic means was endorsed today by delegate after delegate at the party's national congress here.

title: A Borzoi Poiodle Slips by Soviet Customs
description: When a group of refugees from Eastern Europe stepped off Flight 833 from Vienna at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, the most pampered of them stood only two and a half feet high. The refugee, with a long nose and doleful eyes was a borzoi bitch,. one of a very few to come put: of the Soviet Union suite Revolution.

title: Squires Get Loan, Stay In League
. . . Too Little Control
description: What the nation needs is an anticipatory bankexamination and regulation system. A helpful start would be to have the Federal Reserve's economists and bank examiners work together to evaluate the volume and composition of the loan commitments being made by the banks under their supervision, and their anticipated cash flow. It is when commitments are made that the Fed should pay attention. Are loans to the airlines or to oil tanker operators or to condominium builders getting out of hand? Are bank loans to an industry collectively outrunning its probable capacity needs? Answering such questions is the only way to insure that bank inspection is not ineffectual and backwardlooking.

title: Notes on People
description: The Reader's Digest got its third editor in chief in its 53year history yesterday when Edward T. Thompson was named to succeed Hobart D. Lewis, who will continue as chairman of the board. Mr. Lewis succeeded the coeditors and founders, the late DeWitt Wallace and Lila Acheson Wallace, in 1964, Mr. Thompson, a resident of Armonk, N. Y., received a degree in chemical engineering in 1949 from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He began as a technical editor for McGrawHill and came to the Reader's Digest in 1960 after four years at Fortune magazine.

title: 11 City Students Reach the Finals In Westinghouse Science Contest
Hearst Jury Sees Film
description: Movies of the bank robbery for which Patricia Hearst is on trial were shown in court. and two of her former associates pleaded that she not sell them out to gain her own freedom. Details on Page 26.

title: Relief Aides Say 3,000 Died in Quake in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 5Inter national relief workers believe that more than 3,000 people have died since a major earthquake struck this Central American republic early yesterday,

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  ofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: TAXFREE YIELDS CLIMB SLIGHTLY
description: The bond market, which had been pushed down by sales earlier this week as investors prepared to switch into new Treasury securities, bounced back yesterday after the surprising results o the Government's note sale. Trading then quieted down as dealers and investors sat back to analyze the results.

title: About Real Estate
description: The rise of the professional realestate management company run by blacks has been one of the significant side effects of the growth of Governmentfinanced housing.

title: Bobick Tops Boxing Card At Garden
description: Undefeated Duane Bobick will continue his cautious advance to a possible shot at the heavyweight championship tonight in the feature event of a boxing card that contains four 10round fights at Madison Square Garden.

title: 64 WORK IS PLAYED BY LASALLE QUARTET
description: The LaSalle String Quartet, an ensemble known especially for its performance of 20thcentury music, featured Witold Lutoslawski's Quartet (1964) in the concert it gave Wednesday night at Hunter College Playhouse.

title: Radu Lupu Plays Piano Persuasively
description: There are always plenty of pianists around who come out charging, all flags flying, attempting to excite us with trumpets and drums and machinegun fire. There are a few others who try to conquer by indirection, working on our imaginations, slipping under our defenses. They understand that persuasion wins the lasting victories.

title: 2 British Frigates To Guard Trawlers Fishing Off Iceland
description: LONDON, Feb. 5Two British frigates were ordered into the disputed fishing grounds around Iceland tonight to protect British trawlers there.

title: BYRNE'S TAX PLAN DRAWS UNION FIRE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5Charles H. Marciante, president of New Jersey's A.F.L.C.I.O., criticized Governor Byrne's approach to a state income tax today as all or nothing.

title: Wiz Film Rights Bought by Harper
description: Motion picture rights to The Wiz, the allblack musical version of The Wizard of Oz. entirely financed by 20th CenturyFox, have been acquired by Ken Harper, producer of the longrunning Broadway show.

title: Burglars File Complaint
description: CAMP HILL, Pa. (UPI)Burglars broke into Dr. Samuel L. Jones's office, ransacked It and left a note complaining that nothing there was worth stealing. We could not find a thing to steal, said a note left in the doctor's typewriter. However, the note added, Sorry for the mess.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Jane Bryden, Arthur Burrows Sing Wolf's Italian Songbook
description: Hugo Wolf's Italienisches Liederbuch is the last of his song cycles. It is an extraordinary compendium of poetry, mostly about love, and subtly complex music. Its 46 songs make a perfectly timed program, but the collection is a difficult one to master from an interpretive standpoint, and if not a rarity, it isn't exactly a staple in our concert life, either.

title: DR. V. A. HOFMANN
Solti Makes Local Debut With Ninth
description: In his many visits to New York with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Sir Georg Sold has conducted numerous largescale works  the Verdi Requiem, Wagner's Das Rheingold, Schoenberg's Moses and Aaron among them. (On May 14, as an additional example, he will present in Carnegie Hall Wagner's The Flying Dutchman.) His performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony with the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, however, was his first in this city. The occasion was a benefit concert for the orchestra's pension fund. The soloists were Heather Harper, soprano; Mignon Dunn, mezzosoprano; Stuart Burrows, tenor, and John Macurdy, bass. The chorus was the Camerata Singers, directed by Abraham Kaplan.

title: Poodles Remain Most Popular Breed
description: For the 15th consecutive year, poodles are the most popular pure breed in America, according to registration figures kept by the American Kennel. Club. In 1975, 139,750 poodles were listed of a total of 1,022,849 dogs representing 121 breeds.

title: More Cuts Planned In Gasoline Prices
description: Texaco Inc., the Sun Oil Company and the Getty Oil Company announced yesterday that they were cutting the price of gasoline by a cent a gallon and the Sun Oil Company reduced the price by 1.1 cent a gallon following price cuts by other major oil companies over the last 10 days. At the same time, Texaco announced that posted prices for rack and barge lots of selected: residual fuels were being increased in amounts ranging from 20 cents to 30 cents a barrel.

title: A GIFT TO NEEDIEST RECALLS THE PAST
description: A mother whose daughter's name is Sarah Jane recalled that years ago she sent a contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help the plight of a needy child also named Sarah Jane.

title: PAPER STRIKE ENDS AT BATHURST LTD.
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP) Workers at four ConsolidatedBathurst Ltd. pulp and paper mills in Quebec returned to work today, ending a strike that started last Oct. 11.

title: A Turning Point fo the City
description: New York City is entering a state of siege in a war of survival for its life and soul. Its threeyear fiscal plan requires New York City to became Sparta and its managers to become monks. It had a chance of success, all other things remaining equal, but things have not remained equal. Cutbacks in Federal and state aid, increased welfare costs and inflation have caused a deteriorating fiscal situation.

title: People in Sports
description: Rumors that Chuck Knox would leave the Los Angeles Rams to become coach of another National Football League team were ended yesterday when he signed a fiveyear contract with the Rams. There will also be mutual options for five more years.

title: Relief Aides Say 3,000 Died in Quake in Guatemala
197075 Absentee Rates At Big 3 Car Concerns
Commodity Price Index Up 1.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 190.3 from 188.7 last week.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1976

title: Berman Plays With Jersey Symphony
END OF PUBLIC TV SEEN IN CUTBACK
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5The execcutive director of the New Jersey Broadcasting Authority said today that if Governor Byrne's budget cuts of $2.4 million were implemented for the coming fiscal year it would mean an end to public television in the state.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Roderick Beebe Jr. (Yale '33) looks robust. Color in his cheeks, eyes that shine, quick smile. He looks like the kind of fellow who might enjoy leading young men into the wilderness to teach them the ways of the forests and the rivers.

title: Rutgers, Warriors Triumph
LOCKHEED GROUP TO SCAN PAYMENTS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which has aiready admitted having paid at least $22 million on in bribes overseas, yesterday named a fourman committee of outside directors to supervise and audit an investigation of commissions and payments on sales contracts,

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fewer than 100 construction workers were on the job yesterday at eight cityfinanced housing projects threatened with a shutdown because a bill that would rescue them has become stalled in the State Senate. The workers, along with supervisors, were involved in maintenance and security in anticipation of a shutdown. Some were doing roof work on a South Bronx job. The projects, being built under the city's MitchellLama housing program, are in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the world's great players, Adam Meredith, died here in obscurity a week ago at the age of 62.

title: Article 2  No Title
Senate Acts to Curtail Bribes And Kickbacks in Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Senate moved today to damp the payment of fees, kickbacks and bribes in international arms deals when members approved a bipartisan amendment to the military aid bill that would force disclosure of such payments.

title: Shots Traded in Rome At Egyptian Compound
description: ROME, Feb. 5 (AP)Two unidentified gunmen exchanged fire with policemen in the wooded grounds of the Egyptian Embassy late tonight. Hundreds of policemen with submachine guns and tracker dogs mounted a search for them.

title: Outgoing President Gives Her View of Bennington
Hearst Jurors See Film; Harrises Fear a Sellout
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5While Patricia Hearst was showing cool curiosity toward movies of herself as a bank robber, shown at her trial in Federal District Court here today, two of her former associates pleaded that she not sell them out to gain her own freedom.

title: AntiConcorde Measure
description: Special to The New York Times,

title: Books of The Times
description: Jacques Vach, one of the most interesting Dadaists, is said to have ascended the stage of a theater in Paris and threatened with a revolver anyone who dared to applaud a play he disliked. This is the sort of image many people have of John Simon. He is seen as a man who makes theater out of attacking plays, who attempts to put on in his column a better performance than the one he is criticizing.

title: 2 Key MoneySupply Measures in Mixed Pattern
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the two principal measures of the nation's money supply had traced divergent patterns in the latest statement week.

title: 8th Season Starting For Youth Orchestra
description: PARAMUS, Feb. 5The Russian composer Dmitri Shostakovich wrote the orchestra a thankyou note last year after it devoted a concert to his work.

title: SLIPPERY ROADS EXPECTED HERE
description: Commuters in the metropolitan area may have tough sledding getting to work this morning, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Metal Sales Weak
Senator Scott Is Focus Of Gulf Oil Fund Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader, is the focus of Federal investigations for allegedly receiving money from the Gulf Oil Corporation's $5 million domestic political fund, Senate and Justice Department sources said today.

title: Feminist Lawyers Look at Alimony: Not All Bad, They Say
description: Are feminists opposed to alimony? Apparently many of them are, or think they should be, and that applies to both younger and older women.

title: French Fly Troops to Djibouti as Somalia Rift Widens
Special Financing Aids Tenement's Conversion
description: HOBOKEN, Feb. 5A 100 yearold onetime tenement building here, basically sturdy but long empty and decaying, was undergoing a transformation today into what officials hope will be a trim l0unit apartment dwelling, with the help of an unusual Federal, state and local financing program.

title: F.C.C. Rules on Cable TV Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Justice Department challenged today the Government rules restricting the films and sports events that can be shown on cable television and charged that if the rules had been developed by the broadcasters they would violate the antitrust laws.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Long Island Lighting Company plans to sell to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation 50 percent of its interest in each of two 1,150 megawatt nuclear power units planned for construction at Jamesport. The sale price is more than $500 million for the units, which are scheduled for operation in 1983 and 1985. The sale was part of an exchange of planned generating capacity announced earlier this week in which Long Island Lighting would purchase roughly $1 billion in capacity from New York State Electric and Gas.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: PORTUGUESE REDS SPURNED ON PACT
description: LISBON, Feb. 5The Socialists have rebuffed a quiet but insistent effort by the Portuguese Communist Party to ally with them for the coming legislative elections.

title: BUTZ HOLIDAY HELD GIFT FROM RAILROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Southern Railway Company paid expenses for Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz and his administrative assistant at the Southern Railway Club at Dorchester, S. C., during the Christmas holiday, The Washington Post reported tonight.

title: E.P.A. Aide Hits U.S. Steel On Environmental Record
description: The second ranking official of the United States Environmental Protection Agency charged here yesterday that United States Steel has compiled a record of environmental recalcitrance which is second to none. The charge was disputed immediately, at the same meeting, by the company's environmental affairs vice president.

title: French Party Endorsing A National Communism
description: PARIS, Feb. 5A proposal that the French Communist Party broaden its appeal by dropping a key Marxist doctrine and seek power through democratic means was endorsed today by delegate after delegate at the party's national congress here.

title: Carey Tilts to Economy at Expense of Environment
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Governor Carey's decision to stress economic recovery, even at the expense of some of the recent gains of the environmental movement, reflects not only a belief that strict environmental regulations are bad for business, but also a political judgment that the environmental movement has run its course and that most people are now more interested in such issues as jobs and taxes.

title: FOES OF CONCORDE LOSE SENATE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5A Senate committee narrowly defeated today a proposal that would have barred flights by the Concorde supersonic jet anywhere in the United States, except in an emergency, on the ground that the plane is too noisy and poses environmental hazards.

title: POTATO FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday after a report that Belgium now had agreed to the landing of a ship from Maine loaded with potatoes. The May deilvery on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed at 16.05 cents a pound un from 15.70.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Notes on People column in The New York Times yesterday referred erroneously to the late DeWitt Wallace, cofounder and former coeditor of Reader's Digest with his wife, Lila Acheson Wallace, A statement by the Wallaces appears in today's column, on Page 27.

title: ROCKEFELLER PLANS SERIES OF SPEECHES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Acting independently of the White House, Vice President Rockefeller has scheduled a series of 10 speeches around the nation that aides call controversial. They insisted today that he was not running for President.

title: Quota for Women Lawyers Agreed To by Major Firm
description: An unusual agreement that sets a quota for offering more jobs to women lawyers has been accepted by the major New York law firm of Rogers & Wells in the settlement of a sexdiscrimination suit against the highly influential firm.

title: U.N. Aide Asks That More Relief Be Sent to Guatemala
description: An international airlift of relief supplies to Guatemala gathered momentum yesterday, but even before a second earthquake hit the country a United Nations spokesman in Geneva said that aid reaching the devastated zone was probably not enough to meet the minimal human requirements.

title: T. L. Bodnar Weds Linda M. Mancini
description: Linda Marie Mancini, daughter of Judge Philip Mancini of the Connecticut Common Pleas Court and Mrs. Mancini of Woodbridge, Conn., was married there yesterday evening to Thomas L. Bodnar, a lawyer in South Bend, Ind. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Bodnar, also of South Bend, where his father, an orthopedic surgeon, is team physician for the University of Notre Dame.

title: DR. FREDERICK FREED
description: Dr. Frederick C. Freed, formerly an obstetrician and gynecologist at Doctors Hospital and former clinical professor at New York University School of Medicine, died Wednesday at his home, 360 East 55th Street. He was 86 years old.

title: Study of Rhythm Birth Control Is Begun
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP)A Log Angeles hospital has begun what it says is the first federally funded scientific study to determine the effectiveness of the socalled rhythm method of birth control.

title: Hospital Relents on Policy To Allow Midwife's Help
description: Hope Murphy may have a woman coach present during the birth of her child, Huntington (L.I.) Hospital decided after a State Supreme Court justice declined to rule against the hospital, which had previously refused to allow anyone but the father to coach during natural childbirth.

title: People and Business
description: We suffer not from lack of government action, but from excess of government action, the Treasury Secretary, William E. Simon, said yesterday in a luncheon address here launching New York City's bicentennial campaign for United States sayinns bonds.

title: GUATEMALA TOLL OF DEAD MOUNTS AMID NEW SHOCKS
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 6Powerful aftershocks spread panic through the streets of the capital today, just two days after a major earthquake left at least 5,000 dead, by official estimate. Unofficial death toll figures ranged as high as 14,000.

title: 3.6Inch Snowfall Is Recorded in City; Suburbs Hit Harder
description: For more than 16 hours, ending yesterday morning, snow fell on the city and its suburbs. The snow added up to 3.61 inches in Central Park and somewhat more in the outlying areas. During the afternoon there were some scattered flurries.

title: Special Ceremony Is Set For FireAlarm Inventor
ARNOLD PETERSEN, SOCIALIST LABORITE
description: Arnold Petersen, who retired in 1969 after 55 years as national secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, died Thursday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson, N. J. He was 90 years old and had lived in Teaneck, N. J., for many years.

title: Concert: From Marlboro
Star Class Series To Schoonmaker
description: MIAMI, Feb. 6James (Ding) Schoonmaker of Miami, the world champion, and Bill Buchan of Seattle, 1970 world champion, ended the fiverace Star Class Baccardi Cup series tied in points at 305 today. But Schoonmaker was awarded the championship on the basis of overall performance.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: By The Associated Press

title: Wife of Hatfield Called Agent in Sale Sought by the Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A report circulated here tonight that the wife of Senator Mark Hatfield was acting as real estate agent in efforts in which Saudi Arabia was seeking to buy a building for diplomatic offices in a restricted area of Washington.

title: JOBS RISE 800,000, CLOSE TO RECORD FOR SINGLE MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The nation's unemployment rate, reflecting continuing recovery from the 197475 recession, fell substantially in January as total employment showed a nearrecord rise, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Harold Erichs, Treasurer, Financial Officer of Variety
description: Harold Erichs, treasurer and financial officer of Variety, the showbusiness weekly newspaper, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: Affirmative Action, Quotas and Merit
description: The moral legitimacy of affirmative action and quotas favoring racial minorities must be assessed in a social and historical context, in the light of the many conflicting values that our society holds.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side of the  street regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The speed limit on United States Highway 287 is 88 kilometers an hour. For those unfamiliar with the metric system, the translation is on the same sign: 55 miles an hour.

title: Hearing Told of Need to Guard Rights of Cooperative Buyers
description: New legislation to protect the rights of purchasers of condominiums and cooperative apartments was called for yesterday by speakers at a hearing before a state legislative panel.

title: Banks Lend $180 Million To Help Rescue the U.D.C.
description: The yearlong attempt to rescue the stricken State Urban Development Corporation took a major step forward yesterday when 76 savings banks provided a $180 million loan for the agency's use.

title: $98 Million Offer
ALL 6 ACQUITTED IN CARSON TRIAL
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other men were acquitted yesterday of all charges stemming from the death of a 34 yearold Brooklyn man.

title: Antiques: The Carousel
description: The widespread cannibalization of merrygorounds that led three years ago to the founding of the National Carrousel Roundtable has not ended.

title: GAS PIPELINE BACKED FROM ALASKA TO U.S.
Ability Is Issue in New Hampshire Race
Butz, Berated for Visiting Lodge, to Pay Half of Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today he attended a Southern Railway Company hunting lodge party and might do so againbut he later agreed to help the Government reimburse the railway to avoid even the appearance of impropriety.

title: Capping the Tap
description: The selfdefeating stock transfer tax imposed on brokerage houses by New York last year is causing a shift of Wall Street firms to New Jerseysmall so far, but gathering momentum in response to wooing of brokers by that state's Economic Development Authority. New York City is still moving in reverse in its own jobcreation drive, despite the high priority assigned to that essential endeavor by both Mayor Beame and Governor Carey.

title: Folk Dancing Isn't Necessarily Square
description: The man said, as if the idea had Just occurred to him, It's really a sort of subculture.

title: 7 Soviet Jews Say Israel Was Harsh
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6  Seven Soviet Jews were presented publicly by Soviet authorities today to explain why they had chosen to return home after emigrating to Israel.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: AnacondaTenneco Deal Seen as Remote by Crane
description: The chairman of the Crane Company, which holds a large block of stock of the Anaconda Company and which is seeking more, said yesterday that the possibility of a merger between Anaconda and Tenneco Inc. was remote. Such a merger, he asserted, is certainly not in the best interests of Anaconda shareholders.

title: Of Thee I Sing
description: ALLENDALE, N. J.When I first came to the United States over twenty years ago, this country was for me totally virgin land, uncharted, unknown. My experience of my own country was rather thin: War had overshadowed my youth and limited the process of becoming.

title: Somalia Accuses France
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 6 (UPI)Somalia charged today that French forces killed 23 persons, including 11 women and children, in an attack with tanks, armored cars and artillery at a border town last Wednesday.

title: She Helps Gardening Enthusiasts Find Their Way Through Confusing Halls of Ivy
Ethel Shutta, Singer, Dies at 79; Had a 70Year Stage Career
description: Ethel Shutta, the singer whose career in show business spanned more than 70 years, died Thursday night in St. Clare's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Bridge:
description: There are times when a postmortem can add insult to injury, especially in rubber bridge. The declarer brings home a slam by careful play, and the defenders are feeling injured by the fates. But an interfering kibitzer then points out an exotic line of defense that would have defeated the contract.

title: French Veto Move In U.N. Opposing Vote in Comoro Isle
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 (AP)France vetoed a resolution tonight in the Security Council that would have asked the French to call off a referendum Sunday on Mayotte in the Comoro Islands.

title: U.S. Skater Wins
description: Sheila Young, a 25yearold speed skater from Detroit, won a gold medal in the Olympic Winter Games yesterday in Innsbruck, Austria. She finished first in the 500meter sprint in an Olympic record time of 42.76 seconds. Details, Page 13.

title: Unemployment Rate Dips Here, But Is Still Above May's Figure
Reilly Counsel Would Query Prosecutor
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 6Hearings on Peter Reilly's petition for a new murder trial were recessed today amid an unusual legal battle over whether the State's Attorney could be forced to take the stand and testify about allegedly suppressed evidence that might hive cleared the 20yearold youth.

title: CAREY PRESSURED, CUNNINGHAM SAYS
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, asserted yesterday that Governor Carey had been pressured into signing an order enabling Maurice H. Nadjari to prosecute political corruption in the Bronx because he feared being subjected to the vicious slander of Nadjari.

title: Allin Posts 75, Still Holds Stroke Lead
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 6The rain fell today on rich and poor alike, driving up scores in the third day of the Bob Hope Desert Classic. It was hard rain, too, accompanied by strong winds and chilly temperatures.

title: JANE H. LOVEJOY
description: Jane Howell Lovejoy, a former president of the Detroit Board of Education and a former governor of Wayne University, died Tuesday at her home here. She was 75 years old and formerly lived in Amagansett, L. I.

title: We've Lost the Little We Had
description: ZACAPA, Guatemala, Feb. 6The front of the house is standing, but the rest has been destroyed, Rosario Alvarez de Reyes said, pointing at her adobe hut. It will have to be rebuilt, but we don't have the money.

title: Rumsfeld Sees Cruise Missiles As Aid to Strategic Bombers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the air launched cruise missile, which has become one of the controversial issues in the strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union, would be of considerable value in enhancing the capability of strategic bombers.

title: Fire in Canada Kills 8
description: DORION, Ontario, Feb. 6 (ReutersEight members of a family of 11 died today when a fire swept their home in this small community on the TransCanada Highway. The father and seven children died. His wife and two teenage sons escaped.

title: Article 1  No Title
A DUTCH OFFICIAL PAID BY LOCKHEED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has paid about $2 million to Government officials in Japan and $1.1 million to a high official of the Netherlands to promote the sale of its airplanes, the company's chief operating officer said today.

title: Soto Bows To FillIn; Bobick Wins
description: Unbeaten Duane Bobick of Bowlus, Minn., disposed of 34yearold Larry Middleton of Baltimore in desultory fashion last night in their 10round heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden. Bobick won his 34th match, but failed to impress any of the 8,435 fans who contributed to a gate of $67,808.03.

title: Wilson's Press Officer Suing Times of London
description: LONDON, Feb. 6Prime Minister Harold Wilson's chief press officer is suing The Times of London for libel for suggesting, even humorously, that his department might not always tell the truth.

title: Taking of Profit Is a Major Factor
description: Stock prices continued to drop in heavy profit taking yesterday as the first sustained setback to the 1976 bull market hit Wall Street.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: JOBLESS RATE CUT IS HAILED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  President Ford, citing a substantial drop in the unemployment rate last month, assured Republican leaders here today that the steady course he had set for economic recovery would curtail unemployment without quickfix gimmicks and snake oil solutions.

title: Queen, a British Rock Quartet, Plays 3 Shows at the Beacon
description: Queen, the British quartet that opened a threenight run Thursday at the Beacon Theater, makes a particular kind of progressive rock music.

title: Roger Livesey, Character Actor On Stage and Screen, Is Dead
description: WATFORD, England, Feb. 6 (UPI)Roger Livesey, veteran character actor, died yesterday after a 50year stage, movie and television career. He was 69 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Madrid Cabinet Moves to Widen the Right of Assembly
description: MADRID, Feb. 6The Spanish Cabinet, in a move to carry out its promises of political change, today approved legislation that would widen the right of assembly.

title: Market Place
description: Some investors who have used the investment annuity to shelter dividend and interest income from immediate taxes are now combining the annuity wrapper with Keogh plan investments to shelter capital Rains as well.

title: Notes on People
description: Less than eight months after he entered prison, convicted for perjury in a Watergate case, Dwight L. Chapin will be paroled April 2 from the minimumsecurity Federal prison in Lompoc. Calif. Toplevel officials of the Federal Parole Board announced yesterday that it would parole Mr. Chapin, a former appointments secretary under President Nixon.

title: Jamaica's Hotels Losing Tourists Frightened by Violence in Slums
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 6Within two days after warring political gangs attacked each other and the police in the Kingston slums a month ago, the popular Doctors Cave Beach Hotel in Montego Bay across the island received cancellations for 30 of its 75 rooms.

title: SECRECY WARNING IS ISSUED BY LEVI
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 6 (UPI) Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that attempts to monitor United States intelligence agencies should not lead to Congressional attempts to manage them.

title: Jury Sees Enlarged Films Of Miss Hearst in Holdup
CLARK'S COMMITTEE HAS RAISED $60,000
description: The Ramsey Clark/Senate '76 Committee, the campaign organization for the former United States Attorney General in his current effort to win the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, announced yesterday that it had raised about $60,000 from 2,500 contributors.

title: Big Stores Sales Climbed Only 3.5% Here Last Month
description: After an 8 percent gain in December, the largest in 16 months, retail sales of New York's biggest stores showed an average gain of only 3.5 percent in January from the yearearlier level.

title: Same Apartment Taken By 34 Bilked Tenants
U.S., Canada Advance in Softball
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 6 (AP)The United States beat South Africa, 51, today and gained the semifinals of the world softball championships. The United States team from Reading, Pa., will meet the defending champion, Canada, a 10 winner over New Zealand today, in the first semifinal tomorrow. The loser of this game will play the JapanNew Zealand winner in the other semifinal.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY DISMISSES BELSKY
description: Jack D. Belsky, $46,000 ayear chief of the Transit Authority's surface operations until he was suspended on misconduct charges last March, was formally dismissed from the authority yesterday, and lost all his pension benefits.

title: Union Here Delays A Planned Walkout In Nursing Homes
description: The union representing 12,000 employees at 91 nursing homes here agreed yesterday to postpone a threatened strike until at least the middle of next week, pending a hearing in Federal court on a petition by the state to enjoin a walkout.

title: Ashe, Ramirez, Okker, Gottfried Gain in W.C.T..
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 6 (AP) Topseeded Arthur Ashe of Richmond breezed past Jiri Hrebec of Czechoslovakia, 64, 61, tonight in the quarter finals of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: A Provocative View of New Yorkers
description: THE NEW YORKERS. By Andrew Hacker. 182 pages. Mason/C,harter. $10.In The New Yorkers, Andrew Hacker, a. political scientist and obviously a lover of his city, tries to describe the people who live here. His social commentary is rooted in census tracts that cover the Lindsay years, and his analyses are provocative and fascinating and should be readnot necessarily acceptedby anyone who worries about New York.

title: Connally Jests at the Candidates
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6Insiders of the sort that go to Alfalfa Club dinners here are still celebrating John B. Connally's emergence as a comedian. In accepting the club's mock presidential nomination, the former Texas Governor and Treasury Secretary remarked that Howand H. Callaway, President Ford's campaign manager, held a high strategy meeting the other day in the White House messjust down the hall from where they ate.

title: Minuteman 3 Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP)A Minuteman 3 intercontinental ballistic missile was launched early today, Air Force officials said. The launching was conducted by a Strategic Air Command missile combat crew from F. E. Warren Air Force Base in Wyoming. An Air Force spokesman said the launching was part of a series of operational test launches to test the total reliability of the Minuteman system.

title: 4 BANKS DEFEND BOYCOTT POLICY
description: Officers of four major banks testified at a legislative committee hearing yesterday that, in their opinion Arab countries were boycotting Israel for economicand not racial or roilgiousreasons.

title: Kennedy Bronx Victor
Oh Dear, What Can the Matter Be?
ADAMS PROGRAM PROVES POPULAR
description: The highly publicized public television series The Adams Chronicles has, after three episodes, proved one of WNETChannel 13's most popular programs.

title: Impish Artists Twit the State
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6You think you are in a plain dining room at first. There is a table covered with an oilcloth, with cups of steaming tea. Then you realize you are in a studio. Canvases are everywherehung on the wall, stacked in corners. Finally you begin to think you are on a stage, sitting between two young actor who are throwing quick lines back and forth.

title: Problem: $1 Sold Is (X) Earned
description: DALLASA widely publicized survey says the public grossly overestimated the average aftertax profits of United States manufacturers at 32 cents on each sales dollar as compared to the correct figure of 5.2 cents.

title: Wissel in Center Of a Controversy
description: Fordham's basketball coach, Hal Wissel, is caught in a controversy over his relationship with his players and whether his job is secure as he prepares, to send his Rams against St. John's in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. Manhattan plays Fairfield in the opening game at 7 o'clock.

title: JOBS RISE 800,000, CLOSE TO RECORD FOR SINGLE MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The nation's unemployment rate, reflecting continuing recovery from the 197475 recession, felt substantially in January as total employment showed a nearrecord rise, the Labor Department reported today.

title: The Baffler in Brooklyn: Pinto Pony in the Parlor
description: The tenants of apartment 1A on the ground floor of 1583 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn have moved out, leaving behind in the living room a television set and an old couch. And a horse.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Notes on People column in The New York Times yesterday referred erroneously to the late DeWitt Wallace, cofounder and former coeditor of Reader's Digest with his wife, Lila Acheson Wallace. A statement by the Wallaces appears in today's column, on Page 27.

title: PHIL WOODS QUARTET PLAYING AT HOPPER'S
description: Phil Woods's geographica wanderings have taken him from Springfield, Mass., to New York, to Bucks County, Pennsylvania, to Paris and now back to New York, and his musical evolution has followed an equally zigzag course in and out of Charlie Parker influences in search of his own identity as a saxophonist. This week and next he is leading a quartet at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street.

title: White House Discounts Visit, Which Will Be at a Delicate Time
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6White House officials said today that President Ford was irritated about former President Richard M. Nixon's impending trip to China, although publicly he was noncommittal.

title: Some Banks Offer a Trimmed Rate
description: A discounted prime lending rate, known as the superprime, has appeared in the nation's banking system because of slack demand for commercial loans and the fairly wide profit margins currently in effect on bank credit.

title: Cubs Sign Madlock To 1976 Contract
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)Bill Madlock, the National League batting champion last season, signed his 1976 contract today with the Chicago Cubs. The hardhitting third baseman, who topped the league with a .354 average, is reported to have received more than a 100 percent increase in salary.

title: Trip, Initiated by Peking, Set for Feb. 21 and Termed Private
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 6Former President Richard M. Nixon will visit China with his wife, Pat, beginning Feb. 21. A spokesman said that the visit had been initiated by the Chinese Government and would be strictly private.

title: GUATEMALA TOLL OF DEAD MOUNTS AMID NEW SHOCKS
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 6Powerful aftershocks spread panic through the streets of the capital today, just two days after a major earthquake left at least 5,000 dead, by official estimate. Unofficial death toll figures ranged as high as 14,000.

title: Brooklyn Brothers Facing Sentencing On U.S. Tax Fraud
description: Two brothersone the head of a bank and the other the President of an insulation manufacturing companyface sentencing for seeking to defraud the Government of more than $900,000 in taxes on personal and corporate income of more than $1.75 million.

title: Trumpet Concerto Of Rovics Marked By Inventiveness
description: Modernmusic concerts do, not generally feature works that might be described as use ful, so it was a pleasure to encounter one at the Leagues of ComposersInternational Society of Contemporary Music program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night.

title: Permission Given
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 6 (AP)Caroline Kennedy was almost expelled from the Olympic Ice Stadium during the hockey game between the United States and the Soviet Union today when she took pictures from an area that was off limits to photographers

title: The Measure of Greatness
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 6In 1973, at San Sebastian, Spain, Sheila Young fell off her bike and with her arms and legs bleeding went on to win a world cycling championship.

title: Heroic, Inventive Nudes of Philip Pearlstein
description: Proposition: It is in the painting of the naked human figure that national differences in art are most persistent.

title: Anniversaries
description: ALFORDRebecca and Harry Alford, heartlest congratulations to a most wonderful aunt and uncle on their 50th wedding anniversary, Feb. 7, 1976.

title: With Politicians Out of Cabinet, Park Rules South Korea Directly
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean official summed up the situation neatly: President Park doesn't like politics. He wants to keep politics out of government. It's more efficient that way.

title: Disaster in Guatemala
description: The series of earthquakes that has hit areas of Guatemala ranks among the century's major disasters. Official estimates of the dead have passed the 5,000 mark while some relief agencies in the country report tens of thousands injured and many more homeless. Bad as the first reported damage was in the poorer sections of Guatemala City, it is now evident that the destruction was much worse in the interior where towns and villages were partially or entirely destroyed.

title: Art Smuggled Out of Russia Makes Satiric Show Here
description: A dissident Soviet art called Sotsa sprightly kind. of Pop that parodies the propaganda posters and street banners designed for public consumption by Russian officialdomis going on view here for the first time.

title: G,A.O. RESISTS ROLE IN ELECTION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Proposals to keep Federal campaign subsidies flowing to Presidential candidates despite the prospective demise of the Federal Election Commission were strongly opposed today by the official to whom the authority would be transferred, Comptroller General Elmer B. Staats.

title: French Socialists Back Reds New Look
description: PARIS, Feb. 6The French Socialist Party gave cautious approval today to the Communist Party's continuing efforts to portray itself as increasingly independent of Moscow.

title: PEKING ASSAILS FOES OF MAOIST POLICIES
description: PEKING, Feb. 6 (Reuters)The Chinese press said today that a small group of people in positions of power was opposing the policies of Chairman Mao Tsetung and trying to change China.

title: Quota for Women Lawyers Agreed To by Major Firm
description: An unusual agreement that sets a quota for offering more jobs to women lawyers has been accepted by the major New York law firm of Rogers & Wells in the settlement of a sexdiscrimination suit against the highly influential firm.

title: Miss Young Captures Olympic Skating Title
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 6Sheila Young, the 25 yearold speed skating marvel from Detroit, made a shambles of the 500meter sprint, her speciality, today in winning the gold medal in the Olympic Winter Games. Her triumph was the first for an American in the competition that started yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD ORDERS EXTRA FLOOR HELP
description: The New York Stock Exchange, in its second move in two days to cope with the heavy flow of orders from investors, ordered all trading floor members of the exchange to have a representative on the floor at least one hour before trading begins and one hour after trading ends for the day 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.on Monfilly through Friday.

title: Statewide Education Group in Trenton In Drive for Meaningful Tax Reform
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6The New Jersey Education Association, a politically strong teachers lobby, has opened a $100,000 advertising campaign to try to create a demand for a meaningful tax reform in the state.

title: South Africa Sought to Gain Time in Angola, Aides Say
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 5Officials here assert that South Africa undertook its recent drive into Angola on behalf of two nationalist groups there on the understanding that the United States would rush sufficent supplies to make it possible to counter the Sovietsupported movement.

title: Evacuation of Hospital Called Hectic, but No Injuries Are Reported
JAPAN'S IDLE RATE HIGHEST IN 16 YEARS
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6  Japan's unemployment rate in December was the highest in 16 years, the Prime Minister's office disclosed today.

title: U.S.Built Synthetic Fuel Units Urged
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 4Government and industry energy specialists agreed here this week that the United States Government might have to form corporations of its own, like those that manufactured aviation gasoline and synthetic rubber during World War II, to build oil shale and coal gasification and liquefying plants to hold down energy imports.

title: Episcopal Issues: Women and Liturgy
description: The General Convention of the Episcopal church will convene seven months from now in Minneapolis, to consider two major changesacceptance of women into the priesthood and approval of a new Book of Common Prayer. Both issues involve salient features of Episcopal tradition and have generated protracted debates. Most clergy and laity await the September confrontation as a historical occasion of immense impact.

title: Black Jack, Famous As Riderless Horse At Funerals, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Black Jack, the old horse that walked riderless behind the coffin bearing President Kennedy, and thereby provided one of that sad day's most moving images, was put to death today.

title: Arnold Palmer's Father Dies
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 6 (UPI)Milfred J. (Deacon) Palmer, father of Arnold Palmer, died today of a heart attack after a round of golf at the nearby Bay Hill Country Club. The elder Palmer, 71 year old, was found dead in his room by a friend of the family. The friend said Palmer had just completed a round of golf at the club, owned by Arnold. The body was to be returned to Latrobe, Pa., where services were to be arranged.

title: TANKER GROUNDED OFF WAIKIKI BEACH
U.S. Skater Wins
description: Sheila Young, a 25yearold speed skater from Detroit, won a gold medal in the Olympic Winter Games yesterday in Innsbruck, Austria. She finished first in the 500meter sprint in an Olympic record time of 42.76 seconds. Details, Page 13.

title: BEIRUT CHIEF PLANS TALKS IN DAMASCUS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 6After several postponements, President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon will go to Damascus tomorrow to seal with President Hafez alAssad of Syria a Syriansponsored agreement for political changes in Lebanon.

title: More Work
description: The drop in the jobless rate last month from 8.3 percent to 7.8 percent, together with the increase of 800,000 in total employment, is extremely good news, especially for those who have gone back to workand their families.

title: U.S. Judge Lets F .D. A. Ban Disputed Food Dye
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) A Federal judge today gave the Food and Drug Administration permission to ban Red No. 2, the dye most widely used for food coloring in this country.

title: Kissinger to Leave Feb. 16 On Latin America Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger will make a nineday, fivenation trip to Latin America later this month, the State Department announced today.

title: Drug Official Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Peter B. Bensinger was confirmed unanimously yesterday by the Senate as Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, replacing John R. Bartels Jr., who resigned last summer.

title: Five Congressmen Due For Inventors Honors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Seven holders of United States patentsfive of them members of Congress and the other two joint inventors of the yearwill receive awards at an invention exposition to be held tomorrow and Sunday in Arlington. Vt.

title: Joan Little Appeal Filed
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 6 (UPI) A Federal court appeal for Joan Little, the black woman acquitted last year on charges of slaying a white jailer, has been filed in connection with her conviction for breaking and entering and for larceny. Karen Galloway, one of Miss Little's attorneys, said yesterday that a writ of habeas corpus was filed in United States District Court here last week. In December, Miss Little, 21 years old, began serving a 7to10 year term in the Correctional Center for Women.

title: Fire Damages Country Club
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Feb. 6 (UPI)A fire early today heavily damaged the west wing of the Wheatley Hills Country Club here, the police said. No injuries were reported and the cause was not immediately determined.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: PCB: The Case for Federal Standards

title: Levitt Names 3 Bankers To Attest to State Credit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, announced today that the former president of the World Bank, and the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board would participate in a panel to verify and support the state's creditworthiness in an effort to help it regain access to the borrowing markets ill the spring.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Five soldiers were injured, two seriously, when a 66millimeter rocket exploded at Fort Dix, a spokesman reported. Lieut. Col. Robert F. Dunn, the spokesman, said the rocket rolled off a table Thursday while it was being used as an instructional aid. He said it had been fired earlier and had been retrieved for demonstration purposes in the mistaken belief that it had been detonated. Spec. 5 Robert B. Girard, 23 years old, lost both legs in the explosion, was in serious condition at Walson Army Hospital. A sergeant also was seriously injured, but his name was withheld pending notification of family. The three other soldiers were in good condition, Colonel Dunn said.

title: South Korea Forbids Travel By Critic of Its President
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 6 The South Korean Government has refused to give a security clearance to an opposition politician, preventing her from going to Japan today for a brief trip with a party delegation.

title: Bonn Coalition Suffers Vote Setback
Unworthy Response
description: The resolution equating Zionism with racism, which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly last year, was unconscionable, spiteful and clearly counterproductive. A City Council bill to change the name of part of United Nations Plaza to Zion Square represents an inane responseand one that would be equally counterproductive, Both the U.N. resolution and the name change should be consigned to oblivion.

title: ANNACLAPP FOUNDED BABYFOOD BUSINESS
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 6 (UPI)Anna Louise Alberger Clapp, who turned a homemade vegetable soup into the nation's first commercially prepared and marketed baby food in 1922, died Tuesday at Sarasota. Memorial Hospital. Her age was 83. She had resided at the neighboring community of Nokomis since 1964.

title: Dutch Prince Was Given $1.1 Million by Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation paid $1.1 million to Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, who is also inspector general of the Dutch armed forces, to promote the sale of its aircraft, a source familiar with the investigation confirmed today.

title: Dave Anderson
Levitt Names 3 Bankers To Attest to State Credit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, announced today that the former president of the World Bank and the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board would participate in a panel to verify and support the state's creditworthiness in an effort to help it regain access to the borrowing markets in the spring.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Bank of England said today its minimum lending rate had been cut to 9 percent. It is the fourth consecutive week the rate has been cut by onehalf of a percentage point. It has been reduced eight timesfrom a 1975 peak of 12 percentin less than three months and now stands at its lowest level since 1973.

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP IN DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) A record surge in borrowing for auto purchases pushed consumer debt up in December by the biggest margin in 16 months, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Mother in Israel Surrenders 2 Sons To Father in Berlin
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CONGRESS MAY GET FED'S BANK DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, proposed today supplying Congress with information about how the Federal Reserve supervises commercial banks.

title: Explosion in London Subway
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP)An electrical generator exploded in a sheet of flames at a London subway station today, trapping four trainloads of rushhour passengers in smokefilled tunnels for two a half hours, the police said. At least 21 people were treated at hospitals but none were seriously injured.

title: Impish Artists Twit the State
Earthquake Attributed to Westward Movement of North America.
description: The inexorable westward movement of North America relative to the Caribbean region is believed to have been responsible for the earthquake that killed thousands in Guatemala Wednesday and for a damaging aftershock yesterday.

title: POTATO FUTURES SHOW RISE AGAIN
description: Still looking to additional export business, potato futures traders pushed prices ahead again on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May delivery closed at 16.43, up from 16.05 cents a pound.

title: Moynihan Clashes Tartly With Malik In the U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 6Daniel P. Moynihan told the Soviet delegate to the United Nations, Yakov A. Malik, tonight that we don't give a damn in the United States about threats from Moscow.

title: Jackson to See Moynihan Here; Just Old Friends, an Aide Says
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6Senator Henry M. Jackson's schedule for a fiveday campaign swing to four states that began here this morning includes an unusual private meeting Sunday with a man who has no obvious connection with Senator Jackson's Presidential aspiration Daniel P. Moynihan, United States representative to the United Nations.

title: Liberty, Fraternity... and the Quality of Life
PassersBy Pick Over Woman's Past
description: [People picked over Josephine Oliengo Paglieri's belongings Thursday night. Her books, furniture and clothes were strewn about the sidewalk and street, lying in the snow.

title: List of Agencies For the Donation Of Guatemala Aid
description: Americans wishing to contribute. to relief efforts in Guatemala can help most by contributing money to United States voluntary agencies rather than collecting supplies for, delivery to the earthquake zone, according to the Agency for International Development in Washington.

title: My Money Lies Over The Ocean
Art: Constructivism in Poland
description: There is an almost unbearable poignancy about the exhibition of Constructivism in Poland 19231936, which opened this week at the Museum of Modern Art. There are such high ideals represented in these immaculately executed objects! There is such an air of Utopian aspiration about their conception, and such purity of feeling in their forms! Yet, for anyone with a sense of history, the shadow of impending political catastrophe encloses the exhibition in an atmosphere of tragedy. It is as if the logic of history required, as a prologue to unspeakable carnage, an exemplary display of high  minded innocence and fierce intellectual probity.

title: Fire in Hospital Routs Patients Hurt in Jersey Train Accident
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 6More than 50 passengers were slightly injured here today when an ErieLackawanna train slamed into a concrete bumper block in the terminal.

title: W. G. CONSTABLE, ART HISTORIAN, 88
description: William G. Constable, art historian and former curator of painting of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, died Tuesday night in Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Cambridge. Mass.

title: State Lotteries Thrive Despite Problems
Exhibition Recalls Brooklyn Black Section
Rule of Law
description: There is no longer any question that the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in their pursuit of the national interestas they and a succession of Presidents were left to define itbroke a number of the laws of the United States.

title: Soviet Beats U.S. Sextet, 62
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 6A United States amateur team failed tonight to beat the Soviet Union in hockey, but the Americans, younger and much less experienced than their globetrotting foes, put up a stubborn struggle. Two goals, scored in the first period when they were shorthanded, proved costly as they suffered a 6to2 setback.

title: HEARST JURY SEES ENLARGED FILMS
Kissinger Bids Congress Enact Nuclear Fuel Bill
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 6Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger urged Congress today to enact legislation as soon as possible permitting the United States to expand on a large scale its capacity to produce enriched uranium for fueling nuclear power reactors.

title: HARRY STITMAN
description: Harry Stitman, who had been a percussionist with the NBC Symphony Orchestra from 1937 until 1954, died Tuesday in Encino (Calif.) Hospital. He Was 78 years old and lived in Encino,

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Prices Move Down On Amex and OTC In Slow Trading
description: Continued profit taking again weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in slower trading.

title: Dance: New Work by Nancy Meehan
description: Threading the Wave is the name of Nancy Meehan's exciting new dance work. and it is ample proof again that she is one of the major and most serious talents in the modern dance.

title: PROCAREY UNIONS FORM A COALITION
People in Sports
Sports News Briefs
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 6 (AP)Michigan State University will suspend seven football players from its team because of their part in National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations, school officials confirmed today. The Athletic Council chairman, John Fuzak, and Acting Athletic Director Jack Shingleton said seven would be suspended, but that the school would appeal the suspensions to a special N.C.A.A. subcommittee.

title: Aid Is Sought
description: The fire and casualty insurance subsidiary of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is seriously considering the acquisition of the financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Suspect in F.B.I. Slayings Seized by Canadian Police
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Feb. 6 (UPI)Leonard Peltier, sought on charges of murder in connection with the slaying of two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the Pine Ridge Indian reservation in South Dakota last summer, was arrested here today, the police said.

title: Red Wings Beat Islanders, 4 to 3
description: DETROIT. Feb. 6The New York Islanders, who had compiled a 10game unbeaten streak on perhaps their most inconsistent play this season, finally fell out of fate's good graces tonight and lost, 43, to the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Show Ring Torture
description: Congress passed the Horse Protection Act in 1970 to halt the brutal and unnecessary practice of soring Tennessee walking horses to enhance their natural gait. Unscrupulous trainers use soring, a vicious form of foot mutilation, to obtain quick results for the show ring. To be a winner, a Tennessee walker need not be the bestbred or besttrained horse, but only the most tortured.

title: Art Smuggled Out of Russia Makes Satiric Show Here
U.S. Judge in New Hampshire Annuls Law on School Prayer
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 6 (AP) After a hearing that took only 20 minutes, Federal District Judge Hugh H. Bownes declared New Hampshire's public school prayer law unconstitutional today. He issued a permanent injunction against recitation of prayers in school under it.

title: 4 DANCERS HONORED BY JOYCE TRISLER
description: The most famous dance lithograph of the 19th century portrayed the reigning goddesses of the ballot, Marie Taglioni, Carlotta Grisi, Fanny Cerito and Lucile Grahn, united for a glamorous gala performance of Pas de Quatre in London.

title: Screen: Psychic Killer
Mabel McAfee Gabriel, 91, A Writer and Philanthropist
ALL 6 ACQUITTED IN CARSON TRIAL
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other men were acquitted yesterday of all charges stemming from the death of a 34yearold Brooklyn man.

title: Trip, Initiated by Peking, Set for Feb. 21 and Termed Private
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 6Former President Richard M. Nixon will visit China with his wife, Pat, beginning Feb. 21. A spokesman said that. the visit had been initiated by the Chinese Government and would be strictly private.

title: Fire in Hospital Routs Patients Hurt Earlier in Train Accident
description: HOBOKEN, Feb. 6More than 50 passengers were slightly injured here today when an Erie  Lackawanna train slammed into a concrete bumper block in the terminal.

title: A Trail Is Blazed Through Downtown For Historic Walks
description: A permanent historic trail marked with informational plagues linking important sites in lower Manhattan will be completed in time for the climax of the city's Bicentennial celebration on July 4.

title: GAS BILL'S CHANCE CONSIDERED POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The likelihood that Congress and President Ford can agree on naturalgas bill this year was considered slight today in both legislative and Administration circles.

title: New Strike Peril At Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 6 (UPI)Parimutuel clerks at Garden State Park ratified a tentative threeyear contract agreement today but threatened to strike over a management request for a renegotiation option.

title: National Airlines Reaches 3Year Machinists Accord
Defense Chief Warns On Accepting Favors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today he would land all over any Pentagon official who accepted hospitality or favors from defense contractors.

title: Moynihan Clashes With Malik in the U.N.
Politics, Politics, Politics Clatters On a Capital Ride From Washington
description: ABOARD THE JERSEY CONGRESSIONAL, Feb. 6Amtrak's brand new 12car train carrying New Jersey's government and business leaders returned from Washington today with its passengers swapping observations of the past 24 hours and stories of other train trips over the last 39 years.

title: 7 Soviet Jews Say Israel Was Harsh
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6  Seven Soviet Jews were presented publicly by Soviet authorities today to explain why they had chosen to return home after emigrating to Israel.

title: Sorcery III Is First Finisher
description: Special to The New York Times

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternateside ofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1976

title: Fountains Performed Without Pines
description: It seemed odd to hear Respighi's The Fountains of Rome doing a solo turn on Thursday night's New York Philharmonic program, without the onceinevitable companion piece, The Pines of Rome. Michael Tilson Thomas led a suitably splashy performance of The Fountains, however, and possibly this listener was the only one who felt vaguely unfulfilled, as if he had been introduced to Mutt but not Jeff.

title: White House Discounts Visit, Which Will Be at a Delicate Time
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6White House officials said today that President Ford was irritated about former President Richard M. Nixon's impending trip to China, although publicly he was noncommittal.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE IMPENDING CRISIS. 184861. By David M. Potter. Completed and Edited by Don E. Fehrenbacher. A volume in the New American Nation Series edited by Henry Steele Commager and Richard B. Morris. 638 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $15.

title: Wardlaw Favored In Aqueduct Mile
description: Wardlaw, Dan Lasater's winner of two straight stakes, and R.W. Carmac's Mr. Pitty Pat, unbeaten in three starts this year, are slated to hook up today in the $50,000 added Lucky Draw Stakes at Aqueduct The track, which has been closed since Wednesday, because of hazardous conditions, is expected to be in shape for a full card of racing.

title: Senate Group Extends Auto Pollution Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) A major revision of the Clean Air Act giving automobile makers two extra years to produce pollutionfree cars has been approved by a Senate committee. The panel also voted to ban new sources of pollution in areas that already have clean air.

title: Defense Service Medal
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 6today an executive order to create a new medal for military personnel. The award, called the Denfense Superior Service Medal, would go to persons in the armed forces who provide superior meritorious service in a position of significant responsibility for the Secretary of Defense, the Joint Chiefs of Staff or other specified operations.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Sally Little Shoots a 67, Leads by Shot in Florida
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 6 (UPI) Sally Little carded a courserecord 67 today and took a onestroke lead after the first round of the $60,000 Naples Ladies Professional Golf Association Classic.

title: Exchange Seat Price Rises
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $70,000, up $4,500 from Feb. 4.

title: Connally Visiting Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 (UPI)  A 57member American economic missionled by John B. Connally, arirved today for a oneweek visit to Japan.

title: We Are Dealing With Dynamite, a Company Aide Wrote
OSPREY DECLINE APPEARS HALTED
88th Birthday Is Sweet Sou for Mrs. Yung
description: Mrs. T. K. Yung, slight and serene on her 88th birthday, sat beneath a red velvet wall hanging emblazoned with a glittering gold sou, the centuriesold Chinese symbol for longevity.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The startling news that Glen Tetley had resigned from his post as artistic director of the Stuttgart Ballet and the even more startling news that he was to be replaced by his ballerina, Marcia Haydee set me thinking about American choreographers in Europe and European choreographers in America. It is interesting that in the Englishspeaking theater (a comparison with the more international world of ballet that it seems fair to make) although audience reaction may vary slightly in London and New York, the difference of critical appraisal is comparatively small. There usually will be the same pattern in the spectrum of opinion in both cities. This is by no means true in the dance world.

title: Malik Says He Was Wrongly Translated In Moynihan Clash
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7 (UPI)An apparent Soviet warning to the United States to take care touched off a strong outburst in the United Nations last night from the United States representative, Daniel P. Moynihan, but the Soviet representative said later that he really meant take heed. Mr. Moynihan then asked for forgiveness.

title: A Ford, Not an Edsel
I.C.C. Critics Cite Case of the Elusive Rhinoceroses
description: WASHINGTON, Neb. 7At a time when the nation's transportation system was confronted by scores of grave problems, two investigators from the Interstate Commerce Commission were put on the track of a pair of elusive young rhinoceroses named Alexandra and Nicholas.

title: FORD OPENS DRIVE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
The Priorities of School Officials at BudgetSlashing Time
description: In reexamining its priorities to adjust to successive budget cuts mandated by New York City's fiscal plight, local School District 3 on the West Side of Manhattan gave high priority to maintaining its innovative approach.

title: The Dying Of the Light
description: Here in Boston our justifiably large role in the Bicentennial is being celebrated by a series of visits from a multitude of Presidential Candidates, joined to determine what the populace think is wrong about contemporary America so they can best express the same anxieties. And since men of all convictions and of all parties read the same polls and seek to serve the same power, that which unites themin an old American traditionis greater than that which divides. This year it is a shared abhorrence of big government, the source of various afflictions, which all public spirited candidates propose to curedepending upon their particular place on the constituency spectrumby remedies ranging from a Federal Government that builds more guns to a Federal Government that supplies more jobs.

title: ART
description: LIKE several other leading American museums, the Montclair Art Museum has made a high art out of high fashion. In its current Subject of Fashion exhibition, it presents a serious historical study, as well as a beautiful show, of American women's costumes made between 1776 and 1930.

title: Confirmations
description: Nussbaum

title: Caroline Bigelow Is Wed Here to Peter Monk Newell
description: Caroline Elizabeth Bacon Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Bacon of Red Bank. N. J., was married here at noon yesterday to Peter Monk Newell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Newell of Sutton Courtenay, England. The Rev. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Do Any of These Actresses Rate an Academy Award?
description: Here is a scene that could very well come true on Monday night, March 29: It is time for the Academy Award to be presented to the Best Actress of 1975. The black tie crowd in the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center is hushed. A white envelope is handed to a sweating, tuxedoed presenter, who rips it open, flashes a nervous but toothy grin in the direction of the television camera, and intones, The winner is . . . Marilyn Hassett!

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: One would like to think it more than coincidence that the two greatest violinists of their time were born on Feb. 2. It is true that a generation separates them1875 for Fritz Kreisler, 1901 for Jascha Heifetz. Both have been very much in the news during the past year. Kreisler's hundredth birthday did not go unnoticed, and the centenary is still being honored. On Wednesday, for instance, Beverly Somach, at the Lexington Avenue Y, continues her programs in memory of the great Austrian violinist. As for Heifetz, he seldom plays in public these days (what a gesture it would have been had he celebrated his 75th birthday last Monday with a Carnegie Hall concert!), but he did get a sensational birthday present from RCA. A series of multidisc albums was issued, containing very nearly every recording he ever made, from the 1917 acoustics to the concertos and chamber music of the stereo era.

title: The Numbers in Politics Don't Always Add Up
description: Politics is a game of numbers used and misused, nowhere more so than in the competition for Presidential nominations. Attempting to persuade the press and the public that Candidate X is bound for the White House, his campaign manager cites polls, primary results, dollars collected, volunteers recruited, miles traveled, staff members hired.

title: Libyan Gets Asylum
description: CAIRO. Feb. 7 (AP)President Sadat has granted political asylum to Cmar Meheishi, a former member of Libya's 11 member Revolutionary Command Council who was linked to a coup attempt last August, the official Middle East News Agency reported today.

title: ... Mischievous Visit
description: Even before the sensational news had been received yesterday of the appointment of a new and virtually unknown successor to the late Chou Enlai, there was good reason for President Ford to be annoyed by former President Nixon's suddenly announced intention to visit China two weeks hence at the invitation of the Chinese Government.
