Both the invitation itself and Mr. Nixon's ready acceptance of it at this time were mischievous political actsboth reflecting adversely on President Ford himself.

title: Blue Trees, Red Sky
description: We have come to expect fragmented families from Norma Klein and she doesn't disappoint us here. Eightyearold Valerie and 4yearold Marco are cared for by a sitter. Dad is dead and Mom works, because it's something I love. Even if I had a million dollars, I would still work. Another familiar Kleinism. Her women have creative careers which they infinitely prefer to remaining at home icing cupcakes. Would they feel the same way about dreary assembly lines or being a timeclock puncher desperate to badly needed cash?

title: List of Agencies For the Donation Of Guatemala Aid
description: Americans wishing to contribute to relief efforts in Guatemala can help most by contributing money to United States voluntary agencies rather than collecting supplies for delivery to the earthquake zone, according to the Agency for International Development in Washington.

title: Racers 5, Stingers 1
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Feb. 7 (AP)Pat Stapleton, a defenseman, scored one goal and assisted on three by Al Karlander tonight as the Indianapolis Racers beat the Cincinnati Stingers, 51, in a W.H.A. game.

title: Weaver and McCutcheon Star in Coaches' Meet
Third World Agrees on Trade Strategy
description: MANILA, Feb. 7The world's poor nations reached agreement tonight on a detailed strategy to protect their commodity exports to the rich nations and to improve their share in world trade and finance.

title: Card Of thanks
description: TESSERThe families of the late Dr. Emanuel and Norma Teaser, wish to express to their many friends, thanks for their kind expressions of sympathy.

Planning for Tomorrow's Blossoms
Fordham Beaten
How to get a new plane (and its maker)off the ground;
description: For a small nation seeking to build up an air force, Northrop's International Fighter is an idea whose time has come. It is also the result of some curious dealings in Washington, D.C., as well as in foreign palaces.

title: Friday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Don't Make No WavesDon't Back No Losers
description: Once upon a time, not far from the center of the great American city of Chicago, there was an Italian immigrant neighborhood called the Valley. By 1960, the Valley was enjoying a modest urban renaissance led by ItalianAmericans who were determined to improve their homes and businesses, preserve the identity of the neighborhood and remain in the city. Today the Valley no longer exists as a community. It was destroyed when Chicago Mayor Richard J. Daley, after due consultation with representatives of powerful real estate interests, designated the area as the site for a new University of Illinois campus. The houses and small businesses of more than 10,000 people were razed.

title: Things to Do, Things to See
description: FOR any child who has a terrible time reconciling the fact that Lincoln's birthday comes before Washington's, confusion still reigns. Was the 16th President born before the first? he asks. Well, it happens again this yearnext Thursday is Lincoln's birthday and Monday is Washington'spossibly to the confusion of schoolchildren, but to the delight of their parents, teachers, businessmen and government employees.

title: 7 Americans Are Killed In Air Crash in Spain
LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Lucking Out In Gloucester

title: Hua's Rise: Obscurity To the Top
DINING OUT
description: IN a northern Italian restaurant you expect to find risotto, gnocchi, osso buco and pasta in light or creamy sauces. The regional designation also implies cooking that is more subtle, refined and elegant than the robust creations of Neapolitan kitchens.

title: Ga. Tech Conquers N.C. State
Robinson Leads Attack As Bullets Top Hawks
Museum Is Left $100,000
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (API)A welder who did more than 20 years of volunteer work for the Field Museum of Natural History has left the institution about $100,000. The museum said yesterday that Adolph Marx, who did volunteer work in visitor services, died last October at the age of 81. A spokesman for the museum said the gift came as a complete surprise.

title: Reagan Affirms AntiAbortion Stand
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7Ronald Reagan conceded today that the liberalized abortion bill he signed as Governor of California led to abortion on demand in many of that state's hospitals. He told a news conference here that he would not make the same mistake today.

title: 6 Fail in Break  In Effort At Sutton Place Apartment
description: Six men wearing ski masks, one of them armed with a shotgun and another with a revolver, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to break into the Sutton Place apartment of a wealthy electrical contractor.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Waterways Are (Are Not) Being Cleaned Up

title: The Long Weekend: Things to Do, Places to Visit
How an Overnight Turned Into a Full Week
description: AND on through Cork to Blarney Castle . . . That's what the brochure said. But some Irish saint must have whispered in my ear and triggered the impulse to stop overnight in the city tnat straddles the banks of the River Lee. Impulse became resolve, and overnight stretched into a week. Once under the spell of the placeso steeped in history, yet so modernit grew harder each day to move on.

title: INVESTING
description: Despite the outpouring of bad publicity that has afflicted the banking Industry recently, a spot check of lead, ing Wall Street banking analysts shows that with few exceptions they are widely recommending bank holding company stocks.

title: PEOPLE
description: Remember Marion Marlowe? Some two decades ago, she was a star member of his court when Arthur Godfrey was the undisputed King of Television. But the soprano was banished from King Arthur's TV Camelot when she disobeyed one of his fiats: There would be no fraternization among members of the Godfrey court. Miss Marlowe did so by marrying Larry Puck, the show's producer, in 1955, and both were dismissed. The couple eventually bought a home in Sea Bright, which Miss Marlowe still maintains (Mr. Puck died in 1969). The singer, who says she has absolutely no regrets about her dismissal, went on to a longterm contract with the Ed Sullivan Show, and in 1959 she made her Broadway debut in a major role in The Sound of Music. Miss Marlowe is still semiactive, she says, appearing in stock and dinnertheater productions of Man of La Mancha, in which she appeared on Broadway, Show Boat, Gypsy and My Fair Lady.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENS planted with snow crocuses, snowdrops, winterblooming irises and winter aconite are about to come alive. These common names are not misleading. Flowers of these little bulbs open in the sun, even if there is an inch or two of snow on the ground.

title: Loui Levine Plang Wedding in Spring
Horse Show Calendar
POLICE STUDY DEATH OF HOSPITAL PATIENT
description: The police began an investigation into the death yesterday of a 79yearold Bronx hospital patient to determine how her lifesustaining breathing apparatus had become disconnected.

title: Fact and Fiction Are Difficult To Separate in Olympic Setting
Aid Beginning to Reach Quake Victims
description: GUATEMALA. Feb. 7Emergenoy aid is beginning to reach the victims of Wednesday's earthquake who live in the city of Guatemala, but dozens of devastated outlying towns and villages are still without food, water and medical attention.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: This is a treasure chest of a book, a J. B. Priestley kind of countryhouse novel stuffed with crotchets and surprises. Its setting is.,a museumpiece called Cannock (one of our minor stately homes still in private hands, but open to the public from March to November). Cannock is kept in the black by its mistress, Lady Isabella Southwood, who is charged up with a unique mixture of singlemindedness, noblesse oblige and chutzpa. Lady Southwood exploits a crew of willing slave laborers mesmerized by her charm into ignoring minimum wages and maximum hours.

title: GARDENING
description: FOR those unable to migrate to warmer climes, the winter season may seem exceptionally drab and dreary, especially after the novelty of the first winter snow begins to wear thin. Even the nongardener may begin to long for spring, with its green grass and bursting buds. Yet the winter landscape need not be altogether bleak if we plan our gardens for winter interest.

title: Book Ends
description: Money Talk. Many first novels go nowhere; indeed many novelists continue to go nowhere. commercially, several books after their debut, which is an unfortunate cultural fact, but there it is. Yet the first novelist who catches the fancy of the reprinters and the movie companies can earn, in one swoop, more than most novelists make in a lifetime.

title: ExBusboy Discovers Old Silver
Shrinking Truck Drivers Woes
Sharing a Swamp With the Gators
Arms Control Impact
description: A new checkrein is about to be applied to what former Defense Secretary Robert McNamara once called the mad momentum of weapons development  if a weapons system works and works well, there is strong pressure from many directions to procure and deploy, whether or not it adds to American security. Littlenoticed legislation adopted by Congress late last year requires three Administration agencies to present an annual analysis to Congress of the arms control impact of every nuclear weapons program in the budget and of all substantial conventional weapons systems.

title: What's Doing in DALLAS
description: SETTING  A financial, transportation, insurance and banking center, Dallas draws more travelers than any other city in Texas. Dallas works hard, but it also plays hard, as evidenced by an abundance of restaurants, bars, theaters and nightclubs.

title: Pulse of Suburbia
description: >TO anyone hurtling around the highways of Long Island, diners are better than fastfood joints because you can enjoy a varied menu off china plates and ask the waitress for a second cup of coffee. They are also better than more pretentious restaurants because you can inspect the food around the counter, and there is enough light for reading a newspaper.

title: 2 South Africans Killed
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Two South African soldiers have been killed in a rocket attack on a military post in southern Angola, defense headquarters announced here today.

title: Coast Guard Predicts A Moderate Ice Season
description: The Coast Guard, operator of the annual international ice patrol, reported last week that it expected the coming season not to be a heavy one. This estimate was based on observations made Jan. 31 by a flight over Baffin Bay and the Straits of Belle Isle by a Coast Guard aircraft flying out of Thule, Greenland.

title: Baptists Oppose Proposal For Closing of a Hospital
description: More than 500 Baptists representing 142 churches in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County voted unanimously yesterday to oppose any attempt by the city to close Samaritan Hospital, a 59bed churchsupported facility in Brooklyn.

title: Wardlaw Wins by a Nose and Pays $4
description: Outlined against a field of snow, which had curtailed racing here since last Wednesday, Wardlaw won the $56,400 Lucky Draw at Aqueduct yesterday by the length of his nose.

title: JORDAN COMBATS THEFT OF RELICS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 1The Jordanian Government is cracking down on what it calls the wholesale smuggling of antiquities westward.

title: Sheila Young Takes 3d Olympic Medal;East Germans and Russians Triumph
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 7Sheila Young's hopes of two gold medals were shattered today as the Russians and East Germans dominated the third day of the Winter Olympics.

title: Sultan's Luck Captures 2 Hunter Titles
The Reassessor Knocks
Opera: Stafford Dean in Figaro at Met
description: Stafford Dean, an English bass who has sung extensively in Britain and on the Continent, made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday night as Figaro in Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro, which was given a new production earlier this season. Two other major roles were taken by singers who had not sung them here before, Kiri Te Kanawa as the Countess and Benita Valente as Susanna. Returning to roles they had not sung this season were Rosalind Elias as Cherubino and Thomas Stewart as the Count.

title: Leaf Gets 6 Goals, 10 Points
RIVALS SOCIALIZE AT LISBON PARTY
description: LISBON, Feb. 7  After months of tension and suspicion, insults and hostility, a group of Socialists and Popular Democrats, military officers and leftist intellectuals were talking civilly to each other and apparently enjoying it.

title: Hunters' Tool Is Now an Art
description: MANY of the nation's best waterfowl decoy carvers, both amateur and professional, will be competing late next month in the 53rd annual United States National Decoy and Bird Carving exhibit at the Legion Hall in Babylon.

title: For a Harsh Winter, Soft Warmth of Down
description: Down is up. No, this isn't another story about our topsyturvy world. It's about down the fluffy, shaftless undercovering of the breast of waterfowl, preferably ducks and geesewhich is to feathers what caviar is to fish eggs.

title: The Tale of the Heike
Richard Hawryluk, Physicist, Marries Mary K. McMahon
description: Mary Katherine McMahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton D. McMahon of Larchmont, N. Y., was married there at noon yesterday to Richard J. Hawryluk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michal Hawryluk of Brooklyn.

title: ART
description: ONE of the most welcome and exciting additions to the Long Island artscape is the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts. Situated on the lavishly bosky Frick estate in Roslyn, the center is an ideal Elysian environment for the exhibition of sculpture.

title: PAUL O'KEEFE, 76, EXCITY AIDE, DIES
description: Paul Thomas O'Keefe, Deputy Mayor from 1958 to 1961 under Robert F. Wagner and Commissioner of Real Estate in 1962, died Thursday in Mount Kisco. N. Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Lincolndale, N. Y.

title: Black History Week Events Set
Bishop Says Mass for Slain Priest
description: Many worshipers wept yesterday as the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn and 120 priests concelebrated a Mass of the Resurrection in St. Michael's Church for the Rev. Pancratius Krieg, a 76yearold priest who was killed in the rectory by armed robbers last Tuesday.

title: Blacks Issues Are Slighted In Campaign, Leaders Say
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7  Black political and civil rights leaders are concernedsome of them to the point of bitternessabout the feeling that black issues have so far been relegated to the background in the current Presidential campaign.

title: Hechler Step Upsets Governorship Race In West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 7 The race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of West Virginia, whose outcome is likely to decide the political comeback hopes of John D. Rockefeller 4th, has been thrown into turmoil by Representative Ken Hechler's announcement that he is seeking the nomination.

title: 3 Russians Reported Killed
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 7 (Reuters)One of the Westernbacked movements in the Angola civil war announced today that its forces had killed three Russians during a counterattack on the port of Novo Redondo, held by the Sovietbacked Popular Movement, the Zaire news agency said today.

title: Sirica Continues to Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Federal Judge John J. Sirica continued today ,to recover from a serious heart attack. We foresee removing him from the serious list tomorrow morning if he continues to progress in a satisfactory manner, said Dr. Joel Gorfinkel, associate. director of the coronary care unit at George Washington University. Medical Center. The 71yearold judge was stricken Thursday.

title: GARMENT TRUCKERS REJECT A NEW PACT
description: A proposed new contract that would have given 3,000 drivers and helpers M the garment industry wage increases of $33 a week over 40 months was rejected yesterday by members of the Cloak and Dress Drivers Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Review, it was incorrectly stated that Alger and Priscilla Hiss were interviewed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in December of 1974. The year was 1948.

title: Joan Roach Engaged to R. B. Fee
description: John H. Roach Jr., of Greenwich, Conn., and S. Curtiss Roach of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their sister, Joan Rosemarie Roach of New York to Richard Burke Fee of Rye, N.Y. Mr. Fee is the son of Mr. and Mrs. frank J. Fee Jr. of Rockville Centre, LI. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Is it Jersey Without the New?
Gary Teacher Strike Looms
description: GARY, Ind., Feb. 7 (AP)About 1,800 teachers will strike the school system Monday, the president of the Gary Federation of Teachers, Sandra Irons, said today. She said negotiations stopped when the school board refused to change its 6 percent raise offer and a new method of paying sick leave.

title: The Abortion Debate
description: I would like to say a word for the right of the American Roman Catholic bishops to be wrong. Even the most loyal Catholic may not always find the bishops the most adroit political tacticians in their collective actions. But surely they have a right to join the national debate on our public morality. More specifically, one may question the wisdom of one or another element in their pastoral plan for prolife activities. But to charge that the attempt to promote a constitutional amendment to restrict abortion is undemocratic is to impose a double standard on the abortion debate.

title: Indiana Overtime Winner
Turkish Bus Crash Kills 10
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 (AP)A bus skidded off an icy road today and crashed, killing 10 persons and injuring eight, officials said. The accident occurred in the central Turkish province of Konya.

title: The Old Guard Never Changes
description: THE QUESTION of who is and who isn't Old Guard still comes up in Long Island's firmly entrenched social enclaves, but it is of little Import. Brooklyn families like the Livingston trace themselves to the 17thcentury Dutch, The Nicolls of Islip and Nicoll Bay arrived with the 17thcentury English. The Gardiners have owned Gardiners Island since 1639. Virtually everybody else is new.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: D.A. INVESTIGATES QUEENS LANDLORD
description: The Queens District Attorney is investigating charges of criminal negligence against a landlord and the landlord's agent, who are accused of failing to supply adequate heat and hot water to the Stratton Houses, a 255apartment complex at 4510 Kissena Boulevard in Flushing.

title: If You Go ...
description: . . . write or phone Refuge Manager, Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge P.O. Box 117, Waycross, 3a. 31501 (tel. 9122382580) well in advance of your planned visit and he will send you detailed information on canoe trips, guided tours and sightseeing excursions. There are three public entrances to the swamp. At each entrance guided boat tours, walking trails swamp exhibits and picnic facilities are available.

title: MANCE LIPSCOMB, 80, A BLUES GUITARIST
description: NAVASOTA, Tex., Feb. 7 (UPI) Mance Lipscomb, sharecropper blues singer and guitarist, was buried today in this small East Texas farming community where he died Jan. 30 at the age of 80.

title: C.S.E.A. WINS A TEST IN ALBANY ELECTION
description: The Civil Service Employees Association has won the right to continue to represent 40,000 state employees who hold jobs in professional, scientific and technical areas of state government.

title: Coup in Peking?...
description: All previous calculations about China's future in the postChou Enlai period have been called into question by yesterday's surprise news from Peking. The appointment of Hua Kuofeng, Minister of Public Security, as acting Prime Minister is the most astonishing and unexpected development on the Chinese scene in many years. Simultaneously analysts note that First Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping, who was de facto head of China's Government during the last months of Chou's illness and who seemed earlier to be Chou's chosen successor, has not been publicly visible since he eulogized the late Prime Minister at a memorial service last Jan. 15. The suspicion must be strong that Mr. Chou's carefully laid plans for Chinese Government leadership during the period after his passing have gone awry, and that other personalities and other forces now hold the upper hand in Peking.

title: The Fear Is That Hard Times In Japan Will Be Permanent
Timberland Rules Tighten
LETTERS
description: Has Hollywood Ignored the God Question?

title: COAST FARM BOARD RUNS OUT OF MONEY
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) The Agricultural Labor Relations Board ran out of money yesterday and closed its four regional offices after presiding over five months of relative peace in the state's fields.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: H. W. Ebeling, Deborah Foster Wed in Suburb
description: Deborah Gould Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Lee Foster of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon, to Henry William Ebeling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ebeling of Woolrich, Pa.

title: Cecil E. Newman, Headed Minneapolis Black Weekly
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP)Cecil E, Newman, who pioneered black weekly newspapers In Minneapolis and St. Paul, died today at his home, apparently of a heart attack, He was 72 years old.

title: Miss MacIntosh Bride of Veterinarian
PEOPLE
description: Residents of the Hamptons who live in one of Charles Gwathmey's prizewinning houses now have an additional distinction. Their architect, known for the unusual designs of his beachfront homes and who summers in one of them on the South Fork, has been elected to the National Institute of Arts and Letters, an organization that confer its accolades for recognized achievement. Mr. Gwathmey's election makes him somewhat of an oddity, for at the institute he joins his father, Robert, the painter who lives year around in Amagansett in, of course, a Gwathmey house. They are the institute's only fatherandson combination.

title: L.I. Aims for Sun
description: LONG ISLAND is quietly fighting a high stakes battle in Washington. The Island's opponents are 46 states and the prize could ultimately run into hundreds of millions, maybe billions of dollars. The White House is involved, too, and so are some of the best brains in the world of science. There is political maneuvering here and also Congressional lobbying of the most intense kind

title: In a Suburb, Some of the Frills Remain
Bookbinding:
Ruling Party in Tokyo Is Rocked as Suspicion Points at Tanaka
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7  Japan's governing party and business establishment have been rocked by disclosures in Washington that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has paid $12.8 million to officials and executives to sell airplanes here.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Rabbits
Black Capitalism Takes Root in Auto Sales
Advice for the Injured
description: According to the National Ski Patrol System, an injured skier can make things easier for himself and for the volunteers who come to his aid by remembering some basic pointers:

title: Women at the Summit in Summit
It Was Conceived as a Natural Right and Democracy's Necessity
description: In striking down major provisions of the 1974 Campaign Reform Act, the Supreme Court nine days ago wrote another in its long series of essays on the meaning of the First Amendment. A majority reasoned that the spending of money was an essential aspect of freedom of expression in the political area, and it found some of the act's limits on campaign expenditure unconstitutional.

title: Second City: tearing down buildings and building up Daley
description: By now most Americans have owned up to their despoilment of the natural world. They should know more, however, about their willingness to destroy the best things of their own making, particularly their buildings. The problem in Chicago had a twofold background: its downtown area was blocked off by the lake and river, forcing the construction of newer buildings on the sites of old, and it was too wealthy: it could afford to tear down and rebuild.

title: A New Atomic Particle Identified at Fermi Lab
description: A new shortlived atomic particle, heavier than any previously identified, has been detected at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., it was reported at a meeting of the American Physical Society here.

title: DINING OUT;
Wall St. on Overtime to Catch Up
description: The New York Stock Exchange, moving swiftly to prevent runaway paperwork problems because of the heaviest trading volume in history, orders all stockbrokers to report to work yesterday to clear up errors.

title: Miss Clair Affianced To Robert Nerlinger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Clair of Lake Success, L. I., and San Juan, Puerto Rico, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Joy Clair, to Robert Wayne Nerlinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emile Nerlinger of Brooklyn

title: Suit Filed to Aid Boy Nobody Wanted
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has sued the New York Foundling Hospital, the Childrens Aid Society and the city's Human Resources Administration for openended monetary damages on behalf of an 11 yearold boy who lived for two years at Bellevue Hospital because nobody wanted him.

title: North's Williwaw Captures 409Mile Race Off Florida
The Bowling Clinic
description: Once the better bowler has obtained what he feels is the best equipment (equipment means bowling ball to the pro), all he must worry about is getting lined up. That's where the game gets interesting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Building Inspections

title: New and Noteworthy
description: MY MICHAEL. by Amos Oz. (Bantam. $1.50.) Hannah Gonen is married to a man who represents everything a woman presumably should desire, yet her dreams continue to rove: alienation in modern Jerusalem recorded by one of lsrael's most original novelists.

title: Fearful Symmetry
description: Over the past half decade it has not been easy to be a man who writes about women. The skill, intensity and scope of the feminist critique have combined to force everyone to adopt an attitude to the questions posed by feminism. This has been both salutary and enlarging in itself, but now, I think, the meaning and tone of the dialogue should changenot only because there is a great deal at stake politically (e.g., the E.R.A., legislative achievement, etc.) but also because the quality of research and intellectual freedom is being threatened by what was first a discovery, then an exuberance, and may now be becoming an orthodoxy as deadening as it is broad.

title: The computerized supermarket
description: It makes for an unlikely battle flag, but a 1squareinch array of bars and spaces known as the Universal Price Code has become the symbol of a bitter dispute between grocers and consumer groups. Food processors have been putting the U.P.C. on their bottles, cans and boxes for more than a year nowin anticipation of electronic checkout, a controversial automated system that grocers say offers them one of their few opportunities to improve store productivity and cut operating costs.

title: POLITICS
description: REPUBLICAN and Democratic politicians in Suffolk County are predicting that Eugene R, Kelley's days as Police Commissioner are numbered. They cite two clouds over the Police Commissioner's prospects: his bitter feud with Democratic District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien and Democratic capture last November of the county legislature, which has the power to appoint the Police Commissioner.

title: In the Concorde's Flight Path
description: BACK in 1951, before the first commercial jets were introduced at Idlewild International Airport Carol Berman recalled, aviation officials sought to allay the concern of Long Island neighbors who were worried about jet noise and safety.

title: Updating Electric Wall Switches
description: Although most homeowners never think about replacing an electric wall switch until it starts to give trouble, there are actually a number of other reasons why it may be advantageous to replace an existing old  fashioned wall switcheven though it is still operating satisfactorily. Many of the new and improved types available offer conveniences and advantages not afforded by older styles, and many are also much more decorative looking, as well as being more functional.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There are those who insist that a distillation of New York would consist of half sentimentalism, half cynicism. Which is a perfect description of ONE DEAD DEBUTANTE by Heywood Gould (St. Martin's, $7.95). Part of the book is highly cynicalestablished organizations come under scrutiny and are found wanting. Gould is a bit of a social commentator as well, and like the best comic writers (One Dead Debutante is full of comic situations verging on farce) he has a feeling for things ridiculous and a joy in deflating stuffed shirts.

title: REDS DUE TO STAY IN FINNISH CABINET
description: HELSINKI, Feb. 1  Prime Minister Martti J. Miettunen has said that he expects the Communists to continue participating in his twomonthold coalition Government, despite the tough decisions coming up on coping with Finland's severe recession.

title: Edward Kirby 3d Weds Miss Moody
description: Melinda Sears Moody, a candidate for a Master of Science in teaching degree at the University of Florida, was married yesterday in St. James, Md., to Edward George Kirby 3d, who is a candidate for a Ph.D. in botany at Florida.

title: The Tougher Islanders
description: Like a crack in the ice that grows wider for no apparent reason, the gap between the Islanders and the Rangers keeps increasing. In the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League, the Islanders are challenging the Philadelphia Flyers for first place while the Rangers wobble on a treadmill to last place. The one big reason appears clear nowthe Islanders are tougher. Not wild tough like the Flyers; cool tough is the Islanders style. They play tougher than the Rangers do. Perhaps more important, they think tougher. That is obvious from the reaction of Billy Smith, an Islander goaltender, to a thumb injury suffered by Dunc Wilson, a Ranger goaltender, in the Islanders 65 victory at Madison Square Garden last week.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: My house is 45 years old and beginning this past September I have had a problem with water running down the chimney into my fireplace during heavy rains (never happened before). A roofer examined the chimney and told me that the cement coping has crumbled and he also feels the flue is too large. He suggests replacing the coping, adding an extension of 10 inches to each flue and building a large stone hood over the chimney. Since the original design caused no problem all these years I hesitate to make such alterations. Could water be entering through the crumbled coping, or do you think the other alterations are needed?F.H.H., Rye, N. Y.

title: U.S. Astronauts Visit Sadat
description: CAIRO, Feb. 7 (Reuters)President. Anwar elSadat today received the three United States astronauts of the ApolloSoyuz space mission, Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, Vance D. Brand and Donald K. Slayton, who arrived Thursday.

title: Joyce Corey Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton O. Corey of Sharon, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joyce Evelyn Corey, to Steven Hendrix Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Gibson of Chatham, N. J. The future bride is on the research faculty of Cornell University. Her fianc, who is with the Exxon Corporation, Is a tax lawyer with Essochem Europe in Brussels.

title: COURT SAYS INMATE CAN DEFEND A VICTIM.
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) A prisoner has the right to use force in aiding a fellow inmate whom he reasonably believes to he the victim of an illegal attack, even if the attack is by prison guards. the Massachusetts Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Up Against Walt Disney
description: In night court some years back, a cab driver was listening to his arraignment for a traffic offense. The State of New York versus Max Schwartz, droned the clerk. Max leaned over to those of us watching the proceedings and growled, I don't like them odds.

title: Scarlet Routs Navy
Sunday, A Day To Savor
description: SUNDAY is like no other day of the week. At least for me, it has II special flavor. That day, there are certain rituals we go through that are as ingrained a habit as an addict's daily dose.

title: Countess Wed to Thomas Murphy
description: Countess Viviane de Jonghe d'Ardoye, daughter of Count and Countess de Jonghe d'Ardoye of SintGenesiusRode, Belgium, was married in Uccle, Belgium, yesterday to Thomas P. Murphy, son of Doris Murphy of Phoenix and the late Thomas R. Murphy. The Rev. Francis Keefe and the Rev. Darrell Mount performed the ceremony in the St. Anne Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: Notes: Enticing Treats in Store
Music: Jon Vickers Sings
description: Jon Vickers's admirers didn't quite fill Carnegie Hall on Friday night for the Canadian tenor's recital, his only New York appearance of the season. But they filled the hall with their enthusiasm, all the way through the third encore, the Winterstiirme aria from Wagner's Die Walkiire. There was admittedly much to admire, but there was also good cause for dissatisfaction.

title: Wanted: School Dollars
description: LONG ISLAND'S Albany representatives realize that Governor Carey's proposed $110 million cut in state school aid would affect their districts more than most, but are also mindful that money is the main topic of conversation in the capital, with proposals for either increased spending or higher taxes likely to meet with stiff opposition.

title: Miss Smithers Is Betrothed to John C. Koeniger 2d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. S. Phelps Platt Jr. of New York and Chatham, Mass., of the engagement of Mrs. Platt's daughter, Margaret Smithers, to John Crawford Koeniger 2d, son of John C. Koeniger and Mrs. Charles A. Kirkland of Short Hills, N. J.

title: Cape May: A Long Winter's Nap
Illegal Wage Underpayment Un 19% in Last Half of '75
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  Illegal underpayment of workers increased 19 percent in the last six months of 1975 and is likely to continue to rise, according to the Labor Department

title: Banks Face Tougher Regulation
description: Calamities like war and Depression always have been crucibles for change, and the current recession is no exception. The hard times that have struck the nation's banking systemreflected in headlines about problem banks, bad loans, and declining bank earningsis producing the greatest momentum for bank regulatory reform since the 1930's.

title: Revelation of Payments Raises Storm Around Prince Bernhard;
February
description: February is a capricious month, nine years out of ten. It is the last full month of winter by the almanac. It is a time of change and warring weather systems. It was named for Februarius, the feast of purification. In the old calendars it was the final month of the year as well as a catchall for odd days needed to round out the solar year. It ended with the feast of Terminalia, a kind of New Year's Eve celebration that lasted several days.

title: Luba Naumow Wed to James Hill
description: Luba Naumow, a cosmetic buyer with Bergdorf Goodman, was married here yesterday afternoon to James Townsend Hill, a vice president in the corporate finance department of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: French Party Chief's Talk Reported in Part by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (AP)The Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda published an account today of the major speech by the French Communist Party leader, Georges Marchais, Wednesday, but omitted any of his remarks that could be construed as critical of the Soviet Union.

title: JUDGE SEES PERIL TO CLASS LAWSUIT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7The class action lawsuit, in which damages are sought for a large number of citizens with a common grievance, was described by a prominent jurist this week as a vanishing species that should be resuscitated by Federal or state legislation if necessary.

title: The Search For Students
description: SUCCASUNNA DURING the last few months, Kathleen Beck, a senior at Morris Catholic High School, received letters from about 30 colleges interested in having her in their freshman class this fall.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to the Ecuadorian markets by bus from Quito, the Cooperativa de Transportes Nacional bus to Saquisili and the Transportes Occidental bus to Santo Domingo leave from the Avenida 24 de Mayo between Garcia Moreno and Benalcazar. You should buy tickets for all buses the day before. Morning departures to Saquisili are at 3, 5 and 5:45 A.M.; cost: 48 cents one way; duration of trip: two hours. Morning departures to Santo Domingo are at 7, 7:50, 8:50 and 11 A.M.; $1 one way; the trip takes three hours plus. Only oneway tickets can be bought as bus stations do not have the facilities for direct and immediate communication with each other from town to town.

title: Memo Said to Cast Doubts on Legality Of C.I.A.'s Actions
The Dark Side of the Sunshine Law
Helen Williams To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Williams of Tulsa, Okla., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen D. Williams, to Hunter S. Marston 3d, son of Mr. Marston Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Mrs. John H. Dyett of Hobe Sound and Greenwich, Conn.

title: U.S. SEEKS ACCORD ON TURKEY BASES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 2  Turkey and the United States have made substantial progress in negotiating a new agreement on 26 American military installations but important differences remain, according to informed diplomats.

title: Stephenson Women's Golf Leader
R. E. Blacque to Marry Lynda Busch Moecker
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herman Eugene Moecker of Utica, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Lynda Busch Moecker, to Richard Edmond Blacque, son of Valentin Edouard Blacque of CarrickonSuir, Ireland, and London, and June Blossom of New York.

title: HUNDREDS SEEKING CONCORDE TICKETS
description: If the BritishFrench Concorde supersonic transport receives final clearance for landing in Washington and New York, its first flights, at least, will be booked solid with Americans and Europeans eager to pay a premium for becoming a part of aviation history.

title: A Warning Is Issued Here After Coast Anthrax Death
description: The city Health Department has issued a warning against anthrax, a dangerous bacterial disease that, according to, Federal authorities, killed a 32 yearold weaver in California on Jan. 22 after being transmitted by handspun yarns from Pakistan.

title: Holly Kresch Engaged to William Blum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene I. Kresch of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Judith Kresch, to William Mark Blum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clayton I. Blum of Fredericksburg, Va. A wedding in May is planned.

title: Music in Review
description: Tne Audubon Quartet, young string ensemble in residence at Marywood College in Scranton, Pa., made an auspicious New York debut last Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The appearance was part of a series run by Artist Development of Binghamton, N. Y., which coordinates artistsinresidence programs for string quartets and sponsors the groups in New York.

title: Kenneth Light to Wed Miss Perry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Stoddard Perry of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lizabeth Van \Vie Perry, to Kenneth Ian Light, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Light of Syosset, L. I.

title: INDIA STATE CALM AFTER TAKEOVER
description: MADRAS, India, Feb. 7In local government offices, the portrait of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has replaced that of deposed chief minister Muthuvel Karunanidhi.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday incorrectly estimated the rate of population growth in Pakistan. It is actually believed to be 2.9 or 3 percent a year.

title: Marjorie A. Feinman, Rider Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford N. Feinman of Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Anne Feinman. to Michael A. Townsend of Boston, son of Mrs. Mortimer D. Haut of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Merrill Townsend of Roslyn, L.I. Mr. Feinman is president of Hanover Fabrics Inc. here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of the C.I.A., Disguises and Dirty Tricks

title: Speaks to Jaycees
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)Mr. Reagan made bids for votes today at a convention of Florida Jaycees.

title: Somalia Releases Last French Child In Guerrilla Hands
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 7 (Reuters)  A 7yearold French schoolboy who had been kidnapped by guerrillas was freed here today, defusing some of the tension btween Franc and Somalia.

title: LEBANESE RECEIVE A SYRIAN PLEDGE
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 7Syria today gave Lebanon explicit guarantees that the leaders of the Palestinian guerrilla movement would live up to past agreements, respecting Lebanese territorial integrity and national sovereignty.

title: CONFLICT ON SAUDIS DENIED BY HATFIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, denies that any conflict of interest may arise out of his wife's role in trying to arrange the sale to the Saudi Arabian Government of a marble building on a site ithat had been restricted by Congress.

title: Debate Over Assessments in City Sharpens
description: Real estate owners have been reporting sales of apartment houses and older loft and office buildings at prices well below their assessed values for many months.

title: First Sale For Pennsy In Midtown: 230 Park
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad have consummated the first sale from among the bankrupt company's extensive midtown holdings. They have sold 230 Park Avenue, the 34story office building that straddles Park Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets to the New York Bank for Savings for $26 million.

title: Pakistan Is Acting to Stem Emigration
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The Government is moving to slow the flow of what has become one of Pakistan's major exoortspeople.

title: Tracy Garrett, Stephen Rubin Plan Marriage
description: The engagement of Tracy Lee Garrett to Stephen Edward Rubin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Y. Garrett 3d of Westfield, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Rubin of Norton and South Wellfleet. Mass.

title: Penske Has Little Difficulty In Getting Major Sponsors
description: Because of today's high costs of motor racing, it's not enough to have a fast car, or a fast driver for that car. You need money, and that usually translates into sponsorship  a person or company willing to pay a certain amount of money in return for the promotional value involved, or just for the thrill of seeing his name on a sleek race car.

title: Campaign Reform
description: The Supreme Court's thirtyday deadline for reconstitution of the Federal Election Commission has provided Congress with an opportunity to strengthen the Campaign Reform Lawor slowly strangle it.

title: ExGovernor Is Sentenced In Absentia by Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 7 (AP)Sir Oliver Goonetillake, governor general here from 1954 to 1962, has been sentenced in absentia to four years in jail and fined $125,000 for foreignexchange offenses.

title: CAMERA VIEW
MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The roaring bull market of 1976 ran into its first substantial correction last week after setting a 27month high on Wednesday.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT FELL IN JANUARY from 8.3 percent of the work force to 7.8 percent, the largest monthly drop in 15 years .. . The Administrationbacked natural gas deregulation bill was defeated In the House. A substitute bill, winning by a vote of 205to194, will keep price controls in effect for the 24 largest gas producers but will raise prices for smaller producers. According to Robert C. Krueger, Democrat of Texas and sponsor of the defeated bill, its enactment would have raised the cost of gas for the average residential user by $12 a year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The state police arrested 66,976 drivers for drunken driving on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in 1975, up nearly 18 percent from the previous year, according to the Thruway Authority. The fatality rate was 1.41 deaths per 100 million miles traveled, up from a low of 1.01 the previous year. The number killed in accidents on the 559mile road was 58, compared with 41 in 1974. A total of 4.1 billion vehicle miles were traveled, a slight increase over 1974.

title: TV VIEW
description: On Tuesday night at 8:30, CBS's Popi, a new series about a Puerto Rican father with two young sons, was trounced in the ratings by ABC's Laverne and Shirley, a new series about a pair of workingclass women In Milwaukee. In fact, Laverne and Shirley attracted nearly 50 percent of all TV sets turned on at the time, a share that ABC statisticians claim as a record for the premiere of a situation comedy. Is Laverne and Shirley really that good? Or is Popi that bad? Perhaps national TV is simply not ready for a Puerto Rican father. Perhaps it is all a matter of uncontrollable luck. Not quite.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1976

title: CHURCH STRAINED IN EAST GERMANY
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 1A conflict has erupted in East Germany's Protestant Church because a growing number of pastors feel that they can no longer live and work in the Communist country and have therefore sought permission to move to the West.

title: At Princeton, Time of Decision
Notes: Auctions, Agents and the Arts of Texas
description: A kind of mousetoelephant challenge to the auction, house, Sotheby Parke Bernet, has been flung down by a new firm in SoHo, Auction 393. Not exactly your traditional velvetswathed salesroom, the firm is housed in a big white loft at 393 West Broadway, right over the James Yu Gallery. It plans to auction strictly contemporary art, with the first sale set for Feb. 26 (a preauction exhibition opens Wednesday).

title: 3,060 Elite Dogs To Invade Garden For Westminster's Centennial Show
City Plan to Provide Jobs for People 55 and over
Front Page 1  No Title
German Jumpers Are 1, 2
description: SEEFELD, Austria, Feb. 7 In this little Tyrolean resort village where Vermont's Bill Koch two days ago electrified the Nordic skiing world by winning an Olympic silver medal in crosscountry, the United States failed to provide anything resembling a surprise today.

title: Service for Bradford Smith
description: There will be a private funeral service today at 3 P.M. for Bradford Bixby Smith, chief economist for the United States Steel Corporation from 1939 until his retirement in 1965, who died Monday at the age of 76. The service will be held at the family home, 7 Heathcote Road, in Scarsdale.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Fairfield visits St. Peter's at 8 P.M. tomorrow in the Monday night game of the week on Channel 9. A Madison Square Garden doubleheader at 7 P.M. Thursday sends Lafayette against Connecticut and Fordhain against South Carolina. Manhattan plays at Rutgers in a game to be seen on Channel 4 at 2 P.M. Saturday. Columbia plays 8 P.M. home games against Harvard Friday and Dartmouth Saturday.

title: Princeton Beats Cornell by 5335
KALAPARUSHA PLAYS SAXOPHONE HERE
description: Kalaparusha, the tenor saxophonist formerly known as Maurice McIntyre, paints his face, chants and plays bells and other little instruments, like many of his contemporaries among Chicago's younger jazzmen.

title: HORTENSE BRUBAKER
description: Hortense Bass Brubaker, former development director of the Women's Infirmary here and Bridgeport (Conn,) Hospital, died Friday In Charlottesville, Va. She was 71 years old and lived in Ruckersville, Va., and formerly in Westport, Conn,

title: Rochester Priest Is Disciplined For Refusing Luxury Quarters
description: A Roman Catholic priest in Rochester has been relieved of his priestly duties for refusing to live in a parish rectory he considers too luxurious.

title: Depending on the View, His Theory Either Worked or Failed
description: Does anybody really know how to cure the economy of both unemployment and inflationand if so, how soon? The question goes deeper than electionyear politics, involving a reappraisal of the economic revolution led by Keynes in the 1930's.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Albert Hotel, a Greenwich Villge landmark, has been sold by Avon Associates, Inc., which is headed by Sol Goldman, to the Elbro Company, which Is operated by the Elghanyan brothers.

title: Are blacks just another ethnic bloc trying to get ahead?;
description: After two centuries of slavery and another century of Jim Crow secondclass citizenship, the court decisions and civil rights legislation of the 1950's and 60's finally destroyed segregation and overt racial discrimination the barriers that had kept most black Americans, roughly 11 percent of the total population, out of the mainstream of national life.

title: Carter Apparent Winner In Oklahoma's Caucuses.
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 7Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia Appeared tonight to have won a hairbreadth victory over former Senator Fred R. Harris in the Democratic precinct caucuses in Mr. Harris's native state.

title: Strikers at U.S. Hospital in Paris Vote to Remain Out
description: PARIS, Feb. 7Employees of the American Hospital of Paris, one of the most famous in Europe, have voted to continue a strike begun last Monday to protest announced personnel cutbacks.

title: Senegal Leftist Pardoned After Return From Exile
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 7 (Agence FrancePresse)  The former secretary general of Senegal's banned proCommunist African Independence Party, Majhmout Diop, who returned unannounced from exile recently, has been granted a full presidential pardon and his 10year Jail sentence imposed in absentia has been lifted, it was reported here.

title: Boat Shows to Open Saturday In Long Island, New Jersey
description: Three regional boat shows will open their doors shortly with a melange of the latest in boats and accessories. The Long Island and Jersey Coast shows will start Saturday, both for nineday stands, while a new show will make its debut in Suffern from Feb. 21 through 29.

title: Water, Water Everywhere
description: ONCE upon a time, tens of thousands of years ago, it was very cold and a great sheet of ice almost a mile thick covered Long Island.

title: Terror Is Still Not Over In QuakeHit Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 7It's still not over. Almost hourly, the earth does its dance, sometimes an easy sway, sometimes a sharp rumble. Buildings bow, offering fresh bricks, glass and plaster to already littered streets.

title: William Wilson Atkin, 63, Led Silvermine Publishers
description: William Wilson Atkin, president since 1964 of Silvermine Publishers Inc. of Norwalk, Conn., specialist in art and architecture books, died Friday in Norwalk, where he lived. His age was 63.

title: FollowUp on The News
Jeffrey Donahue Jr. To Wed Miss Orbe
description: Mr. and Mrs. Octavius A. Orbe of Ridgewood, N.J., and Hyannis, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Orbe, to Jeffrey W. Donahue Jr. of Chester, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of Vienna. Va.

title: Have You Read Any Good Movies Lately?
AROUND THE Garden
Eligible U.S. Voters Area Record High; Registration Lags
description: A report by the Bureau or the Census last week said that the number of Americans of voting age this year had reached a record of 146.8 million, but a Gallup Poll issued yesterday indicated that the percentage of those actually registered to vote continued to lag.

title: Rebels in New Town Defy Canons of Decor
World News Briefs
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 7 (AP)Two gunmen murdered a Yugoslav diplomat, Edvin Zdovc, today as he prepared to back his car out of the garage of his suburban home and drive to work.

title: Lack of Autopsy in Death of Judge's Wife Is Scored
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 7The credibility of the Erie County Medical Examiner's office has been shaken by a parttime medical examiner's failure to conduct an autopsy or to order routine toxicology tests in the suspected suicide of a judge's wife.

title: Where Do the Summer Dogs Go?
description: AT the conclusion of Labor Day weekend last year, 29 dogs were caught in the municipal landfill dump in East Hampton. No one knows how many got away into the wooded areas surrounding the dump and no one can even guess how many cats there were

title: Legal pollution
description: More and more, legal pollution is clogging the everyday affairs of all of us. Thickening layers of legalism seem to surround our lives. We have far too many laws; we rely too heavily on law as an instrument of social change; we depend too much on courts, legislatures and administrative agencies to resolve our woes. The entire system is in danger of becoming Bleak House writ large unless corrective actions are taken

title: The Forecast for Profits Is More
Anker Suprsedes A Board in Queens Over Bilingualism
Jazz vs. Gregorian Mode at Mass Reflects Dutch Catholic Rift With Vatican
description: AMSTERDAMThe priest, choir and congregation join in a rhythmic chant, accompanied by a snare drum and jazz piano, as the bread and wine is consecrated at St. Dominicis Catholic Church in central Amsterdam.

title: HUA'S CHOICE SEEN AS HINT OF A RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Experts on China here, both in and out of the Government, were surprised today by the selection of Hua Kuofeng as Acting Prime Minister of China and successor to the late Chou Enlai.

title: Reading With RoseColored Glasses
Ford Burned in Effigy
description: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 7 (AP)About 200 demonstrators burned President Ford in effigy tonight prior to his speech before a Chamber of Commerce dinner.

title: The Tenor From the Harvard Business School
Backing Out of Paying Pensions
ECONOMICS ROUNDUP
NUMISMATICS
description: Giving further evidence that it is not out to get collectors, the U.S. Mint has taken a step that will benefit them in two important ways.

title: MarketHopping in Ecuador: Surging Vitality and Swirling Color
description: THE Transportes Amazones bus speeds north from Ambato on the PanAmerican Highway. It is 5:30 P.M. We approach 19,347 loot Mount Cotopaxi, the world's highest active volcano. A hot pink sunset suffuses the landscape, turning Cotopaxi's snowy cone into a mammoth dip of strawberry ice cream. It's the climax of five days of exhilaratingand exhaustingbus excursions to Ecuadorian markets from our quarters in Quito.

title: DROP IS REPORTED IN POLICE BRIBERY
description: Corruption charges against city police officers and reported attempts to bribe officers decreased sharply last year, but officials said the declines might in part be the result of layoffs and largescale transfers in work assignments.

title: Maryland Entry Best in L.I. Bulldog Show
Paula J. Latta Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Y. Latta 2d of Coatesville, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Jane Latta, to Charles Cole Coyne Jr. of Abington, Pa.

title: Looking for Tracks in Winter Snow
description: THE book is called Let's Discover Winter Woods, a Golden/Audubon Primer by Ada and Frank Graham. And Becky, who is 3 years old, has been looking at the pictures in it since August.

title: SUSANNAH M'CORKLE SINGING AT BROADY'S
description: Susannah McCorkle, who is singing this weekend and next at Broady's, Columbus Avenue at 98th Street, has a provocative repertory that cuts across a variety of specialties. Along with the Gershwin and Porter show tunes that might be expected of a supperclub singer, Miss McCorkle draws on Bessie Smith (not the more obvious, familiar Bessie Smith songs but the infrequently heard Money Blues), a Willard Robison song. Don't Smoke in Bed, and a number borrowed from Mabel Mercer, Bart Howard's You Are Not My First Love.

title: Michigan Sets Relay Mark
description: EAST LANSING. Mich., Feb. 7 (AP)Michigan set a world indoor record of 3 minutes 23.6 seconds for the sprint medley relay today during the 53d Michigan State Relays. Jeff McLeod, Jim Grace, Doug Hennigar and Andy Johnson won the event for Michigan.

title: Casper, at 68279, Leads by Stroke
SAN DIEGO SEEKING INQUIRY INTO F.B.I.
Fewer Customers, Builders in Trouble, Neighborhoods Deteriorating
ART VIEW
Editors Choice
description: CHILDREN OF THE SUN, by Martin Green. (Basic Books. $15.) An illuminating work of cultural history that explores the dandyesthete sensibility that dominated England for four decades.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Originals. Among their neighbors on Publishers Row the mass market houses were once known as reprinters. for the big books with which they lured millions of readers to the paperback racks were merely lowpriced editions of works that had made the hardcover best seller list the year before. The phrase no longer fits. These days the offices of every major firm bustle with preparations fcr titles never before published, most of them fiction. Not runofthemill genre fiction, mind you, but fiction designed to appeal to millions.

title: DEMOCRATS RATE FAVORITES ROLE
description: The Democratic candidates for seats in the State Legislature long held by members of their party are expected to win in two special elections this Tuesday, but their Republican opponents hope that enough Democrats will ignore party lines to give them victory.

title: Peace Also Has Nuances
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  After formal pledges in 1972 and 1973 of constant collaboration with the United States to foster peace in potential crisis areas, the Soviet Union in 1973 secretly provisioned the Arabs' Yom Kippur attacks, took initiatives toward direct intervention following the shift of impetus against its clients, successfully urged on the petroleum embargo, and strove unsuccessfully to encourage prolongation of that venture in economic hostilities. Notwithstanding its signature as a guarantor of the 1973 Paris peace accords on Vietnam, the Soviet Union in 197475 abetted the North Vietnamese in scrapping those accords and overrunning South Vietnam.

title: DEFICIT ESTIMATE IS SCARY TO LYNN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Projections by Congressional experts that the budget deficit in the next fiscal year is likely to reach $60 billion or more have caused deep concern at high levels of the Ford Administration.

title: Letters
Rose Davis Is Affianced
description: Rose Grosvenor Davis, a teacher at the Georgetown Day School in Washington, and Fernando Mendoza Sanz, a senior loan officer for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Washington, will be married there this June.

title: The Nation
description: Three middlemanagement engineers who had been responsible for monitoring the performance of nuclear reactors for the General Electric Company, the world's largest reactor manufacturer, have resigned because, they say, atomic power plants are too hazardous to operate. The defection of executives who had played such crucial roles in the reactor industry is a substantial victory for opponents of nuclear power.

title: Anthony J. Bruno Dead at 82; Photographed Star Performers
description: Anthony J. Bruno, photographer of stage, screen, television and opera notables, who was known as Bruno of Hollywood, died Friday in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived in Trumbull, Conn.

title: Section's Cities Top Urban Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Census Bureau reported today that the metropolitan areas of the South and Southwest were about the only ones experiencing any substantial growth in population since 1970. The urban centers of the North and Pacific Coast mostly either Inst population or gained only marginally.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
Gail Kaufman Engaged to James Furgal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Kaufman of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Susan Kaufman. to James W. Furgal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Furgal of Watertown. N. Y.

title: Winifred Spiess Plans Marriage
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter C. Spiess Jr. of Lloyd Harbor and Shelter Island, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Winifred Carol Spiess, to Michael Tobin Kalstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Ka!stein of Huntington, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Economic Planning: A Middle Way
U.S. WEIGHING SALE OF ARMS TO EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Ford Administration, seeking to strengthen ties with Cairo, was reported today close to a major decision to consult with Congressional leaders on ending a longstanding ban on the sale of military equipment to Egypt.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Murphy Wins Bear Mountain Jump

title: Ford Gets Boost for Primaries
description: After his long winter of political discontent, President Ford has every right to be pleased about the substantial decline in unemployment registered in January. The economy is doing just about what he has been saying it would do, which is the best political news for Mr. Ford since Nelson Rockefeller drank the hemlock.

title: BRIDGE
description: Bringing a smile to the face of a friend who is sunk in melancholy is perhaps one of the few unalloyed pleasures that mankind has enjoyed since primitive times. Bridgeplayers can on occasion enjoy such a moment at the end of a session of teamplay either knockout or Swiss. One pair has had a disaster, and their gloom may be supplemented by guilt. But when they join their teammates the clouds vanish away and the sun comes out when they are. advised that the expected heavy loss is in fact a profit. The other pair, rightly pleased with its work, has achieved a marvelous result, more than wiping out the effect of the original misfortune.

title: Area Spans Southern Half of Country
description: ALONG INTERSTATE 95 IN VIRGINIA  All day and through the lonely night, the moving vans push southward, 14wheeled boxcars of the highway, changing the demographic face of America.

title: Article 1  No Title
Danes Say Soviet Bombers Near Air Space Regularly
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 7 (AP)A Danish military spokesman has stated that Soviet heavy bombers in groups of 40 to 50 regularly come within minutes of entering Danish air space over the Baltic Sea.

title: In Europe
description: Americans accustomed to the omnipresent N.S.P.S. volunteers are in for a surprise abroad. On a recent trip to Switzerland, for example, I found only four patrolmen covering the Aspensize Kleine Scheidegg area, and only three men on the nearby slopes at Marmlichen, near the town of Wengen. Continual patrolling (the practice at most United States areas) is difficult in the Alps where trails are unmarked and skiers go off in all directions. There, the infrequent patrolmen depend on walkietalkies and S O S telephones to contact a few expertskiing civilians in each town who have a franchise to rescue fallen skiers at a fee of about $20. That's why most European skiers carry ski insurance, says Karl Gamma: director of the Swiss Ski School Association.

title: CHARLES K. CLINTON ARCHITECT, 86, DIES
description: Charles Kemiteth Clinton, a former New York architect, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived here and in Newport. R.I.

title: Mrs. Kissinger Has Surgery for Ulcer; Reported Excellent
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)Nancy Kissinger underwent surgery today for, a gastric ulcer in which 40 per cent of her stomach was removed. Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said after the operation that his wife was in excellent condition.

title: SUBWAY IS URGED IN BUFFALO AREA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The New York State delegation in Congress, which united last fall in an uphill battle to obtain Federal funds to avert a New York City default, united last week to press for an upstate projecta subway for Buffalo.

title: Abigail J. Free, Marcello Natali Are Wed Here
Penn State Celebrates Bicentennial in Opera
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 7Pennsylvania State University has scored a major victory in the Bicentennial culturalevents race with the premiere here last night of John La Montaine's Be Glad Then, America, a grand and moving operaoratorio documenting and celebrating incidents that culminated in the Declaration of Independence.

title: U.S. Subsidies Vital in Keeping Candidates Solvent
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Federal campaign subsidies, whose continued availability is imperiled by a Supreme Court decision, were the only thing that kept most active Presidential candidates in business after a free  spending pre  election year unparalleled in American history.

title: Norman Granz: Impresario Of Recorded Jazz
STAGE VIEW
Carol Leslie Fiancee Of Murray A. Froikin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Leslie of Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Beth Leslie, to Murray Arthur Froikin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Froikin of Dayton, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: Rochester, N. H., to Drop Public School Prayer Case
MARTIN SCORSESE'S GAMBLE
Ideas &Trends
description: GENEVA  In one of public health's greatest triumphs, the most virulent form of smallpox, a viral killer that also leaves many survivors blinded and scarred for life, has been wiped out of the world.

title: Carey Still Lacks Necessary Financial Backing for Ailing Construction Agencies
description: ALBANY, Feb 7After several days of steppedup activity, Governor Carey still has no agreement from various sources of financing of his cornplicated $2.3 billion rescue proposal for the faltering state construction agencies, which face another default deadline in a week.

title: The Big City Book
description: The prospect of brightly colored oversized picture books about city life is enough to make one's heart sink. But the recent publication of two just such books shows that it is still possible to take an insouciant view of the subjectan accomplishment especially remarkable for Annie Ingle's The Big City Book since the city it purports to introduce to children bears an unmistakable resemblance to New York. That is, as unmistakable.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Malta in winter (winter travel to the island is becoming increasingly popular because of the generally mild temperatures and lack of crowds), you'll find that villas along the sea rent for about $200 a month (or $75 a week) for spacious, wellfurnished accommodations. Flats are less, and rooms at the finer hotels won't cost above $30 a night for a double with breakfast. Price srise perhaps 20 percent from May through September, when it is increasingly difficult to find accommodations without prior reservations. There are numerous villa and flat rental agencies. One of the largest, Cassar & Cooper, at Tigne Seafront, Sliema, Malta, will send an illustrated catalogue with prices and other details.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: GLEN RIDGE is a narrow little borough, a sliver of suburbia wedged tightly between Bloomfield and Montclair. It is just 30 blocks long and only four blocks wide at its middle.

title: Correction
description: A dropped line in last week's sources for oriental vegetables left addresses incomplete. They are: Nichols Garden Nursery, Albany, One. 97321; Kitazawa Seed Co., San Jose, Calif. 95110; Burpee Seed Co., Warminster, Pa. 18974; Park Seed Co., Greenwood, S. C. 29647.

title: France Bids Spinola Leave
description: PARIS, Feb. 7 (Reuter)The French Foreign Ministry said today that the former Portuguese president, Gen. Antonio de Spinola, had been asked to leave France. A spokesman said: He is due to leave France today. We prefer that he goes elsewhere.

title: Questions Basic to 30 Years of Government
description: LONDONAnthony Crosland is Britain's Secretary for the Environment, responsible for public housing and many other major welfare programs, a spender and a Socialist who, right now, is not quite sure where the money for his programs will come. Thus it was the other day that he told a Labor Party conference in Cardiff some plain and unpalatable truths.

title: Joan C. Darcy Is Fiance of Paul Sorgi
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Darcy of Bronxville, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Joan Claire Darcy, to Paul Joseph Sorgi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sorgi of Scarsdale, N. Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: FOOD
description: BREAD lovers can be as passionately partisan as sports fans, who have been known to cross continents to see a championship prize fight or a football game. One such bread devotee reports a special attachment for the Pride Bakey at 460 Broadway, Bayonne, which has been a local landmark since the turn of the century.

title: DR. GIUSEPPE C. BALBO
description: Dr. Giuseppe C. Balbo, a former conductor, professor of music and critic in Italy and more recently a teacher of bel canto, composition and harmony here, died Jan. 30 In Brooklyn Hospital, He was 88 years old and lived at 61 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: The City Council has scheduled the following meetings this week.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to. close de bate on Rice Production Act, which required a threefifths vote of the Senate for passage. Motion passed, 70 to 19, Feb. 3.

title: LABOR AIDE LOOKS BACK ON 21 YEARS
description: Jay Kramer, who has submit ted his resignation as chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, looked back on his 21 years with the agency the other day and made some suggestions for the future.

title: George G. Guimaraes Is Fiance Of Mary E. O'Connell, an Editor
description: Mary Elizabeth O'Connell, an associate editor of Ladies Home Journal, and George G. Guimaraes, a vice president with Young & Rubican International Inc., will be married March 20.

title: DALEY'S MACHINE FACES VOTE TESTS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7  Two Illinois Democratic primary races, one gubernatorial, the other Congressional, are regarded by politicians and political observers here as major tests of the continuing strength of Mayor Richard J. Daley's powerful Cook County Democratic machine.

title: 654 Breakfasts Later, a Capital News Event Goes On
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7A prolific newsgenerating institution that has spotlighted many national figures while remaining anonymous itself quietly observed its 10th anniversary this week.

title: Patricia L. Aronow Sets June 13 Bridal
description: Patricia Leslie Aronow, children's editor for the fashion publication of Tob Associates Inc., and Samuel Barkin, a buyer for the men's store of Bloomingdale's here, plan to be married June 13.

title: Looking Back at Geshka
It's Just Like in Hanoi in 1954
description: SAIGONFor the South Vietnamese the Year of the Dragon will also be the year of reunification, with general elections on April 25. Television, radio and the written press use the words thong nhut (reunification) incessantly in No Chi Minh City, the formal name now for this South Vietnamese capital whose inhabitants are still called Saigonese.

title: For young readers
STAMPS
description: The World Federation of United Nations Associations, which over the years has done much to win friends for, and foster understanding of, the United Nations, is being accorded a twofold tribute, from the U.N. itself and from Alexander Calder, the great American artist whose works have made him also an international institution.

title: G.O.P. Loses A Shelter
description: WHEN you register to vote on Shelter Island, it really means something. Normally Shelter Island, that enclave of nearly 2,000 people on a little island between the North and South Forks of Long Island, is Republican. But in the last 20 years there have been some cliffhangers on Election Day. There was the time when Evans Griffing, the perennial candidate for Supervisor beat out Lew Price by a onevote margin. Only a few years ago, the results were so close that things came to a halt until absentee ballots were counted. Again Mr. Griffing squeezed in, by four or five votes.

title: Violence in Sports: Contact Is Natural
description: After reading Dr. Ross Runfola's article (Violence in Sports Reflection of the Violence in American Society, Jan. 11) on this page, I concluded that the social scientist's attempt to analyze the significance of sports in America could be likened to a cornerback trying to tackle O.J. Simpson one on one on a slippery field. It just won't work.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayAssociated Terrier Clubs specialties, 102d Engineers Armory, Fort Wadsworth Avenue and 16Rth Street; 511 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Gilbert Gets 4 Goals, Rangers Win, 54
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7  The puck changed hands with the ease of a dollar bill tonight but Rod Gilbert and the New York Rangers ended up with the money and a 54 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. On the strength of strong individual efforts rather than team play the Rangers ended the Red Wings unbeaten string at six games.

title: Nancy Potter Is Affianced
description: Nancy Elizabeth Potter, a district officer for the Department of Youth, Ethnic and Community Affairs of the Government of New South Wales, Australia, and Christopher Tyler, who expects to be graduated in December from Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia, plan to be married next year.

title: On the Trail of The Broken Limb
Headliners
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon will travel to China later this month, at the invitation of the Chinese Government. Mr. Nixon paid a highly acclaimed visit to China during his Presidency, in 1972. Mr. Nixon said he was making the new trip on a strictly private basis, and the official White House comment was that he would have no official or diplomatic duties during his visit. But President Ford was reportedly annoyed at the timing of the visit, which will begin just before the New Hampshire Presidential primary, and might remind the voters that it was Mr. Ford who pardoned Mr. Nixon for his alleged Watergate misdeeds.

title: Vandalism Causing Concern in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)Vandalism in Britain has become a national disgrace costing communities and private companies tens of millions of dollars a year, according to a report prepared for the Government.

title: Bayh Finds Carter Posing an Obstacle To His Plans for Victory by a Liberal
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 6  Birch Bayh is clinging to a basic assumption on which he planned his run for the Democratic Presidential nomination  a belief that, as he says, the conservative wing of the party is not going to select the nominee.

title: Treasure Hunters, Not U.S., Are Ruled Galleon Owners
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)A United States District judge in. Miami has ruled that a Spanish galleon that sank with tons of silver aboard in 1622 belongs to the treasure hunters that found the vessel and not to the Federal Government.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: New York CityThe headlines and its own denizens call it dangerous, dirty and, sometimes, a deadbeat. Still, it serves as a major crossroads for international commerce and host to thousands of foreign businessmen each year.

title: LIKE A BULLET FROM A RIFLE
NEW FIRE PROVISO GOES INTO EFFECT
description: The first major provision of the city's new fire code for highrise office buildings, designed to remove a principal cause of fire deaths, went into effect yesterday with the vast majority of buildings in noncompliance.

title: The Political Life Is Clearly Affected
The Region
description: The great debate over oil drilling off the region's coastline is not about if but when and how. It is probable that drilling will begin before 1980. The Federal Government plans to sell leases for East Coast drilling sites this summer. Public hearings on the subject were held recently.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: EAST ISLIPMostly Drawings, an exhibit of drawings in pen and ink, pastels. and powdered graphite, through February, Sundays, 2 to 5 P.M.; Wednesdays, to 10 P.M.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 1 to 4 P.M.; Islip Town Art Gallery, 50 Irish Lane.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE SUFFOLK INQUIRY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 7Suffolk Democrats charged this week that the special state prosecutor's investigation of the county's law enforcement agencies was consuming too much time and public money and urged the State Attorney General to review and expedite the inquiry.

title: Return of the Native
PEKING NAMES HUA AS ACTING PREMIER IN SURPRISE MOVE
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 7China disclosed today that Hua Kuofeng, a relatively unknown Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Public Security, had been appointed Acting Prime Minister, succeeding Chou Enlai, who died on Jan. 8.

title: Martins and FarrellA Matched Pair
Alfred Rosenberg saw a bat
description: As the Nazi High Command awaited their day of judgment at Nuremberg. they were attended by the American psychologist Gustave Gilbert. In the course of his work he obtained a set of Rorschach records. Briefly discussed in Gilbert's 1950 book, The Psychology of Dictatorship, the records then dropped out of sight. Now, many years later, exhumed and newly analyzed by psychologist Florence R. Miele and political scientist Michael Selzer, they have at last been brought before the public.

title: Report to Ford Calls For Amateur Reform
description: Amateur sports in the United States are fragmented, illdefined, nondirected and torn by feuds for public support, the President's Commission on Olympic Sports has warned in its first report to the White House.

title: POLITICS
description: REPRESENTATIVE Andrew Maguire and James. Quaremba played tennis over the Christmas holidays, perhaps for the last time as close friends: Mr. Maguire, a Democrat, represents the Seventh: District in Bergen County and is running for reelection this year. Mr. Quaremba is a Republican and he intends to seek his party's Congressional nomination to oppose Mr. Maguire in November_ The chances are that Mr. Quaremba will win the G.O.P nomination, although James Sheehan, the conservative Republican Councilman from Wyckoff, is seeking the nomination, too. Should Mr. Quaremba prevail, it would create a Congressional election confrontation between two men who have been close friends since they went to high school together in Ridgewood 20 years ago.

title: Groups That Help
description: We tell them It's O.K. to cry and if you're angry at him for leaving you, it's O.K.who has a better right to be angry? said Helen Miles.

title: A New View of Plants from An Old Picture Window
