description: My neighbor, Bob Docking, who is a landscape architect, knew that I'd yearned for a greenhouse for several years. But I wanted something I could enjoy, not just a backyard building.

title: Debauched Kangaroos, the L.I.R.R., and Me
Sunday Observer
description: Recently published material on the sex lives of Thomas Jefferson and John F. Kennedy has prompted many questions about sex and the Presidency. Because of the new public demand for lubricious political disclosure, it is now vital to answer them with full candor. Here are the answers to the questions Americans most commonly ask:

title: Is Peter Brook Beyond Theater?
A Good Beginning
description: The unemployment rate for January has provided additional and substantial evidence that the nation is recovering from recession: The figure for the first month of the election year was 7.8 percent, down from 8.3 percent in December. For President Ford, who has begun campaigning in New Hampshire to keep his own job, the figure was especially welcome.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THERE is an eclectic trend in home decorating today, with people choosing furnishings from a variety of styles, according to Rita Roberts of Affiliated Interior Designers in Millburn.

title: American Bobsleds Battle Odds
description: IGLS, Austria, Feb. 7  The men appeared to be warming up for a track meet, doing wind sprints in their track shoes covered by rubbers and doing handstands and pushups. But their legs were being prepared to do only 30 yards of running and then they would be on their sleds, going up to 75 miles an hour and around a 260 degree curve on a refrigerated course that cost nearly $6 million.

title: The Magic Theater of Richard Foreman
description: This won't be the year that Richard Foreman comes entirely out of the avantgarde closet: he's too busy in there, creating theater that fascinates a small if articulate audience. But it will be the year that more and more people encounter him on the outside, and maybe even go into his closet themselves.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Illiteracy is the fruit of mental colonialism. A people that is educated is a people that Roes forward.

title: Newark Church Music
Notes: Old Dog, New Tricks
description: The folks who brought back The Mickey Mouse Club from the fifties now are bringing back The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin, produced from 1954 to 1958 and repeated on the networks through 1964. The rerunning of Rinny, the heroic German shepherd who actually had his origins in pretelevision movies, involves quite an unusual recycling job. Under the supervision of the series's original producer, Herbert B. Leonard, new opening and closing footage has been shot for all 164 episodes, using the original human star, James Brown (now in his 50's) and a dog named Rin Tin Tin VII. Since this new film is in color, the original episodes have been tinted sepia in an effort to simulate color.

title: N.B.A. Paves an OutofCourt Road
description: Some implications of the historic agreement reached by the National Basketlball Association and its players deserve consideration  implications about other sports, about Congress, about the future shape of the league, about commissioners and even about coaches. In settling out of court the antitrust suit that the players brought against the league nearly six years ago, the two sides agreedthrough negotiationto abandon the familiar and absolute reserve system that almost all club owners in all sports have insisted is necessary for survival.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR various reasons  profittaking, an upward jiggle in some interest rates, worry about future Federal Reserve monetary policy and a more sobering reappraisal of some recent economic data among them  the stock market stalled in its meteoric 1976 advance last week, although still maintaining its fastpaced trading burst.

title: Is Infinite Speed Really an Imperative?
description: James Thurber took an ironic view of his fellow man's fascination with the kind of speeds that were leading inexorably to supersonic. He wrote: Man is flying too fast for a world that is round. Soon he will catch up with himself in a great rearend collision and Man will never know that what hit him from behind was Man.

title: FRENCH REDS END KEY PARTY PARLEY

On the Road To Nowhere
description: THE MUSIC MAN's chant of You Gotta Know The Territory would have 900,154 echoes in Nassau County. That's how many of us live in the amorphous mass of unincorporated territory of the county's three townships.

title: Clifton: A City Of Character
description: CLIFTON IN those prehistoric days when The HeraldNews office was at 140 Prospect Street in Passaic, conveniently across the street from the American Legion bar, Danny Duffield used to be the Clifton reporter. He liked to sit on metal wastebaskets next to other reporters desks (no chairs forDanny; too conventional) and explain, in anecdotal detail, about the crazy place that he covered.

title: An Outsider No More
description: MADRIDFor the first time in forty years this country is developing an active, coherent foreign policy that aims at making it a participating member of the world community as soon as possible and no longer an excluded outsider looking in on other people's activities like some isolated political dodo bird.

title: Rain Dance in Grain Futures Prices

description: BARKASSeth Alan. February 7, 1969. Dear Seth, Dust as we are, the Immortal spirit grows.

title: The World
description: Until last week, the differences between Moscow and Washington over the limits of dtente, especially over the superpowers roles in Angola's civil war, were couched in national rather than personal terms. Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, charged that by accusing Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger of using untenable logic and offering halftruths in recent statements about Angola.

title: EXNEW MEXICO AIDE CITED IN INDICTMENT
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 7A Federal grand jury here has indicted David Norvell, a former New Mexico Attorney General, for corrupt use of the power, influence and prerogatives of the office of Attorney General.

title: How resistant was the Resistance?
description: I've always suspected that the French Resistance was a bit of a hoax, fine for movie scripts and 14th of July speeches, but mythologized out of all proportion. My suspicion was confirmed a few years ago when Andre Malraux, who should know, told me that there had been 4,000 Frenchmen in the Resistance and 40,000 in the Gestapo. It is now further confirmed in Henri Frenay's memoirs, The Night Will End

title: Hanson Baldwin's World War II
description: In the same way classical composers felt that they had not fulfilled themselves until they produced at least one major setting of the Mass, so military historians are reluctant to lay down their pens until they have produced their own version of the Second World War. It is not that we need any more versions: to be frank we could do with fewer. But we turn nonetheless expectantly to Hanson Baldwin's new history. It may not have anything new to say about the war, but it is by Hanson Baldwin, and that is enough to whet our appetites.

title: Hunger for Land Is Turning a Region Of Choice Farms Into One of Houses
description: Somewhat reluctantly, farmers in the tristate area are acknowledging that their particular future has already arrived. It is not a future of verdant fields and pastoral scenes, or even one of open spaces lying fallow. Their future consists of acres of suburban housing developments and shopping centers, of gas stations and fastfood stands and expressways.

title: Luanda Requiring Dispatches to Pass Through Press Unit
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (Reuters) The Sovietbacked Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola has set up a press center in the Angolan capital of Luanda through which dispatches or receipts of news stories must pass, the Luanda radio reported today.

description: Price & Pride has yet to add up to profits for A&P but it has already been a windfall for Ted Pugh and Ralph Strait. Pugh and Strait are the actors who portray, respectively, the prim Mr. Price and the ebullient Mr. Pride in all A&P advertisingand each earned over $100,000 last year for doing their thing in television spots, printed ads and personal appearances at A&P stores. If the campaign runs its scheduled three years, the two could make more than $300,000.

title: $85,198 Trifecta Payoff
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 7 (AP) Really Free, Hy Nero and Hasty Fling finished one, two, three at Garden State Park today, producing an $85,198.50 payoff, which the track said was the largest trifecta return in the history of the United States thoroughbred racing. In the trifecta, bettor must pick the exact order of finish in a race and wager costs $3.

title: A Widow's Life: A Sense of Emptiness
description: CHRISTA BEVERIDGE is a tall, handsome 39yearold woman. After a career here and in Europe, she quit her airlines job nine years ago and she and her engineer husband moved from New York City to Nassau County's South Shore. Shortly thereafter, she gave birth to a son and three years later to a daughter. Christa Beveridge's life seemed full and extremely happy.

title: Kate Furtnett Fiancee of Lieut. Flavin
description: Kathleen E. Furtnett and First Lieut. John R. Flavin, U.S.A.F.. plan to marry June 19 at the Vassar College Chapel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Furtnett of Fishkill. N. Y., and Long Beach Island. N. J. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Flavin of St. Louis.

title: The Peter Plan
description: This book, the third part of a trilogy whose predecessors were titled The Peter Principle and The Peter Prescription. continues the author's effort to project the image of a rationalyet plausiblefuture society. The final volume is divided into three chapters: The Peter Proliferation, The Peter Planet and The Peter Program. The first two exhibit the world as Dr. Peter sees it with his favored options and extrapolations, built into the scene. The final chapter recommends strategies for bringing about that new world. The center of Dr. Peter's vision is a utopian city Excelsior City the date of the action 1990.

Also it has nearly doubled its capacity by branching into a new model line.

title: A Test Of Seriousness
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8All the intelligence investigations of the last year have pointed, logically, toward some system of controls to prevent future abuses. But as the time for legislation comes, defenders of the status quo are making a powerful counterattack. Their aim is to prevent any meaningful restraint on what a President and his men may do by way of ordering covert operations.

title: Earthquake Toll in Guatemala Is Now Put at 12,000; EARTHQUAKE TOLL PLACED AT 12,000
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 8  Estimates of the death toll in the earthquake that struck this country four days ago rose to more than 12,000 today.

title: THREAT OF GAS CUT BY CANADA EASING
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 8A slowdown in demand for natural gas in Canada, coupled with an improved outlook for future production here, has eased the threat of a cutback in exports of that fuel to the United States next winter.

title: Red Smith
description: WINDHAM, N. Y., Feb. 8  From the top of the mountain, white slopes plunge down and down and down again to the toy village of Windham, and beyond a slender white church spire the landscape unrolls to the far horizon, a random patchwork of forest and snow. This is Windham Mountain, formerly Cave Mountain, which was formerly South Mountain, a 3,100foot Catskill with northern exposure. It is a semiprivate ski facility where the Beautiful People come to break bread and bones with HalfBeautiful People and Unbeautiful Penpie when they haven't the time or money to snap a tibia in St. Moritz or Zurz Grenoble. The Windham Mountain Club has members like Whitelaw Reid, who was the next to the next to last publisher of The New York Herald Tribune; like Rushton Skakel, chairman of the Great Lakes Carbon Company; like Gov. Hugh Carey's brother Dennis and like Mortimer Levitt of The Custom Shops. Also among the 490 members are doctors, lawyers, engineers, architects, firemen and cops who never make Suzy's column but care enough about sliding downhill to pay an initiation fee of $750 and annual dues or$300. And finally there is the general frostbitten public, except on weekends and holidays.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  ofthe  street restrictions are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of weather conditions. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

description: How does a man feel after completing a work that has engaged him for 20 years and required the writing of five books? Does he feel regretful? Relieved? Hollowedout? Buoyant?

Much of the time since, Mr. Byrne had tried to get Mr. DeRose dismissed.

Baden, talk about unnatural death and watch slides.

Rizzo of Philadelphia that could produce 40 or more firstballot votes for Mr. Shapp's longshot Presidential campaign, but could also exact a heavy price in liberal sympathy for Mr. Shapp among fervant antiRizzo Democrats.

description: GENERAL

title: Federal Funds Pour Into Sunbelt States
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  The factors behind the emergence of the Sunbelt as a powerful and cohesive region are multiple  rapidly changing industrial, economic and population patterns, new living styles, a balmy climate.

title: Article 1  No Title
DUTCH OFFICIALS NAME BERNHARD IN BRIBERY CASE
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8  The Dutch Cabinet today identified Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands as the Dutch official who, according to a top Lockheed executive, received $1.1 million gift from the company to aid aircraft sales in the Netherlands.

title: Teachers End Strike
description: Striking teachers in Newark voted overwhelmingly to accept a compromise settlement worked out in an allnight bargaining session and to return to the classrooms today after a week's absence. Details are on page 31.

title: SOVIET IMPROVES ARMS TRANSPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Soviet Union's operation in Angola has demonstrated a striking improvement of airlift and sealift capabilities that, United States Government sources say, could be used in the future to support Soviet political and military interests at even longer range.

title: Ashe, Serve Booming, Takes 3d Tourney
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 8 (AP)Arthur Ashe, his booming serve working nearly to perfection, trounced Brian Gottfried, 62, 64, in the final of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today. It was his third tournament triumph on the circuit this year.

title: Houston, as Energy Capital, Sets Pace in Sunbelt Boom
description: HOUSTON  For decades, Houston was a steamy little southeast Texas swamp town commanding little attention and less respect. Genteel Galrestonians dismissed it as Babylon on the bayou.

title: China's Naming of Relatively Inexperienced Leader Raises Many Questions
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 8The surprise disclosure yesterday that Hua Kuofeng, a relatively Inexperienced official, is China's Acting Prime Minister left analysts here with a series of deeply puzzling questions and few answers.

title: MOSCOW EXHIBITS CALM ON ANGOLA
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8The Ford Administration's blunt warnings on the Soviet Union's involvement in Angola appear to have had little effect on Moscow's policy.

title: Jackson Meets With Moynihan During Campaign Visit to City
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, who is running for the Democratic nomination for President, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who says he is not running for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, held a brief private meeting yesterday at Mr. Moynihan's office at the United States Mission to the United Nations.

title: Fletcher of Times Wins Writing Prize
description: For the 12th successive year, Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times has been named a firstplace winner in the Dog Writers' Association of America competition. He was cited for the best dog column or best dog news reporting in the over500,000 circulation category at a dinner in the Statler Hilton Hotel last night.

title: Waldrons Keep Title
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Dance: A Night of Glory
description: Although there are still six performances of the George Balanchine/Nicolas Nabokov full  evening ballet Don Quixote due at the New York State Theater starting on Thursday, New York City Ballet's general repertory season at Lincoln Center ended last night in a glowing suffusion of glory. The final ballet was George Balanchine's Chaconne, one of the new works this season and the kind of choreography that makes a person realize what it is about ballet that makes it the most poetically mathematical of all the arts.

title: Striking Newark Teachers Vote Pact
description: Striking teachers in Newark voted overwhelmingly yesterday afternoon to accept a compromise settlement worked out in an allnight bargaining session! and to return to the classrooms today after a week's absence.

title: Dispute Stalls a Major Project in Queens
Bentsen May Quit Carter and Harris Lead in Oklahoma
Sing Out Magazine Marks 25 Years In True Folk Style
description: The folkmusic magazine Sing Out celebrated 25 years of existence with a benefit concert at Town Hall on Saturday that was more or less a musical trip through its pages and aims. There was music that moved ft om the North American Indian to the more familiar sound of Pete Seeger. Mr. Seeger is a founding father and editor of the magazine.

title: The Chinese Key: II
description: WASHINGTON  Why is Richard Nixon returning to Peking? In a carefully drawn answer to that question, he has given me this statement:

title: 3 FIREMEN KILLED AT QUEENS BLAZE
Ads with Ski Star Ruled Legitimate
description: Advertisements currently appearing in publications with Cindy Nelson, the skier, as the subject are legitimate, according to a member of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: FACTION IN ANGOLA SAID TO FLEE CITY
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 8The population of Huambo, capital of the proWestern forces in Angola, fled in panic Friday and yesterday, accordto reports reaching here.

title: 144 on Offshore Rig Like Different Life
description: ABOARD THE SEDCO J IN THE ATLANTIC, Feb. 7It's a totally different life, said Kevin Kimball, a fledgling roustabout from Bricktown, N.J. You never see land. There's no car to drive away in after work. No girls. Nothing.

title: EUGENIE S. INTEMANN
description: Eugenie Schaaf Intemann, former New York State president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, died Saturday in Westfield, N.J. She was 87 years old and lived here.

title: Gas Fiasco
description: In a surprising reversal, the House of Representatives has sensibly defeated a natural gas decontrol measure that would have illprotected the nation's economic health. Unfortunately, the measure adopted in its place fails to confront fundamental issues of the fuel shortage. Since the House bill differs so significantly from the earlier Senatepassed version, Congress is threatened with total deadlock in this election year on one of the central problems of national energy policy.

title: Eroding Tax Base
description: A projected decline In the value of taxable real property here places new stress on the already troubled threeyear plan to restore New York's fiscal balance.

title: Eagles Hire Vermeil as Head Coach
New Law Snarls Pension Plans
description: The Federal pension law, passed in 1974 to protect workers, has created chaos among the country's 600,000 pension plans and raises the prospect that the cost of compliance will cut into the pay rises of many people this year and next.

title: Art Exhibition Is Opening For Black History Week
description: An art exhibition, a panel discussion on Angola and a film festival will be the features on a Black History Week program that begins today at the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Hearing to Take Up Access by Jurors To a Hearst Tape
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 (UPI)  Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter will conduct a hearing tomorrow on whether the Patricia Hearst jury can consider the This is Tania tape in which the defendant said she robbed a bank of her own free will. Her attorneys said there was a good chance Miss Hearst would testify ati the hearing, with the jury excluded.

title: Baroque Music Masters, Miss von Stade at Hunter
description: The highlight of the Baroque Music Masters concert Saturday night at the Hunter College Playhouse, a benefit for the college's arts concert bureau, was Frederica von Stade's stint as guest soloist. And the highlight of Miss Stade's singing was her first group, devoted to Cavalli and Monteverdi.

title: Economy Hurts Newark Blacks
description: NEWARKAs long as have my health and strength, Fin going to make it, Hattie Cain said.

title: James Plaque Planned In Westminster Abbey
description: LONDON, Feb. 8A memorial stone to Henry James will be placed in Poets Corner of Westminster Abbey alongside the stone honoring T. S. Eliot, another Americanborn writer who became a British subject.

title: TWO MORE BODIES WILL BE EXHUMED
description: Two more bodies will be exhumed today and tomorrow in the widening new investigation into whether nine or more patients were murdered with curare over a 10month period at a small New Jersey hospital a decade ago.

title: Benjamin E. Smith Is Dead
description: Benjamin Eugene Smith, civil rights lawyer in New Orleans, died there Friday of pancreatitis. He was 48 years old.

title: Aftermath of a Fire: Mourning at Two Firehouses
description: Lieut. Joseph M. Beetle, who had spent 29 of his 53 years in the Fire Department, was planning to retire in about two years.

title: West Coast Terriers Dominate
Activist Hostesses Nettle Airlines With Demands
description: Oncedocile airline stewardesses, conditioned by the feminist movement and frustrated by a glamorless job with a glamorous image, have emerged as a militant labor force.

title: Islanders Lose to Flyers
Marijuana Seized on Boat
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 (UPI)  A fishing boat with four tons of marijuana in her hold was seized and two men were arrested Friday when the Coast Guard chased the vessel and boarded her off Point Arena.

title: ASSEMBLY PROPOSES A BAN ON CONCORDE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8The State Assembly will take up this week legislation to bar the Concorde supersonic airliner from Kennedy International Airport, Speaker Stanley Steingut announced today.

title: Dr. Cowan May Enter G.O.P. Senate Race
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Dr. James R. Cowan, a former New Jersey Health Commissioner and now an Assistant Secretary of Defense, may run for the United States Senate seat held by Harrison A. Williams, a Democrat.

title: Grounded Tanker Is Freed
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 8 (AP)1 The Austin, a 633fool tanker was floated free from a reef near Honolulu Harbor where she ran aground Friday morning, a United States Coast Guard spokesman said last night.

title: . . . Test Case in Aid
description: With Presidential approval, Mr. Kissinger has committed the United States to discuss producerconsumer agreements on individual commodities on a casebycase basis. But apart from a new version of the longstanding international tin agreement, in which the Administration has agreed to participate, the coffee pact is the first real test of this commitment.

title: Women Professors Said to Lose Ground On Wages and Rank
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Women on the faculties of the country's colleges and universities lost ground in both salary Increases and rank last year, the United States Office of Education reports.

title: Miller Wins Hope. With a Closing 63
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 8If Johnny Miller were a betting man, he said this afternoon, he would bet on himself to win the Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: Pickup in Business Seen by Purchasers
description: A further improvement in basic business conditions was recorded last month, the National Association of Purchasing Management announced over the weekend.

title: 91 Shot Takes Rich Strub Stake
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. (AP)  George Navonod. a standout as a 2yearold but a dud in 1975, made a strong stretch drive under Fernando Toro to win the $121,900 Strub Stakes for 4yearolds at Santa Anita today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
MARTIN BUSKIN, 45, OF NEWSDAY DIES
description: Martin Buskin, who as education editor of Newsday since 1962 had won many prizes in the field, died of a heart attack early yesterday at his home, 40 Raybor Road, Commack, L.I. He was 45 years old.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: When we printed two recipes calling for powdered lime a short while ago, we did not suspect it would start a controversy as knotted as a kettle of cold, leftover spaghetti. We attempted an explanation in this column and as a consequence became even further tangled.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nearly $1 million a year is wasted in New York State because state taxes are administered by political appointees, the New York Public Interest Research Group said in Albany. The group reported that 64 estatetax lawyers across the state were getting a total of nearly $700,000 in annual salaries. The duties, according to the group, could be handled more efficiently and at far less expense by a smaller number of lesserpaid clerks. In addition to funds for salaries, the treasurers for 44 upstate counties may take $5,000 a year from estatetax revenues as a fee for administering them.

title: Bridge: Game on a Commuter Train Organizes the Unorganizable
description: If somebody took the trouble to organize the unorganizable, a contest between teams representing various commuter trains, the 5:24 P.M. from Grand Central Terminal to Stamford, Conn., would surely be among the favorites.

title: 3 Groups to Be Judged Today at Garden Dog Show
Five Balkan Nations Confer on Region's Problems
description: ATHENS. Feb. 8A conference of five Balkan countries ended here last week with some modest progress toward cooperation on economic and technical problems.

title: Teachers End Strike
description: Striking teachers in Newark voted overwhelmingly to accept a compromise settlement worked out in an allnight bargaining session and to return to the classrooms today after a week's absence. Details are on page 31.

title: Music: Leonard Raver
description: Leonard Raverorganist of the New York Philharmonic, teacher at the Juilliard School and Yale University and the man who played demonstration programs for invited guests on the Kuhn organ at Alice Tully Hall last winter before the instrument was introduced to the publicgave his first official Tully Hall recital Saturday night.

title: A Bloody Sunday Here
description: On a sunny Sunday afternoon, instead of throwing snowballs or watching Russians win gold medals on television, 150 people showed up yesterday at Steinway Concert Hall to listen to the deputy chief medical examiner of the City of New York, Dr. Michael M. Baden, talk about unnatural death and watch slides.

title: 2 Top Fives Nearly Toppled
description: Indiana and Marquette, the nation's two topranked college basketball teams, both narrowly beat the buzzer to avoid upset defeats on Saturday.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  ofthe  street restrictions are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of weather conditions. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Bugging in Moscow Causes Health Scare
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8The American Embassy here has privately warned its diplomats that Soviet electronic eavesdropping devices placed inside the embassy could pose a potential hazard to health through radiation.

title: Hawks Lose Magnuson
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP)Keith Magnuson, Chicago Black Hawk defenseman, will be sidelined for the remainder of the National Hockey League season with a fractured vertebra, dub officials said today.

title: BROOKINGS STUDY OPPOSES BOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8A study published today by the Brookings Institution concludes that there is no urgent military need for the B1 strategic bomber and that it would be costly mistake to order the new Air Force plane into production.

title: E. STANLEY KLEIN, 82, OF J.P. MAGUIRE &
description: E. Stanley Klein, a founder of Fieldcrest Mills Inc., and former president and chairman of John P. Maguire & Company, factors, died yesterday at the Cabrini Medical Institute. He was 82 years old and lived at 440 East 57th Street.

title: 144 on Rig 80 Miles Off Coast Like Different Life
description: ABOARD TKE SEDCO J IN THE ATLANTIC, Feb. 7It's a totally different life, said Kevin Kimball, a fledgling roustabout from Bricktown, N. J. You never see land. There's no car to drive away in after work. No girls. Nothing.

title: BARCELONA POLICE BATTLE THRONGS ASKING HOME RULE
description: BARCELONA, Feb. 8Thouands of Catalans battled with the police today for the second successive Sunday in support of their demands for regional government.

title: Boy Scouts Reaching Out for Handicapped Members
description: I promise to do my best to do my duty to God and ow country, the Cub Scout said, He was grinning. Since September he had learned the handshake, the salute and the other small things that went with scouting.

title: INQUIRY CONTINUES IN HOSPITAL DEATH
description: Police detectives and Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx were continuing their investigation yesterday into the death Saturday of a 79yearold pneumonia patient, Angelina Lettieri, whose breathing apparatus had become disconnected.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford, Jabbing at Reagan in New Hampshire, Stresses His Own Experience in Running Federal Government.
description: DURHAM, N. H., Feb. 8President Ford, stressing that he had already had experience running the Federal Government, urged New Hampshire voters here today to sort out the record from the rhetoric of Ronald Reagan, his rival for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: The Football Players Makes Sport of Art
description: Lee Breuer's Mabou Mines theater company transfixed us with its most recent experimental piece, an adaptation of Samuel Beckett's The Lost Ones, mostly a monologue, now running at the Public Theater. The company's The Saint and the Football Players, which had its New York premiere with one performance Saturday at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, promised to be the opposite a cross between a Roman spectacle and the Super Bowl, This was called a Sports/Arts event, a WarDance, with a 100member cast, a football team, a marching band, a car ballet and a snowstorm,

title: House Gets 2 Plans To Resolve Dispute On Elections Panel
Critic's Notebook: For Many, Writing Is a Hungry Trade
Meet Here Loses McTear, Gets Another School Star
description: High school sprinters being the rage, yes, one will be entered in the 50meter dash at the United States Olympic Invitation track and field meet at the Garden on Feb 20. But, no, he won't be Houston McTear. He'll be William Snoddy, a 17yearold student at Nathan Hale High in Tulsa, Okla. And if your first reaction to that name iswho's he?you're not alone.

title: G.A.O. QUESTIONING LOCKHEED ABILITY TO REPAY IN TIME
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The General Accounting Office has disclosed that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, involved in a worldwide bribery scandal, may not be able to repay its federally guaranteed loans on time. The loan guarantee averted the banktruptcy of the company in 1971.

title: Gains Reported in Creating Bacteria Safe for Tests
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 9Progress was reported today in developing microbes safe enough for use in genetic experiments now regarded as so potentially hazardous that scientists have deferred them until proper guidelines could be drawn up to minimize their risks to society

title: Horse in Apartment Takes on a New Hue
description: Peter Smith spent yesterday morning at a Brooklyn riding academy trying to reclaim the black and white pinto gelding he insists was a present for his 2yearold daughter. The horse had been found last Friday in the Smiths vacated apartment at 1589 Ocean Avenue in Flatbush.

title: Ohio Is Crucial Testing Ground in U.S. Pollution Fight
Bomb Kills a Relative Of Argentine ExChief
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 (Reuters)The daughterinlaw of former Argentine President Alejandro A. Lanusse was killed here tonight when a bomb exploded in her home, the police said.

title: WITNESSES ARGUE PUERTO RICO BILL
In Italy, Sliding From Recent Gains, One View Is: Let's Eat Plenty Now
description: ROME, Feb, 9The Italians, proud of economic miracles that have kept them from the precipice, are in search of another miracle

title: Hams Here Ease Anxiety Over Quake
description: The cold statistics of death and destruction from last week's earthquake in Guatemala caused days of anguish to thousands of relatives in the United States, but ham radio stations in both countries have begun to bring relief to some, grievous certainty to others

title: Thoeni Leads in Giant Slalom, Phil Mahre 4th at Innsbruck
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 9Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, the defending Olympic champion in the giant slalom, raced into the lead in his specialty, as expected, today at the 12th Winter Games, but the big surprise was the fourthplace finish of Phil Mahre.

title: Father and Son
Rockets Beat King, 10586
State Told Parks Are Imperiled; Albany Asked Not to Cut Budget
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9Park maintenance in the state is threatened with collapse, inventories of supplies and materials are depleted, and the entire system of parks is antiquated and stretched to the limit, the State Parks and Recreation Commissioner told a panel of legislators today.

title: Central African Republic Holds 3 in Coup Attempt
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Feb 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  Two Central African Republic officers and a senior ministerial official have been named as leaders of the abortive coup attempt involving a grenade attack on President JeanBedel Bokassa last week, the Central African Republic's Bangui radio, monitored here, has announced. The President was not hurt.

title: MAYOR SHOT DEAD IN A BASQUE TOWN
JUSTICE AGENCY SHIFTING TACTICS
PARKING
description: Motorists in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island will be able to park their ears today on both sides of streets where alternate sideofthestreet regulations al e normally in effect The regulations are being suspended to speed snow removal. In Manhattan, however, the rules will again be in effect All other parking and standing restrictions still apply throughout the city.

title: Ford in New Hampshire: Preview of Things to Come
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The highlight of President Ford's weekend campaign excursion to New Hampshire was, in the view of his political allies, his encounter last night in Durham with Bonzo the Gorilla. Mr. Ford's twoday trek to the state where, on Feb. 24, he will first confront the Republican primary challenge of Ronald Reagan, was prototypical: At a budget) briefing for elected officials, in, a televised news conference and at a question session with students of the University of New Hampshire, Mr. Ford sought to display such a, breadth of knowledge about, the affairs of the Government he heads as to persuade his party to stay with a proven quality. But if Mr. Ford's technique made him appear presidential, as intended, some of his advisers also worried that he seemed ponderous.

title: Soviet Skier Loses Medal Over a Drug
PAYMENT SPURNED IN COOP CITY CASE
description: State officials rejected $650,000 in withheld carrying charges yesterday that had been delivered on behalf of Coop City residents who are battling a sharp increase in carrying charges.

title: Zambia Shuts University More Teachers Arrested
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 9 (AP)The University of Zambia. scene of demonstrations both for and against the Government in recent weeks, was closed indefinitely today after the arrest of two more lecturers, including an American

title: Theater: Aranha Estate in Hartford
Ford May Avoid Congress On Food Stamp Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Ford Administration is exploring the possibility of implementing much of its proposed food stamp reform by issuing new regulations rather than waiting for any Congressional action.

title: After Pat at Turtle Bay
State Putting Pressure on City U.
description: Members of the State Emergency Financial Control Board said yesterday that a decision must be reached soon, perhaps this week, on the question of what to do about supervising budget cutbacks in the City University, the hospitals and Other semiautonomous agencies of city government.

title: FOUR MUSICIANS WIN FISHER PRIZES
description: Ursula Oppens and Paul Shenly, pianists; Ani Kavafian, violinist, and Heidi Lehwalder, harpist, have been named recipients of the first Avery Fisher Prizes. The. noncompetitive awards include $1,000 each an appearance with the New York Philharmonic and six appearances with other United States orchestras, and are designed to recognize exceptionally talented young instrumentalists and to further their careers.

title: Shanker Warns Governor On a Veto of School Bill
AID SUPPLIES POUR INTO GUATEMALA DEAD PUT AT 15,000
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 9Relief supplies poured in by air today and were being moved quickly to areas devastated by the earthquakes of last week, one of the worst natural disasters in Latin American history.

title: Conventions Called Circus
description: NASHVILLE, Feb 9 (UP1)Gov Ray Blanton said today that national party conventions were a circus that should be replaced by binding national or regional primaries

title: Red Wings Waive Redmond; Called Disruptive Influence
description: Imagine. You had a center who had scored 40 goals one season and 47 last season. You traded him. Now you've got a right wing who scored 52 goals and 51 goals in successive seasons, and you've suspended him and put him up for the $30,000 waiver price.

title: Prices Fall Sharply In Potato Futures
description: Potato futures prices dropped sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange when it was reported that a ship loaded with potatoes for Belgium had been diverted and ordered to head for Algeria The May delivery dropped the daily limit of 50 points to close at 15.90 cents a pound when the news was announced around 10.22 A.M over a Reuters wire on the floor of the exchange

description: Designersmany designers seem to have found the key that unlocks the door that opens on a fresh new fashion vista.

description: MOSCOW, Feb, 9 (UPI)The fivekopeck subway ride may be finished in Moscow nearly 30 years after the nickel trip died in New York

title: E. German Skier Keeps NordicCombined Title
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 9Ulrich Wehling of East Germany who broke protocol in 1972 by becoming the first nonScandinavian to win the Nordiccombined skiing championship in the Olympics, retained the title today. But his closest competitors were a West German and an East German teammate

title: 28 Wounded by Arrows In Papua New Guinea Clash
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Twentyeight combatants were treated for arrow wounds today after 800 men fought a tribal battle in Papua New Guinea's highlands, police officials reported.

title: Walton Hurt Again; Sidelined 5 Weeks; About Pro Basketball
description: For someone who espouses health foods, Bill Walton is not very healthy. The latest in a series of mishaps and injuries to befall the 6foot11inch Portland Trail Blazer center, was described as a stress fracture of the fibula bone of the right ankle. The injury will sideline Walton for about five weeks. It was discovered Sunday night after the Golden State Warriors had snapped Portland's sevengame wining streak, 109105

title: New Millionaires Many Rich From Property, Flourish in Egypt's Liberalized Economy

description: Because of a fivepart series on medical incompetence that was published in The New York Times last month, pharmaceutical concerns have canceled advertising worth $500,000 from Modern Medicine, a magazine owned by The New York Times Company.

title: DU PONT INCREASES PRICE ON ITS RESINS
Health Report on Ford Released Despite Objection by His Doctor
Chess:
Common Market Nations Welcome Bid by Greece
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 9 (UPI)The nine nations of the European Common Market officially welcomed Greece's application for membership today and ordered negotiations to begin as soon as possible.

title: COURT BLOCKS BAN ON DISPUTED DYE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia blocked the Food and Drug Administration today from banning Red No. 2, one of the most widely used dyes in foods, drugs and cosmetics.

title: $3.2 Million Apartment Refused by Stewart Mott
Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the. 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Default of Maritime Fruit Threatens British Shipbuilding Industry
description: LONDON, Feb. 9  Three years ago two enigmatic Israelis were hailed as rescuers of Britain's proud but ailing shipbuilding industry when they placed the largest orders shipbuilders here had ever received They ordered 13 ships and took options for 13 more.

title: Market Place
AREA CONGRESSMEN OBJECT TO CONCORDE
Mrs. Dorothy M. Crawford, Helped Found Little Theater
description: Mrs Dorothy M. Crawford, widow of Jack R Crawford, a professor of English at Yale University who died in 1968, died yesterday in the home of a daughter, Mrs. Richard V Holahan, 162 Bay Avenue, Huntington, L I She was 90 years old

title: Lina Wertmuller to Make Movies for Warner Bros.
description: Lina Wertmuller, the Italian director who has scored here with a succession of Italianmade movies, including Seven Beauties, will make her first films for an American company, Warner Bros., under an exclusive contract calling for her to write and direct four Englishlanguage features.

title: A Slow Nuclear Pace Is Cited in Study
description: GENEVA, Feb. 9Other factors besides the crisis of 1973 74 when Arab oil producers reduced output have led Western, European governments to put more emphasis on coal, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

title: City U. Cuts Lead to Little Faculty Change
description: A survey of the various units of the City University shows that most have managed to make the budget cuts mandated for the spring semester without resorting to the dismissal of fulltime faculty members.

title: Springer Gains At Westminster
RITES SET FOR TODAY FOR 2 OF 3 FIREMEN
description: Funerals for two of the three firemen killed Sunday morning in Richmond Hill, Queens, will be held tomorrow They died when a roof collapsed at the scene of a fire at 11925 Liberty Avenue.

title: Aid and Diplomacy . . .
description: Should American economic aid to individual foreign countries depend on the political stands taken by those countries at the United Nations') The issue was most recently raised by votes in the General Assembly last autumn on such diverse matters as Puerto Rican independence, the role of the U. N. in South Korea and, most inflammatory in the public mind, the condemnation of Zionism as a form of racism. It figures in the strategypressed so strenuouslyand controversiallyby Ambassador Moynihan in his recent publicized memorandum the State Department.

description: RICHMOND, Ky., Feb 9 (UPI)Bob Mulcany, Eastern Kentucky basketball coach, resigned his post at the Ohio Valley Conference school today, effective the end of the season. He plans to leave coaching

description: WASHINGTON, Feb 9 (AP) President Ford got on the transAtlantic phone today to congratulate America's Olympic goldmedal winner, Sheila Young, and to tell her the whole country was so proud of you

title: New Inquiry in Czech's 62 Death Here
description: Lawenforcement officials here are searching old records for new clues to a mysterious murder that occurred in the Czechoslovak Mission to the United Nations here. The search is being undertaken as a result of testimony in Washington by Joseph Froilk, a former Czech intelligence agent, to a closed session of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee.

title: An End to Rent Controls on Apartments Over $300 a Month Is Urged
