description: The St. Olaf Choir, a touring chorus of some 65 singers from St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., seemed a bit forlorn Sunday night all alone at Avery Fisher Hall. They stood on risers on the otherwise empty stage, huddled together in their purple robes with white trim on the sleeves that looked like crumpled flippers.

title: Dollar Off Abroad; Gold Also Declines
Bill to Aid City Housing Fails in Senate
France's Reds Cultivate an Image of Independence From Soviet
Production of Steel Shows Drop of 1.5% For the Latest Week
description: Steel production in the first full week of February fell 1.5 percent below the level of the final week of January, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association said that the nation's steelmakers poured 2 29 million tons of steel in the week ended Feb. 7, down from 2.32 million tons a week earlier. The new production capability index slipped to 76.6 percent from 77.7 percent a week earlier.

title: Feiffer Fills Play With Food and Thought
description: The characters in his new play, Knock, Knock, spend so much time at the table, Jules Feiffer said the other day, that someone suggested that it should have been titled, Eat, Eat.

title: Entex Will Acquire A Retail Gas Unit Of Houston Concern
German Living Costs Rise
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Feb. 9The West German cost ofliving index rose 0.8 percent in January from December to stand at 138 2 (base 1970), 5 3 percent above January 1975, the Federal Statistics Office said today. In December, the rises were 0.3 percent and 5.4 percent, respectively.

title: GENESCO STAGES PROFIT RECOVERY
State Court Costs
description: Long before New York City's fiscal crisis had been exacerbated by the increasing burden of cases in the criminal justice system, study commissions and bar associations were calling for the state to assume the costs of court, probation and correction services The idea behind this important step is not just to save money but to promote justice

title: MARTIN JOSMAN
description: Martin Josman, former presdent of the Metropolitan Car Company and a vice president of the American Scholarship Association, died Friday in a Brooklyn hospital He was 89 years old and lived at 1170 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn.

title: TRADING IS QUIET IN MONEY MARKET
description: Still pondering the likely direction of pricesand thus interest ratescredit market participants, including the Federal Reserve itself, maintained that largely amounted to a holding action yesterday in quiet trading. Keeping one eye on the results of the Treasury Department's regular weekly auction of bills, Government market watchers also took note that during the day the rate on Federal funds excess reserves commercial banks may lend one anothertouched the 4 percent level.

title: Accord Bringing Stability To Currency Marketplace
Stott and Ryan On Front Row
Airing the Campaigners
description: The selling of the Presidential candidates has begun on television, arriving with the seasonal snowfalls and primaries. Predictably, the first complaints have been heardand more can be expectedabout inadequate news coverage, time bought and sold on the commercial stations, and the advantage held by a President who is a candidate.

title: At Aid Post, Guatemalans Wait Quietly
Aides Report Bentsen Will Drop Out of Race
description: HOUSTON, Feb 9 (UPI)Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas will withdraw as a candidate for the Presidency and concentrate on his reelection to the Senate, his aides said today. Mr. Bentsen called a news conference for tomorrow in Austin to announce his plans.

title: Grumman Will Pay $28 Million to Iran, Instead of Lobbyists
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Feb. 9The Grumman Corporation, the nation's fifth largest defense contractor, has agreed to pay the Government of Iran $28 million which it has originally contracted to pay to its lobbyists in Teheran to expedite the sales of the controversial F14 Tomcat fighter plane. The arrangement with the lobbyists had incurred Iranian displeasure.

title: Defendant's Image That of the WellBred and Demure
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb 9 Patricia Campbell Hearst looked small and pale as she sat on the witness stand today and told her story of the last two years Sometimes her voice was barely audible, sometimes it was strong

title: Helping New York
Ford Sends Congress Plan On Pensions and Medicare
Going Against Traffic
13 Britons Reported Shot By Firing Squad in Angola
W. VINCENT GRADY
description: BEACON, N Y., Feb 9 (AP)Vincent Grady, a retired State Supreme Court justice, died at his home today. He was 70 years old.

title: DUTCH TO ASSESS BERNHARD'S ROLE
How Career Woman Can Get Ahead by Really Trying
description: Hard work can move you along in the business world, but many women feel they lack that extra asset that can ease their way to the top a mentor.

title: Fire Claims Seventh Victim
description: CHICAGO. Feb 9 (UPI)A seventh person died today from the effects of a fire last Wednesday at the Cermak Nursing Home in suburban Cicero. The victim was Helen Erickson, 81 years old.

title: Nuggets Top Nets, 138119, Extend Lead
PCB Poison
Ford Says He Would Want Kissinger in Future Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 9 (AP) President Ford has said he would ask Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to remain in the Cabinet if Mr Ford is elected President for a full term, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, acknowledged today.

title: Modern Museum May Add Condominium
Dr. Louise A. Johnson, 55, Dies; Directed Study on East Harlem
Conservative Plans Drive for Connally In New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Richard Viguerie, the Conservative fundraiser, said today that he would campaign to get writein votes, for John B. Connally, who is a Republican, on the Democratic side of the New Hampshire Presidential primary on Feb 24

title: Fire Code on HighRises Is Stayed by State Court
No More Dishpan Hands
ExConvict Is Held In Sexual Assault On a Queens Boy, 13
description: A 43yearold, man who was released from prison in 1974 after serving 26 years for the murder of an 8yearold child is to appear at a hearing today in Queens Criminal Court on charges of kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 13yearold newsboy last Sunday.

title: Animal Rights Group Seeks To Prevent Bird Spraying
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky, Feb 9 (AP)The Society for Animal Rights filed today a motion in United States District Court in Washington to block further chemical sprayings of blackbirds in Kentucky and Tennessee according to an aide to Senetor Walter Huddleston

title: Bridge:
description: In general, a competitive auction makes it harder to judge the partnership potential, but in special cases it can make life easier.

title: House Panel Report On Excess Surgery Assailed by A.M.A.
Weekend Boxing
description: BOSTONMarvin Hagier, 160 pounds, Brockton, Mass., knocked out Matt Donovan, 160, Trinidad, 2 rounds.

title: Synthetic Fuels in U.S. Still Held Costly
description: Recent studies have hardened energyindustry estimates that synthetic fuels from coal and shale will remain uneconomic for many years, indicating that government backing would be essential for nearterm, commercialscale tests.

title: Books of The Times
description: It appears to me that sociology is passing from a negative phase to a positive one A few years ago, the social sciences showed off by exposing our imperfections, by classifying and explaining them. There was an implicit sneer in such books, as if the authors were determined to puncture man's conceit, to pluck the feathers from the peacock. Now, it is just the other way around. Instead of concentrating on our vulnerabilities, sociologists are beginning to congratulate us on our strength, our perseverance, our almost paradoxical faith in life.

title: Music: Waart Steps In
description: Most people in the Carnegie Hall audience last night expected to see Lorin Maazel on the podium, facing the Cleveland Orchestra. Instead they encountered Edo de Waart, the young Dutch conductor who heads the Rot terdam Philharmonic. Mr. Maazel hurt his leg in a backstage fall last week, and a pinched nerve resulted.

title: Indiana, Rutgers Triumph
SPAIN DEVALUES CURRENCY BY 10%
description: MADRID, Feb. 9The Spanish Government, faced with speculation against the peseta and a stagnant economy, effectively devalued the currency today by 10 percent.

title: President Nominates Dixon To High Post in Treasury
TRIAL OF L.I. WOMAN IS SENT TO THE JURY
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 9A Nassau County jury started its deliberations today in the murder trial of Jo Anne Brown, who is charged with having shot and killed Burr C. Hollister, law secretary to a State Supreme Court Justice.

title: Sunbelt Still Stronghold Of Conservatism in US.
Lawyer for Peter Reilly Fails in Move To Query Prosecutor About Evidence
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn , Feb. 9A lawyer seeking a new trial for Peter Reilly in the murder of his mother two and a half years ago lost a key move today to put the State's Attorney on the witness stand so he could be questioned about allegedly suppressed evidence.

title: Rabin of Israel Beats Back Opposition Move to Unseat Him
ASSEMBLY VOTES BOND TAX REPEAL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9The Assembly, acting at the urging of city officials and Governor Carey, voted today to repeal the New York City bond transfer tax it voted into existence barely six months ago.

title: TRAVERS DEVLIN, 66, LED TRIAL LAWYERS
description: Travers F Devlin, a past president of the Manhattan Trial Lawyers Association, who was a City Councilman in 1961, died Sunday at his home, 120 Ovington Avenue, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Be was 66 years old.

title: Niger Asks for 200,000 Tons Of Emergency Food Supplies
STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in lighter trading.

title: Papp Starts $780,000 Drive for Delacorte
description: Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, announced yesterday the start of a campaign to raise $780,000 for the rehabilitation of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where millions of people have seen Shakespearean productions over the last 14 years.

title: Rep. Heinz Says Illegal Gifts From Gulf Oil Were Accepted Unintentionally
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) Representative H. John Heinz 3d said today that he received Illegal contributions from the Gulf Oil Corporation in 1971 and 1972, But he insisted they had been accepted unintentionally, and that there was no intent to deceive.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Bunche Memorial Plan at U.N. Cited
C.I.A. DATA ASKED BY TIMES AND CBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Washington Post said tonight that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency have claimed support of some top American news executives for the agency's refusal to give the Senate Intelligence Committee the names of the American news organizations and journalists who had worked with the C.I.A. in the past.

title: Advertising
description: With the cost of television commercial time generally increasing year by year, the question of clutter remains high in the minds of advertisers. Anything that detracts from their expensive communications is of concern to them and their agencies. The new flood of retail advertising is adding to this concern.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William Cahn, former District Attorney of Nassau County, went on trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn on charges of mail fraud in connection with the alleged double billing of the county and various law enforcement organizations for about $50,000 for trips to conventions and other meetings. A Jury of eight men and four women was selected, and opening defense and prosecution statements are scheduled for today. Mr. Cahn, who is 53 years old, faces separate trials later for perjury and tax evasion stemming from the same charges of double billing

title: SOLIAH LOSES PLEA TO SHIFT TRIAL SITE
TV: Two Documentaries on WNET
description: A discovery or, if you will, a confession: I appreciate a documentary most when it is least adorned with extraneous production values. Positive examples, in the purest sense, can be found in any of the films of Fred Wiseman. Negative ones are infinitely more common. Two are being shown on public television this week: last night's 690 Millennia: China's History Unearthed and tonight's The Animals Nobody Loved, a National Geographic special being presented at 8 o'clock.

title: As Fanciful Accessories, Some Evening Bags From India
description: At one time, the royalties of various countries carried no handbags, particularly in the evening.

title: H. R. MacMillan, Lumberman, Dead
News Summary and Index
CORRECTION
description: A United Press International dispatch from Geneva in The New York Times of Feb. 3 incorrectly quoted a message from the International Commission of Jurists to the President of Chile on measures being taken to protect suspects from torture at interrogation centers. The quotation in the dispatch sale There should be doctors at the centers and suspects should be held until all signs of mistreatment disappear. In each case, the the verb should be should have been are.

title: ARTHUR RYDSTROM OF BANKERS TRUST
description: Arthur G. Rydstrom, a former vice president of Bankers Trust Company who was the Denverbased senior vice president in 195357 of the Webb & Knapp Inc real estate concern, died Sunday in St Luke's Hospital in Denver. He was 70 years old

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOWNTOWN OASIS One of the few havens in the Wall Street area with regular aftersundown entertainment is La Bors Di Rom (2696180), where Michael Anthony sings and plays at the keyboard Tuesday through Friday. This is a friendly, informal place and a popular dropin spot for homebound workers. It was thronged the other evening with business people at the bar and couples, secretaries and a few loners at the tables.

title: Percy Faith Dead at 67;Conductor and Arranger
Sports News Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9Superior Court Judge John Benson, who has under advisement a temporary restraining order that prevents the completion of the sale of the San Francisco Giants to a group of businessmen Toronto, heard additional arguments and accepted affidavits today. After meeting with lawyers, Benson said he would need more time24 to 48 hoursto determine whether to drop the restraining order or to make permanent.

title: Challenge to Detente
description: The politics of a Presidential election year, superimposed on a long series of conflicts between the White House and Congress over everything from Vietnam to Angola, has eroded the basis for a bipartisan foreign policy. That backdrop of domestic division has not lessened the need to establish some consensus on how best to handle this country's troubled relations with the Soviet Union.

title: PROSOVIET FORCE TAKES ANGOLA CITY
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 9The central Angolan city of Huambo, where two Westernsupported nationalist movements proclaimed the establishment of a government last November, has fallen to Sovietsupplied Angolan forces led by Cuban troops.

title: Rutgers Freshman a Big Help
description: Jim Bailey jumped high enough to reach well over 10 feet, extended his hand back and over the rim and flipped a Princeton shot halfway up the court in the opening minute of Rutgers victory over the Tigers last week. The 6foot11inch Rutgers freshman's goaltending was obviousobvious to everyone except the officials, who did not call it.

title: LISBON IS WORRIED BY AZORES UNREST
ISIDOR GREENWALD; PROFESSOR AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr Isidor Greenwald, professor emeritus of binchemistry at the New York University, School of Medicine, died Saturday night in Roosevelt Hospital from cardiac and respiratory failure. Dr. Greenwald, who lived at 127 West 79th Street, was 88 years old.

title: Aldona Dvarionas, Pianist, Is Heard
description: Aldona Dvarionas concentrated on the Romantic tradition in her piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night, serving up works by Chopin, Liszt and Scriabin, as well as by her father, the Lithuanian composer and conductor Balys Dvarionas. Her technique and to a large extent her temperament were well suited to the limited program she chose

title: People in Sports
description: Tim Shaw of Long Beach, Calif., who holds world records in three freestyle swimming events, yesterday was named the winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy as the amateur athlete of the year.

title: Baseball Owners Will Keep Fighting Messersmith Decision
description: Baseball's club owners, convinced that somewhere in this baseball  minded land there is a court that will tell them they are right about the Andy Messersmith case, disclosed yesterday their intention to keep fighting. They disclosed nothing, however, about spring training.

title: CHARLES PARR, LED ELECTRIC COMPANY
Miss Hearst Says Captors Forced Her to Rob Bank
INQUIRY ORDERED IN L.I. BABY DEATH
description: RIVERHEAD, L I. Feb 9The Suffolk County Executive ordered his subordinates today to give hips a report on the circumstances surrounding the death of a 10monthold girl whose mother was charged today with fatally beating the child.

title: Zaire Truck Crash Kills 25
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 10 (Agence France  Presse)  A truck carrying men to work crashed off a road near here today, killing 25 persons and injuring dozens more. Witnesses said the driver had been going too fast and lost control of his vehicle.

title: Nitrates, Nitrites: Readers Speak Up
description: With attention having been drawn to the controversy over the treatment of meat products with sodium nitrate and sodium nitrite, which some scientists have listed as suspected cancercausing agents, it was natural that many people would wonder if these chemicals could be removed.

title: Canadian Lumber Industry Sees Peril to Its Exports
CORE SAYS BLACKS SIGN FOR ANGOLA
description: Roy Innis, director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday that CORE had recruited 300 black American veterans to go to Angola in midMarch to assist antiCommunist forces there as combat medics.

title: ASIAN TALKS END; SOME GAINS NOTED
description: PATTAYA, Thailand, Feb. 10 Five Southeast Asian Foreign Ministers wound up a twoday meeting here today with agreement on the broad outlines of a treaty of friendship and cooperation.

title: Sour Sugar ...
description: The latest disquieting disclosures from the internal files of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation strike at the heart of the international arms trade, that dubious traffic in which the United States has the questionable distinction of being number one. American national interests have been illserved by the operating practices of a company which exists today only by grace of a Federal bailout.

title: Stacy Gives Premieres on English Horn
description: The problem with any recital for an unusual instrument is the lack of suitable repertory. New works, eccentricities and transcriptions abound, with all the inevitable problems such byways entail.

title: Money
description: Prime rate 6 6.

title: DEADLINE IS NEAR ON RAIL TAKEOVER
description: The Chessie System and the Southern Railway must notify the United States Railway Association by midnight tonight whether they plan to take over some 3,500 miles of bankrupt Northeastern railroads If the two carriers fail to notify U.S.R.A., the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the Governmentsponsored successor to the Penn Central and several other bankrupt railroads, will be a 18,500mile system, rather than the 15,000mile project planned by the Government.

title: Rough Road in Italy
description: On its face, the Government that Prime Minister Moro is about to present in Italya minority Christian Democratic regime dependent for survival in Parliament on abstentions of Socialists and Republicansis among the weakest of the 38 administrations the country has had since the fall of Fascism. Yet, it must cope promptly with Italy's worst political crisis of conscience and one of its worst economic slumps of the postwar period.

title: Drought Sears Northeast Brazil
description: IRECE, BrazilThere were more than 5,000 peasant women in all, lined up in front of the emergency food post and stretching hundreds of yards down the dusty road that led back to the farmlands parched by drought.

title: Ben Travers Puts Farce in Its Place
description: LONDON, Feb. 10To be 89 years old and alive and well is nice enough. To be 89 years old and have two hits playing simultaneously to capacity crowds in London's West End is nicer still.

title: AN EXCBS WRITER IS LINKED TO C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A staff officer of the Central In telligence Agency worked in the mid1950's as a staff writer for CBS News in New York while he was serving as a deepcover intelligence operative, according to intelligence sources and past and present executives of CBS News.

title: Figure in Lockheed Case Denies Payment to Prince
description: GENEVA, Feb. 10A prominent Swiss lawyer Issued a denial today of allegations that he had served as an intermediary in payments by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands.

title: Law Students Find A Shortage of Jobs
description: Lawschool students; once considered sure to enter a giltedged profession, are graduating in record numbers and finding Increasingly that there are not enough jobs to go around.

title: Bomb Scare in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Feb. 10 (UPI)More than 600 people were evacuated today from a 14story building housing the United States Embassy after a telephone call saying six bombs had been planted in the building and were due to go off. Four truckloads of policemen arrived at the building to conduct a search but found nothing. The deadline passed without incident.

title: Soviet Plans to Expand Fishing Base in Canaries
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Feb. 10 (AP) The SpanishSoviet trade company Sovhispan announced today that it would build a $1 8 million complex in these Spanishcontrolled islands to serve Soviet fishing vessels based here.

title: USERY TAKES OFFICE AS LABOR SECRETARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)W. J. Usery Jr was sworn in a Secretary of Labor today, pledging to cooperate with both labor and management and carry out President Ford's program to create more jobs.

title: An L.I. Park Aide Indicted In OfficialCorruption Case
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 10The Deputy Commissioner of Parks and Recreation for the Town of Hempstead has been indicted on charges of illegally using Park Department personnel for the benefit of the state Republican committee. the District At torney announced today.

title: Rabies Kill 25 in Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 10 (Reuters)Twentyfive people have died after being bitten by rabid dogs in southwestern Tanzania during the last four months, the Government has announced. It said a total of 185 people had been bitten in the period. The announcement said an antirabies campaign in the area had been discontinued because ammunition to shoot rabid dogs was in short supply.

title: BILLION ARMS SALE TO SAUDIS SAID NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 10 (UPI) The United States and Saudi Arabia will announce a $12 billion arms agreement next week, Administration sources said today.

title: Student Is Raped at Yale; A Second Is Threatened
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 10A 26yearold Yale medical student was raped in an offcampus garage and an 18yearold freshman was threatened with rape in her dormitory suite here last night, three weeks after university officials began imposing the tightest security measures in the school's history.

title: Iran Deal Stirs Concern on Grumman's Inflow of Cash
When Love Blooms at the Water Cooler, Fewer Firms Throw Cold Water on It
description: Both John Cavaluolo and Ellen Roche were with First National City Bank, he a vice president, she a personnel officer, when they got married about a year ago. They still work for the bank, which not long ago would have been impossible.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The Book  of  the  Month Club advertises that people who buy through it will save time, energy and money, too. E. J. Korvette says that it sells its books at discounted prices, and Barnes & Noble proclaims that books on The New York Times bestseller list can be bought at cost.

title: 45 MERCENARIES BACK IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 10Fortyfive of 200 British mercenaries fighting in the Angolan civil war gave up their sixmonth contracts at $300 a week and flew home today amid reports of Britons killing Britons. Most had been in Angola two weeks.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, Feb. 10, 1976

title: Policing Construction
description: There is both merit and peril in a Beame administration bill, now before the City Council, which aims to eliminate what the city's Investigation Commissioner has called longstanding, systematic and pervasive corruption in building code enforcement here.

title: Battle Lost
description: Over the past ten yearsa period targeted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for global eradication of illiteracythe number of the world's illiterates has grown from 735 million to 800 million. The magnitude of that defeat in the battle against ignorance provides some measure of the efforts needed to lift vast untutored masses out of their present state of hopelessness and poverty.

title: Where I Stand
description: WASHINGTON  The upcoming Presidential campaign will not be decided by a candidate's bankroll, by the gleam of his smile, or by the size of his political organization. It will be decided, as it should be, by his stand on the issues and by his competence to deal with them.

title: Swiss Programs Seeking To Pump Up Slow Economy
description: BERN, Feb 10 (Agence FrancePresseThe Swiss Government has presented a new program totaling about $470 million to stimulate economic growth.

title: Israelis Pull Back in Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 10 (UPI) Israeli troops have withdrawn from forward positions in Sinai 11 days before the positions are scheduled to be turned over to United Nations forces under the interim agreement with Egypt, the Defense Ministry said today. The evacuated area will serve as a United Nations buffer zone between the Egyptian and Israeli armies.

title: U.S., Poland Draw In Wrestling, 66
description: WARSAW, Fee. 10 (AP) The United States and Poland drew, 66, today in a freestyle wrestling match in central Poland. The best performance of the night was by Wade Schalles of Clarion, Pa, who pinned Leszek Radom at 163 pounds.

title: Starr's Shrinkage Plan for City Slums Is Denounced
Leathers of Israel For Men of Style
description: With the Versailles Room of the St. Regis Hotel as the setting and with the modeling assistance of a couple of Broadway stars, BegedOr, the Israeli leather specialist, turned loose its first men's wear collection the other day.

title: Expense Budget Scored At School Board Hearing
description: The Board of Education's proposed expense budget for 197677, calling for an increase of $435 million over the city's current school appropriation, was sharply criticized at a public hearing yesterday.

title: Proposed Ban on Handguns Killed by House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) The House Judiciary Committee today lulled legislation that would have imposed a nationwide ban on all handguns except for those owned by the police and certified gun clubs.

title: FORD SETS REVIEW OF BRIBES ABROAD BY U.S. COMPANIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Ford ordered today a review of bribery and other illegal activities by American corporations and executives in foreign countries, an order that could lead to Federal sanctions against offending companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times Monday erroneously described the Harvard Crimson as the nation's oldest daily college newspaper. The Yale Daily News, founded in 1878, claims that honor. Although the Crimson traces its lineage to 1873, it was not published as a daily at that time.

title: The High Cost of Being Human
description: Another annual cycle inevitably passed and the pain was eased by a humorous birthday card. The front bore the caption, According to biochemists the materials that make up the human body are only worth 97c.

title: A New Jerry Rubin: Grown Up, Reflective
description: The telephone rang: Hi, this is Jerry Rubin. A pause. Do you know who I am?

title: Retail Store Sales Registered Decline In January From Levels of December
Clothes Aid for Guatemala
description: The Salvation Army, which has been designated by the Guatemalan Government to distribute clothes to earthquake victims, is accepting contributions. They should be addressed: Earthquake, Salvation Army. 50 West 23d Street, New York 10010.

title: Grant Adjudication As Bankrupt Urged
description: The demise of the W. T. Grant company appeared imminent yesterday after 70 years of existence.

title: MERGER APPROVED FOR JERSEY BANKS
description: The merger of the Springfield State Bank of Springfield, N. J., into the United Counties Trust Company of Elizabeth, N. J. has been approved, Paul A. Volcker, president and chief executive officer of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, announced last night.

title: Books of The Times
Borg and Riessen Victors in Toronto
description: TORONTO, Feb. 10 (UPI) Topseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden overcame a shaky start and defeated Geoff Masters of Australia, 64, 63, in the opening round of the Canadian stop on the World Championship Tennis tour

title: Negligence Barred in Starvation Death
description: A Rockland County grand jury that had been investigating the death of a 65yearold resident of an adult home reported yesterday that it had brought no Indictments against the home's owners, according to the Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz.

title: Peking Banquet Sheds No Light On New Changes in Leadership
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 10In a move that did little to clarify the confusion in the outside world over China's current leadership, the country's secondranking deputy prime minister held a banquet in Peking tonight for the visiting head of Australia's proChinese Communist Party.

title: Council Considering Making It Illegal To Drink in Street
description: While public drunkenness hasn't been a punishable offense in the city since Jan 1, drinking in the street would become one under a bill the City Council probably will pass in its next General Session.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BERN, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  A Swiss Defense Ministry inquiry has found no evidence of payoffs by the Northrop Corporation to Swiss officials to win a contract for 72 F5E Tiger jets, a parliamentary committee said today

title: RUSSIANS REBUFF CRITICS OF FARMS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10  The newspaper Pravda today accused Western critics of distorting the Soviet Union's economic situation and particularly its agricultural problems in the wake of the country's worst harvest in a decade.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 10 (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today and hit a fivemonth low in Tokyo. Gold also fell.

title: Top U.S. Official Defends the Safety Of Indian Pt. Plant
description: William A. Anders, chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said yesterday that there was no reason to suspend operation of the Indian Point No 2 nuclear power plant on the Hudson, as a resigning safety official of the commission had urged.

title: DR. CECIL C. GLOSTER
description: Dr Cecil C. Gloster, an obstetrician and gynecologist affiliated with four Brooklyn hospitals, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, while driving He was 59 years old and lived at 37 West 12th Street

title: A French Chef Makes Magic in an L.I. Kitchen
description: LAST HAMPTON, L.I.&3x2014;In the world of gastronomy, noholy in America is outdoing the French when it comes to commemorating the Bicentennial. A few weeks ago the. outfit known as Food and Wines from France staged a luncheon presided over by the Count Philippe de Lafayette, a descendant of the French rebel who aided the American cause. The dessert for the occasion was coupe Jefferson.

title: The Reign in Spain: I
description: MADRIDMore has changed in Spain during the two months since Generalissimo Franco's death than is generally realized either here or abroad. Not only has the monarchy been restored but it is deliberately seeking to establish itself as an institution rather than the credo of one man, as Francoism was regarded.

title: Members Quit as Club Keeps Ban on Blacks
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 10 (UPI)Dr. Frank L. Hereford Jr, president of the University of Virginia; former Gov. Colgate W. Darden Jr. and several others resigned today from the Farmington Country Club after the club affirmed its segregated, whites only policy.

title: Bridge:
Bentsen Abandons Presidential Race
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 10Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas withdrew. today from the 1976 Presidential race, saying that it would not be useful or productive to continue because of his poor showing in the early caucuses.

title: Nixon Visit Symbolic to Chinese
JACK CURNOW
description: Jack Curnow, who had been the outdoor editor of The Los Angeles Times for nearly 20 years, beginning in 1940, died Monday in Huntington Beach. Calif. He was 67 year, old and lived in Santa Ana.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island will be able to park their cars today on both sides of streets where alternate sideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The regulations are being suspended to speed snow removal. In Manhattan, however, the rules will be in effect. All other parking and standing restrictions still apply throughout the city.

title: 144th Strategic Arms Talks
description: GENEVA. Feb. 10 (UPI) United States and Soviet negotiators met for two hours and 35 minutes today in the 144th session of the new round of talks on strategicarms limitation. The next meeting was scheduled for Friday

title: Ford Is Only Republican In the Vermont Primary
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Wednesday, Feb. 10Four Democrats and one RepublicanPresident Fordfiled to run in Vermont's Presidential primary before the deadline last midnight.

title: Leftist Forces in Angola Say They Have Taken 2 Seaports
description: LUANDA, Angola, Feb. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  Sovietsupported Angolan forces announced today that they had taken two key Atlantic ports from their Westernbacked rivals in their continued offensive in the center of the country.

title: PROF. JOSEPH BABOR OF CITY COLLEGE, 80
description: Joseph A Babor, a retired City College chemistry professor, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital, Middletown, Conn He was 80 years old and a resident of Middletown

title: WINE TALK
description: A big department store in Texas offered as the perfect Christmas gift a working chateau in the Sauternes region of France, Price: $800,000.

title: 44 Federal Judges to Sue For Pay Lost to Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  In a highly unusual departure from judicial tradition, 44 Federal judges plan to sue the United States tomorrow for a pay increase.

title: Drought Indicated Over the Corn Belt By Apparently Low Sunspot Activity
description: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 10There are disturbing signs that the Great Plains and western cornbelt states are caught in another period of low sunspot activity, which in the past has coincided with extreme drought in this area.

title: TV: Lanford Wilson's Mound Builders Is an Ambitious and Puzzling Play
description: The Mound Builders is Lanford Wilson's most ambitious play. Unfortunately, at least as presented on public television's Theater in America tonight at 9, it is also one of his more disappointing efforts.

title: Market Place
description: Stung by criticism of their methods by orthodox money managers, the operators of index portfolio investment funds are striking back with criticism of their own.

title: U.S. Radiation Report Worries Foreign Diplomats in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10Reports of potentially harmful microwaveradiation related to Soviet eavesdropping devices in the American embassy here have caused concern among diplomats from other countries, who fear that their embassies might have similar problems.

title: Salade Andre Grimaud
description: (Salad with port wine dressing, foie gras and truffles)

title: 2 Britons Accused of Role In Iranian Sugar Scandal
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  Two executives from Britain's Tate & Lyle Company, Ltd. weer named today by an official source here as involved in a sugar scandal with two Iranian officials who are to be charged.

title: Strategy Smooth as a Swiss Movement
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 10The Swiss delivered a surprising onetwo punch in the giant slalom on an unusually icy course today while the Italians were busy ducking too closely around gates and the Austrians seemed intent on backing away from them.

title: About Real Estate
description: In a matter of weeks, the aerial tramway to Roosevelt Island will be in operation. It will take passengers from Second Avenue at 60th Street on a fiveminute trip over the East River to what the state Urban Development Corporation calls Manhattan's Other Island.

title: New Welfare Cases Checked
description: A review of 684 new cases of aid to families with dependent children opened by the Westchester County Department of Social Services during a fivemonth period discovered that in 2 percent of the cases the new recipients were ineligible to receive aid, according to, Charles W. Bates, the commissioner of the department.

title: Elizabeth French Hitchcock, 63, A Civic Leader Here, Is Dead
description: Elizabeth French Hitchcock. a civic leader here for many years, died at her Manhattan home on Monday. She was 63 years old.

title: White House Gaining in Debate on Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Even before the Congressional hearings are completed, the Ford Administration appears to be winning the annual debate on the defense budget with its gument that the United States must counter a growth in Soviet military power.

title: Revival of Coast Crab Crop Brings Delight and Discontent
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 There's an avalanche of Dungeness crabs pouring out of the Pacific Ocean these days, delighting the palates of crab fanciers, and causing both a boom and discontent among fishermen who thought the Dungeness had all but disappeared at sea.

title: Crime Wave Appearance of New Data Is Illusory
HOUSE HEARS ROTH ON BANK FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Arthur T. Roth, founder of New York's Franklin National Bank and its head until he was forced to resign in 1968, testified today that he repeately warned Federal banking regulators that policies followed by his successors were driving the bank toward disaster but that the Government took virtually no remedial action.

title: Holtz of N.C. State Is Signed To 5Year Pact as Jet Coach
ITALY'S TOP PARTY FORMING CABINET; LONG CRISIS ENDS
description: ROME, Feb. 10Italy's latest political crisis ended today with a decision to form a oneparty minority cabinet of only Christian Democrats.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Wrap it up. Pull it on. Let it flow. The new summer clothes rarely button or zip. They tie or they float.

title: About New York;
description: The man wore dark blue velvet pants, a pale blue shirt, an even paler blue belt and a wide blue tie. There was a picture of Bugs Bunny on the pocket of the shirt; there was a picture of Bugs Bunny on the tie. Eh, what's up, Doc? the man said, and naturally the voice belonged to Bugs Bunny. The man said he thought cartoons today were lousy.

title: ExNassau Prosecutor Goes on Trial
description: The present and a former Comptroller of Nassau County testified in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday that they did not know that the former Nassau County District Attorney, William Calm, was collecting for expenses both from outside organizations and from the county

title: Saigon Forms Bus Company For Service With the North
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 10 (Reuters)A bus company has been formed to run between North and South Vietnam, the South Vietnam press agency, Giai Phong, reports.

title: BOOK SCREENING BY U.S. IS ENDED
description: The State Department has withdrawn a requirement that members of cultural exchange tours it sponsors submit any writings for clearance, and now says that changing concerns and sensibilities make the requirement a historic anomaly.

title: Article 1  No Title
Argentina Seeks Killers Of Kinswoman of Lanusse
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 10 (UPI)  The police began a search today for the killers of the daughterinlav of Alejandro Lanusse, the former President. The woman died in a bomb explosion at her family's downtown apartment.

title: Vital Road in Guatemala Cut by Quake
description: EL PROGRESO, Guatemala, Feb. 10Adobe walls crumbled, the roofs collapsed, and wooden beams crashed down. More than 700 people, perhaps more than a thousand, died underneath it all in this town in last Wednesdays earthquake.

title: President Departing At Carter Products
description: After just a little over year on the job Fred L. Lemont is out as president of the Carter Products division of CarterWallace, the company confirmed yesterday.

title: U.S. Third in Men's Speed Skating, Wins in Hockey; Swiss Skiing Victor
NEW BASQUE KILLING SECOND IN TWO DAYS
description: MADRID, Feb. 10The second killing in the Basque country in two days occurred today in the town of Cizurquil, near San Sebastian, when a 37yearold mechanic was shot in what was believed to be a case of Mistaken identity.

title: U.N. Panel Asserts Chile Is Continuing Repressive Actions
Goodyear's 4thQuarter Profit Rose by 26.7% Above '74 Level
A Challenge in Manhattan: Storing Wine
description: It's become increasingly popular as an apritif, and to a lot of people a meal isn't complete without it. But where, oh where, in the confined space of most Manhattan apartments, does one store wine?

title: Migration Mixes a New Southern Blend
description: NEW ORLEANS  Many Northerners used to think of the states below the 37th parallel as a vast Dogpatch fit only for the nation's amusement and contempt.

title: Food Costs Here Show Slight Rise
description: Food prices in the New York area's retail food stores remained almost unchanged last week, with the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City advancing only 0.2 percent on the week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The attorney for Robert (Sonny) Carson and four other defendants won a delay for the start of his clients prison sentences stemming from a Nassau County conviction on kidnapping and attemptedmurder charges. Judge Bernard Tomson in Nassau County Court adjourned the execution of sentences of Mr. Carson and the others until Feb. 19, while the lawyer, Charles E. Moser, reapplies for a stay of sentence to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court If the adjournment had not been made, all five would have been sent to the Green Haven Correctional Facility in Stormville, N.Y

title: 2 Southerners Will Vie in South Carolina
State Transportation Head Warns of Decayed Roads
description: ALBANY. Feb. 10The State Transportation Commissioner, Raymond T. Schuler, told the Legislature today that a steady deterioration of state highways could be expected because of inadequate maintenance funds under the Transportation Departments austerity budget.

title: Miss Hearst Is Challenged By Man She Held Captive
U.S. JUDGE ALTERS HIS STAND ON BIAS
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10A Federal judge whose decision is the basis for major Supreme Court review on the issue of reverse discrimination has changed his original decision and ruled that the United States Constitution provides protection for whites, as well as members of minority groups, against discrimination

title: Habeas Corpus to Close
description: Alan Bennett's Habeas Corpus will end its run at the Martin Beck Theater after Sun day's matinee. The comedy, costarring Jean Marsh, Rachel Roberts, June Havoc, Paxton Whitehead and Celeste Holm, will have given a total of 95 performances It was produced by James M. Nederlander, Victor Lurie and Michael Codron.

title: People and Business
description: Sidney L. Jones, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Affairs, predicted yesterday that the decline in interest rates would continue further in the next few months.

title: Emily Harris Angry at Denial By Miss Hearst of Love Affair
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP) Emily Harris said she was angered by Patricia Hearst's denial of a meaningfull love affair fith William Wolfe.

title: Juror in Payola Trial Out for Smiling to Star
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10 (AP) A woman juror in a Federal payola trial was dismissed yesterday after she leaned over the railing separating the Jury from the audience, smiled, and mirthfully asked for an autograph from Marshall Thompson, a rock singer in court as a prosecution witness.

title: Reducing Oil imports
description: Although the oil industry has insisted that the United States will become increasingly dependent on imported oil as a result of the passage of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act rolling back crude oil prices, the Federal Energy Administration is far more optimistic that President Ford's goal of reducing on imports to less than 5 million barrels per day by 1985 can be met.

title: Boston Lawyer to Defend Cleaver at Trial on Coast
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 10 George V. Higgins, the Boston lawyer who wrote the bestselling novel The Friends of Eddie Coyle, said in Superior Court here today that he would represent Eldridge Cleaver, the former Black Panther official, at his murder trial later this year.

title: Population Over Age 65 Up 2.5 Million Since '70
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)The nation's elderly population has grown by 2.5 million since 1970, according to new Census Bureau estimates.

title: Rangers Recall Maloney
description: The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League recalled Dave Maloney, a 19 yearold defenseman, from Providence of the American League yesterday. He replaces Gilles Marotte, who will be sidelined for a week to 10 days with a badly bruised ankle.

title: House Committee Revives A Controversial Trust Bill
description: WASHING1ON, Feb. 10A controversial antitrust bill killed last year by heavy lobbying by business, was revived today in the House Rules committee.

title: Thomas Curtis Van Cleve; Bowdoin Historian, 87, Dies
description: BRUNSWICK. Me., Feb. 10 Professor Thomas Curtis Van Cleve, historian and retired senior member of the Bowdoin College faculty, died in the Regional Memorial Hospital here today. He was 87 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DIGGING IN The enterprising Adventure on a Shoestring, a New Yorkbased group specializing in visits to picturesque places and interesting people, departs this morning at 9 45 o'clock on the first excursion of its 13th seasona trip to the Edison National Historic Site in West Orange, N.J. The meeting place for the bus ride is the northeast corner of 41st Street and Eighth Avenue. The $6 attendance fee includes roundtrip fare and admission.

title: People in Sports
description: Oscar Charleston, a longtime star and manager in the Negro Leagues, became the 157th player selected to the baseball Hall of Fame yesterday. Charleston, who resembled Babe Ruth with his bandy legs and big belly, played from 1915 until 1944, when he was 48 years old, and managed until 1954, when he died. He is the seventh player selected by the special committee on the Negro Leagues.

title: Decline Continues In Potato Futures
Carey Asserts Gains Have Been Made To Save State Construction Agencies
description: Albany, Feb. 10Governor Carey's office said today it was close to saving the troubled state construction agencies from default this month and that it had achieved significant movement and progress in the drive to keep them solvent for the next three years.

title: ANGOLAN AID BAN SIGNED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  President Ford signed a $112.3 billion defense appropriations bill today, although he said that Congress had lost their guts by including in the measure a ban on further aid to the forces in the Angola civil war opposing the faction supported by the Soviet Union and Cuba.

title: COURT ISSUES STAY IN THE ROTHKO CASE
House Intelligence Study Ends; Panel Urges Reins on Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The House Intelligence Committee completed its yearlong investigation today by giving final approval to a package of sweeping recommendations for controls over United States intelligence operations. The recommendations were approved on a vote of 9 to 5.

title: Dr. Norman H. Gardner. ExOfficial of A.M.A., 66
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn, Feb. 10Dr. Norman H. Gardner of East Hampton, Conn., a national vice president 01 the American Medical Association in 1962, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital here at the age of 66

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Major league baseball will go to court again, appealing last week's Kansas City court decision upholding the arbitration award of freeagent status to two pitchers, Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally.

title: Turk Postpones U.S. Visit, Dimming Hope on Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Chances for an early agreement on United States military bases in Turkey faded today when a scheduled visit to Washington by Turkey's Foreign Minister, Ihsan S. Caglayangil, was postponed at the last minute.

title: French Weigh Niger's Plea for Food Aid
description: PARIS, Feb. 10A ranking official said today that an urgent request from the Central African country of Niger for food and money was being examined here with attention.

title: U.S. STEEL OFFERS STOCK SPLIT PLAN
description: The United States Steel Corporation said its board had approved for submission to stockholders at the annual meeting a proposal that the company's common stock be split 3 for 2. The meeting is scheduled for May 3 at Atlanta.

title: REAGAN BIDS U.S. EXPLOIT MISSILE
description: EXETER, N.H., Feb. 10In his first major foreign policy speech of the campaign, Ronald Reagan charged today that the United States lacked a coherent global view, a condition that had created confusion among its allies and encouraged the Soviet Union to push for military superiority.

title: Democrats in House Drop U.S. Election Counsel Plan
VISITOR IS KILLED AT BUSCH ESTATE
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (UPI) The 20yearold son of August A. Busch Jr., the brewery executive, was showing a .357 magnum revolver to a longtime family friend when it accidentally discharged early today, striking the man In the face and killing him, the police said.

title: Times and CBS Deny Backing C.I.A. Refusal to Name Reporters
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Executives of The New York Times and CBS Inc. denied today that they had expressed to George Bush, the Director of Central Intelligence, support for the C.I.A.'s refusal to give senators the names of journalfists who had worked for the agency in the past.

title: Notes on People
Substantial Raise Asked as Talks Start on Transit Pact
description: The Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority began critical negotiations yesterday for a new contract. The talks, which came at a time of rising costs and fiscal constraint, could set a pattern for other city negotiations this year and also provide a test for the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: CONGRESSMEN MOVE TO BAN CONCORDE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 10 (UPI) Congressmen moved today to ban the Concorde supersonic jetliner from Kennedy International Airport in New York, but Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. told Congress that he still believed the airliner should have 16 months of trial flights

title: Carey Names 5 Members To State's History Board
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP) Governor Carey has appointed five members to the State Board of Historic Preservation, Including Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the Pulitzerprize winning historian.

title: Winter Wheat Crop Continues to Shrink
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that the nation's winter wheat crop had continued to deteriorate because of drought in the Great Plains. Growers in Kansas, the top producing state, say their 1976 harvest will be the smallest in eight years.

title: Piperade
description: (A tomato and pepper dish)

title: BANKS IN LEBANON REOPEN TOMORROW
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb 10 (UPI)The military committee supervising the ceasefire today ordered additional security measures in preparation for the reopening of Beirut's banks on Thursday.

title: Ibis Jets South to Recover
description: SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla , Feb. 10A young glossy ibis found shivering in the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge near Kennedy International Airport Just before Christmas is due to be released tomorrow in the Ding Darling National Wildlife Refuge on this island off the southwest coast of Florida, after a 1,500mile plane trip for the bird, which, somehow missed out on the normal fall migration.

title: Prices on Amex And OTC Climb In Active Session
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in active trading.

title: Deterioration at Lefrak City Is Reported Being Turned Around
description: The problems of racial change and physical deterioration at Lefrak City in Queens are being turned around, the City Human Rights Commission said yesterday.

title: Anguilla Celebrates New Charter
description: THE VALLEY, Anguilla, Feb. 10 (AP)This tiny Caribbean island celebrated the end of a nineyear fight today with the inception of a new Constitution that makes It a selfgoverning British territory.

title: Women's League Issues A Directory of Officials
description: The 1976 edition of They Represent You, a directory of all national state and local officials elected by New York City voters and currenty in office, has been issued by the League of Women Voters.

title: Small Private Colleges Create Group To Win Sympathy and Public Funds
U.S. Helicopters at Work in Guatemala As Quake Relief Effort Gains Momentum
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 10The emergency relief operation for victims of last week's earthquakes gained momentum today when two huge United States Army helicopters began ferrying tons of food and medicine into devastated zones north of this capital.

title: Hockey Victory Spurs Medal Hopes
About Education
DOMTAR LTD. RAISING PRICE OF NEWSPRINT
description: Domtar Ltd, announced yesterday that it was raising the price of its newsprint in the United States and Canada by. $25 a ton effective March 1. The new price for 30pound newsprint is $285 a ton in the United States and $271 a ton in Canada. The Increase is similar to those announced recently by several other Canadian producers.

title: Scandal Costs Lockheed $ 1.3 Billion Sale to Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 10The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has lost a $1.3 billion order for new airplanes here because of its involvement in a payoff scandal, Japanese Government officials said today. Japan's defense agency, they said, tentatively planned to buy about 100 of Lockheed's P3C Orion antisubmarine aircraft, worth $13 million each, but has now changed its plans.

title: Dances Are Shared By Francis Petrelle And Randolyn Zinn
description: Aside from a genial studiousness, there was little to commend the choreographic designs of Francis Petrelle and Randolyn Zinn as they shared a program Monday evening at the Cubiculo. Their four pieces had a quiet logicbeginning, developing and endingthough. without ever striking a special creative spark.

title: Move to Reject Reilly Bid For New Trial Dismissed
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 10 Lawyers seeking a new murder trial for Peter Reilly abruptly rested their case in Superior Court here today after presenting five weeks of testimony and 39 witnesses.

title: Knicks' 227 Burst Near End Sends Bucks to 10497 Defeat
Yonkers Names City Manager; Castaldo Will Be 4th in 2 Years
description: YONKERS, Feb 10Yonkers today found a new City Manager, its fourth in two years He is Vincent Castaldo, deputy city manager for the last four years.

title: Carter's Campaign Is Producing a Broad Range of Impressions
A CONCERT HELPS NEEDIEST CASES
description: The second annual concert of medieval and Renaissance music was performed by the Kensington Ensemble in the lobby of an apartment building at 25 Parade Place, Brooklyn, as a benefit for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. It produced a gift of $95 from residents.

title: BOTTOM LINE SHOW BY RORY GALLAGHER
description: Rory Gallagher, the Irish bluesrock guitarist and singer, packed them into the Bottom Line for his twonight run that ended Monday. But that's not too surprising since Mr. Gallagher, who hadn't been to New York for about 1 years, was accustomed to playing such larger spots as the Felt Forum and the Schaefer Music Festival.

title: Shumate Paces Braves' Victory
$16 Misunderstanding
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (Reuters)It was not exactly a mistake of Olympian proportions, but nevertheless a little embarrassing to the White House.

title: The Use of Estrogen as a Growth Inhibitor in OverTall Girls Is Being Questioned
description: With estrogen and the reported risks it may carry for postmenopausal women now a matter of deep medical concern, questions are being raised about a littleknown use of the female hormone to control growth in overly tall young girls.

title: St. John's Wins At Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I , Feb. 10 (UPI)  Frank Alagia and Cecil Rellford sparked a 10 point spree in the closing four minutes tonight to pace 18thrated St. John's University to a 5647 victory over the University of Rhode Island.

title: City Forms First Cultural Affairs Agency
description: In a short ceremony at City Hall yesterday, Mayor Beame signed into law a bill establishing the city's first Department of Cultural Affairs, an agency separated from the former Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration. The Department of Parks and Recreation was also designated as a separate entity.

title: Secretive Ballot
description: New York State's local election boards are gearing up for a costly exercise in futility next April 6 unless the Legislature acts promptly to correct an election law absurditya Presidential primary ballot that does not bear the names of Presidential candidates.

title: GUIDELINES NEAR ON GENE STUDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The longsought goal of rules to govern a revolutionary and potentially dangerous type of genetics research came an important step closer to reality today as a twoday meeting of experts ended at the National Institutes of Health.

title: State Audit Accuses City Of Overclaims on Welfare
description: Stephen Berger, the state's Commissioner of Social Services, accused the city's Department of Social Services yesterday of alarming shortcomings in its accounting processes, declaring that a single month's city claims had led to $89.5 million in overpayments in state and Federal funds.

title: Carey Nominates Nun
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP) Governor Carey today announced the nomination of Sister Lorraine Reilly to the board of visitors of the Bronx Psychiatric Center. Sister, Lorraine is executive director of GLIE Community Youth Program Inc. and has taught emotionally disturbed children for several years. She is secretary of the Bronx Federation of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services.

title: Lakeland Terrier Is Judged Best at Westminster Show
description: The form held true at Madison Square Garden last night as the Westminster Kennel Club's centennial show came to a close with a Lakeland terrier named best of 3,098 dogs.

title: Rosemary Harris Carries It Off With Repertory of Stage and Life
description: Rosemary Harris, whose card, if any, at central casting must surely be a clutter of irreconcilable contradictions, plays her life as though she were doing repertory.

title: Broadcasts Aid the Elderly
description: Radio programs providing information for the elderly on housing, health, employment and other matters of interest in Westchester County will be broadcast at 9:35 P.M. on Sundays on Station WFAS and at 7 A.M. every other Saturday on Station WWYDFM, according to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: The Theater: Cracks
State Board Putting Elish In Charge of Budget Cuts
description: City and state sources reported yesterday that the state's Emergency Financial Contol Board would soon take a more direct hand in controlling school and hospital budget cuts by putting Herbert Elish, the board's chief administrator, directly in charge of the controversial task.

title: Mix Them All Together for a Winter Weekend of Fun
description: PAWLING, N.Y.Take a retired seaman, a lawyer and an actuary. Add a teacher or so, a school psychologist and maybe a geologist. Mix lightly with a few secretaries, accountants or salespeople. Stir in a liberal amount of maturty and a dash of youth. Sprinkle with a waggish sense of humor and some quiet intellectualism. Place all in an atmosphere of tolerance and good fellowship. And bind together with a consuming passion.

title: Monday's Fights
description: PARISLoucif Hamana, 158 pounds, Algeria, outpointed Emile Griffith, 158, New York, 10 rounds

title: Poulets Rotis a la Piperade et Sauce Moutarde
description: (Roast chicken with piperade and mustard sauce)

title: Islanders 32 Losers To Canucks
Olympic Games Average 35% of the TV Audience
description: The Olympic Games were among last week's most popular television programs, attracting an average of 35 percent of the audience for the 10 hours of coverage in prime time from Wednesday through Sunday. Four of the five nights of coverage placed among the top 20 shows in the week's Nielsen ratings.

title: Dutch Trial Opens in Plane Bribery Case
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 10The former Dutch reprsentative of the French National Office for Aeronautic Exports pleaded not guilty today in an Amsterdam court to charges that he had offered bribes to two Dutch Members & Parliament in an attempt to sell the Dassault Mirage jet to the Dutch Goverment.

title: FED ACTS TO DRAIN BANK RESERVES
description: The Federal Reserve on two occasions yesterday acted to drain reserves temporarily from the banking system. The Fed's move, which was no surprise to professional participants, appeared to contribute to a slight settling of prices in the credit markets, but did not affect a generally good reception to the day's new offerings.

title: G.M. Vehicles Recalled
description: DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP)The General Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 3,575 automobiles and motor homes in separate campaigns to correct problems involving the automobile transmission and the motor homes steering systems. The company said the recall affects 3,000 currentmodel Oldsmobile Cutlasses and Buick Regals, Centurys, Le Sabres and Electras. The other recall involves 575 G M C. motor homes.

title: Incendiary Bomb in Belfast Ruins a Protestant Center
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 (UPI)An incendiary bomb planted by two gunmen today gutted the headquarters of the Loyal Orange Order, a symbol of Protestantism in Northern Ireland.

title: NEW JOBS MEASURE IS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 10 (UPI) With President Ford threatening to veto one bill designed to provide jobs for the unemployed, the House passed today a second one, which backers said would provide 600,000 jobs.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Until now, the only Lou Holtz many New Yorkers knew was the 80yearold dialect comedian who told Yiddish jokes about Sam Lapidus, his fictional fall guy Lou Holtz put the blame on Sam Lapidus for everything. But now the New York Jets have hired another Lou Holtz as their new head coach This one is 39 years old, short and slim at 5 feet 10 Inches and 150 pounds, the resident football intellect and amateur magician at North Carolina State, where his teams made four consecutive bowl appear ances in his four seasons there If he can guide the Jets Into the Super Bowl within his fiveyear contract, he'll really be a magician. And yesterday he appeared among the mounted heads of animals in the secondfloor Hunt Room of the 21 Club, one floor down from where Charley Winner was introduced three years ago. Coiffed in a blond mod cut, Lou Holtz wore black hornrimmed glasses, a vested charcoal gray suit that had arrived in the mail last week from a Knoxville, Tenn., tailor, a white shirt with a red and black tie, a quick smile, a quick mind and a quick wit. Instead of blaming Sam Lapidus, he blamed has father for his name.

title: Tijuana Mud Slides Kill 2
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Feb. 10 (UPI)Mud slides today swept away 40 shanties, constructed mostly of cardboard, wood and flattened cans. A mother and her infant son were killed.

title: DEMOCRATS WIN SPECIAL ELECTIONS
description: Democratic candidates won two special elections yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens, retaining seats in the State Legislature long held by members of their party.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL,

title: ADOLPH F. PAULI
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 10Adolph F. Pauli, a professor of classics emeritus at Wesleyan University, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Shift by Administration Seen On Bid to Raise Aid to Israel
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 10The Ford Administration seemed today to dampen its previous support for Congressional efforts to increase foreign aid authorization in such a way as to give Israel an additional $556 million in military and economic assistance this year.

title: Black History Month Is Supported by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)President Ford issued a statement today urging Americans to join in observing February as Black History Month.

title: Mighty Winches Lift Old Tug From Muck
description: At 12:15 yesterday, the water off Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport began to churn and gurgle. The winches of the floating derrick Century started to pull, and the 77yearold steam tug Mathilda rose through the murky waters into which she sank mysteriously two weeks ago.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PROFESSOR SCORES ARABS AND SOVIET
description: A philosophy professor told scholars yesterday that the Arabs and the Soviet Union were deliberately trying to bring about the systematic theft of the Holocaust by saying that Arabs today were victims of persecution by Jews in much the same way that Jews had been victims of the Nazis in World War II.

title: The Drinks Go Down Quicker Than the Skiers at Hunter Mountain
description: HUNTER, N.Y.To one too long in city pent, but not fond of snow plows and long lift lines either, there remains the skiing weekend, complete with no skiing.

title: Substantial Rise in Smoking by TeenAge Girls Is Found in Survey
description: Cigarette smoking has increased substantially among teenage girls in the last six years, with 27 percent of girls 13 through 17 years old now smoking and 4 in 10 smokers using at least one pack a day according to the findings of a survey conducted for the American Cancer Society.

title: ABORTION DISPUTE TROUBLING BAYH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Although the abortion issue could hurt several Presidential aspirants, and may have helped former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter to his initial victory in Iowa Democratic caucuses, it is a peculiarly personal and persistent problem for Indiana Senator Birch Bayh.

title: Union Seminary's 13th President Is Installed
description: Dr. Donald W. Shriver Jr., a 48yearold Presbyterian minister and scholar, was formally installed last evening as the Union Theological Seminary's 13th president.

title: 3 Concerns Reported Seeking Purchase of Ailing W.T. Grant
description: Three major corporations emerged yesterday as potential buyers of the financially troubled W. T. Grant Company as a Federal court here heard arguments on a petition to liquidate the giant retail concern.

title: NIXON MOVE ON COX LINKED TO BREZHNEV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) President Richard M. Nixon told resigning Attorney General Elliot T. Richardson during the socalled Saturday night massacre of 1973 that the Sovit leadership would never understand it if the Watergat prosecutor were not dismissed.

title: 'Gable and Lombard' Revives Cliches
description: "Gable and Lombard," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is a fan-magazine movie with the emotional zap of a long-lost Louella Parsons column. It's the somewhat reworked, no longer exclusive story of the Hollywood courtship and marriage of Clark Gable and Carole Lombard in the late 1930's and early 40's.They meet for the first time at one of those screwball parties Hollywood was apparently noted for, an afternoon party where everyone is dressed in evening clothes. Clark refuses to wear what was then known as a "soup-and-fish." He's a rugged individualist. So is Carole, who arrives by ambulance and wrecks Clark's car. They fight. He threatens to spank her. She knocks him down with a punch to the jaw.It's love, of course. At first it's a back-street kind of love (he's married), full of the tensions created by career conflicts, public relations duties and a benign Louis B. Mayer, the true king of M-G-M who doesn't want Clark's career damaged by scandal.But it is also full of precious, golden moments, stolennay snatchedfrom the hurly-burly of Hollywood stardom. They go fishing together. They play practical jokes on each other and though the jokes don't seem very funny to us, we can be pleased that the funnybones of Gable and Lombard are in their ankles. They laugh a lot, and fight, and make up. Through all this we know what they don't know: that the fun-loving, life-loving, beautiful Carole is not long for this world. You might say that theirs was a love stalked by tragedythat is, if you adopted the style of this film.As written by Barry Sandler and directed by Sidney J. Furie, "Gable and Lombard" recalls not "Gone With the Wind," "Honky Tonk," "Twentieth Century," "Nothing Sacred" or "To Be or Not to Be," but clichs culled from the worst movies of that period. The actors don't help. James Brolin and Jill Clayburgh look a little like Gable and Lombard and a little more like Hamilton (George) and Lynley (Carol).Of the two, Miss Clayburgh comes off better. She appears to be creating a character whenever the fear-fully bad screenplay allows it. Mr. Brolin doesn't act. He gives an impersonation of the sort that makes you wonder if he can also do James Cagney and Edward G. Robinson.Miss Clayburgh could be an interesting actress, but she's not a great one, nor is she a star, and there are always problems when small performers try to portray the kind of giant legends that Gable and Lombard were. Because both Gable and Lombard are still very much alive in their films on television and in repertory theaters, there is difficulty in responding to Mr. Brolin and Miss Clayburgh in any serious way. They are stand-ins.Life for actors often gets mixed up with the roles they play, but that's no reason why a movie about actors should get so hopelessly mixed up with the movies the actors made. In "Gable and Lombard," Gable and Lombard "meet cute" (is that Anita Loos's phrase?) not once but a dozen times.Although Carole swears a lot and makes a couple of obscene gestures in the course of the movie, both Gable and Lombard speak in the phrases of refined drivel that Lolly Parsons would have loved.Life is okay, a philosophical Gable says at one point, "as long as you can look in the mirror and like what you see." "Listen," says the emotionally distraught Lombard, "I'm the No. 1 female star in America and I never said 'I love you' to anyone and meant it." My favorite, though, is delivered by Red Buttons, who plays Gable's pal at the time the actor begins to fall for Lombard: "First time a dame ever got to you?"Turn on your telly for the real thing.

title: The Pop Life
description: Arena managers around the country are becoming increasingly concerned with the problem of violence at pop music concerts. And there do not seem to be any obvious solutions.

title: Jackson Leads Alaska Caucus; Many Delegates Uncommitted
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 11Alaska Democrats clung to tradition and chose to remain uncommitted to any of the party's Presidential candidates, reports from precinct caucuses around the state indicated today.

title: HEARST DEFENSE FAILS TO SUPPRESS ADVERSE EVIDENCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11Patricia Hearst lost today her fight to suppress a great amount of evidence that the Government plans to use in an attempt to show that she willingly took part in the Hibernia Bank robbery here on April 15, 1974.

description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 11 (UPI)Frank Arnau, a detective story writer, died today in a clinic here. He was 81 years old.

title: CleanAir Rules Easing for South Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne said today that the state was preparing to relax airpollution emission standards for certain areas of South Jersey to permit industries and power companies to burn fuels with higher sulfur content.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11more than half of the Americans in the 18to25year age group have tried marijuana at least once, according to a Government report made public today.

title: Higher Coffee Prices Are Expected
description: Retail prices of ground coffee, which have risen an average of 40 cents a pound since last summer, should advance at least 35 cents more in the next few months. The cost of instant or soluble coffees will rise proportionately.

title: Burns Expresses Concern Over City's Fiscal State
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed concern today over New York City's fiscal situation, in contrast to the optimism expressed last week by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

JO ANNE BROWN FOUND NOT GUILTY
CARTER DISCUSSES AIMS IN HARTFORD

title: Burns Uneasy Lest News Make Banks Too Cautious
TV: Olympics as Entertainment and Selling Game
description: ABCTV's coverage of the Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria, has registered a surprisingly substantial success in audience ratings. Perhaps viewers are delivering a negative comment on the general mediocrity of the regular schedule. Perhaps the Olympics, after ABC's outstanding coverage of the Summer Games in Munich. West Germany, have now simply become a major event, similar to the World Series or the Super Bowl. Perhaps sports will eventually be the only entertainment left on television.

title: Personal Finance: Tax Planning in Making Bequests
description: Many indviduals in middleincome as well as in upperincome brackets would like to bequeath some of their assets to charity. But without proper planning, such bequests could subject the family of the deceased or the charity to heavy tax burdens.

description: MADRID, Feb. 11A reporter for a Madrid daily newspaper who refused to identify persons attending a clandestine news conference was indicted today for obstructing justice.

The bill guaranteeing equal rights for homosexuals, passed the Houes of Representatives Human Rights and Opportunities Committee 8 to 2 and was forwarded to the Senate, where it passed 23 to 11 last year.

Sometimes these days he moves with his head stooped down and he probably takes longer now to get from one place to the other than he used to, but he has had no inhibitions about setting his mark on the Patricia Hearst trial.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) President Ford today asked the Senate to ratify new tax treaties between the United States and both Israel and Egypt. The accords aim at avoiding double taxation and preventing tax evasion.

title: Chess
description: TORREMOLINOS, Spain, Feb. 10American entrants held the top places in the 16th annual Costa del Sol International Tournament after four rounds of play here in the Cervantes Hotel. I am leading with 3 points and 19yearold Larry Christiansen is running second, a half point behind.

description: Three American Jewish organizations announced yesterday that they would resume travel programs to Mexico, effective at once, in response to what it said was Mexico's newly clarified position on Zionism.

title: Revision Expected to Put City Deficit Near a Billion

description: SEA GIRT, Feb. 11  Two women will be in the class of 36 that is graduated here Friday after an 11week course fur municipal police officers.

description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation disclosed yesterday that the Government would probably incur no loss in the liquidation of the defunct Franklin National Bank and that many Franklin creditors would probably be reimbursed.

title: The Screen
60 Are Believed Trapped By Landslide in Ecuador
description: QUITO. Ecuador, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (Reuters)At least 60 people were believed to have been buried in a landslide tonight in the Pacific port of Esmeraldas in northern Ecuador. Five bodies were recovered before darkness stopped rescue work.

title: Mail Voter Registration Is Ruled Invalid
description: BUFFALO. Feb. 11A new law permitting statewide voter registration by mail was declared unconstitutional today by a justice in State Supreme Court here.

title: Ohio's No. 1 Smith Dies; Entertained With Tales
description: COSHOCTON, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Cleon Dobson, who entertained thousands of visitors each year as Ohio's most famous blacksmith and the star attraction of the canal town of Roscoe, died Monday. He was 87 years old.
