description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 11 (AP)Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, called today for repeal of criminal penalties for possession of less than an ounce of marijuana.

title: Los Angeles Aide Resigns
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (UPI) Maurice Weiner resigned today from the $37,000ayear post of deputy mayor, but insisted he was innocent of lewd conduct charges and he said he would appeal his conviction. Mayor Tom Bradley, supporting Mr. Weiner's protestation of innocence, called a news conference at City Hall to announce that he had accepted the resignation.

title: WILLIAM M'CLOSKEY
description: William B. McCloskey, who retired in 1964 as a vice president of W. R, Grace & Company, the international chemical concern, died Tuesday in Baltimore, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Kissinger to Pay Wife's Way
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Secretary of State A. Kissinger says he will reimburse the Government for the cost of flying his wife, Nancy, aboard an Air Force jet to Boston for ulcer surgery. Through a spokesman, he said today that he also would pay the Treasury the cost of flying her home when she is released from Massachusetts General Hospital, where she is expected to be continuing to improve after the operation last Saturday.

title: MOTHER M. BRENDAN
description: Mother M. Brendan, assistant general of the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and infirm, operating nursing homes in this area, died Monday at the Motherhouse of the Carmelite Sisters at Avila in Germantown, N.Y.

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 10 Senator Henry M. Jackson has embarked on a new campaign strategy  attacking Gov. George C. Wallace directly instead of ignoring him.

description: Reporters on The New York Post refused yesterday to have their names printed above the stories they wrote for the paper, and they said this socalled byline strike would last 10 days.

description: TRANSPLANT The entertainment crew of the Blue Angel, which is no longer with us, seems to have found the right new quarters at La Vie En Rose (7551820), a new name for the Little Hippodrome, the supper club at 227 East 56th Street (between Second and Third Avenues). Audience response earlier this week was enthusiastic to the spangled, helterskelter revue, Pouff, with its nearnudity and female impersonating and the whirling showgirls joined by the club's waiters, who peel down with them.

title: Head of Church Group Is a Woman in Motion
description: BOONTONWhen the New Jersey Council of Churches speaks, it represents the voices of threequarters of a million Christians in the state Since last April, the council's spokesman has been Louise Davidson, the first woman and one of the first lay persons to become president of the interracial, ecumenical organization.

title: ... Policy Alternative
description: On the broader policy issue, the onceshining promise of nuclear power has grown so tarnished that realistic planning for this country's future energy needs must seek alternate fuels for generation of electricity.

title: Lee J. Cobb Dies
description: Lee J. Cobb, the stage and screen actor best known for the role of Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman, died yesterday. He was 64 years old. Page 34.

title: Tarnishing the Atom...
description: Technological decisions about safety precautions at nuclear power plants are too crucial and too complex to be reached through angry public exchanges or attempts to engender panic. When equally authoritative voices shout totally opposite assessments about the safety measures built into the Indian Point No. 2 power plant on the Hudson River, or any of the rest of the nation's 56 licensed reactors, the public has every right to be confused, annoyed and concerned.

title: Students Scuffle in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (UPI)A bus load of black students reportedly angered by a snowball throwing incident scuffled with white students today at a school in the city's northeast area. The 45minute incident before school started was the most serious disruption to occur in the nation's fifthlargest school district since busing for 21,000 students started on Jan. 26.

description: Dr. Donald W. Shriver Jr., a 48yearold Presbyterian minister and scholar, was formally installed last evening as the Union Theological Seminary's 13th president.

WHEAT FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Wheat futures prices rose yesterday on continued reports that the new winter wheat needed moisture to survive in some areas and that high winds had blown away cover for the struggling plantings in some areas. Since the talk of moisture needs began to worry traders a week ago, not to mention farmers, the price of new crop July wheat has risen from $3.62 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade to $3.85 yesterday. The increase yesterday was 8 cents.

description: The nation's saving banks had a net deposit inflow of $775 million in January, a record for the month, according to preliminary figures released here yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

title: Paper Says Hughes Has Left Bahamas For Acapulco Stay
Balkan Amity
description: An assassination at Sarajevo in what is now Yugoslavia provided the spark that ignited World War I in 1914. But even before that killing, the Balkans were notorious as an area in which life was cheap and in which groupsdivided along numerous religious, national and political linesdelighted in warring on their neighbors. To earlier generations of Europeans, the notion that all the diverse peoples of the Balkans might live in peace and willing cooperation for long periods would have seemed as unlikely as a human visit to the moon.

title: The Measure of Greatness
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 11If anyone had told Rosi Mittermaier as recently as two weeks ago that she would win two gold medals and possibly three in the Winter Olympics, she would have disregarded the notion as a crazy dream.

title: Honest Pleasure 14 Length Victor in Flamingo Tuneup
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP)Honest Pleasure made his 3yearold debut an impressive one today, scoring a 14length victory in a $10,000 sevenfurlong exhibition race held before Hialeah's featured Everglades Stakes. Ridden by Braulio Baeza, Honest Pleasure took the lead from his three challengers at the start, led by a length down the backstretch and then moved away with every stride to leave Parc Forillon 14 lengths behind. Improve It was third and El Jaguar finished fourth.

description: PARAMUS, Feb. 11Revolutionary soldiers, puppeteers, a strolling minstrel, storytelling for the young and a show of fashions from 1776 to 1935 brought the Bicentennial to life at the Bergen Mall today.

title: Giscard Spares Killer's Life
description: PARIS, Feb. 11 (Reuters)President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today reprieved an 18 yearold youth sentenced to death and commuted the penalty to life imprisonment. The youth, whose name was given only as Bruno T., in accordance with French laws on minors, had been sentenced for murdering an old woman. There have been no executions in Fance since Mr. Giscard d'Estaing took office nearly two years ago.

title: Newark Bank Guard and Robber Killed
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11A 78 yearold bank guard and one of three bank robbers were killed today in a shootout at the Carteret Savings and Loans Association here.

description: ROME, Feb. 11 (AP) The Vatican today formally rejected a condemnation of Zionism and a call for Arab control of Jerusalem approved at a ChristianMoslem conference held in Tripoli, Libya, last week.

title: Miss Mittermaier Captures Olympic Slalom
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 11Mama has done it again. With the smile of an angel and a devil's daring, Rosi Mittermaier won the women's slalom race at the Olympics today. She now has two gold medals in Alpine skiing, joining such immortals as MarieTherese Nadig of Switzerland, who lost a pole today at the start and surrendered, and Andrea Mead Lawrence of Rutland, Vt.

title: Yale Raises Tuition by $505
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 11 (UPI) Students at Yale University will have to pay $6,425 for annual tuition, room and board this fall. The increase, $505 higher than this year's charge, was announced yesterday by Kingman Brewster Jr., Yale's president, and Hanna H. Gray, the university provost.

title: C.I.A. to Stop Enlisting Agents From the Press and the Church
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it would cease recruiting agents among reporters for American news organizations or American clergymen and missionaries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A state meat inspector who collected $30 a week and meats from the White Eagle Market in Brooklyn under the threat of closing it down as a health hazard was convicted on charges of receiving a bribe and official misconduct. Testimony during a 12day trial disclosed that the inspector, Robert Kingman, 45 years old, of 901 73d Street, Brooklyn, accepted the. payments from December 1972 to September 1973. He resigned shortly after he was indicted late in 1973. Mr. Kingman, who faces up to seven years in jail, is to be sentenced by Justice Leonard Skolnick in State Supreme Court March 30.

title: Bridge

description: TORONTO, Feb. 11 (UPI) Secondseeded Ilie Nastase employed a clever combination of shots and strategy today and defeated Jaime Fillol of Chile, 64, 64, to advance to the quarterfinals in Canada's only World Championship Tennis event.

Our reluctance arises partly from fear of the consequences of reduced energy use, which is due in turn to a lack of understanding of how reductions in energy demand can be achieved.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The Government said today that it would withhold Federal funds from states that did not meet strict new standards for child day care centers.

title: Reagan Calls for Reform Of Welfare in S.I. Speech
CleanAir Rules Easing for South Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne said today that the state was preparing to relax airpollution emission standards for certain areas of South Jersey to permit industries and power companies to burn fuels with higher sulfur content.

title: Prince Bernhard Defended as Dutch Open Inquiry Into Lockheed Payment
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 11Acting with caution and reluctance, the Netherlands has begun an investigation of allegations that Prince Bernhard accepted $1.1 Million from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for help in selling planes to the Dutch Government.

title: CRUDEOIL OUTPUT PLUNGES FOR WEEK
description: Crudeoil production in the United States has fallen to its lowest level since 1965, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Patrick M'Ginnis to Act As City's Culture Chief
description: Mayor Beame appointed yesterday Patrick B. McGinnis as acting Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

title: PERJURY CHARGED TO JUDGE IN BRONX
description: Judge Adolph C. Orlando of the Bronx Court of Claims was indicted yesterday on a charge of lying when he told the State Commission on Judicial Conduct last year that he had not contributed his services to the Bronx Republican Party after he was appointed a judge in 1971.

title: Carey Backs Conference In Brussels on Soviet Jews
description: Governor Carey gave strong backing yesterday to the threeday Second World Conference on Soviet Jewry that opens in Brussels next Tuesday. Like the first conference there in 1971, it will press for greater freedom for Jews and for exit visas to those wishing to emigrate to Israel.

title: HOUSE PANEL ENDS INQUIRY ON SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The House Select Committee on Intelligence prepared to go out of business at midnight tonight after what most of its members and staff have seen as nearly a year of frustration in its efforts to peer into the works of the dozen or so agencies that make up the Federal intelligence community.

title: A Circus Where No One Knows What's Going to Happen
PROSOVIET GROUP IN ANGOLA IS GIVEN O.A.U. RECOGNITION
John E. Norton, U.S. Agent Who Worked With Elliot Ness
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 11 (AP)John E. Norton, a former Treasury agent who worked with Elliot Ness during prohibition, died Monday. He was 80 years old.

title: SCRANTON CHOSEN BY FORD FOR U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11President Ford has asked William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, to replace Daniel P. Moynihan as chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Picatinny Hopes to Name Explosive Used at Airport
description: A spokesman for the Army said yesterday it hoped to establish within the next two weeks what explosives were used in the bomb blast that killed 11 persons and injured 75 last Dec. 29 at La Guardia Airport.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN ARSON AT PLANT
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 (UPI)A Federal judge today declared a mistrial for the last defendant in the spongerubber plant arson trial because the jury could not reach a verdict.

title: Talks on Buying Soviet Oil Reported Stalled on Price Talks on Purchasing Soviet Oil Reported Stalled on Price Issue
Village Voice Publishes Parts of a Secret House Intelligence Report
Sports News Briefs
description: What is billed as the Eastern Seaboard's largest recreational vehicle and camping show opens today at the Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y., and continues through Feb. 16.

title: Opera: Trittico at Met
description: Characterizations by Irene Dalis were a threeply thread that wove through Tuesday night's performance of Puccini's Il Trittico at the Mettropolitan Opera. Miss Dalis, stepping into the season's ninth performance, assumed for the first time here the roles of Frugola in Il Tabarro and the Princess in Suor Angelica. She also made her first appearance of the season in the familiar part of Zita in Gianni Schicchi.

title: Byrne Defends His Plan for Fast Trials
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Governor Byrne said today that he was confident that defense lawyers would not be able to frustrate his 90 days to trial program if it was put into practice in New Jersey.

title: Martin Santini Sr. Dead; Headed Moving Concern
description: Martin Santini Sr., who retired in 1964 as president of the 7 Santini Brothers moving and storage company, died Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: GEORGE W. M'CLAIN 3d
description: George W. McClain 3d, general manager of Jujamcyn Theaters, owners of legitimate houses in New York and Boston, died Tuesday at his home, 101 West 12th Street. He was 68 years old.

title: Lee J. Cobb Dies
description: Lee J. Cobb, the stage and screen actor best known for the role of Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman, died yesterday. He was 64 years old. Page 34.

title: Cuomo Calls G.O.P. Lobbying Approach Foxes Watching Coops
description: ALBANY,Feb. 11Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo today criticized the outlines of a planned Republican bill regulating lobbying activities. He said he would offer his own proposal to Governor Carey giving the regulatory power and subpoena power to investigate lobbyists to the Secretary of State's office.

title: O.A.U. Office at the U.N. Denounces CORE Project
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 11The office of the Organization of African Unity here to day attacked as antiAfrican the decision of the Congress of Racial Equality to recruit black American veterans to go to Angola to assist antiCommunist forces as combat medics.

title: Premier and Black Leader Hold Private Rhodesia Talk
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and Joshua Nkomo, the black nationalist leader, met privately for 75 minutes today to discuss a future Rhodesian constitution.

title: William Ford, Auto Heir, Quits As McCarthy's Running Mate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) William Clay Ford, a Michigan businessman, withdrew today as a standin VicePresidential candidate on an independent ticket with former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, saying there were legal problems in several states.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the name of Penn Kemble, executive director of the Coalition for a Democratic Majority, was changed to Penn Kimball in Tuesday's Notes on People column. Penn T. Kimball, a former staff member at Time magazine, The New Republic and The New York Times Sunday department, has been a professor at Columbia University's graduate school of journalism since 1959.

title: Stock Prices Edge Up; Profit Taking Cuts Gains
description: Stock prices opened sharply higher yesterday, but steady profit taking whittled away at the increase throughout the day. After opening 5.43 points above Tuesday's close, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 971.90, only slightly above the day's low, for a gain of 3.15.

title: REILLY LAWYERS STRESS WALLETS
description: LITCHFIELD. Conn., Feb. 11 The still unsolved mystery of Barbara Gibbons's three wallets was explored in court here today as hearings continued on her son's attempt to win a new trial. He was convicted of her murder.

title: TOM DONNELLY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) Tom Donnelly, a critic of theater, film, television and books for The Washington Post, was found dead yesterday at his home. He was 57 years old. Mr. Donnelly had been suffering from influenza recently, according to Post officials. An autopsy was scheduled.

title: Boycott of Growers Is Urged by Chavez In Elections Fight
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, frustrated at the suspension of California's farm labor elections, called today for a new boycott against selected fruit growers.

title: Hanoi and Vientiane Agree on Measures To Strengthen Ties
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)North Vietnam and Laos today pledged to strengthen relations between the two [Communist] parties and the two countries in a joint communiqu published here.

title: Nuclear Test Set Today
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 11 (AP)A highyield underground nuclear test, the fourth announced this year, is scheduled at the Nevada test site for tomorrow, the Energy Research and Development Administration says.

title: F.D.A. Bans New Use of Red Food Dye, but U.S. Court Sets Further Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration banned the dye known as Red No. 2 effective tomorrow after getting permission from a Federal appeals court.

title: Crusaders 4, Stingers 2
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UPI)Russ Walker scored two first period goals in sparking Cleveland to a 4.2 victory over the Cincinnati Stingers tonight.

title: INTEREST RATE UP ON STATE BONDS
description: Interest rates on tripleA state bonds moved sharply higher yesterday as Maryland borrowed $150 million in they taxexempt bond market. Underwriters led by the First National City Bank won the bonds and priced them to yield almost half a percentage point more than similarly rated bonds marketed Jan. 29 by Illinois in the preceding bond sale by a toprated state. Even with their higher yields, the Maryland bonds did not attract investors especially quickly and about half of them remained in the underwriters hands at the end of the afternoon.

title: Developing Sunbelt Hopes to Avoid North's Mistakes
Danger Signal
description: The future not only of the 50cent fare but of the city's foundering threeyear plan for restoration of fiscal stability hinges on the contract talks that have just begun between the Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority.

title: Aide Named U. C. L. A. Football Coach
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP)Terry Donohue, 3 yearold assistant coach of the U.CL.A. football team, was named the Bruins head coach today. Donohue replaces Dick Vermeil, who announced Sunday that he was leaving the University of California, Los Angeles, to coach the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League.

title: Wisconsin Senate Bars Revisions in Primary
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 (UPI)The State Senate defied the national and state Democratic parties tonight and refused to revise Wisconsin's Presidential primary.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was June of 1970, and an Egyptian delegation headed by the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser was in Moscow seeking arms. A Soviet Union Foreign Ministry official entered the conference room to hand a piece of paper to Vladimir Vinogradov, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs. He gave it to Andrei A. Gromyko, the Foreign Minister, who read it and gave to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin. He read it and gave it to Communist Party chief Leonid I. Brezhnev, who read it and gave it back to Mr. Kosygin. He handed it to President Nikolai N. Podgorny, who returned it to Mr. Koskgin. It was passed to Mr. Brezhnev, who signed it. as did Mr. Kosygin and Mr. Podgrony, and then passed it back through Mr. Gromyko and Mr. Vinogradov to the official, who left.

title: LOCKHEED HEADS EXPECTED TO QUIT IN BRIBE SCANDAL
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's chairman and at least one other top official are expected to step down very soon because of the scandal involving millions in payoffs for plane sales abroad, Government and industry sources said yesterday.

title: Auto Big 3 Accused of Making Unfair Profits in Repossessions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today accused the nation's three largest automobile manufacturers of making unfair profits when they repossess cars.

title: GEORGE SANDERS, OWNED DAY LINE
description: George Sanders, a former owner of the Hudson River Day Line and a City Commissioner of Commerce in the William O'Dwyer administration, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HEARST DEFENSE FAILS TO SUPPRESS ADVERSE EVIDENCE
College Formula Suits Holtz
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 11 About 1 o'clock this morning, three hours after he unsuccessfully attempted to get some sleep, it suddenly occurred to Lou Holtz what he had to do as the new coach of the Jets.

title: ITALIAN CABINET HAS FEW CHANGES
description: ROME, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Prime Minister Aldo Moro tonight announced the formation of his fifth Government, which is seen here as a stopgap solution to Italy's fiveweekold political crisis.

title: Tuesday's Fights
Revision Expected to Put City Deficit Near a Billion
description: City officials said yesterday that the current revision of the city's threeyear austerity plan was likely to indicate that the city's deficit this year had grown more than $200 million, to about $950 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the name of Penn Kemble, executive director of the Coalition for a Democratic Majority, was changed to Penn Kimball in Tuesday's Notes on People column. Penn T. Kimball, a former staff member at Time magazine, The New Republic and The New York Times Sunday department, has been a professor at Columbia University's graduate school of journalism since 1959.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the New York Cocoa Exchange and the citrus associates of the New York Cotton Exchange will also he closed for the holiday. All stock exchanges will remain open.

title: Son of Secret Sellout
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  In this space last week, some new information about the secret sellout of the Kurdish people was revealed: The United States, which had been quietly supplying arms aid to Kurdish rebels fighting for selfdetermination inside Communist dominated Iraq, betrayed our allies at the behest of the Shah of Iran.

title: The Myth Of the Machine
description: The Secretary of Transportation, William T. Coleman Jr., gave us what he promised: an honest decision. ln allowing Concorde a sixteenmonth trial at Kennedy and Dulles Airports, he plainly made up his own mind, without politics or pressure. That much must be, accepted by those of us who regard the BritishFrench supersonic transport as a symbol of the wasteful, selfdestructive impulses in industrial society.

title: Amex and Counter Rise in Active Day; Rate Dip Held Spur
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday, in active trading.

title: Red Smith
description: Rumania came in yesterday, Frank Braynard said at lunch. The Mircea, a sister ship of the Eagle, built in 1936 in Hamburg, a threemasted bark of 265 feet. Her figurehead is a wooden statue of Mircea the Great, the Prince who saved Rumania's independence from Hungary, Turkey and Poland in Fourteen Hundred and Something when Rumania's name was Walachia. The figurehead is like a caricature of the knight, with huge handlebar moustaches. Frank Braynard glowed with a pale blue flame as he always does when he talks about Operation Sail 1976, the seagoing salute America's Bicentennial that he has been working on since 1971. Braynard used to write ship news for the New York Herald Tribune, he has been program director for the South Street Seaport Museum and has completed three volumes of a fivevolume history of the Leviathan. (Frank Hogan, the district attorney in New York, was a deckhand on her in 1925 and Earl Carroll, the producer of Earl Carroll's Vanities, was a fourthclass messman, which is a little lower than busboy.) Braynard was secretary of Operation Sail 1964 when 24 ships from 12 countries paraded up the Hudson under full sail. It was a breathtaking spectacle that many said would never he duplicated in this world, but for Op Sail 76 the general manager, Braynard, has lined up more than 200 vessels from 30odd lands, including 14 or more of the world's last remaining tall ships.

title: 6 Relief Offices Here Collect for Guatemala
description: Guatemalan authorities have authorized six relief agencies with offices in the New York area to accept contributions for victims of the country's earthquake, Antonio Aris de Castilla, the Guatemalan Consul General, said yesterday. The most urgent need is for financial contributions, although some medical supplies are also being sought.

title: Michigander Takes U.S. Downhill Race
description: DURANGO, Colo., Feb. 11 (AP)  David Oswald of Grand Maris, Mich., took first in the men's downhill today in the Rocky Mountain Division of the United States Ski Association Elbert Trophy series.

title: Turkey, Long a U.S. Ally, Now Seeks Wider Circle of Friends
description: ATHENS, Feb. 11Turkish and American negotiators have spent months trying to draft a new mutualdefense agreement, and the Turkish Foreign Minister, Ibsen S. Caglayangil, was supposed to go to Washington this week to conclude the talks. But the visit was canceled at the last minute when it became obvious that the two allies were still far apart. Meanwhile, six American military bases in Turkey remain closed.

title: Democratic Contest in New Hampshire Viewed as 3Man Race
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 11As the day of decision nears, the confusion over who is ahead in the cluttered Democratic Presidential primary election in New Hampshire seems to most observers to be clearing a bit.

title: Market Place
PROSOVIET GROUP IN ANGOLA IS GIVEN O.A.U. RECOGNITION
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 11The Organization of African Unity today recognized the Sovietsupported Angolan nationalist movement as the legitimate government of Angola, according to an announcement from the group's secretariat.

title: C.I.A. to Stop Enlisting Agents From the Press and the Church
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it would cease recruiting agents among reporters for American news organizations or American clergymen and missionaries.

title: SAM RIVERS PLAYING VILLAGE JAZZ CLUB
description: Sam Rivers, who is appearing through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, plays some of the longest tenor saxophone solos imaginable. He began his first set Tuesday evening with a 35minute workout that would have left most younger saxophonists exhausted; then he performed on the flute and soprano saxophone for another half hour.

title: Olympic Censorship
description: In a disgraceful capitulation to Soviet pressure, the International Olympic Committee has canceled the accreditation of Radio Free Europe's reporters to cover the winter Olympics at Innsbruck. The intolerable precedent thus set opens the possibility of nations with the requisite gall and power dictating which newspapers, radio stations or other media may or may not cover Olympic eventsa danger that would be particularly acute at the Moscow games coming up in four years.

title: People in Sports
description: The injuryjinxed Rangers received another jolt yesterday when Larry Sacharuk was operated on for a detached retina in his right eye. The hardshooting defenseman, who was being converted to a right wing, will be lost for the rest of the season.

title: The Considerable Speck
description: HILLSBORO, Va.No one around here brags about it, but this town is probably the richest in the United Statescomparatively. It's not that the people themselves are rich, for there are poor people here and no one in town could be classified as wealthy. But the town has enough in its till to distribute about $100 to every man, woman, and child if it were so inclinedwhich it isn't.

title: SCRANTON CHOSEN BY FORD FOR U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11President Ford has asked William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, to replace Daniel P. Moynihan as chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: PARKING
description: Because of the Lincoln Birthday holiday today, motorists will be permitted to park their cars on both sides of streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. All other parking and standing restrictions will still apply.

title: Lawyer Says Firm Denied Him Partnership on Ethnic Grounds
description: A lawyer who was denied a partnership in one of the country's major law firms has filed suit in Federal Court here charging that he was discriminated against because he is a Catholic and of Italian ancestry.

title: Levi Seeks Consumer Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he planned to hire a consumer affairs adviser to coordinate Justice Department activities affecting consumers.

title: LOCKHEED HEADS EXPECTED TO QUIT IN BRIBE SCANDAL
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's chairman and at least one other top official are expected to step down very soon because of the scandal involving millions in payoffs for plane sales abroad, Government and industry souces said yesterday.

title: Lincoln '76
description: In a Presidential election year that falls during the nation's Bicentennial, remembrance must be strong of the place of human character in public life and of the long dream of achieving equality for all Americans.

title: Firemen Bid Farewell to Fallen Comrades
description: More than a thousand offduty firemen had the sad experience of attending two funerals yesterday, one In Queens and one on Long Island. They were honoring two of their three comrades who were killed last Sunday while fighting an early morning blaze in Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: Roosevelt Entries
GISCARD SEES EUROPE LACKING INFLUENCE
description: ST. JEANDEVENCE, France, Feb. 12President Valry Giscard d'Estaing asserted today that Western Europe was failing to exert any political influence on the conduct of international affairs.

title: A Smorgasbord of Magazines for Youngsters
description: Even in this time of anxiety over Johnny's plummeting reading scores, children's magazines continue to arrive at his doorstep bearing the good news that if enjoyment comes first the scores should take care of themselves.

title: Music: Young Uck Kim
description: Young Uck Kim is a 28 yearold Korean violinist with a fine reputation established through several solo appearances here with orchestras. On Wednesday night, he gave his first New York recital, drawing a nearcapacity audience to Alice Tully Hall and having the inestimable collaboration of Samuel Sanders at the piano.

title: Deliveries to Resume
description: Newsprint deliveries to The New York Times Company, which has a 49 percent interest in the Gaspesia Pulp and Paper Company, are expected to resume the week of Feb. 23, The Times said yesterday. Gaspesia, which is able to produce about 215,000 tons of newsprint annually, provided The Times last year with more than 77,000 of the 265,000 tons the newspaper consumed.

title: TIMES'S REQUEST REJECTED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Central Intelligence Agency has rejected a request by The New York Times, made last month under the Freedom of Information Act, for the names of American and foreign news organizations that have provided cover for American intelligence  gathering activities over the last 28 years.

title: J.C. Snead Posts Lucky 65, Leads
Car Dealers Feel a Mood in the Nation for More and Bigger Autos
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. The nation's car dealers are returning home from their annual convention here fired up with a collective conviction that Americans arc in a mood to buy cars againin big numbers and in big sizes.

title: BOY DIES IN A FALL THROUGH LAKE'S ICE
description: A 10yearold Queens boy died yesterday afternoon after he, his brother and a friend plunged through the ice on Baisley Park Lake, touching off a series or rescue efforts by neighbors, firemen and a police helicopter.

title: Assembly Acts to Make TV's Legally Inviolable
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP)The family television set may soon attain the rank of a legal necessity in New York State.

title: Bowen Cites Reasons Agencies Lose Clients
description: In a speech on how ad agencies should go about winning new business, John S. Bowen, president of Benton & Bowles, also told why agencies lose old business.

title: Valentines Are for Pampering...
description: The stage is set for Valentine's Day down at Shenanigans in Greenwich Village. Christmas is something you're obligated to buy for, but Valentine's Day is a fun, love kind of thing, said Marjorie Stern, coowner of the gift shop at 384 Bleecker Street.

title: Parents Hear Miss Hearst, on Tape, Call Them Pigs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12Patricia Hearst, a small figure in a gaily flowered dress, blanked back tears this afternoon as her trial jury heard a tape recording of the strong, determined voice of Tania denounce her parents as. pig Hearsts and belittle suggestions that her captors had brainwashed her.

title: DrugPrice Posting Upheld
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP)The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled today that it was not unconstitutional for the state to require drugstores to post a list of prices for the 150 most commonly sold drugs. In a unanimous decision, the court denied a claim that the 1974 law was too vague.

title: So. Carolina Turns Back Fordham
Youth Kidnaps Patrolman
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)A 13yearold boy kidnapped a highway patrolman at gunpoint in the officer's own patrol car yesterday. Patrolman Bobby Lee Joe, 30, overpowered the youth about 30 minutes after being held up at gunpoint after picking up the boy as a hitchhiker.

title: LABOR MEN WARM TO ROCKEFELLER
Article 1  No Title
5% PRICE RISE SET BY ALCAN ALUMINIUM
description: The Alcan Aluminium Corporation said yesterday that it would increase by 5 percent the price of selected coal and flat sheet products effective Feb. 16, following similar price rises announced by other aluminum producers.

title: S. E. C. Suspects Boeing Bribes, Files a Suit Demanding Records
Kissinger Assails Report By Pike as Malicious Lie Charges That House Intelligence Panel Produced a Distorted DocumentFord Offers to Investigate Leak
Czechoslovakia Forfeits for Drug Use
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 12A doping penalty against the Czechoslovak hockey team that led to a forfeit of its victory over Poland and a wellearned triumph by the United States over the Polish team today enlivened competition at the Winter Olympics.

title: U.S. WEIGHING USE OF A GERMAN TANK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffman said today that the Leopard II developed by West Germany would be selected as the new main battle tank of the United States Army if it proved superior to a tank neing developed by American companies.

title: COLGATE SLATES RIVIANA MERGER
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company and Riviana Foods Inc. announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge through an exchange of stock valued at more than $166 million. Under the agreement, which would make it possible for Colgate to assume an active manufacturing role in the food business, the companies would achieve a taxfree merger by the exchange of about 7 million common shares of ColgatePalmolive for 6,363,661 shares of Riviana Foods on the basis of 1.1 shares of Colgate for each share of Riviana.

title: Portugal and Spain, With Tension Over, Discuss New Ties
description: LISBON, Feb. 12The foreign ministers of Portugal and Spain met today in the medieval city of Guarda, in northeastern Portugal, to work out new relations.

title: Alexander Lippisch Dead at 81:Messerschmitt Aircraft Pioneer
description: Dr. Alexander M. Lippisch, who designed Germany's early Dornier and Messerschmitt aircraft, including the first operational rocketpowered fighter, died Wednesday in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He was 81 years old.

title: Data Show Colby Backed Study of Legality of Spying
News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1976

title: 1,463 Queried by Phone Under Random Choice
description: The New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Feb, 2 through Feb. 8 with 1,463 adult men and women across the continental United States.

title: Data Questioning Bronx Market Lease Were Withheld From Estimate Board
description: Estimates casting doubt on the merits and costs involved in the Bronx Terminal Market lease, now under investigation by a grand jury, were repeatedly withheld from the Board of Estimate in 1972 and 1973.

title: $473,298 Verdict in Death
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP) The family of a Bucks County electric lineman killed when his pickup truck went out of control has been awarded $473,298 in damages from the Ford Motor Company, The award, made yesterday by a jury in United States District Court, went to Mary Vizzini, widow of Salvatore Vizzini, 37 years old, who was killed Sept. 1, 1973, near Bridgeton, N. J.

title: U.C.L.A. Easy Victor
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP)The sixthranked U.C.L.A., led by Marques Johnson's 19 points, routed Washington State, 10478, tonight in a Pacific8 basketball game. It was U.C.L.A.'s 96th consecutive homecourt victory.

title: Philomusica Plays Delectable Mozart And Brehm Sextet
description: Some of the finest instrumentalists in the East have in the New York Philomusica musical home away from their primary bases of activity. Formed in 1971, the ensemble has a nucleus of 10 or 11 members, but it expands or contracts according to the needs of the performaing moment.

title: . . . the American Posture
description: The question of American aid to Angola was never a simple proposition, in which all merit was on one side; but at crucial points in the Washington debate, some members of CongressSenator Clark of Iowa and Representatives Young of Georgia and Diggs of Michigan, among othersperceived the authentic, longrun American interest in southern Africa far more accurately than the Administration did.

title: Amtrak Trying to Buy Northeast Route
description: Amtrak, which since its tormation five years ago has limited its activities to contracting for passenger train service on the nation's railroads, is now seeking to become an independent railroad with full management and operating control of the 465mile Northeast corridorthe Penn Central Railroad's RostonNew YorkWashington line.

title: Lockheed Shift
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, in the wake of a scandal involving payoffs abroad, is expected to name Robert W. Haack, former president of the New York Stock Exchange. as interim chairman to succeed Daniel J. Haughton, whose resignation is expected. Page 45.

title: GOVERNOR TAKES CONVENTION POST FROM CUNNINGHAM
description: Governor Carey yesterday designated Arthur B. Krim, a longtime Democratic fundraiser, to replace Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, as the New York party's representative primarily responsible for the preparations for the Democratic national convention here.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
CORE Chief Cancels a Speech On Coast After a Black Protest
Buckley and the City Differ On Use of U.S. Police Aid
description: Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd had told him 200 police officers would be rehired under a $5.5million Federal grant, but spokesmen for Mayor Beame and the Police Department said that such a decision had not been made.

title: 18 Hospitals Are Asked To Shut Obstetrics Units
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the city's Health Commissioner, announced yesterday that 18 hospitals here had been asked to close down their obstetrics services because of what he said were their low occupancy rates.

title: U.S. Panel Releases Reports That Critic Says Show Failure to Act on Safety Before Licensing Atom Reactors
Flyers Trounce Rangers
It's a Snap to Get Cars Inspected Now
Easy going Hearst Prosecutor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 United States Attorney James L. Browning Jr. usually likes to play tennis at least twice a week, but things are not usual for him these nays, and so the tennis has the slipped. He has other things to News do. For the first time in six years, Mr. Browning is back in court. He is the prosecutor in the trial of Patricia Hearst, which pits him against F. Lee Bailey, one of the bestpaid defense lawyers in the country.

title: The Judges' Suit
description: There is nothing ennobling about the spectacle of 44 Federal judges haling the Government into court in pursuit of higher pay, But if their lawsuit accusing Congress and inflation of violating their constitutional right to undiminished remuneration during their term of office seems a graceless lapse in decorum, responsibility for this awkward moment in the nation's judicial history Is properly ascribable to Congressional fecklessness.

title: GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: St. Peter's Victor Over Iona, 8473
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12 Two former high school teammates, Cliff Anderson of St. Peter's and Dave Brown of Iona, engaged in a shootout tonight; Brown won the battle and Anderson and his team won the war in a 8473 St. Peter's victory.

title: ABC Expanding Eleanor and Franklin
description: Eleanor and Franklin, the fourhour television adaptation of the Joseph P. Lash book of that title, is to be expanded by ABCTV into a ninepart cycle on the careers of and relationship between Eleanor and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Planning for Health
description: In a carefully reasoned statement the other day, Mayor Beame outlined the harsh, new realities facing this city's healthcare mechanism. New York City, he emphasized, simply cannot continue to provide the same vast sum$2.5 billion, over onefifth of its entire budget for health care. Severe economies are needed, including the closing of obsolete, highcost and inferior hospitals in both the municipal and voluntary systems. The Mayor rightly called for better coordination of the city's private and public medical facilities to insure best use of the reduced resources available.

title: Rough Punch, $7.80, Wins Mile at Aqueduct
New Jersey Briefs
description: Two cousins, both enrolled at Essex County College, were charged with murder and armed robbery yesterday the deaths of a bank guard and a third cousin of theirs during a bank holdup Wednesday. Judge Goldin Johnson of Municipal Court ordered the suspects, Curtis Trent and James G. Jones, both 20yearold residents of Irvington, held without bail pending trial.

title: Flu to the Starboard! Man the Harpoons! Fill em With Vaccine! Get the Captain! Hurry!
description: Worldwide epidemics, or pandemics, of influenza have marked the end of every decade since the 1940's  at intervals of exactly eleven years 1946, 1957 and 1968. A perhaps simplistic reading of this immediate past tells us that 11 plus 1968 is 1979, and urgently suggests that those concerned with the public health had best plan without further delay for an imminent natural disaster.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1976

title: Mayor of Manchester Township May Remain Despite Conviction
PROWEST FORCES IN ANGOLA TO SHIFT TO GUERRILLA WAR
George J. Burger Is Dead at 86; Lobbyist for SmallBusiness Men
description: George J. Burger, who, as vice president of the National Federation of Independent Business, had been a spokesman for the small business man for many years, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 30 Clinton Place in New Rochelle.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Health Department said that a Los Angeles importer responsible for importing anthraxcontaminated yarn that had caused one death in California had brought in 90 percent of the suspect yarn. The concern, Creative Handweavers Inc., was cited as the source by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, which said the company had imported the yarn from Pakistan. Another concern, Tahki Imports Ltd. of New York and New Jersey, was believed responsible for importing the remaining 10 percent of the yarn, the commission said. Creative Handweavers products are not labeled with a company trademark; Tahki yarns are.

title: COLLEGE OBTAINS DEED FROM HARGIS
GOVERNOR TAKES CONVENTION POST FROM CUNNINGHAM
description: Governor Carey yesterday designated Arthur B. Krim, a longtime Democratic fundraiser, to replace Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, as the New York party's representative primarily responsible for the preparations for the Democratic national convention here.

title: Money Talks Again
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 Last September, Robert Kohlos, Mayor Tom Bradley's 32yearold press secretary, quit his job to run for Congress from California's 27th District. This week, he withdrew from the race even before the filing deadlinevictimized, he believes, by the Supreme Court and the campaign finance laws.

title: CHURCH UNIT ASKS TV PROGRAM ON VD
description: The communications arm of the National Council of Churches called on broadcasters to develop programs on prime time to inform teenagers about venereal disease and contraception.

title: A New Daily Competes For Chinatown Readers
description: A new Chinese daily newspaper appeared here yesterday, joining six others in competing for the already tight market of 90,000 readers in Chinatown.

title: 4 Jews Asking Return to Soviet Assert They Were Abused Here
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 12 (UPI)Four Sovietborn Jews said at a Sovietsponsored press conference here today they had been beaten, stabbed and persecuted in New York for having criticized the condition of American Jews.

title: Chicago Banker Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Mitchell Kobelinski, a former! Chicago banker and businessi man, was sworn in today as head of the Small Business Administration. After taking the oath Of office from Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court, Mr. Kobelinski pledged his support to President Ford's economicnd political policies.

title: Kodak Reports Drop In Earnings by 7.1 %
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported earnings declines of 7.1 percent for the fourth quarter and 2.5 percent for all of last year, yesterday from its Rochester headquarters. Sales of the world's largest photographic equipment producer, however, were up 13.6 and 6.5 percent, respectively.

title: Carey Demands Legislature Adopt His Budget Now
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12Governor Carey demanded today that the Legislature approve his budget immediately, adding that a panel of bankers advising State Comptroller Arthur Levitt on credit problems had termed such a move essential to the restoration of investor confidence in the state.

title: Phelps Is a Factor In Fordham Hiring
Old Hearst Estate Is Scene of Blast;Cottage Damaged
description: SAN SIMEON, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)A bomb blast caused an estimated $1 million damage today to a treasure filled guest house at the fabled Hearst Castle. There were no injuries.

title: Amex and Counter In Slight Advances;Options Deals Off
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market were moderately higher yesterday in quiet, semiholiday trading.

title: HUGHES IS REPORTED AT ACAPULCO HOTEL
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Howard R. Hughes slipped into this Pacific Coast resort early today and rented an entire floor at one of Acapulco's most luxurious hotels, sources close to Acapulco's tourism industry said.

title: Loan Decision Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Senator William Proxmire criticized Treasury Secretary William E. Simon and the Emergency Loan Guarantee Board today for what the Senator said was a recent informal decision to allow the troubled. Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to increase its guaranteed borrowings this year by $40 million.

title: Scouts, Islanders Tie, 22
BARRY WHITE SINGS AT THE MUSIC HALL
description: Barry White's fiveday run the Radio City Music Hall, which began Wednesday, promised to be something of a camp event, what with its lavishly advertised 62piece allgirl orchestra. It turned out instead to be more or less what might have been expected from a Barry White concert all along  a little boring, a little silly, a little pompous and entirely unobjectionable.

title: L. E. LAYBOURNE, 62, TIME MAGAZINE AIDE
description: Lawrence E. Laybourne, who retired last year as Time magazine's director of corporate affairs in Washington, died of cancer yesterday at his home there. He was 62 years old.

title: Books of The Times
Judge Signs Order to Liquidate Grant Company Within 60 Days
description: A Federal judge yesterday signed an order providing for the liquidation within 60 days of the W. T. Grant Company, which only two years ago was the third largest varietystore chain in the United States.

title: Advertising
description: The tremors resulting from the financial failure of Lennen & Newell are still being felt four years after the ad agency's demise.few contracts are ever signed, especially in spot television.

title: Amritraj Defeated By Borg
Summer Olympics Turmoil Hurts Canada
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 10Canadians have suddenly discovered, to their intense chagrin, that the widely publicized delays and scandals connected with preparations for the summer Olympic Games in Montreal next July have presented this country with a jolting image problem.

title: Hoboken Wants U.S. or the State To Renovate Its Ferry Terminal
description: HOBOKEN, Feb. 12Mayor Steve Cappiello said today that he hoped the expected acquisition of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad by state and Federal agencies would lead to the rehabilitation and modernization of the rail line's historic old ferry terminal here.

title: Statistical Hypochondria
description: A sort of cancer panic broke out in Washington late last year. In one week alone, more than sixty Congressmen called the National Cancer Institute to find out if a major new cancer menace had erupted. Some published material even suggested that perhaps a longdormant cancer bomb had explodedsome environmental pollutant present for decades that was finally producing enormous numbers of potentially lethal cancers.

title: U.S. Senate Unit Asked to Name Lockheed Bribetakers in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb, 12A number of Japanese officials asked today that a united States Senate subcommittee disclose the names of Japanese politicians, officials and business executives alleged to have taken bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Apple Pie Almost a Collage of Grievances
Westchester Resistance to More Prisons Stiffens.
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12Westchester County, with six state and county penal institutions, may have a seventh soon, and perhaps even an eighth. The cry enough is enough is being raised in the land.

description: Albert H. Blumenthal, the Assembly majority leader, has moved for dismissal of his perjury indictment on the ground that Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor for nursing homes, exceeded his jurisdiction and sought to entrap the legislator in a classic abuse of prosecutorial discretion.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: About Real Estate
description: A consistency of theme has begun to emerge in the rentpolicy recommendations that housing specialists are making to the city. The theme became clear yesterday when the findings and recommendations of a housing study by the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University, financed by the Economic Development Council of New York City, were outlined at a news conference.

title: Indictment Attacked

title: TV Review
description: Fridays at 8 haven't been kind to CBSTV for many a season. The major competitive spoiler has been Sanford and Son on NBCTV. Recall, if you can or dare, some of the CBS clinkers that have graced the slot: Khan! Dirty Sally, Great Day, Big Eddie. The list is chilling. Now, beginning this evening, the candidate is Sara, a Philadelphian who decides to become a schoolteacher for the frontier town of Independence, Colo. The year is 1870. The form, CBS evidently prays, is ageless.

title: Appeals Court Supports Nadjari Inquiry Methods
Many U.S. Executives Reported In Favor of Overseas Bribes
description: Large numbers of American businessmen believe they have not only the right but even the obligation to pay bribes and kickbacks abroad to win contracts for their companies, according to a report issued yesterday by the Conference Board.

title: Powerful Hydrogen Blast Rocks Las Vegas a Minute
Indictment Attacked
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, the Assembly majority leader, has moved for the dismissal of his perjury indictment on the ground that Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor for nursing homes, exceeded his jurisdiction and sought to entrap the legislator. Details are on page 37.

description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 12 (UPI)The director of the United States Agency for International Development, Daniel Parker, arrived here today at President Ford's request to assess the damage in earthquakeravaged Guatemala.

title: Article 2  No Title
U.S.I.A. Realty Concern Told Letters Are U.S.'s
description: What's in a name? Misrepresentation, the Federal Government said yesterday as it obtained a showcause order requiring U.S.I.A. Homes Inc., a Queens realestate concern, to appear in court next Thursday to tell why it should not be restrained from continuing to use its name in advertisements.

title: Notes on People
description: A graduate seminar on ethnicity in politics was the first class yesterday for Daniel P. Movnihan as he returned to the faculty at Harvard University. Mr. Moynihan, whose stint as the chief American delegate to the United Nations will continue until the end of the month, will also teach a course on ideology in foreign policy. Although reporters and photographers had been invited to the seminar by the Harvard news office, Mr. Moynihan refused to let them in.

title: Buckley Will Introduce Bill to Prohibit Quotas in Unions, Business and Colleges
description: Senator James L. Buckley announced yesterday that he would seek legislation to bar the Federal Government from imposing employment quotas in requiring unions, businesses and universities fo achieve job equality for women and members of minority groups.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption for a photograph that appeared in The New York Times yesterday erroneously stated that Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard were appearing in public in Amsterdam on Wednesday. The Associated Press, which supplied the information on which the caption was based, said that the photograph actually was taken May 25, 1974,

title: S.E.C. Suspects Boeing Bribes, Files a Suit Demanding Records
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Securities and Exchange Commission, asserting it had information that the Boeing Company might have made illegal payments to foreign government officials to facilitate sales of its aircraft, filed suit in Federal District Court here today to compel the company to produce its records for examination.

title: STRIKES SETTLED AT 3 PAPER MILLS
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 12 (UPI)Lengthy strikes at three Price Company newsprint plants in Quebec and Newfoundland have ended after ratification of a new collective agreement by more than 1,500 workers.

title: Excerpts From NadjariRogers Letters
Poll Finds Voters Judging 76 Rivals on Personality
description: Nine months before the American public elects a President and two weeks before the first primary is held, the personalities that the candidates have projected appear to be a much more important source of support among potential voters than the stands they have staked out on major issues.

title: PARKING
description: Regulations requiring motorists to park on alternate sides of the street arc in effect again today following the Lincoln's Birthday holiday.

title: Stock Prices Decline;Dow Finishes Off 5.12
description: In a quiet holiday session, stock prices fell sharply in the final hour yesterday, more than erasing a midafternoon advance. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead by nearly 3 points at 1 P.M., closed at 966.78, down 5.12.

title: For a Unified, Neutralized Angola
NADJARI PROTEST BALKED U.S. STUDY
description: A federally ordered evaluation of the office of the special state anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, was quietly canceled last month after Mr. Nadjari requested the power to veto some staff appointments and objected to the involvement of a state agency in arranging the study.

title: House Panel Weighs A New Investigation Of the Nixon Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  A Congressional subcommittee that heard President Ford testify on his pardon for former President Richard M. Nixon is to meet next Wednesday to decide whether to open en investigation into Mr. Ford's decision.

title: HIGHER CAR OUTPUT PLANNED FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12The four American auto companies are scheduled to build 163,239 cars this week, up 1.3 percent from 166,043 last week and 66.5 percent from 101,061 in the yearearlier week, according to Automotive News.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Because of the partial holiday for Lincoln's Birthday, there was no trading in United States Government and agency bonds yesterday. In addition foreigncurrcncy markets, some commodity exchanges and hanks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were closed.

title: Lockheed Expected to Pick Haack as Its Interim Chief
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is expected to name Robert W. Haack, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, as its interim chairman at a board meeting in Burbank, Calif., today, according to informed company sources.

title: F.E.A. Gives Nepco $10 Million Worth Of Oil Entitlements
description: The Federal Energy Administration yesterday granted the New England Petroleum Company crude oil entitlements for the months of December and January

title: About New York
description: They stood up and applauded when Percy E. Sutton walked in. They applauded again when he rose to speak. All easy elegance, the Borough President of Manhattan began talking of places he had had been and people he had seen, and of how sorry he had been to leave, and of how glad he was to be back. Mr. Sutton was with friends.

title: Lincoln Carried His Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb: 12The Librarian of Congress, Daniel J. Boorstin, made surprising discovery today when he opened for the first time a box holding the contents of Abraham Lincoln's pockets the night he was assassinated.

title: Cathedral Plans Poetry Wall for All
description: Anybody in the world who writes a poem can display it in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: CONRAIL TO COST MILLIONS MORE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Conrail, the new Governmentbacked rail system to he formed from seven ailing northeastern railroads, will be 2,000 miles longer and millions of dollars more costly than expected, the United States Railway Association said today.

title: $400 MILLION SALE SET BY EXXON UNIT
description: The Exxon Pipeline Company, one of the companies building the $7 billion transAlaskan oil pipeline, announced yesterday that it planned to sell $400 million of notes and debentures soon. The financing was announced late yesterday at the close of a semiholiday in the credit markets. The corporate bond market advanced fairly strongly for the second day in a row and municipal, bond prices also rose.

title: ...With Sweets and Such
description: When it comes to romance, there's one sure thing about Valentine's Day.

title: Francis: Ranger Specter and Spectator
description: Emile (the Cat) Francis, who as general manager and coach of the New York Rangers, commanded center stage as strongly as Hamlet, haunts hockey like the ghost of Hamlet's father these days.

title: PRESIDENT LISTS PERSONAL ASSETS
Fiscal Fantasies
description: In proposing an expense budget that exceeds current appropriations by $435 million, the Board of Education appears to have been inspired by the Pentagon's padding practice. Whatever may have moved the school board engage in such fiscal fantasies, the effect can only be undermine current efforts to protect education's legitimate claims to a fair share of the city's badly shrunken resources.

title: Screen::'Cher Victor' A Story of Revenge on a Longtime Friend
description: Victor (Jacques Dufilho) is a widower, a small, nervous bullet-headed man with a furious temper. Anselm (Bernard Blier) is, like Victor, retired, but he's everything Victor is notgentle, patient, kind, a slow starter. Victor and Anselm have been friends for 40 years, and for the last eight they have shared a tiny apartment in a middle-class quarter of Paris. It's not been easy.When Anselm, who does the cooking, tells Victor they're having sausages and potatoes for lunch, Victor says crossly he doesn't like sausages and potatoes. "Last week you did," says Anselm. "This week I don't," says Victor. So it goes until one day at the corner pub, Victor, trying to teach Anselm manners in front of a lady, snatches Anselm's beret off his head, only to snatch off Anselm's toupee as well.Victor doesn't know it, but that's the beginning of his end."Cher Victor," the French film that opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is the story of Anselm's carefully plotted revenge on Victor, whom he drives slowly mad with suspicions that Victor's wife, dead eight years, had been unfaithful to her husband throughout their long marriage."Cher Victor" is not exactly a black comedy. It's rather more gray, which, I suspect, is just the tone that Robin Davis, the director, was seeking though the charm eludes me. It's a film of small details, methodically composed, which are sometimes funny in themselves, but which in the end have the effect of canceling one another out.Victor is an unpleasant man, but his bigotry, selfishness and temper tantrums aren't maniacally funny in the way that those of Louis De Funes were in a film like "The Mad Adventures of 'Rabbi' Jacob." He's a difficult old crab, nothing more, neither horrendous nor horrendously funny enough to support the punishment he receives.Anselm, too, fails to be particularly convincing. From the very beginning it is so apparent that here is a worm about to turn that one almost blames him for not controlling events better, but then there would be no film."Cher Victor" is very much a movie that calls attention to its modesty. In its gray sort of way, it seems pushy because though it's not really about anything, it asks for our attention. Mr. Dufilho and Mr. Blier don't overact. Instead they underact with the kind of deliberation that is just as gross as any amount of scenery-chewing.Ultimately "Cher Victor" is less a reflection of life than an accumulation of stunts, including the casting of the now matronly, still handsome but hardly over-the-hill Alida Valli as the two old men's nutty neighbor who imagines herself once to have been a great opera star. Miss Valli and her two costars seem to be having so much fun acting and carrying on that I feel churlish to have to report that I found them all a good deal less than riveting.

title: PARKING
description: Regulations requiring motorists to park on alternate sides of the street are in effect again today following the Lincoln's Birthday holiday.

title: Maine Caucusing Results Show Carter Off 9 Points
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 12 (UPI) Jimmy Carter, former Governor of Georgia, has lost nine percentage points in Maine's continuing Democratic presidential caucuses, while Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona has gained strength. The majority of deelgates is still uncommitted.

title: Dr. Brenner's Rx for a Sick Science
description: Teddy Brenner, who runs boxing in Madison Square Garden when Madison Square Garden has boxing, encountered an old friend named Al Pennino not long ago.

title: I.R.A. Hunger Striker Dies in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 12An Irish Republican Army prisoner died in a Yorkshire prison today after a twomonth hunger strike. There were immediate fears of terrorist reprisals in London and Northern Ireland.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY SPURTS IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The narrowly defined money supply spurted upward by $2 billion to $296.5 billion in the week ended Feb. 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: RUTH M. GOODYEAR
description: Ruth Millett Goodyear, a Buffalo civic leader and a founder of the AlbrightKnox Art Gallery there, died yesterday at the Buffalo General Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Williamsville, N. Y.

title: WHEAT FUTURES UP ON CHICAGO BOARD
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP)Wheat futures advanced strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade today and carried other major commodities to smaller gains also.

title: GEN. GUBBINS DEAD; RESISTANCE LEADER
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) Maj. Gen. Sir Colin McVean Gubbins, head of the British World War II secret service that sponsored underground armed resistance against the Axis powers, died yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: PIERCE SINGS TUNES OF A GENTLE CHARM
description: Bobby Short has become such a dominant figure in the performance of show tunes that one forgets there are a lot of these songs that rarely turn up in his programs. But now Hubbell Pierce, who was working this area when Mr. Short was still getting his repertory and his style together, is filling in some of these gaps at the Bird Cage in Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.

title: 35 IN HOUSE APPEAL ON SOVIET DISSIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 12 (AP) Thirtyfive Representatives wrote today to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in an effort to prevent the arrest of a dissident computer scientist, Valentin Turchin.

title: Article 3  No Title
Aides Say Reagan Has Made Gains In New Hampshire
description: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 12Ronald Reagan completed his fifth campaign swing through New Hampshire today, leaving his advisers in the state notably more confident about chances against President Ford in the Feb. 24 Republican primary.

title: Mueller Gives U.S. a Second Gold Medal;Americans Beat Poles in Hockey, 7 to 2
description: INNSBRUCK. Austria, Feb. 12The United States speed skating team was whooping it up tonight, celebrating its second gold medal.

title: ACQUITTAL ASKED IN DUTCH SCANDAL
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 12A Dutch prosecutor, citing lack of evidence, asked an Amsterdam court in a surprise move today to acquit an arms salesman for France accused of trying to bribe two Dutch Members of Parliament in 1973 to influence sales of Mirage jets.

title: Fort Myers Pacing Nation in Growth
Article 4  No Title

description: ROME, Feb. 12The Vatican today announced the appointment of a new Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary to succeed the late Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty.

title: Hatred and Fear Linger in Lebanon Despite Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 Hatred and fear still lie like a blanket over Beirut and the towns and villages of Lebanon, and keep the country from breathing.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPECTRUM Each Friday through May 21, starting tonight at 7:30, Japan House is showing a series of 15 films based on modern literary works and directed by Japanese masters, with English titles. Admission is $3, at 333 East 47th Street (between First and Second Avenues). The opening movie is Imai Tadashi's Muddy Waters (1953), derived from Higuchi Ichiyo's novel of oppressed women in the Meiji era.

title: RITA SHANE STEPS IN U.S. JUSTICE STAYS TOSING INTRAVIATA CURB ON STATE LAW

title: 2 J.D.L. Members Arrested

The suspects were identified as Marcus Rosenberg, 19 years old, of 226 West 97th Street, and Daniel Simkes, 18, of 535 West 112th Street.

title: REAGAN SPENDING MORE THAN FORD Financial Report?? Provide Insights on Contenders

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Bettly Ford gave her support and a contribution Wednesday to ERAmerica, a new national organization to coordinate of forts to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. Mrs. Ford gave ERAmerica a $50 donation, her press secretary, Sheila Rabb Weidenfeld said.

title: A.T.&T. Rebuffed On Phone Devices

The decision represents a major victory for persons supporting competition in the marketing of telephone equipment.

title: Slides Kill 27 in Turkey

title: So That Boys May Survive as Bachelors
description: HARRISON, N.Y.Nowadays it's not hard to tell the bachelors from the boys at Harrison High School.

title: Copper and Angola Combine to Cause Zambia Crisis
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 11 In the 12th year of its independence. Zambia is locked in the deepest crisis of its existence.

title: B. EARL PUCKETT, LED ALLIED STORES
description: B. Earl Puckett, retired chairman of the Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest departmentstore chains, died of a heart attack yesterday in Fairfield, Ill. He was 78 years old and lived in Fairfield.

title: A.T.&T. IS HEARD ON PRIVACY DATA

description: PRINCETON, Feb. 12 William O. Douglas studied and taught law at Columbia and Yale, but that did not stop the American WhigCliosophic Society of Princeton University from honoring him tonight.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: A few years agohow long has it been now, as many as seven or eight, or maybe 10?when artists discovered that the lofts of the shabby old buildings south of Houston Street could be converted into big. comfortable, welllighted studios, the area was dotted only here and there with small restaurants, usually Italian, of the most modest Greenwich Village type. Some longtime SoHo residents now call those times the Good Old Days.

description: GENERAL

Hynes, the special state prosecutor for nursing homes, exceeded his jurisdiction and sought to entrap the legislator in a classic abuse of prosecutorial discretion.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today accused the House Select Committee on Intelligence of practicing a new version of McCarthyism by producing a report so distorted that it amounted to a malicious lie.
