description: The Film Forum is showing a collection of short works under the title New Women/ New Films, and by far the best of them is about a very old woman making pastry.

title: Key Action on Angola. . .
Very Little of Lincoln In Lincoln's Birthday
description: There was hardly a commemoration in sight. His portrait was little in evidence, except on the money that changed hands at cash registers, even in the stores that used the occasion to promote special sales.

title: GEN.J.H. HESTER, LED INFANTRY IN PACIFIC
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 12 (AP) John H. Hester, a retired major general who commanded the 43d Infantry Division in the South Pacific in World War II, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old.

title: Poll Finds Voters Judging 76 Rivals on Personality
description: Nine months before the American public elects a President and two weeks before the first primary is held, the personalities that the candidates have projected appear to be a much more important source of support among potential voters than the stands they have staked out on major issues.

title: Cheaters NeverWin? Two Do on 2d Tries at Daytona
description: DAYTONA 13EACH, Fla., Feb. 12Dave Mattis and Darrell Waltrip, a pair of admitted cheaters who apparently learned a lesson last Sunday, played it straight today and won the two 125 mile qualifying races for Sunday's Daytona 500.

title: Business Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Carter and the Poll
description: Ever since the Democratic coalition in Presidential politics began to unravel in the late 1960's under the stress of the civil rights revolution and the Vietnam war, the party has been searching for a figure who could reunite it and lead it to victory over the Republicans.

title: Market Place
description: Polaroid, which lost 90 percent of its market value to become one of the most spectacular casualties of the fiveyear bear market, is making one of the best recoveries of the current bull market.

title: South Africa Seeks Accord With Angola Leftists
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 12 (AP)South Africa is openly seeking an accommodation with victorious Communistbacked forces in Angola, but is also preparing for the possibility of a major war.

title: Labor Backs Byrne on Relaxing of Pollution Rules
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12Governor Byrne's plan to relax the state's tough airpollution emission standards in South Jersey to stimulate business was praised today by labor unions and business as a step toward helping relieve the state's chronic unemployment.

title: Peking's Surprises
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 12When Chairman Mao Tsetung hurtled China into the Great Leap Forward in 1958, analysts of Chinese affairs were taken by surprise. When he later summoved the Red Guards to topple the Chinese Cornmunist Party during the Cultural Revolution, no analyst predicted the chaos that followed. When Defense Minister Lin Piao died in a plane crash in Mongolia in 1971 after allegedly trying to kill the chairman, analysts were not even aware of the incident for weeks.

title: Aging Process Catches Up With Cities of the North
description: PITTSBURGHAs the 29th Annual Symphony Ball swirled around him one recent evening, a very rich, very powerful, very old man named Benjamin Franklin Jones 3d stood apart from it all in a darkened corner of the dance floor, nursing his martini and his memories.

title: BYRNE SUPPORTED IN POLLUTION PLAN
R.J. Reynolds Net at Peak for 4th Quarter and Year
Jailing for Contempt Ends For Witness in Hoffa Case
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP)Stephen A. Andretta, a New Jersey teamster, who has been serving a contempt of court sentence since Dec. 11 for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, was freed today.

title: DYE MAKERS APPEAL TO BURGER ON BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Manuacturers of the nation's most widely used food dye asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger yesterday to lift the Food and Drug Administration's ban on its use and sale.

title: Carey Wants Concorde Confined to Washington
description: Governor Carey has told the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that he believes tests of Concorde operations in this country should be limited to Washington and that the supersonic jet should not be allowed to land now at Kennedy International Airport.

title: PRESIDENT LISTS PERSONAL ASSETS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 32President Ford, fulfilling a campaign pledge to disclose his personal finances, made public today documents showing that his net worth increased by $67,000 since he became President.

title: Weekend Colleges Attracting Students and Revenue
description: MayBritt Wang has been a stewardess eight years for an international airline, a job that she says leaves her exhausted after a long flight. On weekends, when she could be relaxing instead, she puts in long classroom hours toward a bachelor's degree at Marymount Manhattan College.

title: U.S. Brotherhood Week Set to Open Tomorrow
description: The National Conference of Christians and Jews 43d annual observance of Brotherhood Week begins tomorrow in schools, churches, synagogues and community centers throughout the country.

title: Blacks Assail CORE on Angola Recruits
SCHORR IS SOURCE OF LEAKED REPORT
description: WASHINGTON,Feb.12Dandel Schorr, a Washington correspondent for CBS News, disclosed today that he had provided a copy of the secret report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence to The Village Voice, a weekly New York newspaper that published the document last Wednesday.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los AngelesCarlos Palomino, 145 pounds, Long Beach, Calif., outpointed Mike Avans, 151,

title: In and Out at Lockheed
PRESIDENT VETOES PUBLIC JOBS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 President Ford vetoed today a $6.2 billion measure to create jobs in state and local public works programs, charging that the legislation was an election year pork barrel that would do more harm than good.

title: REV. WILLIAM CULLEN
description: The Rev. William Cullen, who retired last year as episcopal vicar of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, died Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L I. He was 66 years old.

title: Stage: Count Dracula
MUSIC DIRECTORS TESTIFY ON PAYOLA
description: NEWARK. Feb. 13 (AP)The present or former music directors of three radio stations testified in Federal Court today that they had received cash payments from major record companies despite Federal laws against payola.

title: Ada Campbell Rose, Began Jack and Jill Magazine in '38
description: Ada Campbell Rose, who in 1938 started Jack and Jill, the Curtis Publishing Company children's magazine died Saturday at her home in Rydal, Pa. She was 74 years old.

title: The 260 Countdown for Rutgers
BUTZ WOULD TIGHTEN INSPECTION OF GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Agriculture Department officials called off the nation's leading grain exporters yesterday to Join in a voluntary campaign to clean up the scandalridden cram inspection system.

title: President Terms Reagan Too Conservative to Win
Grain Dealer Held Informed
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 13 (AP) William R. Pearce, a vice president of Cargill Inc., one of the world's largest grain marketing concerns, said today that foreign grain dealers knew what they were buying and were not being deceived. He commented in reference to charges of misrepresentation in grain grading that reportedly are contained in a report by the Federal General Accounting Office.

title: YONKERS ENTERS DEFAULT STATUS
Nigeria at a Glance
description: Vital StatisticsThe Federal Republic of Nigeria is a country of 356,669 square miles (almost as big as Texas and Arizona combined), lying along the tropical curve of the West African coast. The nation is bounded on the west, north and east by the Frenchspeaking republics of Benin, Niger and Cameroon respectively, and on the south by the Atlantic Ocean.

title: J. Snead, Morley Leaders
Anniversary Stroll Marks Restoration Of AlmostLost Leg
description: Leslie Limage walked briskly down a corridor at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday, a year after a Feb. 14, 1975, automobile accident on a Brooklyn street almost completely severed his left leg.

title: U.S. PRODUCTION UP LAST MONTH; PRICE RISE SLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The nation's economy continued its recovery from recession In January and there was further gradual progress in reducing the rate of inflation, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Camp Posts Available
description: Hundreds of job openings as summer camp counselors are available to college students, who may apply at the new camp unit of the New York State Employment Service, on the seventh floor at 247 West 54th Street, state officials have announced.

title: DR. ALBERT O. SEELER
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP)Dr. Albert 0 Seeler, head of the department of medicine and director of medical services at the Massachusetts General Hospital He was 60 years old.

title: IRAN WILL REDUCE OIL PRICE BY 9.5C
description: The National Iranian Oil Company has decided to cut the price on its heavy crude oil by 9.5 cents a barrel in a move considered an attempt to recapture some of the heavy crude oil market that Iran has lost in recent months. The move will be officially announced Monday, it was reliably reported in New York.

title: Music: Thomas Leads Ives's Second
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Former Civil Court Judge Fred G. Montt, scheduled to go on trial Tuesday on charges of perjury, grand larceny and tampering with a witness, lost an appeal challenging the authority of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special prosecutor, to prosecute him and that of Acting Supreme Court Justice Leon Polsky to preside at his trial.

title: Mikell Triumphs At Dartmouth
Briefs on the Arts
Kozakiewicz Vaults 183
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13Wladyslaw Kozaluewicz broke the world indoor amateur record in the pole vault tonight at the Maple Leaf Indoor Games The 22yearold Pole, who was ranked first in the event in 1975, cleared 18 feet 3 inches, just a halfinch more than his countryman, Tadeusz Slusarski, vaulted last weekend in Warsaw.

title: PRICES DECLINE FOR JULY WHEAT
description: With a long holiday weekend ahead, nervous wheat traders sold to take recent profits yesterday on the Chicago Board bf Trade. The key July contract closed at $3.89 a bushel, down from $3.96.

title: DebtorCreditor Swaps Under Scrutiny by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 13The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to strengthen the standards it uses to police business accounting practices in cases where assets have been swapped between debtors and creditors

title: WOOLWORTH SOUGHT GRANT STORE SITES
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it was negotiating with the W. T. Grant Company to take over 15 store sites in nine states closed by Grant before Grant was ordered Thursday by a Federal court to liquidate its entire business.

title: Notes on People
description: The Navy nominated Capt. Fran McKee yesterday as its first woman line officer to be promoted to rear admiral. The two previous women admirals have been chiefs of the Nurse Corps. Captain McKee, in the service for 26 of her 49 years, commands the naval security force at Fort Meade, Md. A chemistry graduate of the University of Alabama, she has a master's in international affairs from George Washington University. Following assignments in procurement and personnel, she was head of the women officers school in Newport, R.I.

title: U.S. Aide to Visit 4 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  Charles Robinson, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, will visit Zaire, Egypt, Algeria and France on a trip beginning Thursday, the State Department said today

title: George Kocolatos, Owner Of Blue Ribbon Restaurant
description: George Kocolatos, owner of the Blue Ribbon restaurant, a former Times Square landmark for six decades and onetime gathering spot of opera notables, died Thursday of a heart attack on his way home to Mount Vernon, N. Y., in a Penn central train. He was 53 years old.

title: Stock Prices Drop 8.42 On Dow in Profit Taking
Rumors of Devaluation Put Pressure on Franc
Market Place
description: One night in January 1975 Mark A. Boyar, a security analyst, sat at home flipping through the pages of the Standard & Poor's Stock Guide His eye caught the name of a companythe Londontown Corporation and that set him off once again on a quest that has become Mr. Boyar's particular passion on Wall Street.

title: BEAME DISCLOSES 297MILLION RISE IN CITY'S DEFICIT
2 Lockheed Officials Quit; Haack Is Interim Chairman
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 13The top two executives of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation quit today in the furor of a worldwide bribery scandal, and Robert W. Haack, a company director and former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was elected chairman pro tem in an effort to oversee the troubled company's survival.

title: Miss de Leeuw Is RunnerUp; Norwegian Wins Speed Event
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 13Dorothy Hamill has won her Olympic gold medal and all is right in the figure skating world. In four minutes of triumphant merchandising at the Winter Games, tonight, she put together a package to pleasure the eye and pound the heart.

title: Wrong Mate
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has the right idea, but the wrong building. Its announced intention to buy the Surrogate Court at Chambers and Centre Streets for offices and a museum has brought howls of shocked dismay from the city, the judges and the Landmarks Commission.

title: SOVIET REBUTS CHINA OVER CLASH REPORTS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today denied Chinese reports of clashes on the border and asserted that the reports were aimed at diverting attention from strife within the Peking leadership.

title: Japanese ExPrime Minister Concedes He Met With Lockheed President in '72
description: TOKYO, Feb. 13Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, who has denied all connections with the Lockheed bribery scandal, said in a statement today that he had met with the company president here in January 1972.

title: Charley Beverage, Golf Pro At Century Country Club, 42
description: Charley Beverage, the golf professional at the Century Country Club in White Plains since 1968, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 42 years old.

title: As Kissinger's Stock Falls, Talk of His Leaving Rises
Railroads in West Shy Off in Backing 7% Rate Increase
description: The Railroads west of the Mississippi River appear to be backing away from the industry's request to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to raise freight rates by 7 per cent on March 21.

title: Art: Cubism and Affinities, Prints at the Modern
LOUISE DAY LEE
description: Louise Day Putnam Lee, who had been an interior decorator with, a Fifth Avenue shop in the 1930's and 40's, died of pneumonia last Saturday at High Ridge House, a nursing home in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 89 years old and lived on Hook Road in Bedford, N Y.

title: Prima Donna Assoluta
description: When Lily Pons made her Metropolitan Opera debut on Jan. 3, 1931, she did not get a rave review from The New York Times. She sang the title role in Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor, and Olin Downes hailed her more for her promise than for her accomplishment But it did not take Lily Pons long to establish herself as one of the most popular singers in the Metropolitan roster.

title: Jersey Bus Service Cutbacks Jolt Riders
description: Thousands of bus commuters from New Jersey to Manhattan, jolted by what is being called the great busschedule massacre of a week ago, are still waiting for the new schedules and for buses that no longer appear.

title: 2 or 3 in New Hampshire Race Plan to Spend $218,000 Limit
Welfare Muddle
description: The discovery by state auditors of alarming discrepancies in New York City's claims for Federal and state welfare reimbursement offers further dismaying evidence of the persistent mangement failures that have contributed so heavily to this city's fiscal crisis.

title: Boise Post to Criner
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 13. (UPI)Jim Criner was named today the new head football coach at Boise State University, replacing Tony Knap. Knap resigned to take the head football coaching job at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas.

title: Upset at Women's Net
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I, Feb 13Allison Macatee of Arlington, Va., upset Nina Bohn of Sweden, 46, 75, 63, in the girls 18 years division of the Port Washington Tennis Classic today.

title: JACOB RASSNER
description: Jacob Rassner, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Rassncr & Rassner and specialist in admiralty law, died yesterday of a heart attack in Houston. He was 72 years oil and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.

title: BillionDollar Deficit . . . . . .
description: The desperateness of New York City's fiscal crisis is reflected in yesterday's official acknowledgment that the deficit to be covered in the threeyear austerity plan has now passed the billiondollar mark, a jump of nearly $300 million over the staggering original projection.

title: Channing Hare, 76, Painter Of Portraits and StillLifes
description: Channing Hare, a portrait and stilllife painter, died Thursday at his Palm Beach, Fla, home. He was 76 years old.

title: Maazel Will Miss Concert
description: Lorin Maazel, who injured his leg recently, will be unable to conduct the Cleveland Orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall on Monday night as scheduled. His place will be taken by Matthias Bamert, the orchestra's assistant conductor. The Dvorak program will include the Carnival Overture, the Cello Concerto with Mstislav Rostropovich as soloist and the New World Symphony.

title: Cleaning Air . . . .
description: Despite the significant progress of recent years, air pollution remains an insidious and persistent menace to public health. Congress now faces critical issues in bringing the Clean Air Act of 1970 up to date.

title: Attacks Against Rightists Spreading Quickly in China
MARX TOYS SOUGHT BY BRITISH CONCERN
description: The Quaker Oats Company announced in Chicago yesterday that it was discussing terms with DunbeeCombexMarx, Ltd. of London, for the English concern's purchase of Marx Toys, a fullyowned subsidiary of Quaker Oats.

title: Seattle, A.L. Take Compromise Road
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 13 (AP)City Council members voted today for a plan that would lead to settlement of a Seattle baseball suit, thus clearing the way for an American League expansion team to operate here in 1977.

title: FRANK SIMMS
description: Frank Simms, a radio and television announcer, died Wednesday at Tequesta, Fla. He was 54 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: U.N. Body Accuses Israel of Crimes
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13The United Nations Commission on Human Rights today approved an Arabinspired resolution accusing Israel of having committed war crimes in the occupied Arab territories. The vote was 23 to 1, with 8 abstentions.

title: The Unadoptable Get a Valentine's Party
description: The basement of Immanuel Lutheran Church was red and white yesterday, with lots of frilly hearts and red balloons and red punch and gumdrops, as 100 people who believe that Love Is a Family gathered to celebrate Valentine's Day.

title: Sal Mineo Knifed to Death in Hollywood
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 13 (UPI) Sal Mineo, the actor who was twice nominated for Oscars, was stabbed to death last night as he returned home from rehearsing for a new play.

title: Wherein the Meyer AtticaProsecution Report Is Faulted
description: Bernard S. Meyer, the special state Investigator of the Attica prosecution, asked me if I wanted to make a statement when I was testifying in his offices last spring. I said I thought he had a unique opportunity to restore the faith of a lot of people that nonpartisan honor is still possible in government. For me the Meyer Report does not do that.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Parsons First at Daytona; Foyt Takes Overall Series
A. B. A. Chief Backs Judges Suit On Pay Calls Congress Unfair
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb 13The president of the American Bar Association expressed strong support today for the 44 Federal judges who sued the United States this week for a pay increase, saying that Congress has been so unfair it invites this test.

title: Operator of Nursing Home Gets 5 Years' Probation
description: Muriel Sturman, operator of the Dumont Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation on her conviction for stealing $187,000 from Medicaid. Her bookkeeper, Bruce Spring, received a oneyear conditional discharge, meaning that he will not have to report to a probation officer.

title: ATOM POWER UNIT IS BEING REOPENED
description: VERNON, Vt., Feb. 13 (AP)The Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation plant began firing up its reactor this afternoon, more than two weeks after it had been shut down because of safety problems.

title: Antiques: American Collectors Delight In Brassware That the British Disdain
description: English brassware may be considered below stairs by British antiques collectors, as Rupert Gentle maintains. But Americans covet it and always have, the British author and specialty antiques dealer insisted this week before returning home to Wiltshire, England.

title: Overseas Refugees in Portugal Press Hard for Place in Society
description: LISBON, Feb 13Refugees from Portugal's former African colonies are putting new pressure on the Government to integrate them into the national life.

title: Rail Traffic Dips
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.4 billion tonmiles, .01 percent below a gear ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 429,525 cars, 0.8 percent below last year.

title: G.M. 1977's: The Energy Babies
Rights Amendment Foe Charges Plot on Children
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Phyllis Schlafly, the leader of the attempt to block ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution, said today that she had new evidence showing that advocates of the amendment wanted to turn over the care of children to the government.

title: Court Reimposes Limit On N.F.L.'s Arguments
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13The National Football League has gained a lawyer but lost another decision by the judge in the antitrust suit brought against it by Joe Kapp.

title: Parmalee Brothers Deny Role in Gibbons Murder
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 13 Michael and Timothy Parmalee testified today that neither of them had anything to do with the brutal murder of their neighbor, Barbara Gibbons, in 1973.

title: LOUIS MORTON, 61, HISTORIAN OF WAR
description: Louis Morton, one of the nation's bestknown military historians, died Thursday evening following surgery at the University of Vermont Medical Center in Burlington. He was 61 years old.

title: NEW CAR SALES UP 21.4% IN FEB. 110
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13Domestic new car sales were up 21.4 percent in the Feb. 110 period, but lack of demand for the new small Chevette forced the General Motors Corporation to delay indefinitely plans to expand production of the minicar at a second plant in California March 1.

title: DR. PAUL A. WITTY, EDUCATOR, 77, DIES
description: Dr. Paul A. Witty, an author, educator and for many years a leading authority on educational psychology and the educational development of children, died Wednesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: BUSING FOES HALT TALK BY JACKSON
Morris Mitchell, First Head Of Friends World College
description: Morris Mitchell, the first president, 1965 to 1968, of Friends World College in Lloyd Harbor, L I., died Wednesday at his home in Clarksville, Ga. He was 82 years old.

title: Budd Nominated President And Chairman at Travelers
description: Edward H. Budd, 42 years old has been nominated president and chief operating officer and a director of the Travelers Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Morrison H Beach, chairman and president, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FROM THE PAST The House of Windsor is being saluted as the central theme of the 32d annual National Antiques Show, honoring the ties between England and the United States and the forthcoming visit here by the British monarch. In the largescale assembly at Madison Square Garden, today through Feb. 22, there will be key sections relating to the Arts and crafts of 18thcentury England, much of it treasured in America today, in furniture, silver, china, pewter, painting, wood and textile, with special commenorative preces.

title: STATE IS HELPED BY TEACHERS FUND
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13In a major boost to Governor Carey's drive to rescue the state construction agencies, the State Teachers Retirement system voted today to buy $20 million in notes to avert a default at the Housing Finance Agency next week.

title: 3 Choreographers Spanning 3 Eras Share a Program
description: Representatives of three generations of choreographers  Katherine Litz, Janet Soares and Jessica Fogelpresented a varied program at the Barnard College gymnasium Thursday evening in conjunction with Dance Uptown.

title: NAVY SEEKS FUNDS TO REBUILD FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Navy presented the Defense Department today a fiveyear $55 billion shipbuilding program designed to rebuild the fleet, now at its lowest level since 1939, to 600 ships by the late 1980's.

title: Former Aide to Cahn Testifies On Briefcase Missing at Airport
description: The briefcase reported stolen from William Cahn, former Nassau County District Attorney, in a Washington airport was not the one he normally carried, Mr. Cahn's former chauffeur and bodyguard, Walter W Voolens, testified yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, where Mr. Cahn is on trial.

title: Eugenio Alvarez, 57, Dies; Official of Housing Agency
description: Eugenio A Alvarez, Deputy Commissioner of Housing Supervision in the city's Housing and Development Administration, died Thursday in Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Books of The Times
description: Doris Day has not made a movie since 1968her last, no landmark, was With Six You Get Eggrollbut her Image is indelible. As Oscar Levant said, I knew Dons Day before she was a virgin. She quotes that, selfmockingly, in her book Doris Day: Her Own Story (her story, but written by A. E. Hotchner). The point is that Miss Day knew herself before Hollywood made her Into a virgin, and she wants to tell us about. There is, she says, an enormous discrepancy between that sexless unsullied sunshine girl of hearth and drivein and the reallife Doris Rappelhoff from Cincinnati. The first chapter promises that there will be no holds barred, no pandering to the public image.

title: MARTIN CARTER, 64, N.Y.U. PLANNING AIDE
description: Martin B. Carter, staff associate in the office of the chancellor for space and planning at New York University and associate professor of management in the schools of business, died yesterday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital He was 64 years old and lived at 176 Bobolink Road in Yonkers.

title: State Education Board Joins Appeal on Mail Registration
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13The State Board of Elections announced today that it would join in appealing a State Supreme, Court ruling that voter registration by mail was unconstitutional.

title: BUSINESS LOANS OFF AT MAJOR N.Y. BANKS
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that business loans at leading New York City banks declined $302 million in the week ended Wednesday. The decline in these loans since Dec. 31 was put at $2.238 billion.

title: Yields Show Mixed Tone At Treasury Bill Auction
In Ohio Melting Pot Ward, the Election Is Far Away
Storm Over. Continent No Longer Cut Off From Britain.
description: A writer prefaced an article on Britain last summer with an apocryphal comment: We begin to see now that a kingdom according to human discourse is not so easily ruinated and will commonly hold by stronger roots than we imagined; we may hold out, if God has not determined otherwise, two or three years longer at this rate, only growing poorer and poorer.

title: STRAUSS PRAISES CUNNINGHAM ROLE
description: Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, said yesterday that Patrick J. Cunningham, the New York State chairman, has one of the most significant roles in the country in preparations for the National Convention, which will open here July 12.

title: German Skier Second in Bid for 3 Titles
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 13You don't need such sophisticated uphill rides as a gondola or a chairliftor long slopesto start a career leading to an Olympic gold medal.

title: EXPERTS DISCOVER GUATEMALA FAULT
Singer Streamlines Corporate Structure
description: The financially plagued Singer Company announced late yesterday afternoon what it called a streamlining of its corporate structure

title: Arabs in Jerusalem Protest Jewish Prayer Ruling
In Sinai, a Texas Twang As Monitor Base Rises
100,000 G.M. Subcompacts Recalled for Brake Defect
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP)The General Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 100,000 1976 subcompact cars to correct defects that could result in a loss of front braking action.

title: End of Medicaid for Abortions Feared
description: Governor Carey's recommendations for budget cuts in Medicaid may bar reimbursements for women undergoing abortions, according to Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, Democrat of Queens, chairman of the Assembly subcommittee on Health Care.

title: $250,000 Demanded From the Hearsts Under Bomb Threat
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)  A terrorist group demanded today that Patricia Hearst's parents pay $250,000 to a defense fund for two members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, William and Emily Harris. within 48 hours or face more bombings like the explosion at the former Hearst estate at San Simeon.

title: Gowon, in Britain, Says He Knows Nothing of Coup
description: LONDON, Feb. 13The previously deposed Nigerian head of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon. said today he knew nothing of the young revolutionaries who attempted to seize power in Lagos this morning.

title: Citibank to Hold Prime Rate
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it was holding its prime rate at 6 percent. The bank dropped its prime to the present rate from 6 percent on Jan. 31.

title: Why Love Isn't What It Was
Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)The Federal Energy Administration proposed today to end its price and allocation controls on residual fuel oil. The F.E.A. said the proposed removal of controls would not result in Inequitable prices for consumers.

title: Bridge :
2 Boat Shows To Open Today
description: Boat shows, loaded with everything from offshore fishing boats and cruising sailboats to ship models and marine accessories, get under way today on Long Island and in New Jersey. Healthy crowds are anticipated, with a combined total of 150,000 visitors expected during the nineday stands.

title: REITS PLANNING AN ASSET SWAP
description: Some of the nation's financially troubled real estate investment trusts are set to offer their bank creditors over the next three months property collectively valued at close to $2 billion in exchange for outstanding loans due the banks.

title: Telethon for Quake Victims
description: A telethon to raise money for victims of the Guatemala earthquake will be broadcast today from 3 P.M. to 11 P.M. by WXTV, Channel 41, a Spanishlanguage station with studios in Paterson, N. J. The money will be given to CARE, a station representative said.

title: Building Unions Eye Bargaining Shift
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 13 Despite warnings of impending labor turmoil in construction, influential union leaders still believe that the future of their industry rests on stablizing industrial relations through new, more rational forms of collective bargaining.

title: A Plan for Conjugal Visits Stirs Protests in Wallkill
Airline Does Not Notify Customers of Subpoenas
description: Although American Airlines requires a subpoena before it releases private information concerning passengers to Government agencies, it does not notify the persons affected of such subpoenas, Jeffrey S. Dunay. an attorney for the airline, told the United States Privacy Protection Study Commission yesterday.

title: Miss Hearst Tells Jurors of Kidnapping
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 Patricia Hearst took the witness stand in her own defense this afternoon and told the story of her kidnapping by a band of revolutionaries who then sought, she said, to use her to accomplish their schemes to overthrow established authority.

title: Prices Move Ahead On Amex and OTC For 5th Day in Row
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted their fifth consecutive advance yesterday in slower trading.

title: NURSING SCHOOL MAY BE CLOSED
description: Students and faculty members of the nursing school of the State University Center at Albany have begun a campaign, backed by the professional nurses' association of the state, to keep the school open in the face of reports that it might close for budgetary reasons.

title: Home TV Sets Store Sound  Color Lessons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Lessons in the form of color pictures and sound, transmitted from a learning center, can be stored in the home television set for display at convenient times.

title: Art: A New Look at Millet, and With Reason
description: We are, It appears, in for a fullscale revival of the work of JeanFrancois Millet (191475). Scholars have lately been looking into his life and accomplishments with a new curiosity, and only a few months ago the centenary of his death inspired a major exhibition in Paris. As the entire 19th century, especially in France, is now undergoing a sweeping revision among art historians, it was inevitable perhaps that Millet, who once loomed as one of the giants of the period, would profit from this wave of fresh inquiry, and he has. In the next few years, we can expect to see a lot more of his work, and see it taken a lot more seriously, than anyone now under the age of 50 would have imagined possible 10 or 20 years ago

title: Charles S. Jones, Air Pioneer, La Guardia School Head, Dies
description: Charles S. Jones, a leading air pioneer, died Thursday at KnudHanson Hospital in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. He was 82 years old and had lived in St Thomas for several years.

title: Princeton Subdues Brown Five, 5647
description: PROVIDENCE, R I., Feb 13  Princeton, the Ivy League's leader, posted 5647 victory over Brown tonight. The Tigers broke open a tight game with spurts of 114 and 104 in the second half and won going away.

title: MEDICAID FRAUDS CALLED RESISTANT
description: Medicaid abuses in the state estimated at $250 million a year will be impossible to climmate unless Federal funds are obtained to help police the program, the city's Health Commissioner and the state's Commissioner of Social Services and Welfare Inspector General agreed yesterday.

title: London's Crufts Bigger Than Ever9,818 Dogs
description: LONDON, Feb. 13Big is the word for it. The biggest dog event in the history of Crufts since Charles Cruft held his first show at the Royal Agricultural Hall here in 1891 opened a twoday stand today at the Olympia exhibition halls.

title: PHILADELPHIA PLAN ON BUSING REJECTED
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 13 (UPI)A state court ordered the Philadelphia school board today to come up with its own plan to bus students to achieve racial desegregation by July 1 after the court rejected a proposal by the state Human Relatons Commission that would have required the busing of 50,000 pupils at an estimated cost of $18 million.

title: People in Sports
description: The annual contract battle between 36yearold Tommy Davis and the Baltimore Orioles came to an end when the Orioles waived their designated hitter. Davis, twice National League batting champion with the Los An geles Dodgers, got a reprieve in his career when he became Baltimore's designated hitter three seasons ago.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Guatemalans Work Amid Death and Rubble to Regain Order
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 13 The earth has calmed now, and so have most of Guatemala's six million people. The rumbles below are fewer, softer and farther apart. The roar above, of planes and helicopters hauling relief supplies, is louder, more frequent.

title: A Block Party That Was a Jolly Learning Experience for West Siders
KISSINGER ASSAILS BAN AT INNSBRUCK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger sent a message to the International Olympic Committee in Innsbruck, Austria, today strongly protesting the exclusion of Radio Free Europe from official coverage of the 1976 winter games.

title: Violets Are a Blooming but No Longer Booming Business
ARGENTINA ORDERS A NEW CONSTITUTION
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The Argentine Government issued a decree tonight directing Congress to revise the Constitution before the next presidential elections, scheduled for May 25, 1976.

title: ELEANOR ELKIN TENNER
description: Eleanor Elkin Tenser, former executive editor of Noble & Noble Publishers Inc., a subsidiary of the Dell Publishing Company, died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived at 40 East 10th Street.

title: Food and Rhetoric
description: Much like the spoiled youngster who takes his bat and his ball on home when the game begins to go badly, the Ford Administration is apparently thinking about circumventing a careful Congressional legislative review of the food stamp program by issuing a set of administrative regulations which would curtail the program drastically.

title: Lily Pons, Star Coloratura of Met, Dead
description: Lily Pons, the leading coloratura soprano at the Metropolitan Opera for more than 25 years, died yesterday at St. Paul's Hospital in Dallas. She was 71 years old.

title: ExRhode Island Governor To Seek Pastore's Seat
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Feb. 13 (UPI)Former Gov. John H. Chafee announced yesterday that he would seek the seat of Senator John O Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island.

title: Ruth Gillmore, ExActress And a Teacher at Buckley
description: Ruth Gillmore, former actress and a teacher of drama and speech at the Buckley School from 1935 to 1963, died Thursday in Nantucket, Mass, where she lived.

title: Reagan Says U.S. Must Continue Its Support of Taiwan Regime
Nigerian Chief Ambushed by Insurgents
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Saturday, Feb. 14Selfdescribed young revolutionaries tried to seize control of the military government early yesterday. Later in the day, the Nigerian radio said that the coup had been crushed.

title: Angola Faction Said to Move Into Bush
233 Bargains in Apartments Attract 300 Elderly
Dollar Is Mostly Up As Gold Price Dips
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 13 (UPI)The dollar closed higher on all European money markets except Zurich today as midweek speculative pressures subsided in the wake of efforts by central banks to stabilize their currencies.

title: Gerulaitis Reaches Toronto Semifinals
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13 (AP)Thirdseeded Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, defeated Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 16, 62, 64, in the quarterfinals of a $64,000 World Championship Tennis event tonight.

title: I.R.A. Hunger Striker's Death Touches Off Rioting in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13 (UPI)Rioting swept Roman Catholic areas of Belfast today, with mobs of youths hurling bombs and hijacking cars to build burning barricades following the death of an Irish Republican Army man who had been on a hunger strike.

title: Music: Red, White, Blue
description: It probably was inevitable in this season of rapidly accelerating Bicentennial fervor. The American tenor Paul Sperry began a threerecital series devoted to songs of his native land on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A. dressed in a red suit, a blue bow tie and a white shirt. His pianist, Martin Katz, wore a blue suit, a red bow tie and a white shirt. The series is called, with a certain amount of thematic overkill, Red, White and Blue.

title: Park Service Warns of Peril of Power Plant Pollution
description: DENVER, Feb. 13 (AP)An Interior Department document made public yesterday indicates apprehension by National Park Service officials that power plants in Utah, New Mexico, Arizona and Nevada may seriously harm air quality at monuments anti scenic sites.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Selfdescribed young revolutionaries tried to seize control of Nigeria's military government early today, but the Nigerian radio said the attempt had been crushed. Brig Muritala Rufai Mohammed, who became head of state in a coup seven months ago, was said to have been caught in a blaze of gunfire, but his fate was unknown.

title: Burger Refuses to Defer Ban on Red No. 2 Food Dye
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused today to postpone a ban on the use of Red No. 2, rejecting a plea from makers of the widely used coloring agent.

title: White, Osburn Win Heat
description: SIDNEY, Australia, Feb. 13 (AP)Reg White and John Osburn of England, who had already clinched the title yesterday, won the seventh and final heat of the. Tornado world sailing championships today on Botany Bay.

title: Joseph G. Herzberg Dead at 69; Editor at Times, Herald Tribune
description: Joseph G. Herzberg, former city editor of The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times's first cultural news editor, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: 1,500 Firemen Attend Funeral Of 3d Comrade Killed at Blaze
description: For the third time this week, long lines of firemen in their dressblue uniforms formed an honor guard yesterday at the funeral of a comrade killed in the line of duty.

title: Opponent of ActorCandidate Supports EqualTimeRule Suit
The Reign in Spain: IIProspects
description: MADRIDIn a previous column I described the initial goal sought by Spain's new regime as a search for stability. What are the prospects of that pleasant condition?

title: Dance: Grand Quixote
description: George Baianchine's threeact ballet version of Don Quixote is a grand pageant. Mistakenly, It has been considered oldfashioned, a throwback to the fulllength 19thcentury ballet. Yet it is people who like 19thcentury ballets who seem to have the most trouble with it.

title: BONNPARIS MOVE ON FRANC URGED
Northrop Chief Stays Despite Payoff Scandal
description: The resignations of Bob R. Dorsey as chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation and of Daniel J. Haughton as chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, in the wake of mammoth bribery scandals, leave Thomas V. Jones, presidebt of the Northrop Corporation, a major aerospace manufacturer, as one of the few corporate chiefs to withstand the disclosure of massive corporate payoffs.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME strange, surprisingeven shackingthings have been happening in the economic and political worlds in recent weeks that have shaken some assumptions on economic policies and progress for the long term, both here and abroad.

title: For young readers
description: Yesterday's parents were tonguetied when It came to discussing sex with their teenagers. Today's parents get inarticulate and discomfited when it comes to discussing love.

title: Dry Rot
description: Corporate corruption, said the millionaire industrialist turned United States Senator, is the dry rot of capitalism. When Charles Percy of Illinois, formerly president of Bell & Howell, made this remark some time ago he confidently believed that the extent of this corruption was minuscule.

title: Washington, In 70 Faces, In Showing
WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONAlmost a year ago, Congress passed a joint resolution requiring quarterly disclosure by the Federal Reserve Board of its monetary policy targets. After initial resistance to the resolution, the Federal Reserve has complied, and now Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Fed, says he thinks it was a good idea after all.

title: In Search of Kafka And Other Answers
description: It is Franz Kafka who was responsible for getting me to Prague to begin with. I began reading Kafka seriously in my early thirties at a time when I was enormously dismayed to find myself drifting away, rather than towards, what I had taken to be my goals as a writer and a manat a time, in other words, when I was unusually sensitized to Kafka's tales of spiritual disorientation and obstructed energies. That those trying years provided me with a means of penetrating a great writer whose concerns had previously evaded me, makes me almost willing to he grateful for the obstruction and disorientation I had to experience to begin to get in touch with his fiction. The ways in which Kafka allowed an obsession to fill every corner of every paragraph, and the strange grave comedy he was able to make of the tedious, enervating rituals of accusation and defense, furnished me with any number of clues as to how to give imaginative expression to preoccupations of my own.

title: Nets Beaten In Overtime
description: DENVER, Feb. 14 (AP)With his team trailing by 19 points at the half, Ralph Simpson provided the spark tonight to send the Denver Nuggets to a 108103 overtime victory over the New York Nets before a record American Basketball Association crowd.

title: BRIDGE
description: The citizens of Rome have won about as many world team titles in the last two decades as all other players put together. The credit for this remarkable achievement belongs to four men: Walter Avarelli, Giorgio Belladonna, Massimo D'Alelio and Benito Garozzo. (Two other Italian stars of equal magnitude do not qualify for this company.Pietro Forquet comes from Naples, and Camillo PabisTicci from Florence.)

title: . . . Versus the Traditional Rooted Crown Method
description: Asparagus can be grown from one, two and three yearold crowns. Oneyearold roots will yield a small cutting in three years, whereas threeyearold roots will yield spears for cutting the year after planting.

title: Coins & Antiques
description: Approximately 40 dealers are in the numismatics section of New York's 32d annual National Antiques Show which opened yesterday for a nineday run (through Feb. 22) in the Exposition Rotunda of Madison Square Garden. The show's hours are 1 to 10 P.M. daily and 1 to 7 P.M. today and next Sunday; the admission is $3.

title: Canada Will Begin Trade Talks Soon With Europe's Nine
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: The art critic as lover, husband and friend
GoGo Bankers, and How They Went Out of Control
description: WASHINGTONA harried Federal banking official was participating in a private meeting with a Congressman and his staff in the midst of the current controversy over problem banks. At one point, the official, in obvious need of sleep and worn thin emotionally, said: I make $35,000 a year. Do you think I'm going to go in and tell some bank president making hundreds of thousands how to run his bank? Do you think my examiners, who make less than I do, are going to do that?

title: COLUMBIA PLANS PROBLEMS CENTER
description: Columbia University is planning to establish a research center to study the major social problems of advanced societies.

title: Vast Park Improvements Due in Hudson County
description: UDSON COUNTY, the most densely populated of New Jersey's 21 courrties, has received tentative approval from David J. Bardin, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, for $1.6 million in parkimprovement grants under the Green Acres program.

title: Rockefeller Compares Lefkowitz to Lincoln
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was likened to Abraham Lincoln last night by Vice President Rockefeller before about 1,000 Republicans at the New York County GOP Committee's Lincoln Day dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Ellen M. Baar Wed To Gerald Jacobs
description: Ellen M. Baar of New York, research manager for Playboy magazine, and Gerald A. Jacobs, also of New York, director of statistical services and special projects for ZiffDavis Publishing Company, were married yesterday evening at the St. Regis.

title: The WhimWham Book
description: Remember writing a letter to a friend and putting SWAK on the back of the envelope? Blowing all the, seeds off a dandelion to get your wish? Signing someone's autograph book U R 2 Good 2 B 4 Got IO? The tooth fairy? Singing Be Kind to Your WebFooted Friends and John Jacob Jingleheimer Schmidt? Take heart. The kids are still doing that today. Some things never change. There's plenty of new material, elephant jokes and rank outs, but they're variations on old themes. Whether it's culled from the past or created today, if it's in current use Duncan Emrich calls it American folklore, and it's the stuff of which The WhimWham Book is made.

title: Bank Robber Here Does Best Work on Camera
description: A surveillance camera at a Manhattan bank yesterday picked up a familiar facea robber who had been similarly photographed at work in about a dozen other banks around town in the last few months, the police reported.

title: EMPHASIS SHIFTS IN GUATEMALA AID
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 14Most of the 60,000 or more people injured in last week's earthquake here have now received basic medical attention, although United States Army rescue teams today found new villages affected by the disaster where no help had yet arrived.

title: CUTS URGED BY G.A.O. IN PENTAGON FLIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)  Congressional auditors have estimated that the Defense Department could save $3.5 million and 48 million gallons of jet fuel if military passengers on special charter flights could be diverted to regular commercial flights.

title: STATE CRITICIZED ON PATIENT SHIFTS
description: The State Department of Mental Hygiene has been charged with wholesale transfers of residents of the Willowbrook Development Center to other large institutions in violation of a consent agreement entered into last April before Federal Judge Orrin G. Judd in Brooklyn.

title: Endpaper
description: Since 1952, Peter Beard, photographer, adventurer and sometime eccentric, has been keeping a diary. More than just a chronicle of events. appointments and insights, the diary is a collage of the minutiae that assail his life: images ripped from magazines, torn ticket stubs, snapshots of friends like the late Isak Dinesen. and even fragments of scorpions from Africa. where he spends six months out of every year. These four days from his diaries are, to him, the essence of time and chance. The diaries are a dictionary of images, he says, fragments of existence that evoke the insanity of our era.

title: Wedding for Margaret E. Gaskell
description: Margaret Elaine Gaskell of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gaskell of Fernier, British Columbia, was married in South Norwalk, Conn., yesterday afternoon to Jacques de Spoelberch, son of Vidcountess Eric de Spoelberch of Haverford, Pa., and the late Viscount de Spoelberch of Brussels, who was the chief test pilot for the Belgian Air Force at his death In 1939.

title: TransAm Rebounds With 11Race Slate
description: In the case of the TransAmerican championship, apparently you can't keep a good man down. Launched in 1966, the motor racing series sanctioned by the Sports Car Club of America has been counted out more times than a thirdrate fighter.

title: Swiss Rail Crash Kills 6
description: YVERDON, Switzerland, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Six persons, including two railroadmen, were killed and about 40 were injured in a headon collision between two passenger trains on a singletrack local mountain railroad near here today, the police said.

title: Englewood's New Mayor Gets Involved
description: TALL, slim Sondra Greenberg, a 47 yearold wife, mother and indefatigable community worker who has the freckles and large bluegreen eyes of the typical American girl, is the new Mayor of Englewood, a suburban city of some 25,000 that is probably best known for the estates scattered over its treefilled East Hill area, for the bevy of musicians, artists and comedians who make the town their home and for the fact that its schools were among the first in the state to be integrated.

title: Chaste view from New Haven
description: Robert Brusteindean of the Yale Drama School, exNew Republic theater critic, intellectual roustabout, the ghost at many a symposium on whither the artshas stitched together 32 sermonettes on the dishabille of culture in these anxious, impacted times. Most of them appeared previously in the pages of this newspaper and The London Observer. Several are speeches to or about the school and the repertory company he directs. All view with alarm.

title: John Huston on Kipling, Hemingway and Jack Daniels
description: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico Years ago John Huston, already a famous film director, walked into 21 and spotted one of his idols, H. L. Mencken. I went over to him and said, I'm John Huston. The old man said something complimentary about a couple of stories I had written for the American Mercury and then asked, What do you do now? I make movies now, I said. Oh, he replied, you'll get over that!

title: Dance: Greenhouse Offers Five Choreographers
description: The dark and the light shared a program at the Riverside Church Theater on Friday night, when the Greenhouse Dance Ensemble presented works by five choreographers.

title: Those Who Remain in the Hamptons
description: EAST HAMPTON IT was the dead of winter. Thelma Henner, a middleaged woman alone, stood shivering from the cold and stared at a stack of unpaid bills on her kitthen table. She closed the doors to the kitchen., turned on the gas and went to the phone.

title: Goldin Assails City's Dependence On Unrealistic Real Estate Taxes
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin issued a report yesterday criticizing the way in which he said the city's rainy day fund was depleted and assailing what he described as the projection of unrealistic realestate revenues into the city's budget.

title: ECOLOGICAL DRIVE OFF IN AUSTRALIA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 14 Australia's economic recession has taken the steam out of an alliance of environmentalists and trade unionists that had halted more than 40 development projects Valued at some $4 billion.

title: Soviet Acknowledges a City Exists
description: The Soviet Union has acknowledged the existence of the long secret city of Leninsk, site of the Baikonur spacelaunching complex in Central Asia.

title: Men Against Tanks
description: A man who writes entertaininglythe word is selected carefullyabout antitank warfare is someone special. John Weeks can do it. By a selfimposed restriction, he does not deal with armored vehicles or selfpropelled guns, but only with weapons which are carried, pulled, or pushed by men on their feet. If this seems unpromisingly grim material, you have not met the Smith Gun, a device issued to the British Home Guard in the dark days of 1940, which was fired by turning it on its side so that one wheel became the gun's base. Weeks is rich in such gadgets, many of them more or less dangerous to the user, and all requiring a high degree of dedication to be effective.

title: Argentine Military Takeover Threatens as Wrangling Over Regime Mounts
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14The political maneuvers of President Isabel Martinez de Pern to maintain her hold on power against mounting opposition are pushing Argentina dangerously close to a military takeover, according to a growing number of national leaders.

title: 7 HOSPITALS SEE INSURANCE CRISIS
description: Administrators of the seven hospitals that constitute the Orange County Hospital Association warned last week that the rising malpractice insurance rates they are paying and a recent freeze on reimbursements from Medicaid and Blue Cross insurance may lead to Insolvency.

title: Nostalgia Trip, Led By Benny Goodman, Fills Carnegie Hall
PEOPLE
description: Add to the seemingly endless list of athletes who have churned out autobiographies the name of Bill Bradley, the celebrated former Princeton AllAmerican basketball, star, linchpin on a winning United States Olympic team, Rhodes scholar, photographer, prison reformer and theatrical investor. With the frames in a period of several weeks in the 197374 season of his team, the New York Knickerbockers, Dollar Bill Bradley tells in the book, due from Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company, all about the weariness of the athlete as he travels from city to city, and, he says, what you feared so long, the deterioration of your body, the beginning of a very special part of your life.

title: Airlines Downgrade the Upper Class
description: Any day now, first class passengers may find airlines pulling seats from under them.

title: Art as Art
description: The Selected Writings of Ad Reinhardt. Edited by Barbara Rose. Documents of 20thCentury Art Series. Illustrated. 236 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Walton to Zern to Salmon
No Place Better
description: I NEVER liked to live in cities. We always chose the country if we could. So when we returned from England in 1940, after living there for seven years, we came out to Remsenburg, where my daughter had a house. We rented that first summer, found our property and, except for a trip to Hollywood for a year to write Weekend at the Waldorf, we have made this our permanent home ever since.

title: In the Jersey Tradition: The Citizen as Critic, Fiscal Watchdog
Financial Aid Office Beckons Rutgers Students
description: STEVEN INSLEY climbed the stairs to the Financial Aid Office for the first time since he enrolled at Rutgers University in September. 1974.

title: Air War Over Latin America
description: LIMA, PeruNationalism is taking to the air over Latin America.

title: The Nation
description: For the first time since she was kidnapped two years ago, Patricia Hearst has given her own version of the incident and its aftermath under oath, and subject to crossexamination, Testifying in her trial on bank robbery charges, Miss Hearst said she collaborated with her abductors, the Symbionese Liberation Army, only because they threatened to kill her if she did not.

title: Radioactive Safety Urged
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 14 (UPI) Government Accounting Office Is recommending tighter safety procedures for users of radioactive materials for medical, industrial and educational, purposes. The agency said that Federal inspectors found more than 2,000 safety violations among users of radioactive materials in 1974.

title: NEW ETHICS ASKED IN FOREIGN TRADE
description: BURBANK. Calif., Feb. 14The two senior executives of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation! who resigned under pressure yesterday have called for the establishment of new standLards of international business and suggested that they did not quit willingly.

title: Increasingly, It Is Feminine and Demanding Work
description: The entry of millions of now invisible workers Into the postrecession competition for jobs may make the road to full employment a lot longer than even the pessimists now predict. It is not a matter of whether the nation sticks with the slowthrottle approach to recovery chosen by the Ford Administration or switches to the more stimulative policies favored by the Democratic majority in Congress; nor of the chronic argument among economists over whether the United States undercounts or overcounts its unemployed.

title: CENTENNIAL NEAR AT JOHNS HOPKINS
description: BALTIMORE, Feb, 14Johns Hopkins University, an institution that has shunned bigness to make a virtue of smallness, will celebrate the 100th anniversary of its founding next week in a series of events that will culminate in a Commemoration Day Convocation on Feb. 22.

title: U.S. Judge Backs Alabama On Confederate Flag Place
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 14 (AP)  A Federal judge has ruled that Alabama is not prohibited by law from flying the confederate flag from the dome of the state Capitol at a point. higher than the United States

title: The Art of Repairing Cut Glass
description: THERE is a fourinchhigh cutglass container on our coffee table that must weigh a quarter of a pound and which is used to hold cigarettes only when we have guests. With the revival of interest in cut glass, there have been more than casual comments about the piece, including expressions of admiration for the workmanship and several offers to buy it.

title: Thermal Energy Scores
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 14 (AP)Bill Shoemaker rode Thermal Energy to a halflength victory in the $33,700 San Vicente Stakes today at Santa Anita.

title: Susan Rubin Married to M.P. Koeppel
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue last evening Susan Yvette Rubin, an account executive with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne Inc., was married to Mitchell P. Koeppel, who is president of Koeppel Enterprises, specialists in industrial real estate. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman performed the ceremony.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
DOROTHY WRINCH, BIOCHEMIST, DIES
description: Dr. Dorothy Wrinch, internationally known crystallographer and biochemist, died Wednesday in Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: From a $150 Dingy to a
Phoebe Snow
description: In the 50's, Greenwich Village symbolized the freedom trail, which so many of my generation rode, if only on weekends, in pursuit of spiritual elbow room. It was a pseudo liberation we experienced, but being naive, maybe dumb and surely harmless, we enjoyed it immensely. In the 60's and early 70's, the Village took on a darker coloring. Reaction to the New Permissiveness had set in. The freaks, who were always in evidence hovering on the fringe, began emerging from their cocoons, then shedding them altogether. Weirdos became omnipresent, drugs were the Leitmotif of the streets. It was definitely a turning point.

title: FINNS MOLD PACT TO CUT RECESSION
MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: After showing strength in the first three days of last week, the stock market ran into the Lincoln's birthday holiday on Thursday and potential buyers appeared to have left town.

title: Food and Drug Unit Cites Medical Pumps' Fire Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has announced that about 4,250 medical suction pumps in use throughout the nation's hospitals are being refitted because they pose a potential fire hazard.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVER GUILTY OF MURDER
POINT OF VIEW
description: Some respected economists have recently stressed the importance of using figures on employment, not merely unemployment, when evaluating the nation's economic performance. While employment statistics are one of many overall economic indicators, I strongly oppose their misuse as a tactic to diminish or ignore the seriousness of the nation's unemployment problem.

title: Why Five Basketball Stars Gravitated to Columbia
description: When a high school senior named Shane Cotner began telling his friends in Kirkwood, Mo., last spring that he had made up his mind to go to college at Columbia, they were happy for him. So you're going to Mizzou, they said. That's terrific.

title: Selling Secrets
description: The winding trail of the secret intelligence committee report from its origins in the House of Representatives to the pages of The Village Voice raises at least as many ethical issues for journalists as it poses sleuthing problems for those in the executive branch or in Congress who may be inclined to trace this leak back to its spout.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Metropolitan Opera staged a new Aida, a week ago Tuesday, and during one intermission a few of the boys in the back room were reminiscing about Aida's past and present. What probably started it all was the Metropolitan Opera's fact sheet on the opera.

title: The Environment vs. the Economy
description: FOR MOST American, two of the most critical issues facing this country today are the economy and the quality of lifea safe and pleasant environment. We are coming increasingly to the realization, however, that we cannot hope to solve the problems we face in either of these two areas as long as we approach them separately.

title: A Song for the Suburbs
description: ARTISTS are supposed to struggle in garrets in the city, not in suburban homes. That is a basic rule in the handbook for struggling artists.

title: The Life of Bertrand Russell
There's an Issue in New Hampshire, but No Debate
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 14Turning up a real issue that separates the rivals in either the Republican or the Democratic Presidential primaries in New Hampshire, almost everyone agrees, is about as likely as finding a daisy on the wintry slopes of Mount Washington.

title: Letters
description: I took great offense at James T. Wooten's extremely, biased article on the Wallace Presidential campaign (Wallace's last hurrah? Jan. 11). I am not, never have been and never will be a Wallace supporter, but as a steady reader of The Times I expect a degree of objectivity, even in reporting on a candidate whose views, record and style one cannot support. Mr. Wooten's central metaphor of Wallace as salesman Willy Loman was uncalledfor and his editorializing was unforgivable, going so far as to tell the American public in effect not to vote for Wallace...he could hardly be expected to bring to the White House those qualities of moral and spiritual leadership he believes are required of the next President of the United States.

title: ART
DEFICITS DARKEN TURKISH ECONOM
description: ANKARA, Turkey  After years of steady growth and prosperity, the Turkish economy is in deep trouble. Analysts here are not optimistic about the chances for a rapid recovery.

title: ParkingTicket Ploys
The Genetic Engineers Still Await Guidelines
description: Just about a year ago 140 molecular biologists met at Asilomar, a conference center on California's Monterey Peninsula. Because the meeting involved a group of exceptionally highpowered and competitive scientists attempting to regulate themselves before expanding a new line research, it was an event rare in the history of science. In four days, the scientists agreed, voluntarily and almost unanimously, to a set of severe and cumbersome safety restrictions on their work.

title: Women Who Help to Rule the State
description: IN another time, Ann Klein might have been working out of Tin Pan Alley, Alene Ammond could have been dancing Swan Lake to adoring thousands and Anne Martindell might have been dumbfounding the Supreme Court with unusual legal arguments.

title: The Macy Tapes
description: Macy's now measures up. On Jan. 11 The New York Times told of the trials of a customer in Macy's men's wear department. All he wanted was a pair of pants, but he gave up when he couldn't find an interested clerk with a tape to measure his waist.

title: Citing a Wounded City, Group Assails Cuts in Budget
description: Budget cuts have made New York a wounded city in terms of human services, and the frightening picture so far is only the first phase of threepart slashes, a task force of the Community Council of Greater New York has charged.

title: YONKERS IS TOLD STATE WILL ACT TO BAR DEFAULT
Shah Says Iran Will Sell Oil to All, Including Israel
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran said in a radio interview here that his country would continue to supply oil to all buyers and would not. worry whether some of it went to Israel.

title: PEOPLE
description: THERE was a stuffy no a few weeks ago when Frances Galasso of Oyster Bay, a 29yearold Nassau County detective, asked for maternity leave. Bureaucrats couldn't find a rule in the book that granted such a leave to care for an adopted child. Finally.

title: Secret Lanvin Scores by Neck

title: Jefferson's Crisis Over Race
description: HARTFORD The inner torment of Thomas Jefferson is the core of Ray Aranha's new play. The Estate, now having its premiere engagement through March 7 at the Hartford Stage Company. Jefferson, as Mr. Aranha sees him, was torn between morality and expediency. A Southerner who owned slaves, be was apparently offended by slavery, but was incapable of taking a positive stand against it. To demonstrate the pressures felt by Jefferson, the playwright, who is himself black, juxtaposes two historical facts: Jefferson's affair with Sally Hemings, a mulatto slave in his household and a halfsister of his deceased wife, and his relationship with Benjamin Banneker, a selfeducated free black scientist who at one point solicited accreditation from Jefferson for his discoveries.

title: Iran to Press Grumman For $28 Million Rebate

Even the traditional glass or plastic lens is not really essential since a pinhole punched in the lighttight box (opposite the film) will have much the same effect.

title: The Flutterers
description: The sparrows make late winter a pleasanter time, especially for country folk. Not English or house sparrows, those raucous little city gamins, but native American sparrowsthe song sparrow, the tree sparrow, the whitethroat, the pine siskin, the field sparrow, the occasional chipping sparrow. Finches, all of them, in the big classification of the ornithologists, but simply sparrows to most of us. They come to the feeding stations, they are busy as bees on the hillside where weeds still stand with a few seeds, and they chatter eagerly in the most untoward weather. On warm days they sing a little, foretaste of the lively songs they will sing after March has made its turn.

title: Concert

It is impossible to account for the quantity and quality of them, but one after another they present themselves, and many of them are very good indeed.

title: Theater: The Heiress Michael Kahn Directs McCarter Production
description: PRINCETON, N. J. Feb. 13 One should sometimes distrust the memories of one's youth, if only because those memories bear a burden of youthful prejudice. When, 25 years or so ago, I first saw Wendy Hiller in The Heiress, a play by Ruth and Augustus Goetz based on the Henry James novel Washington Square, I recall thinking o fit as an efficient ut pallid echo of an extraordinarily rich novel. Of course, I was right at the time, but I was also insufferably snobbish then. I patronized the wellmade play, and I despised.the dramatic crudities of this particular work compared With the patrican virtues of James's dense and complex novel.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Lime is not a fertilizer. It is an addition to soil to adjust the soil's chemistry. Farmers used to call it a soil sweetner. In the Northeastern soils, which tend to be acid, the acidity releases certain plant nutrients and permits them to be taken up by plant roots. This is particularly true with iron, manganese and aluminum. These are nutrients needed in small quantities by plants, particularly the ericaceous rhododendrons, azaleas, hillies, etc. How, ever, too much availability of these nutrients to certain other plants can create a toxicity problem. Lime is added fo lock them up. On the other hand phosphorus, required fot good develpment of flowers and fruit, is more readily available to plants when the soil is properly limed. This sort of soil chemistry is too complicated to solve by guesswork.

title: The Lure of Two Baltimore Museums
description: BALTIMORE Baltimoreans who are interested in their city's cultural progress may not be happy when they hear a New Yorker describe their two major art museums as peaceful, but that is what they arepeaceful, and delightfully so, in comparison with the hubbub of New York's Metropolitan Museum and Museum of Modern Art. Not that the Baltimore Museum of Art and the Walters Art Gallery are quiescent. At the moment, both are in their finest fettle to date, which is the reason for this article advising a visit. But their atmosphere is more like that of the Frick Collection and the Morgan Library, where the greatest enjoyment is available to the few, than that of those other New York museums whereadmirably, of course  the few are sacrificed to the cultural elevation of the many.

title: Headliners
description: Judge Adolph C. Orlando has been indicted on 12 counts of lying to the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, when he told the commission that he had not worked for the Republican Party after he was appointed a judge in 1971. Judge Orlando was indicted by the special grand jury that is handling corruption cases brought by Special Prosecutor Maurice Nadjari. The 12 counts of the indictment deal specifically with the Judge's statements that he did not help the party draft its rules, that he engaged in no political activity, and that he made no contributions to the Republicans after he was appointed to the bench. Such political activities on the part of a judge are not considered indictable offenses, in themselves, though they might be ground for dismissal from office. Judge Orlando has been relieved of his judicial duties pending the outcome of the case. He pleaded not guilty to all the charges.

title: Design
description: David O'Grady's studio has the feeling of oldworld architecture he likes 10foothigh ceilings, a working fireplace with a marble mantel, wide moldings. To his mind, these details help compensate for the small (18 by 20 feet) floor space. When decorating. O'Grady, who is a freelance art director, made good use of his artistic talents. His room looks well furnished but not too cramped or cluttered. There's an overstuffed sofa with 1930's flavor; two antique chairs, one a tortoiseshell Regency deck chair and the other an early modern tubular chair recovered in white canvas, which came from a shoe store on 88th Street; a wicker Peacock chair; and a wicker daybed. Six people can be accommodated for parties. Straw baskets serve as occasional tables as well as provide extra storage space. A black and white vinyl floor and walls hung with baskets perk up the kitchen, which is no bigger than a closet but is just the right size for a bachelor who, luckily. doesn't like to cook.
