description: Something new has been added to the technique of crime solving. Read about it in OGILVIE, TALLANT & MOON by Chelsea Quinn Yarbro (Putnam's, $6.95). The title of the book iS the name or a law firm in San Francisco, and Moon is a fullblooded IndianOjibwa, to be exact. We all know that American Indians have certain attributes in their genes, that the veneer of civilization peels off with the least provocation. To disbelieve that would be like doubting the prevailing high intelligence of Jews or the ability of blacks to make great, rhythmic music. Certain things are not to be questioned.

title: CANADIANS DEBATE CENSORSHIP ISSUE
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 14Opposing viewpoints from a provincial court and a royal commission have stirred a major debate in Canada on the subject of Government censorship.

title: The World
description: The Military in Portugal Gives Up Veto

title: Firestone Agrees to Pay $750,000 in Safety Ad Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to spend at least $750,000 on tire safety advertising to settle a Government complaint about misrepresentation of safety qualities in previous advertisements.

title: Diminutive Speedsters Aren't Kid Stuff
Seizure of Rebels in Saigon Is Reported
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14 (AP)The Hanoi Radio said today that Roman Catholic rebels led by a priest had staged an uprising for 15 hours in a Saigon church and killed a member of South Vietnam's security forces before being captured.

title: Grease Slides Into Its Fifth Year
description: How to explain the fact that the musical Grease, which has never had a single star on its marquee or even one song on everyone's lips, has just entered its fifth year? This lowbudgeted rock n roll spoof of the fifties is Broadway's longestrunning show (1,642 performances to date), and has thus far returned to its backers a nifty $7,000 profit for every $1,000 invested.

title: Marcus Lamb Marries Miss Weinlandt
description: Priscilla Noelle Weinlandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Weinlandt of New York and Saltaire, Fire Island, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Marcus Nicholas Lamb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Marcus Lamb of Highland Beach, Fla.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: I. From My Father Bertrand Russell; International; Keystone. 2. From The Autobiography of Bertrand Russell (Little, Brown 1968). 3. Christopher S. Johnson. 5. From My Search for Patty Heart UPI. 6. Charles Harbutt/Magnum. 14. From The Whim Wham Book. 17, Culver Pictures.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: STROLLERS are rare Long Island birds: even the Audubon people don't track them Whatever else it is, the Island is no pedestrian place. When walkers are seen, they often as not show up in groups of four carrying golf bags. In winter many of these clubtoters head south with the other birds while the bipeds that remain stay in their cars.

title: Yonkers Residents Take News of Default in Stride
description: YONKERS, Feb. 14  St. Valentine's Day and bankruptcy were two visible elements today in Getty Square, this city's main shopping district.

title: TV VIEW
description: We should be taking the Olympic Games seriously. After all, in the spirit of international competition, some more athletes may be murdered at any moment. And we know, from the experience at Munich, what an advantage it is to have ABC's army of commentators and armada of cameras on hand for live coverage of a terrorist attack. If terrorists scheduled all their attacks to coincide with major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the World Cup and the Hearst trial, they would assure themselves not only of maximum publicity, in color, by satellite, but of slow motion and instant replays, too. And were they to strike at Innsbruck, there would be the added dividend of Pierre Salinger's observations.

title: ISRAEL SEEKING NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: In a move to arrest the decline of emigration to Israel in recent years, the Jewish Agency for Israel is developing projects to stimulate such emigration.

title: Portuguese Rulers Confer on Question Of Recognizing Government in Luanda
description: LISBON, Feb. 14Portugal's ruling Council of the Revolution met in an extraordinary session today to decide whether to recognize the People's Republic of Angola.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT wasn't until Tuesday morning that Panel E became a cog in the slowly grinding gears of the Essex County petit jury mill in Newark. Most of us had come the day before, making our way to the new granite courthouse on West Market Street through a vicious snow and Ice storm, only to be told that jury duty had been called off for the day.

title: Lucy Muhlfeld Is Jersey Bride
Peso Devalued 3.4%
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14 (AP)The peso will be devalued 3.4 percent on the official trade market effective Monday, the Central Bank said today. It was the second devaluation this month and the fourth of the year.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: BELLA PORTNOY KALB

title: 3 IN IVY GROUP ADD EARLY ADMISSIONS
description: Harvard, Princeton and Yale have joined the five other Ivy League colleges in an earlyadmissions program that would mean students who applied by Nov. 1 would have a rejection or an admittance for the next academic year by Dec. 15. Tradtionally, applicants applying in January are notified in April.

title: FOOD
description: CHANCES are that anyone of the wine and cheese parties in vogue in Tenafly these days already has made the acquaintance of Fine Spirits Wine & Cheese, a shop at 14 Riveredge Road.

title: Happiness Is Doing Well or Staying Warm
The Ik in the Armchair
description: I recall coining home from work about 35 years ago to find my mother sitting in a chair and weeping bitterly. Alarmed, I asked her what was the matter. She told me that she had just heard a news report on the radio about a tornado in Texas that had destroyed a school building killing several children and injuring scores of others. The poor children! she kept repeating over and over again.

title: Growing (Up) At Thirtyseven
description: In 1970 Jerry Rubin had everything. He was the author of a bestselling book, he was famous as a leader of a mass movement and he was deeply in love. Then life came crashing down around him. In two short years, his political movement disappeared, a group of young kids publicly retired him for being over 30 and the woman he adored walked out on him. Newspapers began describing him as erstwhile and aging. People started relating to him as an image, not as a human being and, worst of all, Jerry himself believed the image. He felt dead at 34.

title: Rising Fees for Corporate Directors
description: The outside director, the nonemployee who, for a fee, offers his or her expertise to the corporate board, is being paid more.

title: Article 1  No Title
Hot Singe, at $8.80, Triumphs at Suffolk
New Soccer Club Gets Swept Away by Jaws
description: The Surf got washed away, a victim of Jaws.

title: Bostonians Play Berlioz Requiem In a New Setting
description: Thanks to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, New York has been made aware of a magnificent setting for special largescale concerts that has been ignored by major music organizations until now.

title: The Man of the Golden Strings
description: MINNEAPOLISWhen the octet of strolling violinists stop at the candlelit table of Curtis LeRoy Carlson in the Flame Room of Radisson Hotel there is more sonority in their bowing, more oomph in their vibrato than if they were serenading some itinerant button merchant seeking surcease from the day's trials.

title: CAREY HELP ASKED IN UTICA CONFLICT
description: A long feud between the municipal labor unions in Utica, N.Y., and that city's combative, populist Mayor, Edward A. Hanna, resulted last week in appeals from both sides to Governor Carey.

title: Bombay Duck Scores
As G.E. Goes, So Goes Economy of 2 Counties
description: HUDSON FALLS. N. Y.From any point in this river town one must look over the roof of the General Electric plant to see the mountains beyond. The plant's presence is more than just visual in an area where the unemployment rate has averaged 11 percent. for more than a year and jobs are still hard to find.

title: Q: Is City Redlined'? A: Almost; Mortgage Money Is Hard to Find, But Opportunities Do Still Exist
description: New York City has been redlined.That is the view of many real estate operators who have experienced increasing difficulty in obtaining mortgages for rentcontrolled apartment buildings, commercial properties, and new construction during the last two years.

title: Gerulaitis Topples Nastase and Gains Final
Gun Owners Take Aim
description: NEW JERSEY gun owners are rebelling against a proposal by State Senator Alexander J. Menza to take away their handguns.

title: 200 Score Failure By City to Settle S.I. Transit Strike
description: About 200 Staten Island residents, many in Colonial costumes and several on horseback, saying transportation here hasn't really changed much since the olden days, rallied yesterday at the Staten Island Mall.

title: Schooling in Capitalist America
How I Flopped On the TalkShow Circuit
GIFTS TO NEEDIEST PASS $1 MILLION
Dorothy A. Kirmse Has Nuptials
description: Dorothy Anne Kirmse, daughter of William A. Kirmse of New York and Mrs. Andrews Kirmse of Dallas, Pa., was married in WilkesBarre, Pa., yesterday to George Baily Scarlett 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Scarlett of Kennett Square, Pa. The Rev. Stewart Pierson performed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: The Social Art of Music at Home
Soviet Wins in Hockey; U.S. Fails
description: United States hopes for a hockey medal in the 12th Winter Oympics at. Innsbruck, Austria, were dashed yesterday when the West German team scored a 41 victory over the Americans. With their surprise victory in the sixteam roundrobin tournament, the West Germans clinched the thirdplace medal.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HOMEOWNERS who take winter vacations that necessitate closing the house and leaving it vacant during cold weather and city dwellers who own second homes or vacation retreats that are unoccupied for long stretches during cold weather are often faced with the problem of how to prevent plumbing freezeups in the empty house.

title: ACE, BRITISH GROUP, AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Ace is a British rock group that reflects the lighter rather than the wilder, side of the art. The quintet opened at the Bottom Line club, West Fourth Street, on Friday with a performance that showed close attention to harmonies and a shifting dancing beat. Obviously, the sounds of black discotheque music, particularly on Ace's hit recording, How Long, are not unknown to the group's collective ear. Here, once again, an example of the distillation of an American music form translated but not changed through a British attitude. The kind of rock music that Ace turns out can certainly be called middleoftheroad.

title: Is There Life On a Plastic Planet?
description: . . . It had something to do with saving little scraps of conversation. . . . If you put them away in some little scrapbag in your head, sooner or later along came another scrap that matched a piece you already had there.

title: Miss Burke Bride Of J. M. Coleman
description: In Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday afternoon, Dorothy Ellen Burke and Joseph Michael Coleman were married by the Rev. Francis X. Mulhall.

title: Penn Downs Yale Six
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP)Mickey Ball scored the winning goal midway through the second period last night as Penn defeated Yale, 52, in hockey and raised its record to 513. Yale is 414.

title: Miss Hearst's Interview With Captors Reveals Early Shock and Gradual Change to Friendly Feelings
Electronic Banking Beats a Ban
description: CHICAGOSoon after the ice goes out of Lake Michigan this spring, two of Chicago's largest savings and loan associations will be linked by computer with two of the city's largest commercial banks and with three of the area's biggest supermarket chains.

title: ALCOHOL IS LINKED TO SEX PROBLEMS
description: Prolonged drinking of alcohol, which alters male sexual behavior, accomplishes these changes by stimulating the liver to drastically step up its destruction of the male sex hormone, according to results of a scientific study that was reported Friday.

title: Press Strike In Madrid Over Before It Starts
description: MADRID, Feb. 14 (Reuters) A strike by Madrid journalists ended before it began today after the Government declared it illegal.

title: Gun Charade
description: Strange things are being done under the Washington sun as Congress moves toward yet another shadow dance on the subject of gun control. As the House Judiciary Committee prepares to mark up a subcommittee bill, spokesmen for the gun lobby are circulating among Congressional opponents of the measure, urging that they help make the bill as strong as possible. Meanwhile, lobbyists in favor of tight new controls are opposing even a ban on the cheap, inefficient handguns, called Saturday Night Specials, which almost everyone agrees are bad for people.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Chris Evert, the 21yearold tennis pro who earned more than $400,000 last year, was named yesterday as the first winner of the Haig and Haig Woman Athlete of the Year award. Miss Evert, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the United States, French and Italian opens in 1975. She collected 620 points in balloting by an international panel sports writers in winning a $10,000 prize and a sterling silver trophy. She will receive the awards here March 19.

title: Catherine Haas of ABC Bride of Ronald Korda
description: Catherine Ann Haas and Ronald Steven Korda were married yesterday evening by Justice Alvin Ruskin of the State Supreme Court at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard V. Korda, in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: 2 Die in Blasts in North
description: LISBON, Feb. 14 (UPI)Fire and explosions in the northern town of Mirandela killed two persons, including a 12yearold boy, and injured seven others, police officials reported today. Townspeople, blaming Communists, tried to attack party militants.

title: Russian Six Takes Title; U.S. Medal Bid Fails
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 14United States hopes for a hockey medal in the 12th Winter Olympics were dashed today and the Soviet Union's expectations of winning the championship almost met the same fate.

title: The Chinese Are Told Little, And Accept It
description: Chinese officials have a phrase for anyone, Chinese foreign, who speculates on what is going on behind the scenes in that most secretive of countries. The phrase, yao yan gong chang, means rumor factories, and they have been busy in the days before the disclosure that Hua Kuofeng has taken over as acting Prime Minister, succeeding the late Chou Enlai.

title: A Short Cut to Growing Asparagus ..
description: Grow asparagus from seed. It's possible. A new method developed by Dr. Stephen A. Garrison, at Cook College of Rutgers University, establishes an asparagus bed by eliminating the nursery period for developing crowns.

title: Point of View
description: Presidential politics is bound to play a decisive role in the current housing recovery. Some would argue that the national commitment to provide 2.6 million housing units is too high. But no one argues about the devastating effect of our current housing recession.

title: Actors Guild Benefit
description: The Episcopal Actors Guild has chosen Wednesday night's performance of The Royal Family at the Helen Hayes Theater for Its annual theater benefit. Tickets, ranging in price from $20 to $40, may be obtained from guild headquarters, 1 East 29th Street.

title: TEACHER RESIDENCY IS UPHELD BY COURT
GARDENING
description: A FEW shrubs bloom between the middle of February and the middle of April. The exact dates depend both on the season and on the situation.

title: Byrne Retreats on the Environment
description: THE Byrne Administration is turning its back on the toughest collection of environmentalProtection laws ever enacted by any state. The Governor, in his annual legislative message, said that the cutbacks he was proposing did not involve any longterm or irreversible harm. That is true, but the cutbacks will mean that New Jersey's air won't be as clean as it has been recently.

title: ROME AIDE DENIES LINK TO LOCKHEED
description: ROME, Feb. 14in a country where charges and countercharges swirl constantly over the heads of politicians, Italians generally have been surprised to see a Cabinet minister quit while denying and demanding an investigation into charges that he took bribes from officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Will Dropping Liquor Agents Open Door
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has proposed abolishing the enforcement arm of the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control, and thus, in the view of A.B.C. officials, opened the door to a takeover of the New Jersey liquor industry by organized crime.

title: Wilder, Florida U., Upsets Dash Field
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: [Alfonse] D'Amato's [Hempstead] Supervisor] attack upon the fiscal management and administrative needs of the public schools of Nassau County must be answered.

title: Mauranna G. Lynn Is Engaged To Christopher Andrew Saks
description: Mauranna Gerarda Lynn, an administrative assistant on The Washingtonian magazine. in Washington, and Christopher Andrew Saks, a staff member of the Washington computer center of the Department of Agriculture, plan to be married on June 12 in St. Michael's the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Copter Training to Shift
Columbia Sues City Hospitals Corporation Over the Costs It Incurred in Closing of Delafield Hospital
description: Columbia University has sued the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation for more than $540,000 in severance pay and other expenses that the school says it was forced to pay after the agency closed Frances Delafield Hospital last summer.

title: Skidmore to Benefit
description: The Skidmore College Alumnae Club of New York will hold its annual scholarship fund benefit at the Feb. 24 performance of Round the Garden at the Morosco Theater. Tickets, $20 each, include reception at the Williams Club and may be obtained from Barbara Doyle, 2 Peter Cooper Road.

title: Lisbon Urging ExManagers to Return
description: LISBON, Feb. 14A year ago Antnio Trindade dos Santos, the general manager of a large cottonspinning mill, was held prisoner for 55 hours and then expelled from his factory by workers. Now they are pleading for his return.

title: Policemen Suspected in Violent Joyride
description: The officers allegedly beat two civilians so severely that one lost an eye. and the other was hospitalized with a brain concussion.

title: The Region
description: An independent examiner has agreed with the New York State environmental commissioner that the General Electric Company is breaking state law by discharging a toxic chemical (polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's) into the Hudson River. Now the question is what the state is going to do about it.

title: Voices That Are Heard
description: MAJOR decisions affecting Long Islanders are made on several levels. There are the public officials whose governmental actions are highly visible. There are the less visible political party leaders who generally control nominations for public office and thus can make or break the public officials.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Music in Review
description: Too many young musicians make debuts while their training is still underdone, but there was nothing halfbaked about the recital of Carol Mont Parker at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. Miss Parker. a graduate of Queens College who has studied with Leopold Mittman and Josef Fidelman, put on an engrossing demonstration, particularly in Schumann's knuckle  cracking Symphonic Etudes and only a little less impressively in Bach's Partita No. I in Bflat Beethoven's Les Adieux Sonata and Chopin's Ballade No. 4 in F minor.

title: Six magnificent
description: IN THE ENDLESS SUMMER of East Africa's Serengeti Plain, survival belongs to the strong and the swift. To the lion and the antelope. The elephant and the giraffe. The rhinoceros and the cheetah.

title: Tigers In Spain's Tank
description: MADRIDThe two tigers in Spain's present political tank are Manuel Fraga Iribarne and Jose Maria de Areilza, Count Motrico, respectively Ministers of Internal and External Affairs. Both are from the northwest, former Franco ambassadors, and had previously become known as adherents of reforming and democratizing this country.

title: Ghost Village, Once an Arsenal, Is a
description: BATSTO Two hundred years ago, it was a vibrant town of 1,000 in which bog iron was smelted and cast. Today, it is a ghost village with an operating post office and sawmill and two dozen other restored buildings. Only two oldline residents are left.

title: ART VIEW
description: The art of the portrait, though nowadays unsanctioned by either a significant body of esthetic ideas or a movement of likeminded artists who specialize in its production, nonetheless persists as a thriving artistic enterprise. There is certainly nothing in the theories that dominate contemporary art that calls for it, yet the portrait continues to be paintedand admired. Evidently, for both the artist and his subject and for the public, too, it answers to a need greater than that of the purely esthetica need for something in art that is beyond art.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Taxes Compelling Heirs to Sell Farm Land
description: SPRINGFIELD, Neb. Lloyd Royal, 59 years old, drives a 7yearold Chevrolet with 110,000 miles on it. He lives in an ordinary farmhouse next to a barn lot. If anyone called him rich, he would laugh.

title: Ford Aides Said to Defer Suspension of I.R.S. Chief
Child Care to Gain
description: Thursday's performance of A Matter of Gravity at the Broadhurst Theater will benefit Windham Child Care of 1 Park Avenue. Tickets, at $60, $40 and $30, are available from the beneficiary.

title: HUMPHREY IS AHEAD OF WALLACE IN POLL
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama remain the first two choices among Democrats for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: THE SUPER BOWL
description: According to Roger Tory Peterson's Field Guide to the Birds, the bible in such matters, a Carolina wren and a longbilled marsh wren differ in that the latter has black and white stripes on the back. Moreover, the marsh wren's voice is reedy and gurgling, running into a guttural rattle: cutcutturrrrrur, while the Carolina's song is chirpity, chirpity, chirpity, chirp.

title: JAPANESE COMBAT ILLEGAL ENTRANTS
Fight on T.V.A. Dam Fails
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 14 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit gave the Tennessee Valley Authority permission yesterday to proceed with construction of the Duck River Dam project.

title: Turkey's Goal: Independence, Respect
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel told an interviewer recently: This is not a barren nation from the standpoint of civilization. Turkey emerged from the Ottoman Empire, which lasted 624 years; definitely we have our own civilization, a great one. I do not. think we are in need of swinging this way or that. We are cooperating with Western countries and with Moslem countries, as well as our neighbors. Independent countries should follow an independent policy.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: There was something steady and secure, something quilted, wadded and infinitely supportive, about the art world of Europe in the 19th century. It was very unpleasant if no one wanted to buy your workas was the case with Claude Monet and Camille Pissarro at a critical stage in their careers. But (contrary to rumor) it was rare for a good artist to be in that position. Once in, you were in foreverunless, like Gustave Courbet, you were sent to jail.

title: LEAK IS STUDIED FOR ILLEGALITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Justice Department is attempting to determine whether Federal statutes were violated in connection with the disclosure to various news organizations of the final report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, officials of the Department confirmed tonight.

title: POLITICS
description: ALTHOUGH it easily qualities as the leastcoveted prize of the year, a growing number of New Jersey Republicans are either declaring their candidacies or encouraging speculation about their seeking the, party's nomination to oppose Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. in November.

title: Letter from Washington
Bobby Orr's Return: Does It Matter?
description: The entire National Hockey League is waiting for Bobby Orr to return from his latest knee surgery. But from Vancouver to Back Bay, there are fears that Orr never will return to his oldtime form.

title: JOHN CRAWFORD, BRIDGE STAR, DIES
description: John R. Crawford, one of the greatest of contract bridge players, died of a heart attack at his Manhattan home yesterday morning. He was 60 years old.

title: Voodoo Rites in Brazil
description: BAHIA, almost everyone calls the lively capital of the Brazilian state of Bahia. For good reason. The official name is a mouthful; Sao Salvador da Bahia de Todos os SantosHoly Saviour of the Bay of All Saints. The city lies some 760 miles north of Rio de Janeiro on a tropical peninsula between a deepblue bay and the Atlantic. Chief entry port for black slaves for more than 300 years, Bahia, beneath its Portuguese veneer, remains the most African city in Brazil. It now swarms with a population of 1.2 million, 70 percent black or mulatto, and it is the center of a vibrant AfroBrazilian cult called Candombl, a form of voodoo.

title: Move to Cite Schorr
description: ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP) Representative Samuel S. Strattont, Democrat of New York, said. today that he would move in the Congress to cite Daniel Schorr, a CBS reporter, for contempt for arranging publication by The Voice of a secret House intelligence committee report.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Several hours after I'd seen Martin Scorsese's new film, Taxi Driver, last week, someone said to me with the kind of smugness with which pronouncements about the weather are made, Well, it's the sort of film you either love or you hate. There's no middle ground. As I remember, my answer was noncommittal but the more I thought about the remark, the more uneasy I hecame. There is or should bea very large middle ground surrounding this vivid and violent film, about a Manhattan cabbie who finds salvation through slaughter, made by one of our more talented young filmmakers (Mean Streets, Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore). Either to love or to hate it is not to pay attention to it, Rather it's to gulp it down whole, without chewing. Mindlessly.

title: Martha C. Battle Wed to a Banker
description: Martha Chamberlin Battle, was married yesterday afternoon to Anthony Woodward, a second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in London.

title: Miss Parker Bride of Norman Wood
description: Charlotte Anne Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Parker of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate heart of Mary to Norman Ray Wood, son of Mrs. Robert L. Wood of Newton Centre, Mass., and the late Mr. Wood.

title: Vermont Triumphs In Skiing
description: HANOVER. N. H., Feb. 14 The University of Vermont won the Dartmouth College Winter Carnival today with a pair of individual winners and a strong team showing. Vermont had 339 points, beating the host team by 5 in what turned out to be a twoteam battle.

title: FORD URGES FIGHT ON VIOLENT CRIME
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14 President Ford declared today that the time has come for society to act in its own selfdefense against violent crime and terror.

title: A 5YearOld Boy Loses His Heroes; Who Will Tell Him?
description: The boy is 5 years old. He has a quick, easy smile, an alert, facile mind. His acts are impulsive, his movements not yet totally coordinated, his moods unpredictable. Although his concentration span is short, the boy has the ability to immerse himself, to become instantly involved in a given project. Last summer it was baseball.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 14 President Chung Hee Park of South Korea handpicked a list of 73 candidates for the National Assembly today.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Madison Square Garden will present a Thursday doubleheader and a Saturday tripleheader. Thursday's program, starting at 7 P.M., sends Manhattan against Long Island University and Notre Dame against Fordham. On Saturday, starting at noon, it's Rutgers against American University, Manhattan against Navy and, in a women's game, Queens against Delta State.

title: Janet Rady Bride Of Henry M'Donald
description: Janet Elizabeth Rady and Dr. Henry Stanton McDonald of Summit, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. New Vernon. N.J., by the Rev. George E. Chorba.

title: Events Today
description: The Peter Pan Game: musical marionette show; 11 A.M., 1 and 3:30 P.M., Swedish Cottage, Central Park West off 81st Street, near the Delacorte Theater. (Call 9889093 for free reservations:)

title: ALBANY NOTEBOOK
description: THE sonic boom from the giant Concorde supersonic jet airliner is creating a sort of sonic boon in politics of the Long Island delegation to the State Legislature.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: A few weeks ago when American Ballet Theater was playing at the Uris Theater, one of the frequent topics of intermission conversation in the foyer was how well New York City Ballet was dancing a little farther uptown at Lincoln Center. This was not meant to denigrate Ballet Theater, but was a recognition that City Balletvery possibly spurred by a new sense of competition, although it is difficult to imagine George Balanchine being spurred by anything so mundanehas reached a new level in its dancing.

title: Wendy Hausman Sets May Bridal
description: Marjorie Hausman of Woodmere, L. I., and Eugene Hausman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Robin Hausman, to Norman Weisman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Weisman of Hackensack, N. J., and Palm Beach, Fla. The couple plan to be married on May 1.

title: U.S. Wrestlers Top Poles
description: WARSAW, Feb. 14 (AP) United States freestyle wrestlers won six of eight matches at Wroclaw today in their fourth meeting with the Poles. Four other bouts were not run because wrestlers of both teams were suffering from the flu.

title: Closing In on Corporate Payoffs Overseas
description: As the evidence mounts of massive American corporate payoffs overseas more and more observers find it difficult to treat the issues as a simple matter of corporate morality, or as a regrettable but standard  operating procedure in various exotic countries.

title: Leaders of 100 Black Groups Told of City's Convention Virtue
description: Governor Carey joined city officials and businessmen here yesterday in promoting the virtues of this city as a convention center.

title: Bill Asks Federal Program To Aid the Victims of Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 14 (AP) A Federal program to compensate both crime victims and witnesses is being proposed in the House by Representative. Martin A. Russo, Democrat of Illinois.

title: Mrs. Carner 4 Ahead
No Problems, Bernhard Says of Bribery Charges
description: AMSTERDAM, Feb. 14Relaxed, smiling and seemingly unaffected by the Lockheed bribery charges leveled at him a week ago, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands attended with Queen Juliana a gala ball here last night to aid wildlife in the Galapagos Islands.

title: Report From India
description: I first went to India In 1971 to participate in an international meeting of solidarity with the struggle then going on in East Pakistan, soon to become Bangladesh. There was an atmosphere of vibrant democracy and hope. The conference had been organized by Jaya Prakash NarayanJP to almost everyone, venerable Gandhian  and there were vigorous debates. Everything turned on one's attitude toward her, to Indira Gandhi, who totally dominated the scene. JP, I remember with some irony, was attacked from the Left for being too sympathetic to the woman who would jail him four years later. The papers were filled with reports,gossip, discussion. A fantastic intellectual life flourished on this tormented subcontinent.

title: POLITICS
description: NASSAU politicians will soon find out how successful Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta might be he had more time to devote to party politics. The Nassau Republican chairman, whose county organization rivals the hamburger drivein as a symbol suburban fixation and success, will retire after 10 years in the Assembly following this legislative session.

title: Music/Recordings
description: Silver Convention, a rock group from Germany, will appear for the first time before an American audience at the Felt Forum on Feb. 28. Even though few people seem to know much about the group's background, it has still racked up an impressive Set of statistics during the year just passed. Fly, Robin, Fly, for example, the group's debut single, is a frothy pop confectionits silky strings, emphatically disco  flavored danceable rhythmic pulse and chorus of female voices cooing a simple lyric helped the disk to sell 1.5million copies. In addition, Save Me, the debut LP from which the tune was plucked, received gold certification. Nominated for two Grammys (Best Instrumental RhythmandBlues Performance and Best Composed Instrumental), the group has also been hailed by the music trade paper Record World as last year's Top New Vocal Combination.

title: TRENTON NOTE BOOK
description: TO suggest that the State Legislature is a do nothing body, as some have done, notably Governor Byrne, is not precisely accurate. While it true that the Legislature almost never meets and passes anything, individual legislators are often quite busy. They are busy drafting proposed laws, and seldom find the time to pass them.

title: Insurance Sales
description: It was a dismal year for sales of individual life insurance policies, but last year Savings Bank Life Insurance in New York State chalked up the best results in its 36 year history.

title: Reagan Wants Carolina River Included in U.S. Scenic System
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Ronald Reagan, in a move that may help him politically, has come out for placing a 26.5 mile stretch of the New River in North Carolina in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System so as to block construction of a twodam hydroelectric project.

title: Some RedHot Plots For Moguls of Mayhem

Watching a giant movie frog, for example, give warts to the entire population of Onomatopoeia County, Louisiana, can only help us endure the normal catastrophes that await us the minute we leave the theater. To insure, therefore, against a possible dearth of suitable plots, I'd like to offer the following synopses free of charge to movie moguls who may run short:

Robert Moran's Eclectic Music Played at WBAl

But Mr. Moran, to judge from an evening of his works presented Friday at the WBAI Free Music. Store by members of Buffalo's Center for the Creative and Performing Arts, remains stylistically very much a San Francisco composer.

title: Dr. Rhys Williams Hays, 49, U. of Wisconsin Medievalist
description: Dr. Rhys Williams Hays, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin who specialized in the medieval period, died Friday at Stevens Point, Wis., of internal injuries after having suffered a fall two weeks ago. He was 49 years old.

title: Consumer Chief: Think Before You Act
News of the Realty Trade
description: The Bank of Boston International, a wholly owned subsidiary of the First National Bank of Boston, will abandon Wall Street and move to the General Motors Building at 767 Fifth Avenue.

title: A Year in Europe To Cure the Blues
description: No one is less suited to the role of citizen of the world than I. Several decades ago I was transplanted from South Carolina to the North, but every April I get homesick. Watching spring unfold outside the train window while traveling south is all the adventure I need. Charley and I have stayed on in the same house in the same Connecticut suburb while our neighbors have come and gone with alarming frequency and our children have grown and left home. The small maple tree in the field has become a big maple.

title: A FREED ACTIVIST SEES NO CHANGE
description: Nothing has changed, Martin Sostre, the black Puerto Rican who came to symbolize the prisoner's rights movement while spending all but three of the last 23 years of his life in state jails, said last week on the second day of his freedom.

title: IndiaBangladesh Inquiry

description: WHEN the United States struck down parts of the 1974 campaign spending law, Representative Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, went to see Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, chairman of the House Administration Committee, which put the law together in the first place.

title: Alberto Mondadori, Member Of Italian Publishing Family
description: VENICE, Feb. 14 (AP)Alberto Mondadori, a member of Italy's major publishing family, died of a heart attack today while vacationing here. He was 62 years old.

title: Builders Year: The Long Sleep
The Heifetz Of The Horn
Still Building at 79
description: WHEN Frank Gumina was 12 years old, his father died, leaving him with one thought: Go to America. At 15, with only two years schooling behind him and a future that immigrants of 1913 knew awaited them in this country, the youth left Italy to do exactly what legend said could be done. He becat..e a millionaire.

title: Eric Talks to the PDP8
description: THE average teenager might brag about his 10speed, allaluminum French racing bike. Or Japanese seethroughthelens, automatic 35mm. camera. Or fully nylon featherweight Scandinavkin backpack.

title: Jim Clark: An Ordinary Human Being Who Found His Vocation
description: There is no archetypal race driver, and the next world champion could be that unemployed guy you see collecting his benefitas in the case of Graham Hillor else the cocky little kid down the road with the flashy Austin Healey and the jaunty walk to match, like Jackie Stewart. The emergence of a world champion racing driver is not the result of selective breeding, of tender or rich upbringing, or of opportunities served up on a silver plate, but rather the result of a strange chemistry, the ingredients of which exist in nearly all of us, but not in the correct proportions. Why is it that, years after his death, motor racing enthusiasts around the world still revere the name of Jim Clark? Why is it that the 1974 Indianapolis winner, Johnny Rutherford, on receiving the Jim Clark Memorial Trophy in the United States some time ago, said, I know now that I think about him so much and only wish that I could better emulate his.example in every way? Why is it that, when the Russian cosmonaut, Yury Gagarin, shook hands with Clark, he said, I suppose you'll be as proud of me as I am of you?

title: Mary G. Scripps Becomes Fiancee Of Student Here
description: Mary Gibbs Scripps, a greatgreatgranddaughter of James E. Scripps, founder of The Detroit News, and Jeffrey Dieffenbach plan to marry in June.

title: Angola's Neighbors Are Fearful
Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Benchley: Success Is a Maneater
description: PRINCETON IT'S a strange feeling, says Peter Benchley, having people loathe you, hate your guts, in the abstract, when they haven't even met you. You don't have a chance to explain, present your side of it, argue that, really, I'm not such a rotten guy.

title: 4 More African Countries Said to Recognize Luanda
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)  Four more African countries were reported today to have recognized the Luanda Government of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.

title: The Bacchae: A Revival of Dionysiac Revelry
description: In the script, it's called dionysiac revelry. It is defined as what happens when an impetuous Greek god chases all the women out of town. But in Princeton, a burst of latterday dionysiac revelry has led to two productions of ancient Athenian dramas by students who have donned grotesque masks and flowing robes, and assembled themselves into chanting choruses.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: TV VIEW
description: The stender, somewhat fragile looking man enters the house, goes to the closet, exchanges his suit jacket for a cardigan sweater and sits down to take off his shoes and put on casual sneakers. He smiles shyly at the camera and, in a soft and rather tentative voice, sings a series of questions: Would you be mine, could you be mine . . . Please won't you be my neighbor? This wholly nonthreatening figure is, of course, Fred Rogers, the creator, writer, composer and host of Mister Rogers Neighborhood, the longestrunning children's program on public television. This week, beginning tomorrow, five new halfhours will be used to introduce a gigantic rerun of 460 Mister Roger's Neighborhood episodes. Specially updated, the library will fill a MondaythroughFriday cycle for 92 weeks.

title: Women's College Quintets Vie for Fans Equal Favor
Three Riders Tie For Jumper Title
When ShowandTell Is a Mortal Game
The Spillover From New York's Default
Alvan Schulman Weds Eugenia Shanklin
description: Dr. Eugenia Shanklin of Princeton, N.J., an assistant professor of anthropology at Trenton State College, was married here yesterday evening to Alvan M. Schulman, president of Marvin Josephson Associates Inc., a New Yorkbased company whose main operating division is International Creative Management, a theatrica ltalent agency.

title: Tug Crews Vote to Rejoin The I.L.A. After 22 Years
description: Local 333, United Marine Division. the 8,000member labor union that represents tugboat workers in the port, came home last week. Results on a union referendum made public last week showed that an overwhelming majority of the independent local was in favor of rejoining the International Longshoremen's Association, from which it had seceded in 1954.

title: Namath Deal Hamstrung
description: Joe Namath believes he needs another operation, this time to repair a torn hamstring muscle in his left leg. The hamstring, says the New York Jets quarterback, limits my mobility more than my knees do. Strangely, the hamstring injury occurred nearly two years ago in a Bahamas waterskiing accident when his towrope snapped. Throughout the last two seasons it was seldom menby either Namath or the Jets medical staff. Now it has emerged as a factor that hamstrung the Los Angeles Rams as much as the quarterback's $450,000 salary in the recent trade discussions. Quietly, the Rams are still thinking about acquiring Joe Namath, but his hamstring ailment must be clarified.

title: TENNECO REPORTS SENSITIVE GIFTS IN U.S. AND ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14In a report on what it called apparently improper practices, Tenneco Inc., a Houstonbased conglomerate, has admitted paying $500,000 to the military in a foreign country for protection of employees working in remote, dangerous locations and for rental of aircraft and equipment. It did not name the country.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE 70YEAR EXISTENCE OF THE W. T. GRANT COMPANY was ended as a Federal judge ordered its liquidation in the next 60 days, wiping out the jobs of 24,000 employees. Possible purchasers, however, of all or some of Grant's remaining 359 stores are reported to be S. S. Kresge Company and the Greyhound Corporation.

title: Korea's Atomic Reversal
description: For the first time, France has cooperated with the United States in the struggle to halt the spread of nuclear weapons around the world, and the result has been a major victory for nonproliferation.

title: IRAN SEEKS TO END WIDE TAX EVASION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14The Iranian Government. hoping to shrink its budget deficit, plans a vast campaign against corporate taxevasion as well as other forms of corruption, wellplaced Iranian and Western informants reported this week.

title: PANEL CITES DOUBT ON COLD REMEDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. I4Few of the active ingredients in cough and cold remedies sold without prescription can be rated safe and effective, a panel, of experts has concluded after a review that has taken more than three years.

title: Cochran Hill Ski Area: A Family Affair in More Ways Than One
description: RICHMOND, Vt.Jon Perry, 9 years old, muscled into a group of people in the steamy lodge who were talking about why they liked to ski on Cochran Hill. Then he blurted out: I figure if the Cochrans four kids could go to the Olympics, it must be a pretty good course. That's part of the story. Mickey and Ginny Cochran taught their four children to ski on their own backyard slopes and every one of them went on to fame if not fortune, Mrs. Cochran says.

title: Angolan Leader Counsels Nationalists to Begin Guerrilla War Against Foe
Daytona Beach: Tumult and Shouting
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14All right now, who here in this room wants David Pearson to win?

description: By Gordon Thomas and Max Morgan Witts. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $8.95.

title: HAWAIIANS DEMAND REPARATIONS OF U.S.
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 14Descendants of native Hawaiians who lost vast amounts of land in the overthrow of Queen Liliuokalani in the 1890's are asking for reparations estimated at $35 billion.

title: A Favorite Restaurant
Islanders, Knicks Defeat 76ers, 10197
J.D. Campbell Weds Jean Walker
description: The marriage of Jean Burton Walker, a freelance writer, to John David Campbell, a senior securities analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, took place at noon yesterday in Ridgewood, N. J. The parents of the couple are Mrs. Burton Walker of Nashville and Walter V. Walker of Leesburg, Fla., and the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Melvin R. Campbell of Ridgewood. Dr. Campbell performed the ceremony in the West Side Presbyterian Church, of which he is pastor.

title: High Adventure and Blinding Speed: Copter Skiing, Bobsledding
description: Hundreds of feet below us, vast sheets of perfect whiteness, snowdusted cliffs and clumps of dark green firs rolled past. When we hit, jump out two feet from the helicopter and squat down, shouted our guide as the helicopter churned over the frozen peaks of Utah's Snowbird ski resort. With a bounce, we settled down on a narrow ridge 10,000 feet up in the Wasatch Range.

title: Cruise Missile Launched
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 14 (AP)The United States has made a successful underwater test launching of a lowflying, subsonic cruise missile. The Tomahawk, one of two cruise missile designs being tested by the Navy, was launched yesterday from a submerged torpedo tube off the San Diego coast near San Clemente Island, a Navy spokesman said.

title: Up from underground
description: BOSTON. A bearded young man carrying a stack of tabloid newspapers daringly picked his way through rushhour traffic across from the Boston Public Garden on Arlington Street, peering in the car windows of commuters and shoppers and outoftown visitors, shouting with mock urgency: Buy a hippie newspaper! Read all about itdope, sex, communes. orgies! Get in on the underground!

title: Home Design Is Life and Death For Disabled
Water, Water Everywhere: Johnstone Putting Boats on It
description: Sailing, which has generally been regarded as a pastime of the leisure classes, is evolving to the point where access and expenses are within the realm of most people. Bob John stone is seeing to that. Last winter Johnstone looked at the bleak Chicago Walerfront and envisioned Lake Michigan covered with small sailboats. But he found that the waterfront was restricted to harbor boats and that sailing was dying in nearby Wilmette, Ill. The result was Sail 75, an innovative public sailing program started last summer in Wilmette.

title: Environmentalists Map Biggest Political Year
description: WASHINGTON  Environmental activists are gearing up for what they expect to be their most influential political campaign year yet.

title: Kerry B. Noll Becomes Bride Of T.J. Muzyka
SixTeam League In Lacrosse Folds
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 14 (AP) Gerry Patterson, commissioner of the National Lacrosse League, said yesterday that the sixteam league would disband before the opening of the 1976 season because of financial uncertainties.

title: Women to Be Reserve Pilots In South African Air Force
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Women pilots are to fly parttime In the South African Air Forceprovided they have their own planes and at least 150 hours of solo flying.

title: City's Building Industry Faces Still Harder Times
description: New York City's oncedynamic construction industry, already in its worst tailspin since the Depression, faces still bleaker days and there is no indication whenor whetherthings might get better.

In addition to the traditional florist and gardencenter sources, plant boutiques and bargain outlets have sprung up in nearly every shopping area to meet the demand. The sight of green leaves protruding from a brown paper bag is not uncommon in any crowd of shoppers.

title: Rutgers President Looks Ahead in Anger
description: NEW JERSEYANS see and read more about Mayor Beame and Governor Carey and their money woes than they do about their own state's fiscal problems. But not only are New Jersey's fiscal difficulties dwarfed by New York's, they are very different in nature. Basically, New York has borrowed until it is broke. New Jersey, a rich state, simply likes to pretend it is poor.

title: Winthrop Minot to Wed Gale O. Winslow in June
description: The engagement of Gale Oakley Winslow to Winthrop Gardner Minot has been announced by Dr. Thomas Scudder Winslow of New York, father of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Hobart Amory Hare Cook of Greenwich, Conn., and the late William Amory Gardner Minot.

title: Bentsen Backers Eye Humphrey

Many of them say theh are uncommitted since Mr. Bentsen's exit announcement last week, but they are also talking about Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota as either their next preference or their next cover.

Moynihan from the United Nations is now generally being treated by Administration officials and news media opinionmakers as an amusing aside, News perhaps a mere Analysis matter of politics or personality, just another coming and going in the world of powerseekers. It was that, but it also revealed something much deeper about how Washington works.

description: A 26yearold Brooklyn man died, apparently of drowning, yesterday afternoon when a twoman kayak flipped over in a choppy channel in Jamaica Bay, the police reported.

description: BERKELEY TOWNSHIP, Feb. 15Representatives of eight boards of education in Ocean County yesterday approved a proposal to defy state law and cancel schoolbudget elections scheduled for March 2. Representatives of all 29 boards in the county are expected to meet here next Wednesday to consider countywide endorsement of the proposal.

title: Newark Diocese Episcopalians Confer With Bishop Candidates
description: SADDLE BROOK, Feb. 15The event was billed as meet the candidates and nearly 700 people assembled yesterday in the Marriott Motor Hotel here to assess the seven men who sought their backing.

description: Of Nuclear Energy and U.S. Survival

title: A Touch of the Critic
description: Jewish writers don't write about their children: they write about their childhood. I think it was Graham Greene who said that an unhappy childhood is a writer's goldmine.

title: Foes Treat Top Teams Rudely
description: On a day dedicated to expressions of love and endearment, a bunch of underdog college basketball teams displayed not a sign of affection for top ranked opponents on Saturday. When St. Valentine's Day ended, there were two prominent victims and a host of gasping survivors.

title: Developers Degrading Thai Resort
description: PHATTHAYA, Thailand, Feb. 11  Two years ago Phatthaya was a quiet, idyllic beach resort, the green palm trees rustling quietly over the bleached sand along the Gulf of Siam.

title: Taiwan Makes Use Of Military Trials In Fight on Crime
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 15The Nationalist Government here has adopted a stronger policy in combating crime by assigning certain robbery cases to military courts and making more frequent use of capital punishment.

title: Robin Stieber Bride of Victor Komisar
description: Robin Sue Stieber, who is in the municipalbond department of Weeden & Company here, was married yesterday at noon to Victor Komisar, a tax accountant with Cushman & Wakefield Inc., realtors. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Garrick Ohlsson Plays Chopin Honestly, Beautifully
description: Can any other pianist play Chopin at once more honestly and beautifully than Garrick Ohlsson? The question was prompted by Mr. Ohlsson's Tully Hall recital Saturday night. He devoted it to the Polish composer and focused attention upon two forms  polonaises and mazurkas.

title: 5 Brooklyn Composers Grace Philharmonia Concert

description: Intense fare competition, unusual in the airline industry, has broken out among the major domestic carriers, bringing new bargains to the nonbusiness traveler.

title: . . . a Rescue Device
description: The arts are, in fact, seriously threatened; they face huge and increasing deficits. Along with the city itself, many institutions are fighting for survival. The Museum of Modern Art has found one way out that might reverse disaster in its own case, and hold hope for other of the city's cultural institutions as well.

title: Latin America at Last
description: In his first mission abroad after President Nixon named him Secretary of State in 1973, Henry A. Kissinger called on the President of Mexico and said the visit underlines the importance we shall attach to relations with Latin America. A short time later he signed with Panama's Foreign Minister an agreement on eight principles to govern negotiation of a new canal treatya significant advance which he followed with a successful meeting in Mexico with 24 hemisphere foreign ministers.

HANOCH GIVTON, AN ISRAELI CONSUL
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP) Hanoch Givton, consulgeneral of Israel, died yesterday of a heart attack, a consulate spokesman said, in Midway Hospital, where he was admitted Tuesday suffering from pneumonia. He was 58 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15The invitation from President and Mrs. Ford mentioned a professional athletes prayer brunch in the White House at 11 A.M. It was a bright, breezy morning, and several strollers were being turned away from the northwest gate when a group arrived that included Forrest Gregg, who was an allpro tackle with the Green Bay Packers, and Raymond Berry, an inmate of the pro football Hall of Fame who now helps Gregg coach the Cleveland Browns. This isn't a tour? one of the passersby asked. when the athletes were admitted with their wives. No. Well, say hello to Jerry for me. The group went inside where an orchestra was playing. Gregg looked around with silent approval. There is a faint edge of gray in the big man's haircut but his face showed none of the ravages of his first season as a head coach, a season he has described as an experience I don't need again. Now as he gazed around, a man told him: You're in the White House. Where do you suppose you'd be if you had a winner?

title: H.E.W. COMPLAINS OF LOW MANPOWER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has told the courts that the Ford Administration will not provide the department with the manpower it needs to fulfill its legal obligation to investigate and correct discrimination.

title: Esposito Scores 2 Against Scouts
Zambian Leader Foresees A Bloodbath in Rhodesia
Posters in Shanghai Said to Attack Teng As a Khrushchev
description: PEKING, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping was alluded to today as China's second raw Khrushchev in wall posters appearing at Shanghai University, informed suurces said.

title: Casting a Lifebuoy
description: Hope dies hard. Even in that grim, disturbing portrait of a welfare mother that appeared in a recent issue of The New Yorker, there are a few barely detectable flashes of aspiration and ambition. Carmen Santana, the subject of the article, surveys the wreckage of her life and murmurs the faintest appeal for help, for some kind of work that will bring purpose and direction to her life.

title: Where French Bidders See Red
ULSTER SOLDIERS GET PRESS CARDS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Monday, Feb. 16 (AP)The British Army acknowledged today that it had issued false press cards to soldiers serving in Northern Ireland.

TOWN IS DROPPING NUN PROSECUTION
description: The Borough Council of Glen Ridge, N. J., has decided to drop charges against five Roman Catholic nuns accused of violating a zoning ordinance by living together in a 10room, onefamily house.

title: The Stage: Every Night
Alexander Saunders, 67, Dead; Hudson River Conservationist
description: Alexander Saunders, president of Alexander Saunders & Company, international suppliers of foundry equipment, and a leading conservationist, died yesterday in Butterfield Hospital in Cold Spring, N. Y. He was 67 years old and lived in nearby Garrison, N.Y.

title: $431 Million Relief Aid May Be Lost by the City
description: The Federal and state governments may disallow as much as $431 million in welfare rent costs that the city has paid since 1968, according to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt. These are claims for which it has already been reimbursed, so the money would be withheld from future payments.

title: Bailey Confident Now
COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Levies Dull Bahamas Glitter as Tax Haven
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 10This legendary tax havenor offshore financial center, as it prefers to be calledis suffering another of its periodic crises of confidence following the announcement of new levies to close a budget gap and foster Bahamianization of foreigncontrolled enterprises.

title: Knicks Defeat 76ers Again
Sabres Bow, 3 to 1, in Ragged Game
Kathryn Rose Bride of B. I. Gertz
description: Kathryn Ellen Rose, a freelance magazine writer and member of The New York Post features staff, was married here yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Ira Gertz, a lawyer with Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts.

title: Legislature Has Refined Public Relations
Inquiry in Mob Takeover of Business Led to Arrest of Detective in Slaying
description: Colorado and New York officials yesterday said the arrest Saturday night of a city police detective as the hired killer of a Denver businessman was a result of an investigation of an underworld takeover of a business conglomerate.

title: Gerulaitis Defeated By Borg
description: TORONTO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Bjorn Borg steadied his game after a poor start and beat Vitas Gerulaitis, 26, 63, 61, in the final of the World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Doctorate for Menahin Is a First for Sorbonne
description: PARIS, Feb. 15For the first time, a musician has been awarded an honorary doctorate by Paris's 719yearold Sorhonne university.

title: Maria Regina Trackmen Take Title in C.H.S.A.A.
Superhousekeepers: The Women Behind the Successful Women
description: Behind every successful working woman, there isideallyanother woman who takes the children to Scout meetings and bandages their bruises, who keeps the dust from accumulating and the laundry from piling up, who copes when the dishwasher goes on the blink and works overtime when her boss has an unexpected evening meeting.

title: Conservative Action Parley Votes Heavily for Reagan
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15 (AP) The Conservative Political Action Conference overwhelmingly voted today in favor of Ronald Reagan for President.

title: Kennedy Queried, but Noncandidacy Is Accepted
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 12 Not one to hide his light, Senafor Edward M. Kennedy has been carefully casting it in a narrow beam to avoid leaving an impression that his Shermanesque withdrawal from Presidential politics this year might be subject to revision.

title: Art and Life ...
description: The arts in New York supply much of this city's strength and style, as well as a substantial part of its revenue. Its unique cultural resources not only are incomeproducingthe current figure is put at $3 billion a yearbut must weigh heavily in any future plan to bring the city back to full health.

title: Avalanches Hit Ski Areas; At Least 9 Dead in France
description: PARIS, Feb. 15 (AP)Avalanches roared down crowded ski slopes at French resorts from the Alps to the Pyrenees today, killing at least nine people, including JeanPierre Augert, a former member of France's national ski team. Several other people were reported missing as rescue teams searched avalanche areas with flashlights.

title: Little Change in Nigerian Policy Foreseen
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 15  Western diplomats said today that Nigeria's foreign policy, especially its vigorous support of the Sovietsupported faction in Angola, was unlikely to change as a result of the assassination Friday of Gen. Murtala Ramat Muhammed, the head of state.

title: Safety of Breeder Reactors Questioned
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15A leading Government expert has said that possible core nuclear explosions in experimental reactors that the Government expects to be built all over the United States is creating great uncertainty regarding their design requirements.

title: F.P.C. RECRUITING EXG.E. OFFICIAL
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15  Whitman Ridgeway, a retired vice president of the General Electric Company who for years sold generating equipment to electric utilities, has been recruited to head the Federal Power Commission's Bureau of Power.

title: Republicans Chastise Their Legislative Chiefs
description: The state's Republican legislative leadersthe majority leader, Warren M. Anderson of the State Senate, and the minority leader, Perry B. Duryea Jr. of the Assembly were rapped on the knuckles by Republican Party leaders last Tuesday at a private and unannounced luncheon at an Albany restaurant.

title: BURGER ACCUSES CONGRESS OF LAG ON COURT REFORM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger lashed out at Congress again today in his annual State of the Judiciary Message, blaming Congressional inaction for most of the problems now facing the Federal courts.

title: Hilary Elgart Wed To Dr. Valenstein
description: Hilary Elgart, daughter of Mrs. Jack Elgart of Roslyn Heights, and the late Mr. Elgart, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Steven Louis Valenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Valenstein of Baltimore.

title: Screen: 'Chinese Bookie':Cassavetes Is Director of Bland Effort
description: John Cassavetes's "The Killing of a Chinese Bookie," which opened yesterday at the Columbia I and II Theater, is like the last three of the director's films ("A Woman Under the Influence," "Husbands" and "Minnie and Moskowitz") in the way it resolutely refuses to come to a point strong or interesting enough to support the loving care that's gone into its production, particularly on the part of the actors.Watching the film is like listening to someone use a lot of impressive words, the meanings of which are just wrong enough to keep you in a state of total confusion, but occasionally right enough to hold your attention. What is he trying to say? It takes a little while to realize that maybe the speaker not only doesn't know but doesn't even care to think things out. He hopes that if he continues to talk he may happen upon a truth as if it were a found object.Though "A Woman Under the Influence" contained an impressive performance by Gena Rowlands as a truly mad housewife, the film never succeeded in establishing her in any convincing frame of family or society. She was one woman with her bag of tricks doing her show on a barren stage. The film lacked a consistent point of view, or perhaps it had as many as it had actors, director and cameramen."The Killing of a Chinese Bookie" has nothing to compare with the spectacle of the Rowlands performance in "A Woman Under the Influence," but next to that earlier film it's virtually Bressonian in the rigidity of its purpose and style. It even has a story of sorts.The story doesn't always make sense, but supporters of Mr. Cassavetes can argue that narrative coherence is not his bag. My suspicion is that either the film has been sloppily edited or that the director has no film idea on how to film the sort of sequences in which one actor with a gun stalks another actor with a gun in a dark garage. In the trade this is known as an action sequence and it quickly becomes rather too existential if you can't figure out who is stalking whom, or why."The Killing of a Chinese Bookie" is about Cosmo Vitelli (Ben Gazzara), the owner of a tacky nightclub on Hollywood's Sunset Strip, and Cosmo's troubles when the mob coerces him into carrying out a contract murder in order to pay off a $23,000 gambling debt. That's the story, but the film has less interest in story than in character, for which, in Mr. Cassavetes's vocabulary, you may also read actor.Mr. Cassavetes's way of film making is to set up actors, whom he admires, trusts and finds endlessly fascinating, in situations in which they are as likely to philosophize about acting as about life. Actingperformanceis a legitimate metaphor for certain kinds of lives but by the end of "The Killing of a Chinese Bookie" you may rightfully expect more than you have actually received. This includes a lot of enigmatic snatches of Cosmo's nightclub shows, bits and pieces of intentionally awful sketches, as well as Cosmo's relationships to his "girls" and his emcee (a self-described "freak," played with good, self-contained desperation by Meade Roberts, the screen writer.Perhaps because of the limitations imposed on Mr. Cassavetes by his screenplay, his actors are more restrained than they have been in his past efforts, though some of them are nice to see because they are familiar, especially Seymour Cassel (so good in "Faces" and "Minnie and Moskowitz") who plays a polite mobster.Mr. Gazzara is also comparatively restrained, or perhaps inhibited, by the requirements of the particular character he's playing here. It's a thoughtful, intelligent interpretation of a role that just may not have as much depth to it as he's ready to give it. Like the movie itself, it is, finally, bland.

title: Lover of the City
description: Joseph G. Herzberg's formal education ended in high school, but few professors could rival him in depth or universality of knowledge. He was erudite in every field from art to zoology, but New York City was his special love, and his passion for making sense of its lunacies contributed to the formidable record he established as city editor of The New York Herald Tribune in the years of its greatness.

title: 50 Picket Movie House To Protest Violent Film
description: About 50 people, some accompanied by children, picketed a movie house in the Times Square area yesterday to protest the showing of a film purporting to show scenes of sadism, atrocities and murder.

title: Lincoln Unity Spirit Mends Florida Rift
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 15The Presidential primary as party irritant was illustrated here in recent days by a squabble over the annual Lincoln Day fundraising dinner of the Orange County Republican Committee.

title: Fare Cutting Intensifies Among Domestic Airlines
description: Intense fare competition, unusual in the airline industry, has broken out among the major domestic carriers, bringing new bargains to the nonbusiness traveler.

title: $45 Million of Medicare Funds Goes for Kickbacks, Panel Finds
Flyers Win, 2 to 1, From Canadiens
5 Youths Charged With Felonies In Terror on IRT Subway Train
description: Five teenaged Brooklyn boys who were arrested late Saturday night after passengers on an IRT Lexington Avenue subway train had been terrorized and three persons were injured were charged yesterday with felonious assault, the police reported.

title: Algeria Bars Rabat's Planes
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Algeria has closed its airports to Moroccan aircraft, the Public Works and Communication Ministry has announced.

title: The Public Works Veto
description: By his veto of the $6.2 billion public works bill, President Ford has sharpened the crucial issue of how to deal with the nation's persistent problems of unemployment and inflation.

title: Article 4  No Title
Newton's Other Law Is Hailed on Its Tercentenary
description: As anniversaries go, the event will not be one for mass appeal or public celebration, yet to scientists the world over, to cultural historians and to sociologists this Wednesday has a joyous significance. It will be the tercentenary of one of the most important aphorisms in the history of science and culture, and it was struck off by Sir Isaac Newton on Feb. 18, 1676. It is:

title: Democratic Factions Seek Accord on JobsforAll Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Representatives of three centers of influence in the Democratic Party  the A.F.L.C.I.O., the Congressional Black Caucus and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota  have been quietly negotiating for weeks in an effort to draft legislation that would commit the Government to create a job for everyone who wants to work.
