Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, FEB 16

title: Doctorate for Menuhin Is a First for Sorbonne
Gambia Recognizes Luanda
description: BANJUL, Gambia, Feb. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)Gambia tonight recognized the Angolan government formed in Luanda by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, becoming the 36th member of the Organization of African Unity to do so.

title: City Ballet Winds Up A Season for All Fans
description: Going against the grain has always been the New York City Ballet's most charming perversity. Yesterday the company closed a 14week season that has been remarkable even for an organitation that rarely makes life easy for itself.

title: Winter Olympics End Peacefully
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 15We meet again in Lake lacid were the last official words that rumbled out of the loudspeaker in three languages as the 12th Winter Olympic Games came to a triumphant and peaceful end tonight on the great arch of the Bergisel Hill high over this medieval town. The 1980 Games will be staged in the upstate New York resort.

title: Senators and Bush Heading for a Clash on C.I.A. Journalist Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15A delegation of the Senate Intelligence Committee will meet Tuesday with George Bush, the new Director of Central Intelligence, to request formally the names of journalists who have worked for or with the Central Intelligence Agency, according to Senate aides.

title: Police Battle Busing Foes Marching in South Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15Hundreds of white antibusing demonstrators battled with the police this afternoon in front of South Boston High School.

title: J.C. Snead Triumphs Over Bies by a Shot
$4.2 Million in Cuts Restored
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 (AP)Commissioner Burke has restored $4.2 million to local school budgets from 20 localities across the state. This represents more than 65 percent of the funds cut from local school budgets by the 20 municipal governing bodies. The cuts had been appealed to the Commissioner's office.

title: $431 Million Relief Aid May Be Lost by the City
description: The Federal and state governments may disallow as much as $431 million in welfare rent costs that the city has paid since 1968, according to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt. These are claims for which it has already been reimbursed, so the money would be withheld from future payments.

title: Refugees Termed Homesick
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Feb. 15 (UPI)Dave Lewis, an official of the United States Catholic Conference, said today that many Vietnamese refugees were homesick, but few wanted to return to their homeland. He was the conference's director at Fort Chaffee, the largest refugee camp in the United States, and is directing a followup program to help resettled refugees.

title: Iran, With Oil Income Slipping, Shelves Some Ambitious Projects and Delays Others
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15Plans for the construction of more than $5 billion in petrochemical facilities in Iran have been delayed, set aside or thrown into question in recent months, largely as a result of Iran's lagging oil revenues, according to wellplaced members of the Teheran business community.

title: Article 2  No Title
Mr. Lincoln's CoverUp
description: WASHINGTONA longsealed box preserving the contents of the pockets of Abraham Lincoln on the night he was killed was opened last week by the Librarian of Congress, Daniel J. Boorstin. The box contained eleven favorable newspaper clippings and a $5 Confederate bill.

title: India Mine Search Goes On
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 15 (Reuters)A total of 283 bodies have been recovered so far from the scene of India's worst mining disaster at the Chasnala mine in the northeast of the country, officials announced tonight. At least 375 were trapped when the mine flooded Dec. 27.

title: Miss Frederick Retains Pentathlon
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 15 (AP)Jane Frederick, a willowy athlete from Santa Barbara, Calif., retained her national women's Amateur Athletic Union pentathlon title last night and qualified for next month's United StatesSoviet Union dual track meet.

title: Bush Won't Say Angolan Aid By U. S. Intelligence Has Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 George Bush. the Director of Central Intelligence, declined to rule out today the possibility that American intelligence agencies were continuing financial or other support to antiCommunist forces fighting in Angola.

title: American Museum Pinched for Funds
description: John Deola of Brooklyn jabbed his pen toward a periwinkle in a glass display case. What that is, is something like a foot. he announced, pointing at a brownish disc on the mollusk. Amazing, really. I never even knew clams could move.

title: After Circus With Elephants, Garden Getting One With Donkeys
2 Schools Nearing Completion May Be Auctioned by the City
description: Two nearly completed schools in Brooklyn may go on the auction block to help ease the city's fiscal troubles, but the Board of Education and local school officials oppose the plan.

title: WALTER H. CAMPBELL
description: Walter H. Campbell, a senior editor with Penthouse magazine, died yesterday at his home, 33 Stuyvesant Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Philippine Talks Planned
description: MANILA, Feb. 15 (UPI)The United States and the Philippines will open formal talks in Washington in April on a new military bases treaty, President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced here. He said at a news conference that the first round of negotiations between Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romuio will begin April 12.

title: Connally Was for Burning
description: John B. Connally, former Treasury Secretary, said in a television interview yesterday that President Nixon should have lit a bonfire in the Rose Garden of the White House and burned the incriminating Watergate tapes, the Reuters news agency reported.

title: In Rubble Of Quake: Vigilantes
Nigeria's New Head of State
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 15Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, who yesterday was named head of government of the most populous and powerful black nation in the world, is called the Prime Minister by Nigerians, even though News no such title exists in their military government. Man in the News

title: Harris Urges a Halt in Building And Use of Atom Power Plants
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15  Former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma, a Democratic Presidential candidate, called today for a halt in the construction or use of new nuclear power plants. He was joined at a news conference here by two past winners of the Nobel Prize who endorsed his suggestion.

title: Zoning Case Facing Nuns Being Dropped in Jersey
description: The Borough Council of Glen. Ridge, N..J., has decided to drop charges against five Roman Catholic nuns accused of violating a zoning ordinance by living together in a 10room, onefamily house.

title: Chrysler's Plant in Spain Striving for Labor Peace
description: MADRID, Feb. 15The Chrysler Corporation's Spanish subsidiary in nearby Villaverde is now back at work after almost three weeks of disruption, but Renault, one of its major competitors, has not been so lucky.

title: A Moderate on Palestinians Named to High Israeli Post
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 15  The Israeli Cabinet approved today the appointment of Prof. Shlo mo Avineri, a noted political scientist critical of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's policies on Palestinian Arabs. as director general of the Foreign Ministry, the highest post in the civil service.

title: Caucuses Role Vital In Democratic Race
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15For the first time in recent political history, preprimary caucuses in a handful of relatively small states have significantly influenced a contest for a Presidential nomination.

title: Kraftco Will Close Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (UPI)The Kraftco Corporation will close its Scaliest Foods division bottling plant here by September, company and union officers announced, throwing 200 employees out of work.

title: After Circus With Elephants, Garden Will Get One With Donkeys
Craft Union Votes To End Walkout At Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) Members of one of six striking craft unions at The Washington Post voted 129 to 58 today to accept a contract offer from the newspaper's management and return to work.

title: OFFICIALS DIVIDED ON SPY AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Sharp disputes within the Administration over proposals to control the intelligence agencies could delay President Ford's announcement of reforms and dilute their impact, Administration sources said today.

title: The Critical Worlds of Irving Howe
description: It comes as rather a surprise that Irving Howe is so affable. Much of what he has had to say about politics and culture for the last 30 years has been gloomy. There is a poem by Wallace Stevens, Esthetique du Mal, about the politics of emotion and the logical lunatics who serve those politics, who would walk by the lake at Geneva and not be aware of the lake ... not be aware of the clouds,/ Lighting the martyrs of logic with white fire. One thinks of Mr. Howe, walking the banks of the Hudson, as the sort of person who always notices the clouds and carries a skeptical umbrella.

title: Nigeria: A Coup Fails
description: The only thing entirely clear so far about the attempt of a small group of army officers to overthrow Nigeria's military Government is that it was badly conceived. Evidently, the selfstyled Young Revolutionaries thought it would be sufficient to murder the head of state, Gen. Murtala Ramat Muhammed, seize Radio Nigeria and broadcast nroclamations of their takeover.

title: Army Will Put Off Shift of Employees From Ft. Monmouth
description: FORT MONMOUTH, Feb. 15 The Army has agreed not to transfer any more employees from Fort Monmouth until a suit contesting the transfers can be heard in Federal Court, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: Humphrey Wins Nomination Of Convention at Bowdoin
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 15Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has maintained that he is not a candidate, won the nomination for President today at Bowdoin Colleges threeday model Democratic National Convention.

title: West Orange Honors Edison's Centenary
description: WEST ORANGE  Residents of this community paid tributed Saturday to Thomas Alva Edison, celebrating the opening of his experimental laboratory 100 years ago.

title: ANNA E. GROSSO
description: Anna E. Grosso, retired chief pharmacist at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, died Friday in the hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 1536 East 3Sth Street in Brooklyn.

title: HEARST JURY HELD INFORMED ON CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb, 15An 879page court transcript discloses that most of the people selected for the Patricia Hearst jury had extensive knowledge, through news accounts, of incidents involving the defendant, from her kidnapping two years ago to her arrest last September.

title: 3 in Plane Crash Saved
description: SORRENTO, La., Feb. 15 (UPI)Sheriff's deputies waded through swampland infested by snakes and alligators today to rescue three persons stranded for 20 hours with the wreckage of a singleengine plane. Those rescued were Hugh Moore, 25 years old; Penny McGinty, 25, and Susan McGinty, 18, all of Alexandria, La.

title: Article 3  No Title

description: Unable to balance its budget over three years simply by squeezing, New York City will make a serious effort through its amended fiscal plan to shift some functions to Albany and Washington, according to Donald Kummerfeld, the City Budget Directordesignate.

title: Ashe in Semifinals
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 15 (Reuters)The W.C.T. tournament resumed here today after having been suspended for two days because of an attemped government coup.

description: Susan Wagner High School scored 181 points and won its sixth straight Staten Island Public Schools Athletic League winter track and field championship yesterday at the Curtis High Field.

title: Policy on Aliens Opposed
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Ed Davis, Los Angeles police chief, said last night that the United States had a no win policy in efforts to stem a tide of illegal aliens that is flooding the nation and taking jobs away from Americans. Chief Davis, in an address to the National Border Patrol Council, accused the Federal Government of refusing to face the fact that illegal aliens are not free and cheap labor.

title: Rosewall Beats Laver
description: KEAUHOUKONA, Hawaii, Feb. 15 (AP)Ken Rosewall, displaying his allcourt form, defeated his fellow Australian, Rod Laver, 64, 61, 63. and won the $10,000 winnertakeall W.C.T. Avis Challenge Cup match today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Debate Is Narrowing Over Nuclear Safety
description: Statements by both opponents and supporters of nuclear power indicate that the recent resignations of several industry and government safety engineers have come as the technical issues concerning the safety of atomic energy are narrowing, rather than widening. Instead, the debate about nuclear safety appears to be shifting toward issues that could be called sociological or institutional. The main concern is whether nuclear fuel processors, the electric utility industry and the agencies that oversee them are organized so as to maintain maximum pressure for nuclear safety. Technical concern about the possibility of major releases of radioactivity from nuclear powerplant accidents has received wide public attention for more than five years, virtually since the first nuclear plants with a capacity of more than 500 million watts began supplying electricity in the United States in 1969. News.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: It is a question that will seem in the minds of many readers about as moot as how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. But we've spent a good deal of time recently pondering the best and most efficient technique for serving Stilton cheese. Do you scoop it with a scoop or with a spoon and leave a standing rim, or slice and cut the cheese with knife, serving the rim as well?

title: The Politics Of Patriotism
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15When someone who has suffered an apparent embarrassment chooses to dramatize it, we begin to wonder. Why protest so much? Was it really a defeat? Or might the episode be useful to the seething loser for some unseen purpose?

title: Israel Extends Restrictions On Currency for Travelers
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 (AP)The Israeli Government imposed new fiscal restrictions today on Israelis traveling abroad and on imported services in a move to bolster dwindling foreign currency reserves and encourage exports.

title: Wendy Blatt Bride Of Paul Glassman
Winter Olympics End Peacefully
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 15We meet again in Lake Placid were the last official words that rumbled out of the loudspeaker in three languages as the 12th Winter Olympic Games came to a triumphant and peaceful end tonight on the great arch of the Bergisel Hill high over this medieval town. The 1980 Games will be staged in the upstate New York resort.

title: Inquiry in Mob Operations Led To Detective's Arrest in Killing
description: Colorado and New York officials yesterday said the arrest Saturday night of a city police detective as the hired killer of a Denver businessman was a result of an investigation of an underworld takeover of a business conglomerate.

title: MOROCCANS TELL OF SAHARA LOSS
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 15 (AP)Algerian regular forces have recaptured the desert outpost of Amgala from Moroccan troops in Western Sahara. the Moroccan Government announced today.

title: BOBBI BAIRD SINGS AT THE BALLROOM
description: Amid the kitsch and camp that frequently pass for talent on the local cabaret circuit, Bobbi Baird stands out like a beacon. Although Miss Baird, a striking woman whose blond hair frames a strong, firm face, is making her first extended supperclub appearance, at the Ballroom, 458 West Broadway just below Houston Street, she is a polished, accomplished Performer.

title: Pel the Traveling Salesman: Foot's on the Ball, Not in a Door
New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Carey's office has asked the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, for a report on the Nov. 2 death of Maryjane Dahl, a 16yearold who had been in a coma for eight days before she died in Nassau Hospital, after her respirator was disconnected. Patrick Beary, legislative chairman of the Diocesan Union of Holy Name Societies of the Diocese of Brooklyn, said Judah Gribetz, the Governor's counsel, reported the request after his organization urged last month that a special prosecutor supersede Mr. Dillon. Mr. Dillon had said that the evidence did not warrant grandjury action, but Mr. Beary contended that the case could open the door to euthanasiamercy killings.

title: Neal Rosenau Marries Hedda Ribolow
description: Hedda Joy Ribolow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ribolow of Brooklyn, was married in Commack, L.I., yesterday afternoon to Neal B. Rosenau, son of Mrs. Herbert Hagenow of La Porte, Ind., and the late Martin E. Rosenau. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Berman, brotherinlaw and sister of the bride.

title: Patricia Taner Has Nuptials
description: Patricia R. Taner and John M. Leff, secondyear medical students at the State University's Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Justice James J. Leff of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. Leff of New York. Justice Leff performed the ceremony.

title: BURGER ACCUSES CONGRESS OF LAG ON COURT REFORM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger lashed out at Congress again today in his annual State of the Judiciary Message, blaming Congressional inaction for most of the problems now facing the Federal courts.

title: About New York
description: WINDHAM, N.Y., Feb. 15  The New Yorkers were coming down the ski slope in various attitudes of grace. Some more or less bounced; others did it with style. The best ones among them were the children. They had no fear. They smiled. There were children all over the ski slope.

title: NoFault GuiltFree History
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. ot long ago I finished giving a course about Nazi Germany to 100 Harvard undergraduates. Although I've given a somewhat similar course on the same subject before, the reactions of my students this time were different, even puzzlingand in the end quite disconcerting.

title: Wallace Gets 49% in Mississippi Vote
FARMERS FEARFUL OF MILK DUMPING
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15 (AP)Many of New York State's dairy, farmers may be forced toi dump millions of gallons of milk at substantial losses this spring because there are not enough plants to process the milk, Richard McGuire, State Farm Bureau president, warned today.

title: Three Are Now Reported Dead In Rebellion in Saigon Church
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  A South Vietnamese security officer told reporters today that two dissidents were killed and five, including a priest, were arrested Friday when security forces crushed an armed rebellion at a Roman Catholic Church.

title: Humphrey Tied With Ford, Ahead of Reagan in Survey
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's popularity as a Presidential candidate, even though he has not announced his candidacy, has grown to the point that his support now matches that of President Ford and slightly exceeds that of former Gov. Ronald Reagan, according to the latest survey by the Gallup Poll.

title: DR. LEO STERN DEAD; AN ORAL SURGEON, 78
description: Dr. Leo Stern, who retired in 1958 as director of the dental service at Mount Sinai Hospital and as clinical professor at its medical school, died yesterday at his home, 200 East 78th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: WURF UNION QUITS A.F.L.C.I.O.BRANCH
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, largest public employee union in the A.F.L.C.I.O., withdrew today from the federation's Public Employee Department, charging that membership was a waste of time and money.

title: OFFICIALS DIVIDED ON SPY AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Sharp disputes within the Administration over proposals to control the intelligence agencies could delay President Ford's announcement of reforms and dilute their impact, Administration sources said today.

title: Englishman Held in Threat
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15 (UPI)Peter Jackson, 25 years old, of London, was jailed today awaiting a hearing before a Federal magistrate on charges of telling the crew of a National Airlines jet that there was a bomb aboard the plane. The authorities said Mr. Jackson was restrained by crew members and passengers as the plane flew over Bermuda yesterday, 90 minutes from Miami on a flight from London.

title: HIRAM J. BEHRMAN
description: Hiram J. Behrman, a founder of the New York accounting firm of H. J. Behrman & Company, died yesterday in Great Neck, L. I. He was 93 years old.

title: GEICO'S TROUBLES LAID TO LOW RATES
description: Persistent campaigns by the nation's automobile insurance companies for swift and substantial rate increases received unexpected aid from the brush with disaster reported last month by the Government Employees Insurance Company, one of the nation's major automobile insurers.

title: Michele Ingrassia Wed to Bruce Haber
description: Michele Ingrassia of Hollis, Queens, a reporter on the Nassau County staff of Newsday, was married last evening to Bruce J. Haber, an assistant vice president and account executive for the United Viriginia Factors Corporation here. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, LI., assisted by the Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic Driest.

title: Boston Sunday Globe Poll Finds 61% Favoring Udall
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15 (AP)Massachusetts voters look most favorably upon Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona among the Democratic candidates in the state's Presidential primary, according to a poll conducted for The Boston Sunday Globe. It reported that 61 percent of those reached said their opinion of Mr. Udall was favorable.

title: Tedd Joselson Makes Piano Debut
description: Tedd Joselson, the pianist who made his New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, is only 24 years old, but already he has had an unusual career. Without benefit of a major competition victory or other publicitygathering triumph, he has won a record contract and a number of engagements on the major concert circuit, mostly through the championing of Eugene Ormandy. But whether he is yet a great performerthe slogan under which Lincoln Center seems locked into presenting recitalists  seems to question.

title: Miss Godwin's Gamut
description: Books of The Times

title: HENRY BEROL DEAD; RAISED DOGS, HORSES
Syrian Confers With Lebanese To Build Support for Reforms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 15Syria's chief mediator in the Lebanese crisis, Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Xhaddam, today continued his round of meetings with political figures to consolidate support for the reforms announced last night by President Suleiman Franjieh and to plan the next stages of political evolution in the country.

title: Pearson Crashes but Is Victor
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15  After 499 miles of racing on asphalt, the $350,000 Daytona 500 was decided on the turf today following a dramatic collision between those old rivals, Richard Petty and David Pearson. The crash sent their cars spinning off the wall and onto the grass between the pit row and the track at Daytona International Speedway.

title: STEWART HENSLEY, A U.P.I. REPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)  Stewart Hensley, chief diplomatic and State Department reporter for United Press International who covered major international developments in Asia, Europe, Latin America and the Middle East for more than 30 years, died today at George Washington Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Latin Americans Hope Kissinger Trip Will Mend Rift
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15During his Latin American tour this week, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger will be meeting, government leaders who are confused about the kind of relationship they want with Washington, irritated by economic issues between their countries and the United States, and deeply concerned about Mr. Kissinger's ability to forge a foreign policy in the face of mounting opposition from the United States Congress.

title: Cubans Are Voting On New Constitution Decentralizing Rule
description: HAVANA, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Carrier pigeons flew today from remote villages in the Sierra Maestra with early returns in Cuba's first national vote since Fidel Castro seized power in 1959.

title: A Homeowner Commutes For City Welfare Check
description: Twice a month, a 49yearold woman commuted between her home in New Jerseyshe owned the house jointly with her motherand her apartment in Manhattan.

title: Article 3  No Title
Defense Aide to Resign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) President Ford accepted today the resignation of James R. Cowan as Assistant Secretary of Defense, effective March I. The White House press office had no immediate announcement of a successor. Also acknowledged by Mr. Ford was the retirement of Federal Judge Edwin F. Hunter Jr., who served in the Western District of Louisiana since October 1953. His retirement is effective Thursday.

title: N.B.A. Gains By Shortage Of Winners
description: Of the 18 teams in the National Basketball Association, six have winning records. Three of thosethe Boston Celtics, Buffalo Braves and Philadelphia 76ersplay in the Atlantic Division, and only the Golden State Warriors have a winning mark in the nine  team Western Conference. To some the statistical oddities leave the N.B.A.'s credibility open to questions.

title: FORD TO INCREASE BUDGET REQUEST ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  President Ford, changing budget plans he introduced just last month, disclosed today that he would ask Congress to increase spending for elementary. and secondary education in each of the next three fiscal years.

title: Flu Widespread in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 (UPI)One person in every 50 in Britain has the flu, health officials said today. They said about 150 deaths related to the disease were reported last week compared with 79 the week before.

title: Swedish Bus Blast Kills 15
description: JONKOPING, Sweden, Feb. 16 (UP1)A chartered tourist but carrying 44 persons, most of them elderly, burst into flames and exploded near this central Swedish city tonight, killing 15 passengers. The police said 27 others aboard were injured.

title: Winner Take Nothing
description: Because it has been ecstatically reviewed by New York movie critics, I go to see Seven Beauties. We spend two hours in a Nazi concentration camp and see humanity as scum, or willing to become scum in order to survive. The one principled man in the film begs for death. The one with some slight political sense of which way the world is tending drowns himself in a vat of excrement. What has living in New York done to the perceptions of New York film critics?

title: Another U.S. Compromise Position Is Reported Reached on Strategic Arms

description: After an absence of several years, Ivan Rebroff returned to Carnegie Hall, his bantering charm intact, his microphone technique mercifully improved, his stock of (mostly) Russian folk songs as entertaining as ever.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Edward E. Cubberly, a lawyer and deputy manager of Sargent Shriver's campaign for the Presidential nomination, died of cancer yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 36 years old.

description: PARIS, Feb. 16Nearly eight years after the studentled disorders that frightened most of the country, France is becoming concerned again about its young people.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 16The State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus was assured tonight by Governor Carey that the cuts in his austerity budget would not hurt those who have just begun to make it the poor and members of minority groups in the state.

title: 4 Bombs Explode in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Four bombs exploded at Belfast's main post office today in a renewal of the violence that has claimed 11 lives and caused heavy damage since the death of the Irish Republican Army hunger striker, Francis Stagg in an English prison last week.

title: WALLACE MAKES A STOP IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, making the first New York appearance of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said here today that he would field full delegate slates in 25 of New York's 35 districts for the state's April 6 Presidential primary.

title: POOR LANDS SEEK WIDENING OF DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The United States and other industrial countries have just begun to study a new, detailed and relatively sophisticated plan agreed upon by the less developed countries for dealing with the increasingly worrisome problem of their debts.

title: Reserves Being Trained To Face Soviet in Combat
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga. First foxhole you ever dug! a Regular Army captain exclaimed to a squad of National Guardsmen on a recent exercise, adding, Well, the next one may be for real.

title: Juan Carlos Is Met By Strike of 7,000 On Barcelona Visit
description: BARCELONA, Feb. 16King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofia began an official tour of dissident Catalonia today and ran into more dissidencea strike by 7,000 municipal employees angry about their low pay.

description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 George Meany, accusing President Ford of lacking compassion for the jobless, spoke out in favor of a full employment program today and called on Congress to override the President's veto of the $6.2 billion public works bill.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Laws passed by individual states to protect local companies from being acquired by outsiders are threatening the evenhanded administration of securities regulations and may, in fact, not be in the best interests of stockholders, a top official of the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today.

description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 16You gotta, as the old musicalcomedy song said, have a gimmick.

Unradical, Unoriginal, Untried
GRAIN INSPECTION BY U.S. IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and Dick Clark promised legislation today to carry out recommendations by the General Accounting Office for an allFederal grain inspection and weighing system.

title: DEADLINE NEARING ON ELECTIONS UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Congress returns from a holiday recess tomorrow to determine whether and how to continue the Federal Election Commission, which has less than two weeks left under last month's Supreme Court ruling. Unless the Senate and House act to reconstitute the agency within nine working days, the commission will lose all its major powers, Federal campaign subsidies to candidates and conventions will cease and the 1976 Presidential election will proceed virtually unregulated.

title: Relief Rolls Here Drop to Under a Million
description: New York City's welfare rolls dropped below a million persons last November, for the first time since last March, with 997,708 recipients tallied in the latest report given to the State Department of Social Services.

Art: Modern's Tower May Add Pictures at an Exhibition
description: News of the Museum of Modern Art's plan to build a 40  story condominium apartment tower atop its present building on West 53d Street was scarcely out last week before the predictable jokes began making the rounds. And is it true, some wag was heard to ask at an East Side dinner party the other night, that the tenants will get to hold their bar mitzvah parties in the Founders Room? Are they going to offer up a few of their Picassos as a bonus with the bigger apartments? asked another.

title: TRADING IN EUROPE OF DOLLAR IS MIXED
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The dollar had a mixed day on European money markets today as speculative pressures on continental currencies almost disappeared.

title: Failure of Move to Raise Rail Bridges Leads to Effort to Lower Freight Cars
description: City and state officials, frustrated in a longpending program to elevate railroad bridges so that large container and piggyback freight could move on an overland route between upstate terminals and the metropolitan area, now hope to solve the problemby getting lower railroad cars.

description: In a caption accompanying an article in The New York Times yesterday on superhousekeepers, Barbara Barrie, the actress, was incorrectly identified as Barbara Harris.

title: Nets Top Colonels By 10099
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16 (UPI)The New York Nets froze the ball for the final 18 seconds tonight and preserved ,a 10099 victory over the Kentucky Colonels in the American Basketball Association. Julius Erving was the standout for the Nets with 31 points, 13 rebounds and five assists.

title: Electronic Transfer Of Money Is Studied
description: The number of checks being written is growing so fast that it will be many years before electronic transfer of money catches up or brings a decline in check usage, a yearlong study by Arthur D. Little Inc., a Bostonbased consulting organization, concluded yesterday.

title: Music: Lythgoe, Pianist
description: Clive Lythgoe is an individualist, and a valuable one, a British pianist who specializes in American music. In an American musician such a concentration might seem merely jingoistic or provincial; in an Engishman it is the height of handsacrossthesea sophistication. Further, Mr. Lythgoe proves to be a firstrate pianist.

title: 3 CITY COLLEGE ACES AND GAMBLER HELD IN BASKETBALL FIX
BOSTON' ASSESSES 2 NONCANDIDATES
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16If the Democratic Party were a corporation and Gallup Poll preference points were stock, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota would be the largest single shareholders in the party and, in tandem, a controlling bloc.

title: Platform Tennis
description: U.S. MIXED DOUBLES

title: Books of The Times
description: A book about crabs? Don't go away quite yet. There's more to crabsat least the Atlantic blue crabs that live in the Chesapeake Baythan you may think. Marvelous at swimming. they arc capable of darting rapidly in any direction as well as hovering like a helicopter about to deposit a President. Tender at lovemaking, the male (or Jimmy) cradles the mature female (or Sook) until she moults her hard shell, then rears up and copulates for from 6 to 12 hours, then cradles her once more (the two together are called doublers or buck and rider) until her new outer layer grows safely hard again. Prodigious at migrating, Atlantic blues have shown up as far from their home grounds as the Black Sea and the Eastern Mediterranean (from where Israel fishes and sells them for export, since dietary laws prohibit their consumption). A gustatory delight, blue crabs are removed from Chesapeake Bay at the rate of between 150 and 240 million individuals a year, worth approximately $55 million. But not least among the blue crab's many surprising achievements is to have inspired William W. Warner to write Beautiful Swimmers: Watermen, Crabs and the Chesapeake Bay. For into his graceful meditation on this singular creature, Mr. Warner has woven everything from adventure to zoology. And this reader came away as refreshed and stimulated as he would have been by a week's worth of sailing on the Chesapeake.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1976

title: Schneider Gets Post at Juilliard
description: Alan Schneider, considered one of the foremost directors of the avantgrade in the United States, has been named director of the drama division of the Juilliard School in Lincoln Center.

title: Weaver of Power Sets U.S. TwoMile Record
description: When Maurice Weaver passed the mile mark in the twomile run at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday in 4 minutes 35.8 seconds, his coach at Power Memorial, Brother Bielen, was hoping he could beat the meet record of 9:20.

title: Rally Beats Off Purdue, 7471
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 16 (AP)  Undefeated Indiana rallied from an 11 point deficit in the first half and, led by Scott May's 26 points, edged Purdue, 7471, in Big Ten basketball tonight. It was Indiana's 22d straight triumph and 13th in the conference.

title: Judge Mercorella Called In Nadjari S.L.A. Inquiry
description: Judge Anthony J. Mercorella, who is under investigation by a special grand jury seeking to determine whether he purchased his Civil Court judgeship, is also a subject of a special grand jury inquiry into possible corruption in the State Liquor Authority.

title: Music: Cello Elegance
description: Robert Sylvester, who appeared Sunday night as the second artist in the Eastman School of Music faculty series at Alice Tully Hall, might best be described as a slightly imperfect Apollonian cellist.

title: WBAI Faces a Financial Crisis; Manager Planning to Cut Jobs
description: WBAIFM, the listenersupported radio station that has won thousands of adherents by thumbing its nose at the establishment, was reported yesterday to be facing one of the greatest financial problems in its 16year history.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1976

title: Hearst Jury Visits Houses Reported Used by Captors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 The jury in the Patricia Hearst bank robbery trial visited today the two places where Miss Hearst has said she was held in closets for almost two months, tied, blindfolded and brainwashed.

title: The Courtroom Below Patty Hearst's
description: In the same Federal courthouse in San Francisco where the Patty Hearst trial is being conducted on the 19th floor, the Joe Kapp trial will begin next Monday on the 18th floor. His courtroom will be smaller, with only about 50 seats for spectators. And his jury will be smaller, only six instead of a dozen. But his trial looms as one of the most compelling in sports historya peek into the machinations of the National Football League as they affected a tequiladrinking quarterback who thrived on defiance. The primary issue will be whether Sports Joe Kapp was damaged, and if so, how of much, by the N.F.L. contract structure that Federal District Judge William T. Sweigert ruled illegal 14 months ago. One of Kapp's attorneys has predicted that his client might be awarded as much as $10 million in treble damages, surely a minimum of $2 million. Perhaps significantly, if Joe Kapp collects, dozens of other N.F.L. players will be tempted to file suit for having been damaged by the N.F.L.'s refusal to modify its contracts on college drafts after Judge Sweigert's original ruling.

title: The Buck Starts Here
description: DURHAM, N. C.The widespread loss of confidence in American institutions, and the resulting threat of a wholesale dismantling of a generation's legislative achievements, have prompted an urgent need to think seriously about new ways to restore the public's sense of control over government.

title: Death in State Park Studied
description: The State Police in Stony Point, N.Y., are investigating the death of a man whose body was found Saturday by hikers on property owned by St. JohnintheWilderness, a church in Bear Mountain State Park. The man, who had been shot once in the head, was unclothed, and a police spokesman said his fingerprints would be checked for identification by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: No Yonkers Default
description: Yonkers officials completed a stateaided $13.1 million financial package yesterday, averting what would have been a default today. But even as they resolved their fourth such crisis in three months, new financial difficulties loomed. Page 19.

title: No Yonkers Default
description: Yonkers officials completed a stateaided $13.1 million financial package yesterday, averting what would have been a default today. But even as they resolved their fourth such crisis in three months, new financial difficulties loomed. Page 19.

title: Somerset Narrows Agency List
description: Somerset Importers, which was to have decided on an agency for its Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch, last week got down to Friday evening without a final decision. But it did eliminate one of the three contenders, Needham, Harper & Steers, the incumbent. Still in the running are D'ArcyMacManus & Masius and Doherty, Mann & Olshan, a subsidiary of Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Dail Farber Is Married To Phillip Fried Here
description: Dail Farber of Cresskill, N.J., widow of Mitchell Farber, was married here yesterday afternoon to Phillip F. Fried of Fort Lee, N.J. The ceremony in the Garden Room of the Essex House was performed by Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: 12 COUNTRIES SIGN A POLLUTION PACT
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 16 Twelve nations today signed a convention to fight pollution an the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Chess:
SPRUCE FALLS POWER ENDS PAPER STRIKE
description: Newsprint and electrical workers returned to their jobs yesterday at the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., at Kapuskasing, Ontario. Their return ended a fivemonth strike at the mill, which can produce about 335,000 tons of newsprint a year.

title: Vincent Van Gogh Museum Rocked by Policy Dispute
description: AMSTERDAM, Feb. 16The. Vincent van Gogh Museum, which has become one of the Netherlands's most popular cultural centers since it opened in 1973, has been rocked by a dispute over budget and exhibition policy.

title: Lockheed Chairman In Ottawa for Parley
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 16 The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's new chairman, Robert W. Haack, and a representative of Lockheed's bankers have flown to Ottawa in an effort to save a huge order for antisubmarinewarfare planes to the Canadian Government.

title: Nadjari Investigates Some Policemen For Compromising of Police Inquiries
description: Several members of the city's Police Department who may have compromised official police investigations are being investigated by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: WILLIAM PRICE DIES; RETIRED BANKER, 78
description: William G.F. Price, a retired banker long associated with the, city's garment district, died yesterday in a Naples, Fla., hospital. He was 78 years old and lived also in Brookfield Center, Conn.

title: In Burbank, Many Workers Defend Lockheed Payments
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 16  The grayhaired Lockheed secretary was angry, but more than that, Barbara Alexander was perplexed over why the world suddenly seemed to be caving in on her employer of 16 years because of its secret payments to government officials abroad.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a caption accompanying an article in The New York Times yesterday on superhousekeepers, Barbara Barrie, the actress, was incorrectly identified as Barbara Harris.

title: Helping New York
description: Some years ago, a group of youths used to hang out around the terraced steps on the steep slope between Broadway and St. Nicholas Avenue in Upper Manhattan. Their noise, vulgarities and incessant littering were the scourge of the neighborhood, but no one could get them to move.

title: Aqueduct Victory By Christopher R.
description: With a holiday crowd of 39,404 looking on in springlike weather, Shamrock Farm's Christopher R. rallied in the final furlong yesterday and took the second running of the S38,250 Sporting Plate Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: On a TwoMile Dive In the Caribbean Sea
description: Ta ta, says John D. Donnelly, our diving pilot, over his radio link to the mother ship Lulu, as he allows water to flood the ballast tanks of our deepdiving submersible Alvin. Our sinking journey of an hour and a half into the Cayman Trough has begun.

title: U.S. Moscow Envoy Reported to Be Ill; Embassy Denies It
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP) The Boston Globe reported today that Walter J. Stoessel Jr., the American Ambassador to Moscow, had a mysterious blood ailment possibly caused or aggravated by high levels of Soviet microwaves beamed at the American Embassy.

title: RODINO PRESSURE ON U.S. REPORTED
description: Under pressure from Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration is continuing to finance an experimental crimefighting project in Newark that is described by its local director as a demonstration of what not to do to reduce crime in the cities.

title: An Exploded Myth
description: Teachers unions fabricated the slogan, Teachers Want What Children Need; and the publicschool establishment has enthusiastically endorsed the idea that the entire system has only the children's interests at heart. Admirable as those sentiments are, they are unfortunately based on myth.

title: City Celebrates Holiday With Sales and a Wisp of Spring
description: There were fifes on Fifth Avenue, boy scouts on Wall Street, a sort of revolution at Washington Square and, of course, storewide sales.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BACK IN THE CLOUDS Diners and sippers at the Rainbow Room tonight who step onto the dance floor will have cause for nostalgic recall as Ray Heatherton leads his new band and shares the baton and vocal duties with his son, Dick, a disk jockey for WCBSFM. Thirtyseven years ago, his father first introduced the Ray Heatherton Orchestra at the same bandstand, 65 floors above Rockefeller Center. The new engagement of the Heathertons and their instrumentalists, through March 21, also marks the first anniversary of the return of parquet dancing at the Rainbow Room, under the management of Tony May and Brian Daly. The partners also operate the adjacent Rainbow Grill. where Allen & Rossi and Jeanne Napoli are performing through Saturday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Eight persons remained hospitalizedmost of them in serious conditionfor injuries suffered in a twocar, headon collision in which two Trenton teenagers and a Pennsylvania woman were killed. The police said that Sean P. Walsh, 19 years old, and his brother Kevin, 18, both of Trenton, and Mrs. Eleanor S. Disbrow, 37, of Pipersville, Pa., were killed in the collision on Route 27 in Titusville, near Trenton, late Friday night.

title: LOU DERMAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) Lou Derman, a television comedy writer who was one of the writerproducers on All in the Family this season, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 61.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 16Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger began his first extended trip to Latin America in Venezuela today with heavy emphasis on oil prices expected in talks with officials here.

description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16 Sparked by its doubleduty hurdles trio of Reggie Blackshear, Joe Myatt and Larry Bunting, Seton Hall University won the Metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track championship for the second time hi a row today at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium. Seton Hall scored 70 points, with Manhattan second with 49 and Ade1phi third with 48.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 16 Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia has won a slim victory over former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma in final tabulations of the Oklahoma Democratic precinct caucuses.

description: YUMA, Colo.If you like little House on the Prairie, you'd love Yuma.

description: When Patricia Hearst's lawyers present witnesses in court, as they are expected to, alleging that she helped rob a bank because she had been brainwashed to abandon her parents values and embrace those of the self  styled Symbionese Liberation Army, the lawyers will be delving into a bizarre realm of human behavior that has been exploited for centuries but never fully understood by psychiatrists.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Statistics compiled by the Board of Public Utility Commissioners show that New Jersey residents are paying more to heat their homes now because of a monthly automatic rateadjustment system that it approved.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16Soviet migrs and leaders of Jewish groups in the United States and Europe charged today that antiSemitism had grown sharply in Russia in the last two years and that intimidation of Jews seeking exit visas was on the rise.

title: THORFIN HOGNESS, CHEMIST, 81, DIES
description: Dr. Thorfin R. Hogness, Professor emritus of chemistry at the University of Chicago and director of plutonium research for the Manhattan Project during the last years of World War II, died Saturday in a retirement home in San Jose, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: Helping New York
Independence for Antigua Is Top Issue As Caribbean Island Votes Tomorrow
description: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, Feb. 15 A hardfought election here Wednesday is expected to decide whether this British outpost in the Caribbean, and probably four other former colonies, will move quickly to sever their last ties with Britain or continue as associated states of the United Kingdom.

title: Safety Factors in Shipbuilding Are Posed as Inquiry Is Called Into Disappearance of an OreOil Carrier
description: A formal inquiry into the causes of the sudden disappearance of the 227,556ton oreoil carrier Berge Istra in the western Pacific last December will begin shortly in London. The London inquiry is expected to raise questions about safety factors in the current state of shipbuilding and ship operating technology.

title: BENJAMIN KNOBEL
description: Benjamin Knobel, a retired builder and operator of motionpicture theaters in the New York area, died in Miami Saturday. He was 85 years old and lived in Surfside, Fla.

title: Some Garment Workers Facing Layoffs in Dispute Over Pay
description: The twoweek contract settlement between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the dress industry is threatened by an intraindustry dispute that threatens the layoff of an undetermined number of garment workers today.

title: Penalties Planned for Landlords Who Fail to Register Apartments
description: City housing officials say they are drawing up procedures for penalizing many of the landlords who have failed to register certain apartments under the rentstabilization program.

title: JAPANESE DENIES AIDING LOCKHEED AT TOKYO INQUIRY
description: TOKYO, Feb. 16An influential Japanese business executive who is a director of All Nippon Airways denied today that he had helped to sell Lockheed airbuses to the domestic airline.

title: Rockefeller, Despite Odds, Still Eyes Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Vice President Rockefeller, regarded as a pariah by many in his own party, called a liability by President Ford's campaign staff and losing influence within the Ford Administration, has still declined to abandon his lifelong ambition to be President of the United States.

title: Bridge:
description: By a curious paradox, the annual eclipse of New York players in the McKenney Trophy, awarded for tournament performance in a calendar year, is directly attributable to the strength of competition here.

title: Bendix Splits Stock 4 for 3
description: The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday a 4 for 3 common stock split and voted a 15 percent increase in the common stock dividend. On a presplit basis, the new quarterly dividend is 57 cents a share, up from 50 cents a share.

title: FORD TO INCREASE BUDGET REQUEST ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  President Ford, changing budget plans he introduced just last month, disclosed today that he would ask Congress to increase spending for elementary and secondary education in each of the next three fiscal years.

title: Roger Brown Released
description: With Webster back playing, the Denver Nuggets of the American Basketball Association have placed Roger Brown, the reserve center, on waivers. . . . Also in the A.B.A., the Nets, in need of backcourt help with Brian Taylor recovering from his recent automobile accident, have acquired Ted McClain from the Kentucky Colonels. McClain averaged 7.9 points in second season with the Colonels. He had played three seasons with the defunct Carolina Cougars. . . . . Larry Siegfried, a threeyear starter for Ohio State University and a Houston Rockets assistant coach, said he was, very interested in becoming the Buckeyes new coach. Fred Taylor, Siegfried's former coach, recently resigned.

title: Prison Urged Only for Top Crimes
description: In the fall of 1971, a group of 16 lawyers, legal scholars and social scientists asked themselves: Should there be prisons?

title: A Brainwashing Defense: Delving Into Murky Area

description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 16  With the immediate crisis apparently over, the United States today announced the withdrawal of a 100bed field hospital and six Army helicopters that had been involved in earthquake relief operations here.

title: ProWestern Angola Force Says It Has Begun Guerrilla Warfare
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 16 (AP)  Westernsupported Angolan nationalists who abandoned conventional warfare against their rivals last week and fled into the bush have reportedly begun guerrilla attacks against Cuban soldiers aiding the People's Republic of Angola.

title: Trooper Is Buried; Radio Groups Start Fund to Aid Family
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Feb. 16 (UPI)About 2,000 policemen, some from as far away as Virginia, attended funeral services today for Carl P. Moller, a Connecticut state trooper killed while assisting a motorist on Interstate 84 in Hartford.
