description: CHATTANOGA, Tenn., Feb. 16 (AP)The Hamilton National Bank of Chattanooga. was declared insolvent today by the United States Comptroller of the Currency and was acquired immediately by the First Tennessee National Corporation, a bank holding company based in Memphis, Tenn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Con Ed: About the Business Exodus

title: Notes on People
description: The 30,000member JapaneseAmerican Citizens League, which is seeking a Presidential pardon for Iva Toguri D'Aquino to wipe out her treason conviction as the Tokyo Rose of World War II, has acquired a new ally in John Mann, who was foreman of the allwhite San Francisco jury that found her guilty in 1949. Mrs. D'Aquino, aged 59, served more than six years of her 10year sentence and was stripped of American citizenship but never deported. She runs a familyowned import shop in Chicago. Caught on a visit to Japan by the outbreak of war, Mrs. D'Aquino made Englishlanguage broadcasts to American troops for Radio Tokyo.

title: HELEN KATZMAN LEYDEN
description: Helen Katzman Leyden, wife of Bernard Leyden, head of the Leyden Group, freight forwarders, customs brokers and travel agents, died Saturday of a heart attack at her home in Old Westbury, L. I. She was 55 years old.

title: INDIA RESTRICTS PRESS EXECUTIVE
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 16  The Government has withdrawn the passport of one of India's leading newspaper executives, thus preventing him from leaving the country.

title: Indictments of Police Near In Bergen County Beatings
description: Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, said yesterday he expected indictments against police officers from five North Jersey communities who allegedly beat two civilians and took part in wild car rides through four towns.

title: TwoBit Investments Yield $1Million
description: PARSIPPANY  TROY HILLS, Feb. 16Two neighbors in Cliffside Park, a 56 yearold bachelor, and a mother of two grown children, jointly won the state's 42d Millionaire Drawing today with their 50cent weekly New Jersey lottery ticket.

title: New Arms Proposal Given to Dobrynin At White House Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union conferred for more than an hour today with President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger on new sets of proposals from each government for reaching a new pact on strategic arms, an authoritative American source reported.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: ROCKABYE HAMLET composed by Cliff Jones. Directed and choreographed by Gower Champion. Starring Larry Marshall and Alan Weeks. At the Minskotf Theater, 45th Street, west of Broadway, at 6:30

title: Assembly Will Meet Today to Discuss New Taxes Budget and School Funds
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16  The State Assembly, which has been criticized for delaying work on New Jersey's acute fiscal problems, may take the first step tomorrow toward enactment of new taxes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Limiting the RipOffs
description: Both the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes and a committee of the Public Health Council have issued major statements, introducing and defending their own designs for improved control over the way in which the state reimburses the capital costs of nursing homes.

title: RODINO PRESSURE ON U.S. REPORTED
description: Under pressure from Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration is continuing to finance an experimental crimefighting project in Newark that is described by its local director as a demonstration of what not to do to reduce crime in the cities.

title: Vail of Mets Hurt Playing Basketball
description: Mike Vail, the New York Mets outfielder, suffered a dislocation of his left foot while playing basketball in Norfolk, Va., Sunday, a spokesman for the Mets announced last night.

title: MOROCCANS RETAKE AN AREA IN SAHARA
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 16 (AP)  Fighting subsided in Western Sahara today after Moroccan forces resumed control of the area of Amgala, scene of two bloody battles in Morocco's undeclared war with Algeria.

title: Future of the C.I.A.
description: The Congressional investigations of activities conducted by the Central Intelligence Agency in violation of its charter and of the laws have been essential to reestablishment of public trust in the Federal Government's badly eroded integrity. These inquiries have turned a valuable spotlight on past abuses and provided information on which to base reforms necessary to prevent this dismal chapter of the nation's history from repeating itself. Since the House committee has gone out of business with no apparent move toward remedial legislation, the task of initiating reforms now rests with the Senate. Future abuses cannot be prevented by mere reliance on the investigations shock effect.

title: Article 1  No Title
$27 Million Bonds Retrieved And Postal Aide Is Arrested
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)The authorities said today that they had recovered $27 million in negotiable bonds stolen from the United States Postal Service and had arrested a postal supervisor in connection with the theft.

title: E.E.C. PLANS TO AID ITALY WITH BILLION
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16The European Common Market approved in principle tonight a $1 billion loan to help hardpressed Italy, and a $300 million loan to Ireland, officials said

title: JAPANESE DENIES AIDING LOCKHEED AT TOKYO INQUIRY
State Would Turn Pingry School Site Into an Institution for the Handicapped
description: HILLSIDEDr. Daniel Ringelheim, a Deputy State Commissioner of Education, is enthusiastic about the planned conversion of the present site of the Pingry School into state school for the handicapped, probably by the fall of 1978.

title: Two Craft Unions Cross Picket Lines At Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Several hundred printers and mailers crossed the picket lines of the striking pressmen's union at The Washington Post tonight, a spokesman for the newspaper's management said. The printers walked off in sympathy when the mailers struck Oct. 5. Both unions are part of the International Typographical Union, which reportedly ended strike benefits for Post employees on Feb. 11.

title: PACKAGE AVERTS YONKERS DEFAULT
SMALLCAR TREND SEEN MODERATING
P.L.O. RULES OUT ISRAEL LINK ANEW
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 16A prominent Palestinian guerrilla leader was quoted here today as having vowed that under no circumstances would the Palestine Liberation Organization recognize the state of Israel.

title: 2 Ethiopian Oppositionists Slain by Security Forces
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Government announced today that security forces had killed a retired major general and a former district administrator, both opnonents of the regime.

title: Adm. James D. Barner, 85, Commanded ShangriLa
description: Rear Adm. James Duke Barner, an early Naval aviator who commanded the carrier ShangriLa in the last attacks on Japan, died Sunday in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Kensington, Md.

title: New Threat to Mrs. Peron
description: As Argentina lurches into evergreater political and economic chaos, rumors are flying for the second time in as many months about a military move to oust President Isabel Martnez de Pern. Indeed, it is probably only the stillpainful memory among army leaders of the ineffective and unpopular militarydominated governments between 1966 and 1973 that has kept the widow of Juan Domingo Pern in the Casa Rosada this long.

title: Kennedy vs. Humphrey: One Vote for Beauty
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) An 84yearold Boston woman spotted notable noncandidates Hubert H. Humphrey and Edward M. Kennedy entering a popular harborfront restaurant for lunch today and could not resist.

title: Repairs Burden Fire Dept. Garage
description: The huge garage and storage facility in Long Island City that handles virtually all Fire Department vehicle maintenance is critically overcrowded, in serious need itself of repair and increasingly unable to handle vehicle repair demands, according to high department officials.

title: Leader of Nigerian Rebels Tried to Telephone Gowon
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 16 Half an hour after Gen. Murtala Ramat Muhammed was killed last Friday, the army officer who led the abortive coup went to the office of the British High Commissioner and tried to telephone Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the former head of state, in London, according to wellplaced sources.

title: Taft Moves Ahead; Meets Ft. Hamilton
description: Taft High School took a giant step yesterday in its bid for a third consecutive Public Schools Athletic League basketball title. The Blue Devils defeated South Shore, 6258, and advanced to a quarterfinal meeting against Fort Hamilton on Saturday.

title: E.E.C. PLANS TO AID ITALY WITH BILLION
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16The European Common Market approved in principle tonight a $1 billion loan to help hardpressed Italy, and a $300 million loan to Ireland, officials said.

title: TeenAgers in Boston Toss Rocks and Bottles
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP)The Police patrolled Boston's streets tonight after a large group of teenalters threw rocks and botlies and set fires near the Bunker Hill Monument.

title: A Fair Copyright Law
description: The long vision of the framers of the Constitution is being tested this week in the Senate where, after years of debate, a vote is scheduled on bringing the 1909 copyright law into the twentieth century. Technological revolutions in mechanical photocopying and communications should not undermine the fundamental constitutional aim of granting authors the exclusive right to their writings for a limited time as a means of promoting the progress of the useful arts.

title: Layer: A New Face in Team Tennis
description: Rod Laver, who has won more major championships than any other player, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the San Diego Friars of World Team Tennis. G. Allan Kingston, president of the Friars, declined to give details of the contract, but said in San Diego that it went beyond 1976 and made Laver the highestpaid player in the threeyearold league.

title: EICHARD WEDDERSPOON
description: Eichard G. Wedderspoon, an artist and professor of painting at Syracuse University from 1923 to 1949, died Sunday in Langhorne, Pa. He was 86 years old and Eyed in Yardley, Pa.

title: Honolulu Nurses End Strike
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 16 (AP) Nurses at six Honolulu hospitals, ratified a new twoyear contract last night, ending a 19day strike that drastically reduced hospital care service in the state.

title: Advertising
description: Although its sales have been growing at the rate of 26 percent a year without an advertising campaign, Purolator Services has decided to find out how much better it will do with one.

title: In Chicago, the Pump Room's Glamour Goes on the Block
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16It was a bit like taking the pages of a scrapbook and scattering them to the wind here the other day, as Chicago auctioned off another piece of its history.

title: CLIFFORD T. MORGAN, PSYCHOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Clifford T. Morgan, an experimental and physiological psychologist, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 60 years old.

title: Market Place
5 Are in Race for Mills's Seat in House
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.. Feb. 13 Five persons have announced as candidates for the seat in the House of Representatives held by Representative Wilbur D. Mills. even before he has disclosed his own reelection intentions. Several others are reported to be on the verge of running.

title: Shop Adds Sparkle to Old Park Cabs
description: In 22 years of carving furniture in his small shop in Rossville, Staten Island, John Cammalleri thought he had made every object that could be made from wood.

title: Card Of Thanks
description: GLOSTERCecil Dr. The family of the late Dr. Cecil C. Gloster are very grateful and appreciative to everyone for their kind and deep expression of sympathy.

title: Redmond Status Still Clouded
description: The National Hockey League might do well to consider opening a missing persons bureau. Two recalcitrant goaltenders, Gary (Suitcase) Smith of Vancouver and Cesare Maniago of Minnesofa, walked off in the middle of games the night of Feb. 8, and only this week found their way back to the ice. Mickey Redmond of the Detroit Red Wings, who was reinstated from irrevocable waivers last week, has not been seen near the Detroit Olympia Stadium since Jan. 18. The Red Wings have played 11 games since then. After Redmond returned from the Mayo Clinic with a report on his ailing back he remained uncommunicative about his plans. The Clinic had said he could either quit hockey, play with pain or undergo intensive treatment. The Red Wings, tired of waiting to hear from Redmond suspended him and put him waivers Feb. 9.

title: In PioneerStyle Boots, The Klutzy Look Is Chic
description: They're clunky and clodhopperish, and they look like the kind of boots that should be worn to clean out the cow barn, which they are, in many parts of the country. They've also been known to cause blisters and bleeding and accidental falls. And they're relatively expensive, between $50 and $75 a pair.

title: MRS. PERON ENDS CONGRESS SESSION
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 (AP) President Isabel Martinez de Pern ended a special session of Congress tonight in the midst of a 24hour business strike against her economic policies.

title: The Primary English Class Is Staged
description: Communication is presumably what life is all about. It is undeniably what Israel Horovitz's play The Primary English Class is all about. The play opened last night at the downtown Circle in the Square. At one juncture Mr. Horovitz makes the shrewd point that in, this city we have a perfect balance between maniacs and nonmaniacs, and the play sets out to prove that contention.

title: 15,000 JOBS ENDED BY POSTAL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The United States Postal Service reported today that it had eliminated nearly 15,000 jobs from its payroll in a year in an effort to reduce the agency's operating deficit.

title: Stability Expected For Money Market
C.I.A. SAID TO SPY ON REDS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Feb. 16  Today's issue of Humanit, the Communist Party newspaper, charged that the United States Central Intelligence Agency had, with the knowledge and assistance of French intelligence aides, been spying on French Communist Party officials.

title: Mayers Win, Lose in U.S. Indoor Open
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 16 (UPI) Sandy Mayer eliminated Tom Kreiss. 75, 62, in the first round of the $50, 000 national indoor open tennis championships today. Jimmy Connors had the flu and his match was delayed until Wednesday.

title: Public Union Scrap
description: With city and state governments in financial distress all over the country, the last thing they need is renewed jurisdictional warfare among their unionized civil servants. The withdrawal of the 700,000member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees from the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s new Public Employees Department is a signal that in the brotherhood of labor may once again boil over in destructive interunion raids.

title: Hialeah Track. Purchased by Jerseyan
description: MIAMI, Feb. 16 (AP)Directors of Hialeah Park voted today to sell the thoroughbred track to John Brunetti for $15 million, approximately the same sum he offered in a deal that fell through last year.

title: Two Presidents Heard: A Farewell and a Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  Two Presidential message were read to Congress todayGeorge Washington's Farewell Address and Gerald R. Ford's veto of a bill Democrats say would create 600,000 jobs.

title: Commodore John W. Anderson Of the U.S. Lines Is Dead at 77
description: Commodore John W. Anderson of the United States Lines, former captain of the superliner United States and top master mariner of the United States merchant marine, died Sunday in Tenafly, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: F. HENRY SAVAGE Sr.
description: F. Henry Savage Sr., who retired in 1964 as general sales manager, vice president and a director of the International Paper Company, died Sunday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 78 years old and lived at Woods Hole Drive in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Hearst Jury Visits Houses Reported Used by Captors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 The jury in the Patricia Hearst bank robbery trial visited today the two places where Miss Hearst has said she was held in closets for almost two months, tied, blindfolded and brainwashed.

title: U.S. Checks State Budget To Be Sure It's Balanced
LAWYERS CRITICAL OF SUIT BY JUDGES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 The lawsuit by 44 Federal judges seeking a pay increase is being greeted in the legal profession with some sympathy, some skepticism and a great deal of embarrassment.

title: Chargers Promote Sanders
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 16 (UPI) Johnny Sanders, who began his pro football career 23 years ago as a parttime scout with the Los Angeles Rams, was chosen today to replace Harland Svare as general manager of the San Diego Chargers.

title: Kreisky Visiting Prague
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 16 (Reuters) Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria and his host, Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal of Czechoslovakia, discussed bilateral relations and economic cooperation in a private meeting here this morning.

title: N.B.A. Wins a Point in Court Here
description: Judge Robert L. Carter of Federal District Court here granted yesterday a motion filed by the National Basketball Association to enjoin a former player, Chet Walker, from prosecuting a suit in a Federal court in Philadelphia. Walker had challenged the league's option clause in papers filed Jan. 30. The N.B.A.'s motion contended that since Walker was already a plaintiff in the Oscar Robertson suit, he is barred from bringing a separate suit on the same issue in another court. An outofcourt settlement of the Robertson suit was reached by the league and the players association during the AllStar break almost a month ago.

title: Amex Stocks Climb On Heavier Trading; OTC Issues Decline
FINANCIAL GUARANTY BY GAS USERS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Gerald L. Parsky, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that consumers, not the Government, should provide financial guarantees necessary to raise billions of dollars to build a delivery system for natural gas from Alaska's North Slope.

title: Iran F14 Decision
description: The Government of Iran is reported to have decided not to order any more of the FI4 fighter planes from the Grumman Corporation beyond the 80 planes currently being produced for the Iranian Imperial Air Force. Page 53.

title: Senate Votes to Make Public the Details of U.S. Weapons Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Senate voted today to make public details of munitions sales, by the United States to other nations.

title: Petitions Are Filed by Jackson For Delegates in 2 City Districts
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson filed with the Board of Elections yesterday petitions containing thousands of signatures for his candidates for delegate to the July 12 Democratic National Convention from two of the city's Congressional districts.

title: 2 STOCKHOLDERS SUE LOCKHEED ON BRIBES
Notes on People
description: A New Yorkbased, interracial committee announced yesterday the formation of the Eldridge Cleaver Defense Fund. The. chairmen will be Bayard Austin, president of the A. Philip Randolph Institute. Besides legal defense for the former Black Panther leader in his coming trial for attempted murder, the fund also seeks to provide bailstill unset as Mr. Cleaver remains in San Diego's Federal jailfinancial aid for his two young children and an opportunity for the recently returned fugitive, the author of Soul on Ice, to speak and write about his newly favorable view of this country and the American system.

title: FOREIGNERS BUY MORE U.S. STOCKS
NORTHROP NET UP 23.7% TO RECORD
description: The Northrop Corporation, one of the aerospace companies accused of stimulating sales of military aircraft through illegal payoffs abroad, reported yesterday record results for the fourth quarter and all of last I year. Profits for the quarter rose 23.7 percent. lifting the annual earnings by 36.5 percent.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (UPI)Koichi Wajima of Japan won his third World Boxing Association junior middleweight crown today in a 15thround knockout over Yuh JaeDo of South Korea, the champion. Wajima, 32 years old, knocked out Yuh at 1:47 of the final round, with a right straight to the face, regaining the title that he lost to Yuh last June 7.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Everyman's Panacea
description: In what must be the most famous comment on the impact of economists on politicians, Cabinet officials, central bankers, or businessmen, John Maynard Keynes said that practical men, who believe themselves to be quite exempt from any intellectual influences, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.

title: CITY URGED TO END WORK ON SUBWAY
description: The wisdom of continuing, work on the subway line to connect Manhattan and Queens, through the 63d Street tunnel under the East River was questioned yesterday at hearings on Mayor Beame's proposed $1.466 billion capital budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

title: Civil Rights in India Severely Limited Under Emergency Powers
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 17Last summer, when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi began imposing stringent emergency regulations upon India, she said that they were a temporary necessity because the country's 28 yearold democracy had given too much license to people.

title: BLACK POLITICIANS OPPOSE MOYNIHAN
description: A group of black Democratic officials declared yesterday that Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, was unacceptable to them as a possible Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New York.

title: When the School Day Ends, The City Is Their Classroom
Port Area Study Planned
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will undertake a major study in the port area looking to attract industry and arrest the movement of jobs and businesses from the region, Dr. William J. Ronan, the authority's chairman, has announced. The study, authorized by the agency's board of commissioners, will cost $250,000, it was said.

title: Pike Critical, but Senators Welcome Ford's Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Representative Otis Pike, chairman of the House intelligence committee, criticized the controls that President Ford announced for intelligence operations today as unlikely to curb abuses because only the executive branch will know what is going on.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GARDEN TIME Although Moss Hart's play The Climate of Eden ran for only 20 performances on Broadway in 1952, it was a strangely haunting drama, centering on a closeknit, freethinking family in a jungle setting. The play, which Mr. Hart directed and adapted from a novel by Edgar Mittelholzer, had a cast headed by John Cromwell, Penelope Munday and Isobel Elsom and also included a young Rosemary Harris.

title: Basketball Scoring
Caribbean Dives a New Chapter in Exploration
SCHERING CHECKING FOREIGN PAYMENTS
description: the ScheringPlough Corporation, reporting that foreign subsidiaries had made payments in three unidentified foreign countries to get Government contracts, disclosed yesterday that it had named a special committee to determine whether the company had made any political contributions or improper payments.

title: The Men Chosen by Ford As Intelligence Overseers
description: President, Association of American Railroads since 1973 . . . Secretary of the Army in the Johnson Administration . . . served as Under Secretary in Kennedy Administration . . . presided over controversial cutbacks and reorganization in the Army Reserve and National Guard . . . a lawyer who was in and out of Government several times . . . born in Romney, W. Va., March 25, 1912 . . . graduated from Princeton and University of West Virginia Law School . . . practiced law in West Virginia and taught at the law school . . . later practiced law in Washington. as partner in Steptee & Johnson . . . member of legal staff, Office of Price Administration during World War II . . . counsel to United States economic mission to Greece. 1947 . . . married former Helen Wales, four children.

title: Assad Meets Stevenson
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 17 (Reuters)President Hafez alAssad has conferred with Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d on Middle East developments. The Illinois Democrat arrived here Sunday.

title: Fedders Talks Held
GOLDIN ACCUSES HEALTH INSURERS
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that audits of programs under which the city bought health insurance for its employees had turned up improper and unsupported charges by Blue Cross amounting to more than $1 million a year.

title: CHINESE FACTION IS ATTACKED ANEW
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 17In one of the sharpest attacks yet on alleged rightists, China's official daily newspaper, charged today that unnamed capitalist roaders within the party had distorted an important instruction from Chairman Mao Tsetung last year and instead emphasized a call for unity, stability and economic growth.

title: Governor Brown's America
CONSUMER NOTES
description: In January 1975 an opinion poll conducted for the Business Roundtable by the Opinion Research Corporation asked this question.

title: Latin America Is Offered U.S. Plan on Cooperation
description: CARABEDELLA. Venezuela. Feb. 17Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today offered Latin America a sixpoint plan of United States cooperation in solving economic and other problems and he called on the countries involved to get down to serious business in discussing it.

title: 15,000 ARE LET GO BY DRESS SHOPS
description: An estimated total of 15,000 garment workers were laid off yesterday when contractors whose shops do the sewing and sonic cutting of dresses balked at paying the new wage rates negotiated by dress jobbers and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on brainwashing in The New York Times yesterday, the authorship of two books was Inadvertently transposed. The books and their authors are Coercive Persuasion, by Dr. Edgar H. Schein (with Inge Schneier and Curtis H. Barker). and Thought Reform and the Psychology of Totalism, by Dr. Robert J. Lifton.

title: 10496 Setback by Warriors an Old Story
description: The Knicks lost to the Golden State Warriors, 104 96, last night at Madison Square Garden and the script was the same as in so many of their previous 29 losses this National Basketball Association season.

title: Students Join Forces With Faculty Against Cuts in State Aid to Colleges
description: TRENTON. Feb. 17Squeezed between the prospect of sharp tuition increases and the threat of faculty strikes against layoffs and for higher salaries students at state colleges find themselves in a shaky alliance with the teachers in protesting against proposed huge reductions in state aid to the schools.

title: Laos Group to Visit Moscow
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17 Agence FrancePresse)Prime Minister Kaysone Phomvihan announced here today that he would head a Laotian delegation to the forthcoming 25th congress of the Soviet Communist Party in Moscow.

title: Brooklyn College Wins
description: Brooklyn College scored 24 straight points, all from the field, within 8 minutes 40 seconds of the first half, and coasted to a 9854 victory over Pratt Institute in a Knickerbocker Conference college basketball game last night on the winners court. The Kingsmen raised their wonlost record to 814, but 51 in the league. Pratt, 813 overall, is 26 in the conference.

title: REAGAN ASSAILED
Area of San Andreas Fault Rising
description: Since 1960. an area along the San Andreas Fault 40 miles north of Los Angeles has risen some 10 inches, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: JULIA RAFFES, AIDED CHILD GUIDANCE UNIT
description: Julia Gertrude Brown Raffes, a psychiatric social worker who spent most of her career in the treatment of emotionally handicapped children in this city, died Monday evening in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 431 East 20th Street.

title: Drugs Found Supplement To Breast Cancer Surgery
Latin America Is Offered U.S. Plan on Cooperation
description: CARABEDELLA, Venezuela, Feb. 17Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today offered Latin America a sixpoint plan of United States cooperation in solving economic and other problems and he called on the countries involved to get down to serious business in discussing it.

title: 63 SAVINGS UNITS ON PROBLEM LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Government agency charged with regulating savings and loan associations disclosed today that 63 institutions are now carried on its socalled problem list, compared with 51 at the end of 1974.

title: Usery Welcomed At Labor Parley; Ford Is Assailed
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17The executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. gave a generally friendly welcome today to the new Secreatry of Labor, W. J. Usery Jr., but George Meany said that the federation no longer had any working relationship with President Ford and the White House.

title: Udall Hoping It's All Coming Together
Scientists and Arms
description: The spiraling arms race is no longer a race of numbers but of technology. The strategicarmslimitation and Vladivostok agreements set numerical ceilings on the number of strategic nuclear weapons and delivery systems. These quantitative limits were set fantastically high, since the Americans and the Russians were already able to wipe out each other's major cities (over 100,000 in population) by 36 times and 12 times respectively.

title: Nigerians Storm British and U.S. Offices
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 17 Several. hundred students stormed the British High Commission and the United States Embassy here today, smashing windows, wrecking cars and causing thousands of dollars in damage.

title: Aid to Handicapped Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The House approved today a more than $820 million authorization measure to extend the program of Federal aid to states to carry out rehabilitation programs for the handicapped. The measure was approved on a voice vote and sent to the Senate.

title: GUIDELINES DUE
REAGAN ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON. Feb, 17President Ford, in a nationally televised news conference, said tonight that Ronald Reagan was too conservative to be elected President.

title: If You've Never Eaten Eel, Now's the Time and Here's How to Cook It
description: MATELOTE OF EEL

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In Pounds Sterling per metric ton) COPPER

title: Article 5  No Title
Daley Seeks to End Freeze on Funds With Hiring Plan
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP)Mayor Richard J. Daley, struggling to end a court freeze on $150.8 million in Federal revenue sharing funds, announced today that Chicago will hire about 400 police officers under race and sex quotas established in a Jan. 5 court order.

title: CHURCHES UNIT ASKS VD EDUCATION ON TV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)  The National Council of Churches today urges broadcasters to start primetime informational and educational programming immediately to inform teenagers about veneral disease and contraception.

title: JOE M'DONALD SINGS WITH A NEW IMAGE
description: Nearly a decade ago, Joe McDonald used to lead one of those exotically named San Francisco rock groups as Country Joe and the Fish. They were famous (notorious?) for the Fish Cheer, which employed a common fourletter word and was designed to integrate the youth culture and alienate the elders. Either youth  culture demographics have altered or Mr. McDonald has changed, because now that the San Francisco rock scene is officially nostalgia, he emerges singing Our Wedding Day.

title: Fewer Subcompacts Set
CHILDREN AS VICTIMS: 1
The Privileged Many
U.S. and Soviet Ask Early Action to Ban Weather Warfare
description: GENEVA, Feb. 17The United States and the Soviet Union called today on the 20nation Disarmament Conference to complete this year the draft of an international convention to outlaw all attempts to manipulate th weather or modify the environment for military of other hostile purposes.

title: If You've Never Eaten Eel, Now's the Time and Here's How to Cook It
description: MATELOTE OF EEL

title: MORE CONGESTION IN TUNNEL LIKELY
UOP PULLOUT SET IN REFINERY PLAN
Ad Council to Attack Child Abuse
description: Child abuse is the latest social problem that will be attacked by the Advertising Council, the public service arm of the advertising industry.

title: Victims of Quake Reported Getting Useless Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Relief organizations in Guatemala are being sent a tremendous load of useless material by wellmeaning Americans, Representative Ken Hechler said today after a weehend visit to the Central American country, which was hit by an earthquake Feb. 4.

title: Weekly Market Basket
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 0.4 percent last week, the average cost of the 38 items in the market basket priced by the City Department of Consumer Affairs totaling $71.91, 32 cents les than the week before.

title: Rock Island, After Decade, Reports Profit in Quarter
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP)Rock Island Lines, which filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws last March, lost $31.1 million in all of 1975 but recovered enough by the last part of the year to show a fourthquarter profit of $4.7 million, the carrier announced today.

title: GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: 2 Inquiries Pressed Here On Denver Killing Suspect
description: Investigations by the Police Department and Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, were under way yesterday in parallel cases growing out of activities of Michael Borrelli, a retired detective who was arrested last week on murder charges in Denver.

title: ALBERT F. BENDER OF U.N. DIES AT 61
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17Albert F. Bender Jr., chairman of the United Nations Joint Inspection Unit, died yesterday in Geneva at the age of 61.

title: Cunningham Bitterly Condemns Nadjari
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman and Bronx County leader, has asked that Maurice H. Nadjari be prohibited from investigating and prosecuting him because Mr. Nadjari is emotionally unsuited to be a special prosecutor and is motivated by a plan to warp and perversely manipulate national politics.

title: Senators Won't Seek Newsmen's Names at C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Operations abandoned today its efforts to obtain the names of American and foreign journalists who have cooperated with the Central Intelligence Agency, saying that their identities were not crucial to the success of its investigation of the Federal intelligence agencies.

title: O'Dwyer's Stolen Car Safe at Station House
Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Mrs. Peron Moves To Block Challenge To Her By Congress
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Argentina was technically without a Congress today as President Isabel Martinez de Pern struggled to block efforts to impeach her or declare her unfit to rule.

title: An Ancient Chinese City Revives 2,000YearOld Weaving Tradition
2 MARUBENI AIDES RESIGN IN SCANDAL
Makeup Tools: A Bagful Of Tricks
description: Finger face painting is out. Brushes, crayons, gadgets are in. After all, Leonardo didn't paint the Mona Lisa with his fingers. Professional makeup artists are depending more and more on their skill with tools and passing on their tricks to customers.

title: For First Time in U.S., Divorces Pass 1 Million
description: The number of divorces in America in one year passed the onemillion mark for the first time in history last year, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: City Dips Into Treasury Loan To Maintain CashFlow Plan
description: The city had to forgo the additional use of pension funds to maintain its emergency cash flow plan yesterday, resorting to an extra Treasury Department loan because Congress has not yet passed legislation protecting the taxexempt status of the pension funds.

title: British Retrench on Higher Education Under Economic and Social Pressure
description: LONDON, Feb. 17After a decade of rising expectations among students, teachers and public officials, higher education in Britain has run into trouble and appears to be entering a period of prolonged retrenchment.

title: About New york
description: Somewhere south of Wards Island, spending the winter on the East River, are a lot of canvasback ducks. Somewhere in Central Park, but usually near Fifth Avenue because they seem to like the East Side better, are wild rabbits. There are foxes in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, pheasants along the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn, and muskrats all over Staten Island. Somewhere in the city there may even be a wild deer.

title: Toxic Liquid Routs 350
description: TRAINER, Pa., Feb. 17 (UPI) The leakage of a toxic, flammable liquid from a Penn Central Railroad tank car forced the evacuation of about 350 persons from a fivesquare block area in this Delaware County community late last night.

title: Music: Rostropovich and Clevelanders
description: The scene at Carnegie Hall on Monday night resembled nomination night at a political convention  except that it is hard to think of a candidate these days who can churn up the kind of adoring frenzy that greeted Mstislav Rostropovich's playing of the Dvorak Cello concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra. He undoubtedly could have carried by acclamation whatever precinct Carnegie Hall lies in.

title: Trichinosis Is Laid to Pork in Hamburger
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17Fortyfive cases of trichinosis were reported in New Jersey last year, and state health officials said today that they probably resulted from the grinding up of pork in hamburger by some meat markets.

title: PBS PLAY TONIGHT CAUSES CONFLICT
description: The presentation of the Elie Wiesel drama Zalmen or the Madness of God, on PBS tonight has been withdrawn by the Boston station. WGBH, to avoid a conflict with the current stage production of the play at the Shubert Theater there.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Mets conceded yesterday it was doubtful that Mike Vail would recover from his foot injury and open the baseball season in right field on April 8.

title: Waldheim Sees Cypriots
description: VIENNA, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations met Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders separately today before renewing negotiations amid at prodding the two men toward settlement of the 12.yearold Cyprus crisis.

title: Artists Protest Restorations at the Met
description: Waving signs that read Restoration Means Mutilation, Who Hacked Hals? and Rembrandt Didn't Die, He was Cleaned Away, a group of 50 art students, artists and teachers marched from the Art Students League on West 57th Street to the Metropolitan Museum yesterday afternoon.

title: LONGTERM LOANS NOW YONKERS AIM
description: YONKERS, Feb. 17The city of Yonkers, saved over the weekend from its fourth default deadline in three months, moved today toward the long. term financing that state officials indicated was the city's only hope.

title: 2 Boston Youths Arrested In Charlestown Disturbance
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)Two teenagers were arrested tonight in the second consecutive night of minor disturbances by small groups of youths in Boston's rharlestown section.

description: UTILITIES

title: College, School Results
description: Colleges

title: Davidson Stars in Goal for Winners
Democrats Mostly Agree, Emphasis Differs

Elderly Urge Legislators Not to Lower Medicaid Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17Elderly persons pleaded today with the Appropriations Committee of the State Assembly not to lower state aid to Medicaid, as proposed by Governor Byrne.

title: CAHN PROSECUTION COMPLETED BY U. S.
description: The prosecution completed its case against William Cahn, former District Attorney for Nassau County, in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday, and the defense case began.

title: Music: Harris Is Feted
description: Monday was George Washington's official birthday, and the Long Island Chamber Ensemble of New York used its concert in Alice Tully Hall that night to honor Roy Harris. The occasion was appropriate because he is one of the most American of composers and he had celebrated his 78th birthday Feb. 12.

title: Wetlands Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) President Ford signed a bill today that continues authorization of funds to purchase wetlands for the protection of migratory waterfowl. The measure increases the appropriations for wetland acquisition from $105 million to $200 million.

title: 67 High Sets Record; Dressing Is a Problem
RAINFALL SKIMPY; WHEAT PRICE IS UP
description: Dry weather continues to dominate traders thinking about the prospects of the winter wheat crop and to attract new speculative buying. All of this sent wheat futures up about 10 cents a bushel yesterday. The March delivery closed at $3.92 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, up from $3.82 at the end of the previous session.

title: Demise of Labor Board Perils Agriculture Truce in California
description: SAN DIEGO  A fragile peace exists in the fertile Imperial Valley, 100 miles east of here and just north of the Mexican border, where 15,000 migrant farm workers are picking lettuce and asparagus.

title: Business Spur Cited
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Governor Carey, in a move to spur the state's lagging economy, asked the Legislature today to delay indefinitely the implementation of major parts of the State Environmental Quality Review Act, which he signed with praise seven months ago.

title: Article 6  No Title
U.S. Coupon Issues Purchased by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve was active in the Government market yesterday, partly for its own account and purposes and partly for customers accounts. The activity, one day before its regular monthly. Open Market Committee Meeting and three days before the Treasury's $2.5 billion note auction, did not particularly surprise knowledgeable market) participants,

title: Trial Begins on Blaze In Police Chief's House
description: MORRISTOWN. Feb. 17Police Chief Andrew Gugliemini of Netcong and an insurance adjuster went on trial here today on charges that they hired an autobody repairman to burn down the chief's house to collect $68,450 in insurance.

title: British Communists Issue Criticism of Soviet Acts,
description: LONDON, Feb. 17In an apparent bid for broader public acceptance, the small British Communist Party has published some criticism of the Soviet Union and called for the achievement or Socialism in Britain by democratic means.

title: F.B.I. TO INVESTIGATE REPORT DISCLOSURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been ordered by Attorney General Edward H. Levi to assist the Justice Department in its investigation of the unauthorized disclosure of the final report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Stage: Getting Through
description: Getting Through the Night, a new play by John Ford Noonan (the 11th in seven years by this prolific playwright), ends with the accidental suicide of one of the major characters. It is a clear case of a play's cutting its own throat.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Feb. 17, 1976

title: About Education
description: A new testing technique designed to compensate for the alleged cultural bias of standard I.Q. tests has been developed by Dr. Jane R. Mercer, chairman of the sociology department of the University of California at Riverside.

title: GUIDELINES DUE
The Quake Hit a Stricken Lan
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 14There is a story told here about an American church relief worker, newly arrived to help earthquake victims, who ventured into Guatemala's shantytown slums for the first time.

title: Coopman Not in Ali's Plan
description: SAN JUAN P.R., Feb. 17Unconcerned by his world heavyweight championship defense against JeanPierre Coopman here Friday night, Muhammad Ali forecast today an exhibition against a Sumo wrestler in Tokyo, a July 4 title bout with Ken Norton in Pontiac, Mich., and other stops this year in Costa Rica, Germany and the Sudan.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN ALBANY TO ACT ON EARLY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature agreed with Governor Carey today to try to enact the New York State budget ahead of the March 31 deadline as a symbol of the state's worthiness for credit and an effort to persuade the financial community to lend the state the $4 billion it must borrow after April 1.

title: Pupils Interview Gibson on Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 17  A group of eighth graders learned today that Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson had once been offered a bribe, but issued a collective sigh of relief when he told them he had turned it down.

title: FIRE FATAL TO 3 IS CALLED ARSON
description: The fire that caused the death of three firemen in Queens on Feb. 8 was without a doubt caused by an arsonist, according to Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan.

title: 2 Yachts Missing After Ocean Race
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, FEB. 17 (AP)  The Cam'rita of Sweden and Naomi of the United States, participants in the Cape TownRio regatta, were still missing today, but organizers of the race believe they had probably decided to withdraw from the race without notifying the officials.

title: A SEETHING SURFACE IN CASIO'S PIANISM
description: Some artists have enough panache to cover a multitude of musical sins, and Ignacio Ocasio joined their ranks at his Carnegie Recital Hall debut Monday night. The 22yearold pianist graduated in 1972 as class valedictorian from the Conservatory of Music in his native Puerto Rico and later earned a Ph.D. in physics and chemistry from the University of Puerto Rico.

title: CRANE EXTENDS BID TO ANACONDA
description: The Crane Company said yesterday that it had extended for a third time its offer to buy up to 5 million sharesaround 23 percent of the Anaconda Company. Anaconda,which has been fighting the Crane offer since late last year when it was first made, has agreed in principle to merge with Tenneco Inc.

title: Market Place
description: Fortified with new patents, the Zenith Radio Corporation may be preparin for the introduction of a radically different line of color television sets next fall.

title: Some days you can eel it and eel it and eel it and still come home emptyhanded but this year I've had pretty good luck.
A $50 MILLION LOAN IS GRANTED TO IRAN
description: The Industrial Credit Bank, wholly owned by the Iranian Government, has received a $50 million loan from a syndicate of 20 banks led by Kuhn, Loeb & Company, the investment concern announced yesterday.

title: Article 8  No Title
Golf's Top Stars Are Capital Fellows
description: Purses on the professional golf tour will reach a record high of $9,073,450 this season. With that kind of money it is easy to fill a field. But it's not so easy to get the superstars, and this is one of the major worries of tournament promoters.

title: 250 Attend Sal Mineo Funeral; Actor Is Called Gentle Person
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Feb. 17When Plato, the alienated teenalter played by Sal Mineo, died at the end of the 1956 film Rebel Without a Cause, he. was mourned only by the family housekeeper and two highschool friends.

title: Ralston Recovers Prestige on Court
description: Give Dennis Ralston credit as the frontrunner for the comeback man of the year in tennis.

title: New Round on Cyprus
PAUL RUSSO DIES, EXRACING DRIVER
description: Paul Russo, an auto race driver for 33 years and a veteran of 15 Indianapolis 500's, died in his sleep Sunday night in Daytona Beach, Fla. Mr. Russo, a resident of Indianapolis, was in Daytona for Sunday's 500mile stockcar race. He was 62 years old.

title: Article 7  No Title
Carter's Campaign Program Contrasted With His Record on the Issues While He Was the Governor of Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 17 (AP)Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia, campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination, points to his reorganization of state government as a model for streamlining the Federal bureaucracy.

Reid, said today that he would issue orders closing the Hudson River as a commercial fishery for most species of fish because of their contamination by polychlorinated biphenyls, commonly known as PCB's.

description: The American Bar Association, bitterly divided and under pressure of lawsuits, moved to allow limited advertising by lawyers of their services and fees. Page 13.

title: 4 IN THE UKRAINE LOSE PARTY POSTS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (Reuters) A Communist Party leadership shuffle in the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second largest republic, has cost four leading Communists their places in the Ukrainian Politburo, according to a Kiev newspaper reaching here today.

title: Iran F14 Decision
description: The Government of Iran is reported to have decided not to order any more of the F14 fighter planes from the Grumman Corporation beyond the 80 planes currently being produced for the Iranian Imperial Air Force. Page 53.

description: Investors turned their attention yesterday to a number of lowpriced issues and other specialties as the general market suffered a mild sinking spell.

description: American wine drinkers have an ambivalent approach to German wines. On the one hand, we consume an ocean of Blue Nun and have made it one of the few successful brand names in the wine world.

title: The Korean Greengrocer: Produce Is More Varied
description: It's like this, said a veteran produce supplier in a raspy Brooklyn accent, as he unpacked a crate of extra fancy figs at a Bronx Hunts Point Market stall. When I first came into this businessthat was before the warto do business here you had to know Jewish phrases. Then some years later you had to pick up a few Italian words to make it. Now I'm trying for all the Korean words I can. There are that many Korean buyers now.

title: Drugs Found Supplement To Breast Cancer Surgery
description: A three  drug combination treatment after surgery for breast cancer has dramatically reduced recurrence of cancer among patients who face a high risk of suffering a relapse, according to preliminary findings reported this week by Italian researchers.

description: The Nedick's people say that the northwest corner of 34th Street and Broadway is the busiest in the world. Their flagship store sits on that corner, serving hot dogs and orange drinks et al. to 8,000 people a day. Another company's flagship store, Macy's, stands next door, bringing Nedick's the customers.

title: Business Briefs
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 14 hit its highest level of the year at 2.34 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 2.4 percent from 2.29 million tons the preceding week. The new production capability index also hit a 1976 high of 78.4 percent against 76.6 percent a week earlier.

title: Nevelson Sculptures Weave a Magic Spell
description: Louise Nevelson is one of the busiest artists in townindeed, one of the busiest artists in many a town. Commissions abound, and the work pours forth from the studio with an uninterrupted regular ity.

title: Miss Evert Struggles To Victory
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (UPI)A rusty Chris Evert struggled past 19yearold Mariana Simionescu of Rumania, 62 64, in the opening round of the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Detroit Tennis tournament tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1976

title: Leader of Britain's Roman Catholics
description: LONDON, Feb. 17The Abbot of Ampleforth was named today to become the spiritual leader of Britain's four million Roman Catholics. When he was told to leave the cloistered life of his Yorkshire abbey, he said today, he was shattered and distressed. feeling that he had always been overassessed. But as a monk, he said he accepted the appointment as Catholic Archbishop of Westminster.

title: U. S. IS PRESSED ON SOVIET JEWS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 17Nearly 1,200 delegates of Jewish organizations burst into applause today as Senator Frank Church accused the United States Government of failing to press Moscow for more humane treatment of Soviet Jews.

title: Food for More Than Thought
description: LONDONSo far there is little sign that the world at large and the United States in particular have yet come to grips with what will almost inevitably become a crucial international problem during the next U.S. President's term, namely the threat of mass starvation in many lands.

title: Rice Growing Curb Ended By a Bill Signed by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) President Ford signed into law today a bill lifting Federal controls on rice production, Mr. Ford's approval of the bill, which was bitterly opposed by many farm groups in traditional growing areas of Louisiana, Texas and California, means that farmers are now free to grow as much rice as they please this year without fear of Government penalties.

title: Drastic Changes Seen for Baseball
description: With the Giants of the National League expected to remain in San Francisco and the American League committed to making Seattle its 13th team next year, the major league baseball setup is unstable. Further drastic changes must be made within the next 12 months, and officials at the highest levels are wrestling with the pros and cons of various possibilities.

title: Books of The Times
description: Many of the same characters, places and fantasies recur in General Westmoreland's autobiography and Jack Valenti's memoir of President Lyndon B. Johnson. Both principals got stuck in the Big Muddy, neither quite knew what went wrong to the very end of their public careers, and their stories add small and selfrevealing footnotes to the history of the Vietnam War and its political and military rationale.

title: Jackson Says Ford Plans For Navy Imperil Security
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the Ford Administration was placing national security in grave peril by advancing what he described as an inadequate program for rebuilding the Navy.

Gay Jitterbug SixLength Victor at Hialeah
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP)Gay Jitterbug ran away from previously unbeaten Elocutionist and easily withstood a late charge by a 22to1 shot today to win the featured $15,000 race by six lengths at Hialeah Park race track.

title: Landlords Accuse 11 Oil Companies Of a Price Intrigue
description: One hundred and twentyseven owners and operators of housing developments and other large properties in the New York metropolitan area have charged 11 major oil companies with conspiring to keep oil supplies low and prices high in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Alabama Reopens Inquiry in 1963 Church Bombing That Killed 4
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 17  Attorney General Bill Baxley has reopened an investigation of the bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church in 1963 in which four young black girls were killed. He has learned the names of nine men that a former F.B.I. informer says were involved in the bombing. a Birmingham newspaper reported today.

description: Marjorie Muir Worthington, author, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 77 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (Reuters)The head of the Citizens for Reagan Committee said today that it was ludicrous of President Ford to claim that Ronald Reagan was too conservative politically to win a national election.

title: Labor's Highest Chiefs Planning Tremendous Effort for Election
description: BAL HARBOUR, Ha., Feb. 18Organized labor's top leaders have been making plans here this week to mount what they say will be the most effective political action effort in the history of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Northrop's Board Reappoints Jones to Its Two Top Positions
description: Thomas V. Jones, one of the corporate chiefs in the United States who has withstood the disclosure of huge company payoffs, retained his No. 1 position at the Northrop Corporation yesterday. The company's directors returned him to the post of chairman and announced that he would keep the title of chief executive officer.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) President Ford submitted to the Senate today a SpanishAmerican military cooperation treaty and said he envisioned integration of Spain into the institutions of Europe and the North Atlantic defense system.

Flanagan, the executive. director of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Usery's Mother Dies at 72
description: MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Feb. 18 (AP)Kffie Mae Phillips, mother of Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr., died here today. She was 72 years old. Besides Mr. Usery, she is survived by a daughter, Mary Durden, and four sisters.

title: A.T.&T. Dividend Up
description: Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company voted to raise the quarterly dividend to 95 cents from 85 cents. The increase is the largest ever declared by the company and the 10th since 1959. Page 51.

description: The United States yesterday seized a 24,000ton freighter flying the Bahamian flag, the S.S. Pyramid Veteran, because the vessel arrived here last, month with 112 pounds of co1 caine hidden in her prow locker area.

title: MRS. PERON PLANS NOT TO RUN AGAIN

description: The Reader's Digest gave a news conference yesterday morning to announce what it calls the biggest, most expensive single print ad ever to run anywhere at any time.

title: JAMES M. GAINES, 64, TEXAS BROADCASTER
description: James M. Gaines, a former vice president of NBC and a broadcasting executive in San Antonio, died Tuesday night at Northeast Baptist Hospital there after having suffered a stroke. He was 64 years old and lived in San Antonio.

title: Nassau School Aide Named
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18 (AP)The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, has appointed Philip H. Dennis, an assistant superintendent at Mount Vernon public schools, as administrator for the financially troubled Roosevelt School District in Nassau County.

title: Prices Move Down in Money Markets

title: COURT OVERTURNS BLUE LAW RULING
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has overturned a decision by the State Supreme Court in Orange County upholding enforcement of the state's Sunday closing laws. The Appellate Division called for a trial to determine whether the laws were constitutional as they were now being enforced.

title: Senator Asks Full Disclosure Of Names in Lockheed Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) Senator William Proxmire,. chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, says the Government should make publie the names of all foreign officials who took payoffs from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: MAGNETIC FIELD LINKED TO OZONE
description: A team of atmospheric scientists has concluded that a series of events almost a million years ago may possibly have weakened the earth's ozone shield, permitting excessive ultraviolet radiation to reach the earth and cause the extinction of several species of tiny marine animals.

title: MRS. MEIR PLEADS FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18Golda Meir, the former Prime Minister of Israel, strongly urged the Soviet Union today to lift restrictions on the emigration of Soviet Jews and said that international public opinion should be mobilized to put pressure, on Moscow.

Anthony Genovese, the attorney for Gilmour, said the suit was still pending against the other other two defendants. Yonkers Raceway and Harness Tracks Security, Inc.

The increase is the largest ever declared by the giant communications company that will observe its 100th anniversary on March 10.

description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. reported. yesterday a 69.2 percent in crease in net income in its first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 3 on a 12.6 percent advance in sales.

title: Bridge:

title: PRICE UNIT STUDIES AUTO CRASH PARTS

description: Harry Rodman, retired director of advertising for Lord & Taylor, died Tuesday evening, apparently of a heart attack

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18When the Soviet Union's 5,000 Communist delegates gather in the Kremlin next Tuesday to begin their party's 25th congress, they are expected to perform a planned ritual of speeches and votes that will be a far cry from the dynamic, contentious congresses of the party's early days.

title: A DISPUTE DELAYS SHIFTS IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18Efforts to form a Lebanese government of national union have run into difficulties, prompting a threeman Syrian mediation team to extend its stay here for several days.

title: World Cup Rosi Mittermaier's Goal Now
description: It was difficult to believe: There was Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany insisting last week after winning Olympic gold medals in the downhill and slalom, that she considered winNews ning, the overall World Cup chamof pionship more imSkiing portant. After all, she explained, winning one downhill and one slalom represent only two single efforts. The World Cup, in contrast, is for an entire season's racing. Surely such a title is more important.

description: Eddie fowling, for 40 years a stage figure as a singer, dancer, actor, playwright, song writer, producer and director, died yesterday. Page 38.

title: Usurped Authority
description: Arbitration is an invaluable device for resolving disputes arising out of the interpretation of labormanagement contracts, and nowhere more so than in the unionized civil service. But when an arbitrator reaches beyond the terms of a contract to tie the hands of elected officials in establishing priorities for allocating scarce municipal resources, the city has no option except to go to court to repel this usurpation of its own rightful authority.

title: N. Carolina 77, Miami (O.) 75
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Feb. 15 (AP)Phil Ford hit two foul shots with four seconds remaining tonight to give thirdranked North Carolina a 7775 victory over Miami of Ohio. Miami has a 147 record. The Tar Heels are 212.

title: Beame's Plan to Sell 2 Schools Being Erected Draws Criticism
description: A suggestion by the Beame administration that two uncompleted publicschool buildings in Brooklyn be put on the auction block was sharply criticized yesterday by community and Board of Education representatives.

title: JULIUS A. MIGEL, 98, WORLD FEDERALIST
description: Julius A. Migel, a silkmanufacturing executive and later an officer of many organizations seeking a stronger United Nations and eventual world government to insure peace, died Monday in Westerly, R.I. He was 98 years old and lived in Westerly.

title: Pro Transactions
description: DETROIT (AL)Signed Willie Horton, designated hitter.

title: Screen: 'I Will, I Will ...':Comedy Stars Gould and Diane Keaton
description: In "I Will, I Will . . . For Now," a long, long comedy about a jittery modern marriage, Diane Keaton plays the part of a headache and Elliott Gould that of a loud noise. The film opened yesterday at the Sutton, Paramount and Loews Astor Plaza Theaters.Miss Keaton rolls her eyes and looks miserable and appealing. Mr. Gould roars and wheedles and sulks and looks selfish and appealing. They are very rich, live in a sumptuous New York apartment, employ a humorous Spanish maid (Thelma Ritter used to do it Swedish), and have no recognizable worries.They do have unrecognizable worries, of the carpentered sort Hollywood used to invent for Rock Hudson and Doris Day to thrash around with. In this case, a stale 1950's poundcake of a moviethe old double-takes, smirks, shoulder shrugs are lifted carefully from their moth covers and hung upon us once morehas been given what will pass for a 1970's gimmick.The couple's sex life is poor. He is quick and she is dead, or virtually. "You make love as if you were catching a Fifth Avenue bus," she says. "You make love as if you were playing chess," he says.They have divorced each other, are unhappy, reuniteby contract arrangement rather than actual marriageare still unhappy. A vampish upstairs neighbor lends him "The Joy of Sex" to improve things. He puts his back out following the instructions.They go to an expensive sex clinic and there's a lot of underwear in the wrong beds, but no real sex. She still can't melt. "Give me a four-letter word for sexual intercourse," the clinic ring-master asks her. "Love," she says.I like that line, but not much else. Norman Panama, who directed and wrote a great many comedies over the last 30 years, a number of them successful, directed this one and helped write it. Neither job is well done.Nor is the acting, although Paul Sorvino is mildly amusing in a supporting role until he chokes it to death, To cast Elliott Gould for repartee comedy is to mistake a camel for an antelope. "I Will, I Will" should make people happy that they don't make movies like that any more.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Passaic man was sentenced to up to 93 years in jail after being convicted of sending threatening and obscene letters to women jurors. The man, Donald Dietz, 50 years old, was convicted Feb. 4 on a total of 26 counts involving physical extortion, sending obscene letters and threatening to kill. Judge Paul Huot handed down a 74to93year term and ordered Mr. Dietz remanded to the state prison.

title: A Supersalesman Turns From Vacuum Cleaners to Homeless Pets
The Port Authority's Role
description: In turning down the New Jersey Port Authority request for $278 million to extend PATH to Plainfield, N. J., the United States Urban Mass Transportation Administration gently criticized the applicant's failure to develop and submit a comprehensive plan for transit development for northern New Jersey.

title: City Approves the Leasing Of Garden for Convention
description: The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a $1.9 million contract for the exclusive use of Madison, Square Garden for the Democrat National Convention for two months starting June 1.

title: Profit Without Honor
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18Even in the slowesttorecover metals and mining industry, the feeling is that 1976 will turn out to be a very good year. But along with the warm glow of anticipation that suffuses most businessmen comes the defensive chill: The only thing harder to do than to apologize for no profits is to explain away profits.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 18 Republican women who are feminists and who are determined to achieve a larger role for women in their party are organizing in states from coast in coast.

Nixon, agreed today to significant administrative changes in settling a class action stockholders suit.

District Court Judge H. Alfred Cassasa made the ruling because, he said, the state had failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Mr. Rieck's behavior constituted disorderly conduct.

Aquarius V Wins Catamaran Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18 (AP)Aquarius V from the Cabrillo Beach Yacht Club in Los Angeles won the Little America's Cup for C Class catamarans today by beating Miss Nylex, the Australian defender in the deciding seventh heat. Aquarius scored a 5minute23second victory. It was the first American victory in the series. Britain has won eight times, Australia three and Denmark one.

title: ERA IS ILLUMINATED BY CHATMON'S BLUES
description: Sam Chatmon is a black singer and guitarist whose repertory includes folk songs that predate the blues. Few of his surviving contemporaries retain a fraction of their musical abilities, but the 77yearold Mr. Chatmon is an exception. His touch and time are still sure and his sweet, high tenor, which sometimes takes on a cracked blues coloration and sometimes slides effortlessly into falsetto is unimpaired.

title: BARCELONA POLICE DRAFTED BY ARMY

Every work on the program was packed with information, as the computer boys say, and a good deal of concentration was demanded from pianist and audience.

The 19yearold from Milligan, Fla., who is coholder of the world record of 9 seconds for the 100 yard dash, is reportedly struggling to raise his grades to a C average so he can take advantage of the football scholarhip offered to him.

title: Good Start in Caracas

In a major speech at Caracas, first stop of his sixcountry tour, Mr. Kissinger followed his own advice to put aside slogans and turn from rhetoric, endeavoring instead to respond to specific demands in aid and trade policy made on this country by the Latin American governments.

title: A Patrician for U.S. Post at the U.N.
description: Early in December 1968, William Warren Scranton, who is to be named the United States representatives at the United Nations, was sent to the Middle East as a special envoy by Presidentelect Richard M. Nixon. the While in Israel, Mr. Scranton, former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania, suggested that the United States ought to adopt a more evenhanded Middle Eastern policy and not necessarily espouse one nation over some other. And a week after he returned to the United States he went further. We are interested, very interested, in Israel and its security, and we should be, Mr. Scranton said. But is is important to point out to the Middle East and to people around the world that we are interested in other countries in the area and have friends among them.

title: 11 Die in Egypt Train Crash
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Feb. 18 (Reuters)At least 11 people were killed and 50 seriously injured when a speeding train smashed into a stationary train near here yesterday, the police said today. More people were believed trapped in the wreckage.

description: Computers began arriving in American newsrooms five years ago, and they are increasingly transforming the scene of bustle and clatter so familiar to lovers of latenight movies.

description: Plans for developing an electronic newsroom to serve the writers and editors of all the news, features and other editorial copy in The New York Times were announced yesterI day by the newspaper and the Harris Corporation of Cleve land.

The proposition that OPEC is facing imminent disintegration was described vari ously in interviews of experts as wishful thinking, dream: ing and spitting in the wind.

title: CORRECTION

title: Bribery Laid to Passaic Freeholder

title: Spurring the Economy...
description: Governor Carey's deep concern over the flight of industry from New York is one that must be shared by every New Yorker. The progressive weakening of the economic base, which has been going on for some time, undoubtedly is a major factor in the state's current fiscal crisis, as is the case with New York City. The future wellbeing of New York Stateand the city depends, as Mr. Carey has observed, on a vibrant and balanced economy.

title: PRICE FIXING LAID TO 23 PRODUCERS OF FOLDING BOXES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A Federal grand jury today charged 23 manufacturers of folding paperboard boxes, including the industry's three largest, with engaging in criminal conspiracy to fix prices.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18President Ford proposed legislation today that would make it a serious crime for Government employees to disclose the ways in which the Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal agencies collect and evaluate their information.

title: Connors Advances In Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors played his first match in the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships tonight and scored a 61, 64 victory over Bill Maze. Maze, a 20yearold Stanford sophomore, was overpowered by the more experienced Connors.

title: Coalition Opens Campaign T o Ban Meditation Classes
Mr. Ford Attacks
description: With his campaign in the early primary states visibly sagging, President Ford has taken the offensive against his Republican challenger, former Governor Ronald Reagan. It is unusual for a White House incumbent to use his press conference to criticize an intraparty foe; the traditional strategy is to pretend lofty indifference and thereby avoid implying that the challenger has equivalent Presidential stature.

title: Moscow Art Collector Reports Big Robbery
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP)More than 1,000 paintings and drawings worth $1.5 million were stolen from one of the most valuable private art collections in the Soviet Union, the owner reported today.

The incidents were touched off by the hijacking of a school bus carrying French children on Feb. 3.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 18 Governor Carey announced today that, beginning April 1, statechartered banks would be required to disclose the geographic sites of their mortgage loans asthe first step in a state effort to identify and eliminate the practice of redlining.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

The robber, who has worn a rabbitfur coat during several of his holdups, is reported to be 20 years old and a former Golden Gloves boxer. He lives in Brooklyn but he has not been seen by members of his family for several weeks. He reportedly has a police record.

description: William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, testified yesterday that after he was indicted he had tried to persuade an informant whom he had codenamed Sam Houston to come to his defense.

title: Free Lift Rides Turn Skiers Into Helpers
description: Bill Norton, the manager of the stateowned Cannon Mountain in New Hampshire, did what no ski area operator usually likes to do. He offered free skiing to about 1,000 devotees. I had no choice, said Norton. About six to eight inches of heavy powder had dropped on the mountain. But the snowfall had been followed by a light rain. If I wasn't careful, I might find myself with one big iceskating pond.
