description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Senate, by a vote of 97 to 0, approved legislation today to revise the nation's copyright law for the first time in 67 years.

title: Cabaret: Emotive Songs
description: Ellen Greene first called attendon to herself as a singer in predominantly homosexual cabarets. Then she was an actress, most recently in the Paul Mazursky film Next Stop Greenwich Village. And now, just before she goes into rehearsal for Jenny in the Richard Foreman production of The Threepenny Opera at Lincoln Center, she has returned to the cabaret circuit, where she opened a two week run at Reno Sweeney on Tuesday.

title: Nixon Leaving Today On Journey to Peking
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 19 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon flies to China tomorrow for a controversial visit labeled strictly private by the White House but denounced by a leading Democrat as an outrage meant to embarrass President Ford.

title: U.S. Envoy in Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 10 (Reuters)The new United States ambassador to Australia, James Hargrove, presented his credentials to the Australian Governer General, Sir John Kerr, today.

title: California Air Resources Board To Outlaw Most Lead Additives
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 Calling lead additives in gaso line a health menace, Califor nia's Air Resources Board voted today to eliminate the major portion of lead additives in the state over a threeyear period beginning Jan. 1.

title: Nazareth Quartet Wins Distance Medley Relay
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 19 Nazareth of Brooklyn won the distance medley in 10 minutes 29.5 seconds tonight in the championship section of the Nassau County Relays at the Coliseum.

title: Uneasy Duluth Filtering Water
description: DULUTH, Minn.  The firehouse in Duluth's Lakeside section is a little like the communal well in a primitive village. All day long, cars pull up and people carrying an array of containers enter a door to obtain drinking water from one of three spouts hanging over a metal trough.

title: Article 3  No Title
Nails for Female Coffins
description: It is distressing news that teenage girls now are smoking nearly as heavily as teenage boys not because the boys are smoking less but because the girls are smoking more. The number of smokers among girls in the 13to17 age group has increased by a halfmillion in little more than five years. A quarter of all girls in this age bracket smoke, and of these 40 percent smoke more than a pack a day. Among young women 18 to 34, the proportion of smokersabout one in threehas increased only slightly since 1969, but the number of heavy smokersi.e., those smoking a pack or more a day has risen from 51 to 61 percent.

title: BRITISH SEE PERIL FACING RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Feb. 19British officials are growing increasingly concerned that the success of Sovietsupported forces in Angola could lead to further wars of liberation engulfing all of southern Africa.

title: The Mastersingers At the City Opera
JAMES FARMER QUITS CORE IN ANGOLAFEUD
description: NAIROBI, Henya, Feb. 19 (UPI)James Farmer, a founder of the Congress of Racial Equality, said today that he was resigning from the group because of internal differences over the Angolan civil war.

title: Seniority Dilemma ...
description: In overturning a courtordered racial quota designed to protect the jobs of black and Puerto Rican school principals, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit recently in effect proscribed racial discrimination even when it is intended to aid disadvantaged minorities. The decision voided an effort by a Federal district judge to prevent the firing of minoritygroup supervisors through application of the seniority principle.

title: Stock Volume Sets a Record; Dow Industrials Climb 15.67
description: Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange set a record of 39.21 million shares yesterday as stock prices rose. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.67 points.

title: Market Place
description: Some months ago institutional investors were nervously considering problems of the international Business Machines Corporation.

title: Frank Sullivan, Humorist, Dies at 83; A Gentle Wit and Spoofer of Cliches
description: Frank Sullivan, the humorist, died yesterday in the Saratoga Hospital, Saratoga Springs, N. Y. He was 83 years old and lived alone at 135 Lincoln Avenue in Sartatoga Springs.

title: Egyptian Parliamentary Group Studies Accusation of a Boeing Payoff to Airline
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19 (AP)An Egyptian Parliamentary committee has heard charges by one of its members that officials of Egyptair, the Governmentowned airline, took commissions on the sale of aircraft from the Boeing Company, Cairo newspapers reported.

title: College, School Results BASKETBALL
description: Colleges

title: Books of The Times
description: Gone are the days when Jacob Potofsky, head of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, could make a grand gesture by resigning from the board of the City Center of Music and Drama Inc. in 1952 because its own New York City Ballet planned to perform in Franco Spain. The decibel count on ideological fervor is rather low at the City Center nowadays. Pinstripe suits are more in evidence among its officers than union labels.

title: Dance Umbrella Season Opens With Muller Work
ANTITRUST BILL LOSES SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Ford Administration, in the face of strong protests from businessmen, particularly from investment hankers, has reversed course and withdrawn its endorsement of legislation strengthening the Government's ability to prevent mergers of large corporations.

title: CITY LAYOFFS HURT MINORITIES MOST
description: City officials reported yesterday that layoffs resulting from the fiscal crisis were having devastating effects on minority employment in government.

title: Burns Warns of JobsPlan Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned Congress today that efforts to improve the job situation by a larger budget deficit, which would mean a more stimulative Government fiscal policy, could well backfire.

title: Paperboard Industry Ending Severe Slump
Scranton for the U.N.
description: In manner and style, William W. Scranton, President Ford's reported choice as chief United States Representative to the United Nations, will probably furnish the most striking contrast imaginable to his colorful predecessor. Yet there can be no doubt that the former Pennsylvania Governor, Congressman and aide to two Secretaries of State will defend the genuine interests of the United States as zealously as did Mr. Moynihan.

title: Copyright Revision Is Voted by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Senate, by a vote of 97 to 9, approved legislation today to revise the nation's copyright law for the first time in 67 years.

title: Ethyl Plans a Sale To Boise Cascade
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to purchase the Oxford Paper Division of the Ethyl Corporation for about $90 million in cash, including working capital., The division consists principally of a paper mill at Rumford. Me., and 335,000 acres of timberland. The mill produces about 280,000 tons a year of converting, printing and publishing papers.

title: JAPAN TO PRESS BRIBERY INQUIRY
description: TOKYO, Feb. 19Prime Minister Takeo Miki of Japan told his nation today that Japanese democracy would suffer a fatal wound if the Lockheed bribery scandal was left unsolved.

title: Competency Tests Planned For High School Diplomas
description: High school students in the state would not receive diplomas until they had demonstrated competency in four basic subjects under a proposal that the State Education Commissioner plans to submit to the Board of Regents.

title: Karen L. Bressler Is Married Here
description: Karen L. Bressler, a vice president, secretary, treasurer and a member of the board of directors of Karlin Productions Ltd., an independent motion picture producing company here, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Rosenberg, a member of and floor trader at the Commodity Exchange.

title: Scranton Declares He Is Ready to Fill U.N. Post If Named
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP)Former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania said today that he would serve as chief American delegate to the United Nations if appointed.

title: Jersey Nuclear Complex Seen as a Peril
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb, 19A study to be published later this month by the Brookhaven National Laboratory warns of per1 ils to people, the pine barrens and the resort industry if a multibilliondollar cluster of nuclear energy plants were placed in Ocean County, N.J.

title: Vaulters Go for New Heights In Meet at Garden Tonight
description: Mosf of the pack will be out on the track, but the really big deal could be out in the field tonght at the Olympic Invitational meet at the Garden. If things go as predicted, Dan Ripley and Wladyslaw Kozakiewicz will be dueling at 18 feet and over in the pole vault, and a world record amateur indoor vault is a strong possibility.

title: Chinese Aides, Targets of Official Attack, Still Appear in Public
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 19A number of senior Chinese officials who were purged during the Cultural Revolution and who would seem to be targets of a recent series of attacks have appeared in public in the last few days.

title: FORD MOTOR NET UP IN 4TH PERIOD
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19The Ford Motor Company reported sharply higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1975 of $170 million, or $1.82 a share, cornpared with $22 million, or 24 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1974. Earnings for the full year, however, fell to $323 million, or $3.46 a share, down 11 percent from $361 million, or $3,86 a share, in 1974.

title: Cunningham Ousts 2 Women Officials From Committee, and a Third Resigns
Gaudaur Pact Renewed
description: TORONTO, Feb. 19 (AP) Jake Gaudaur's contract as commissioner of the Canadian Football League was renewed today for five years. Gaudaur has been C.F.L. commissioner since 1968.

title: Notes on People
description: Anne Armstrong's husband, Tobin, held the Bible yesterday at her swearingin as Amhassador to Britain. President Ford, looking at a beaming Betty Ford, said Mrs. Armstrong was an example of the kind of woman his wife is always needling me to appoint: Whenever [Mrs. Armstrong] has done something, she has done a superb job.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EN GARDE! The Count of Monte Cristo immediately rings a bell with many people as a classic adventure brimming with action and intrigue. There was the old Alexandre Dumas novel. There have been two film versions and various sequels pelting us on latenight television. In past years, an American stage version had sucessc; James O'Neill, the father of Eugene, virtually made a career of portraying the count.

title: Tate Gallery Buys Pile of BricksOr Is It Art?
description: LONDON, Feb. 18It is a pity, in a way, that a piece of brick sculpture put together by the New York minimalist Carl Andre has achieved its greatest public notoriety on the eve of the bicentennial exhibition of the paintings of John Constable, as maximum a figure as there is in the rich history of English landscapes.

title: 1,200 in Nassau And Queens Protest Plans for Concorde
People and Business
description: Richard C. Bond, a director of the Kraftco Corporation, consented yesterday to a Federal Trade Commission order that would bar him from serving simultaneously as a director of the SCM Corporation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Train Kills 111 Antelope
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb, 19 (UPI) Officials of the Idaho Fish and Game Department said today that a Union Pacific railroad train hit a herd of antelope on Tuesday between Lake Walcott and American Falls Reser voir and at least 111 animals had died.

title: Two Police Groups Oppose Schwartz
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Leaders of two statewide organizations of law enforcement officers urged the State Senate today not to confirm Governor Carey's apointment of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the State Commission of Correction, but several topranking lawyereducators held that he was highly qualified for the post.

title: Gerulaitis Routed; Connors Advances
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 (UPI)Haroon Rahim routed Vitas Gerulaitis and Jimmy Connors defeated Brian Teacher in thirdround action tonight in the national indoor open tennis championships.

title: Wheat Futures Rise in Price; Soybeans Also Gain
description: When an expected rain failed to fall over parched areas yesterday, wheat futures had no place to go except up in price. New crop wheat for July delivery closed at $3.92, up from $3.89 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, At this price the July delivery is selling almost 10 cents above the nearby March delivery, which is an old crop month.

title: LABOR UNIT DEFENDS FOOD STAMP CONCEPT
description: BAL. HARBOUR, Ha., Feb. 19 The executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. strongly defended food stamps today and accused the Agriculture Department of failing to administer the program in a way that would prevent fraud and cheating.

title: Gulf Oil Is Fined $20,000 For Violating Energy Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Gulf Oil Corporation pleaded guilty in Pittsburgh today to four counts of a criminal indictment involving Federal energy regulations and was fined $20,000 by Judge Daniel Snyder in Federal District Court.

title: Turkish Workers Home With a New View
description: SEREFLI KOCHISAR, TurkeySeveral years ago Durmus Buyukatak joined the great wave of Turkish workers heading for Western Europe. Now he is back here on the rolling steppes of central Anatolia, a janitor in a saltprocessing plant financed by the savings of 1,800 fellow workers.

title: Britain Slashes Spending On SocialWelfare Items
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Government, conceding that the cost of Britain's ambitious socialwelfare programs was crippling the economy, today announced vast cuts in its publicspending plans.

title: An Andre Is What It Is, Not Another Thing
description: Carl Andre has been internationally known as a gifted and serious artist since the late 1950's. His reputation owes nothing to sensational publicity of the kind that for the moment surrounds it in London. It has been made, on the contrary, in tranquillity (and, initially, in isolation). Mr. Andre made the work he wanted to make. If people wanted to see it, so much the better. If not, he'd make it anyway.

title: 3 Democrats File for President in State
description: Three of the Democratic candidates for PresidentBirch Bayh, Jimmy Carter and Henry M. Jacksonfiled delegate petitions in almost all of New York State's 39 districts yesterday.

title: BACHE PROFIT RISES SHARPLY IN QUARTER
description: Benefiting from the growth in stocktrading volume, Bache Group Inc., parent of the brokerage firm of Bache Halsey Stuart Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the quarter ended Jan. 31 rose to $4.5 million, or 62 cents a share, from the yearearlier $1.1 million, or 14 cents a share, Revenues climed to $62.5 million from $47.9 million.

title: Bridge:
description: Few people appreciate that a classical education has some advantages for a serious student of bridge. For the last two decades, it has been important to study the deeds of the Romansadmittedly modern Romans. And Classical Greek has now entered the picture unexpectedly.

title: INCREASE PLANNED IN AID TO JOBLESS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Assembly Democrats today disclosed a proposal aimed at increasing the benefits paid to the state's unemployed and to shoring up the rapidly dwindling state unemployment insurance fund. These two goals would be achieved by instituting a new system of determining employer contributions.

title: Smith Speech Expected
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Rhodesian leaders, geared for a more intensive antiguerrilla struggle, today withheld comment on Britain's warning. Prime Minister Smith is expected to make some sort of reply in Parliament tomorrow.

title: SENATE SUSTAINS VETO OF MEASURE ON CREATING JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Ford won another confrontation with Congress today as the Senate sustained his veto of a $6.2 billion measure aimed at creating jobs in state and local publicworks programs.

title: The Mating Game in an Electronic Age
description: A young woman sat in a darkened conference room in a Manhattan office building the other day, her attention fixed on a television set at the end of the room. On the screen a 42yearold financial analyst was talking about his profession, his hobbies, and what in a woman would turn him off or turn him on. A few minutes into his tape she glanced at another woman across the table and shook her head.

title: ARAB PUBLICITY UNIT FACES U.S. CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Justice Department today charged the Arab information Center and its director, Amin Hilmy 2d, with baying violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act in its propaganda efforts on behalf of the League of Arab States.

title: A View From The West
description: DENVER, Feb. 19It is easy to find out what the Presidential candidates are saying these days, for they are saying very little, but finding out what the American people are thinking is a harder proposition.

title: Mrs. Ford Is Asked To Say What She Does
description: KEENE. N.H. Feb. 19 (UPI) Betty Ford was called on today to say what she does at the White House besides attract celebrities.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CUNNINGHAM TOLD BY COURT TO OBEY NADJARI SUBPOENA
description: State Supreme Court Justice Leonard H. Sandler yesterday ordered Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman and Bronx County leader, to appear before a special grand jury investigating the sale of judgeships in the Bronx.

title: BRITISH SEE PERIL FACING RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Feb. 19British officials are growing increasingly concerned that the success of Sovietsupported forces in Angola could lead to further wars of liberation engulfing all of southern Africa.

title: Paris to Back Credits For Indian Purchases
description: PARIS, Feb. 19 (AP) France has agreed to back credits of 340 million francs, or $77,3 million, to India for purchases of goods and services in France, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Policewomen Upheld in Attack on Seniority in Layoffs
description: A Federal appeals court declared yesterday that Civil Service seniority was not immune from legal challenge by women police officers who were dismissed in the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Music: Ruggles Century
description: The question after Wednesday night's Carl Ruggles centenary retrospective concert at Columbia's McMillin Theater is not so much whether Ruggles is as great a composer as his champions say he is, but whether a concert by the Performers Committee for 20thCentury Music is a proper showcase for making such a judgment.

title: . . . Minority Aid
description: So far as the New York school situation is concerned, the argument can certainly be made that any ironclad seniority rule is stultifying; but subjective personnel policies have too often been used as a cover for discriminatory practices and political favoritism.

title: PRIMARIES SCORED BY ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Vice President. Rockefeller asserted today that Presidential candidates were campaigning on personalities and promises in the primary elections. We are not having an informed debate on the grave issues that face present day America. he said.

title: Uneasy Duluth Filtering Water
description: DULUTH, Minn.  The firehouse in Duluth's Lakeside section is a little like the communal well in a primitive village. All day long, cars pull up and people carrying an array of containers enter a door to obtain drinking water from one of three spouts hanging over a metal trough.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Edith Grossman was pregnant, and she and her husband, Norman, wanted to try a natural childbirth method that was really natural. They didn't think the Lamaze method, the one that comes to mind most readily, was natural enough.

title: U.S. Mission at U.N. Got Private Money For Entertainment
description: The Government budget for social events given by the United States, Mission to the United Nations has been supplemented for many years by private contributions. This special fund has been channeled to the mission by the United Nations AsSociation of the United States of America, a private group of United Nations supporters.

title: Fed's Entry in Money Market Helps Strengthen Bond Prices
description: Credit market participants, escpecially those directly engaged in the Government sector, yesterday noted testimony by the Federal Reserve Board Chairman, Arthur F. Burns, that conceded room to maneuver on the nation's money supply. Then they watched with interest the central bank itself provide, through repurchase agreements, reserves to the nation's banking system.

title: COLLEGE PROTEST TURNS TO VIOLENCE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19Police dogs were used today to break up a disturbance by a splinter group of college students who scuffled with state troopers on the steps of the State House after pelting it with rocks and 2by4's and demanding to meet with Governor Byrne.

title: Foolish Pleasure Out of Race
description: MIAMI. Feb. 19 (UPI) Foolish Pleasure, John L. Greer's 1975 Kentucky Derby winner, was withdrawn today from Saturday's $100,000added Widener Handicap at Hialeah Park. He developed a boil [in the left hoof] and it's still a little tender,explained the colt's trainer, LeRoy Jolley. If this was an ordinary horse, we'd probably run him, but you don't take chances with a good one.

title: City Chess Team Wins
description: New York's chess team has defeated a major rival, San Francisco, in the third round of the National Chess League matches. In the nineteam roundrobin of telephone matches Wednesday night and early yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club, New York vanquished San Francisco 42, putting the West Coast players' record even at 11 with one match victory, one tie and now a loss,

title: Cavs Down Blazers for 7th in Row
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers trounced the Portland Trail Blazers, 11294 tonight for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory.

title: Messersmith Awaits ThirdStrike Call in Pitch for Freedom
description: Andy Messersmith, who gained 39 victories the last two seasons, could gain another today in the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Kansas City. If he does, the pitcher could come closer to being a free agent, able to sign with any major league club.

title: Strikes in Spain Expected To Change Labor Setup
Music: Tashi Plays Tashi Premiere
description: Tashi is the name of a highly successful and unusual chamber ensemble made up of Peter Serkin, pianist; Ida Kavafian, violinist and violist; Fred Sherry, cellist, and Richard Stoltzman, clarinetist. A piece has now been written and named for the ensemble. Composed by the Indefatigable Charles Wuorinen, it was given its premiere in a concert at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night.

title: LOCKHEED THINKS CONTRACT IS SAFE
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation believes that its proposed $750 million contract to supply Canada with 18 Orion long range patrol aircraft has not been jeopardized by the recent revelations that the company paid bribes to obtain foreign contracts.

title: Carter Resists Advice to Hit Back at Opponents' Gibes
description: CONCORD. N. H., Feb. 19 When some of Jimmy Carter's oppnnents began to criticize him by name last week, there was some talk among his advisers of responding in kind.

title: Article 5  No Title
South Africa Sees Hope Of Angola Understanding
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 19The expectation that South African soldiers would be facing Cuban columns heading from Angola to SouthWest Africa has given way here to feelings that some diplomatic accommodation can be struck! between South Africa and the Luanda government.

title: CAPITAL PLANNING BY CITY IS SCORED
description: Three days of public hearings on Mayor Beame's drastically curtailed $1.466 billion capital budget ended yesterday with pleas for the resumption of work on several suspended projects and with a mournful characterization of the proposed spending plan as the city's book of broken promises.

title: Joseph Henabery, Film Director, Dies
description: Joseph E. Henabery, veteran motion picture director and silentfilm actor, who played the role of Abraham Lincoln in D. W. Griffith's The Birth of a Nation. died Wednesday at the Motion Picture Country House in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 88 years old and lived in Tarzana, Calif.

title: Mr. Arbuthnot's Expertise
description: The clich was the butt of much of Frank Sullivan's humor, and to convey his japeries he invented Mr. Arbuthnot, an expert on the timeworn word and phrase. Following is one example of Mr. Arbuthnot's talents, freely excerpted from Mr. Sullivan's The Busy Clich Expert, from A Pearl in Every Oyster. (Little, Brown & Company, 1938: reprinted by Grosset & Dunlap, 1962):

title: Addabbo and Californian Deny Charges of Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Representatives Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, and Robert L. Leggett, Democrat of California, said today that they were being investigated by the Justice Department on charges of having accepted a bribe of under $10,000 last fall from the South Korean Government.

title: Ali at 226 For Bout Tonight
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 19 Uninspired by what appears to be a mismatch, Muhammad Ali will defend the world heavyweight boxing title tomorrow night in a scheduled 15round bout that will test the credibility of the challenger, JeanPierre Coopman of Belgium, as well as the resiliency of the champion.

title: CUNNINGHAM TOLD BY COURT TO OBEY NADJARI SUBPOENA
description: State Supreme Court Justice Leonard H. Sandier yesterday ordered Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman and Bronx County leader, to appear before a special grand jury investigating the sale of judgeships in the Bronx.

title: Halliburton Plans Split
description: The Halliburton Company announced yesterday the approval of a 3for1 stock split, which would give each shareholder two additional shares for each one held at the close of business on March 29. The company also announced a quarterly dividend increase on its common stock to 42 cents a share from 33 cents, payable March 23 to shareholders of record March 5.

title: E.C.A.C. Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: With the Lion, Ali Is a Lamb
MILTON COHEN
description: Milton Cohen, vice president and general manager of Hertz System Inc., a licensee company that rents and leases cars and trucks in affiliation with the Hertz Corporation, died Wednesday in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 58 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: United Cites Strike
description: United Air Lines Inc., which is still recovering from the after effects of a 16day strike in December, and National Airlines Inc., which resumed service only on Jan. 6, after having been struck since Aug. 31, both reported losses for January.

title: Lebanon Peace Is Expected to Strengthen Syria in Mideast Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 The Syrianimposed peace that is settling over Lebanon already contains hints of a firmness and political tidyness within both Lebanon and the Palestinian guerrilla movement that have been conspicuously absent in the last 10 months of nearanarchy and civil war.

title: Loans From Abroad Flow To Chile's Rightist Junta
description: Since Chile's rightwing military Government took power in a coup two and a half years ago, it has received some $2 billion in foreign credits, despite extremely adverse economic problems, a compilation from World Bank sources shows.

title: Ford Asks $25 Million Aid For Devastated Guatemala
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate $25 million in earthquake relief funds for Guatemala.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERNSTEINAda, Feb. 20, 1942. In Ioving memory Children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren.

title: 2 Vital Primaries for 4 Liberals
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 10 The headlines on the mornings after the New Hampshire primary next Tuesday and the Massachusetts primary a week later will tell who won. Less obvious  but of equal or perhaps greater importance will be the outcome of a campaign involving four liberal Democratic Press dential contenders.

title: Printers Leader Denies Cutoff of Strike Benefits
SENATE SUSTAINS VETO OF MEASURE ON CREATING JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Ford won another confrontation with Congress to1day as the Senate sustained his veto of a $6.2 billion measure aimed at creating jobs in state and local publicworks programs

title: Frank Sullivan Dies
description: Frank Sullivan, the humorist, died yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 83 years old. Page 36.

title: Study Finds Democratic Nations Stay With Liberalized Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19No democratic nation, once havin liberalized the availability of abortion, has returned to more restrictive laws, according to a new study of abortion laws around the world.

title: Law on Counsel Fees Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A judge has ruled here that a section of the Family Court Act is unconstitutional because it provides for granting counsel fees to a wife's lawyer but not to the husband's.

title: Sabres Defeat Flames
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 19 (AP) Thirdperiod goals by Rick Martin and Bill Hajt carried the Buffalo Sabres to a 31 National Hockey League victory over Atlanta tonight and extended the Flames streak on the road without a victory to eight games.

title: Group Led by C.I.A. Board Nominee Reportedly Got $15,000 From Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  A private humanitarian organization headed by Leo Cherne, one of President Ford's appointees to a new committee that will investigate possible abuses of authority by the Central Intelligence Agency, reportedly received some $15,000 of C.I.A. funds in the mid1960's that were channeled through a New York City philanthropic organization.

title: About New York; What's New on 7th Ave.? Don't Ask
description: The place to feel the pulse of the garment district is Dubrow's, which is a large cafeteria on Seventh Avenue and 38th Street. People from the garment district eat there, and when they do they talk about things that matter. What matters most right now is the dispute between the contractors and jobbers. No one in Dubrow's yesterday liked it.

title: Reforming the C.I.A.
description: President Ford's reform and reorganization of the country's foreign intelligence agencies is an important first step toward the elimination of abuses and the improvement in functioning that months of Congressional and press investigation have shown to be needed.

title: CONNALLY BACKED IN WRITEIN DRIVE
SYRIA SEEKING CURB ON P.L.O. IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 Syrian mediators have begun talks here toward defining the status of the Palestinian guerrilla movement in Lebanon.

title: Ashe Subdues Smith
description: ROME, Feb. 19 (UPI)Topseeded Arthur Ashe turned back a determined Stan Smith, 57, 64, 64, tonight and gained the semifinals of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: MACK MORRISS, 56, COMBAT REPORTER
description: Mick Morriss, a top combat correspondent for the Army magazine Yank in both Europe and the Pacific during World War II, died of emphysema Wednesday in a Johnson City, Term., hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: City Record Is Ending The Saturday Edition
description: The City Record, which has been recording the city's official business daily since 1873, will eliminate its Saturday edition beginning in March, but will continue to print five days a week. The Municipal Service Administrator, John T. Carroll, said the new schedule would save the city $104,000 a year.

title: MEETING APPEALS TO SOVIET ON JEWS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 19An international conference on the plight of Soviet Jews ended tonight with a call on Moscow to end the campaign of antiSemitism and to allow free emigration of Jews to Israel.

title: HAROLD G. KERN, 77, BOSTON PUBLISHER
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Harold G. Kern, for 37 years the publisher of The Boston HeraldAmerican and The Sunday Herald Advertiser and its predecessors. The Boston RecordAmerican and Sunday Advertiser, died here today. He was 77 years old.

title: HELMS WON'T FACE BREAKIN CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Justice Department said today it would not prosecute Richard Helms for his role in a 1971 domestic burglary, but an official said that Congressional testimony of the former Director of Central Intelligence was being reviewed.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GLOSTERDr. Cecil. The family of the late Dr. Cecil C. Gloster are very grateful and appreciative to everyone for their kind and deep expression of sympathy.

title: FORD INTENSIFIES ATTACK ON REAGAN
description: KEENE, N. H., Feb. 19  President Ford accused Ronald Reagan of pure political demgoguery here tonight while his aides began trying to minimize the importance of the New Hampshire Presidential primary.

title: Notre Dame Is Victor Over Fordham, 9178
description: A fine individual effort by Adrian Dantley, Notre Dame's 6foot5inch allAmerica basketball candidate, foiled a hustling upset bid by Fordham last night in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Records of Day Schools Sought in Medicaid Fraud
description: Records of about a dozen Hebrew day schools suspected of having served as vehicles for Medicaid swindles have been subpoenaed by Charles J. Hynes, the special prosecutor for nursing homes, according to Jewish religious sources.

title: STOCKS UP AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Responding to signs that the inflationary spiral was decreasing, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted another strong gain yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Sale of Chevettes In 1976 Model Run Expected to Lag
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20Robert D. Lund, manager of Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation, today revised downward his estimate of Chevette sales in this model year from 275,000 to 240,000.

title: Suffern Boat Show Will Begin Today
description: With more than 140 boats on display, the first Suffern (N.Y.) Boat Show opens its doors today at the Rockland Community College fieldhouse for a nineday stand.

title: Moves by House Against Schorr Raise Issue of Freedom of the Press
description: A demand was made in the House of Representatives yesterday that the Congressional press credentials of a television news reporter be revoked because he leaked a secret Congressional report to The Village Voice.

title: DUTY RISE ASKED ON SHOE IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The International Trade Commission ruled unanimously tonight that imports are damaging the United States shoe industry, and most of the six commissioners recommended to President Ford a sharply higher tariff on the imports.

title: BIG BANK CONCERN FILES BANKRUPTCY
description: Hamilton Bancshares Inc., a major regional holding company with banking interests in Tennessee and Georgia, filed for voluntary bankruptcy yesterday in Federal District Court in Chattanooga.

title: Gulf Oil Trying to Open Talks With Luanda on Cabinda Wells
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it was trying to open negotiations with the Sovietsupported Angolan government at Luanda with the aim of resuming operation of its oil wells off the coast of the Angolan territory of Cabinda.

title: Britain Trims Its Welfare Sails
description: LONDON, Feb. 20In presenting the Government's new spending plans yesterday, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, sounded more like a cautious

title: Fordham Confirms Release of Wissel
description: Fordham University officially confirmed yesterday that Hal Wissel will not he retained as head basketball coach next. season. He will finish the final two games of this season and then the university will begin its search for another coach. Wissel, who is finishing his fifth season at Fordham, has one year remaining on a twoyear contract.

title: Nixon Is Off on 2d Trip to China To Revisit Scenes of a Triumph
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 Richard M. Nixon set out today on his second trip to China, this time as a private citizen invited by the Chinese Government to revisit the scene of one of the brightest moments of his Presidency.

title: Clarkstown Told to Pay $1.7 Million Left Off Tax Bill
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Feb. 20A state Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the town of Clarkstown must make up the $1.7 million tax payment that Rockland County left off the town's 1974 tax bill in an administrative error.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Claudius Matthews wore a bulletproof vest. His hearing room in Brooklyn Criminal Court was cleared of spectators, the police formed a protective cordon outside, and the defendant's lawyer waived a hearing following telephoned threats that Darwish Ali Darwish, 25 years old, an Arab charged with murder, would be killed by the family of the victim. Mr. Darwish, of 396 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, was said to have fired three shots into the head of Carl Ennab, 35, Monday night at an Arab social club 196 State Street, in the climax of a long feud between their families. Mr. Darwish's lawyer, Jack Evseroff, did not ask for bail, fearing for his client's life, and his client was ordered held in administrative segregation at the Brooklyn House of Detention pending a court appearance Monday or Tuesday.

title: Knicks' Lineups
description: AT GARDEN. 8 P.M.

title: Ending Competition Between Public and Private Universities Here
description: The new austerity in higher education afflicts public and independent institutions alike, and, at least in New York State, tomorrow will be even harsher than today.

title: Nixon Trip Revives Issue Vexing to Ford in Primary
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 20 Former President Richard M. Nixon's departure on a visit to China today has forced to the surface an awkward issue that President Ford had been hoping to avoid in his close and possibly crucial contest with Ronald Reagan in the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Lutz, Panatta Win
description: ROME, Feb. 20 (UPI)Bob Lutz of the United States and Adriano Panatta of Italy joined Arthur Ashe and Dick Stockton today in the semifinals of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Wall St. T rading at Record As Prices Hit 3Year High
description: Wall Street had its busiest day in history yesterdayagain. Trading volume reached 44.51 million shares, breaking the record set only a day earlier, and stock prices rose to a threeyear high. Brokers attributed the upsurge in part to growing speculative interest by individual investors.

title: A Diplomatic Passport For Former President
description: SAN DIEGO. Feb. 20 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon is going to China as a private citizen but with a diplomatic passport, according to State Department officials.

title: FOOD PRICE CUTS IN JANUARY EASED RATE OF INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The nation's inflation rate continued to moderate slightly in January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.N. Aide to Visit Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Roberto Guyer, United Nations Under Secretary General, will leave on Monday for Israel, Egypt, Syria and Jordan to explore prospects for a resumption of Middle East negotiations, it was announced here today.

title: Circle in the Square
description: A quarter of a century agowhich is eons in the life of the theaterthe founders of what became a major force in the Off Broadway movement sat around an abandoned nightclub in Sheridan Square, trying to dream up a catchy name for their new, nonprofit enterprise. How about Chicken in the Basket? someone suggested. Reason and artistic director Theodore Mann prevailed, and Circle In the Square was born.

title: Antiques: At the Garden
description: The National Antiques Show, New York's largest and oldest antiques show, is filled this year with as much glitter, color and abundance of wares as always.

StampBurning in Laos
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 21 (AP)The Communist government of Laos will burn a series of stamps commemorating the United States Bicentennial next Thursday, the Vietname radio said today. The stamps were printed last year before the Communists completed their takeover.

title: For the DressAlike Couple
Wall St.Trading at Record As Prices Hit 3Year High
TALKS CONTINUING IN DRESS INDUSTRY
description: Several hours of meetings yesterday failed to end a dispute between two types of dressindustry employers that has idled 20,000 to 30,000 workers since last Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: ORDER IS ISSUED FOR BOEING DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) A Federal judge today ordered the Boeing Company to turn over to the Securities and Exchange Commission any documents that might show foreign payoffs by the aircraft manufacturer.

title: Open Interest

title: Fight for Stability
description: The lockout that has idled over 20,000 dressmakers in the metropolitan area is an unhappy reflection of a quiet revolution in industrial relations in what was once New York City's busiest industry.

title: Brooklynites Take Hand in PotholeFilling
Connors, Mayer Advance
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 20 (AP)Jimmy Connors, the defender and topseeded player, and fourthseeded Alex Mayer scored straightset victories tonight in quarterfinal matches at the United States national indoor open tennis championships.

title: ARGENTINA ELECTION IS SET FOR DEC. 12
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20 (Reuters)The Argentine Government announced tonight that presidential elections would be held on Dec. 12

title: I.C.C. Supports Rise In RailFreieht Rates
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized yesterday the 67 big railroads of the country to increase their freight rates by an average of 4.7 percent on March 6.

title: A DAYCARE STUDY FINDS FAVORITISM
description: A fouryearold report on the city's daycarecenter leasing program suggested that major developers of the centers appeared to receive favored treatment from the city, said that speculation in daycarecenter leases can obviously lead to serious abuses, and concluded that a limit should be placed on the number of daycarecenter leases which may be acquired by a single developer or group.

title: Red Smith
description: SAN JUAN. P. R., Feb. 20All Gaul, a fight writer named. Big Julie Caesar reported some time back, is divided into three parts. And, he added, the Belgi were the bravest.

title: Citibank Holds 6% Prime
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it was keeping its prime rate at 6 percent.

title: Teng Named in Hangchow
description: PEKING, Feb. 20 (Agence FrancePress)  Hundreds of posters have appeared this week on the streets of Hangchow, southern China, and nany attack Mr. Teng by name.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Attorney General's office said yesterday that Dr. Allan G. Beck of Budd Lake had pleaded guilty Morris County Court to a charge of fraudulently obtaining a powerful painkilling drug. Dr. Beck, 32 years old, agreed to surrender his medical license and to undergo treatment for a personal drug problem, the office said.

title: Ripley Vault, Stones Jump Break Marks
OPEC to Meet May 27 and Discuss Prices
description: The oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet May 27 in Jakarta, Indonesia, to discuss prices and other issues, an OPEC representative announced yesterday in Vienna.

title: Con Edison Gains Support For the Use of Dirtier Fuel
description: Business and union spokesmen were ranged against environmental protection advocates yesterday in support of a Consolidated Edison proposal that it be permitted to use fuel oil with a higher sulfur content at its electricity generating stations in the city to reduce customer energy bills by 2.8 Percent.

title: FOOD STAMP CURB ORDERED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) President Ford has ordered the Agriculture Department to bypass Congress and swiftly issue regulations which will set in motion the reforms needed in the food stamp program.

title: GriffithBaker Bout Set
description: Emile Griffith, who won the world welterweight championship three times and the middleweight title twice, will fight Irish Mike Baker in a 10round middleweight bout at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., on March 1.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Offers Help To Neuter Home Pets
description: Dog and cat owners of limited means will be able to have their pets neutered at minimal cost under a special program that has been instituted by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, it was announced yesterday.

title: BRAZIL STRESSES DEFICIT IN TRADE
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, Feb. 20 Secretary of Slate Henry A. Kissinger met today with the ranking officials of the Brazilian Government, but both sides appeared to be far apart on key issues that have strained relations between the United States and Brazil.

title: $14 Million U.S. Aid For Projects Voted By State Crime Unit
description: The State Crime Control Planning Board yesterday approved 66 grants of Federal funds totaling $14,840,512 for law enforcement and criminaljustice projects in the state, including $7,383,015 for 24 Projects in the city.

title: Rogovin Photographs of Buffalo Are Shown

description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 20 The Government made a cautious gesture toward home rule in Catalonia today near the close of a visit by King Juan Carlos.

title: U.S. for Majority Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The United States expressed firm support today for majority rule in Rhodesia and said it hoped that negotiations between black and white leaders there would end the southern African country's constitutional crisis.

title: Icebreakers Cut a Path for Finnish Trade
description: ABOARD THE ICEBREAKER URHOA weak winter sun hung somewhere over a horizon obliterated by the vast monotony of snow and white sky. The Finnish icebreaker Urho rumbled as the steel bow sliced cleanly at 15 knots through nearly two feet of snowcrusted ice on the frozen Gulf of Bothnia.

title: Buckley Softens His Opposition To Extending Election Group
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley withdrew today his opposition to temporarily continuing the Federal Election Commission. An aide said the move amounted to an invitation to the Justice Department to ask the Supreme Court to extend its deadline for reconstituting the panel.

title: Harry J. Fishbein Is Dead at 78; Won 16 National Bridge Titles
description: Harry J. Fishbein, one of America's leading bridge players, died in the New York Infirmary Thursday, following a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: Music: Levine Conducts
description: Any symphony orchestra would rather play well than poorly, if only because playing well is easier on mind and body. You may think you have been bored at some concert, but imagine how the musicians felt after rehearsing that boring program intensively and then playing it three or four times within a week. They like the time to pass pleasantly at least as much as anyone else.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BABBLE AND STARES IN WILSON DIA LOG
description: Were Robert Wilson's dia log mounted modestly below 14th Street, it might have faded quietly as a bit of pathetic, experimental rubbish. Overproduced in the Whitney Museum's vast fourthfloor gallery on Thursday evening, it emerged as an exercise in unrewarding hubris.

title: FORD SAID TO PICK NEW NATO ENVOY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Presidet Ford is expected to announce soon the nomination of Robert StrauszHup, currently United States Ambassador to Sweden, as the new envoy to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Administration officials said.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands in The New York Times of Wednesday. it was incorrectly stated that the Hoogovens Steel Works had merged with the big German chemical manufacturer Hoechst. Actually Hoogovens merged with the German iron and steel company Hoesch.

title: Pardon Me, Comrade
description: Richard M. Nixon sits high on the wall Draped in Mao ties and Lincolnesque shawl, Balancing chopsticks, headlines and all While Gerald R. Ford may have a great fall.

title: Boston U. Aims for Recognition
Tax Consultant Arrested
description: DALLAS, Feb. 20 (UPI)Peter Klyne, an author and consultant on how to avoid paying income taxes, was arrested yesterday by Internal Revenue Service agents on a charge of violating tax laws. United States Attorney Michael Carnes said an indictment alleged Mr. Klyne had prepared false documents for Anthony Francis Caterine, a Dallas talent agency owner.

title: Lisbon Expected to Recognize Luanda Regime as Government
For New York, a Time of Testing as the Nation Looks On
description: Whether or not the promises of social and economic entitlements of the 1960's can be rolled back to a lower order of magnitude without social upheaval is being tested in New York City.

title: THREE WORKS GIVEN BY STUTTGART TRIO
description: The Stuttgart Piano Trio, which gave the first of two Mozart Mendelssohn  Schubert concerts Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall (the second will he Thursday) as part of its third American tour, is capable of stirring, straightforward accounts of its music. The trouble is that the trio's playing was sometimes too stirring for its own good.

title: Inquiry Service Set Up To Assist Guatemalans
description: The Salvation Army has begun an emergency telephoneradio inquiry service to Guatemala to assist individuals who are seeking information on relatives in the earthquakestricken country.

title: STATE STUDY ASKS CITY TO DISSOLVE HOSPITAL AGENCY
description: The State Health Department has called for the virtual dismantling of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, saying that its central office is caught in a maze of bureaucratic inefficiencies from which there is no exit.

description: Dr. John A. P. Millet, psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died Wednesday in Nyack, N. Y. He was 87 years old.

title: Women and Money: Simple Advice
Trabert Is Cup Captain Again
description: Stan Malless, president of the United States Tennis Association, said yesterday that Tony Trabert would be retained as Davis Cup captain, despite the loss to Mexico in this year's competition.

Market Place
description: Whenever the stock market booms, corporate managers begin to watch the price of common shares in relation to convertible securities.

title: Future of Cable TV: The Picture Brightens
description: The legislative climate for cable television has improved markedly in the last few weeks. For years, the cabletelevision industry has been linable to find adherents to its cause within the Government and has been frustrated in its attempts to stir a national debate on the role of cable in the future communications of the country.

title: Communists Focus on Local Needs in an Italian City
description: CESENA, ItalyThe Mayor pushed back from his desk, walked into an adjoining conference room used for marriage ceremonies and pointed to the inscriptionover a baroque mirror that has hung for years in the old City Hall. It reads: Remember that you govern men.

title: Miss Evert Victor
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20 (UPI) Topseeded Chris Evert, leaving the baseline only twice, methodically crushed Elly Apel Vessies of the Netherlands, 61, 60, tonight and moved into the semifinals of the $75,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

title: Stage: Same Time, 1976
description: Confession. The other day I did not like Same Time, Next Year, which is still playing perfectly happily at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, as much as I liked it the same time last year. Now this confession could quite easily be pussyfootedit could be suggested, for example, that the present cast is not so good as the original. And, in fact, it probably is not. It was to review the two new actors in the play that I went to see it again.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The Better Business Bureau of Greater Newark reported this week that customers who had sent away for certain brandname samples of cosmetics through magazine ads had complained by the hundreds about what they received in the mail, if they received anything at all.

title: POSTAL RATE LIFTS COSTS IN CITY AREA
description: Prices paid by consumers in the New YorkNorth Jersey region continued a moderate rise of seventenths of 1 percent last month, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: Allison Takes Pole
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 20 (AP)Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., making his first shorttrack start in a Mercury, won the pole position today for Sunday's eighth annual Richmond 400 Grand National stock car race. Allison was clocked at 92,716 miles per hour.

title: People in Sports
description: The Yankees are bringing Tommy Davis back to New York. They signed the Brooklynborn Davis as a free agent yesterday, and a spokesman said they planned to use him as their righthanded designated hitter, platooning him with Ron Blomberg. This is the 10th major league club for the 36yearold Davis, who was released about a week ago by the Baltimore Orioles. He had originally signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers but by the time he had made it to the major leagues, they had moved to Los Angeles.

title: Pure Prairie League Playing Country Rock at Bottom Line
description: Disco music is supposed to be slugging it out with rockandroll at the top of the charts these days. But they are hardly the only fads around. County, rock continues its steady inroads into national taste, particularly the easily swinging sort that traces its roots to the late Bob Wills.

title: The Flexibility and Fun Of Mixing Modular Units
description: The modular wall system has come a long way since Paul McCobb, the late American designer, promoted the look of unified bookcases, chests, cabinets, drop  lid desks and bars some decades ago.

title: First ShipShore Satellite Scheduled to Orbit Today
description: Marisat 1, the first of two United States communications satellites designed to link ships to stations on shore, is scheduled to he placed onto a circular orbit more than 22.000 miles above the equator at 7:30 o'clock this morning.

title: A Radiant Tebaldi Delights Her Fans At Carnegie Recital
description: You know something, Renata Tebaldi said to her adoring audience at Carnegie Hall on Thurday night, I love you very much. Just watching the soprano, radiant and luxuriating in the ovations that preceded, punctuated and followed her recital, one could not doubt the sincerity of her statement. Just watching her fans during the six encores, as they clustered around the stage, handing up flowers, blowing kisses, waving and cheering, one could not doubt the continued effectiveness of the diva's theatrical magic.

title: Plea to Trap Killer Tiger
description: DACCA. Bangladesh. Feb. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Worried Bangladesh forest authorities have launched an appeal for the trapping of a Royal Bengal tiger that has killed about 30 people since 1971 in a region about 350 miles southeast of Dacca.

title: Ali's Uppercut Knocks Out Coopman At 2:46 of Fifth Round in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 20 As easily as Clyde Beatty used to tame the lions in his circus act, Muhammad Ali retained the world heavyweight boxing championship tonight with a fifthround knockout of JeanPierre Coopman, the alleged Lion of Flanders, before a noisy gathering of 10,000 spectators in the Roberto Clemente Coliseum.

title: Ski Resort Boom Is Over Despite Crowds in Rockies
description: DENVER, Feb. 20The Western ski resort boom, which saw 14 new ski areas open in the Rocky Mountain States from 1964 to 1974, is just about over.

title: RICH, POOR NATIONS END AMICABLE TALK
description: PARIS, Feb. 20Senior officials from rich and poor countries completed two weeks of talks tonight in what was described as a constructive and cooperative atmosphere marked by progress.

title: Ali Retains Title
description: Muhammad Ali easily retained his world heavyweight boxing title last night as he knocked out JeanPierre Coopman of Belgium in the fifth round of a scheduled 15round bout in San Juan, P.R. Page 17.

title: Toonerville, Star on Turf, On New Track in Widener
description: MIAMI, Feb. 20The withdrawal of Foolish Pleasure makes tomorrow's Widener Handicap at Hialeah more interesting, but also removes virtually all of is significance. Without Foolish Pleasure, it is just another race with a $100,000added purse. Now, LeRoy Jolley, Foolish Pleasure's trainer. must decide whether to run the horse in the Santa Anita Handicap on March 7 at a mile and a quarter or race in the $50,000added Donn Handicap at seven furlongs on opening day at Gulfstream, March 6. Then it will be the Gulfstream Handicap on March 20 and on to New York for the New York Racing Association's triple crown for handicap horses.

title: ACCOUNTING RULE IS STIRRING DEBATE
description: An obscure and involved new accounting rule, affecting the way Americanbased multinational corporations translate their farflung earnings and balancesheet items into dollars, is expected to produce volatile swings in quarterly reported earnings by many of the nation's leading companies. But the change would not affect real operating earnings or cash flow.

title: Treasury 21Month Note To Yield Around 6.62%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Treasury sold today $2.5 billion of 21month notes at an average return of 6.62 percent. The department received $4.8 billion of tenders for the notes, which will carry a coupon interest rate of 6 percent.

title: PHILIPPINE REBELS KILL 21 IN AMBUSH
description: ZAMBOANGA, The Philippines, Feb. 20 (AP)Heavily armed men believed to be Moslem rebels ambushed a passenger bus, killed at least 21 persons and wounded several others in a town 87 miles north of Zamboanga, survivors said today.

title: Youth Seized in College Protest Strolled Off Under False Name
description: TRENTON. Feb. 20  The state police were seeking today the identity of a youth arrested during a melee in front of the State House yesterday.

title: Soccer Player, 23, Dies
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20 (AP)Oscar Suraez, a 23 yearold Argentine soccer forward whose team toured Zaire last month, has died of malaria in a hospital near here. Hospital officials said today that Suarez apparently had contracted malaria during the tour. Earlier, he had been reported to be suffering from hepatitis.

title: Montreal Conquers Rangers
Youth in Wheelchair Appeals to Ford To Save School for the Handicapped
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 20A youngster who is confined to a wheelchair and who speaks with the aid of an electric amplifier dictated letter to President Ford this week, asking him to save the A. Harry Moore School.

title: Dodge Mansion Opening to the Public
Marion Javits Confirms Bid to Represent Mexico
description: Marion Javits, wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York. has confirmed reports circulating for months among Jewish organizations here that she and Ruder & Finn, the public relations firm, had made a bid last fall to the Mexican Government to do public relations work aimed at mending its problems with the Jewish community in the United States.

title: Books of The Times
BIG BANK CONCERN FILES BANKRUPTCY

description: While William Cahn, former District Attorney of Nassau County, was combining business with pleasure by gambling in Reno and Las Vegas during official trips, he was lecturing publicly against legalized gambling, it was brought out yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: U. S. Indecision and the World
description: LONDONThe degree of decline in United States prestige abroad exceeds by far what most Americans imagine to be the case. The uncertainty of U. S. leadership, the insistence on exposing vital secrets, and an exaggerated case of normal election year paralysis have inspired grave doubts about Washington's capacity to act.

Nixon's departure on a visit to China today has forced to the surface an awkward issue that President Ford had been hoping to avoid in his close and possibly crucial contest with Ronald Reagan in the New Hampshire Republican primary.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Senators drafting intelligence supervisory legislation appeared today to abandon plans to require the White House to give Congress prior notification of secret operations.

description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed part of a New York Civil Liberties Union complaint charging that some children in foster care were being denied their constitutional rights because no efforts were being made to find adoptive homes for them.

title: Law Firm's Alleged Role in Lockheed Case an Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Allegations that the prestigious law firm of Coudert Brothers served as a middle man for European payments by the scandalridden Lockheed Aircraft Corporation have posed what sortie experts view as new, hard questions about the responsibility of lawyers in the context of corporate corruption.

title: Princeton Crushes Dartmouth by 7451
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 It has been seven years since Princeton won the Ivy league basketball championship. But tonight in Jadwin Gymnasium the Tigers solidified their hold on first place by routing a badly disorganized Dartmouth team, 7451.

title: IVETTE HERNANDEZ GIVES PIANO RECITAL
description: Ivette Hernandez, a Cubanborn pianist now living here. ended her recital at Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday night with 13 dances by Ignacio Cervantes. The composer, also Cuban. lived during the second half of the 19th century and was a protg of Gottschalk. Among other works. he left a set of 37 dances, from which those played by Miss Hernandez were drawn.

title: Corruption's Menace
description: The acts of multinational and multimilliondollar bribery committed by representatives of Lockheed Aircraft Corporationactions that are shaking confidence in the business and political institutions of Japan, the Netherlands, and other countries, including the United States will be shrugged off by some cynics or pragmatists nothing more than business as usual, as the Watergate scandals were justified by many of Mr. Nixon's sympathizers as nothing more than politics as usual.

title: Rene Cassin, Jurist, Dies; Won Nobel Peace Prize
description: PARIS, Feb. 20Ren Cassin, internationally known jurist and winner of the 1968 Nobel Peace Prize, died here today at the age of 88.

title: Hyperbole in Brasilia
description: Hyperbole is standard fare at banquets for visiting statesmen; but Secretary of State Kissinger's 15page paean of praise for Braziland by implication for its authoritarian military regimewent beyond the bounds of reason, The speech will harm this country's relations with other Latin American nations, give respectability to leftist charges of collusion between Brasilia and Washington, and bolster the image of the United States as supporter of rightwing dictatorships.

title: Plea for a Historic Flagpole
description: John Van Arsdale scaled a greased flagpole one day in 1783 and won himself a footnote in American history.

title: Sadat to Visit Arab Oil States In Urgent Search of Support
description: CAIRO, Feb. 20President Anwar elSadat will fly to Saudi Arabia with all the important members of his Cabinet tomorrow in an attempt to obtain urgently needed political and financial support from the Arab oil countries. Visits to Kuwait, Abu Dhabi, Bahrain and Qatar were added to the schedule at the last moment.

title: Intelligence: Ford Plan May Have Rekindled Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  President Ford. possibly more by accident than intent, appears to have rekindled the great debate on the future and control of the United States intelligence system. The subject had been moribund here for several weeks, lost in trivia about who leaked what to whom and the fading interest of an electionbound Congress.

title: STATE STUDY ASKS CITY TO DISSOLVE HOSPITAL AGENCY
COAL MINING TRIED BY HAMILTON BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20In the months before its collapse, Hamilton Bancshares Inc. appears to have participated in a bizarre attempt to help pull one of its subsidiaries out of difficulty through a Tennessee coalmining venture.

title: 25,000 Teachers Will Get Salary Rise
description: Acting on new advice from City Hall, the Board of Education will give 25,500 teachers salary stepups they are eligible for on March 1, even though the board and the teachers union still have not reached agreement on a citymandated deferral of pay raises.

title: Claude Carpenter, Designer Of Film Sets, Won 5 Oscars
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 20 (AP) Claude E. Carpenter, winner of five Academy Awards for set decorations in Viva Zapata!, Grand Hotel and other movies, died Wednesday at the age of 71.

title: A Carolina Town Is Cynical on Vote
description: SANFORD, N.C., Feb. 15Roy Stewart, the paving company owner who is also Mayor of this Southern industrial town of 11,500, worries about unemployment in his town, the high cost of living. inflation, crime and drugs. But mainly, like a great number of others in this Sports  minded town, he worries about the fate of the American Legion baseball team, the state champions who were Knocked out of national contention last season by a controversial loss.

title: Television Sets Cleared
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 20 (UPI) More than I million Zenith. color television sets, found capable of surpassing the acceptable level of radiation. emissions, do not pose any significant injury risk. the United States Bureau of Radiological Health said today. The bureau said it had run tests on the sets after it was discovered that failure of a capacitator could result in release of more than the 0.5 millrogentgen an hour or radiation permitted by Federal standards. Calculations showed, however, that the risk of cancer death or genetic damage was not sufficient to require Zenith to either notify owners or modify the sets, bureau said,

But once that had been said there was a great deal to enjoy.

title: Notes on People
description: The new director of Radio Free Europe is Albert E. Hemsing, a former filmmaker for clothing and textile unions here and teacher of film technique at City College. He has been at the American embassy in New Delhi since he was brought in by Daniel P. Moynihan, then ambassador, to head the United States Information Service there in 1973. Mr. Hemsing, who has resigned from the Foreign Service after 18 years, succeeds Ralph E. Walter, who will be programming vice president of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, which broadcasts to the Soviet Union. Mr. Hemsing is a 1942 City College graduate with a master's degree from New York University. From 195155 he directed films in Europe for the Marshall Plan.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The face of fortune smiled upon Wall Street last week. In fact, it grinned. On Friday, capping a memorable fourday week, volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to a recordshattering 44.51 million shares. The previous record, 39.21 million shares, had been set just the previous day. The Dow Jones industrial average, not to be outdone, moved to its best levels in three years. The Dow climbed 12.04 points on Friday to close at 987.80, up 28.70 points for the week.

title: Criminals At Large
That oldtime religion is good enough again
description: Forward they come, streaming toward the lighted armory stage by the hundreds, sometimes by the thousandsthe crippled, the cancerous, the arthritic, the ulcerated. The organ croons Just As I Am. The voice of the evangelist soars heavenward as his or her hands touch shrunken legs and swollen torsos, Do it now God, do it now! In the name of Jesus, heal! A generation ago religious healing was relegated to the Christian Scientists, to tambourine  thumping pentecostal store fronts and miraculous Catholic shrines. But in the last two decades a mammoth revival of healing evangelism has swept across America, bursting class and denominational barriers, moving from makeshift tents first into giant auditoriums and onto network TV, and then into respectable churches. The message of this movement is also about salvation from sin, but the main thrust is something else: miracles still happen and God's spirit is abroad in the land healing and making whole. In a significant rebirth of a phenomenon that has been part of religion since its inception, healing the sick is the central feature of the spiritual renascence this book describes.

title: A sixties dropout in 18thcentury Germany
description: Hermann Hesse was a dropout who felt that school had nearly ruined him. All that I learned there, he said, was Latin and lying. Which is one reason why he has been so popular with the recent generation of American students. They turned to a German writer because there isn't very much in AngloAmerican literature to satisfy an angry discontent with official knowledge, a discontent aspiring to he philosophical. The very idea of the growing up novel (Bildungsrornan), that German specialty, implied a criticism of the limitations of formal education. Goethe doesn't show Wilhelm Meister in the classroom nor Thomas Mann Hans Castorp; their true education is an education in life. It's true a great English poet had called books barren leaves and disliked his Cambridge years, finding Nature (and the dropout Coleridge) better teachers. But Wordsworth (though loved by Paul Goodman) was too dull for the student movement of the sixties. It was Blake whom Allen Ginsberg chantedbut not the Blake who said that to Labour in Knowledge is to Build up Jerusalem, and to Despise Knowledge is to Despise Jerusalem & her Builders.

title: A professional guide to watching tennis
description: Last September, much to most everyone's surprise, the quiet, unassuming Manuel Orantes of Spain calmly squelched the brash, cocky American superstar Jimmy Connors in the U.S. Open championships at Forest Hills. Since then. Connors has been tasting revenge. A televised rematch has been arranged for next Saturday at Las Vegas, where the winner will receive $250,000. Such TV challenge matches seem to have joined the ranks of a few other sports eventslike the Super Bowl or the Olympicsthat periodically assault the public consciousness. Watching Billie Jean King conquer male chauvinism or Connors humble the great Rod Laver has been to watch a happening.

description: MIAMI, Feb. 21Charisma won the Lipton Cup race on the. Southern Ocean Racing circuit today and restored the faith of her owner, Jess Philips, in the sport of yacht racing.

title: GARDENING
description: MANY gardeners do not realize that small and mediumsized dahlias can be grown from seed and thus provide the summer garden with some of its brightest and most prolific blooms. They are endlessly useful to fill in between clumps of daffodils, tulips or bearded irises, and to combine with marigolds for a spectacular color riot in late summer; or, of course, to grow in masses by themselves.

title: An American's record of a troubled time
description: Nothing, it seems, cools off so completely as dated political passion and anger. The Flower and the Nettle harks back to an old, furious controversy and makes us wonder sadly what it was all about. Why did we attack our erstwhile hero so savagely?

title: House Plant Bonsai
A Sense of Self in Pop Music
description: LONG ISLAND is still a suburb. But to a much greater extent than New Jersey or Westchester County or even, maybe, New York's own boroughs beyond Manhattan, Long Island has a distinct sense of self. Or at least that seems to be the case in popular music after talks with leading personalities on the popmusic scene in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: ART
description: WERNER GROSHANS, whose oil canvases and pastels are on view at the Montclair Art Museum, restores faith in the craft of painting. Unlike many contemporary artists, Mr. Groshans has learned what all art students were once required to learn as part of their profession: the fundamental uses of color, the skills of drawing and an understanding of the figure.

title: Pamela Becker Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Becker of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Rose Becker, to Edward Joseph Feinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Feinstein of Holyoke, Mass.

Catherine B. McKee Planning Marriage to Lee M. Donovan
description: Catherine Barbara McKee, granddaughter of the late Joseph V. McKee, who was Mayor of New York, plans to be married April 3 to Lee Millard Donovan, a senior vice president of the Commerce Bank in Bethesda, Md.

title: WOMACK CHEERED IN MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: Frankle (Hollywood) Crocker, the popular radio personality, probably did not intend to pith representatives of the Philadelphia, Discotheque, Southern Soul and Motown Sounds, against one another in a battle of the bands when he organized the latest edition of his New York Music Festival. But the bands he picked for the festival, which ends a threeday run this evening at the Radio City Music Hall, are all characteristic of their respective genres and all of them are currently enjoying hit records. A battle for the affections of the audience was inevitable, with the outcome something of a surprise.

title: Kathryn Kuhlman, Evangelist And Faith Healer, Dies in Tulsa
description: Kathryn Kuhlman, regarded by devotees and doubters alike as one of America's most popular evangelists and faith healers died Friday at the Hillcrest Medical Center in Tulsa, Okla., where she had been since undergoing openheart surgery Dec. 28. She had always kept her age a secret, but was believed to be in her early 60's.

title: Congress and Mr. Schorr
description: A member of Congress has demanded the revocation of the Congressional press credentials of Daniel Schorr, the CBS news correspondent who leaked the House report on intelligence to The Village Voice. At the same time, the Justice Department is conducting an investigation to see if Federal espionage laws were violated by the leak. Mr. Schorr has contended that once he became aware that he possessed the only copy of the report outside the Government, he could not be the sole person responsible for suppressing it.

title: Apollos Get U.S. Flavor
description: Eugene Czyzowych, who has often coached the United States national team, has signed to coach the New York Apollos of the American Soccer League.

title: What They Are Saying
description: A World Team Tennis spokesman explains the difficulty in signing Bjorn Borg to play in the league: Every time World Team Tennis makes him an offer, the King of Sweden matches it.

title: Cypriot Leaders Plan More Talks
description: VIENNA, Feb. 21 (Reuters)Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders today laid down a twostage timetable for further talks on the future of their divided island and voiced confidence that negotiations were back on course after months of delay.

title: Cruft's Is for the Exhibitors And Westminster for Viewers
description: LONDON, Feb. 21Cruft's is a show for the exhibitor, Westminster for the spectator. Westminster had only eight rings In Madison Square Garden, because of space limitations, but Cruft's had a lavish,32 in three huge exhibition halls, covering 13 acres, in Olympia. The Westminster Centennial show in New York, forced to limit its entry, had 3,098 dogs. Cruft's. striving to hold down by requiring a placement at a championship show, had a record 9,818, beating the previous mark by 1,551.

title: The Lost War
description: Letters from British Officers During the American Revolution. Edited and annotated by Marion Balderston and David Syrett. Introduction by Henry Steele Commager. 237 p.p. New York: Horizon Press. $11.95.

title: TV VIEW
description: Tonight at 9, ABCTV will present the television premiere of The Last Detail, a 1973 film starring Jack Nicholson. Once again, presumably, TV will be bringing free to its audience a commodity that tens of thousands have paid for at the box office. The problem is thatit isn't quite the same commodity. It looks the same, but it hardly sounds the same. And, commulatively, the changes have been so extensive that the presentation of the TV product as the movie widely praised by film critics begins to border on deception.

title: Notes: Wooing Big Money for Off Off Broadway

Aid for the Schools?
description: The state of the nation's schools has had such low priority as an area of national concern for so long that President Ford's promise of an increase in the education budget offers at least a glimmer of hope. Instead of holding fast to current levels of elementary and secondary school support, Mr. Ford now hints at some slight raising of the ceiling which he had previously imposed.

title: Tribal Pride In Burlington
description: DRIVEN from their ancestral homeland by what they say is a continuing pattern of racial discrimination and drawn to the Delaware Valley by the greater economic opportunities of the industrial North, a group of migrants who claim descent from the oncepowerful Powhatan Nation of southern Indian tribes have turned the Burlington County community of Moorestown into the center of a unique and ambitious effort: to preserve the current of ancient Indian identity while struggling toward the mainstream of modern American life.

title: Panama Canal: Like a Journey Down the Evolutionary Tree
description: FOURTH of July Avenue is a wide and busy thoroughfare. I paused where it runs between the countryclublike splendor of Ancon Hill, in the United Statescontrolled Panama Canal Zone, and the crowded tenement neighborhood of El Chordllo, in the Republic of Panama. Along here in 1964 antiAmerican riots took the lives of three Americans and 21 Panamanians. According to the Panamanian tourist map I had in my pocket, I was on Avenida de los MartiresAvenue of the Martyrs.

title: Satellite Is Placed in Orbit For Navy Communications
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI)  The world's first maritime communications satellite, Marisat I, was placed in a stationary orbit today over the Atlantic Ocean where it will provide instant communications for the United States Navy and merchant ships.

description: Dr. Joseph Lander, a psychiatrist and neurologist who headed the psychiatric department of the Jewish Board of Guardians here from 1955 to ]968, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.
