description: Gov. George C. Wallace's campaign organization in this state has entered candidates for delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 23 of the 39 Congressional districts. This put him in a tie for fifth place in the number of districts entered by the Presidential aspirants.

title: G.E. Wins Appeal on Work
description: PHILADELPHIA. Feb. 21 (AP)A Federal court has reversed a lower court decision prohibiting the General Electric Company from transferring work from its Philadelphia plant to a plant in Iowa. A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit Wednesday that G.E. was allowed to transfer work to other pants without conferring with local union members.

J., confirms the tightmoney situation has eased with many institutions in recent months.

title: MacDonald, Larouche Lead Rout by Penguins

Peking Struggle
description: A climax seems to be nearing in the furious power struggle that exploded in public in Peking after Chou Enlai's death last month. Even as recently as the time of Chou's funeral, it had seemed likely that his designated successor, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping, would take the helm of China's Government.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Dance and the epic form. Already we are in trouble. Epic and dancedo they go together? Imagine Beowulf in dance terms (with a different unfavorite ballerina getting her comeuppance as Grendel's mother every successive night?) or the Iliad or Paradise Lost. Imagine the scope, intention and intensity of Wagner's Ring even as a fundamental, but occasionally guiltily admiring, antiWagnerite, I must admit that such epic density is beyond the grasp of dance. Dance is cryptic. It scratches on a small stone the same imprint that a Wagner would plant a flag on Everest for. But what happens when ballet has illusions of epic? Note the word illusionspresumably, I have already given my hand away.

title: Kennedy Kopechne Report Questioned
description: A new investigation by two journalists into the drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's car on Chappaquiddick Island in 1969 has turned up evidence casting doubt on two portions of the Senator's sworn testimony and statements by a deputy sheriff who contradicted him at an inquest.

On Friday night, Montserrat Caball was on hand to fill the title role once again, and Shirley Verrett sang Adalgisa for the first time in her career. The opera almostbut not quitetook on the stature it is supposed to have.

Just now, the pianist on this Mostly Mozart program, Anton Kuerti, is giving a preconcert recital of the Moonlight. Sonata. The hall is not yet quite as full as it will be when the concert formally startslike most Rampal concerts in New York nowadays, this one is sold outbut the Green Room is very full. To be exact, it is filled mainly with handsome women, all of whom are devoted, in one way or another, to JeanPierre Rampal.

If he fails, and I believe he (lees, it is in part because he has set his own standards high and refused to distort the evidence.

title: Strange Customs, and Often Primitive Ways
description: Cultural anthropologists, or ethnographers, have traditionally studied exotic and isolated peoples. Taking up residence in an American Indian reservation or a village in India or Africa, they have pursued research that remains for the most part marginal to the everyday concerns of Americans. Although most anthropologists still follow this course, In the last few years an increasing number have turned to exploring the urban United States.

title: Book Ends
description: Chuck's Book. Charles W. Colson, whose book Born Again was published last week, excites ambivalent emotions in the American breast. On the one side we have Bad Chuck. Nixon's hatchetman: and on the other. Good Charles. practicing Christian. Whatever the state of Mr. Colson's soulGod and he only knowhe spells Controversy, which in turn has been known to sell books. Hence, aided by a spate of prepublication peeks at the book by political columnists, Born Again went into first and second printings totaling 60,000 copies before publication. As resident Recording Angel here, we will tot up the accounts on both sides of the ledger from the standpoint of its publishing history. First the good news. Mr. Colson turned down fivefigure offers from several major publishing houses and instead took his book, for considerably less advance money, to a small firm in Lincoln, Va., called Chosen Books. Since Chosen Books is actually an editorial packaging or manuscript preparation firm, specializing in religious books, Born Again is distributed by Fleming H. Revell, an old established religious publisher which is far from a devout band of amateurs, having published a whopping best seller called The Total Woman. Then too, on the commercial side, Mr. Colson is off on a major twomonths, promotion tour. On the other hand, Mr. Colson's tour is being plannedaround his busy schedule of lectures, fees from which he donates to his prison ministry. Of course, with all the publicity the book could make a lot of money; but on still another hand, Mr. Colson says he will also donate part of his book royalties to the Fellowship Foundation, a group of Washington Christians who sponsor prayer breakfasts and other good works.

title: The Psychological Birth Of the Human Infant
description: In the 1930's and 40's Anna Freud argued hard and repeatedly for what, in her scientific papers and at professional meetings, she called direct observation. No one was really opposed to the idea. Why would anyone who called himself or herself a child psychiatrist be against watching children as carefully as possible? But Miss Freud had good reason to keep insisting, in her tactful but firm way, that those whose job it is to understand troubled children, and bring to them a measure of relief from difficult and exhausting worries or fears, had best not presume what a given child is thinking and feeling, or maybe struggling against bravely but unsuccessfully. She was especially concerned that all too often younger children, not yet able to speak their minds, end up being spoken for. She knew that even older children of, say, 8 or 9 are often reluctant to talk at any great length about what is troubling them.

title: Marine Midland Pays for Its Fling
Apartment Hunting Among the Remains of an Indian Civilization
description: DURING the Age of Chivalry to Europe. the American Indians of the Southwest were creating the world's first apartmenthouse state, a series of huge dwellings that were, in fact, compact cities. They are, to an amazing degree, still with us. today. But unlike their European counterparts, so often palaces of the elite, the Indian remains speak of the common man: family living quarters, market plazas, municipal shrines. They bear mute testimony to the fact that there was an egalitarian society in America seven centuries before the Declaration of Independence.

title: Design
description: Author Peter Benchley and his wife, Wendy, wanted a New York, piedaterre, so they bought a tiny coop near Lincoln Center in a good building where they had once lived and for which they retained a strong sentimental attachment. They asked architect J. Woodson Rainey Jr. and his wife, Toni, who lived in the building, to redesign the 12by22foot space for them. The room had once been a servant's during the days when the building was a residential hotel, and it had not been renovated for 40 years. It was partitioned into a bedroom and a bathroom; the building's rusty steam pipe ran through a space over the door; and there was so little daylight that lights were needed at high noon. The only reusable surface was the floor, says Woodson Rainey. The need to build a kitchen and a new bathroom and to hide the plumbing lines led to the room's most dramatic architectural feature. The Raineys built a platform, two steps up from the living area, to create a space for the kitchen and the bathroom. This platform crosses the room on the diagonal and extends as a ledge beneath the windows. A long step, which can serve as a table or as a place to sit, juts out into the room. over the platform, at a 45degree angle. Part of the ceiling was lowered to cover the steam pipe. There are only two pieces of conventional furniture, an Italian sleep sofa and an antique Windsor chair. The walls are all white, except for the front door, which is bright yellow. A thin stripe of the same shade of yellow outlines one wall in the kitchen. To hide the dismal view and to provide light, the Raineys extended the window wall six inches and installed fluorescent lights behind translucent panels of etched glass.

title: John Jay
description: Though he was never President, Commander in Chief, or author of grand national testaments, John Jay was nevertheless among the most talented and influential figures of the revolutionary generation: president of the Continental Congress, a principal negotiator of the treaty which gained the nation's independence, Secretary for Foreign Affairs in the Confederation Government, first Chief Justice of the United States, negotiator of the critical Treaty of 1794 with Great Britain that bears his name, coauthor of the Federalist Papers, and Chief Justice and Governor of New York. His many capacities, and his wide associations in New York City and State, always made him useful and available to others. His integrity was unimpeachable, his judgment unfailingly sound. He counted as friends and fellowrevolutionaries the other great men of his time, few of whose accomplishments outdistanced his own. Why is he not better known and better appreciated?

title: Hurdling Mark Falls
description: OAK PARK, Ill., Feb. 21 (AP)Greg Foster of Proviso East High broke the national indoor high school record in the 60yard high hurdles today in the time of 7 seconds. The previous record of 0:07.3 was set by James Kappel of Plainedge High School of North Massapequa, L.I., in 1974.

title: An Early Blooming
description: THERE is a place in Huntington where the temperatures are in the 70's, the days are long and summer seems lust around the corner. The place is a greenhouse sheltering thousands of plants and flowers that are being prepared for Flora 76 at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Lafayette, Taft Gain Semifinals
description: Lafayette High School will get another chance at Taft. The Brooklyn school, which lost to Taft last season in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball final, scored a powerful 8972 victory over Kennedy yesterday in a quarterfinal game at Wagner College on Staten Island. In the first game, Taft trounced Fort Hamilton, 81 49, so the semifinal match was set. The Blue Devils, as Taft's team is called, have won the P.S.A.L. title the last two seasons.

title: Ludell

Roberto Delgado rode the winner, which paid $7.80, $3.80 and $3 for $2 across the board. The winner ran the six furlongs in 1:43 35. Second was the favored Hot Singe ($4 and $2.80) and third Demon Flight ($4.20).

title: Miss Young Is Leading In Skating
Growth of the American Revolution 17661775
description: In 1960 the late Bernhard Knollenberg, in Origin of the American Revolution, 1759 1766, endeavored to establish the thesis that while Great Britain's passage of the Stamp Act of 1765 touched off American colonial violence, the colonists had been brought to the brink of rebellion by a number of earlier provocative measures from 1759 to 1764. These restrictive measures, he contended, continued to be felt after repeal of the Stamp Act and contributed substantially to the discontent that culminated in the Revolution.

title: Grey Gardens: Cinma Verit or Sideshow?
description: On Oct. 22, 1971, at the urging of sonic annoyed townsfolk, the Suffolk County police raided a house in East Hampton. There, in the house called Grey Gardens, they found two women, many cats, much litter and quite a few violations of local ordinances. What made the case more noteworthy than the usual recluseinmessyoldhouse story was the discovery that the inhabitants were related to Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis. Seventysevenyearold Edith Bouvier Beale was the sister of Jackie's father, which, naturally, made Mrs. Beale's daughter, 54yearold Edie, Jackie's cousin.

Thompson, minority counsel to the Ervin Committee, chose the latter and was booedof course as a partisan obstructionist.

title: Choral Society Offers Mendelssohn's Elijah

It would be hard to think of music so totally out of fashion today as Mendelssohn's oratorios, and the countless anonymous Victorian dramaticreligious choral works they inspired. Even now, when we are seeing something of a counterreaction against the excesses of the earlymid20thcentury. hardliners, it is rare to come across a major performance of Elijah in a prominent concert hall with a full orchestra.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

In a letter to the regional office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Mr. Badillo said that the spending plan, drawn up by a mayoral task force headed by First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti and awaiting final approval by the Board of Estimate, would use the Federal money to finance projects cut from the city's capital budget, not all of which would benefit poor communities such as the South Bronx.

title: KIM REAPPEARS IN NORTH KOREA
Chronicles of life on the edge
description: In The Odd Woman (1974), her bestknown work so far, Gail Godwin attempted a fleshedout portrait of a beleaguered but plucky modern woman: the novel virtually sagged under the weight of the author's earnest sympathies and attentions. Dream Children, her first collection of short stories, now returns to the bloodless control of her first two novels (The Perfectionists, 1970, and Glass People, 1972), with their internal psychologically naturalistic landscapes. While broadly representative human experience continues to elude, or perhaps simply not to interest her, Godwin at least recovers here from the oppressive gabbiness of that last book.

description: THE relations between business and government in American life have swung back and forth like a pendulum. But the basic position, dating from the days of Jefferson and then of Jackson, has been an adversary relationship. This meant that even though free choice by the individual business enterprise was endorsed as the core of the American economic process, government and society have sought to limit the role of business, keep it out of government, regulate and administer it, scold and punish it, with myriad laws and rules.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AVESTA, Sweden, Feb. 21 (AP)Odd Martinsen of Norway beat Bill Koch of the United States by 50 seconds today and won an international I5kilometer (9.3mile) crosscountry ski race. Martinsen, who led all the way, covered the distance in 43 minutes 1 second. Koch, from Guilford, Vt., who won American's first ever Olympic crosscountry medal placing second in the 30 kilometer event in Innsbruck, Austria, recently, finished just second behind. Martha Rockwell of Putney, Vt., finished Putney, Vt., was fourth and Doug Peterson of Minneapolis fifth.

title: Unhappy Anniversary for the Macon Whoopees
description: Two years ago this month, the Macon Whoopees died. This is a belated obituary, a story you haven't heard earlier because everyone involved has been too ill to talk or write about it. It is a tale told here by one of the idiots involved, full of the sound and fury of hockey, signifying everything that has since gone wrong in professional sports.

description: PEKING, Feb. 21 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon returned to China today four years after the high point of his Administration and was greeted by Acting Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng and Foregn Minister Chiao Kuanhua.

title: Frank Sullivan, Humorist
description: One of journalism's gentler and subtler writers, Frank Sullivan, died last week. Mr. Sullivan was a master at poking fun at the cliche and the homily. His fictional character, Mr. Arbuthnot, was an alleged expert on cliches, and would, in mock conversation, string hackneyed phrases like wash on the line for the reader to laugh at, Though he produced six hooks, and countless magazine articles in his 40year career, Mr. Sullivan claimed, I dislike itworkingand sometimes I don't do any. When The New York World, the paper he worked for, folded in 1931, he moved to Saratoga Springs, N. Y., to begin a freelance career that lasted until 1974. Once I visited New York for 20 years, he said, but I wouldn't live there if you gave me Philadelphia. When I die, he said, I want to go where The World has gone and work on it again. Gary Hoenig

Closed windows and drapes barely muffled the grinding gears of trucks, uses and motorcycles. We stuffed our ears with wadded Kleenex and stared wildeyed at the ceiling.

title: Taking Him for Granted
description: PRINCETON, N. J.The portrait of George Washington on the dollar bill epitomizes the formidable selfcontrol and the remoteness of the statesman, thinlipped and with a Roman nose, staring at us from his 18th century. In doing so it recalls the concepts that help us take him for granted: Boy and man of unassailable honor, impeccable keeper of personal and public accounts, steadfast patriot, religiously optimistic and humanitarian soldier, patient and surprisingly competent first President.

title: Inquiry Into Madness Dubious About Experts
description: A writer who has specialized in chronicling collapses (Decline and Fall, a story of The Saturday Evening Post, and Before the Deluge, a book on preHitler Germany), Otto Friedrich of Lattingtown has just published a book on emotional collapses. Going Crazy: An Inquiry Into Madness in Our Time is its title. Its author, who is also a Time senior editor, believes that he himself has been fleetingly mad, and his book describes his experiences as well as those of other psychological walking wounded.

title: Teenagers on the Air
A Special Silver Dollar
description: The Feb. 8 column carried the Mint's announcement that the fabulous Eliasberg U.S. typecoin collectionconsisting of a choice specimen of each of the hundreds of different types of coins issued for circulation since 1792would be put on public display this spring in the main mint in Philadelphia. The Mint took pains to emphasize that the collection includes an 1804 silver dollar (the historic Stickney coin), but did not even mention the controversial nature of this coinage. The fact is that all of the 1804dated silver dollars (a specimen is illustrated above) were special presentation coins, somewhat like the frivolous noncirculating legal tender proof coins being issued by many foreign governments today. All of the 1804 silver dollars were struck in the 1830's and later, not in 1804; they were made for private purposes and were neither issued nor intended for circulation. Nevertheless, by some mysterious chemistry combining secret origins and ownership and endless publicity, these dollars have become glamorous and famous; they command sixfigure prices and are highly esteemed by the cognoscenti. Of course, the Eliasberg collection also includes specimens of all of the legitimate coinsthe commonest and the great raritiesstruck for circulation during the 184year history of the U.S. Mint.

title: The Hawk That Dare Not Hunt by Day

title: London
description: A series of villages linked by a public transportation system. That is the key to understanding London. Each village approached by visitors has its own cluster of sights worth seeing and restaurants to visit. But which restaurants can offer satisfactory meals at reasonable prices? It needs only one bad lunch or ruined dinner to destroy the memory of a fine gallery or a great theatrical production.

title: VATICAN DISPUTED BY HOMOSEXUALS
Sadat Starts Tour to Seek Aid From Arab Oil States
description: CAIRO, Feb. 21President Anwar elSadat, who has been absent from the international scene for several months, flew today to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on the first leg or a weeklong tour of oilproducing Arab countries. In an interview published here before his departure, Mr. Sadat said he expected his tour to result in a financial blood transfusion into Egypt's arteries.

title: Marriage Announcement 18  No Title
description: Maureen Vesey Engaged

title: Candidates on TV Provide Varied Diet That May Pall but Is Difficult to Resist
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18Wagging his finger, Senator Henry M. Jackson appeared in Caroline Dilworth's living room here last night and started posing brusque questions about Jimmy Carter's stands. Miss Dilworth wagged her finger at her television set and threw the questions back: Where do you stand? she asked the Senator. What would you do?

title: The Hot New Sport of Cold Weather Camping
description: WE set off Into the High Peaks region of Adirondack Park on a bright January morning that followed two days of heavy snow. In the parking lot near the trailhead we checked our equipment for the last time, dancing up and down to keep our feet warm, the dry snow fanning from our boots like sifted flour.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The brick used around my fireplace is apparently a sandy type because every time someone touches or brushes against it particles of sand fall to the floor and on the mantel. Can you recommend some kind of sealer I can put on that will prevent this?A.R.P., Reisterdam, Md.

title: GRADING OF BEEF CHANGED BY U.S.
description: Beginning tomorrow, new standards for grading beef will go Into effect, but it will be weeks before any of the beef reaches the meat counters in the New York area's supermarkets and butcher shops.

title: When Rampal played second flute
description: Though Rampal is undisputed master of the flute, he will play with almost anyone. The proof is that, when I told him I also play flute. his face lit up as if I were the lost chord. Ah, Pierre, he said to me, then we must duetter.

title: East German Tries to Flee
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 22 (AP) An East German drove his car through border barriers early today seeking to flee to the West, but the car stalled and East German border guards opened fire with submachine guns, thwarting the attempt, West German officials said.

title: Bypass Cuts Into Income Of Thruway
description: EAST GREENBUSH, N.Y. The last link of Interstate 90 will open here in the spring, but already the incomplete tollfree highway is causing a financial headache for the New York State Thruway Authority.

title: Aid for Lip Watch Plant Divides French
NORTHROP REBATE REPORTED IN IRAN AS AN ATONEMENT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22The Californiabased Northrop Corporation recently paid an unannounced rebate of $2 million to the Iranian Government to atone for ethically questionable payments to third parties in connection with earlier sales of military aircraft to Iran, highly placed Iranian sources disclosed over the weekend.

title: Irwin Is Victor By 2 Strokes
OPTIMISM FOUND ON RATE OUTLOOK
description: Despite a recent outbreak of doubts about shortterm interest rate patterns, a number of professionals, at a twoday meeting here last week, expressed optimism on the business outlook and what they viewed as the comparatively moderate interest rate changes that lie ahead. The panelistsbankers, economists and financial executivestaking part in the Conference Board's annual financial conference suggested that:

title: Small Explosive Goes Off At Hearst Offices Here
description: A small explosiveapparently a firecracker placed in a canexploded last night at the entrance of the Hearst Corporation's executive offices at 959 Eighth Avenue, near West 57th Street, the police said. There were no injuries.

title: Malmquist Takes Harris Ski Jumping
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 22Lack of snow, springlike temperatures, a heavy overnight rainfall, and parking lots deep in mud failed to keep the Brattleboro Outing Club from staging its annual Fred H. Harris ski jumping tournament today;

title: Gibson Ministers to Newark's Needs With Large Amounts of Federal Aid
description: NEWARKA visiting Congressman once observed that Newark, this showplace of urban maladies, had received every Federal grant available except a program or two aimed at fattening cattle.

title: Resch in Goal in 40 Victory
Bob Short Hospitalized
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 22 (UPI)Bob Short, prospective coowner of the San Francisco Giants, was hospitalized today with a broken elbow and pelvis, and a family spokesman said he would not be able to go to Chicago Tuesday for a scheduled meeting of National League owners.

title: Reliving for TV the Lives of Illusion at Cambridge
description: LONDON, Feb. 22  They were a golden generation, men and women who attended Cambridge and Oxford in the 1950's. unscarred by the war, confident of the future, selfassured. charming and aggressively optimistic.

title: 1,500 Cars Disrupt Traffic at Kennedy To Protest the SST
description: A motorcade of 1,500 cars protesting planned flights of the BritishFrench Concorde supersonic transport jet slowed traffic on main roads at Kennedy International Airport for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An international teacherrecruiting agency, with headquarters at Princeton, has signed a conciliation agreement with the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith and New Jersey's Division on Civil Rights that it will place special emphasis in assigning Jews to locations where they are not presently employed. The agreement, signed by International Schools Services Inc., also provides that it will not deny employment to Jewish Americans.

title: Japan's Slump Brings Fear of Social Unrest
Blacks Are Developing Programs to Fight Crime in Communities
description: Black groups in many cities have embarked on a new effort to cope with crime in their communities through such widely varied programs as videotape education projects and big brother counseling.

title: BRUBECK QUARTET IS TOGETHER AGAIN
description: After going their separate ways for the last eight years, the members of the last and longestlived Dave Brubeck Quartet, who had played together for a decade, came together again Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall for a concert. This was part of a reunion tour that began Tuesday in Princeton. It was as if the quartet had picked up where it left off in December 1967, refreshed by a vacation from constant traveling.

title: Ford and Carter Supporters Invade Florida for Votes
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 22 Two of the Presidential candidates saw an opening in Florida this weekend and took it.

title: Survey Finds City Facing Loss of 800,000 People
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  A state, survey predicts that New York City's population will drop by 800,000 by the end of the century, with most of the decline in Manhattan and Brooklyn. And in the rest of the state the population growth rate is expected to come below estimates made just two years ago.

title: James A. Newcombe, 34, Goodyear RadioTV Aide
description: James A. Newcombe, radiotelevision specialist for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Coml)any, who coordinated the use of Goodyear's three domestic blimps with television networks and film producers, died Saturday in the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 34 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Bruins Down Rangers by 52; Islanders Turn Back Capitals
description: Given little cause to root for their hockey team last night, Ranger fans began cheering the weather report at Madison Square Garden. The chilling news that the temperature was going to drop to the low 20's received a bigger ovation than the Rangers pair of goals in a 52 loss to the Boston Bruins.

title: Sonics Topple Lakers
News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1976

title: The E1 Is Gone, the Scene Is Ritzier But Is Old Third Ave. Any Better Off?
description: Stephen Foster called it home, Greta Garbo called it an antique shop, and it may be the only street in Manhattan where Ernest Hemingway broke a shillelagh over his own head just to prove to John O'Hara that although good writers may be thinskinned, they can have thick skulls.

title: Bridge:
description: The defending champions, in a stunning upset, crashed to defeat in the fourth round of Grand National knockout play here Saturday night.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PARENTS PRESSING AMNESTY BATTLE
Israel Moves for Talks
description: The Israeli Cabinet has agreed to ask the United States to sound out Egypt, Jordan and Syria about negotiating nonbelligerency agreements instead of formal peace treaties. Details on page 4.

title: Article 3  No Title
Price Wins 440
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Flu Pandemic?
description: The experts of the Federal Government's Center for Disease Control have raised the possibilityand it is only thatof a worldwide influenza pandemic on the scale of the 191819 disaster.

title: Ellis Briggs, Writer, Dies; Was Envoy to 7 Countries
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga. Feb. 22 (UPI)Ellis O. Briggs, a writer and former Ambassador to seven countries, died here last night at the age of 76.

title: Canarsie Reaches Semifinals
description: Canarsie demonstrated yesterday why many basketball observers consider it the finest high school team in the country. The Chiefs, in an awesome performance in the second half, defeated DeWitt Clinton, 7046, and gained the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: Death Penalty Is Demanded in France
description: PARIS, Feb. 22A clamor for the death penalty had erupted in France since the discovery that Philippe Bertrand, an 8 yearold boy kidnapped in his home town of Troyes last month. was murdered.

title: Woman Betters 400Meter Mark
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 22 (UPI)Rita Wilden bettered her own world indoor best for the 400meter run today with a time of 56.26 seconds on the final day of the European indoor track and field championships. The West German woman's previous mark was 5628 seconds.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Six hours of negotiations failed to produce an agreement to end the industry dispute between dress manufacturers that has led to the closing of 500 to 600 shops since last Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The shutdown by contractors has idled 20,000 to 30,000 workers and delayed delivery of spring dresses to stores throughout the country. The contractors sew the dresses for the jobbers, who design them and market them. They are seeking higher rates from the jobbers to pay for the higher wages contained in the new contract negotiated earlier this month with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: Platform Tennis Paddling to RoofTop Heights
description: Platform tennis used to be scoffed at as that chickencoop game. But in. the last few years it has boomed loudly in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and many other parts of the country. And now a sponsor has put up $40,000 for a circuit ending with a championship playoff in April in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: FRIEDA EVERS
Personal Finance
description: The 1975 Federal income tax forms provide for a number of tax credits that can reduce the amount due. Each of these credits may be claimed on a different line of the basic Form 1040.

title: Fights Disrupt Caucuses Of Puerto Rico Democrats
AntiDefamation League Wins Agreement on Teacher Hiring
description: An international teacherrecruiting agency, with headquarters at Princeton, has signed a conciliation agreement with the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith and New Jersey's Division on Civil Rights that it will place special emphasis in assigning Jews to locations where they are not presently employed.

title: Miss Burka Skate Champion
EQUITY IS ACCUSED ON THEATER CODE
description: Six months after a new code governing Off Off Broadway theaters was imposed by Actors Equity and then suspended, after a bitter debate, the issue remains unresolved.

title: MANUEL SIWEK, 67, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: Manuel Siwek, who as president of Grosset & Dunlap, the book publisher, introduced a concept of mass marketing for books, died Saturday of a massive heart attack on the island of Captive, near Fort Myers, Fla., where he had been vacationing. He was 67 years old and lived in Rye. N.Y.

title: Report of Miss Hearst's Rescue Backed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22On a Sunday in March last year a young woman fitting the description of Patricia Hearst was rescued from a ledge overlooking the Pacific Ocean in a state park just south of San Francisco.

title: CocaCola Is Seeking Overseas National Airways
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York announced yesterday that it was planning to acquire Overseas National Airways and two pleasure riverboat companies owned by the airline for stock and debentures valued at more than $27 million.

title: News Media Magnify Campaign
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 22Jimmy Carter, the former Georgia Governor, told a Democratic forum at a Manchester high school last night that what the voters did here on Tuesday would be magnified 100 times. As living evidence that this was not a hyperbole, nearly onethird of the audience he was facing was made up of the national press.

title: Ford Has Last Word With a Governor
A Question of Honor
description: WASHINGTON  If there is one thing the past years have taught us, it is the importance of a keen and high sense of honor in those who handle our governmental affairs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Authorities searched the muddy, rainswollen Delaware River for four teenagers who jumped from a drifting makeshift raft and were believed to have drowned Saturday afternoon. A Camden, N.J., Fire Department spokesman said the search was repeatedly interrupted by torrential rain falling over southern New Jersey. As the Camden Fire and Police Departments and the Coast Guard again suspended their efforts for the night, officials identified the boys as 15yearold Roberto Vinetue, his brother Louis, 14, Dennis Nieves, 13, and Domingo Vasquez, 14. We are assuming they drowned, a spokesman said.

title: Scientists Debate Question of Race and Intelligence
description: BOSTON, Feb. 22The issue of whether or not there are ethnic or racial differences in average intelligence, usually left off the agenda of scientific meetings as being either inconsequential or too explosive, has been debated here at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: Sense in the Skies...
description: The country's airlines have had more and longer strikes in recent years than any other major industry, and none has had a worse record in this respect than National Airlines. Only last month National resumed flights after being grounded for more than four months by a walkout of unionized flight attendants. In 1974 a strike of ground mechanics shut down the airline for more than 100 days and it had an even longer suspension in 1970 as the result of a strike by its clerks and ticket agents.

title: Mastroianni Stars in Salut L' Artiste
Woman Gets Editor's Post At Harvard
College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL Collages

title: Navy Fund Reported Diverted to Glomar
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Central Intelligence Agency diverted more than half a billion dollars from Navy research, including vital antisubmarine warfare programs, in its effort to raise a sunken Soviet nuclear missile submarine from the Pacific Ocean, a maritime magazine reported today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ROME, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Jean Pierre Coopman of Belgium, beaten Friday by Muhammad Ali, was knocked out again today. this time by the European Boxing Union. Coopman was banned from Union competition for two years.

title: FEMINISTS PROTEST OVER MEDICAID CUTS
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 22More than 75 supporters of the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization of Women today picketed Morven, the Governor's residence, to begin a campaign to restore cuts in Medcaid programs that took effect last month.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: CANADIAN PARTY ELECTS A LEADER
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 22The Progressive Conservative Party, the principal opposition to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, tonight elected as its leader a littleknown, 36yearold Member of Parliament from Alberta, Joseph C. Clark.

title: Slight U.S. Drain Seen In Investment Overseas
description: Several recent independent studies indicate that the investment of $200 billion overseas by the United States in the last 25 years may have resulted in a slight loss of national income, a decline in American jobs and a shift in the distribution of income from labor to the multinational corporations, their employees and shareholders.

title: MEREDITH B. GIVENS, A MANPOWER EXPERT
description: Dr. Meredith G. Givens, economist and an authority on manpower and labor statistics, died yesterday on a visit to State College, Pa. He was 77 years old and lived in Franconia, N.H.

title: Fights Disrupt Caucuses Of Puerto Rico Democrats
description: CAROLINA, P. R., Feb. 22The efforts of the Democratic Party of Puerto Rico to elect delegates to the national convention broke down today amid disputes reflecting the longrunning fight over the island's status as a commonwealth.

title: Foss Creates Frolic for Percussionist
description: Lukas Foss is either one of the more important synthesizers and eclectics among today's composers or one of the more clever cultural magpies, and only time will decide that. His Concerto for Solo Percussion and Orchestra, which had its first New York performance yesterday at Carnegie Hall. certainly put into one package most of the fads and fancies that have absorbed the attention of composers during the last halfcentury.

title: U.C.L.A. Suffers 3d Home Defeat In Last 11 Years
description: U.C.L.A.'s basketball pride has been hurt and in Pauley Pavilion of all places.

title: Sheet Metal Turns the Ordinary Into Furniture That's Sculpture
Mueller Is Beaten By Dutch Skater
description: INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 22 (UPI)Peter Mueller of Madison. Wis., winner of the Olympic gold medal in the 1,000 meters, had to settle for second place in his specialty at an invitation match today.

title: Laws, Men And the C.I.A.
Jackson Tours City and Upstate, Predicting Victory in Primary
description: HORSEHEADS, N.Y. Feb. 22 Senator Henry Jackson made a quick foray today into New York, a state whose primary election, he told reporters during a bouncing, sliding jet ride upstate, would end with only three Democrats left in the race for President.

title: Shoe Retailers Attack Plans to Curb Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Shoe retailers have asked President Ford to reject a recommendation of the International Trade Commission for new import restrictions on footwear.

title: JEAN SERVAIS, ACTOR, COMEDIAN IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Feb. 22 (UPI)Jean Servais, an actor and comedian who was known for his portrayals of gangsters and business executives, died of heart failure after an operation on Tuesday. He was 65 years old.

title: Survey Finds City Facing Loss of 800,000 People
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  A state survey predicts that New York City's population will drop by 800,000 by the end of the century, with most of the decline in Manhattan and Brooklyn. And in the rest of the state the population growth rate is expected to come below estimates made just two years ago.

title: Dr. Harold Shub, Internist And Cardiologist Here, 52
description: Dr. Harold Shub, an internist and cardiologist here, active in forensic medicine, died Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., after having suffered a stroke. He was 52 years old.

title: Peaking Nets Drub Nuggets by 11595
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 22 Though the American Basketball Association playoffs are still seven weeks away, the New York Nets and the Denver Nuggets gave partisans at the Nassau Coliseum today a preview of how the finals might look.

title: 1,500Car Motorcade Protesting SST Disrupts Kennedy Traffic
description: crayoned sign proclaimed. 1775 First Battle of Concord, 1976 Second Battle of Concorde, another declared in the effort to set up a noise that could be. heard around the worldor at least, it was hoped, in Albany.

title: Runaway Car Kills 4 at the Plaza
description: A car running out of control outside the Plaza Hotel on Central Park South struck and killed four men and left three other persons injured early yesterday as it mounted sidewalks, sheared off utility posts and overturned a horsedrawn Victoria carriage.

title: Irish Mourners Fight Policemen Near Grave of Hunger Striker
Khan and Binns Capture Doubles
description: Sharif Khan and Ken Binns, professionals from Toronto who were seeded third, won the City Athletic Club open squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday. They defeated Colin Adair and Steve Moysey, Montreal amateurs, in the final, 1510, 1512, 156.

title: Soviet Arms Outlay May Take a Bigger Share of Resources Than C.I.A. Had Estimated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Central Intelligence Agency is coming to the conclusion that it has been underestimating, perhaps by more than 50 percent, the share of Soviet economic resources being devoted to defense.

title: Japan's Slump Brings Fear of Social Unrest
description: KAWASAKI, JapanKyoko Kikuchi is a trained computer keypuncher. She is experienced and eager to work. And she is unemployed.

title: Grumman's Fees to Iran Beg Questions
Tool Orders Show Uncertain Pattern
description: Orders for machine tools, an important economic indicator, came to $104 million last month, or 25 percent more than in January, 1975, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend. However, last month's total was down 9.6 percent from the level of December, 1975.

title: President Has No Plans To Be Briefed by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  President Ford has no plans to be briefed by former President Richard M. Nixon when Mr. Nixon returns from his trip to China, a White. House spokesman said today.

title: Advertising
description: Good news, El Exigente fans. The demanding one has survived Savarin coffee's switch to a new ad agency. You'll see it for yourself if you're watching television today, because this marks the beginning of the new advertising campaign by Scali, McCabe, Sloves. This agency got the account Oct. 1 after it had been at Foote, Cone & Belding for 18 years.

title: Cordero Scores In Coast Stakes
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)Angel Cordero Jr.'s crosscountry flight to ride Lightning Mandate paid off today with a twolength victory in the 38th running of the $88,100 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: City U. Chancellor Urges Closing of Three Colleges
description: The Chancellor of the City University is proposing to close John Jay and Richmond Colleges and the Hostos Community College and converting two fouryear liberal arts colleges in poverty areas  Medgar Evers and Yorkto twoyear community colleges with an emphasis on professional training.

title: The E1 Is Gone, the Scene Is Ritzier But Is Old Third Ave. Any Better Off?
description: Stephen Foster called it home, Greta Garbo called it an antique shop, and it may be the only street in Manhattan where Ernest Hemingway broke a shillelagh over his own head just to prove to John O'Hara that although good writers may be thinskinned, they can have thick skulls.

title: Stones Again Sets High Jump Record
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 22Dwight Stones, a mystery even to himself, cracked his world indoor record in the high jump for a second night in a row last night at the 10th San Diego indoor games.

title: Remains of 2 U.S. Servicemen Are Flown From Saigon to Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 22 The bodies of the last two American servicemen to die in Vietnam were brought to Bangkok from Saigon today by two aides of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

title: Portuguese Are Divided By Recognition of Luanda

description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22The Californiabased Northrop Corporation recently paid an unannounced rebate of $2 million to the Iranian Government to atone for ethically questionable payments to third parties in connection with earlier sales of military aircraft to Iran, %highly placed Iranian sources disclosed over the weekend.

title: Albritton Sets Mark In ShotPut
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 22 (AP) Terry Albritton of the University of Hawaii broke the world amateur shotput record twice yesterday with puts of 71 feet 7 inches and 718 in an allcorners meet at the school.

title: Florence Ballard Dead at 32; Original Member of Supremes
Statement by Nixon Seen as Reflecting Major China Stand
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Feb. 23  Richard M. Nixon's implicit criticism of President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger last night for taking part in the Helsinki talks on European security echoed one of China's most fervent attitudes.

title: 5 FLEE DRUG CENTER; POLICE RECAPTURE 2
description: Five men climbed down a bedsheet rope early yesterday and escaped from a state rehabilitation center in Queens, the police said. Two of the inmates were captured about six hours later.

title: About New York Shutting the Gates
description: It is a good deal less charming than Harvard, and not nearly so traditional as Yale. The Borough of Manhattan Community College. is in seven buildings scattered from West 47th to West 70th Streets and its students are for the most part disadvantaged, which is one of the newer words for poor. Once, they would never have been in college at all.

title: Soviet Relieves Minister In the Republic of Georgia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (UPI)The science minister of the Soviet Republic of Georgia has been relieved of his duties at his own request, according to the Georgian Communist Party newspaper, Zarya Vostoka.

title: All Right, Bunnies  Forward, Hop
Bethlehem Steel Sued
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 22 (UPI)  The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources has accused the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and company officials of endangering public health in Johnstown by polluting the air with cancercausing chemicals. Fines have been asked against the company and its officials that could total more more than $11 million.

title: Dissident Soviet Historian Is Held 36 Hours by Police
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (UPI)The dissident Soviet historian, Andrei Amalrik, returned to Moscow today after having wen held 36 hours without charges by the police.

title: MassProduced Precision Guided Weapons Are Said to Be Revolutionizing Military Doctrine and Tactics
description: Precision guided weapons, now being produced in the thousands by the United States, tile Soviet Union and West Europeans powers, are revolutionizing military doctrine and tactics.

title: Amor Artis Presents a Vivaldi Program
description: For one who tires quickly of the repeated notes, the sequences and the racing up and down of triads with which Vivaldi filled so many measures of his works, the Amor Artis Vivaldi concert at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night was not an unalloyed pleasure. But there was much to enjoy in it, and, in any case. there were enough Vivaldi fans to sell out the house well in advance of the event.

title: Legalized Marijuana Urged
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP)  The Oakland Tribune called for total legalization of marijuana in an editorial today that called a new state law making possession of small amounts of the drug punishable by a minor fine a hypocritical, halfway measure. The newspaper said studies and reports had shown marijuana to be saferthan alcohol or tobacco and there was no evidence that it was addictive or led to use of heavy drugs.

title: Theater: Tot Family, From Hungary
Canada Party Elects
description: The Progressive Conservative Party of Canada, principal opposition to Prime Minister Trudeau, elected a littleknown Albertan, Joseph Clark, as its leader. Page 13.

title: Jordan Sees Gains in Close Ties With Syria
CORRECTIONS
description: An article In The New York Times reported incorrectly Saturday that Harold and Alfred Satin, nursing home operators convicted of Medicaid fraud, faced proceedings to revoke their license for the Fieldston Lodge in the Bronx. They are not associated with the Fieldston Lodge, but face revocation of their licenses for the Hillcrest Nursing Home in Spring Valley and Kings Terrace in the Bronx.

title: Girl, 3, Tossed and Killed
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 22 (UPI)John Ellis Sr., a 28 yearold mental patient, enraged by a domestic argument, tossed two of his children, Yolanda, 3, and Christopher, 6, off a secondfloor apartment balcony onto an asphalt parking lot today, killing the girl and seriously injuring the boy, the police said. A third child, John Jr., 8, was thrown down a flight of stairs but was not seriously injured. Mr. Ellis was charged with one count of murder and two counts of aggravated assault and battery with intent to kill.

title: Imagine a Colt Named Woody Hayes
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 22In the fourth race there was a 3yearold filly named Just a Memory, a daughter Olden Times and Sentimental Girl bred in Kentucky. Senor Rafael Hernandez said she had a chance, even though the good sprinter, Bold and Brave, had a daughter in the race named Amalia R., who had lost only twice in six starts, once by a nose and once by a neck. When she lost by a neck it was Just a Memory who beat her. Senor Hernandez called attention to the silks worn by the jocky on Just a Memory, brown with a white cross on the hack. Those were his daughter's colors, he said. His daughter Martha, he explained, had been a Carmelite nun for 17 years. had become ill and come home.

title: Israel Authorizes U.S. Move for Talks With Arabs
Isadora Duncan's Daughter
description: Lisa Duncan, one of the six adopted daughters of the dancer, Isadora Duncan, died Jan. 24 in Dresden, Germany. She was 76 years old. In the 1920's and 30's Miss Duncan danced with the Isaclorabelles and later taught dancing in Paris. Surviving are four sisters.

title: Nastase Defeats Connors
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 22 (UPI)True to his prediction, Ilie Nastase made turkey out of his close friend, Jimmy Connors, today and ended the American star's threeyear reign as national indoor tennis champion, 62,63,76.

title: F.C.C. Reviewing Network Radio Policies
description: The Federal Communications Commission has begun a review of its regulations and policies concerning network radiothe first such study since 1941, when the agency adopted eight rules for network radio.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Court Decides Pullman Porters Long Were Victims of Job Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Pullman car porters were portrayed over the years as ambassadors of goodwill, always, courteous and correct, contented and eager to serve.

title: Loss of Control by Blacks Stirs Dispute at L.I. Bank
description: The Vanguard National Bank, which opened in Hempstead, LI., in May 1972 to serve the black community and became part of the Treasury Department's minority banking program, is embroiled in a controversy because blacks no longer consider it a minority bank.

title: On Campaign Finance
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Supreme Court opinion in the campaign financing case sustains most parts of a major political reform: the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1974. Yet much press comment has chided the Court for throwing out a few minor features of the law. Such a signal victory ought not to be portrayed as a serious defeat.

title: Baritone Doubles in Meistersinger and Pinafore
ELIZABETH A. WRIGHT
description: Elizabeth Atwell Wright, author and former director of curriculum Of the New Haven public schools, died of cancer Saturday in Stuart, Fla, She was 56 years old.

title: SCHORR LEAK HURT SECURITY, BUSH SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) George Bush, Director of Central Intelligence, said today that national security had been harmed by a leak of parts of a report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence to The Village Voice newspaper, but he did not know if damage could be proved in a court of law.

title: Sudan Executes 3 More
description: CAIRO, Feb, 22 (AP) There Sudanese soldiers were executed in Khartoum today after being convicted of taking part In an abortive coup against President Gaafar alNimeiry, the Sudanese state radio said. The executions brought. to 18 the number executed since the attempted coup last September.

title: JACK L. SCHWARTZ
description: Jack L. Schwartz, who had been in the women's apparel business here 60 years, died Thursday in Miami Beach. He was 82 years old.

title: Pace of New Hampshire Campaigning Slows Before the Primary Tomorrow
description: CONCORD, N.H. Feb. 22 On this last gray, drizzly Sunday before the year's first Presidential primary election on Tuesday, the usually frantic: pace of campaigning slowed noticeably.

title: Parishioners in Brooklyn Back Bishop on Homosexuals' Rights
...Discord in the Fields
description: The pioneering farm labor law that brought peace to California's fertile valleys has been nullified through a cutoff in enforcement funds, thus raising anew the danger of violence in the fields and of consumer boycotts that would inflict damage on merchants and other noncombatants all over the country.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect In 13 Holdups Is Seized
description: Edward Streets, who had been sought as the rabbitfurred robber of 13 Manhattan hanks, was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the city police.

title: Chopped Liver, With Feeling
description: All the world's a stage when you really need that job. Books of The Times
description: The monotony of my days can scarcely be conveyed in these notes, writes Albert Speer, former armaments minister and No. 2 man in the Third Reich, in the 18th year of his 20year confinement in West Berlin's Spandau prison. The forever unchanging sameness of more than 6,000 days cannot be recorded. A great poet might possibly be able to express the numbing evenness, the emptiness and helplessness, in short the intangible horror of imprisonment. Compared to what should be said, the diary remains nothing but a catalogue, usually of trivialities. Which is true enough: It would be absurd to argue that reading Spandau: The Secret Diaries in the cornfort of an armchair can remotely approximate Speer's lifeconsuming ordeal. Still, the book does contain indirect signals of what the 20 years of confinement were like. There are the 31,816 kilometers that Speer paced off in the prison yard: In his imagination, this 12year stroll took him south to Italy, then east as far as Guadalajara, Mexico; eventually, there are even diary entries describing the scenery through which he imagined himself to be walking.

title: New Jersey Briefs

The suspect, identified as Marcos Antonio Ramos, 26 years old, was arraigned on Saturday before Municipal Court Judge Joseph Houston on five counts of attempted murder and one count of arson and was ordered held without bail.

title: Larouche Leads Surge Of Penguins
description: Pierre Larouche, the cherubic Pittsburgh center, has been more and more difficult to stop on the ice. Last week The King as he has taken to calling himself, led the Penguins on a scoring rampage that included a 61 victory over Kansas City, a 75 triumph over Toronto, a 101 rout of Chicago and a 22 tie with Detroit (the team's sixth game in eight nights). Larouche, who is only 20 years old, picked up 15 points in his last five games and is now the fifth highest National Hockey League scorer with 37 goals and 47 assists. A teammate, Jean Pronovost, is right behind him in the standing.

title: Books of The Times
description: Karl Jaspers said something to the effect that communication is a struggling love with other persons. The pathology or the perversions to which this particular form of love is vulnerable are nicely illustrated in colleges and universities, where different generations suppose that they have come to instruct the others. The student brings his burgeoning self; the younger faculty members are surfers on the tide of history; the administration is in its second childhood, torn between peer bonding and sibling rivalry.

description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI)Charles O. Finley and Company, which owns the Oakland A's baseball team, has failed to. file corporate income tax returns for three years, the Internal Revenue Service said today. The company last filed a tax return for 1971, the I.R.S. said, but added that the 1975 tax was not due until next Oct. 31 because of the fiscal period used by the Finley enterprise. The returns unfiled. for 1972, 1973 and 1974 were to have included revenues from the American League team and the Charles O. Finley and Company Inc. insurance company.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 23 (AP)  Quinn Buckner broke out of a seasonlong scoring slump with 24 points tonight as topranked Indiana trounced Iowa, 10181. and clinched a tie for its fourth straight Big Ten basketball championship.

title: MOVES BY BRITAIN ANNOY RHODESIAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 23 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight that he preferred to see Britain involved in direct negotiations toward a constitutional settlement of Rhodesia's problems rather than to negotiate behind his back with black nationalists.

title: HIGH COURT BARS POLISHJOKE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Supreme Court refused without comment today to listen to a plea made on behalf of PolishAmericans for a chance to go on television to respond to four derogatory Polish jokes that were told on a nationally broadcast network talk show.

title: Illegitimate Spokesman
description: In the words and pictures flowing out of China these days, Richard M. Nixon looks for all the world like a private traveler impersonating an American President. Everything about that trip is mischievous.

title: CANADIAN OFFICE IN BEIRUT SEIZED
Cutting Arms Sales
G.A.O. URGES CURB ON F.B.I. CONTROL OVER DISSIDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  The General Accounting Office today urged Congress to place legislative controls on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's use of preventive measures to avoid violence by domestic dissidents.

title: SCHORR RELIEVED OF DUTIES BY CBS
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23CBS News formally relieved Daniel Schorr today of all duties as a Washington correspondent pending resolution of a Congressional investigation of his leak of a House committee's intelligence report to The Village Voice.

title: PAKISTAN PUSHES A SEARCH FOR OIL
description: KARACHI, Pakistan Pakistan is conducting an urgent search for oil in the hard, dry plains in the north and along the swampy coastline near here.

title: L S. LOWRY DEAD; ARTIST OF BLEAK
description: MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 23 (AP)  L. S. Lowry, an artist who painted the drab industrial scenes and working people of his native Lancashire, died today in a hospital at Glossop. He was 88 years old.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Remarks on Kennedys Explained by Kunstler
description: CHENEY, Wash., Feb. 23 (UPI)William M. Kunstler, the lawyer, has said that he was quoted totally out of context in Dallas regarding the assassinations of President Kennedy and his brother Robert. Mr. Kunstler said he was as grieved as anyone by their deaths. He admitted on Saturday it was bad judgment to talk about it in Dallas.

title: Article 1  No Title
Defending Dan Schorr
description: In suspending Daniel Schorr from his reporting duties, CBS News has succumbed to a campaign launched within the Ford Administration to picture the Central Intelligence Agency as an erring but basically worthy victim of those who leak its vital secrets and reporters who print them.

title: Japanese Raid Lockheed And Others in Bribe Case
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 24 Japanese policemen and tax officials this morning raided offices and homes of executives of Lockheed Aircraft, the Marubeni Trading Company, and Yoshio Kodama, Lockheed's lobbyist, in the first major investigation of the bribery scandal here.

title: 16 Travel Concerns Are Accused by City
Dance: Mime of Poland
description: Very possibly the worst thing to happen to Poland since the Polish ham and the Polish joke occurred unsensationally and briefly last night at the Beacon Theater, a littleknown former movie house at 74th and Broadway, which could know better days with careful management. The show is the Menagerie of the Empress Phylissa as danced and mimed, or mimed and danced, by Henryk Tomaszewski's Polish Mime Ballet Theater.

title: ECONOMY SURVIVES GUATEMALA OUAKE
2 Infants Fulfill Dream Of Unmarried Sisters
2 Amex Seats Sold
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of two seats. One seat was sold at $59,000, up $9,000 from the previous sale of Feb. 13. The other seat was sold later at $60,000, up $1,000 from the $59,000 sale.

title: G.A.O. URGES CURB ON F.B.I. CONTROL OVER DISSIDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  The General Accounting Office today urged Congress to place legislative controls on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's use of preventive measures to avoid violence by domestic dissidents.

title: Nightshirts, for Fashionably Cozy Sleepwalkers
description: When night falls over the city, it's not necessarily matching tops and bottoms that more and more people wear for their rendezvous with Morpheus. It's that relic of the past: the nightshirt.

title: 116th St. and Eighth Ave. Is Supermarket Offering the Entire Range of Illicit Drugs
LEAR ASSAILS F.C.C. ON FAMILY VIEWING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23Norman Lear, producer of television comedies, said today that the Federal Communications Commission had acted improperly in failing to hold public hearingsas it is required to do in rulemaking proceedingswhen it became involved in the discussions with broadcasters that led to the industry's adoption of the family viewing period.

title: Toward Energy Independence
description: WASHINGTON  In all the debate and commentary on the Energy Independence Authority proposed by President Ford, few have bothered to address the key question: Can this nation afford continuing and increasing dependence on imported oil?

title: Former Belgian Phone Head Given Jail Term for Bribery
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Germain Baudrin, the former head of the Belgian staterun telephone and telegraph authority, was sentenced today to nine months in prison on bribery charges linking him with the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: High Court Will Decide If U.S. Cheats Widowers
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government is illegally discriminating against tens of thousands of American widowers on the basis of sex by making it easier for widows than widowers to get Social Security survivor's benefits.

title: 13 MORE FOOD SPOTS TERMED VIOLATORS
Bridge:
description: If there had ever been an award for bringing an atmosphere of friendly good humor to major bridge tournaments in the last 40 years, it would no doubt have gone to Harry Fishbein, who died here Thursday at the age of 78.

title: FUTURES PRICES MAKE ADVANCES
description: Muchneeded rain and snow came to Kansas and some other wheatgrowing areas over the weekend, but winds came, too. The swirling winds did enough damage to the wheat to offset most of the gains from the moisture. As a result, traders pushed prices ahead yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, where the new crop July wheat contract closed at $3.94 a bushel, up from $3.88.

title: Frontiers of Science, From Microcosm to Macrocosm
ELISCU IN SPOTLIGHT AT LYRICIST SERIES
description: Edward Eliscu is not a name that evokes immediate recognition, although many of the songs to which he has contributed lyrics are well known  among them, Carioca, Without a Song, More Than You Know and, surprisingly, They Cut Down the Old Pine Tree. But for those who heard Mr. Eliscu in the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Sunday evening, he can now he identified as a witty and urbane man with a devotion to social justice as well as the author of lyrics that say a great deal more, but in satirical or emotional terms, than one normally gets from popular songs.

title: SAIGON WILL ADMIT FOREIGN TOURISTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (Reuters) South Veitnam will reopen its doors to foreign tourists next month for the first time since the war ended last April.

title: Indiana Box Score
description: IOWA (88)

title: REAGAN LEADS POLL OF CALIFORNIA G.O.P.
Speculation on Eve of First Primary: What Is Making Ronald Reagan Run?
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 22A midwinter thaw has drained the New Hampshire landscape of its hard vitality. The place has a wetgray smudged look, like the chipped facades of the old textile mills along the banks of the Merrimack River, where drifting gulls glide downstream on currents fed by melting snow and ice.

title: Interpreter Cries Help At Nixon's 23 Skiddoo
description: PEKING, Feb. 23 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon spotted three colorfully dressed young women from Tibet and Mongolia today, and asked their ages. One said she was 19, another 20. the third 23.

title: NO OUTBREAK SEEN OF KILLER FLU VIRUS
description: GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 23 (AP)  The World Health Organization said today that it had no evidence of an outbreak of the killer flu or swine virus that caused 20 million deaths in 191819.

title: People and Business
Cowen & Company In Deal To Acquire G. S. Grumman
description: Cowen & Company. a retailoriented brokerage firm, announced here esterday that it had reached agreement for the acquisition of G. S. Grumman Associates, the Bostonbased researchoriented stockbroker.

title: HEART RISK LINKED TO ESTROGEN DRUGS
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI)A study published in today's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association has found that risks of cardiovascular disease may increase for post  menopause women who take estrogen hormones.

title: Concert: Rostropovich
description: It should come as no news at this late date that Mstislav Rostropovich, who appeared in recital Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, plays the cello surpassingly well.

title: Spirit of Nikolais Puts an Edge To Finish of Riverside Dances
description: The spirit of Alwin Nikolais hovered over the program of Susan Lundberg, Gale Ormiston and Luise Wykell at the Theater of Riverside Church Sunday afternoon. Traces could be seen in the meticulous finish of the movement and the reserved emotional tone of the choreography, which one could more easily admire than warm to for the most part.

title: Irving L. Gelder, 82, Dies; Led Construction Company
description: Irving L. Gelder, former president and chairman of the CauldwellWingate Company, a major construction concern here, died Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Children for Adoption Abound Near U.S. Base
description: BAN CHAING, Thailand  There are babies for saleseven of them  in the small wooden but down a dirt road off the main highway in this southern Thai hamlet.

Blocked Track
description: Conrail will not operate its first trains until April 1, but the Federal design for a revitalized Northeast railroad system has already suffered its first derailment.

title: New Hampshire to Vote In First Primary Today
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 23The citizens of New Hampshire will vote tomorrow in the nation's first preferential Presidential primary election.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS AND VOLUME OFF
description: rose a fraction in active trading. Chase Manhattan Bank however, fell a fraction in reaction to a critical commentary in the same publication.

title: Newsprint Mill Reopens
description: THOROLD, Ontario, Feb. 23 (AP)The Ontario Paper Cornpan's newsprint mill here began operations this morning following the ratification yesterday of a new threeyear agreement by 950 production and steam plant workers. The workers had been on strike at the 240,000 tonayear plant since Sept. 17.

title: U.S. BIDS TWO LINES TO JOIN RAIL PLAN
description: The Government will make a new attempt to bring two private railroads, Chessie System Inc. and the Southern Railway Company, into the northeast rail reorganization plan centered on a new Federally sponsored carrier, the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: Stein Lays Windfalls to Adult Homes
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that many of the 428 privately owned adult homes in the state were taking advantage of inadequate State supervision to make windfall profits and in return were offering a standard of care that engendered suffering and despair.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23A top official from the Consolidated Edison Company of New York testified today that the former Government official who criticized the safety of one of the utility's reactors was acting in an unconscionable and unprofessional manner.

title: Candidates Not Profiting From Alienation of Voters

description: TRENTON, Feb. 23The Assembly Taxation Committee set as a minimum goal today the development of tax proposals to raise $378 million for financing the State Education Act of 1975.

title: Even Off Its Mark, Lead Shot Is Found Hazardous to Fowl
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15A Fish and Wildlife Service environmental study shows that every year millions of ducks, geese, swans and coots fall prey not only to the hunters downing them but also to those who miss them.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted another advance yesterday despite some profit taking that reduced the size of the gains.

title: Ormandy Leads Philadelphia Orchestra in Prokofiev
description: It was sweet to hear Prokofiev's Classical Symphony again. It has never entirely disappeared from the repertory, but long gone are the days when Koussevitzky used to program it virtually at every second Boston Symphony concert. Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra did the honors last night: The concert took place in Carnegie Hall, to which the orchestra has returned after a decade or so uptown in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Diamond Concern Negotiates to Keep Share of Angolan Wealth
description: LISBON, Feb. 23 (Reuters)One of the world's biggest diamond companies has begun negotiations with the new Angolan Government at Luanda toward handing over its huge mining concessions in the West African country.

description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 23 New Hampshire is a happening.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Cornmittee deadlocked today on a comprehensive bill making changes in the food stamp program.

description: Between the prosciutto and the chicken came the amenities. Between the chicken and the chocolate ice cream came the interrogation.

description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Feb. 23A kidnapping suspect who according to authorities seized his guard's gun in an attempt to escape from the Westchester County Medical Center where he was a gunshot patient, was shot and killed today by an offduty policeman visiting a patient.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Portland General Electric Company said yesterday it had increased its proposed public offering of common shares to 2 million from 1.5 million. The offering, through underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, is scheduled for Thursday.

description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 23Israel's governing Labor Party, torn by rifts in its leadership, has now been hit by a new blowthe resignation of its secretary general.

description: Baseball's player relations committee, representing the club owners, decided yesterday to delay the start of spring training indefinitely and expressed a willingness to forego the season if necessary.

title: Golf Resumes at 40 for Chi Chi
CAR THAT KILLED 4 FOUND DEFECTFREE
description: Police accident investigators said yesterday that they had found no evidence of mechanical failure in a Car that went out of control on Central Park South near Fifth Avenue early Sunday and struck and killed four pedestrians, but they did not rule out human error as a factor.

title: Music: Rossini's Mass
description: Rossini's Petite Masse Solennelle dates from late in his life, 1863. Today it is rarely heard, and thus Musica Aeterna's two performances this weekend at the Metropolitan Museum of Art were especially welcome.

title: Library Opening Ends 40Day SitIn
description: It was victory day yesterday at the Columbia branch of the New York Public Library as, it was reopened following a 40day, aroundtheclock sitin.

title: Backers of Schwartz for Correction Post Putting Pressure on Legislative Panel
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Supporters of Herman Schwartz, Governor Carey's controversial nominee to head the Commission on Corrections focused their persuasive efforts today on Senator Ralph J. Marino, the Nassau County Republican who heads the Senate Committee on Crime and Correction and who will almost certainly east the swing vote when the committee votes on Mr. Schwartz's confirmation in the next several days.

title: Columbia Oarsman Is Missing As Rough Water Swamps Shell

description: Since attendance at concerts of early music seems to be on the upswing, and Music for a While is among the most distinguished purveyors of this repertory, it was standing room only Sunday afternoon at the St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: ISRAEL LOSES ROUND ON AID IN THE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23  A House Appropriations subcommittee has refused to go along with a recent Senate action that would have had the effect of providing Israel with an additional $500 million in economic and military aid this year.

title: Japanese Raid Lockheed And Others in Bribe Case
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 24Japanese policemen and tax officials this morning raided offices and homes of executives of Lockheed Aircraft, the Marubeni Trading Company, and Yoshio Kodama, Lockheed's lobbyist, in the first major investigation of the bribery scandal here.

title: Article 4  No Title
Litton to Run for Senate
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Feb. 23 (AP)  Representative Jerry Litton formally announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate. Mr. Litton, 38 years old, is opposing two other major rivals in his drive to succeed Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri, who is retiring. The others are Representative James Symington, the Senator's son and former Gov. Warren E. Hearnes.

title: URBAN AID VOTED BY STATE SENATE
Carolina College Head Quits
description: HICKORY, N.C., Feb. 23 (AP)Dr. Raymond M. Bost said today that he was resigning as president of Lenoir Rhyne College to become president of the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Philadelphia on Sept. 1.

title: PROF. MOSES LUTZKI, BIBLIOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Moses Lutzki, formerly pro, fessor of bibliography at Yeshiva University for 20 years, who was known for describing and deciphering medieval Hebrew manuscripts, died Friday in a nursing home at Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: Bail of $100,000 Each Set for 6 Linked to Coast Bombing Group
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23Six persons who have been linked to the Emiliano Zapata Unit, an underground group that has taken responsibility for several recent bombings, were arraigned in Federal District Court here today on charges of possessing unregistered destructive devices.

title: 3 Chemical Branches Here Among Six Banks Held Up
description: Six banks here were held up yesterday, including three Chemical branches and a Brooklyn bank, where a holdup suspect was captured. The Chemical Bank branches and the amount stolen were as follows: at 4024 Boston Road in the wood. $4,881; 201 Park Avenue, at 17th Street, undetermined and 130 William Street, in the financial district, $1,818.

title: SCHORR RELIEVED OF DUTIES BY CBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23CBS News formally relieved Daniel Schorr today of all duties as a Washington correspondent pending resolution of a Congressional investigation of his leak of a House committee's intelligence report to The Village Voice.

title: Redmen Rally to Win, 7160
description: St. John's basketball team has specialized this season in stopping the hearts of its partisans and coach and last night's game against Holy Cross at the Redmen's Alumni Hall was no exception.

title: Wedgwood Serves Good News for City: It's Decided to Stay
STATE U. CUTS SPARK PROTEST IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Fell. 24 (AP)A recomenclation that Albany State University eliminate its School of Nursing and 11 other degree programs prompted a small demonstration on the campus this afternoon.

title: Expansion Planned In Women's Track
description: One day after the Colgate Women's Games finals were held at Madison Square Garden before nearly 9,000 spectators, officials at the ColgatePalmolive Company announced plans yesterday to expand the track and field program next year.

title: Stocks Rise to a 3Year High
WHEAT FUTURES CLIMB IN PRICE
description: With traders keeping a weather eve on the Southwest and finding little hope for rain, wheat prices hounded up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Early in the session there had been some reports of a possible onetenth inch of rain in Oklahoma and Nebraska, but this was not enough to alleviate worries.

title: Market Place
description: When James J. Ling's conglomerate empire, OmegaAlpha Inc. came apart in September 1974, it was the second time that he had fallen back after marching into the ranks of the Fortune 500 from shoestring beginnings.

title: CUNNINGHAM GETS INQUIRY DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Governor Carey indicated today that Patrick J. Cunningham, the New York State Democratic chairman, would either have to clear himself of charges of corruption before the National Democratic Convention in July or resign his party post.

title: NLT Carries Out $33.2 Million Sale Of Ralston Stock
description: The NLT Corporation announced yesterday completion of the previously reported sale of 700,000 common shares of the Ralston Purina Company at $49.125 a share for total net proceeds of nearly $33.2 million. NLT, an insurance holding company whose diversified interests also include Grand Ole Opry, said it had acquired the Ralston Purina shares as an investment in early 1971 for $24.735 a share, or a net total of nearly $17.1 million.

title: Lawyer Pledges to Fight Against TV Polish Jokes
