description: BASEBALL

title: Andre's Bricks at Tate Removed After Spraying
description: LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Britain's most controversial artistic exhibit, a pile of 120 fire bricks, was removed from public view at London's Tate Gallery today after a young man sprayed blue food coloring over it.

title: Flyers Tied at 55 in Parent's Return
MORE VOLUNTEERS WANTED BY CITY
description: Threading his way carefully to avoid offending the municipal unions, Mayor Beame aninounced yesterday that the city would enlarge its program of volunteer service by private citizens as a method of dealing with some of the effects of the budget crisis.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
Iran's ExNavy Chief Is Jailed and Fined 4Million in Payoffs
PRICES ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Heartened by some favorable economic news, prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market registered another advance yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Levi Strauss Accused Of Improper Payments
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (UPI)The country's oldest and most famous manufacturer of blue jeans has joined the list of companies accused of making improper payments abroad to do business.

title: Dow Is Up by 8.27 to 993.55Volume Shows Gain
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two cargo supervisors for National Airlines have been convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn on charges of stealing $40,000 worth of digital watches from the airline's cargo terminal at Kennedy International Airport on May 28. The two, Leonard Accardi, 42 years old of 1469 Fast 55th Street, Brooklyn, and Umberto Raddeo, 40, of 9445 134th Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, were caught in the act by Federal Bureau of lnvesigation agents who had staked out the area. Richard W. Appleby, an assistant United States Attorney, said a third defendant, Joseph Ferraro, 41, of 1540 East 5th Street, Brooklyn, had pleaded guilty before the start of the trial and had then testified for the Government.

title: People and Business
description: By a vote of 11 to 1, the Senate Public Works Committee yesterday postponed indefinitely consideration of President Ford's nomination of James F. Hooper 3d as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Federal regional development agency that is also the nation's largest electric utility. The committee's action. which followed two days of hearings on the nomination last week, eliminates Mr. Hooper from future consideration by the Senate.

title: Upset Victor in Canada
description: Canada's Progressive Conservative Party, out of power since 1963, has unexpectedly elected the youngest leader of its long history to carry the battle to Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Liberal Government. Joseph C. Clark, 36, is not only a fresh face in Canadian national politics but a relatively new one in Parliament, having been elected from the Rocky Mountain riding of Alberta little more than three years ago.

title: Mao's View Quoted in China Dispute
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 24For the first time since the current series of attacks on rightists in China intensified earlier this month, the Government newspaper today quoted Chairman %Mao Tsetung as personally expressing indignation at the rightists.

title: Blaze Hits Empty Tanker BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP)
description: A smoky, stubborn fire was extinguished today after blazing for more than 12 hours in the hull of an empty tanker anchored in Baltimore Harbor. There was no danger of the ship's sinking, the Coast Guard said. and no oil had leaked into the harhor. The crew of the Christion, a 662foot Greekregistered ship, remained on hoard while the fire was fought.

title: Foreign Payments Conceded By Richardson  Merrell Inc.
description: RichardsonMerrell Inc. has acknowledged that an internal audit, disclosed a number of foreign payments of questionable legality or propriety.

title: 3 Major Retail Chains Raise Their Dividends
description: Three of the nation's major retail chains yesterday raised their dividends in response to recent good business.

title: Commonwealth Role For Mariana Islands Approved by Senate
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24The Senate voted today to grant commonwealth status to the northern Mariana islands, paving the way for the first territorial expansion of the United States since 1925, when Swains Island was annexed to American Samoa.

title: Senate Panel Votes FoodStamp Curb
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24The Senate Agriculture Committee, breaking a deadlock, pushed through today what supporters termed a conservative but not punitive compromise foodstamp plan that would drop about three million people from the program. The vote was 10 to 4.

title: Justices Question Rights of Inmates
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 24The Justices of the Supreme Court raised question after question today about the rights that inmates in state prisons now have to ask the Federal courts to reverse their convictions on the ground that state court proceedings violated their Fourth Amendment rights. against illegal search and seizure.

title: Hoffa Jury Recalls Witness
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UPI) A New Jersey witness who already has made more than 1,000 brief appearances is scheduled to return tomorrow before a Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R, Hoffa, former head of the teamsters union. Stephen A. Andretta, 40 years old, of Little River, N. J. was subpoenaed to answer more questions stemming from the testimony he gave earlier, federal sources said.

title: Garrity Orders Boston to Have 20 Percent Black School Chiefs
description: BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) United States District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. ordered today that whites and blacks be appointed alternately to administrative vacancies in the Boston public school system until 20 percent of the administrators were black.

title: Baseball World Wonders And Frets Over Impasse
description: Bill Veeck has a new baseball team, at a cost of $10 million, but he doesn't know when he'll get to watch it play. New York City has a new, Yankee Stadium, of a cost of more than $100. million, but it doesn't know when its baseball team will play there.

title: Israelis Will Pay A 70% Income Tax Under a New Levy
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 24Israelis, already the highest taxed people in the world, will pay 70 percent of their income to state and city revenue collectors in the fiscal year beginning April 1.

title: $1,500,000 FRAUD LAID TO MAN ON L.I.;
description: Andrew De Lillo, the head of two large Long Island companies making concrete pipes and girders, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of ernbezzling nearly $1.5 million from a union pension and retirement benefit fund.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on news coverage of the New Hampshire primary that appeared Monday in The New York Times, it was incorrectly reported that The Boston Globe had not carried the results of the Iowa Democratic caucuses on the front page. The results appeared on the front page of The Globe on Jan. 20.

title: Search Fails to Find Abbey's Body
description: A threeman scuba team from the Harbor Patrol and a diver hired privately were unable yesterday to locate the body of Steven Abbey, the Columbia University oarsman who droWned on Monday in the Spuyten Duyvil. The other eight crewmen swam safely to shore after their racing shell was abandoned because of strong currents.

title: H. Allen Smith, Humorist, Dies
description: H. Allen Smith, the former New York newspaperman who parlayed a dour view of the world into a bestselling career as one of the country's most popular and prolific humorists, died yesterday in a San Francisco hotel.

title: Canada May Let Provinces Bar Land Sales to Aliens
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (AP)The Government announced today that it would propose changes in Canadian law to give individual provinces the right to bar the sale of land to nonCanadians or foreigncontrolled corporations.

title: Kissinger, at End of Latin Tour, Rules Out Cuban Intervention
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 24Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger attempted today to reassure the Central American nations that the United States would not permit intervention by Cuban armed forces in the hemisphere.

title: Rep. Taylor to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Representative Roy A. Taylor, Democrat of North Carolina, announced today that he had decided not to seek reelection after 16 years in Congress.

title: CUNNINGHAM SEEKS STAY ON SUBPOENA
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court will consider arguments tomorrow morning on whether to grant Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, a stay of his scheduled appearance before a special grand jury on Tuesday.

title: Notes on People
description: According to unconfirmed reports from Los Angeles, Zubin Mehta will replace Pierre Boulez as conductor of the New York Philharmonic. Officials of the New York orchestra and of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which Mr. Mehta has conducted since 1961, would neither deny nor confirm the rumor yesterday. Mr. Mehta, 40 years old, was born in Bombay and is regarded as one of the glamour conductors on the international scene. He has been among several candidates mentioned since last May, when Mr. Boulez's decision to step down at the end of the 1976 77 season, after seven years, was confirmed.

title: Ideology the Key Factor
description: CONCORD. N. H.. Feb. 24In the end, the most important thing to the voters of New Hampshire was neither television blitzes nor platform personalities nor early morning visits to plant gates. It was ideology. Most of the conservative. Republicans, a New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,235 voters across the state showed, chose Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California, and most of the liberals chose President Ford, with the moderates divided.

title: Oswald's Gun Fired 2 Shots, Expert Says
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP)An independent medical investigator, confirming the findings of the Warren Commission, says only two bullets were fired at President Kennedy and both came from the gun of Lee Harvey Oswald.

title: Bronx Legislator Reports He Is Indicted in Bribe Bid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24State Assemblyman Alan Hochberg, protesting his innocence, disclosed today that he had been indicted by a state grand jury. on charges of official misconduct and violating the stale election law.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: WELLSHerry K. Memorial meeting, Februery 28, 4 P. M. Cemmtmity Church, 40 F. 35th St., New York City

title: Now for Another Great Season
CHINA SAID TO DROP PRODUCTION OF ICBM
Voters Views Sampled As They Left the Polls
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on interviews with a random sampling of New Hampshire voters as they left the polls yesterday. Fifteen voting precincts throughout the state were selected and, within each precinct, each voter had an equal chance of selection.In all, 1,235 voters were interviewed, including 561 Democrats and 674 Republicans.

title: Bridge
description: In bridge, as in other recreations, professional and amateur are ambiguous terms.

title: House Ethics Committee Begins Inquiry on Schorr
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Congress began its investigation of the Daniel Schorr affair today as more details came to light of the manner in which he had leaked a House intelligence report to The Village Voice, the New York newspaper.

title: United Nations Study Says Spreading Deserts Are Caused by Man's Misuse of the Land
description: BOSTONDeserts are on the march, persistently swallowing up arable land and the industrialized world will pay for it in higher food prices and possibly in political turmoil as well, a national meeting of scientists has been told.

title: PANEL BACKS UNIT ON INTELLIGENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Senate Government Operations Committee voted 12 to 0 today to create a panel to monitor intelligence operations. It included procedimes that could result in the expulsion of a Senator who leaked secrets.

title: Tenant Coalition Proposes Uniform State Regulations
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The New York State Tenants Coalition today called for abolishing the myriad rent control mechanisms around the state and substituting a uniform regulatory system that would require landlords to demonstrate an economic need for rent increases.

title: Rockefeller Urges a U.S. Takeover of Welfare Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Vice President Rockefeller proposed to the nation's Governors today a fivepoint program to simplify and in some respects to enlarge greatlyFederal financial aid to the states and their needy citizens.

title: CAHN'S SECRETARY TESTIFIES FOR HIM
description: The defense rested yesterday in the trial of William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, and the prosecution began Its rebuttal.

title: Top G.E. Nuclear Power Aide Calls Engineers Charges Old
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The lop nuclear power official at the General Electric Company testified today that safety questions raised by three former company engineers about reactors did not present a single new issue,

title: Buffalo Registers Last 9 Points Monroe Miffed Braves Defeat Knicks, Scoring Last 9 Points
Albany Out To Rewrite '73 Trot Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24  Was there a mistake in the final draft of a bill here three years ago that allowed Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways to react a $15million windfall? Or was a provision that allowed the two tracks to keep almost all the extra 8 percent takeout on exotic wagers a deliberate legislative effort. to help the tracks make up losses from offtrack betting?

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Most Valuable Associate
description: John W. Benesch Associates, General Agent for the Mutual Benelit Life insurance company, has selected Ronald S. Berger, C.L.U. as the organization's Most Valuable Associate for 1975. Mr. Berger has served the industry and his clientele with devotion.

title: ExState Justice Charged With Lying to Grand Jury
description: Joseph A. Brust, who retired two months ago as a Bronx Supreme Court Justice, was indicted yesterday on charges that he lied when he denied being influenced by Anthony Mercorella, a former City Councilman, now a Civil Court judge, in several court matters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Why Ford's C.I.A. Reform Won't Work

title: 500 DressMaking Shops Expected to Reopen Today
description: More than 500 dressmanufacturing shops in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are expected to reopen today after having been closed since Feb. 17 in a dispute between two employer groups.

title: Baryshnikov, Jamison To Dance in Ailey Work
description: Alvin Alley will choreograph a duet for Mikhail Baryshnikov and Judith Jamison, marking the first time that Mr. Baryshnikov, the Russian ballet star who defected to the West in 1974, will appear with a moderndance company. The still untitled work will have a score by Duke Ellington.

title: Sales of New Cars Rose 20.7% in 10 Days
SINATRA IS HONORED BY CITY AND FRIARS
description: It was hard to see and nothing to hear, but Frank Sinatra was honored by New York City and the Friars Club last night in what appeared to be a semipublic ceremony in a foyer of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel's Grand Ballroom, where the club paid tribute to the singer at a dinner.

title: Article 3  No Title

AntiLeak Bill Found of Little Effect by Some Experts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Some present and former Government security officers contend that President Ford's new secrecy bill will not materially change the Government's power to halt leaks of information.

title: Bronx Legislator Reports He Is Indicted in Bribe Bid
TOP ALABAMA JUDGE BARS ANOTHER TERM
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 24 Chief Justice Howell Heflin, whose efforts on behalf of judicial reform in Alabama during the last five years have attracted national attention, announced yesterday that he would not seek reelection this year.

title: Carter Finds Result Is Awfully Nice

description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1976

title: Jersey Inquiry Finds No Cause For the Bruises on Coma Victim

description: City University administrators are considering a set of reorganization proposals drawn up by a group of faculty members that include the charging of tuition.

title: RAW MATERIALS WILL COST MORE
Nixon Says His Toast in Peking Intended No Criticism of Ford
GOING OUT Guide
description: ORIENT EXPRESSIVE Two years ago, during a world tour by the Ensemble Nipponia, which makes its Amercan debut here tonight, a European critic wrote that the concert of traditional and contemporary Japanese music, played on ancient, exotic instruments, opened up a completely different world of sound.

title: Nixon Calls on Scali, Ill With Bronchitis In a Peking Hospital
description: PEKING, Feb. 24 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon today visited his former United Nations representative, John A, Scali, who is in a Peking hospital with acute bronchitis.

title: Employers Seek Access To State Criminal Records
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The State Division of Criminal Justice Services heard testimony today against proposed rules limiting access by employers and others to the five million criminal record's kept by the division.

title: WilsonCosgrave Talk Set
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) Prime Ministers Harold Wilson of Britain and Liam Cosgrave of Ireland will meet in London on March 5 to assess subsequent moves in the critical Northern Irish situation, the British Government announced today.

title: Purchase Of Giants Approved
French Pledge to Oppose Concorde Restriction Here
description: PARIS, Feb. 24Marcel Cavaill, French Secretary of State for Transport, today assailed as discriminatory and anticonstitutional a bill passed by the New York State Legislature that would in effect bar Concorde flights into Kennedy International Airport.

title: Gil Evans Improves His Jazz Patterns With 14Piece Band
description: Gil Evans is 63 years old, but this may still be the year that he finally breaks out to a wider American market. If he does, it will be overdue recognition for one of the most fascinating men in contemporary American music.

title: City Univ. Tourney Will Begin Today
description: The City University of New York basketball tournament opens today with eight teams and free admission. City College, seeded No. 1, will open play at 1 o'clock against Queens College. Baruch will meet Brooklyn in the other afternoon game.

title: Council Votes Bill to Make Street Drinking Illegal
description: After a heated debate that divided ethnic groups and split political groups, the City Council passed a bill yesterday that would make it an offense to drink alcoholic beverages on city streets. The vote was 25 to 12.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Jumped 2.3% in January
28 Western Railroads Remain Out of Rate Rise
description: The 28 railroads operating west of the Mississippi have informed the Interstate Commerce Commission that they will not join Eastern and Southern railroads in the average freight rateinc rease of 4.7 percent that would take effect March 6.

title: CHINA SAID TO DROP PRODUCTION OF ICBM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Lieut. Gen. Daniel O. Graham, former director of the Defense. Intelligence Agency, said today he believed China had made a political decision not to produce an intercontinental ballistic missile so it would not have a weapon directly threatening the United States.

title: Soaring Prices and a Health Scare Shake France's Oyster Lovers
Presidential Primary Ballot Bill Revives in AlbanyThen Dies
FORDREAGAN CONTEST VERY CLOSE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARY VOTE
JURY DELIBERATING IN JERSEY DISK CASE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 24 (AP) Jury deliberations began today in the Brunswick Record Corporation fraud case, the first major criminal trial involving alleged payola since the practice was discovered in the 1950's.

title: CUNNINGHAM GETS INQUIRY DEADLINE
New Jersey Briefs
description: Richard Feinberg, owner of one of the largest Pocono Mountains retirement communities, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Newark to using false advertising to sell $700,000 worth of building lots in his development. Mr. Feinberg, 47 years old, of Somerset, president of the Pocono Haven Corporation, a 215lot tract in Mount Pocono, Pa., pleaded guilty before Judge H. Curtis Meanor to two counts of mail fraud, punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a $2,000 fine.

title: Orpheus Gives Chamber Works Two Premieres
description: Without the traditional crutches of form such as sonata and fugue to fall back on, composers in our day are forced to perform feats of ingenuity in devising usable molds for their music. Two examples of this sort of invention turned up at Carnegie Recital Hall on Mon. day night when the Orpheus Chamber Ensemble gave first performances of Meyer Kupferman's Skywriters and William Bland's An Impressiori by Arp.

title: 3 Arrested in 50 Burglaries At 4 Projects in Brooklyn
description: Two Housing Authority detectives known as the Lone Ranger and Tonto arrested three alleged members of a sixman gang yesterday accused of having hroken into and rifled the apartments of at least 50 people in four Brooklyn housing projects since early last month.

title: Fairfield Beats Iona
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb.24 (AP)  Steve Balkun scored 25 points and grabbed 15 rebounds tonight and led Fairfield to its third straight victory, an 8762 decision over Iona.

title: $1,500,000 FRAUD LAID TO MAN ON L.I.
description: Andrew De Lillo, the head of twn large Long Island companies making concrete pipes and girders, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of embezzling nearly $1.5 million from a union pension and retirement benefit fund.

title: FULL VOICE URGED FOR SPANISH LABOR
description: MADRID, Feb. 24  If the Spanish Government's youngest minister has his way, the statecontrolled syndicate organization grouping management and labor under one roof will be transformed into a democratic and representative union of workers within the next year.

title: Payoff Statement To S.E.C. Revoked By a Tenneco Aide
Sears Considered Vesco a Good Guy, Lawyer Tells Hearing on Disbarment
Nets, Paced By Erving, Top Squires
It's a BigMoney Week on Tennis Courts
description: This is the week tennis serves a blistering ace against the prophets of doom. Some observers have been predicting that the $10 million bubble (the estimated total of 1976 prize money) is about to burst, that sponsors are preparing to withdraw., because they are not getting their money's worth from the sport.

title: Gov. Lamm Apologizes To Colorado Editors
Bruises Remain Mystery As Inquiry Into Coma Ends
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24  The State Attorney General's office ended today its grand jury investigation into the cause of bruises on the body of Karen Ann Quinlan without reaching any conclusions on how they were inflicted.

title: Ideology the Key Factor
If Bread Boredom Sets In, Try an Innovative Slice
Commonwealth Role For Mariana Islands Approved by Senate
Seven Ethiopian Ministers Are Dismissed by Military
Food Costs Here Rise 1.1 Percent in One Week
description: Food costs in the New York area rose 1.1 percent last week. The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went up 76 cents on the week to a total of $72.67 for the 38 items in the city's market basket, the city Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Vermont Primary: More Rural, Remote
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.The people who disparage New Hampshire's Presidential primary as too rural, too remote, too early and too small to he taken seriously ought to see Vermont.

title: Rights to Chorus Line Acquired by Universal
description: An agreement has been reached for Universal Pictures to acquire motionpictures rights to A Chorus Line from the producers of the Broadway musical hit, the New York Shakespeare Festival company headed by Joseph Papp.

title: Cerro Stockholders Vote Company's End To Join Marmon
description: Some 200 stockholders of the Cerro Corporation voted the company out of existence at lengthy threehourand 45minut special meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Cars of Jobless Migrant Workers Jam Europe's Roads
The Congress at a Glance
description: PARTICIPANTSThe 4,998 delegates to this 25th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party were selected by local party organizations in the country's 15 republics. Delegates include most of the highly influential party members on both local and national levels, as well as some drawn from a variety of occupations and ethnic groops to bolster the image of grassroots participation. Television pictures from the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses, where the sessions are being held, show that most of the delegates are middleaged and elderly men, although women are also present.

title: Crew Saved in Bahama Race Sinking
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 24A yacht sank in the MiamiNassau race just before dawn today and all of the crew were rescued by another yacht. The lost vessel was Mary E II, a 40 foot sloop owned by Charles Benson of Chesapeake Bay, Md., and the rescuing craft was J & B, jointly owned and sailed by Mort Engel and Jack Sutphen of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Columbia Five Is on Way Up
description: College basketball coaches usually don't get enthusiastic over an 813 wonlost record. But Tom Penders of Columbia is an exception.

title: Chrysler Quarter Loss Is $27 Million
2 EnergySaving IND Cars in Service
description: Subway cars 3700 and 3701 went hack into circulation yesterday, after a trip to California, looking no different from other cars, but embodying an energy  saving principle that may make them the prototype of trains of the future.

title: Sisters Return to Natural Mother Upheld
description: A lowercourt ruling that four young Nassau County sisters must he returned to their natural mother was upheld here yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: The Misleading Primaries
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PENSION TAX RISE IN 77 IS DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Senate Finance Committee gave a strong hint today that Congress would not enact a Social Security tax increase of any kind this year.

title: HOUSE UNIT REVIVES STRIP MINING ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The House Interior Committee approved, 28 to 11, today a bill calling for Federal controls on strip mining, even though President Ford has twice vetoed similar measures.

title: LOCKHEED IS SUED BY STOCKHOLDER
Merlino Bill Would Unite Three State Departments
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24  The Senate majority leader, Joseph P. Merlino, introduced today legislation that would abolish %the Departments of Banking, Insurance and Public Utilities and reorganize them into a new Department of Regulated Commerce.

title: Scanlon Quits M.A.C. Publicity Position
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday announced the resignation of John P. Scanlon as its $37.000 ayear pudicrelations chief because of outside activities that it characterized as illadvised and not acceptable.

title: How the New Puritani' Was Staged
description: Both Sandro Sequi, the stage director, and Richard Bonynge, the conductorthe men primarily responsible for the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Bellini's I Puritani that will be unveiled tonightsee their task as the evocation of the feeling of how theater was in that epoch, as Mr. Sequi put it yesterday.

title: GORDON SKADRA, LED PRESBYTERIAN UNITS
. . . Halting Pakistan
description: France and Pakistan have submitted a safeguards agreement that is now before the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna and is expected to receive approval in the next few days. Once this framework for I.A.E.A. inspection is accepted, France will be free to proceed with sale of the plutonium reprocessing plant under terms of the new sevennation suppliers agreementunless the Ford Administration can persuade both countries to hold off.

title: L.I. Fraud Indictments
description: Andrew De Lillo, the head of two large Long Island companies making concrete pipes and girders, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of embezzling nearly $1.5 million from a union pension and retirement fund. Page 21.

title: Searches and Freedom
description: The Supreme Court put a disturbing dent in the Fourth Amendment recently. The case involved the apparently innocuous issue of whether the stolen credit cards in a defendant's car when he was arrested should have been admitted in evidence against him at his trial.

title: British Diplomatic Team To Visit Rhodesia Today
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 24A highlevel British diplomatic mission will come here tomorrow to consult with both the white Government and black nationalists involved in constitutional negotiations, the office of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced today.

title: Overkill on the Hill
description: The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct seems to be having difficulty deciding just what it is supposed to investigate in the Daniel Schorr affair. That is understandable since it was given a decidedly foggy mandate when the House voted overwhelmingly last week to have it determine whether the CBS correspondent was in contempt of Congress.

title: U.S. PRICE SUPPORTS
2 AIRLINES SHOW BETTER RESULTS
Tuition Rates Increased By Fairleigh Dickinson
description: RUTHERFORD, Feb. 24 (AP)  Fairleigh Dickinson University today announced approval by its board of trustees of tuition increases for the 196777 school year of 6.6 percent at the undergraduate level and 9.4 percent for graduate students.

title: 40 Artists in Bergen Mall Show
description: Forty artists from three counties will be represented at the 20th annual Bergen Mall art show tomorrow through Saturday.

title: CORRECTIONS
TV: Candidates on Display in Presidential Forum
description: Presidential Forum, a publicTV panel arrangement featuring several candidates for the Presidency, began Monday evening on Channel 13 with a shot of two youngsters and a woman washing a car. The vehicle was yellow Datsun. Perhaps,some viewers may nave thought, the images were making a subtle statement about imports, though it wasn't clear whether the message was pro or con. Or perhaps, in a burst of inspiration, Andy Warhol had been hired to produce the series. Set to the sound ofpolitical oratory, two hours of carwash would be bestowed upon the audience.

title: YUGOSLAVS REVIEW AMERICAN'S JAILING
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Feb. 24An Ameircan sentenced here to seven years' imprisonment for spying after photographing a sugar refinery last summer will get an appeal trial tomorrow.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOLEDO, Feb. 24 (AP)Larry Kristoff, the coach of the American team, announced the remaining selections today for his team for the World Cup of Wrestling beginning Sunday at the University of Toledo. The United States will challenge the Soviet Union, Iran and Canada in the twoday competition.

title: Italy Will Reopen Exchange Market
description: ROME, Wednesday. Feb. 25 (Reuters) The Italian Treasury Ministry said last night the official foreign exchange market would reopen Monday.

title: Music: Miss Bonazzi Sings With Style

description: ACCRA, Ghana. Feb. 24 (AP) Government officials have confirmed the arrest and detention of Dr. Kofi Awoonor, a Ghanaian novelist and poet who has taught at the State University of New York in Stony Brook. L.I.

Patient Shifts Won't Save Much, State Mental Health Chief Says
description: ALBANY, Feb, 24Governor Carey's drive to transfer mental patients out of big institutions and into local communitiesa move he said would reduce the cost of mentalhealth carewill not save much for the state this year or next, a panel of legislators was told today.

title: TOPPER SUIT SETTLED BY SHEARSON HAYDEN
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, the brokerage firm, said yesterday that it. had paid $1.675 million to three major investors to settle a 1971 lawsuit arising out of its purchase of $5.25 million of notes in the Topper Corporation, a toy company that went into bankruptcy four years ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: The beginning of this rich, astute novel by Helen Yglesias takes place at sea, metaphorically speakingwith the narrator, Anne Goddard, recalling scenes from childhood in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The bare board kitchen floor, flooded with sudsy water, is . . . a sea. [My mother] scrubs on her hands and knees, with a woodenbacked brush, while I ride the waves, my boat the unevenly balanced kitchen table. Outside the window, a monster rattles by. I transform the Myrtle Avenue El into the terrifying noise and flash of the famous storm of her crossing to America on her voyage from nowhere to the here I am born to give her substance.

title: CARTER IS IN CITY FOR APRIL VOTES
description: While voters were casting ballots in New Hampshire yesterday, Jimmy Carter spent hours campaigning here in preparation for the April 6 primary in which New York delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be elected.

title: Four in Texas Family Slain, Then Survivor Kills Suspect
Five Asian Nations End Meeting With a Pledge for Cooperation
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 24 The leaders of five Southeast Asian nations wound up a twoday meeting on the island of Bali today. signing the first treaty binding them and a declaration looking toward further cooperation.

title: Spirited Atmosphere of 1972 Primary Is Missing at Polls in Franklin, N.H.
description: FRANKLIN, N.H., Feb. 24The townfolk trickled into the local firehouse and the City Hall all day today and gabbed about nearly everythingeverything, that is, except why they were there.

title: H.U.D. Nominee Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Constance B. Newan of Washington, D. C., to be an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

It Was a Summery Sort of Party
description: When you get a good idea let's say a June in January partyyou don't forget the whole thing just because you're 23 days late. Not if you're Maggi and Clyde Newhouse.

title: City University's Future
description: Faced with the certainty of drastic budget cuts for an indefinite future, the City University must choose between two painful courses of action. One alternative would leave the institution's existing structure essentially intact, forcing a spread of all too meager funds over many more programs than they can cover effectively. The other path entails the elimination through merger of some existing unitsa direction proposed last year by Dr. Robert Marshal:, president of City College, and more recently by Chancellor Robert Kibbee.

title: Arab Oil Wealth Helping Jordan Expand Facilities of the Nation's Only University
description: AL JUBAYHAH, JordanThe Middle East nil boom has been an indirect bonanza for Jordan University, the only university in this sparsely inhabited Arab kingdom.

description: The defense rested yesterday in the trial of William Cahn, the former Nassau Cqunty Disitrict Attorney, and the prosecution began its rebuttal.

title: From Harvard to Harvard: a Scholar's Odyssey
description: Robert Fitzgerald, Harvard 33, never went to graduate school, but today he is the university's Lord of the Word, Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Orators.

title: About Education
description: It was not so long ago that legal education was a boom industry, with the demand for law school seats far outstripping the supply, and colleges and universities rapidly planning to begin new law schools.

title: Concorde and the Law
description: The vote in the State Legislature against the Concorde on Monday has abruptly sharpened what had been somewhat diffuse debate over whether it would be legal toban the supersonic airliner from News@@@ Kennedy InterneAnalysis@@@ tional Airport. It also has reinforced the views of experts on both sides that, since the governmental system is far from supersonic, it is extremely unlikely there will be a final verdict for many months. In other words, almost no one looks for Concorde flights into Kennedy before next year, if then.

title: Zambia, on Angola
House Unit Approves Measure To Prohibit Small New Pistols
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The House Judiciary Committee approved today an amendment whose sponsor says it will outlaw seven out of 10 handguns made and sold in this country.

VITAMIN C CLOUDS VITAL BLOOD TEST
U.S. COURT FORBIDS BUMPING ANDQUOTA
Theater League Bids Cinemas Refrain From Using Sex Films
description: The League of New York Theaters and Producers has appealed to owners of firstclass film houses in the midtown theater district to refrain from showing pornographic films.

title: Senators Tackle Issue of Who Will Own Federally Irrigated Lands in California
description: FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 19In the late 1940's, Cye G. Vaughan joined his father and mother in an attempt to raise wheat, cotton, potatoes, milo and alfalfa on 320 acres of raw land they had bought near Bakersfield, 108 miles south of this central California city in the San Joaquin Valley.

title: Caso Appoints Inspector Head of Police in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 24The appointment of Inspector Daniel P. Guido as Commissioner of the Nassau County Police Department was announced today by Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24The Minister of Defense has resigned after a disagreement with President Isabel Martinez de Pern over Government policy toward the armed forces, reliable sources said today.

title: Court Scores Marines For Pregnancy Ouster
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that it was unconstitutional for the Marine Corps to discharge women marines automatically because they became pregnant.

title: Article 2  No Title
McCaffrey &
description: McCaffrey & McCall, for 11 years the agency for RollsRoyce, has certainly changed its tune. Now it's singing Thank Heaven for Little Cars.

title: About New York; Lincoln Said That? Well ... Not Exactly
description: On Lincoln's Birthday, Tiffany & Co. took out an advertisement, quoting the great President as having said, among other things, that You cannot help the poor by destroying the rich, and, You cannot lift the wage earner by pulling down the wage payer.

title: PENSION TAX RISE IN '77 IS DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Senate Finance Committee gave a strong hint today that Congress would not enact a Social Security tax increase of any kind this year.

Brezhnev, Opening Party's Congress, Declares Detente Aids Soviet Growth

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 A psychiatrist called by Patricia Hearst's defense testified today that hers was a classic case of coercive persuasion that caused her to take part in the bank robbery for which she is on trial.

title: Japan Asks U.S. Disclosure Of Payoffs by Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Hours after presenting his credentials to President Ford, Japan's new Ambassador, Fumihiko Togo, turned over a letter to the State Department from Prime Minister Takeo Miki asking full United tSates disclosure about Lockheed payoffs.

title: XEROX PRICE PLANS SET ON NEW RENTALS,
Maloney to Stand Trial for Assault
Law Students to Help Write Regulations for SolidWaste Industry
People in Sports
Tampico, Ill., Hails Native Son Reagan
description: TAMPICO, Ill., Feb. 24All of Tampico (pop. 850) turned out today to welcome native son Ronald Reagan back to the place of his birth.

title: Doubleday Discussing Takeover of Dell To Form Huge Publishing Organization
description: Doubleday & Company, which is reported to publish more books than any other American publisher, and the Dell Publishing Company, one of the major publishers of paperbacks and other books and magazines, are discussing a consolidation in which Dell would become a subsidiary.

title: N. Carolina Clinches
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 24 (AP)  North Carolina's Phil Ford canned all 16 of his free throws tonight in a 26point effort that paced a 9179 rout of North Carolina State. It gave the fourthranked Tar Heels the regular season championship in the Atlantic Coast Conference and improved their record to 232 over all. State dropped to 196.

title: Portugal's Military Insists That Voting Be Held on April 25
description: LISBON, Feb. 24Portugal's military leadership expressed its concern today over the increasing activity of certain antidemocratic and reactionary sectors, but insisted on holding national legislative elections on the original target date, April 25, to mark the second anniversary of the milltary coup against the former rightwing dictatorship.

title: Dominick Salvati, Partner In Brooklyn Architect Firm
description: Dominick Salvati, senior member of Dominick Salvati & Son, architects, of Brooklyn, died Monday at Deepdale General Hospital, Little Neck, Queens. He was 86 years old and lived at 8063 256th Street, Floral Park, Queens.

title: Symphony Hall Gets Reopening Tuneup
From Harvard to Harvard: a Scholar's Odyssey
New Nuclear Threat...
description: The United States has won another battle against the spread of atomic weapons in the newly ratified agreement with six other major supplier countries adding technology to the list of civilian nuclear exports that trigger international inspection. But it is still a long way from winning the war.

title: Polish Independent Catholic Loses Seat in Parliament
description: WARSAW, Feb. 23 (Reuters), The last small group of independent legislators in Poland appeared on the point of dissolution today after its Roman Catholic founder, Dr. Stanislaw Stomma, lost his seat.

title: Castro's Zealots Or Helots?
description: LONDONAn important question currently facing the world is whether the Cuban troops which just spearheaded the Popular Movement (M.P.L.A.) victory in Angola were fighting because of Fidel Castro's zeal for thirdworld revolutionary causes or because they served his Soviet ally's strategic purposes as ideological mercenaries helping tilt the international power balance.

title: Church Doubts Caucuses In Carolina Will Help Him
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 24Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, who addressed a Richland County Democratic Party fundraising luncheon here today, said he expected to receive little support in the Democratic precinct caucuses that will be held Saturday.

title: Beame Leads in Appeal For More Aid to Cities
Gore Mt. Expects Snowmaking Help
description: NORTH CREEK, N.Y., Feb. 25About 40 years ago, ski trains steaming into this sleepy central Adirondack Mountain community shortly after dawn would be greeted by villagers. They would make visiting skiers feel at home, even taking them into their homes for as little as $1 a night. It was just as the Depression was tailing off. 62  year  old Bill Sullivan, owner of a boxlike local country store, reminisced today. Our people knew skiers meant income for the town. And in those days everyone here was interested in anything resembling income.

title: U.S. TO EVALUATE STEEL REGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Administration announced today that it would make a comprehensive evaluation of the total impact, costs and benefits of Federal regulation on a basic industry, steel.

title: DrugShipping Fraud Stirs Bank Dispute
description: PARIS, Feb. 25An international shipment of pharmaceuticals that was found to be only sawdust, stones and coarse yellow powder has led to a bitter banking dispute in Europe and raised some issues about the financing of international trade.

title: Unbeaten Rutgers Gains 24th Victory
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Mike Dabney scored a careerhigh 33 points tonight as fourthranked Rutgers held off a scrappy William and Mary basketball team and posted a 10090 victcry, the 24th for the unundefeated Searlet Knights.

title: LOUIS HORN
description: Louis Horn, founder in 1929 of Royal Typographers, an advertising typography concern, died Tuesday at his home in Far Rockaway, Queens. Mr. Horn, who retired a year ago as president and chairman of the board, was 75 years old.

title: One Ford TV Favorite PreEmpted News Conference
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Feb. 25President Ford's television adviser said yesterday that last week's news conference on the reorganization of intelligence agencies had been scheduled at 8 P.M. instead of the more desirable hour of 9 in order to avoid a conflict with one of the President's favorite television shows. Police Woman.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Hundreds of employees of the Commodore Hotel crowded into the hotel lobby yesterday for a fivehour strike to protest what they said was the owner's refusal to give them retroactive pay increases. The employees said the increases were effective last June 1. They were also striking in an attempt to force the owner, Penn Central, to sign their new union contract, which provides for severance pay. A spokesman for the company said Penn Central could not afford to meet either demand. At the urging of union leaders, the staff went back to work at 4 P.M.

The Brezhnev Report
description: Despite its lack of surprises, Leonid I. Brezhnev's report to the 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress merits careful study. In effect, it represents the most uptodate exposition of the party linea detailed recital of all the key foreign and domestic policy positions of the small group that rules the Soviet Union. It is also the political platform on which Mr. Brezhnev and his colleagues expect to be reaffirmed in power at the end of this highly disciplined meeting, whose final decisions have been planned well in advance.

description: By a vote of 4to3. the Federal Communications Cornmission's joint. Federalstate regulatory committee looking at competition in the telephone industry, recommended yesterday that the telephone industry he allowed to continue to require the use of protective devices on basic phone equipment when it was provided by customers instead of the phone company, pending the results of an economic impact study on competition in the industry. The F.C.C. is expected to vote on the recommendation March 18. It had earlier outlawed the requirement for protective devices on extra phone equipment and imposed in place of that industry policy a program for registration of all telephone equipment to meet Federal standards.

description: It was a day to take off one's coat. It was a day to roll down the car windows, to eat ice cream, to drive through the park in a horsedrawn carriage. It was a day to go outdoors and perch on a rock or sit on a benchor just lean against a building, head tilted up to the sun, and dream about the spring. People did just that all over the metropolitan area yesterday. At 2:50 P.M. the temperature reached 70 degrees and it became the warmest February 25 since 1930, when it was 75. As the photographer who took this picture of a couple in Central Park said: It looked as if everybody in offices and in schools fell in love and went to the park to take a walk and hold hands. It was like a spring love affair.

title: Notes on People
description: Fred W. Heise, one of the three Apollo 13 astronauts who narrowly escaped death in space after an oxygentank explosion, has anotherif less protractedly suspensefulride in his future. He will command the first freeflight test of the space shuttle, probably in July 1977, when it is released from a 747 jet 25,000 feet over California to make a glidertype, unpowered landing as if it had just reentered the earth's atmosphere. In the 1970 mission that kept the nation holding its breath, Mr. Haise commanded the lunar module that had to skip its moon landing to remain attached as a rescue ship for the damaged command module.

title: NORTH KOREAN LAG ON DEBT REPORTED
description: TOKYO, Feb. 25  North Korea is reportedly in such difficulties in its balance of payments that it is not making interest payments on its foreign debt, according to Asian diplomatic analysts here.

title: Moscow Rays Linked to U.S. Bugging
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Soviet officials have privately conceded that microwaves have been beamed at the American Embassy in Moscow, but they justified the possibly harmful activity as necessary to jam American listening devices on the roof of the building.

title: Canadiens 3, Scouts 1
Monsanto Lifts Output
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 (UPI)The Monsanto Company announced today that it was increasing the output of vydyne and Vydyne R (mineral reinforced) nylon engineering plastic with the construction of new units at its Pensacola, Fla., plant. The new units, to be completed in 1978, will double the output of vydyne and extrusion resins and increase the cutput of vydyne R fivefold. Vydyne resins are used in the automobile, appliance, industrial and textile machinery industries.

title: EDUCATION AGENCY, SUED BY STATE U.
Roosevelt, L.I., Gets an Alternative to the Supermarket
description: ROOSEVELT, L.I., Feb. 25 When the A. & P. moved out of its spacious building here 14 months ago, it left this community without any supermarket where shoppers could buy food at reasonable prices.

title: Mariners 2, Saints 1
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 25 (AP)Norm Ferguson retrieved his rebound and fired a 10foot shot into an unguarded net at 8:13 of suddendeath overtime tonight to give the San Diego Mariners a 21 victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints. whose World Hockey Association franchise is on the brink of folding.

title: SPAIN IS CRITICAL OF U.S. ON ANGOLA
Pentagon Is Investigating Military Beef Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Pentagon is looking into the possibility that fraud and bribery have been involved in the purchase of beef for the armed services.

title: U.S. OIL IMPORTS RISE TO RECORDS
description: Foreign oil imports into the United States rose to record levels last week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: VIRGINIA TO LOOK INTO C.I.A. ACTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  A Virginia prosecutor whose jurisdiction includes the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency has asked the Justice Department for evidence it has developed on a 1971 breakin ordered by Richard Helms, then the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Humphrey Leads in Minnesota As Former Foes Rally to Him.
Bill to Allow Investments In Public Housing Gains
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25The Assembly gave final passage today to a measure that would allow private investment in 29 public housing projects in New York City. This would enable the city to raise $70 million to $80 million needed to complete eight of the projects.

title: Bumblebee 3 Wins Race To Nassau
Taft's Coach Relaxed in Quest for Third Title in Row
description: On Saturday morning Don Adams will keep his weekly tennis date. On Saturday afternoon he will keep his yearly date as a coach in the Public Schools Athletic League basket% ball semifinals. Adams, who %coaches Taft High %School from the Bronx, is remarkably unmoved as his team nears its third consecutive P.S.A.L. championship. No team in recent memory has accomplished that feat.

title: Seals Vanquish Rangers by 64
City's Inquiry on Market Leases Assailed by Developer in Court
description: The city's investigation into the leasing of the Bronx Terminal Market Was challenged in State Supreme Court yesterday by the Arol Development Corporation, lessee of the market, as unduly broad and a fishing expedition.

title: Reagan Puts His Net Worth at $1,455,571
description: CHARLESTON, Ill., Feb. 25Ronald Reagan released a financial statement today that placed his net worth at $1,455,571.

title: 14 Die in New Violence By JUAN de ONIS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 Ten guerrillas were killed in the northern province of Tucumn today, according to a military statement, while urban terrorists killed an army colonel, two policemen and a wealthy businessman.

title: The Selling Of a Perfume (In This Case It's Cardin's)
description: There it is on the small print of the package  Behind every great woman, there's a man. It's the kind of switch on an old saw that advertising writers love. And the man who would like to give women a touch of greatness is the French couturier Pierre Cardin, who is in town to help along the debut of his newest brainchild, a perfume called simply Cardin de Pierre Cardin.

title: REV. DANIEL F. MEEHAN
description: The Rev. Daniel F. Meehan, who had spent 20 years as a Navy Roman Catholic chaplain, retiring as a captain, died Monday in Mercy Hospital in Springfield, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: Chess:
description: It is curious how patterns of winning vary from one competition to another. Sometimes solid positional play dominates an event; at other times it gets nowhere and most of the games are decided either by mating attack or successful defense.

title: A Study Finds Women Unaware of Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Women, generally, are not aware of the nature or the extent of sex discrimination, according to a report on women and housing prepared for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: RHODESIA REPORTS KILLING 24 REBELS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 25The Rhodesian Government announced today that its security forces had engaged in hot pursuit of nationalist guerrillas along the Mozambique border, killing 24 and losing one soldier.

title: 2 Americans Freed By Captors in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25Two American Government employees who were kidnapped here four months ago were freed tonight, apparently unharmed and In good health.

title: Burden Is Critical of HIP's Medical Care

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 25The Rhodesian Government announced today that its security forces had engaged in hot pursuit of nationalist guerrillas along the Mozambique border, killing 24 and losing one soldier.

Contract Awards
description: The Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Systems Inc., a unit of Litton Industries, announced yesterday receipt of a $200 million Navy contract for advanced procurement of materials and equipment to be used in construction of four new destroyers for Iran.

title: Bill in House Links Bank Interest Rise To Home Investing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The House Banking Committee decided today to permit any commercial banknot just those with total assets of less than $25 millionto pay an extra quarterpoint interest on savings deposits provided it also meets a rather stiff standard for investments in housing.

title: Moscow Rays Linked to U.S. Bugging
Sports News Briefs
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 25 (AP)Seven Michigan State University football players were barred today from competition by the school's Athletic Council because of their alleged involvement in National Collegiate Athletic Association rule violations. The players may, however, be declared eligible by the N.C.A.A. before fall games begin, said John Fuzak, the Athletic Council chairman, who is president of the N.C.A.A. Today's move was taken in order to lay the groundwork for an appeal to the N.C.A.A. for reinstatement. N.C.A.A. rules threaten a university with more penalties unless it rules ineligible any player involved in rule violations. Michigan State already has been put on three years probation and limited in football scholarships after being found guilty last month of 34 violations.

title: COCOA FUTURES DROP BY 2C LIMIT
Glomar Explorer, Built to Raise Soviet Sub, Faces Decision: To Be Scrapped or to Be a DeepSea Driller
description: The Glomar Explorer, built at vast expense to raise a sunken Soviet submarine, faces a deadline to determine if she should be sold for scrap or used to perform roles in deepsea drilling beyond the capability of any other vessel.

title: Financing Congressional Elections
Veeck to Open Training Camp For Ballplayers Not on Roster
description: Another headache developed for baseball yesterday when a dispute arose within the group that is trying to buy the San Francisco Giants and keep them from moving to Toronto.

title: PROTEST AT CITY U. JOINED BY HUNDREDS
description: Hundreds of students from John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan and Richmond College on Staten Island demonstrated yesterday to express vehement opposition to Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee's proposals for closing their schools.

title: Carter Target of Liberals After New Hampshire Gain
Dow Tumbles 15.74 to 978.83
description: The credit markets, which have been heading toward lower interest rates for a week and shouldering a heavy volume of new issues with a great deal of success, ran into rougher going yesterday. Bond prices

title: Issue of Wage Freeze Bedevils Transit Talks
description: Negotiators for the Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority appeared yesterday to be on a collision course on the issue of wages as they bargained over a new contract for 32,400 bus and subway workers.

title: FUND FOR NEEDIEST NEAR RECORD HIGH
description: The 64th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which will officially end Monday, has collected $1,017,243 since it opened Dec. 7.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1976

title: Aqueduct Race Charts;  1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)
description: Thursday, Feb. 26. 43d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Posters Assail Teng
description: For the first time in a current campaign against rightists in China, wall posters in Peking identified Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping by name as a target of the attacks. [Page 8.]

title: Unemployed of the Ruhr Are Existing on Hope and Benefits
Busing Complicates Massachusetts Race
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26Busing is a volatile, uncertain issue in the Massachusetts primary that could further complicate the already confused Democratic Presidential race.

title: Japan Calling 3 in U.S.
description: The lower house of the Japanese Parliament subpoenaed three Americans to appear before it next week in the continuing investigation of the Lockheed bribery scandal. Details on page 7.

title: Some Albanians Are Ordered to Change Names
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb: 26 (UPI)Alhania has ordered all persons whose names do not conform to the nation's political, ideological and moral standards to change them, an Albanian embassy official said today.

title: L. J. SCHLAIFER
description: L. J. Schlaifer, who had spent more than 60 years in motionpicture sales and distribution, died yesterday at his home it; Forest Hills, Queens. He was 84 years old.

title: The Moynihan Puzzle
description: Daniel P. Moynihan bade farewell to his United Nations staff yesterday and moved back to his Harvard professorship. But he left behind him puzzlement over whether he would run for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New York The 48  year  old Mr. Moynihan has told friends privately that although he would like to be a Senator, feels he is qualified for. the job and is confident that he can win both the nomination and election, he will not run in the face of his flat disavowal of political aspirations, made last fall.

title: Ensemble Nipponia Gives a Quick Tour Of Ancient Music
description: If the Broadway run of Pacific Overtures presages an American infatuation with the traditional music of Japan, it will be necessary for the soloists of the Ensemble Nipponia to return for more engagements. The ensemble, performing at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, offered a quick tour through some ancient Japanese styles that are unfamiliar in the West and a perspective on a movement combining traditional techniques with modern compositional structures.

title: Advertising
description: Do you think you can spot a good commercial? That doesn't mean a commercial that entertains you or gives you a laugh, but one that is persuasive and sells products or services.

title: 4 SENATORS SEEK NEW GRAIN AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Four Democratic Senators proposed today legislation to create a new, semiautonomous agency within the Department of Agriculture to reform the nal tion's scandalridden graininspection system.

title: CRIMINAL RECORDS WILL BE EXPUNGED
description: ALBANY. Feb. 26An estimated total of 370,000 state residents 76 years old and older who have criminal records on file with the state will have those records purged if they have not been convicted of a crime in the last six years or are not now in prison or on probation.

title: Toms River's Bicentennial to Include a Public Hanging
description: TOMS RIVER, Feb. 26The Toms River Town Clerk will be hanged next month. The public is invited.

title: City Sees No Quick Need To Bolster Pension Funds
description: Mayor Beame's study of a possible need for increasing the city's funding of municipal pension systems, expected next week, will not necessarily mean the city will have to produce the extra money right away, officials said yesterday.

title: SADAT GETS VOW BY SAUDIS ON AID
description: CAIRO, Feb. 26Saudi Arabia has promised Egypt an immediate grant of $300 million and has reportedly agreed to join other oilproducing Arab countries in a collective program of assistance to the Egyptian Government.

title: $2 MILLION PAID BY CARRIER CORP.
description: The Carrier Corporation and its subsidiaries made $2.1 million in overseas payments over the last four years, the company acknowledged yesterday.

title: Aides Call President Amateur Campaigner
Pakistan Accepts Canadian Atomic Curb
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (AP)Pakistan has agreed not to use waste fuel from a Canadiansupplied nuclear reactor without Canadian permission, authorities here said today.

title: Ford View of Vote: Nixon Trip to China Probably Harmful
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Ford said today that former President Richard M. Nixon's trip to China probably was harmful to Mr. Ford's campaign in the New Hamp. shire primary election.

title: AUTO PRODUCERS INCREASE OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26United States automobile manufacturers are scheduled to build 823,000 cars next month, up 68 percent from the 490,109 built in March 1975, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: Report on Ford Timing For TV Show Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)The timing of President Ford's televised news conference at 8 P.M. on Feb. 17 had nothing to do with a show called Police Woman, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was with a certain trepidation that one began reading Telephone: The First Hundred Years, John Brooks's seventh work of nonfiction and first book since his instructive and entertaining history of postWorldWarII Wall Street, The GoGo Years. This uneasiness was momentarily assuaged when Mr. Brooks first seemed to identify the source of it in wellfounded suspicions about the arrangements behind . . . all books about corporate affairs, and then reassured us that while the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had given him more or less free access to its files, the book had been written without any corporate strings attached. Thus comforted, one read on . . only to discover that the trouble anyway is that Telephone is a history of corporate affairs.

title: U.S. FREES INMATE HELD YEAR TOO LONG
Instant Replays Help on Slopes
description: KILLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 26 Instant Replay and Instant Progress are the names given to the ski instruction program introduced at Killington, a major Green Mountain resort

title: Decline Is Reversed
description: The value of construction contracts awarded last month was 25 percent higher than the value of those awarded during January, 1975, according to an F. W. Dodge report yesterday on construction activity in the United States.

title: Bishop Expands on Statement About Homosexuals
TRUCKS ARE HALTED BY STRIKE IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 26A nationwide trucking strike contributed to Spain's nagging social unrest today.

title: JOSEPH WEIL, 100, YELLOW KID, DIES
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPHJoseph R. Weil, the confidence man known as the Yellow Kid, died today at the Lake Front Convalescent Center here. He was 100 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article In The New York Times yesterday incorrectly quoted a Moreland Commission report as saying that Grand Brokerage Inc. had sold insurance to six Bernard Bergman nursing homes. The report identified only three as Bergman houses. Grand Brokerage reports it actually served only two of them.

title: Senate Unit Passes Bill to Reconstitute U.S. Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) The Senate Rules Committee approved today a bill to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission, which next week loses its power to give matching campaign funds to Presidential candidates.

title: UNIT ON PALESTINE IS MEETING AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26A new United Nations committee, set up to press Palestinian claims, against Israel, started functioning today with a call for redress of a 30year injustice in the Middle East.

title: City Weighs Plan to Withdraw From Social Security System
description: City officials are considering a plan to withdraw city employees from the Federal Social Security system, in an effort to save an estimated S200 million a year. a City Hall aide confirmed last night.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEEKS FULL LEAK INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The House ethics committee moved today toward a fullscale investigation of the leaking of the House intelligence committee report in which it would have broadened powers to subpoena witnesses and they would be questioned under oath by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Trade Volume, Off in '75, Apt to Rise
description: GENEVA, Feb. 26World trade, which grew in value about 4 percent last year but only because of price increases, should expand this year in volume as well as value, accord. ing to an international study.

title: TWO DEATHS LINKED TO FOOD ON FLIGHT
description: PINNEBERG, West Germany, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Two returned vacationers died here of an intestinal ailment the day after they came back from the Canary Islands aboard a Spanish charter airliner, health authorities said today.

title: JAPAN SUMMONS 3 U.S. WITNESSES
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26The lower house of the Japanese Parliament today subpoenaed three Americans to appear here under oath next week in the continuing investigation of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation bribery scandal.

title: Commentary: Cretin's Delight on Film
description: Snuff is a contemptible movie now showing in Times Square. It is advertised as being so bloody that it could only have been made in South Americawhere life is cheap. Snuff is also, in the slanguage of underground film freaks, a term denoting the actual murder, on camera, of a woman. The rumor among the freaks for months has been that several such movies were indeed made recently in Buenos Aires. Snuff seeks to capitalize that rumor.

title: Harper's Names Publisher
description: James A. Alcott, president of the Harper's division of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, was appointed yesterday to the additional post of publisher, The Associated Press reported. He succeeds Russell Barnard, who resigned.

title: Sending the Message
description: CULLOWHEE, N. C., Feb. 26What governor of what state has overseen state expenditures that have grown by 356.9 percent while Federal Government outlays were going up only 176.7 percent? What governor in the same period has expanded his state's bureaucracy by 113.3 percent while the Federal bureaucracy was growing by only 17.1 percent? George Wallace of Alabama, that's who, in the period 1962 to 1974.

title: 2 Americans Freed In Lebanon Rejoin Families in Greece
description: ATHENS, Feb. 26 (AP)Two United States officials held four months by kidnappers in Lebbanon in 4by9foot cells, and fed only bread, rice, eggs, yogurt and cheese, today feasted on smoked salmon, veal, red wine and champagne as they were flown to Athens.

title: Nyquist Warns City University Against Reduction of Semester
description: ALBANY. Feb. 26The Senate Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, today warned the City University that reducing class time by two weeks to save money this spring would jeopardize the value of any academic credits awarded during the shortened term.

title: Canadian Edition of Time Plans Cutbacks Because of Ottawa Bill
News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Ouster Move Against Mrs. Peron Fails
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26An effort to bring a vote of impeachment against President Isabel Martinez de Pern failed in Congress early today as Peronist forces closed ranks against the opposition.

title: CUNY's Future
description: Should taxes support public higher education? The New York electorate thought so in 1847, when it used to be consulted about such things. At that time there were no universities in the United States, only colleges; New York wanted for its own citizens an education as complete as could be bought anywhere.

title: Candidates Vie For Free Media
Marti's 66 Is Best Score Before Rain Suspends Golf
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 26 Fred Marti, a personable 35yearold Texan who has not won a tournament in his 13 years on the pro tour, waded over a rainsoaked golf course today and shot 31,3566 on the opening day of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: Youth Who Slew Student In IRT Gets a Life Term
description: An 18yearold youth who pleaded guilty to knifing a graduate student to death on a subway train last year was sentenced to the minimum term in prison yesterday after the victim's parents had asked the presiding judge not to he harsh.

title: Patman Has Pneumonia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, the 82yearold senior member of Congress, is seriously ill, his office said today. An aide said Mr. Patman went into Bethesda Naval Hospital on Tuesday for treatment of what proved to be pneumonia.

title: ANACONDA SUPPORTS TENNECO MERGER
description: The Anaconda Company yesterday mailed letters to stockholders urging them to approve the proposed merger of their company into Tenneco Inc., through a previously announced exchange of stock.

title: Stellar Playing Adds to Drama, Shifts Balance
description: For a big star, taking over another man's role has certain risks to it. Of course, it has been done beforeremember that golden succession of Dollies in Hello, Dolly! culminating in Ethel Mermanyet for all that, it is possible that Richard Burton's assumption of the role of the psychiatrist Martin Dysart in Peter Shaffer's Equus is the most remarkable.

title: U.S. Traffic Safety Chief Quits As a Decision on Air Bags Nears
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 James B. Gregory, head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, has abruptly resigned, just before his scheduled appearance before a House hearing on the Automobile air bag.

title: Ashe Vanquishes Smith In 2 Sets at Rotterdam
GasLine Fire Under Control
description: WHITHARRAL, Tex., Feb, 26 (AP)Firefighters brought under control today a blaze near the site of a gasline fire and explosion that killed one person and critically injured four others near this West Texas community. A spokesman for MidAmerican Pipeline Company, the line's owner, said that a ninemile section had beef shut off.

title: TV Review

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader, was born in New York City and spent the first years of his life in Greenwich Village, where his father was a porter at the old Van Renssalaer Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

title: Marion Javits Issue Focuses Unwelcome Spotlight on Publicizing of Foreign Clients
Issue of Western Sahara Causes a Rift at African Talks
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 26African foreign ministers, who began a weeklong meeting here with a show of unity over Angola, are now struggling with a series of divisive and potentially explosive issues.

title: HENRY KOCH DEAD
