description: George Ball, a senior partner of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that the only realistic way to halt the payment of overseas bribes by American corporations was for the United States Government to impose as strict a standard of conduct abroad as that required at home.

title: Senators From Hinterlands Recall Early Years in City
Dr. Eric J. Hewitt, 70, Chemist and Researcher
description: Dr. Eric J. Hewitt, former vice president and director of research for the Evans Research and Development Corporation, and former consultant to the Research Corporation, a science advancement foundation, died yesterday in Stamford, Conn. He was 70 years old and lived in Westerlev. R.I.

title: Harrises Assail Articles On Miss Hearst and Them
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (UPI) William and Emily Harris said today that reports about them and Patricia Hearst in Rolling Stone magazine were fabrication and lies.

title: NEW LISBON PACT TO BRING AN END TO MILITARY RULE
description: LISBON, Feb. 26Leaders of Portugal's armed forces and the five main political parties signed an agreement today to end military rule and establish a democratic system.

title: Train Asks Stiff Toxic Chemical Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, strongly urged Congress today to approve effective toxic substances legislation in this session.

title: Big Board Seat Prices Increased From Feb.18
description: Responding to the heavy volume of trading, the New York Stock Exchange reported three seat sales yesterday, one at $85,000 and another at $88,000 and a third at $95,000up sharply from the $75,000 in the last sale on Feb. 18.

title: Ford Food Stamp Plan Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Agriculture Department officials proposed today a sweeping set of food stamp reforms that would force 5 million people out of the program and save taxpayers $1.2 billion.

title: Controversial Reporter
description: Daniel Schorr, the CBS newsman who gave a House intelligence report to a newspaper and thus touched off aCongressional investigation that began this week, is a toughminded reporter who has %been raising troublesome and, to some, embarrassing questions since he started his journalistic career. This has made him the center of more than one controversy with Government officials and his employers.

title: Average Stalled at 996 for Third Day
description: The stock market registered its biggest drop of this year yesterday after bluechip issues stumbled during their assault on the psychologically critical 1,000 mark in the, Dow Jones industrial average.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: INSIDE STORY Cave Henry IV (PL 56566), where Charles Albert presides at the keyboard five nights a week, has several things going for it, starting with privacy. The restaurant's facade, at 227 East 50th Street, directly opposite the bright, midblock street light between Second and Third Avenues, has a cloistered, medieval look about it. But several steps down, below sidewalk level and past an iron railing, the wooden door with its yellow fleur de Its yields a surprise.

title: The Latins and the U.S.
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 25Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's recent tour through six Latin American countries has dramatized a new element in an often troubled relationship: the increasing role of Congress in the making and execution of United States policy.

title: Judge Orders Cohn To Repay $219,000
description: Roy M. Cohn and his law firm were ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to pay $219,000 with interest to replace funds that were allegedly spent improperly in violation of an agreement to preserve the assets of a company in a stockfraud case.

title: Students and Officials Protest Proposed End of City U. Colleges
City Opera
description: The New York City Opera's production of Die Meistersinger, which gave a welcome new dimension to Wagnerian tradition here when it was new last fall, did nothing to advance understanding of its modestly proportioned, Englishlanguage version in the spring season's third performance Wednesday night.

title: 2 Olympians Win Downhill Skiing
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo., Feb. 26 (AP)Greg Jones of Lake Tahoe, Calif., and Susie Patterson of Sun Valley, Idaho, both Olympians, captured downhill victories today at the United States national alpine ski championships.

title: Community Boards Assured by Beame Of No Fund Cut off
President Seeks $1 Billion As Energy Fund for States
New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph Kallinger was moved to Bergen County yesterday from Huntingdon State Prison in Huntingdon, Pa., to face trial on murder and other charges. Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., Bergen County Prosecutor, said he would be arraigned in Hackensack today. Mr. Kallinger was sentenced in Harrisburg, Pa., Dec. 18 to 30 to 80 years in prison for robbing four suburban Harrisburg women. The 39yearold Philadelphia cobbler is also accused of the murder of Maria Fasching during a break into a house in Leonia on Jan. 8, 1975.

title: Rhodesia Premier Discussing Crisis With British Envoy
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 26 (Reuters)The British, special envoy, Lord Greenhill, met with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tonight for exploratory talks on the Rhodesian constitutional crisis.

title: Comparison of Loan Rates
SCOTTI ASKS COURT TO DROP ALL CASES ON ATTICA BUT ONE
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 26The special Attica prosecutor requested today that all but one of the remaining indictments stemming from the 1971 uprising at the state prison be dismissed in the interests of justice.

title: Boston Doctor Who Got Death Threat Is Worried, but Still Walks the Streets
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26Dr. Louis F. Alfano, the obstetrician who is president of the Massachusetts Medical Society, received a death threat early last month.

title: Deliberate' Slayings On Increase Here
CITY WEIGHS ENDING OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: City City officials are considering a plan to withdraw city employees from the Federal Social Security system, in an effort to save an estimated $200 million a year, a City Hall aide confirmed last night.

title: Union Endorses Jackson
description: The executive council of the 120,000member International Longshoremen's Association has unanimously endorsed the Presidential bid of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, who is a candidate for the Democratic nomination. United Press International reported yesterday. A union spokesman said that the endorsement was voted Wednesday at the I.L.A.'s quarterly meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: F.B.I. Reported to Have Halted Efforts To Detect Foreign Undercover Agents
Subpoenas Ineffective Here
description: Special to The New York Times

title: U Conn. 99, N. Hampshire 54
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP)The University of Connecticut put together, scoring strings of 8, 7, 12, and 7 points and built a 3424 halftime advantage into a 9954 rout of New Hampshire tonight.

title: Article 2  No Title
Carter Target of Liberals After New Hampshire Gain
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26The first signs of a stopCarter effort have begun to emerge among liberal Democrats as a result of Jimmy Carter's triumph in the New Hampshire Presidential primary two days ago.

title: Editorial Article 1  No Title
J.S. LOVE CHARGED IN COMMODITY CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Commodities Futures Trading. Commission charged today that J. S. Love and Associates Options Ltd. had violated antifraud and investment advisory laws in its business of selling options on London commodity contracts to investors in the United States.

title: DOROTHY T. STANFORD
description: Dorothy Taylor stanford, former wife of Alfred Stanford, a vice president of the nowdefunct New York Herald, Tribune, and mother of Peter Stanford, president of the South Street Seaport Museum, died Monday in Essex, Conn. She was 75 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)The Senate approved a $2.026 billion appropriation today for reorganizing seven financially ailing Northeastern and Midwestern railroads into a single, Governmentsupported railway system. The Senate sent the appropriation bill to a conference committee to resolve its differences with a Housepassed measure specifying the same amount of money but other ways of parceling it out.

title: U.K.'s Austerity Plan
description: The fouryear austerity program introduced by Britain's Labor Government is based on the American axiom, There is no such thing as a free lunch. Three decades of a cradletograve welfare state have exhausted the taxpaying capability of wealthy Britons and have imposed such tax burdens on lower income groups that it is sometimes more advantageous to stay home and collect unemployment insurance than to work and pay taxes.

title: Ceausescu Again Rejects Moscow Line
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26  The Rumanian Communist Party leader called today for a new unity of Communist parties that would allow each party to freely develop its own political course.

title: About New York
How Troop Deployment Was Faked for Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Johnson stood hand over heart and tearyeyed at Pope Air Force Base in North Carolina on Feb. 17, 1968, watching what he thought was a planeload of gungho paratroopers taking off for Vietnam.

title: Excited About Equus Role as Psychiatrist
description: Outside the Plymouth Theater, where Richard Burton is now starring in Equus, young women were impatiently waiting, clamoring for a postmatinee glimpse of the actor. Backstage, in Mr. Burton's dressing room, there was a message written on a mirror with an eyebrow pencil: You are fantastic, love. There was no signature, but, said Mr. Burton, the message was from his estranged wife, Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Need for Toxic Control
description: The Kepone disaster at Hopewell in Virginia, now painfully documented, points up the drastic need for Government action to arrest the danger of a chemically poisoned environment. Kepone is the chemical compound that has so far hospitalized thirty persons, most of them workers in a small plant that manufactured the product on behalf of the Allied Chemical Corporation, and the rest their wives and children. All the victims suffer in one degree or another from tremors, blurred vision, failing memory and the alltooreal threat of liver cancer, sterility or both.

title: Bridge
description: The Greater New York sectional championships, the first tournament of the year in New York City, begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: ALFRED G. STOUGHTON
description: Alfred G. Stoughton, whop retired in 1969 as an information specialist for the United States Public Health Service, died Monday in Northampton, Mass., where he lived. He was 72 years old.

title: Music
description: The Orford String Quartet, one of Canada's finer exports, played an arresting Canadian work at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. The choice program also included Haydn's Quartet in F minor (Op. 20, No. 5) and Ravel's Quartet in F.

title: Mr. Cunningham's Choice
description: Governor Carey expressed an Impatience that is widely shared when he suggested that Patrick J. Cunningham must either clear himself of corruption charges or step down as chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

title: Jury Considers 7 Fraud Counts Involving Cahn Expense Reports
description: A jury of seven men and five women began deliberating the fate of William Calm, former District Attorney of Nassau County, at 4 P.M. yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Levitt Says Albany No Longer Will Aid Yonkers on Default
description: YONKERS, Feb. 26State Comptroller Arthur Levitt informed Yonkers today that it could no longer rely on the state to save it from default.

title: SADAT GETS VOW BY SAUDIS ON AID
description: CAIRO, Feb. 26Saudi Arabia has promised Egypt an immediate grant of $300 million and has reportedly agreed to join other oilproducing Arab countries in a collective program of assistance to the Egyptian Government.

title: Tiffany in a Tiff Over Touch of Class
description: A tempest has been brewing in a sterling silver teapot since Tiffany & Company decided to observe Lincoln's birthday.

title: USERY DENIES WAGES INCREASE INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 26 (UPI) W. J. Usery Jr. Secretary of Labor, told Congress today that labor was catching up with inflation, not causing it.

title: Marlboro Mayor Asks State Protection Against Violent Escaped Mental Patients
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, Feb. 26Mayor Arthur Goldzweig asked Governor Byrne today to declare a state of emergency at the state psychiatric center here, because of growing community concern over the number of escapes by violent patients.

title: Young &
description: About seven months ago Holiday Inns approached Young & Rubicam and asked it to handle a special project. create sonic advertising. The agency came up with The best surprise is no surprise campaign that's now appearing.

title: Suit to Bar Stamp Denies Bell Invented Telephone
description: A suit was filed yesterday seeking to prevent the United States Postal. Service from issuing a commemorative stamp honoring Alexander Graham Bell as the inventor of the telephone.

title: Ford Ends Hooper Backing
Pfizer Raises Its Dividend
description: Directors of Pfizer Inc. raised the quarterly dividend to 21 cents from 19 cents a share, payable March 26 to shareholders of record March 8. The board said it intended to discontinue paying yearend extra dividends effective in 1976. Last year shareholders received four quarterly dividends of 19 cents each and a 5cents extra in December.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 26A comparison of the most common loan rate charged to borrowers on consumer type loans made during the months of November 1974 and November 1975:

Ford Victory Discounted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Ford eked out a narrow victory in New Hampshire because loyal Republicans respected his office rather than his position on issues, Ronald Reagan's campaign manager said today.

title: HOUSE TO STUDY BANK OVERSEEING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) A House Government Operations subcommittee voted today to investigate Federal supervision of the nation's 60 largest commercial banks.

title: Mankiewicz Will Seek Gude's Seat in House
About Real Estate
description: In the Queens community of Rosedale a builder put up 44 townhouse condominiums nine years ago. One of the buyers was Sheldon Katz, a hairdresser in Brooklyn.

title: Sales and Net at Peak For Macy and Esmark
GROWTH PICKS UP IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The growth in the nation's money supply continued to accelerate, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

title: Aquarium Reports Eggs Laid by Chain Dogfish
description: The New York Aquarium at Coney Island yesterday reported that one of its 2footlong members of the shark family, a chain dogfish, had laid two eggs.

title: F.T.C. Investigating Role of Physicians Within Blue Shield
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission announced today an investigation of the Blue Shield medical insurance program to look for what commission sources described as possible conflicts of interest by doctors involved with its operation.

title: 51% Share of North Sea Concessions Won by Britain From 2 Oil Companies
description: The British Government achieved a longsought breakthrough yesterday with an announcement in Parliament that the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Continental Oil Company had agreed to let the Government have 51 percent ownership of their oil concessions in the North Sea.

title: Consumer Loans Found Less Costly Outside City

description: Joseph Weil, whose nickname can be traced to the Outcault comicstrip character of the 1890's, told in his 1948 autobiography of tricking the wealthy who wanted something for nothing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne said that the question whether the BritishFrench Concorde supersonic airliner should be allowed to land at Kennedy Airport should be left to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the field. He said at a news conference in Trenton that he had talked with Governor Carey about abill passed by the New York Legislature aimed at barring the Concorde, and that Mr. Carey believed the bill did not appear to be very effective.

title: First Puritani Since 1918 Electrifies Met Audience
Business Comes To Aid of P.S.A.L.
description: Efforts to restore funds to the Public Schools Athletic League took a giant step forward yesterday when the Bristol  Myers Company announced it would begin an eightweek assistance campaign in city high schools.

title: Morgan Parker, Invented Disposable Medical Scalpel
description: Morgan Parker, retired board chairman of Becton, Dickinson & Company, manufacturer of medical, laboratory and industrialsafety products, died Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Katonah. N. Y.

title: Met Boheme March 27
description: Puccini's La Boberne will be given for the only time this season by the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, March 27, in a special nonsubscription performance. The cast will be headed by Montserrat Caballe as Mimi and Luciano Pavarotti as Rodolfo. Tickets, $6 to $20, are available by mall order or beginning Sunday at noon, at the box, office.

description: Albion's Fatal Tree: Crime and Society in Eighteenth Century] England, by E. P. Thompson, Douglas Hay, Peter Linebaugh, John C. Rule, Calvin Winslow (Pantheon Books, $15; paperbound, $5.95).

title: Kissinger Rules Out a Halt In Testing of Cruise Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today rejected a call for the United States to declare a moratorium on the testing of the strategic cruise missile, a weapon of pinpoint accuracy that is the focus of negotiations on a new AmericanSoviet strategicarms agreement.

title: Reagan's Predicted Margin of Victory in Florida Revised Downward by Manager
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26The manager of Ronald Reagan's campaign in Florida revised downward today his estimate of how well the former California Governor would do in the state's primary March 9.

description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurer, plans to invest about $4.4 billion this year in bonds, mortgages and real estate for its general portfolio, a sharp increase from the $2.6 billion invested last year, the company announced here yesterday.

title: Decision Avoids Defying Order of MacPhail
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)Bill Veeck, defying the spirit but not the letter of American League directives, announced today that the Chicago White Sox would open spring training for 25 nonroster ballplayers next Monday.

title: Soviet Bureaucracy Stumbles Sometimes, Congress Is Told
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26Tucked among the highsounding slogans of selfcongratulation that dominate the speeches at the 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress are some juicy giblets of selfcriticism that reveal the powerful Communist Party as a sometimes stumbling bureaucracy.

title: Traffic Ticket Protested By 300 Hasidic Jews
description: Three hundred Hasidic Jews from the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn converged on a police station on the Lower East Side last night and for several hours protested the issuance of a ticket to the driver of an emergency vehicle serving the Hasidic community, the police reported.

title: NEW LISBON PACT TO BRING AN END TO MILITARY RULE
description: LISBON, Feb. 26Leaders of Portugal's armed forces and the five main political parties signed an agreement today to end military rule and establish a democratic system.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26A second defense psychiatrist testified today that he believed Patricia Hearst's statement that she participated in the robbery of the Sunset branch of the Hibernia. bank here because she feared she would be killed if she did not.

description: So baseball's spring training season opens on time, after allif not for Catfish Hunter and Andy Messersmith, then for M. Donald Grant's old buddy, Cleon Jones, for Bob Oliver, late of the New York Yankees, for five others who have sunk their fangs in majorleague sirloins at one time or another, and for 18 itinerant laborers on Chicago White Sox farms. Love and Bill Veeck, it seems, laugh at locksmiths, although Veeck isn't laughing as heartily as he would like. Having sunk $10 million of his own and friends money into purchase of Chicago's

title: Dividend Up 2c
BEAME ASSURES BOARDS OF FUNDS
description: The Beame administration, overruling officials of its Budget Bureau, assured the city's 62 community boards yesterday that their annual financing of $15,000 would not be cut off, as had been threatened earlier in the week.

title: North to Have 8Seat Edge In New Vietnam Assembly
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam. Feb., 26 (Agence FrancePresse) The constituent national assembly, which is to be elected) for the whole of Vietnam on April 25, will have 488 seats, it was officially announced here yesterday.

description: The listed option market, always a haven for the speculator, is enjoying a resurgence of popularity now that underlying stock prices are climbing sharply.

title: ALABAMA SLAYING LAID TO KLANSMEN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.. Feb. 26 A former Ku Klux Klansman testified today that he, along with three fellow members of the organization. ahudcted a young black man in 1957 and forced him to jump to his death from a bridge over the Alabama River.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
Indiana Clinches Big Ten
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 26 (UPI)Scott May made up for cold shooting by his Indiana teammates with a seasonhigh 41 points tonight and led the topranked, unbeaten Hoosiers to a 9667 victory over Wisconsin, clinching the Big Ten Conference basketball championship.

title: Increase Noted in Permanently Disabled Who Seek Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The number of Americans who are classified as permanently disabled and who receive disability benefits is increasing, but Federal officials and private insurance companies are not quite sure why.

title: SCOTTI ASKS COURT TO DROP ALL CASES ON ATTICA BUT ONE
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 26The special Attica prosecutor requested today that all but one of the remaining indictments stemming from the 1971 uprising at the state prison be dismissed in the interests of justice.

title: Bridge:

title: People and Business

Lauterbach, now chairman and president, will continue as chairman, chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee.

title: Surrogate's Court Official Seeks Quashing of a Nadjari Subpoena
American Marianas
description: Congress acquiesced this week in the first outright territorial annexation by the United States in a half century. Though many constitutional and legal questions must be resolved before the 14,500 inhabitants of the northern Mariana Islands actually become American citizens, there may be no further occasion for Congressional participation in this dubious political evolution.

title: UMass. 81, Providence 79
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)Mike Pyatt drove in for a gametying layup with 11 seconds left in regulation time and scored the goahead basket with 2:06 remaining in overtime tonight, lifting Massachusetts to an 8179 victory over Providence.

title: SPAIN ENDS RULE OF WEST SAHARA
Bayi Hopes to Run 4Minute Mile Tonight
description: Every year the Amateur Athletic Union runs its track and field meet, advertised as the United States indoor championships. This year two of the individual favorites come from those great. states of Tanzania and PolandFilbert Bayi, a miler, and Wlndyslaw Kozakiewiez. pole vaulter. Yesterday both men discussed today's meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: Byrne Bars Paying Fees of Bank Suing The Port Authority
Posters in Peking Attack Teng By Name for the First Time
description: PEKING, Friday, Feb. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping was publicly attacked by name for the first time today in the campaign against rightists in China.

title: Four Record Executives Convicted in Payola Case
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26 (UPI)Four executives of the Brunswick Record Corporation were convicted today on payola charges involving underthe table sales of more than $350,000 in record albums. Two codefendants were acquitted.

title: ITALY SEEKING LOAN FROM WEST GERMANY
description: Italy, which has been under pressure on the foreign exchange markets, is seeking a loan of $500 million from the West German Bundesbank, according to reports circuIating in Rome yesterday.

title: Concert: James Levine
description: With James Levine in charge of the New York Philharmonic, last night's program went from Weber to Berg to Mahler. The Berg was the Three Orchestral Pieces (Op. 6). Ten years ago or so, when the Second Viennese School (Schoenberg, Berg, Webern) were very much in the limelight, scores like this were being brought to the public. Leonard Bernstein conducted the Three Orchestral Pieces 10 years ago. But now that the furor has died down, the Berg and equivalent works seem to be slipping from the repertory.

title: Pentagon Urging Missiles To Counter Soviet Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) The Pentagon's research chief, Malcolm Currie, said today that the United States must develop highly accurate missiles to be able to knock out heavily protected Soviet industrial plants and command centers.

title: CITY SEEKS REPEAL OF CURB ON RENTS
SHOP TALK
CRIMINAL RECORDS WILL BE EXPUNGED
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26An estimated total of 370,000 state residents 76 years old and older who have criminal records on file with the state will have those records purged if they have not been convicted of a crime in the past six years or are not now in prison or on probation.

title: Consumer Loans Found Less Costly Outside City
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26New York City consumers can find substantial savings on loans for such items as automobiles and appliances in New Jersey and Westchester County, according to a report on 10 metropolitan areas and the State of California by a House subcommittee.

description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla., Feb. 25Betty Ford is in Florida this week for her first extended trip without her husband since the beginning of the Presidential campaign.

title: Disaster
description: WASHINGTONFour years ago in a mountain hollow in Logan County, W. Va., The Pittston Company's massive refusepile  dam collapsed without warning to the people in the long, narrow Buffalo Creek Valley below. This failure unleashed over 130 million gallons of water and coalwaste materials. A 20to30 foot wave of rampaging water and sludge, sometimes traveling at speeds up to 30 miles per hour, devastated Buffalo Creek's 16 small towns, killed over 125 men, women and children, and left over 4,000 survivors homeless.

title: Mutual Funds' Assets Rose In January Money Markets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Assets of mutual funds investing in the money markets increased by $56.6 million in January, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF WHEAT DECLINE
Prof. Leland H. Jenks, 83, Wellesley Economist, Dies
description: Leland H. Jenks, who retired in 1957 as professor of sociology and economics at Wellesley College, died Saturday in Wellesley, Mass., where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: Rusty Staub became the first player in the history of the Detroit Tigers to gain a multiyear contract when he signed yesterday for three years at a reported $140,000 a season. Staub, 31 years old, was traded by the Mets to the Tigers after the 1975 season for Mickey Lolich after spending four years with the New York club. The lefthanded hitting outfielder batted .282, with 19 home runs and 105 runs batted in last season.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Profit taking and an absence of bullish economic news depressed prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market.

title: Russians in Contact With U.S. Officials To Buy More Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Agriculture Department officials said tonight that the Soviet Union's grainbuying officers had been in contact with United States officials recntly about buying more wheat and corn from the bumper 1975 crops.

description: For a series of visits to Laurent, a hautecuisine, hauteservice and rather hautepriced restaurant now entering its 26th year at 111 East 56th Street, I had my best suit pressed and took the pseudonym Harold Ruhowsky as being suggestive. somehow, of eminence either in the arts an orchestra conductor, perhaps?) or in the mysterious world of finance. It worked fine until the last visit, when the management spotted the imposture and welcomed me as a restaurant reporter.

title: Reaction to Eastchester Teacher Strike Interpreted as Sign of Taxpayer Revolt
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 26An angry meeting between striking school teachers and parents in this strifetorn community last night demonstrated what educators have been saying for some time: that a suburban taxpayer revolt is in progress.

title: GEORGE L. WATSON, CIVIL ENGINEER, 91
description: George L. Watson, a retired civil engineer who was a consultant to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on the construction of the Lincoln Tunnel, the George Washington Bridge and the Bayonne Bridge, linking Bayonne, N.J. and Staten Island, died Wednesday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 91 years old and lived in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
FRANK HUBBARD, 55, MADE HARPSICHORDS
description: Frank Hubbard, a leading maker and restorer of harpsichords, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Newton, Mass. He was 55 years old and lived in Waltham, Mass.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 26Representative Robert L. Leggett, Democrat of California today asked Attorney General Edward H. Levi to start an investigation to determine who in the Justice Department had leaked information to news organizat:cns that Mr. Leggett and Representative Joseph Addabbo, Democrat of Queens. were being investigated on charges of having accepted bribes from the South Korean Government.

title: TV: Presidential Forums Are Offered in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26What would it take to induce the voting and viewing public to focus on condidacies for the Presidency for longer than the 30 seconds of the typical television spot or the minute or two normally devoted to individual candidates in the course of the evening newscasts?

SADAT SAYS POLICY OF KISSINGER IS DEAD
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Feb. 27 (UPI)  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's stepbystep Middle East peace policy was dead. He urged an early reconvening of the Geneva peace conference with Palestinian participation as the only way to settle the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Talks to Begin to Avert A Bus Strike in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Feb. 27Negotiations between the Amalgamated Transit Union, division 819, and Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company, will begin tomorrow and continue throughout the weekend in an effort to avert a strike scheduled for 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: Leader of a Socialist Party Shot and Killed in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Feb. 28 (Reuters)A Thai Socialist leader was shot and killed early today in what appeared to be part of a growing leftright political conflict.

description: The American Stock Exchange, which has been in deep slumber for more than two years, has awakened with ebullience.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 27The Assembly majority leader, Albert H. Blumenthal, said today he would insist on retaining some rentincreasing restrictions in governmentfinanced housing in New York City, should the city or state governments sell their mortgages on the projects to private investors.

title: U.S. Court Rejects Petition By Du Pont on Christiana Bid
description: The Du Pont Company announcd yesterday that the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Eighth District in St. Louis had rejected petitions for a rehearing on terms of the proposed merger of Christiana Securities Company into Du Pont. A Du Pont spokesman said the company planned to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court.

title: U.S. BACKS AWARD FOR CHRISCRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  ChrisCraft Industries Inc. appears to be a step closer to collecting more than $36 million in damages and interest from a suit it began over a tender offer in 1969.

description: Jeanne Fox Winarick, vice president of Winward House, antiques dealers, died of cancer Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived in IrvingtononHudson, N. Y.

title: ITALIAN RED TAKES INDEPENDENT LINE AT SOVIET PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27The widening rift between Moscow and recalcitrant Western European Communists was dramatized today as the head of the Italian Communist Party used the forum of the 25th Soviet party congress to spell out the political views that have provoked growing displeasure from the Kremlin.

title: Tomorrow in Oklahoma Is Prayer Day for Rain
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 27 (AP)Sunday has been proclaimed a Day of Prayer for Rain in Oklahoma by Lieut. Gov. George Nigh, acting in the absence of Gov. David Boren. The day will coincide with similar days proclaimed by mayors of several western Oklahoma cities.

Bright Shirts, Fine Music And Netherlands Flair
description: The Netherlands Wind Ensemble is a young group20 men, whose average age is 32and wants you to know it. For some years the ensemble has been recognized as one of the finest organizations of its windy type, but musical quality alone does not always mean success in the concert business. So the Netherlanders work assiduously at projecting a brash, antitraditional image, starting off by corning out in satiny shirts in such hues as heliotrope, bloodshoteye red and RollsRoyce silver.

title: Urban Dog Population Is a Rising Problem

description: Dr. Arthur C. Cole, professor emeritus of history at Brooklyn College, died Thursday in Naples, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: This could be regarded as the book about the American Revolution that the general reader has been awaiting, for it brings together in a totality the whole Revolution and its necessary antecedents since early Colonial days. Everything about the book is spacious and on a grand scale. The dominant theme itself is grandthat the Revolution was the movement of a whole people, who, as a result of their victory, came to regard themselves as Americans, a people apart from others in the world.

title: People in Sports
description: Lou Holtz, the new head coach of the Jets. increased his coaching staff to five yesterday with the addition of Jerry Kirk and Burley Crowe.

title: Miss Evert Gains
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI)  Chris Evert and Rosie Casals won quarterfinal matches tonight in the $75,000 Sarasota stop on the Virginia Slims tour. Miss Evert, secondseeded, beat Carrie Meyer, 61, 36, 60, and Miss Casals defeated Mona Gurrant, 57, 76, 60.

description: The recent rise in demand for larger cars was called a temporary resurgence yesterday by Gerald C. Meyers, executive vice president of the American Motors CorPoration.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the F.B.I. had not curtailed its efforts to identify and track down hostile undercover intelligence agents operating in this country.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27President Ford is expected to name Thomas S. Gates Jr., a banker and former Secretary of Defense, as the next chief of the United State liaison office in China.

description: Elizabeth Keen has turned a sharp and witty eye on the ballroom dance floor to populate her humorous panorama of whirling couples and bygone mores in Rainbow Tonight. It has something to do with the time of Valentino and the later Lindy Hoppers and lots about the simple impulse that music imparts to receptive bodies. The company presented the work's first performance Thursday night at the Roundabout Stage One in the Dance Umbrella series.

description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1976

title: Mild Quake in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27 (UPDA weak earthquake shook the southern Honshu region in northern Japan early today but caused no casualties or damage. the meteorological agency said. It said the center of the quake was in Miyagi province, some 200 miles northeast of Tokyo.

title: ITALIAN RED TAKES INDEPENDENT LINE AT SOVIET PARLEY
Nixon Trip: Peking's Purpose Seems Clear
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 27As Richard M. Nixon boarded his plane at Peking yesterday to continue his visit to other parts of China, he turned and jubilantly waved an almost Presidential goodbye to a delegation of senior Chinese officials. The trip, which is to end in Canton on Sunday, has clearly given the former President an opportunity to try to recoup some of the stature he has lost since he visited China four years ago at one of the brightest points of his Administration.

title: Carter Attacks Widened By Massachusetts Rivals
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27Six nights! ago Representative Morris K. Udall flanked by three other major Democratic Presidential candidates  sat on the stage of a New Hampshire high school and said, hope we will have a gentle, civil campaign. His companions seemed to nod, sympathetically.

title: SENATORS VOTE CURB ON FORD'S TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to recommend a tax cut of no more than $20.6 billion in 1977$8.5 billion below what President Ford proposed.

title: U.S. Agency Urges a Drive to Bar Cancer by Screening Chemicals
description: Prevention of cancer througn a greatly expanded effort in screening chemicals for lethal properties was urged as a national priority yesterday by the nation's top environmental agency.

title: JUNE M. BURDINE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27 (UPI)June Marion Burdine, last member of the family that founded Florida's Burdine's department store chain, died yesterday at the age of 50.

title: Dartmouth 61, Columbia 57
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27 (AP)Larry Cubas hit a 20 foot jump shot with 6 seconds left tonight And Adam Sutton tossed in free throws just before the final buzzer that gave Dartmouth a 6157 victory over Columbia.

title: KEY U.S. FIGURES SHOW ECONOMY IS GAINING VIGOR
description: Two key statistics announced yesterday ill Washington indicate that the economic recovery is gaining strength.

title: SYRIANS ABANDON BEIRUT MEDIATION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 27The Syrian mediation team that negotiated a ceasefire in the Lebanese civil war returned to Damascus last night without having reached its goal of bringing about a Lebanese government of national union.

title: In These Liberated Times, Every Day Is Leap Day
description: Besides being the Bicentennial, 1976 is also Leap Year historically a time fraught with romantic promise for unmarried women. This was before The Liberation.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 195.9 from 195.2 last week.

title: Borg Beats Laver In $100,000 Match
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Feb. 27 (AP)  Bjorn Borg, Sweden's 19year old tennis star, defeated Rod Layer, almost twice Borg's age. 64, 62, 75, tonight in a $100,000 winnertakeall match,

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Some Scorn It, But March Leek Is Easy to Love
description: Revered by the ancient Egyptians as a symbol of the universe, yearned for by the Hebrews in their flight through wilderness, and an emblem of virtue to the Romans who carried this upright member of the onion family into Britain, the leek achieved its true apotheosis in Wales.

title: Union Votes to Strike 91 Nursing Homes
Investigation Asked In A.S.P.C.A. Killing Of 9 Dogs in Bronx
description: The actress Gretchen Wyler, a former board member of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, yesterday called upon the City Council or some appropriate authority to investigate the society for permittig the destruction of nine dogs o Feb. 20 within an hour of their arrival at its Bronx shelter. Three employees were later discharged for prematurely killing the animals.

title: Princeton Downs Yale Five, 6853
Marlboro Is Given Promise On StateHospital Security
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, Feb. 27Plans for immediate improvement of security at Marlboro State Hospital to prevent escapes by patients were announced today following a fourhour conference attended by state and local officials.

title: City Plea for Volunteers Stirs Flood of Responses
Hearst Acts Likened to Those of Victims of Chinese
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27A researcher on thought control and political conversion as practiced in China testified today that Patricia Hearst's case history echoed what he had found in his interviews with brainwash victims when they passed through Hong Kong af ter being released by Peking.

title: Music: Romero Guitars
description: The Romeros have been coming to New York more or elss regularly since their debut 14 seasons ago, offering shrewdly devised programs that do not change essentially in content. In this they are undoubtedly wise, for their latest concert here, in Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, was enjoyable. The four guitaristsCeledonio Romero and his sons, Celin, Pepe and Angelperformed as soloists and as a quartet, offering music that effective and varied.

title: Silver Convention Debut Off
description: The American debut of Silver Convention, the Munichbased disco group, scheduled for two shows tonight at the Felt Forum, has been canceled. Ticketholders may obtain refunds at the Felt Forum box office or by mail. A representative for the group's record company said that one of the three women singers, Ramona Wolf. was III. The promoter of the concerts charged fraud, and his lawyer said he was filing a $2 million suit against the group,

title: UTAH MINIBUS USES HYDROGEN FOR FUEL
description: PROVO, Utah, Feb. 27 (AP); A Provo company unveiled today a 19passenger hydrogen powered bus that its developers said would show hydrogen to be one answer to the energy problems.

title: Approaching 1,000 ...
Flamingo Favorite Is Honest Pleasure
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27Judy Hancock, a former rider who now works as an exercise girl for LeRoy Jolley, has had a bird'seye view of Foolish Pleasure and Honest Pleasure this winter. In her opinion, Honest Pleasure may be a better colt than Foolish Pleasure. Honest Pleasure is a pure athlete, Miss Hancock said today. He just goes out there and does everything easy as pie. Foolish Pleasure is great, but you have to make him work at it.

title: Market Place
description: Longtime followers of the Simplicity Pattern Company may think current strength in the leading producer of dress patterns for the homesewing market reflects an earnings turnaround.

title: Judgeship's Loss Laid to Grain Inquiry
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27The extensive investigation of grain industry corruption is partly responsible for depriving the head of the inquiry, United States Attorney Gerald J. Gallinghouse of the Federal judgeship he has long sought, according to political sources.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MANILA, Feb. 27 (AP)  Alfonso Lopez of Panama wrested the World Boxing Association flyweight title tonight from Erbito Salavarria of The Philippines with a technical knockout 33 seconds into the 15th round. Carlos Padilla Jr., the referee, stopped the fight after Salavarria went to his knees in his own corner under a barrage of lefts and rights to the head and body.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday on efforts to block the nomination of former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia, it was incorrectly reported that several editors of The Washington Post attended a dinner party at which there was considerable antiCarter comment, Only one Post editorPhilip Geyelin, editor of the editorial pagewas at the dinner, and Mr. Geyclin said he had not participated in the antiCarter discussion.

title: Wheat Contracts Rise on a Variety Of Bullish News
description: Recovering from Thursday's sharp decline, wheat futures jumped yesterday as much as the 20 centsabushel daily limit in one contract on the Chicago Board of Trade. The March delivery closed at $3.90, up from $3.70.

title: Buckley Says Senate Report On C.I.A. in Chile Is Biased
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Senator James L. Buckley. Conservative  Republican of New York, says that the report on Central Intelligence Agency activities in Chile issued last December by the Senate Intelligence Committee is slanted and biased.

title: EMHART AND USM BACK PACT ON TIE
Prof. Fraser P. Price, 58, Chemist at Massachusetts
description: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)Fraser P. Price, professor of polymer science at the University of Massachusetts, died yesterday after a ski outing. He was 58 years old.

title: Mistrial in Cahn Case
description: A mistrial was declared last night in the case of William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, who had been accused of fraud involving the use of the mails. There will be a retrial. Page 54.

title: Harvard 66, Cornell 63
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Waiting For The Girls
description: When I regularly attended burlesque there was always one comedian equipped with what was called a bladder. This was a balloonlike, airfilled bagit may even have been a bladder, for all I knowwhich he employed to hit straight men, candyandpostcard vendors and the clumsier chorines whenever the show threatened to lag. He invariably wore grotesque baggy trousers from which the bladder would be produced with extravagant flourishes, and the house would break up, or yawn, according to his skills, as he swatted it against skulls, hips and abdomens.

title: SOVIET COMPLEX IS FIRED ON HERE
description: Four shots were fired into the Soviet residential complex in the Riverdale section of the Bronx early yesterday morning, shattering a groundfloor Window. The police said no one had been injured.

title: U.S. Trade Group Cites 24.7% Drop In '75 Steel Imports
SWISS BANKS HIT LOCKHEED STUDY
description: GENEVA, Feb. 27Leading Swiss banks are upset over a Government decision to permit Dutch investigators into the Lockheed bribery scandal to come to Switzerland even though they do not believe that it undermines the law protecting business secrets.

title: SINGERS' SHOWCASE IN CALIFORNIA SOUL
Pistons Defeat Knicks
description: DETROIT, Feb. 27  The Knicks drive to escape the Atlantic Division cellar took a frustrating turn tonight when they lost to the Detroit Pistons. 9793.

title: Nixon Gets a Rousing Welcome In Canton Near End of His Tour
Into the Lion's Den
description: When he was mentioned in 1967 as a possible successor to Leonard Bernstein at the New York Philharmonic, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic declared: My orchestra is better than the New York Philharmonic. . . . Artistically, it would not be a step up for me. And, he was quoted as saying: Why not send our worst enemy to the New York Philharmonic and finish him off, once and for all?

title: Retrospective on Sculpture of Ruth Vollmer
State, in an Economy Move, Abolishes Office of History
AMEX PRICES SLIP ON RATE OUTLOOK
description: Increasing concern over the outlook for interest rates sent prices lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Yale Protest Backs Women as Priests
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27 Students at the Yale Divinity School and faculty members today staged a Eucharistic fast, substituting water for wine in a symbolic gesture to express concern over the inability of Episcopal women to achieve official recognition as priests in their church.

title: FORD SEEKS VOTES OF FLORIDA LATINS
Flu Found Epidemic In 4 Regions of U.S.
description: Influenza has reached epidemic proportions in four regions of the country, but the Federal epidemiologists who analyze flu statistics said yesterday that they did not expect it to develop into a nationwide epidemic this year because the usual seasonal peak had been passed.

title: SelfHelp and Survival
description: Although it has been treated with skepticism by cynics and with scorn by most of the city's labor leaders, Mayor Beame's call for thousands of volunteers to help maintain city services is an important element in New York's fight for survival.

title: HONEYWELL CITES PAYMENTS ABROAD
Strikers Cut Heat and Light At U.N. Building in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb. 27 (Reuters) The United Nations European headquarters building here was without heat or light today for the third day because of a strike by about 2,700 employees.

title: ... No BackOffice Crisis
description: The relative ease with which brokerage and clearing houses have handled these weeks of record trading volume stands in sharp contrast to the scary backoffice crises of the late 1960's. Ordinary investors as well the brokers themselves can heave sighs of relief at the benefits which automation and innovation are bringing to the securities industry.

title: GUSTAV E. HOPPE
description: Gustav E. Hoppe, who retired in 1962 as New York area supervisor of the Western Electric Company after 43 years of service, died Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 76 years old and formerly had lived in Freeport, Li., where he had been a Republican committeeman.

title: WOMEN CALL SHOW AT MODERN SEXIST
description: While a group of women artists (and two mule supporters) picketed outside the Museum of Modern Art yesterday morning, oanne Stamerra, a young woman sculptor, slipped inside the museum and placed pink erasers stencilled Erase Sexism at MAMA at inconspicuous sites.

title: Udall in Boston Visits the Newly Jobless
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27  Back when the ships in Boston Harbor were clippers, the Boston & Lockport Block Company was a respected name in rigging, and it had endured on the same grimy East Boston street for more than a century. Today, a bright new For Sale sign hangs outside; the concern has been bought out, and its 129 employees will be out of work tomorrow.

title: Efrem Cardinal Forni, 87, Dies
description: ROME, Feb. 27Efrem Cardinal Forni, whose long diplomatic career spanned the reign of four Popes, died yesterday, in a Rome hospital, the Vatican; announced today. He was 87 years old.

title: Basketball Coach Quits
description: LIVINGSTON, Ala., Feb. 27 (AP)Gory Elliott, Livingston University basketball coach, has resigned, effective immediately, Athletic Director Jim King said today. No successor has been named.

title: Auction of New Art in SoHo Disappoints
Columbia Still Leads Swimming
description: Columbia utilized its best weapon, Don Spencer, for the second consecutive day, lengthening its lead to 41 points over Fordham in the threeday Metropolitan Collegiate swimming and diving championships yesterday at Columbia's Uris pool.

title: Penn, 96, Brown 75
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP)John Engles triggered an early secondhalf burst tonight that powered Penn to a 9675 victory over Brown.

title: State Seeks a Computer System to Save Welfare Costs
GOING OUT Guide
Race and Sex Factors in Michigan Police Shootout
Severino Wins Twice In P.S.A.L.
Contract Awards
description: The Navy awarded two contracts totaling $295.8 million to Todd Shipyards to build guided missile frigates on a fixed price incentive. Bath Ironworks Inc., a unit of the Congoleum Corporation received a similar contract for $223.8 million.

title: 50 Peddie Students to Go on 28State Tour
description: HIGHTSTOWN  Beginning June 13, 50 students from the Peddie School here will embark on a nineweek journey through 28 states and the District of Columbia as Bicentennial goodwill ambassadors for Governor Byrne and the New Jersey Legislature.

title: Ford Puts Off Speech At California Dinner
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 27 (UPI)President Ford has postponed an appearance at a $1,000aplate Republican fundraising dinner here next month so he can devote more time to campaigning in the Florida and Illinois primaries.

title: The Oarsman Who Never Missed Practice
description: On the small dock near the Columbia University boathouse, faraway noises intruded on the stillness. From inside the big nylon bubbles came the hollow thwacks of students playing tennis. Over in Inwood Hill Park, an old man yelled, Blackie, get over here, at an unleashed dog running on the grass. Out on the Spuyten Duyvil, sea gulls squawked. Across the water, under a huge light blue C painted on the sheer cliff supporting a Riverdale apartment house, a Penn Central train clanked toward the Marble Hill station. But at the dock, four empty launches floated silently. The boathouse was padlocked. The old building with offices and locker rooms, its bricks painted white and its doors and windows light blue, appeared deserted. And out around the bend below Baker Field, close to the other shore, divers in frogmen suits slipped quietly in and out of the murky gray water from a dark blue police launch and tried to find Steven Abbey's body. Yesterday the police abandoned the search after five days. And today sonic of the Columbia crews will resume rowing on the Spuyten Duyvil, where 19yearold Steven Abbey drowned last Monday morning when the lightweight crew's shell was swamped,

title: Warren Beatty Weighing a Race As HumphreyKennedy StandIn
Draft Boards Are Shut First Time Since 1947
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)The last of the nation's military draft boards shut down today, completing the first nationwide closing since 1947.

title: Bayi Takes A.A.U. Mile in 3:56.1 at Garden
description: Filbert Bayi is a cautious speaker, if not a deceiving one. The other day he said he would try his best to break four minutes in the onemile run at the Amateur Athletic Union national championship track meet at the Garden. But he didn't promise.

title: Rhodesia Calls Charges of Massacre Ridiculous
CONFLICT DENIED BY SAFETY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 James B. Gregory, National Highways Traffic Safety administrator, said today that his resignation was unrelated to a forthcoming decision on whether to require air bags on all new automobiles.

title: Margaret Ely Has Nuptials
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Watertown, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Samman Ely of Watertown to Paul M. Winship of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Jeffrey L. Kittridge performed the ceremony.

title: Life on End of a Leash Isn't Bad
description: They always say the city is no place for a dog. It's a shame, they say, scowling and shaking their heads. Keeping a fine dog like that cooped up in the city! Isn't it a shame?

title: REPUBLICANS FACE FIGHT OVER RULES
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 27A new fight appeared to be looming today within the Republican Party over its rules for broadening the participation of women, young people and ethnic minorities.

title: Costa RicaCuba Trade Deal
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 27 (Reuters)Costa Rica has resumed trade with Cuba with the sale of 4,000 tons of beans for $2 mililon, the Export Promotion Center announced today. It was the first commercial deal between the two countries since 1964, when the Organization of American States imposed economic sanctions on Cuba.

title: Shaheen Refinery Seeking Way Out of Finance Maze
Court Tells Grand Jury To Resume Goldman Case
Consumer Notes
description: A supermarket on wheels is scheduled to go into operation next week to serve the elderly poor of Monmouth County.

title: Hua Kuofeng. Really, Not an Enigma.
Colonels Enraged After Loss to Nets
A Tragedy Puts Focus On a Basketball Recruit
Specifics of Player Plan Are Outlined

title: C.I.A. Estimates That Soviet Spent 40% More Than U. S. on Defense in the Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that by one measure the Soviet Union spent 40 percent more than the United State on defense in 1975.

title: Journey To the End Of the Night
description: PARISThe passionate dislike Richard Nixon has engendered among millions of Americans beclouds and confuses their view of his Peking trip. They seemingly forget that the world's greatest political problem is whether China will remain relatively friendly to the United States or, instead, will swing back toward Russia when the postMao succession is settled.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph Kallinger, a Philadelphia shoerepair man accused in a threestate crime spree, pleaded not guilty to an 11count indictment yesterday at the Bergen County Courthouse. Superior Court Judge Morris Malech did not set bail, and Mr. Kallinger was returned to the Bergen County Jail after the 15minute court session. No date was set for preliminary hearing or a trial.

title: Miss Hearst Off Stand, The Crowd Is Thinner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 The hallways outside the courtroom of the Patricia Hearst trial have been calmer the last few days.

title: Eskimos Seek Fifth of Canada as Province
REV. W.K. TRIVETT, FORDHAM PROFESSOR
description: The Rev. William K. Trivett. a Fordham University professor and administrator, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in MurrayWeigel Hall on the Bronx campus, where he lived. He was 62 years old.

title: City Plea for Volunteers Stirs Flood of Responses
description: Responses from New Yorkers eager to offer their services to a city in crisis have swamped the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center in the last three days.

title: Con Edison Gets 5% Rise In Rates, 5th Since 1970
description: The Public Service Commission granted the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday a 5 percent increase in electricity rates, to yield $114.4 million in additional revenues annually.

title: The Screen: 'Inserts':Old Hollywood Evoked in Sex-Movie Story
description: Not yet 30, Boy Wonder (Richard Dreyfuss) is washed up as a Hollywood director. The year is 1930, and Boy Wonder is reportedly finished. Josef von Sternberg has told someone that he saw Boy Wonder panhandling on the Sunset Strip. Boy Wonder is not quite forgotten, though. Someone tells someone else, who tells Boy Wonder, that "that new guy at Pathe, Clark Gable," has said he'd like to work for Boy Wonder, which gives Boy Wonder a laugh. Boy Wonder is now making pornography films in a corner of the living room of his Spanish-style Hollywood mansion."Inserts," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is the story of 99 manic minutes in the life of Boy Wonder, during which a couple of leftovers from silent Hollywoodtechnology's rejectsmeet and, figuratively speaking, rub shoulders with some hustling representatives of the new, talking Hollywood. The arena for confronations is Boy Wonder's living room, which, like Boy Wonder, the film refuses to leave."Inserts," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is essentially a stunt, a slapstick melodrama in the form of a one-act, one-set, five-character play. It is, however, a very clever, smart-mouthed stunt that, in its self - described "degenerate" way, recalls more accurately aspects of old Hollywood than any number of other period films, including "Gable and Lombard." It's not anything that "Inserts" says, but something to do with the dizzy pace, the wisecracks, the lack of sentimentality and, mostly, the characters, who could be shadowy parodies of once-living legends."Inserts" marks the directorial debut of John Byrum, the not-yet-30 screen-writer ("Mahogany," among other things), who, on the basis of this breathless stunt, not only knows how to write but also how to direct, especially when it comes to actors.Mr. Dreyfuss must occasionally make plausible dialogue that's too self-conscious for the movie's good, but he gives a remarkably funny, tough and bristly performance as the Hollywood has been who looks scarcely old enough to vote. His chief adversary, a bootlegger on his way to becoming a Hollywood mogul, is played by an equally young but immensely talented English actor, Bob Hoskins, who suggests at least two real-life moguls that I can think of.Veronica Cartwright, who looks a little like Maggie Smith, plays a former Hollywood star now reduced to drugs and porno-film parts, and Jessica Harper, who had a small but vividly funny role in Woody Allen's "Love and Death," plays a tiny, sweet-looking girl with a ferocious ambition to become an actress in "real movies"and will do anythig to succeed. Stephen Davies, another newcomer, completes the cast as a young man who supplements his earnings as a Forest Lawn gravedigger by acting in Boy Wonder's porno-films, waiting for his star potential to be recognized and made legitimate.Although "Inserts" has been rated X, it is not pornographic itself. It's a beautifully acted, tough-talking comedy that, at its wildest moments, manages to evoke the comedies of the late Joe Orton. It won't warm the heart, but its bleakness is almost buoyant.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Scores of policemen combed a downtown area of Hempstead, L.I., in an unsuccessful earlymorning search for a sniper who fired three wild shots at four officers who were investigating a suspected burglary at the New China Inn. A police spokesman said the shots had come from a nearby apartment building preceded by shouts from a man who had called the four officers pigs. The police seized three unarmed burglary suspects on the roof of the restaurant but they were not believed connected with the sniping.

title: Gates, ExDefense Chief, Likely to Get Peking Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27President Ford is expected to name Thomas S. Gates Jr., a banker and former Secretary of Defense, as the next chief of the United State liaison office in China.

title: Cahn Gets a Mistrial in DoubleBilling Case After Jury Reports Deadlock
description: A mistrial was declared last night in the case of William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, who had been accused of fraud involving the use of the mails.

title: Moscow Microwaves
description: At least the main outlines of what might be called the Case of the Moscow Microwaves have finally emerged. For at least fifteen years the United States Embassy in Moscow has been systematically Irradiated by microwaves generated in equipment installed nearby by Soviet intelligence agencies. The objectives of this bombardment presumably were to eavesdrop on conversations in the embassy and to attempt jamming electronic monitoring equipment installed in and on the embassy. The United States State Department knew about this irradiation and protested from time to time, but the facts were kept secret from both the American public and most of the people In the embassy complex.

title: Carey Is Expected to Lose On Corrections Nominee
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Herman Schwartz. Governor Carey's nominee to head the Commission of Corrections, appears increasingly likely to be the first major gubernatorial nominee in recent memory to be denied Senate confirmation.

title: MORE ATTICA CASES DROPPED BY COURT
description: Three indictments stemming from the 1971 Attica prison riot were dismissed yesterday in Buffalo.

title: Mistrial in Cahn Case
description: A mistrial was declared last night in the case of William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, who had been accused of fraud involving the use of the mails. There will be a retrial. Page 54.

title: In SouthWest Africa the Big Question Is Whether Change Will Come in Time
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Feb. 22  Since the involvement of Cubans and Russians in the Angolan war, the dominant question here has been not whether social and political change will come to this sparsely populated territory administered by South Africa, but how it can be effected before there is armed conflict.

title: PHELPS DODGE CABLE TO RAISE PRICES 5%
description: The Phelps Dodge Cable and Wire Company announced yesterday that it planned to increase prices for all underground residential distribution cables rated 15,000 volts and higher by aproximately 5 percent. The increases, which will become effective on Monday, were said to reflect higher raw material and manufacturing costs. The company is one of seven operating units of Phelps Dodee Industries Inc.

title: COURT REPRIEVES ELECTION PANEL
Cunningham Wins a Stay Of Grand Jury Subpoena
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, won a round yesterday when the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court delayed for at least two weeks his appearance before a special grand jury investigating the possible sale of judgeships in the Bronx.

title: AlgerianAided Sahara Front Proclaims Republic
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 27 (AP)Challenging the division of Westrn Sahara between Morocco and Mauritania, an Algerianbacked guerrilla movement has proclaimed the establishment of a democratic republic in the territory, formerly Spanish Sahara.

title: MULTINATIONALS FOUND TO AID U.S.
description: A crosssection of Americanbased multinational companies showed a greater increase in exports and in employment of American workers between 1970 and 1973 than did manufacturing concerns in general, according to a study just completed by the Business International Corporation.

title: Payment Reported By U.S. in Death Of Aide in Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The husband of a woman who died of cancer after working at the United States Embassy in Moscow sued the United States Government, alleging she was a victim of radiation, and received a settlement, informed sources said today.

title: Posters Directly Attack Chou Deputy
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 27The appearance today of wall posters in Peking that attacked and named Teng Hsiaoping, the Deputy Prime Minister, appears to he a watershed in the political conflict that has swept China over the last month.

title: Sagner Reports End Of the Long Holdup In Highway Program
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27The Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation, Alan Sagner, announced today that snarls that had delayed $180 million worth of highway projects had been surmounted and that many of the projects would he up for contracts earlier than expected.

title: Okker Advances
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 27 (UPI)Torn Okker of the Netherlands moved into the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis tournament today by defeating Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 61, 64.

title: Notes on People
description: Ending a long but dwindling career as a professional hunter of Communists and fellow travelers, J.G. Sourwine retired yesterday, still asserting that we are the No. 1 target of a Communist conspiracy to dominate the world, and that subversion continues in and outside the Government,

title: Hurdles Mark Falls
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 27 (UPI)Dan Lavitt of Raytown, (Mo.), South High turned in an indoor national high school record of 6.9 seconds in the 60yard high hurdles semifinals today at the 48th Big Eight indoor championships.

title: Screen: French Provincial With Jeanne Moreau
description: Jeanne Moreau has a genius for the particular. She could be marched off for execution and her fretful gait, her expression, her silences would argue so strongly against any mere universal application of law that the firing squad would fall apart arguing.

title: Red Dye No. 2: The 20Year Battle
Mass for Frank Stagg
description: A memorial mass for Francis Stagg, an Irish prisoner who died Feb. 12 after a 61day hunger strike in a Yorkshire. England, prison, will be offered tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Carmelite Roman Catholic Church, 329 East 28th Street. Marchers will assemble at the United Nations Plaza and move on to the church in a symbolic funeral procession. Similar memorial services are planned in eight ether United States cities and Toronto.

title: R. C. McDonald Jr. Weds Donna Schnip
description: Donna Rae Schnip, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Irving Schnip of Norwich. Conn.; Warren, Vt., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday evening to Richard Chauncey McDonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonald of Windham Center, Conn., and Hilton Head Island, S.C.

description: Incoming

title: Legal Services Support
Study Predicts Profit in Fusing KLM, Sabena and Luxair Lines
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 27A fusion of the national airlines of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg would create a strong company capable of showing a profit of $75 million by 1980, according to a report by McKinsey & Company, New York management consultants, that was issued here today.

title: Vilas Beats Solomon
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 27 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas defeated Harold Solomon, 62, 63, tonight and Alex Mayer beat Sherwood Stewart, 64, 64, in quarterfinal matches of the WCTRobintech Classic. Roscoe Tanner and Phil Dent, who won earlier, will play in the semifinals tomorrow and Vilas will meet Mayer tomorrow night.

title: How 16 New Rochelle Students Became Francophiles
Australia Trails, 10
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 27 (AP)New Zealand took a 10 lead over Australia in the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final today before failing light caused postponement of the second singles match.

title: BARCELONA STRIKERS BATTLE WITH POLICE
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 27 (Reuters)The police clashed with striking construction workers in the center of Barcelona tonight and fired rubber bullets to stop them from putting up barricades, witnesses reported.

description: CHICAGOThe large, silky haired dog, mostly Afghan hound, galloped wildly along Oak Street, a strand on Chicago's Gold Coast bursting with chic boutiques. Half a block behind, a young couple, yelling as they ran, tried to catch it although the chase was hampered by their clumsy mod shoes.

title: Brig. Gen. William Lee, 72, Taught Eisenhower to Fly
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Feb. 27 (UPI)Brig. Gen. William L. Lee, U.S.A.F., retired, former commander of Amarillo Air Force Base, died here today. He was 72 years old.

title: 10 Airlines Receive C.A.B. Permission To Increase Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to let nine airlines raise their fares In the 48 contiguous states by 2 percent over the next two weeks and said that one carrier may raise fares by 1 percent.

Cunningham Wins a Stay Of Grand Jury Subpoena CUNNINGHAM GETS SUBPOENA DELAY

description: The yearend financial results are in for the three corporate giants whose television networksCBS, NBC and ABCare slugging it out for the attention of the vast American audience. But the results conceal as much as they reveal.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It came as a shock at first to the 178 employees at the Belvidere Mountain Quarry and Mill in Lowell, Vt. Most thought they had jobs for life. Then in February 1974 the GAF Corporation, owner of the asbestos mine, announced that it wo.uld shut down rather than put $1.5 million into federally ordered antipollution equipment.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Early American Coppers, Inc., better known as the Early American Coppers Society, is one of the least formal and yet most seriously scientific and successful of the many specialinterest groups within the hobby. Although its members are principally dedicated to the study of types and varieties of the two early U.S. copper coinsthe large cent and the half cent (both minted from 1793 to (1857)they also delve into Colonial copper coins. All during the year the members of E.A.C. share their knowledge through the pages of their official publication, PennyWise, and through small regional meetings held in conjuction with major numismatic conventions. Once a year, however, they put it all together at their own exclusive convention, and the. 1976 meeting is to open here in New York City next Friday. It will run through Sunday.

title: Georgine's wardrobe is small, choice and elegant. Susan has a wardrobe matched to her student life.
description: she was hired as an assistant fashion editor at Glamour. The job, she says, was making pretty pictures. She left to have three children in four years and then slowly redid an East Side brownstone. These days she's back to pictures as a volunteer guide at the Metropolitan Museum. Her wardrobe is small, choice and elegant.

title: Danes Argue Over Government Order to Raze Free City, an Alleged Haunt of Criminals and Addicts
description: COPENHAGEN. Denmark, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Danish Government is preparing to evict 600 to 700 men, women and children from a sellproclaimed free city in the heart ot Copenhagen.

Dances Presented By Marian Sarach And Bryan Hayes
description: Character vignettes provided Marian Sarach with her most accomplished vehicles. Her innate performing lan with a hint of desperation lurking c about the edge raises these portraits to a fine state of humorous frenzy. She and Bryan Hayes shared a program at Washington Square Methodist Church Friday evening.

title: ...and another word about color
description: Chances are that no matter how clear and glowing her skin is a woman will still want to wear makeup. A little color on the lips and cheeks always helps. while even the brightest eyes can be made more interesting with the proper eye shadow and mascara. And, of course, makeup can be just plain fun, too.

title: Classic Yachts Sought For Parade on July 4
description: Operation Sail, the Bicentennial salute to sail, is looking for classic yachts to join the 18mile parade up the Hudson River July 4. To date, 198 sailing ships, including nearly every seaworthy tall ship in the world, have entered. Now everyone thinks his yacht is a classic but there are stipulations. We are looking for classic, antique or character boats, or boats indigenous to a certain part of the country such as the Chesapeake Bay skipjack, explains Zelda Mueller, ship coordinator.

title: The Ultimate Togetherness: 4 Adults, 3 Children, 1 Car
description: Outside the car window some of Nova Scotia's most magnificent scenery was unfolding. We stared, breathless, stirred to great emotion by the wild beauty around us. Suddenly the silence was broken by a small voice. Laura, it chided reproachfully. you're not being nice to your caterpillar.

title: Poor but Hopeful
description: LONDONBangladesh is not merely poor, it is the poorest of developing countries, but for the first time in its five years of independence there is hope for a better future.

title: The Region
description: The New York State Legislature has voted to prevent landings of the Concorde supersonic jet at Kennedy International Airport, but despite the large no vote (139 to 4 in the Assembly, 46 to 10 in the Senate) it is still not certain if the flights Wilt be banned.

title: On Writing Well
description: An informal guide, says the subtitle. Informal it issmooth, colloquial, seemingly effortless. To writing nonfiction, it goes on to say. Wellthat depends on what you mean by nonfiction. William Zinsser, a veteran of The Herald Tribune and Life and of years of freelancing, is primarily concerned with popular journalism as it is practiced (less and less) in magazines and (more and more) in daily papers. Not the nonfiction of studygroup reports or academic tomes, and not straight news reporting, either. The book grew out of a writing course he now teaches at Yale, so the tone is that of a veteran addressing beginners. But the message can be absorbed with profit by any writer, no matter what his experience or his field.

title: Jackson Pins Hopes on Massachusetts
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb.28Senator Henry M. Jacksonof Washington keeps goingaround telling everybody thathe is going to win the Massa chusetts Democratic Presiden tial primary next Tuesday.

description: Today

title: A Fern That Doesn't Look Like A Fern
description: Staghorn ferns suggest the antlers of en Alaskan moose, rather than a conventional fern. Their mature forked leaves with leathery texture have a graygreen finish softened by a coating of fine hairs. Contrary to common thought, these plant curios can be grown in the home, if given reasonable care.

title: Mental Care Fees Backe?? For Criminal Case Suspects
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 28 (AP)  The New Hampshire Supreme Court has ruled that persons committed to the state mental hospital in criminal cases must pay for their board and care if they have the money

title: No Fume Doesn't ean Don't Get Angry
description: SOME people collect postage stamps, others collect coins. I like to collect languages arid pieces of lantuages. Yes pieces. A language is one of the few things that you can put into OPeration at once, as soon as You have learned a few phrases; nativespealter fluency is desirable, but not al all essential.

title: CLASSIC COLLECTOR
description: Not counting a lavender disaster in the sixth grade, Donna Lang can't remember ever making a big clothe.s mistake. To judge from the crowding in her closet, she still loves every skirt, jacket, top and pair of pants she's bought in the last 12 years. Her wardrobe today includes 15 and a half pairs of brown, gray and tan leather gloves and well over 40 pairs of shoes. She used to have 65 sweaters, hut a few weeks ago she reorganized a cupboard and now there are only 41.

title: Employees To Buy Factory
description: It looks like the sword of Damocles is about to be lifted from our heads, Robert Mitrani, industrialrelations manager for the Okonite Company, said last wek when it appeared that the company's 1,900 employees soon would be able to buy Okonite from its bankrupt parent, Omega Alpha Inc. of Dallas.

title: Two Playwrights Clowning Around
description: John Guare's Rich and Famous (at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Newman Theater) and Israel Horovitz's The Primary English Class (at Circle in the Square Downtown) are both clown plays masquerading as comedies: Instead of moving aggressively, as comedies do, to create a world and convey an attitude toward it, they amble from incident to incident, as if the writers had had no better idea than to create a modest situation as an opportunity for some gifted comic performers to exploit. Since there is not nearly as much clowning on the New York stage as there should be, both plays are welcome, on the principle that a good laugh is always welcome. But neither writer has quite had the power to turn clownery into comedy: Guare's play, about making it in the money world of show biz, is a string of picaresque sketches, and Horovitz's, about bedlam in an Englishforforeigners class, is overextended sketch.
