title: CHESS
description: Attacking when you should be defending, advancing when you should be consolidating or opening a position when your opponent leads in development, is a surefire way to lose.

title: Red No. 2, a food coloring consumed daily by millions of Americans, was tested time and again for safety. Yet now, nearly a century after its introduction, the Government's top regulatory officials have concluded that its safety remains uncertain.
description: It had been a rough few months for Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, as he worried over the controversial color additive Red No. 2. First, the General Accounting Office and Senator Gaylord Nelson charged that his agency had dillydallied for 15 years without making a final decision the safety of Red No. 2 and thereby exposed the public to needless risk. Next, the Health Research Group, a Ralph Nader affiliate that had led the charge against Red No. 2 for four years, complained that serious safety questions were still unresolved. Then came a grueling appearance on CBSTV's Face the Nation,

title: In Massachusetts, the Democrats Have All the Fun
description: BOSTONIt is appropriate that in the Massachusetts Presidential primary all nine of the leading Democratic candidates are competing, while in the Republican contest President Ford and Ronald Reagan are running a shadow campaign, with neither setting foot in the state. Complexity and diversity are the distinguishing features of Massachusetts politics.

title: Hudson's Savior of Culture
description: CHARLES K. ROBINSON agrees that the empty and vandalized Hudson County Courthouse in.Jersey City is rrot the likelkst place in which to function as director of the Hudson County Office of Culture and Heritage Affairs. The big, bare room in which he works, a former jury chamber, has a peeling ceilingandd scabrous walls, and is so short on furniture that visitors sit on two lawn chairs borrowed from Mr. Robinson's own back porch.

title: Rangers Defeated by North Stars, 5 to 3
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 28John Ferguson, the New York Rangers coach, and his Minnesota North Star counterpart, Ted Harris, got together briefly before tonight's game and had a few laughs about the time when they were Montreal Canadiens teammates.

title: Despite Ages of Captivity, The Armenians Persevere
description: We are lunching, a Russian business acquaintance and I, at this touchingly downatheel Moscow hotel, strictly for locals (it's called the Minsk). I am slightly giggly from quaffing vodka on an empty stomachand probably from being seated too close to a motley group of earnest musicians who are playing a 1950's medley for these husky, miniskirted girls and their immaculately attired beaus prancing around the floor within inches of our table. We are sharing one of the few available tables with a short, darkcomplexioned man in an open shirt who smiles at us from time to time.

description: CLARK, N.J., Feb. 28 Ef forts to avert a strike Mondayby members of the Amalga mated Transit, Union. Division 819. against Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest buscompany, continued in daylongcontract bargaining today atthe Ramada Inn,

title: Faulty Pipeline Welding Brings Suit for $40 Million in Damages
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 28 A dispute between the company responsible for building the Trans Alaska oil pipeline and a contractor hired to check, pipeline welding has developed into two lawsuits in which one side seeks $40 million in damages.

title: POLITICS
description: DOMINIC BARANELLO, the Suffolk Democratic chairman, was the first major Democratic county leader in the state to support Hugh L. Carey for Governor. In fact, he cast his lot with Mr. Carey when most other Democratic leaders were brushing off the Brooklyn Congressman as a futile challenger of Howard J. Samuels for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1974.

title: Tea: Old Ties, New Markets
description: The most important tea party of the year is to convene tomorrow morning at the headquarters of the Food and Drug Administration in Brooklyn. Seven expert tasters will get together over several hundred cups of tea to set quality standards for the tea that Americans will drink in the 12 months starting May 1.

title: 31 STATES CLAIMING U.S. OVERPAYMENTS
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. ?? (AP) The Social Security Administration made overpayments of $197 million to the nation's elderly, blind and disabled in the first six months of a new distribution system, according to an independent audit report.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONLast year the nation had its highest unemployment in the 30 years since World War II, right? Right.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Even at their best, movies probably can never more than entertainments for the child imprisoned in the oldest of us. So writes Russell Baker, the New York Times columnist, in a recent piece questioning the sensibilities if not the sanity of the New York critics who were so taken by Lina Wertrnuller's Seven Beauties. Mr. Baker loathed the movie, which he describes as a message film. He's always been wary of messages in movies, he says, because, among other reasons, Stalin and Sundayschool teachers had a habit of slipping messages into stories.

title: Yale Swim Team Upsets Harvard,
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 (AP) Phil Moriarty, the retiring Yale swimming coach, was presented with one of his most gratifying victories today as Yale defeated previously unbeaten Harvard, 6449. Many in the crowd of 1,600 at the Kiputh Exhibition Pool included former swimmers who returned to root Yale to a winning season in Moriarty's 17th and final year as head coach. The triumph over Harvard, now 71, gave the Elis a 76 mark for the year.

title: DINING OUT
description: WITH the first bite, the cooking of China's Hunan and Szechuan provinces comes as a shock. Fiery hot spices and flavored oils set it apart. It undeniably exciting. This taste, like everything else, has to do with the weather and economics. Hunan and Szechuan summers are hot and steamy, as they are in other parts of the world where the cuisine is emphatically Peppered. Volcanic seasoning also makes the food go farther. One consumes less spicy meat, more rice.

title: Ward Canaday Is Dead at 90; Developer of the Military Jeepl
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 28  Ward Murphey Canaday, who developed and produced the military Jeep during World War II, died yesterday at his home. He was 90 years old.

title: Eleanor White,Carlton Durling To Wed in June
The Confessions of a Convert to Long Island
description: WHEN my husband band accepted a job in New York City several years ago, and the prospect of moving to Long Island loomed before us, I was devastated. Though we had been through moves before, the New England mill town where we then lived had become part of us. Three of our children had been born there. and we felt we belonged. We had put down roots and planned to stay.

title: Track Crown To Penn

title: Marquette Defeats Irish For 19th in Row, 8175
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 28 (AP)Secondranked Marquette held Adrian Dantley to 6 points in the first half, then withstood a secondhalf surge and beat Notre Dame, 8175, in basketball today. It was Marquette's 19th straight victory.

title: Beauty: From the inside out
description: Although for centuries poets have held that beauty's but skin deep, most modern physicians would hold just the opposite: that the real secret of making the most of whatever physical attributes one happens to have inherited is to work from within. That is. stay healthy. To doctors, that is a truism. It's like titsing for motherhood and appk pie, and against sin, says

title: How Soccer Can Become A Major American Sport
description: Soccer will not replace American football. It will not survive at the expense of baseball. The indoor game will not knock basketball and hockey out of the winter sports picture. Soccer will not replace any of the popular professional sports in the United States.

title: PEOPLE
description: IT seems like only yesterday that anytime you went the movies or turned on the television set or attended the theater in search of diversion, there was Paul Ford, playing one of his wonderful comic characters. Writers had a field day trying to describe himpessimistic bloodhound, cantankerous seal, Thurber cartoon, were some of the combinations they tried. But now it is unlikely that there will be any new creations from the man who entertained millions as Colonel Hall, the longsuffering commanding officer of the Sergeant Bilko Show and who starred on Broadway in plays like Command Decision and What Did We Do Wrong and in Hollywood in films like The Russians are Coming, The Russians are Coming and Never Too Late. Now 74yearsold and ailing, he has been confined to a wheelchair since last January at the United Presbyterian Residence, a nursing home in Woodbury, where he spends a good deal of his time reminiscing about his career.

title: FOREST FIRES CLOSE PARK HIKING TRAILS
description: Forest fires driven by gusty winds forced the closing of hiking trails in the Harriman and Bear Mountain sections of Palisades Interstate Park yesterday afternoon.

description: This Week

description: IS it vigilanteeism? Union doesn't think so. Is it unconstitutional? Possibly. Is it what Union wants? Yes, says Mayor John Zimmerman. Emphatically yes, says Township Administrator Louis Giacona, adding: The Supreme Court said community standards. so we're setting the standards for our community. Unconstitutional? It may well he. But we needed something.

title: Opera: Bilby's Doll Opens in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 28Down town Houston is about as farremoved from a 17thcenturyNew England Puritan settle ment as one could imagine,but it was here that a newopera about witchcraft inSalem, Mass., received itspremiere last night.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to Tobago. you can fly there via BWIA, Pan American. Air France, KLM and VIASA to PortofSpain, Trinidad; from there, take a short connecting flight on Trinidad and Tobago Air Services. Round trip fare: $353. There is also steamship service on MooreMcCormack, Royal Caribbean, Royal Netherlands and Alcoa. Connecting air flights do exist, but if you have to stay overnight in Trinidad, the Be! Air Airport Motel is the most convenient. For $27 to $30 per double room, you will be accommodated cleanly, if not very quietly.

title: Insanity from the outside and the inside
description: Books about going crazy written by the sufferers themselves, or from their standpoint, are appearing more frequently. They are, it seems to me, increasingly relevant to what the rest of us, who have never embarked on that frightening journey, need to know about it. Madmen, once so unintelligible, are beginning to come through. Mark Vonnegut's The Eden Express, one of the most recent survivor's reports, is also one of the best. These books can do more than any psychiatric textbook to make us confront the alienation of the psychotic, to put us in his situation as he looks out at the keepers and spectators. Without this view we must ourselves be spectators: those who write about it must move us from fear to pity, from spectacle to understanding, or we will stay on the outside looking in.

title: Mary Remington Shaw Is Engaged
description: Mary H. Shaw of Dedham, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Remington Shaw, to Peter Wallace Gallaudet of Washington, son of Mrs. Stephen H. Swift of South Dartmouth, Mass., and the late Edward Denison Gallaudet of Hartford. .

title: Three Big Rescues By the F. D. I. C.
description: In the last twoandahalf years, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's insuring abilities have been tested by the three largest bank failures in United States banking history. In order of size they were:

title: Faschnacht!
description: The citizenry of Basel are a reserved lot, but each year, during the few days before Lent, they cut loose. Faschnacht is the Swiss version of Mardi Gras, celebrated throughout the nation but most spectacularly in this city on the Rhine. For three days and nights, townspeople in medieval garb invade the old quarter, lanterns in hand. Fife and drum echo along the ancient winding alleys. Bands of musicians roam from beer hall to tavern with drunken abandon. Along the main streets, parades of floats move: citizens are pelted with political leaflets mixed with confetti and fruit. By dawn of Ash Wednesday, the rites of spring sufficiently celebrated, the Swiss return to mundane reality. Not even a trace of confetti remains on the streets as the townsfolk hurry after trams on their way to work.

title: M. C. Ross Fiance Of Marie Dempsey
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dempsey 2d of Cleveland and Murray Bay, Quebec, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Jeanette Dempsey, to Michael Charles Ross. son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton W. Ross of Narberth. Pa.

title: An Olympic Medalist at 16 Is a Superstar at 20
description: At 16, the sturdily built girl from Northbrook, Ill., used her arms, legs and determination to win gold and bronze medals in speed skating in the 1972 Winter Olympies. Last week, she brought her trademarks out of retirement to win the Women's Superstars competition in Rotunda, Fla.

title: Harris's Fate Is Linked to Defeating Bayh
description: BOSTON, Feb. 28One dayin early January Fred R. Harris,his wife, LaDonna, and a fewof his young staff wrappedthemselves in laughter as theycampaigned through an Iowablizzard in a rented camper.

title: Clown Prince of Racing Hopes to Revive CanAms
description: The late Bloys Britt. who covered the motor sports scene for the Associated Press, once wrote a story on Oscar A. M. Koveleski of Scranton, Pa., whom he described as the clown prince of auto racing. Koveleski does much to live up to that title. He is a truly zany person who seemingly goes froth one madcap adventure to another. One of his more wellknown efforts was the founding of the Polish Racing Drivers of America (P.R.D.A.), which has no real purpose, except to relieve tension.

description: BOONE, N.C.

title: A DropOut SingsOf Her Tangled Life
description: Recluslveness is more andmore a part of pop musicthese days. Bob Dylan didn'ttour for eight years. NeilDiamond didn't for four. Carole King determinedly avoided live performances untiljust recently, and Brian Wilson still does. David Bowiehas retired twice, althoughhe can't be said to haveexactly shunned the spotlight. But the recently endedthreeyear retreat of LauraNyro, New York City's veryown pop composer, singerand flower child, has beendifferentmore real andmore complete. The othersall continued niaking records, and those records or an occasional furtive appearance kept them in the publiceye. Miss Nyro had built anincreasingly successful careeras a songwriter and singerwith her striking blend offolk, rock, soul, jazz andBroadway. Her popularity asa songwriter was attestedto by the hits which others,above all the Fifth Dimension, enjoyed with her music.By the early 1970's sheseemed poised on the brinkof huge success as a singerin her own right.

title: The World/Continued
description: PEKINGIn China President Ford's stock is down to an almost unspeakable level and in high circles Henry Kissinger is most easily remembered as a man who went to a formerly Chinese city, Vladivostok, to thoughtlessly prepare another defeatist arrangement with Moscow. Richard Nixon, sometimes referred to as the President in retirement received a special welcome, a welcome appropriate to his contribution to ChineseAmerican relations, the official formula goes.

title: Connors Crushes Orantes
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 28 It was strictly no contest today as Jimmy Connors ripped through Manuel Orantes, 62, 61, 60, and remained undefeated as champion of the Caesars Palace Tennis Specials.

title: Lieut. Millard to Marry Mary Jean Eisenhower
description: Mary Jean Eisenhower, youngest of the four grandchildren of Mamie Eisenhower and the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower. plans to be married ill May to Second Lieut. James Brewton Millard, who is stationed with the Army at Fort Benning, Ga.

description: For a few days this week it seemed as if the days of the 1960's student rebellions had returned to Tappan Zee High School in Orangeburg.

description: CUT OFF. La.Midwinter is the only comfortable season for visiting the Cajun country. The mosquitoes are bad In the summer. which in the bayous and plains of south Louisiana runs roughly from the beginnings of Lent until just before Christmas.

description: To think about walls at alland the point is that one doesn'tis to conceptualize, with difficulty, something blank. neutral and finite that deadends space. A totally negative thing, a wall  or is it?

title: Comments from Two Readers
description: The arlicle "Bucking out of Paying Pensions" which appeared in this section on  Feb. 8 eleicited several responses from readers, the burden of which was that, pension reform efforts have been unfairly maligned. Following are two of those letters.

title: Following in the Steps Of Robinson Crusoe
description: I am under strict instructions from my recent traveling companions not to reveal the location of the best beach in Tobagoperhaps in the world. But they have agfeed to let me describe it: A gently curving expanse of beige sand. Rows of tall, stately coconut palms yielding to the trade winds, forming the first ring of a forest that climbs a steep hill behind the beachand keeps it hidden. Foamy white breakers crashing against threestoryhigh boulders at one end of the arc; softer waves washing the rocks at the opposite end. In the middle the warm navyblue water changing from lakelike calm on some days to swells of raging force on others, settling mostly into symmetrical rollers that curl over perfectly for body surfing. We decided to call it the Secret Beach. and we spent most of our days there in splendid isolation.

title: College President to Resign
description: WAYNE, N.J., Feb. 28 (UPI) William J. McKeefery, president of William Paterson College, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of his current term next June. Ile has been president of the state college since 1973.

title: Music in Review
description: If Marlos Papadopoulos hadfinished his first recital hereas impressively as he hadbegun, his ranking amongthe better pianists of his gen eration would have beeneasier to determine.

title: More Is Less
description: The New Hampshire primary has served the clear and important purpose of confirming through the voting booth what had seemed increasingly evident: President Ford is as much a challenger as the next man, Ronald Reagan, for the Republican Presidential nomination, and Jimmy Carter, the exGovernor of Georgia, is a serious, not a transient, entrant in the Democratic race.

title: DOUBLING OF CUTSSEEN FOR THE CITY
description: Heads of the city's majorvoluntary human service agen cies asserted yesterday thatthe city faces budget cuts ofmore than $2.4 billion in itsthreeyear fiscal plan when!losses of state and Federal aidare included  not just thelatest official estimate of$1.021 billion based only oncity tax funds.

title: THE SEXY SEASON
description: There is no fussing around this spring. Clothes are carefree, soft and light. Designs are held together by a minimum of ingeniously placed seams or wrappings and are totally void of extraneous de. tails, busy trimmings or complicated cuts. Fashion has settled for freedom, and the silhouette has never been purer or more classically simple. Any design today that shows its shape on the hangor. relies on a zipper to pull it together or has any resemblance to a stiff paperdoll dress ought to be under museum glass. The nonconstructionists have won. In fact, spring clothes are so light and limp they almost fall oft their hangers. They wrap, sash, slip over the head in seconds and fold up into practically nothing.

title: Iran Accused at Meeting Here of Torture and Repression
description: Opponents of the Shah of Iran met at Columbia University last week to discuss torture and repression that they say persist in Iran.

title: New Jersey
description: THEATER

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: LEADING INDICATORS of national economic performance showed a 2.2 percent rise in January, the largest increase since July, 1975, winding up at 106.3 percent of the 1967 average.... The United States had a trade deficit $72.6 million in January after a $724.2 million surplus December.... New orders for durable goods jumped 2.3 percent in January to $43.82 billion from $42.84 billion December.

title: And now a word about cosmetics...
description: All right, say a woman has been eating a balanced diet and getting the proper amount of sleep, hut she still thinks her skin could look better. After the doctors have had their say, the cosmetics people want to put in a word or two. This spring, they've come out with plenty of new skintreatment products for the woman who feels she has to put something specific on her face.

title: Epilogue
description: A court has recently ruled, iii a suit begun in 1963, that Ptiliman car porters were for years discriminated against by the Pullman Company. A group of porters now have told of their experiences and of the company's attitude toward them.

title: TV VIEW
description: Last Sunday and this morning, at 11 o'clock, CBS's venerable but splendidly energetic Camera Three has been presenting a celebration of the late Noel Coward. The two halfhours were produced, directed and written by Sheldon Larry, a 27yearold native of Canada. He arrived in this country last year by way of eight years in England and considerable experience with the British Broadcasting Corporation. Like many other observers of the electronic animal, he finds American TV brilliant in technique but weak in content. The opposite is generally true of the British product. But Mr. Larry is convinced that American content can be improved and be successful within the stringent limits, primarily economic, of the present system. His experiences with the Coward project provide some insight into both the possibilities and the impossibilities of that perhaps redical thought.

title: The Secretary Will Take Support Where He Can Find It
description: WASHINGTONNot since Woodrow Wilson toured the country for the League of Nations has a senior Administration official barnstormed on behalf of a foreign policy issue as Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has done. Mr. Kissinger is doing it for he same political reason as Mr. Wilson: He is running out of support in Washington and has been trying to win arguments in the heartland that he can no longer win in the capital.

title: Colonels Rout Nets By 126100
Detective Story: Death on a Roof
description: THE frontporch roof on Jean Pierre Boulanger's house needed tarring, and he wanted to complete the chore before he and his wife, Gladys, began a short holiday trip last July 5. So, in his leisure on July 4, Mr. Boulanger, a prosperous architect, worked with trowel and tar bucket heneath the maples that shaded his twostory colonial home at 579 Shunpike Road, Chatham Township, in Morris County.

title: Niagara Falls Offering Welcome to Concorde
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 28 (UPI) If the Concorde supersonic jet is banned at New York City's Kennedy International Airport, it would be more than welcome in Niagara Falls, the resort city's mayor said today.

title: Giants
description: The giants of Giants are the executives of UBC, the nation's fourth major television network. Most gigantic of all is its founder, the inevitable nonpareil, the great god, David Abrams, whom age is slowly forcing into retirement. A slew of presidents and vicepresidents, including Abrams's nambypamby son, are eager to use the old man's departure to become other sorts of presidents and vicepresidents. They plot against each other with a vengeance, if not with any great clarity, chiefly over expenseaccount lunches, the interoffice telephone and each other's wives.

title: KENNEDY CRITICIZES U.S. ON POLICY IN U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy today charged that a State Department plan to win support for the United States in the United Nations did it in a way that was in clear violation of Congressional directives.

title: Irene Kaletsch Becomes Bride
description: In St. Peter's Lutheran Church here at noon yesterday. Irene Diaman Kaletsch of New York, daughter of Mrs. Alexander C. Diaman, also of New York, and the late Mr. Diaman, became the bride of William R. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y. He is the son of IVIrs. Douglas R. C. Miller of London and the late Mr. Miller.

title: Crisis in Argentina Recesses for Carnival
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28Argentina's political crisis, which many believe is moving toward a military coup, went into recess today for a long Carnival weekend.

title: Teddy Aspegren Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Bacon Aspegren of New York and Southampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theodora Vantine Aspegren, to George William Rahhe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Rabhe of New York and East Hampton, L. I.

title: CANADIANS SPLIT ON ALIEN DOCTORS
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A regulation requiring immigrant doctors in British Columbia to practice in remote, cold, thinly populated areas of the vast province for their first five years has come under fire from civilrights groups and others, including some doctors.

title: ART
description: WOMEN artists can often catch the tragedy, atrocity and horror of war with more dramatic incisiveness than men artists. Their powerful point of view max be linked to their removal from the field of action, giving them a larger picture of the event. Or, it may he that they are more sensitive to the futility of war and more repulsed by its ugliness.

title: Jean M. Giblin Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Burke Giblin of New Vernon, N.J., and Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Marie Giblin, to Alfred D. Haynes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haynes Jr. of Allendale, N.J.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Camera buffs often combine their interest in photography with other hobbies by recording activities and events of interest to themselves, or to potential viewers. This is particularly true of these who are interested in wildlife, including birdwatchers, fishermen, hunters and nature lovers. A patient and observant photographer can put together an exciting and exceptionally interesting wildlife slide showif he or she goes where wildlife may be found.

title: HEAD OF THE CLASS
description: Roslyn Dobey has a fulltime teaching job, a parttime selling job, is working on her master's degree in education, takes an exercise class once a week, cooks dinner for her husband and still finds time somehow  to shop for c lot hes.2:30 to 7 on Wednesdays, she says matteroffactly, 'In the summer, when school is closed. I have more time to shop. I must have spent $500 on clothes last summer. For winter I bought a pair of boots, a coat, three or four skirts, threeno fourturtlenecks, a blazer and five or six pairs of shoes.

title: The Sheik of Britain's Oil
description: LONDON  Six months ago Lord Keartonwho was C. Frank Kearton until the Government knighted him and then made him a life peerbegan his days as a pensioner. He would tend the roses at The Old House, his home 40 miles northwest of London semirural Whitchurch, he told friends. He would enjoy his nine grandchildren, and he might get a parttime assignment to a Government committee somewhere.

title: AREAS COMPAREDON REALTY TAXES
description: The property tax burden on northern New Jersey home owners is substantially smallerthan it is for homes with the same market value in West chester and Nassau Counties,according to a new study bya private research group.

title: Private Colleges in Peril
description: The private colleges and universities of New York State, beset by financial problems and competition from public institutions that offer education at considerably lower prices, are moving from a troubled present into an uncertain future.

title: Soviet Publishes Details on Venus Craft
description: After four months of analysis, the Soviet Union has madn public the first detailed findings of its two spacecraft. that reached the planet Venus last October. Some of the information is expected to help the Americans in planning their own Pioneer mission to the planet, scheduled for 1978.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday's Fight
description: ManilaAlfonso Lopez, 11l pounds, knocked out Erbito Salavarria, 110, The Philippines, 15 rounds, to capture the World Boxing Association flyweight title.

title: The Professionals
description: While Yonkers sat out one of its nowregular default vigils recently many people following the city's plight were introduced to an official whose functions are little known. J. Emmet Casey, the outgoing city manager, worked his last weekend alongside Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli and state officials to secure $13 million needed to meet maturing notes and city payrolls. He and they succeeded.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Spring
description: March Isn't spring, in this latitude, although the spell of mild weather during late February made one think spring, Actually, spring is starting to move north right now. And once spring starts north it travels at a fairly regular and predictable pace, if one takes account of local conditions such as March snowstorms, The rate travel is approximately sixteen miles a day. A man on foot could easily keep up with it,

title: Rutgers, 250, Downs L.I.U.
Houston Boy, 8, Unties Knots, A Second Red Food Dye Is Now Suspect
description: HOUSTON. Feb. 28An 8 yearold boy untied himself and escaped from the locked tritalt of an automobile after he had been kidnapped and held eight ,hours for $1 million in ransom here yesterday.

title: Domestic and Diplomatic Policies Are Only Rarely Attuned
description: In a creative twist on Philadelphia's bicentennial celebration, 128 members of Congress have so far agreed to sign a Declaration of Interdependence drafted by Henry Steele Commager, the historian.labor, food, transportation, population, culture, communication, terrorism, revolution, law enforcement, arms, narcotics, religion, ideology.

title: The World
description: Reports that the United States and six other major industrial countries have signed an agreement to develop new safeguards on the nuclear facilities that they export appear to have raised more questions than they answered.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HEERENVEEN, the Netherlands, Feb. 28 (AP)Eric Heiden, 17yearold American, stole the show at the world speed skating championships today by capturing the 500meter race. However, he slipped to 16th place in the 5,000. Hans Van Heiden of the Netherlands won the 5,000 and finished fourth in the 500 to take a commanding lead halfway through the championships. Dan Carroll of the United States was eighth in the 500 and 10th in the 5,000.

title: Looking for:
description: Flyingsaucer tales long ago ceased to he news. Just when the great U.F.O. fever began to wane cannot be pinpointed precisely, but it was somewhere around the time when a West Coast housewife told an inquiring reporter: I don't understand all this excitement about flying saucers. Why, they come through our backyard all the time.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two teenagers were arrested in Catskill, N.Y., andcharged in connection with sniping Friday on four vehicles,including a loaded Greyhound bus, along the Gov. ThomasE. Dewey Thruway, authorities said. State police declinedto identify the youths, but said a 15yearold was chargedwith juvenile delinquency and released in his parentscustody. They said that a 16yearold youth was arraignedon a charge of firstdegree reckless endangerment andreleased in 6500 bail pending further diposition.

title: XRays Beamed on Prisoners To Test Sterility by Radiation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission beamed Xrays into the testicles of 131 prisoners in Oregon and Washington in the 1960's to test if he:ivy rnfli7,t;rm could make them sterile, the Energy Research and Development Administration confirms.

title: SHOP TALK
description: UNTIL recently, those parents who wanted to buy the educational toys and sturdy juvenile furniture made by Childcraft had to travel to one of the company's two New York stores.

title: GARDENING
description: RECENT concern for the environment has resulted in the removal from the market of many widely used pesticides as being too dangerous, excessively persistent or detrimental to various ecological relationships.

title: Canadians Heatedly Debating Proposed Penal Code Reforms
description: OTTAWA. Feb. 28An inItifsive national debate has begun in Canada over sweeping reforms of the criminal code proposed by the Government.

title: Islanders Wives A Different Goal
description: I REALLY love it, said Michele Nystrom, the nine month bride of Bobby Nystrom, the big right wing for the New York Islanders hockey team, It's a very exciting life. It's a little different than having a husband going to work 9 to 5.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
Dance: A Step Beyond MixedMedia
description: The Mimi Garrard DanceTheater, which presented aprogram Friday night at thetheater of the RiversideChurch that will be repeatedthis afternoon, is attemptingsomething new in an areathat might have previouslyseemed at a dead end.

title: In This Issue
description: GENERAL

title: NUCLEAR SAFETY IS ISSUE ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28They have the money, hut we have the people.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Build Upstate Prison
description: OTISVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 28Construction of the first Feder al prison in New York State, a 500 inmate facility for men in upstate Otisville, will begin in the fall if building funds of $21.7 million are appropriat ed by Congress.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: When President Ford, in a postmortem on his narrow victory in the New Hampshire primary last week, attributed his success partly to the good economic news of the last few weeks, he Identified an issue that he and others believe will loom importantly in the November election.

title: Linda Macwithey Sets Spring Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Linden Macwithey of White Stone, Va., and Glenburnie, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter. Linda Blair Macwithey, to Timothy Gamier Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Baldwin of Oakmont, Pa.

title: Welfare Queen LosesHer Cadillac Limousine
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (UPI)Linda Taylor, who came tonotice when Ronald Reagan,in his Presidential campaign,cited her as an example ofan alleged welfare abuser,has had her Cadillac limou sine seized by the police here.

title: Germans Build Soviet Ship
description: HAMBURG, West Germany (UPI)A Hamburg shipyard is Ibuilding the largest crane ship in the world for the Soviet Union. A spokesman for Blohm Voss said that the ship would have a giant crane able to lift 2,500 tons. The ship will be built in three parts, transported to the Caspian Sea and assembled there.

title: Army Beats Navy In 2 of 3 Sports
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 28 (AP)  Army defeated Navy in swimming and gymnastics today but the Midshipmen heat the Cadets in rifle shooting. Navy won the rifle competition, 2,825 points to 2,769 as the teams rolled up the highest point total in the history of the meet.

title: Ideas &
description: The Faustian bargain struck by all technological societies seems to have left mankind with a permanent mortgage on its peace of mind. For all the benefits of speed, power and comfort there are all too many risks  to the human race, its environment, its posterity.

title: Amid Perpetual Din, Residents Say Enough
description: The neonlit marquee in front of McCabe's Steak House in Rosedale pretty much sums up the local sentiment. Stop the S.S.T. it says. That message also shouts from hundreds of hastily tacked wall posters in the area. It is, actually, more than a message; it is a declaration of war. You walk into a local bar, and. as likely as not, someone will hand you a leaflet and harangue you about the supersonic Concorde. Rosedale, a pleasant, mostly residential section of Queens, is an agitated community these days.

title: David Meyer Is a Mother
description: What happens when an insecure, misogynistic, thoroughly shallow human being falls in love with a liberated, freespirited, thoroughly shallow human being? If your immediate response is, not much, you probably won't find Gail Parent's second book very funny. At. 33. after years of successfully manipulating women into and out of his bed on the strength of his sexy eyes and glamorous iab in television programming.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Sirloin steak at 81.39 pound? A quart of mayonnaise that wholesales for $1.05 on sale at 88 cents? Apples at 12 cents a pound? These prices aren't taken from advertisements of a decade agothey're today's in California.

title: Drought Perils Wheat in Old Dust Bowl
Brazil's Underground Riches
description: RIO DE JANEIROFrom the Amazonian rain forests through the parched northeast and down to the rolling hills of southern Brazil, giant earthmoving machines are tearing open a treasure trove at minerals.

title: POLITICS
description: IT used to be that Governors and Presidents were the dreadnaughts of American politics. The power. and majesty of their office were so formidable that, like thickplated battleships, it took more than one or, two torpedos to send them to the bottom.

title: THE SEXY SEASON
The Unspeakable Confessions Of Salvador Dali
description: The Divine Salvador (his epithet) Dali's contribution to modern art isn't the nightmarealley dreamscape; Georgio de Chirico decreed those nostalgic shadows and tick  tack recessions while the divine Sal was a 10yearold exhibitionist and (according to his latest autobiographical effusion) turgid molester of terrorized chambermaids. Nor did he promulgate those Dalian , passages of caramelized hue that look as if they had been suckled and licked into place along marine horizons; he was intelligent enough to borrow the technique from such academic hasbeens Meissonier and Detaille.

title: ... and Conserving It
description: Conservation is not merely smaller cars, lower highway speeds and turning off unneeded lightsthough such shifts in habit are certainly the beginning of it. Conservation also implies a longerrange structural program of modernizing factoriesparticularly in the energyintensive industries like primary metals and paper manufacturing. Roger Sant, assistant F.E.A. administrator for conservation and environment, argues that a longterm national investment of $500 billion in conservation technology would save twice as much energy as a comparable investment in new supplies would produce.

title: This Week in Sports
description: College Basketball

title: Pace of City Life Found 2.8 Feet per Second Faster
description: The pace of life in big cities is faster th:in it is in small townsabout 2.8 feet per second faster, according to a study by a Princeton University psychologist and his wife, who is an anthropologist.

title: Philadelphia Archdiocese Raising High School Fees
description: PHILADELPHIA. Feb. 28 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Archdiocese has announced that it would raise tuition next September for students attending its 30 Roman Catholic high schools, but that that would still leave an anticipated operational deficit of nearly $1 million.

title: Tenant Frontier, Moving South, Reaches Wall Street
description: New York's newest frontier is also one of its oldestjust north of where the Dutch built their wall. This time, however, the homes settlers are devising on Thames Street, that twoblock windswept canyon on Manhattan's tip, involve not roof raising but the recycling of some vintage real estate.

title: City Council SessionsScheduled This Week
description: City Council committeeswill conduct the followingpublic hearings this week:

title: Music: National Chorale
description: It's often more fun, in aghoulish sort of way, to writeabout a really bad perform ance than about one thatjust forged ahead, doing itsjob but not really enjoyingitself. The National Chorale's two a half hour run through of the Bach Massin B minor Friday nightat Avery Fisher Hall wasjust that kind of occasion:a functionally decent ac count of a great mas terpiece that never reallytranscended tile perfunctory.

title: Marlene Wantland Engaged to Jonathan Moreland
description: Marlene Gail Wantiand and Jonathan Thomas Moreland, graduates of the University of Oregon, will be married April 10 in Portland, Ore.

title: For young readers
description: A charming, animated television special, Maurice Sendak's Really Rosie, has spawned a hodgepodge of a book, combining Sendak's script and lyrics with color pictures reproduced from the show, some of Sendak's preliminary drawings, and Carole King's music. One purpose clearly served is to make available the sheet music for Carole King's seven songs, but the point of putting all this together in one package escapes me.

title: Benson to Continue Racing Despite Loss of Mary E II
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 28Charles (Chuck) Benson and his wife, Caroline, managed yesterday to compose a verbal obituary for the yacht Mary E II, which sank last Tuesday in 2,100 feet of water during the MiamiNassau race.

title: Bunker Hunt of Dallas at 50: Just an Ordinary Billionaire
description: DALLASNelson Bunker Hunt, perhaps the only billionaire on the east side of this town, turned 50 last weekend.

title: U. S. Freezing Out India In Reaction to Mrs. Gandhi
description: Besides postponing a plan to resume economic aid to India, the Ford Administration has quietly but firmly turned its back on other cooperation until Prime Minister Indira Gandhi becomes openly friendlier toward the United States.

title: Blackbirds, Roosting by the Millions, Damaging Farms in South
description: RUSSELLVILLE, Ky. James Simmons, a Russellville grain farmer, has been battling the growing hordes of blackbirds that have descended on his 700acre farm for five years now, watching his seed grain devoured, his harvest contaminated, his young pigs grow sick and die.

title: Senate Panel Acts to Prevent Leaks in Spy Study
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 28  The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will take extraordinary precautions next week to prevent its final report front being leaked to the news media, committee sources say.

title: John Garnbrill Fiance Of Eunice M. Jennings
description: The engagement of Eunice Mallory Jennings to John Larner Gambrill has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Jennings of Byram, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 19.

title: Jamie C. Wise Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vernon L.Wise Jr. of Butler, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Cyn thia Wise, to Vance McClel land Smith 3d, son of Mr. andMrs. Smith Jr. of Gibsonia, Pa.A June wedding is planned.

title: A MILITANT INDIAN IS SEEKING REFUGE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 Three years ago, militant Indians occupied Wounded Knee, S.D., In what one of their leaders called a desperate attempt to seek redress of their deplorable living conditions.

title: FRENCH SPEAK OUT AT SOVIET PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28  The Kremlin was confronted directly today by thP new independence of the French Communist Party as the ranking French delegate told the 25th Soviet party congress that his party would pursue a socialism in he colors of France.

title: What's Doing in VERMONT
Bold Forbes Triumphs By 3 Lengths on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI)Bold Forbes stamped himself a top Kentucky Derby prospect when he captured the ninth running of the $44,850 San Jacinto Stakes for 3yearods at Santa Anita today. Bold Forbes scored a threelength victory in running the mile in 1:35.

title: Manhattan School Stages Street Scene
description: Street Scene, a realistictenement melodrama thatwon the Pulitzer Prize for itsauthor, Elmer Rice, in 1929,may have seemed unlikelymaterial for a Broadwaymusical, yet with a score byKurt Weill it turned up asjust that in 1949. It was nota big success, but it had arun of 148 performancesvery respectable for a theaterpiece of its musical weight.

title: MRS. LEVENTRITT, GAVE MUSIC PRIZE
description: Rosalie Joseph Leventrilt, a music lover who devoted her life to furthering the careers of talented musicians, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 5
description: Morning

title: The Nation
description: Another conflict has arisen between the Ford Administration and the Democratic Congress over the legislators right of access to secret intelligence data. A House subcommittee has voted to recommend that four Federal intelligence officers and one former aide be held in contempt for refusing to provide information about Government monitoring of telegraphic messages.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Times erred In An earned income credit example of its income tax guide published last week under the headline A Year of Change for Form 1040. In the section on the credit, the Federal payment made to poorer people, the following example appeared:

title: Paperbacks
description: A CITY ON A HILL, by George V. Higgins. (Baltontine, $1.75.) The ways and woes of a Massachusetts Congressman who aspires to be a Presidentmaker: told largely through dialogue that always seems authentic but on occasion is confusing.young and old to come to terms through their daily life with the inevitability of death.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Probably the best of this type of series to appear since Harry Kemelman's Rabbi Small books, Arthur D. Goldstein's saga of Max Guttman continues with NOBODY'S SORRY HE GOT IKILLED (Random House, $6.95). Guttman stories have appeared twice before; in 1972 there was A Person Shouldn't Die Like That and late in 1974 You're Never Too Old to Die. Guttman, a retired cutter in New York's clothing district, is the elderly Jew with a knack for solving mysteries. These he solves not like Rabbi Small and his pilpul but by oldfashioned investigation coupled with native shrewdness.

title: Silver Dollar Tree From Australia Will Grow Indoors
description: Eucalyptus greens are widely popular at florist shops in the metropolitan region for their decorative value because they are ornamental and durable. Many of them come from California or the South, where they sometimes are called blue spiral, but here, in the current spirit of New York's semideflated optimism, they often are called silver dollars.

title: Nixon Opponent in 46 Race Named to California Panel
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP)Jerry Voorhis a former congressman who was Richard M. Nixon's first opponent for political office, was appointed to the California Commission on Aging yesterday by Gov. Edmund Brown Jr.

title: Article 1  No Title
The Frog
description: A frog that became addicted to morphine during experiments at the Federal hospital at Lexington, Kentucky, fell into my hands at the conclusion of their experiments. As a frog, he was a wreck. Unless he had morphine he wouldn't eat or even look at a fly. I kept him as a pet and gave him a name, but it became rather a problem supplying him with morphine. Being merely a laboratory assistant and not a doctor or even a nurse I had no access to the drug which many doctors here are studying, attempting to discover a cure for human addicts.

title: Computers Will Be Used To Analyze Golf Mistakes
description: Computers have not yet reached the point where they can sink 20foot putts, but the Metropolitan Golf Association has hired a numbersstinger that they can do other useful chores.

title: Olympics: Innsbruck Revisited/An Amateur Replies
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BOND SALES URGED TO DEVELOP ISRAEL
description: American and Canadian Jewish leaders were asked yesterday to provide a major share of Israel's economic development budget of $1 billion through an intensive sale of Israel bonds here and in other democratic nations.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We have a light over our dining room table that I thought was brass, but now there are black spots as though the brass has worn off. Is there a brass paint I can buy to cover these dark spots and look right, or can paint it a color? If so, what kind of paint do I need? Mrs. H.C., Southwick, Mass.

title: Cocaine Seized at Airport
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Customs Service agents yesterday seized 71/2 pounds of co Caine, valued at $1.8 million, from a Venezualan man who was carrying the drug in the false bottom of a suitcase at Washington's International Dulles Airport, a Customs Service official said. The man arrested was Greroio K. Harmandarian, 25 years old, who came in on a Pan American plane from Guatemala City. Ciliatemala, by way of Caracas, Yene/ualn.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The following letters were received in reaction to articles by Mario Pei on Talking Brooklyn in Joisey? (Jan. 18) and dropping the New from New Jersey (Feb. 8.):

title: Migration A Problem In Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  Historic Istanbul, one of the oldest crosswords in the world, is drowning under a flood of people.

title: Huge Wave Encountered By Dutch Cruise Liner
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 28 (AP) A freakish wave, estimated at 60 to 100 feet high, smashed nearly broadside into the cruise ship Rotterdam in the Mediterranean while the 40,000ton ship was on a world cruise, a passenger said.

title: Nothing Has Replaced the Kissinger Shuttle
description: CAIRO  A twoyear period of American predominance in Middle East diplomacy has come to an end. It did so when Israeli and Egyptian forces completed implementation of the second Sinai disengagement agreement.

title: Parking Space a CleanAir Target
description: One stratagem that Federal and state officials are using in their campaign to clean up the urban environment is to attack the automobile in a highly sensitive place: the parking place.

title: Molloy Trackmen Take C.H.S.A.A. Indoor Title
description: Maurice Weaver was determined yesterday to post his second straight national flatfloor record when he stepped to the line for the onemile run at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track championship at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Is the State Taxed Out?
description: NEW JERSEY may have gone as far as it can go in the area of state taxing, which seems to be reaching a level of diminishing returns, A study of the cost of government in New Jersey and its taxes indicates that new taxes could depress the state's economy and create new unemployment and welfare problems,

title: U.S. Expects Gain for Poor Lands in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Despite growing debts and continuing large balanceofpayments deficits, the great majority of the lessdeveloped countries should be able to avoid disruption and financial crisis this year, according to a detailed new analysis by the United States Treasury.

title: Rep. Abzug Wants Persons Told of U.S. Files on Them
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Government agencies will be required to notify individuals of all files maintained on them if a bill proposed by Representative Bella Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan, becomes law.

title: Politics Called Factor in Eastchester Teacher Strike
description: EASTCHESTER. Feb. 28k sixweek teachers strike that has divided this Westchester, iCounty suburb had political as well as financial origins, a ;teachers representative said today.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE wife and I celebrated our 25th wedding anniversary this month and we went all the way to Manhattan to do, it. The truth is, we are not party enthusiasts and we have, in recent years, been shouting surprise all over the Island to astonished friends who walk Into restaurants and homes to find their loved ones staging This Is Your Life on the occasion of their 25th anniversary or their 50th birthday (men only).

title: Democrats in Puerto Rico Reach a Truce
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. Feb. 28Rival factions that have clashedover the selection of 17 dele gates to the Democratic Na tional Convention have agreedto allow each side to certifyits own results by Monday andto challenge these choices byMarch 11.

title: Honest Pleasure 11Length Victor in Flamingo
The Other Free Agent
description: Confident that an appellate court will uphold his liberation from baseball's reserve clause, perhaps in a ruling tomorrow, Andy Messersmith is waiting for the auction to begin on his value as a righthanded pitcher. But the other free agent in the arbitration case, Dave McNally, insists that he has no intention of returning to baseball because his left arm has no value. Dave McNally is selling cars, trucks and tires in Billings, Mont., where he grew up. Cynics assume that a good offer develops, Dave McNally will sell himself. But he sounds as if he's sincere in his retirement.

title: Prodding the Bull Market?
description: It's like sharks, said Donald M. Kimsey, a market analyst for Dean Witter & Company, a brokerage house, trying to explain the stock market's momentum. When there's blood in the water, a lot of people start moving at the same time.

title: ART VIEW
description: The late Morris Kantor (18961974) was so much better knownand belovedas a teacher than as an artist in the last decades of his life that we are only now beginning to catch up on the actual scope of his artistic achievement. His long years of service at the Art Students League, at Cooper Union and in the art departments of universities all over the country earned him the esteem and affection of several generations of artists whose workand whose liveshe deeply affected, but to the swinging public of the 1960's and 70's he had become an obscure figure. The openings of the exhibitions he continued to have in those years were more regularly attended by artists and students than by smart collectors or museum officials, and his name, which in the 30's had signified something special on the American art scene, had more or less been dropped in the new histories of American art that were published in his old age. For the art public of the present day, he is likely to loom as a new name.

title: Theater: Death of a Hero
What's in a pattern?; The business has been subjected to rude shocks in recent years.

title: TV VIEW
description: I went fishing the other night in prime time and thought, for a heady moment, that I'd caught a trend. You can usually tell a trend: it is bigger than a flicker of interest and smaller than a Kulturkampf. It measures 750 words, or the length of an average TV column, with one scaly idea and dorsal, caudal, anal, pelvic and pectoral digressions. Also, it smells smart. This trend, alas, was still a tad, and I had to throw it back to eat some more adjectives.

title: Headliners
description: James B. Gregory has resigned as head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Mr. Gregory says be quit for strictly personal reasons, but the resignation comes at a time when the safety administration and its parent agency, the Department of Transportation, are still considering a longdelayed decision on whether to require the installation of the controversial automobile air bag in all new cars sold in this country. Mr. Gregory is known as a strong supporter of the air bag system. But he told a House subcommittee that his decision to quit had nothing to do with the air bag controversy. He also denied that Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. had asked him to resign. A final decision on the air bag matter, said Mr. Gregory, may be rendered by August.

title: Alison Finney, Paralegal, Fiancee
description: Alison Warren Finney, a paralegal for urban housing projects with the New York law firm of Tufo, Johnston & Allegaert, plans to be married May 30 to Henry Blanchard Stebbins, who is in his third year at the Boston University School of Law.

title: PEOPLE
description: Julian Boyd, Princeton University's noted Jeffersonian scholar, has entered his 33d year of tracking down the letters and documents of the nation's third President. Working out of the Fireside Library, Mr. Boyd and his staff have gathered a staggering number (more than 6.000) of items concerning Jefferson, including 18,000 letters. Nineteen volumes of the papers have already been published, and Mr. Boyd plans 41 more. It is hoped the collection will eventually include all letters written or received by Jefferson, plus his speeches, legal briefs and architectural renderings. Of great help to Mr. Boyd in his monumental task has been the fact that Jefferson kept a meticulous log of every letter he wrote or received from age 25 until his death in 1826.

title: News of the Realty Trade

title: Duvillard Wins Slalom; Vermont Men Triumph
Stranger than fact
description: The account that Bo and Peep give of their earthly mission has parallels in several currently available sciencefiction paperbacks. Alison Lurie's Imaginary Friends, published in 1967, tells of the Truth Seekers, a group living in a small American city. They believe they have made contact with superior beings who have long since transcended material bodies and who inhabit a planet called Varna, many light years distant from the earth. Scouts from Varna have observed our solar system from a spaceship and, through cosmic vibrations, the Varnians are guiding the Truth Seekers spiritual development toward higher planes.

title: Tunedin and turnedoff
description: For a writer, television is the most useful possible invention with the single exception of the selfcorrecting typewriter. It can be taken strictly on its own terms, as a diversion from deadlines and past due bills, as a muscle relaxant, a hallucinogen in which the cares of the world are swept away by squealing tires, hospital emergency rooms and gleaming teeth. It can also serve as a limitless source of material: one of this city's newspaper people has been producing a multiweekly column on public events without ever leaving home, through the convenient expedient of telling us what we saw on the previous day's news show. If you have sufficient faith in your own intelligence, and a big enough bag of theories, you can turn any TV program into a launch pad to publication.

With such a season, talk turned to thoughts of the April playoffs.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Mrs. Warren's Profession, Bernard Shaw's third play, was written by a Shaw who was not quite Shaw yet. He was still very much under the influence of Ibsen, but an Ibsen mistaken forthanks largely to the inadequate translations of William Archera social reformer who happened to use the stage as his platform, rather than recognized for what he was: a great dramatic poet who often dealt with social. problems. In 1893, when Mrs. Warren was written, the 37yearold Shaw, though still a fledgling dramatist, was already a socialist of long standing, and a reformer, I would imagine, since his first conscious look at the world. It is thus understandable that he should have written supposedly lbsenite thesis plays like Widowers Houses and Mrs. Warren's Profession. In the latter, he proposed to show that prostitution is purely a social evil caused by the barbarous underpayment and inhuman working conditions meted out to wretched women who chose to remain what a hypocritical society called virtuous.

title: The Selchie's Seed
description: I believe, I believe, but not this book. I am willing to believe in the selchle (the seal people) and grant that a selchle's daughter may long to return to the sea, and may eventually do so, abandoning human form. What I find difficult to swallow hook, line and sinker is that a daughter descended from a long line of seal people would fall head over flippers in love with a whale. Yes, even if he is a firma creature of such magic it takes on any form it wishes and takes away anything it desires.

title: Doing time at Q
description: This is a firstrate autobiography, for Malcolm Braly (pronounced Brawly) is not just another excon with a story to tell but a writer of many gifts. Of all the books I've read by and about prisoners, False Starts stands right at the top and for good reason: It rings true all the way through (and I mean true in the gut sense and not just in fidelity to detail). and it's sharp, ironic, civilized and moving.

title: It Comes From Africa's Blacks and the Russians

title: Quick, Who Was the Neil Simon of 1906?
description: In their Bicentennial rush to revive works by homegrown playwrights, theater companies across the country have been discovering that American drama did not spring to life in 1920 with Eugene O'Neill's Beyond the Horizon but actually led a full and healthy existence long before the turn of the century. Moreover, the recent success on Broadway of William Gillette's 1899 melodrama, Sherlock Holmes (as revived, ironically enough, by Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company), suggests that there may be commercial as well as historical gold buried in the annals of American theatrical history.

title: Milestone in Portugal

The agreement points the way toward civilian government, with power shared between a President and a Parliament, both popularly elected.

title: Notes On Seeing Barry Lyndon
description: The movies could make their maximum contribution to culture by following the lead of Stanley Kubrick's Barry Lyndon in recycling unread literature. Movies based on works that are still breathing  for example, War and Peace, Ulysses, Death in Venice"have the drawback of presenting themselves as replacements for the originals, and, since they are reproductions in a different medium, are likely to be regarded by the audience as distortions or vulgarizations. Only a graduate student in English, however, would be likely today to have read Thackeray's Barry Lyndon. Why would anyone else take up time with this item of 19thcentury pop entertainment? Years ago, Somerset Maugham, recognizing that such works are not being read, suggested that they ought to be reissued in versions cut down to their plot outlines.

title: The Friendly Faces of Southampton
description: HERE I sit on a house in the woods two miles north of Southampton Village, 10 miles east of the swiftly flowing Shinnecock Canal and Ib0 miles from Times Square by way of the of tenclogged Long Island Expressway. But from where I am, New York might as well be 00 light years away rather than the two hours it takes of flogging my motor car thr,Jugh what I am convinced are the world's worst drivers.

title: BRITISH OIL WORK WORRIES RUSSIANS
description: LONDON, Feb. 28The Russians are sharply increasing their intelligence activities in the North Sea because they fear that their ships and submarines will soon be severely restricted by the British oil installations there, according to an economist at HeriotWatt University in Scotland.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Juilliard School has never been known as a center of avantgarde activity, or even for any great concentration on contemporary music in general. Primarily it is a virtuosoproducing plant, and some of the world's most formidable young performing talent is attracted there. But it has a respected composerPeter Menninas its head, just as Mennin's predecessor, William Schuman, was a respected composer. It does give composition courses, has avantgarde musicians represented on its faculty, and does not hesitate to put new music on many of its public concerts.

title: The Role of the Supreme Court In American Government
description: This modest and graceful book, the outcome of lectures delivered at All Souls College in Oxford, contains many thoughts of value, the reflectionssometimes almost the musings of an academic lawyer who knows government from the inside, who was drawn (rather, one suspects, against the grain of temperament) into the central place of heat in one of the great constitutional controversies of our times and who brought to and brings from that experience the academic's interest in good theory, in the placing of event in the longer tides of history, the rescue of happening momentary sensation.

title: The victim of a full European education
description: Tadeusz Borowski was only 24 when his stories about Auschwitz first began to appear in Poland 30 years ago. Although the horrors they deal with were perpetrated by a generation largely dead and gone and we have had troubles enough to contend with since then, the impact and power of the stories is as unsettling now as it must have been then. Presumably that is a measure less of what Borowski and his fellow prisoners suffered than of his unique skill as an artist.

title: Lunch in a Picture Gallery
description: One night when the late Dick Conlon was managing Gallagher's steak house on West 52d Street, a horrid thought frightened him out of sleep. Suppose there were a fire, he was thinking. The building could be repaired or the restaurant reopened somewhere else, but no power on earth could recover the pictures that line the walls, the irreplaceable photographs of Lillian RusSell and Chauncey Depew, of Thomas Hitchcock Sr., Harry Payne Whitney, Harry Sinclair, young Max Hirsch, George Bull, Dan Brouthers, Honus Wagner, Joe Tinker, Sarah Bernhardt, Enrico Caruso, Julia Sanderson, Fritzi Scheff, Ethel Barrymore  a graphic record of the sporting and theatrical life of New York since the turn of the century. Dick Conlon slept no more that night. As soon as it was day he got hold of a photographer. One by one those pictures were copied, reframed and rehung, and the duplicates

title: Samizdat from a basement in Ann Arbor
description: Our literature has no need of Gutenberg's invention. the great Russian poet Anna Akhmatova observed over a decade ago. Substituting for the presses that are denied many writers in the Soviet Union is the humble manual typewriter. In the sixties, the typing and circulation, chainletter fashion, of unorthodox writings became known as samizdat (selfpublishing)a pun and, as it turned out, a highly effective joke on gosizdat, the State Publishing House. Sornizdat has made known to an incalculable number of Russians such works as Boris Pasternak's Doctor Zhivago, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's The Cancer Ward and Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita. In the seventies, however, the stringencies of the age have sharply politicized samizdat; belleslettres have increasingly given way to protest documents, news reports of conditions in prisons and camps, and bulletins on the various dissident movements.

title: Two reports on the lonely crowd
description: There exists in human nature a strong propensity to depreciate the advantages, and to magnify the evils, of present times, wrote Edward Gibbon. It is a thought to fortify oneself with when confronting two books each grimly portraying an aspect of the disintegration of our society. For some future Gibbon might benignly view as adaptation or evolution those phenomena that, to us, feel like the dissolving of the social glue that holds us together.
